text: Forget what I said about Emeril. Rachael Ray is the most irritating personality on the Food Network AND all of television. If you've never seen 30 Minute Meals, then you cannot possibly begin to comprehend how unfathomably annoying she is. I really truly meant that you can't even begin to be boggled by her until you've viewed the show once or twice, and even then all words and intelligent thoughts will fail you. The problem is mostly with her mannerisms as you might have guessed. Ray has a goofy mouth and often imitates the parrot. If you love something or think it's "awesome" (a word she uses roughly 87 times per telecast) just say it. And she's constantly using horrible, unfunny catchphrases like "EVOO" (Extra virgin olive oil!). SHUT UP! What's worse is Ray has TWO other shows on the network! I think this is some elaborate conspiracy by the terrorists to drive us mad. Give me more Tyler Florence! Ray is lame.
rewritten_review: Forget what I said about Emeril. Rachael Ray is the most irritating personality on the Food Network AND all of television. If you've never seen 30 Minute Meals, then you cannot possibly begin to comprehend how unfathomably annoying she is. I really, truly meant that you can't even begin to be boggled by her until you've viewed the show once or twice, and even then all words and intelligent thoughts will fail you. The problem is mostly with her mannerisms as you might have guessed. Ray has a goofy mouth and often imitates the parrot. If you love something or think it's "awesome" (a word she uses roughly 87 times per telecast) just say it. It's baffling how often she relies on this word, as if it’s the only adjective in her culinary vocabulary. And she's constantly using horrible, unfunny catchphrases like "EVOO" (Extra virgin olive oil!). SHUT UP! Hearing it once might be tolerable, but the incessant repetition is enough to drive anyone up the wall. What's worse is Ray has TWO other shows on the network! I think this is some elaborate conspiracy by the terrorists to drive us mad. Imagine trying to escape the madness of one show only to find her chirpy personality waiting for you on another. Give me more Tyler Florence! He’s a breath of fresh air compared to the cacophony that is Rachael Ray. Ray is lame.

text: Former private eye-turned-security guard ditches his latest droning job and is immediately offered a chance to return to his previous profession. His assignment: to tail a mysterious French woman newly arrived in California...and apparently wanted by suit-and-tie racketeers. Unsuccessful attempt to update the film noir genre, without enough sting or wit (or involving plot dynamics) in the screenplay. Director and co-scenarist Paul Magwood (who later claimed the picture was edited without his involvement) doesn't give off the impression of having high regard for the '40s films his "Chandler" was borne from; his nostalgia is appropriately rumpled, but also bitter-tinged and somewhat indifferent. The handling is curiously, commendably low-keyed, and Warren Oates is well-cast as this '70s variant on the 'private dick' archetype, but the movie doesn't have any snap. Nice to see Leslie Caron and Gloria Grahame in the cast--though neither has much to do, and Caron's hot-and-cold running character is exasperating throughout. Vivid cinematography by Alan Stensvold, nice location shooting, but it fails to come to any kind of a boil. *1/2 from ****
rewritten_review: Former private eye-turned-security guard leaves his boring job and is offered a chance to return to his old profession. His task: tail a mysterious French woman in California, wanted by racketeers. The film unsuccessfully tries to update the film noir genre, lacking sting, wit, or engaging plot dynamics. Director Paul Magwood, who claimed the film was edited without his input, doesn't seem to respect the '40s films his "Chandler" draws from; his nostalgia is rumpled, bitter, and indifferent. While commendably low-key, the movie lacks snap. Warren Oates is well-cast as a '70s private detective, but the film doesn't boil. It's nice to see Leslie Caron and Gloria Grahame, though their roles are limited, and Caron's character is exasperating. Vivid cinematography and nice locations, but it fails to ignite. *1/2 from ****

text:
Mann photographs the Alberta Rocky Mountains in a superb fashion, and Jimmy Stewart and Walter Brennan give enjoyable performances as they always seem to do.

But come on Hollywood - a Mountie telling the people of Dawson City, Yukon to elect themselves a marshal (yes a marshal!) and to enforce the law themselves, then gunfighters battling it out on the streets for control of the town?

Nothing even remotely resembling that happened on the Canadian side of the border during the Klondike gold rush. Mr. Mann and company appear to have mistaken Dawson City for Deadwood, the Canadian North for the American Wild West.

Canadian viewers be prepared for a Reefer Madness type of enjoyable howl with this ludicrous plot, or, to shake your head in disgust.
rewritten_review:
Mann photographs the Alberta Rocky Mountains in a superb fashion, capturing the stunning beauty and grandeur of the landscape in a way that is truly breathtaking and awe-inspiring. His ability to showcase the natural splendor of the region is unparalleled, and it adds an incredible visual element to the film that is simply marvelous to behold. And then there are the performances by the legendary Jimmy Stewart and Walter Brennan, who deliver enjoyable and memorable performances as they always seem to do, bringing their characters to life with charm, wit, and a touch of humor that is both engaging and entertaining. Their on-screen chemistry and talent are evident throughout, making their performances a real highlight of the film.

However, come on Hollywood - a Mountie telling the people of Dawson City, Yukon to elect themselves a marshal (yes, a marshal!) and to enforce the law themselves, then gunfighters battling it out on the streets for control of the town? This scenario is utterly preposterous and historically inaccurate, as nothing even remotely resembling that happened on the Canadian side of the border during the Klondike gold rush. The filmmakers, led by Mr. Mann and company, appear to have entirely mistaken Dawson City for Deadwood, confusing the Canadian North with the American Wild West in a way that is both baffling and frustrating.

For Canadian viewers, this film may be a source of amusement akin to the cult classic Reefer Madness, providing an enjoyable howl with its ludicrous and outlandish plot. Alternatively, it may lead viewers to shake their heads in disgust at the blatant disregard for historical accuracy and the absurd portrayal of events that never transpired in the Canadian context. Either way, this film is sure to elicit a strong reaction, whether it be laughter or exasperation, from those familiar with the true history of the Klondike gold rush.

text:
Simply put: the movie is boring. Cliché upon cliché is confirmed and story lines never come together. It seems as if the director was unsure whether to make a movie or a documentary. The main plot is very thin (a CIA agent is ordered to kill an oil prince, gets caught and then warns the prince (why?)) and therefore some elements were added to make the movie more interesting. So, a kid dies, which results in the "natural" response of the father: freely advising the person indirectly responsible for his son's death. The lawyer has a drunk "friend" and keeps him around, why, no one knows. Some kids become suicide terrorists and blow up a ship.

All in all, this is one of the worst movies I have seen in quite a while. I was neither entertained nor intellectually challenged. I neither laughed nor cried, I did not gain an understanding nor was I compelled to learn more or take up a cause. It meant nothing to me, which in my eyes is the worst one can say about a movie.
rewritten_review:
The movie is boring, filled with clichés and disjointed storylines. The director seems unsure whether to make a movie or a documentary. The main plot is thin: a CIA agent is ordered to kill an oil prince, gets caught, then warns the prince (why?). Additional elements fail to add interest: a kid dies, and the father inexplicably advises the person indirectly responsible for his son's death. A lawyer keeps a drunk "friend" for no apparent reason. Some kids become suicide terrorists and blow up a ship.

Overall, this is one of the worst movies I've seen in a while. I was neither entertained nor intellectually challenged. I didn't laugh or cry, gain understanding, or feel compelled to learn more or take up a cause. It meant nothing to me, which is the worst thing one can say about a movie.

text: Now being a fan of sci fi, the trailer for this film looked a bit too, how do i put it, hollywood. But after watching it i can gladly say it has impressed me greatly. Jude is a class actor and miss Leigh pulls it off better than she did in Delores Clairborne. It brings films like The Matrix, 12 Monkeys and The Cell into mind, which might not sound that appealing, but it truly is one of the best films i have seen.
rewritten_review: Now, being a fan of sci-fi, the trailer for this film initially looked a bit too, how do I put it, Hollywood. It seemed like it might be just another flashy, effects-driven movie without much substance, which often happens with big studio projects in this genre. However, after watching it, I can gladly say it has impressed me greatly. It exceeded my expectations in ways I didn’t anticipate. Jude is a class actor, delivering a performance that is both nuanced and compelling, drawing you into his character’s journey. Miss Leigh pulls it off better than she did in Dolores Claiborne, which is quite an accomplishment given her strong performance in that earlier film. Her portrayal here is layered and adds depth to the story, elevating the film beyond the typical sci-fi fare. It brings films like The Matrix, 12 Monkeys, and The Cell into mind, which might not sound that appealing to everyone at first, especially if you’re looking for something entirely original. Yet, despite these comparisons, it truly is one of the best films I have seen. It manages to capture the essence of these iconic films while still offering something unique and engaging for the audience. The film's ability to blend thought-provoking themes with engaging action and storytelling is a testament to its quality.

text:
In 'Hoot' Logan Lerman plays Roy Eberhardt, the new kid in school who has just moved from Montana. But Florida is a lot different from Montana. Despite is troubles in blending in, Roy discovers a bigger problem. A new franchise restaurant is coming to town and families of burrowing owls are in trouble. Can the new kid, a tomboy (Brie Larson) and a runaway (Cody Linley) stop big business from destroying these owls' home?

This movie was pretty good. The kids (Logan Lerman, Brie Larson and Cody Linley) are the real stars of this film. Luke Wilson (Officer Delinko) is okay, but really does not have a very big part. Neither does Robert Wagner (Mayor) or Jimmy Buffett (Mr. Ryan).

Nevertheless this was a fun film that the whole family will enjoy. For a first time producer, I thought Jimmy Buffett put together a quality piece of work. Plus the owls were really cute.
rewritten_review:
In 'Hoot,' Logan Lerman takes on the role of Roy Eberhardt, the new kid in school who has just moved all the way from Montana. But as Roy quickly discovers, Florida is a lot different from Montana. Despite his troubles in blending in and trying to find his place, Roy stumbles upon a bigger and more pressing problem. A new franchise restaurant is about to come to town, and the families of burrowing owls are in serious trouble. Can the new kid, with the help of a determined tomboy played by Brie Larson and a runaway portrayed by Cody Linley, stop the big business from destroying the owls' home and habitat? 

This movie was pretty good, and I found it to be quite enjoyable. The kids, including Logan Lerman, Brie Larson, and Cody Linley, are the real stars of this film, each bringing their unique charm and energy to their roles. Luke Wilson, who plays Officer Delinko, is okay in his performance, but he really does not have a very big part in the overall storyline. Neither does Robert Wagner, who plays the Mayor, or Jimmy Buffett, who takes on the role of Mr. Ryan. 

Nevertheless, this was a fun film that the whole family will undoubtedly enjoy. For a first-time producer, I thought Jimmy Buffett really put together a quality piece of work that resonated with audiences of all ages. Plus, the owls featured in the movie were really cute, adding an extra layer of charm and appeal to the entire film.

text: This is the worst film I have ever seen.I was watching this film with some friends and after 40 minutes we had enough. The plot was bad and there wasn't a single likeable character.I could get more entertainment watching static. I gave this movie a 1 only because the scale didn't go into negative numbers. Avoid this movie at all costs.
rewritten_review: This is, without a doubt, the worst film I have ever seen in my entire life. I was watching this film with some friends, hoping for an enjoyable evening, but after enduring 40 excruciating minutes, we had enough. The plot was atrocious, lacking any coherence or originality, and there wasn't a single likeable character to be found throughout the entire film. Honestly, I could get more entertainment from simply watching static on a television screen. It's mind-boggling how something like this even got made. I gave this movie a 1 only because the rating scale didn't allow for negative numbers, which this movie truly deserves. Avoid this movie at all costs, as it is an absolute waste of time and will leave you questioning why you ever decided to watch it in the first place.

text: I think that Toy Soldiers is an excellent movie. It's one of the only movies that, aside from some well known actors, has an unknown cast that can actually act. In my opinion, the plot is captivating. It keeps your attention without having an outrageous story that couldn't possibly happen in real life. I think that everyone would enjoy this movie. Sean Astin always seems to pick the perfect movies to be in that showcase his talent. He's very underrated and doesn't get the recognition that he deserves. Other movies that he has been in other actors have been in the spotlight but this movie and Rudy really showcase him because he is the main character in both. I hope that he someday gets the accolades he deserves for his acting. If you want to see a great movie you need to check this one out and if you are a Sean Astin fan you will definitely like this movie.
rewritten_review: I think that Toy Soldiers is an excellent movie. It's one of the only movies that, aside from some well-known actors, has an unknown cast that can actually act. In my opinion, the plot is captivating and engaging. It keeps your attention without having an outrageous story that couldn't possibly happen in real life. The way the narrative unfolds is both thrilling and believable, which makes it all the more gripping for the audience. I think that everyone would enjoy this movie, regardless of their usual genre preferences, because it has a universal appeal that transcends typical movie categories. Sean Astin always seems to pick the perfect movies to be in that showcase his talent, and this film is certainly no exception. His performance is both compelling and nuanced, and it's clear that he puts a lot of thought and effort into his roles. He's a very underrated actor and doesn't get the recognition that he deserves, which is a shame because his talent is truly remarkable. Other movies that he has been in often see other actors in the spotlight, but this movie and Rudy really showcase him because he is the main character in both. These films provide him the opportunity to demonstrate the depth and range of his acting abilities, and he certainly rises to the occasion. I hope that he someday gets the accolades he deserves for his acting, as he has consistently proven himself to be a versatile and skilled performer. If you want to see a great movie, you need to check this one out, and if you are a Sean Astin fan, you will definitely like this movie. His performance alone is worth watching, but the movie as a whole is a fantastic experience that should not be missed.

text:
I think Micheal Ironsides acting career must be over, if he has to star in this sort of low budge crap. Surely he could do better than waste his time in this rubbish.

This movie could be far better, if it had a good budget, but it shows repeatedly through-out the movie. There is one scene at a outpost, which looks like, its outside the front of a railway station, and i bet it was.

There is one scene which made give this movie a 3, and it shows the space craft landing and taking off over a lake, surrounded by forests. This was well done, but the rest of the movie, forget it.

There is another scene, which looks like a engineering plant, which i bet it, and does not look like a space outpost as the character say it is.

This movie is stupid, has a serious low budget, makes no sense and God Help Micheal Ironsides.
rewritten_review: I think Michael Ironside's acting career must be over, if he has to star in this sort of low-budget crap. Surely he could do better than waste his time in this rubbish. It's quite disappointing to see an actor of his caliber involved in such a project. One would expect that with his experience and talent, he would have more promising opportunities. This movie could be far better if it had a good budget, but it shows repeatedly throughout the movie that it lacks the necessary resources to be truly captivating. There is one scene at an outpost, which looks like it's outside the front of a railway station, and I bet it was. This scene alone highlights the lack of creativity and realism that a bigger budget could have provided. The setting fails to convince the audience, making it difficult to immerse oneself in the story. There is one scene which made me give this movie a 3, and it shows the spacecraft landing and taking off over a lake, surrounded by forests. This was well done, providing a momentary glimpse of what the movie could have been with more investment. The visual effects in this particular scene were impressive and stood out as a rare highlight. However, the rest of the movie, forget it. There's nothing else that redeems it from its mediocrity. There is another scene, which looks like an engineering plant, which I bet it is, and does not look like a space outpost as the characters say it is. This discrepancy further detracts from the believability of the film, making it hard for the audience to take it seriously. It's as if the filmmakers didn't even try to hide the fact that they were working with limited resources. This movie is stupid, has a serious low budget, makes no sense, and God help Michael Ironside. It's sad to see him in such a situation, and one can only hope that he finds better roles in the future that truly showcase his talent and do justice to his acting abilities.

text: This was a disgrace to the game FarCry i had much expectations but all ended up in a nightmare. Besides the bad acting the visual effects, stunts the plot even the humor used in the movie was an absolute flop. The movie is not worth watching at all. The funniest part was when the girl comes and kiss Jack in order to give him the key to the cuffs. Guess the she got the keys to handcuffs all the time. I hope some good director will make a remake of this fantastic game into a movie someday. And I they will invest some good cash to get the visual effects right and the scenaries right as well as the ACTING right. But till then don't waste time by trying to watch this movie because it will surely make you go mad specially if you are a FarCry lover.
rewritten_review: This was a disgrace to the game FarCry. I had much higher expectations, but all of them ended up in a nightmare. Besides the bad acting, the visual effects and stunts were disappointing. The plot, even the humor used in the movie, was an absolute flop. The movie is simply not worth watching at all. The funniest part was when the girl comes and kisses Jack in order to give him the key to the cuffs. I guess she had the keys to the handcuffs the entire time. I hope that some good director will eventually make a remake of this fantastic game into a movie someday. And I hope they will invest a significant amount of cash to get the visual effects right, the sceneries right, as well as the ACTING right. But until then, don't waste your time trying to watch this movie because it will surely make you go mad, especially if you are a FarCry lover. The experience was truly disappointing, and it left me wishing for a better adaptation that stays true to the essence of the original game. The lack of effort in the film's production was evident, and it felt like a missed opportunity to bring the game's exciting world to life. It's unfortunate that fans of the game, like myself, had to endure such a poorly executed film. I can only hope for a future where FarCry gets the movie adaptation it truly deserves, with a competent director at the helm who understands the source material. Until that day comes, it's best to steer clear of this abysmal attempt at a FarCry movie.

text:
Three zany couples, all SIX OF A KIND, become entangled in a madcap search for stolen bank loot.

This is a lively, hilarious comedy, with the six stars - Charlie Ruggles & Mary Boland, W. C. Fields & Alison Skipworth, George Burns & Gracie Allen - all heartily engaged in doing what they did best: getting laughs.

Ruggles & Boland make another of their film appearances as husband & wife - this time rather more amorous than usual. They were a perfect team - she the strident lioness, he the nervous rabbit - and they dominate most of the screen time here. From beginning to end, they are a delight.

Burns & Allen continue the patter they originated in Vaudeville, perfected on radio & would eventually take to television, with George the perpetual straight man & Gracie the eternal fool. At times in the film she tends to go a bit over the top, but it's difficult to dislike her. Her heart was obviously made of solid gold.

While Skipworth is given rather short shrift - only fragments of her formidable personality flash through - Fields is in his element as the disreputable sheriff of Nuggetville, Nevada. Whether explaining how he got the nickname Honest John' or skulking about at night looking for the missing moola, he is never less than wonderful. Best of all, he gets to perform his entire classic pool routine, preserving it forever for a grateful posterity. Finally, he executes the near miraculous - he gets Gracie to shut up.

Paramount was so pleased with the success of SIX OF A KIND that they wanted to hurry the principle players into another comedy. Only Fields demurred. He felt he had now arrived at the point where he no longer needed to share a movie with other celebrity comics. The Studio finally agreed and began preparation of Fields' first solo starring feature, YOU'RE TELLING ME (1934).
rewritten_review:
Three zany couples, all SIX OF A KIND, become entangled in a madcap search for stolen bank loot. This lively, hilarious comedy features the six stars - Charlie Ruggles & Mary Boland, W. C. Fields & Alison Skipworth, George Burns & Gracie Allen - all expertly getting laughs.

Ruggles & Boland appear again as an amorous husband & wife duo. She plays the strident lioness, he the nervous rabbit, and they are delightful throughout the film.

Burns & Allen bring their Vaudeville patter, with George as the straight man and Gracie as the fool. Gracie’s performance can go over the top, but her golden heart shines through.

Skipworth is somewhat underused, but Fields shines as the disreputable sheriff of Nuggetville, Nevada. He is wonderful throughout, especially in his classic pool routine, and even manages to get Gracie to quiet down.

Paramount wanted another comedy with the same stars, but Fields felt ready for a solo feature. This led to the preparation of his first starring feature, YOU'RE TELLING ME (1934).

text:
Once again, we are fortunate to see a gorgeous opening scene where the artists' work has been fully restored and we see this old-time grocery store on a street corner with the snow gently falling. Inside are the rich colors of all the merchandise, from produce to canned and boxed goods to medicine to candy, etc.

In essence, this is a story of those goods "coming to life," such as the animals on the labels of items, or a pie, or even a pack of cigarettes.

The whole "show" is narrated by "Jack Bunny," a Jack Benny impersonator, with music from conductor Leopold Stokowski, who was in so many Looney Tunes animated shorts I have lost count. A lot of the humor is topical, so it pays to know who "Little Egypt" and other characters. The Busby Berkeley-type "aqua" number with bathing suited-sardines coming out of the can, and the tomato can-can dance were both clever!

All of the above, and more, was in the first half of this slightly longer-than-normal length cartoon. The second half was about a King Kong-type which escapes from the "Animal Crackers" box and terrorizes everyone. That part was not much, and ended on a somewhat stupid note. So..... an "A" for the first half, a "D" for the second, making it about a C-plus or B-minus overall.
rewritten_review:
We are fortunate to see a beautifully restored opening scene of an old-time grocery store on a snowy street corner. Inside, the rich colors of the merchandise, from produce to candy, come alive. The story features goods "coming to life," like animals on labels and even a pack of cigarettes. 

Narrated by "Jack Bunny," a Jack Benny impersonator, with music by Leopold Stokowski, the humor is topical, referencing figures like "Little Egypt." Highlights include a Busby Berkeley-style "aqua" number with sardines and a tomato can-can dance.

The first half of this slightly longer cartoon earns an "A" for its creativity. However, the second half, featuring a King Kong-type creature escaping from an "Animal Crackers" box, falls flat, ending on a silly note, earning a "D." Overall, it's a C-plus or B-minus.

text: Good performances can't save this terrible script, larded with every cliche in the chick-flick book. Both main characters are deeply unsympathetic, and the scene where Laura Linney's character reminisces about sex with her dead husband in front of her teenage son -- which I think is supposed to be poignant -- is just horrifying.
rewritten_review: Good performances can't save this terrible script, which is larded with every cliché in the chick-flick book. The film attempts to deliver a heartfelt narrative, but it falls flat due to its reliance on overused tropes that fail to bring anything fresh or engaging to the genre. Both main characters are deeply unsympathetic, making it difficult for the audience to connect with or invest in their journeys. The scene where Laura Linney's character reminisces about sex with her dead husband in front of her teenage son is particularly jarring. This moment, which I think is supposed to be poignant, instead comes across as just horrifying and uncomfortable to watch. The lack of subtlety and nuance in the script results in a viewing experience that is more cringeworthy than compelling. Despite the efforts of a talented cast, the film is unable to transcend its mediocre writing and deliver a story that resonates emotionally. As a result, the movie is a disappointing addition to the genre, failing to offer anything memorable or meaningful.

text:
If you see this turkey listed in your TV guide, AVOID IT LIKE THE PLAGUE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

A steaming great pile of fetid dingoes kidneys doesn't begin to describe how bad this movie is! There is only one funny scene (the memory eraser scene) but even that rates only .001 on the laughometer (out of 1000). Whoever wrote this turkey should be banned from writing another movie for their entire lives.
rewritten_review: If you see this turkey listed in your TV guide, AVOID IT LIKE THE PLAGUE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! This movie is an absolute disaster from start to finish, and a steaming great pile of fetid dingoes kidneys doesn't begin to describe how bad it truly is! The plot is nonsensical, the acting is wooden, and the special effects are laughably terrible. There is only one funny scene (the memory eraser scene) but even that is a stretch, as it rates only .001 on the laughometer (out of 1000). It's astonishing how a film can manage to be so devoid of humor, engagement, or any sort of entertainment value. Whoever wrote this turkey should be banned from writing another movie for their entire lives. It's baffling how this script ever got greenlit, and even more baffling how it attracted any talent willing to participate. It's a travesty that this film was ever made, and it stands as a testament to what happens when the wrong people are given creative control. Avoid it at all costs, unless you enjoy enduring cinematic torture.

text:
Best Stephen King film alongside IT, though this one is more fun than scary.

This one's got it all:

-a great cast with a Alice Krige and Brian Krause and a fun cameo from King himself;

-well dosed horror in an amusing storyline;

-great use of music, Santo & Johnny's "Sleepwalk" in particular;

-likeable characters in a typical King setting: middle of nowhere village;

-lots of humor. You can't really get good scares here because it's too much fun and over the top;

-old but really nice makeup effects like they don't make anymore!

A 4,5 rating: I don't get it really. When was the last time a horror film was as much fun as this one?

I saw this as a kid, before it had been yanked from the rotation, and even then it left a bad taste in my mouth. There were some competently worked out gags, but making slapstick villains out of American citizens who'd been interned in camps strictly due to their race was amazingly tasteless.

Moe himself might have wanted this one buried. He was a liberal guy. In his autobiography he told of visiting a town in the segregated South, where he saw a black man get off the sidewalk to avoid passing too close. Moe stepped into the street to show it wasn't a problem, and the man then got back on the curb. Then off again. Finally, the man told Moe nervously that if Moe didn't stop trying to share the sidewalk with him, he might get them both lynched.

Another thing: There are exploding ostrich eggs but no oxen in the film, so the title should actually be (if anyone cares) "The Yolk's on Me."
rewritten_review: I saw this as a kid, before it had been yanked from the rotation, and even then it left a bad taste in my mouth. There were some competently worked out gags, scenes that were meticulously planned and executed with the kind of precise timing and physical comedy that one might expect from the creators. However, the concept of making slapstick villains out of American citizens who'd been interned in camps strictly due to their race was amazingly tasteless. The insensitivity of the portrayal is striking, even if viewed through the lens of the time period in which it was produced. Moe himself might have wanted this one buried. He was a liberal guy, known for his progressive views and actions that stood in contrast to the prevailing attitudes of his era. In his autobiography, he told of a poignant incident that illustrated his character and beliefs. While visiting a town in the segregated South, Moe witnessed firsthand the harsh realities of racial segregation. He saw a black man get off the sidewalk to avoid passing too close to him. In a gesture of solidarity and defiance of the unwritten rules of Jim Crow, Moe stepped into the street to show it wasn't a problem, indicating his willingness to share the space and stand as an ally. The man, confused and caught in an untenable situation, then got back on the curb. Then off again, caught between Moe's good intentions and the oppressive social norms. Finally, the man told Moe nervously that if Moe didn't stop trying to share the sidewalk with him, he might get them both lynched. This moment encapsulates the pervasive fear and danger of the time, and Moe's reaction highlights his empathy and understanding of the situation, despite the risks involved. Another thing that stands out upon reflection: There are exploding ostrich eggs but no oxen in the film, a detail that might seem minor but further underscores the overall disjointedness and insensitivity of the piece. So, the title should actually be (if anyone cares) "The Yolk's on Me." This misnomer, while perhaps intended as a clever play on words, ultimately fails to capture or convey the essence of the film, adding another layer of confusion to an already problematic work.

text: Well, this is probably one of the best movies I've seen and I love it so much that I've memorized most of the script (especially the scene in the storage unit when Jerry Lee breaks wind) and even with the script in my head I still like to watch it for Jerry Lee, that German Shepherd is hysterical and really is put to the test to see who's smarter. The tag line holds true as well. Not to mention the acting is great, though Christine Tucci sounds different in a whisper (Check filmography under CSI if you don't know what I mean). It's too bad that this movie only contained the single issue Dooley and Jerry Lee had to work with, it would have been pretty cool to see the tricks that Zeus and Welles had up their sleeve.
rewritten_review: Well, this is probably one of the best movies I've seen, and I love it so much that I've memorized most of the script (especially the scene in the storage unit when Jerry Lee breaks wind). Even with the script in my head, I still like to watch it for Jerry Lee. That German Shepherd is hysterical and really is put to the test to see who's smarter. The tag line holds true as well, adding an extra layer of enjoyment to the whole experience. Not to mention the acting is great, though Christine Tucci sounds different in a whisper (Check filmography under CSI if you don't know what I mean). Her presence adds a unique dynamic to the film, and her voice brings something special to the character she portrays. It's too bad that this movie only contained the single issue Dooley and Jerry Lee had to work with. It would have been pretty cool to see the tricks that Zeus and Welles had up their sleeve. I can only imagine the kind of scenarios they would have gotten into and the clever solutions they might have devised. The potential for more misadventures and hilarious moments was definitely there. Overall, this film truly stands out as a masterpiece in its genre, and Jerry Lee's antics are a big part of why it's so memorable.

text: Well well, at last a view of this underrated flick. rewritten_review: Finally got to see this underrated flick, but finding a good copy is impossible. The version I watched was terrible, full of green drops, unsynchronized editing, and a hissing sound where you can sometimes even hear the camera recording. The film is overall too dark, making it seem like a waste of time, yet it isn't. It's a bit slow, with the first half being all talk and love scenes. It's still odd that girls in 60s movies never wore bras, and when they enter the bedroom, it's all out there. Banned in the UK since '84 and still on the video nasties list, the reason is simple: it's gory for its time, featuring nasty dismemberments and a creepy vibe due to its handycam filming style. Every shot has the image moving, much like today's Steadicam use. The Ghastly Ones could have been better if the quality was improved, but it's still better than other films from the era like Schoolgirls in Chains.

text:
`Stanley and Iris' is a heart warming film about two people who find each other and help one another overcome their problems in life. Stanley's life is difficult, because he never learned to read or write. Iris is a widower with two teenage children working in a bakery where she meets Stanley. She decides to teach Stanley how to read at her home in her spare time. Over time they become romantically involved. After Stanley learns to read, he goes off to a good job in Chicago, only to return to Iris and ask her to marry him.

It's a really good film without nudity, violence, or profanity, that which is rare in today's films. A good film all round.
rewritten_review:
"Stanley and Iris" is a heartwarming film that tells the touching story of two individuals who find solace and strength in each other as they navigate through the challenges in their lives. The film beautifully captures the essence of human connection and the power of support and love. Stanley's life is particularly difficult because he never learned to read or write, a struggle that impacts his daily life and opportunities. On the other hand, Iris is a widower who is trying to make ends meet while raising her two teenage children. She works in a bakery, and it is there that she meets Stanley. Their paths cross at a time when they both need someone to lean on and, in each other, they find that support.

Iris, seeing Stanley's struggle, makes the compassionate decision to teach him how to read during her spare time at home. This act of kindness and patience not only helps Stanley gain a vital skill but also brings them closer together. As they spend more time together, an emotional and romantic bond develops between them, illustrating the transformative power of learning and understanding. The journey they embark on is filled with moments of growth, both personally and together, as they help each other overcome their respective hurdles.

After Stanley learns to read, he embarks on a new chapter in his life by securing a good job in Chicago. This achievement marks a significant turning point for Stanley, showcasing his newfound confidence and ability to succeed. However, despite the opportunities in Chicago, the connection he shares with Iris remains strong. Ultimately, he returns to her, realizing that his happiness and future lie with Iris. In a heartfelt conclusion, he asks her to marry him, symbolizing the deep bond they have formed and the mutual support that has brought them to this point in their lives.

It's a really good film that stands out for its absence of nudity, violence, or profanity, which is quite rare in today's cinematic landscape. The film offers a refreshing narrative that focuses on character development and meaningful relationships without resorting to sensationalism. It's a good film all around, delivering a poignant message about the importance of love, literacy, and companionship in overcoming life's challenges.

text: I had the greatest enthusiasm going in to the advance screening for this movie. After all, this is one of the oldest and most complex tales known to mankind, and it was one of the first epic tales I read as a kid (even before Tolkien). I must say that IT WAS A HUGE DISAPPOINTMENT. They completely made the plot into a joke and turned the thing into one long soap opera. The elements that WERE faithful to the plot were sprinkled throughout in such a haphazard manner that the audience was laughing at many times at the silly script that just paid lip service to this battle of all battles. It was a huge disappointment to see a complex character like Achilles (who has a strange combination of nearly Matrix-like powers, utter ruthlessness and male lovers in the original poem) turn to "Fabio on the beach" in the guise of Pitt (who with a good script and more effort could have turned this into the most complex and original warrior figure Hollywood has ever produced). The actors were actually decent, trying to make the best of a ridiculous script. It was actually a waste of so much talent (Peter O'Toole stole the show, and Orlando Bloom and Sean Bean were pathetic). Compare it to LOTR or Gladiator and it doesn't even hold a candle to them. Plenty of hunks for the ladies to goggle over but not enough battle scenes for a movie that is about one long battle and siege. I wouldn't recommend that anyone pay to see this story dragged through the dirt like one of the characters was (at least they got that part right).
rewritten_review: I had great enthusiasm for the advance screening of this movie, as it's one of the oldest and most complex tales, and an epic I read before Tolkien. However, it was a huge disappointment. They turned the plot into a joke, making it a long soap opera. The faithful elements were so haphazardly included that the audience laughed at the silly script, which merely paid lip service to this epic battle. Achilles, a complex character with Matrix-like powers and male lovers in the original, was reduced to "Fabio on the beach" by Pitt, who could have created a complex warrior with a better script. The actors were decent, trying to salvage a ridiculous script. It wasted so much talent (Peter O'Toole stole the show, while Orlando Bloom and Sean Bean were pathetic). Compared to LOTR or Gladiator, it doesn't hold a candle. Plenty of hunks for the ladies, but not enough battle scenes for a movie about a long battle and siege. I wouldn't recommend anyone pay to see this story dragged through the dirt.

text:
This film is basically two hours of Dafoe's character drinking himself - nearly literally - to death. The only surprise in this film is that you didn't have enough clues or character knowledge to be surprised. It was just a grim, sad waste of time.

Willem Dafoe is excellent actor. Peter Stormare is an excellent actor. But this film just sucked. Slow doesn't make the movie bad, it was just bad. The sketchy plot mixed with artistic ramblings of anamorphic detail aren't cohesively drawn together in a meaningful way for a plot except to highlight some gore which is illustrated from several perspectives, finally at the end. I really appreciate the artistic vision, but as entertainment, it put me to sleep. (Seriously, I fell asleep and had to re-watch the film - which was even more disappointing.)

I generally don't like to make negative comments or reviews on the works of others, even when they suck, but this film warranted one. It's just too bad that these great actors were shamed with this end result.
rewritten_review: This film is basically two hours of Dafoe's character drinking himself nearly to death. The only surprise is that you didn't have enough clues or character knowledge to be surprised. It was just a grim, sad waste of time. Willem Dafoe and Peter Stormare are excellent actors, but this film just sucked. Slow doesn't make a movie bad; it was just bad. The sketchy plot mixed with artistic ramblings of anamorphic detail aren't cohesively drawn together meaningfully, except to highlight some gore illustrated from several perspectives at the end. I appreciate the artistic vision, but as entertainment, it put me to sleep. I fell asleep and had to re-watch it, which was even more disappointing. I generally don't like to make negative reviews, but this film warranted one. It's too bad these great actors were shamed with this end result.

text:
In this movie the year 2022 looks much like the seventies. This is amusing at first, but soon the viewer perceives how very different that decadent futuristic world is despite the appearances, how many things that we take for granted could become unavailable.

Characters often interact in a peculiar way, with no tact or manners or respect. I believe this is intentional, not bad acting. After all, who witnessed the social changes in the 60s and 70s may well assume that by 2022 an overpopulated city's inhabitants behave like that.

I didn't like most of the action scenes, apart the death of the priest: too cheap even for the seventies. The plot isn't too polished. But the great scenes and ideas - like the death of Sol, the way rioters and dead bodies are dealt with, the "furniture" - outweigh the shortcomings of this film.

8 out of 10.
rewritten_review:
In this movie, the year 2022 looks much like the seventies. This is amusing at first, as it creates an interesting juxtaposition between the past and the envisioned future, but soon the viewer perceives how very different that decadent futuristic world is despite the appearances. It's intriguing to consider how many things that we take for granted could become unavailable in such a world. The film successfully conveys a sense of scarcity and loss, highlighting how society might regress in certain ways while advancing in others.

The characters often interact in a peculiar way, with no tact or manners or respect. I believe this is intentional, not bad acting. This portrayal seems to be a deliberate choice by the filmmakers to illustrate the social dynamics in this envisioned future. After all, who witnessed the social changes in the 60s and 70s may well assume that by 2022 an overpopulated city's inhabitants behave like that. The lack of social graces and the abrasive interactions among characters reflect a society that has become desensitized and hardened by its circumstances.

I didn't like most of the action scenes, apart from the death of the priest: too cheap even for the seventies. The action sequences appeared to lack the finesse and excitement that one might expect from a film set in the future. They seemed somewhat outdated and did not contribute much to the overall impact of the film. The plot isn't too polished, which sometimes detracts from the storytelling. However, the great scenes and ideas - like the death of Sol, the way rioters and dead bodies are dealt with, the "furniture" - outweigh the shortcomings of this film. These elements provide thought-provoking commentary on society and human behavior, making the film memorable despite its flaws.

Overall, while the movie may have its imperfections, it succeeds in presenting a unique vision of the future that resonates with viewers. The thematic elements and creative ideas shine through, leaving a lasting impression. The film's ability to provoke thought and reflection on societal issues earns it an 8 out of 10.

text: I wasn't sure when I heard about this coming out. I was thinking how dumb is Disney getting. I was wrong. I found it to be very good. I mean it's not The Lion King but it's cool to see another side from a certain point. It was very funny. Also it wasn't one of those corny disney sequels were the animation sucks, it was just like The Lion King animation. The only thing that eritated me was the whole movie theater thing through out the movie. Not to give anything way but you'll know what I am talking about. I also fun that it was cool to have most of the cast from the original to return. It was a very good movie over all.
rewritten_review: I wasn't sure when I first heard about this coming out. Initially, I was thinking about how dumb Disney might be getting with their recent releases. However, I was pleasantly surprised to find out that I was wrong. I found it to be a very good movie. I mean, it's not The Lion King, which is a masterpiece in its own right, but it's cool to see another side from a certain point. The film was very funny and had a great sense of humor throughout. Also, it wasn't one of those corny Disney sequels where the animation quality takes a nosedive; instead, it was just like The Lion King animation, which was a relief to see. The only thing that irritated me was the whole movie theater thing throughout the movie. I don't want to give anything away, but once you watch it, you'll know exactly what I am talking about. Additionally, I found it cool that most of the cast from the original movie returned to lend their voices to this one. Their presence added a layer of authenticity and nostalgia to the experience. It was a very good movie overall, and I would recommend it to anyone who enjoyed the original.

text:
Far richer in texture and character than even the classics from the 30's and 50's. George C. Scott was born to be Scrooge, just as he was born to be Patton. Mr. Scott will be known as one of the greatest actors of the 20th century. The character of Scrooge as played by Mr. Scott seemed to jump off the screen. Scott as Scrooge brought an richer, more robust, yet a more deeply moving Scrooge to the screen than any of his predecessors in the role of the meanest man in 18th century London. Mr. Scott seemed to bring Scrooge to a more personal, understandable yet highly conflicted level; his role was acted with the great authority Scott always bring to the screen: yet his usual bellicose voice would sometimes be brought to a whisper, almost as a soliloquy, as he would berate the Christmas holiday in one breath, yet reveal his own human frailty in his next line. He could portray the sour and crusty Scrooge, and a misunderstood, sympathetic Scrooge all in the same scene.

Truly a remarkable performance by a giant of his generation.
rewritten_review: Far richer in texture and character than even the classics from the 30's and 50's. George C. Scott was born to be Scrooge, just as he was born to be Patton. Mr. Scott will be known as one of the greatest actors of the 20th century. The character of Scrooge as played by Mr. Scott seemed to jump off the screen. Scott as Scrooge brought a richer, more robust, yet a more deeply moving Scrooge to the screen than any of his predecessors. Mr. Scott seemed to bring Scrooge to a more personal, understandable yet highly conflicted level; his role was acted with the great authority Scott always brings to the screen. His usual bellicose voice would sometimes be brought to a whisper, almost as a soliloquy, as he would berate the Christmas holiday in one breath, yet reveal his own human frailty in his next line. He could portray the sour and crusty Scrooge, and a misunderstood, sympathetic Scrooge all in the same scene. Truly a remarkable performance by a giant of his generation.

text:
It seems that Dee Snyder ran out of ideas halfway through the script. The second half of the movie is basically just a rehash of the first, which makes the film very boring. To sum up: Cop's daughter is suckered into party via chatroom where she is sexually molested/tortured by psychopath (played by Snider). Cop rescues her, psychopath is put in therapy/jail. Psychopath is released four years later and the whole thing is played out AGAIN. Within all this are many unexplained plot elements: Why was "Captain Howdy" psycho in the first place? What's with the one-time personality detour to bible-thumper? How does he kidnap all the adults and manage to sew their mouths shut without a struggle? And perhaps the biggest unsolved mystery of all... how does a 6'2" man with pink hair hide himself completely behind a 5'6" average build woman? These are just some of the questions I had watching this film.

It seems that Snyder was trying to make some kind of commentary on a) the "dangers" of online chatrooms, b) the hypocrisy of Christian sexual mores, and c) the effect our twisted puritanical society has on us as individuals. If that is so, he failed. The movie is just too poorly done to entertain, never mind convey social messages. The torture scenes are stupid and boring, bordering on silly (especially when Snyder goes into one of his "pain and death" monologues), and everything else is just plain dumb. The "call tracing" scene is really lame... when are the cops gonna get caller ID and *69? The young partner of the main cop character is particularly awful... he shouldn't be working as an actor, basically. And the audio in the final showdown scene is really poor. I guess they couldn't afford two boom mikes?

The rest of the acting is not awful but it's not good either. The cop is pretty one note, and his detached quality is not quite believable. Dee Snyder is actually not too bad, but he snarls and sneers way too much. Robert Englund (who deserves way better) puts in a somewhat amusing performance of a hypocritical redneck. If you're a big Robert Englund fan the movie is probably worth seeing just for him. Everyone else is forgettable.

In conclusion, we've seen all these plot elements done before and done better, in films like SILENCE OF THE LAMBS, HELLRAISER, and TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE. I suggest you rent one of those instead of watching this turkey. 3/10.
rewritten_review: Dee Snyder's film runs out of steam halfway through, essentially rehashing itself and becoming quite dull. The plot: a cop's daughter is lured to a party via chatroom and is tortured by a psychopath (Snider). The cop rescues her, the psychopath is jailed, and after four years, it all happens again. Unexplained elements abound: Why is "Captain Howdy" a psycho? Why the brief Bible-thumper phase? How does he kidnap adults and sew their mouths shut without resistance? And how does a 6'2" man with pink hair hide behind a 5'6" woman? Snyder attempts to address online chatroom dangers, Christian sexual mores, and societal influence, but fails. The torture scenes are silly, and the rest is just dumb. The "call tracing" scene is outdated. The young cop partner's acting is terrible, and the final showdown's audio is poor. The acting overall is mediocre; the cop is one-note, Snider overacts, and while Robert Englund is amusing, he deserves better. For Englund fans, his performance might be worth a watch. Otherwise, stick to films like SILENCE OF THE LAMBS or HELLRAISER. 3/10.

text:
If you value your freedom!

I first got seriously interested in The Branch Davidian debacle after reading an article in UK journal "The Fortean Times." Wanting to learn more, I rented this documentary and after watching it, I was stunned at what I saw. This film peaked my interest in the subject and I have read several books on the subject since then. This film is a must see for people who only know the facts as reported in the so called "mainstream" media. The baldfaced lies, double talk, and contradictory statements made by officials and politicians shown in this film will make you think twice about calling people who question the governments actions in this fiasco "nuts" "loonies" and "kooks."

Whats scary is that I know some people who consider themselves open minded "intellectuals" and freedom loving "liberals" who are still convinced that the government did the right thing at Waco and refuse to watch this film or read any of the books on the subject. They continue to insist its not worth their time because its all propaganda from gun loving, Clinton hating, religious fanatic,right wing anarchist nuts. One publication from an organization comprised of many so called "great minds" that claims to be dedicated to promoting "reason","common sense" and "rationalism" condemned the film claiming it would poison peoples minds and strongly suggested this film should be suppressed. They even hinted the Davidians had it coming. I won't mention its name since I'm a coward. If you are one of those reading this (of course you probably would not be reading this anyway), I can only say its a shame you won't open your mind.
rewritten_review:
If you value your freedom! 

I got interested in The Branch Davidian debacle after reading an article in UK journal "The Fortean Times." I rented this documentary and was stunned. This film piqued my interest, and I've read several books on the subject since. It's a must-see for those who only know the mainstream media's version. The lies and contradictory statements by officials and politicians shown in this film will make you reconsider labeling those who question the government's actions as "nuts." 

It's scary that some self-proclaimed open-minded "intellectuals" and freedom-loving "liberals" still believe the government did the right thing at Waco. They refuse to watch this film or read any books on the subject, dismissing it as propaganda from gun-loving, Clinton-hating, right-wing anarchists. One prominent organization promoting "reason" and "rationalism" condemned the film, suggesting it should be suppressed and hinted the Davidians had it coming. I won't mention its name since I'm a coward. If you're one of those reading this, it's a shame you won't open your mind.

text:
'Rise of the Footsoldier' follows the unrelentingly cruel journey of gangster Carlton Leach and his associates through drugs, violence, sex, violence, guns, violence and did I mention violence?

Protagonist Carlton Leach (Ricci Harnett), member of the I.C.F (Inner City Firm); a group of football hooligans turned professional gangsters, guides the audience through the events leading to the 1995 'Range Rover Killings', in which three gang members fell victim to particularly vicious professional 'hits'. Leach's success as a doorman and talent for locating aptly violent friends to control unruly punters at a local nightclub launches him into the company of notorious drug dealers and gangsters, profitably benefiting from the 80s/90s rave scene and drug culture.

Opening with brutally realistic shots of the dead men, the viewer is left thirsty to understand what happened, but left wholly unsatisfied. The next 2 hours meander through a series of countless character introductions. Each of these basically establishes yet another typical 'hard man', shows him assaulting usually undeserving victims, before probably coming to an even nastier end. What little emotional understanding the audience is allowed to form for a few of the characters (for example a family man blamed for missing drugs) is quickly destroyed when they are either anti-climactically killed, or their storyline left unresolved. The hints of a plot introduced in the beginning are inadequately concluded with vague impressions of how the murders occurred, as the events are slotted into place with little reward for persevering with the hazy muddle of previous events.

This film has been made with a standard formula in mind, for an audience who prefer violence and 'ard nut' slang to an actual storyline. 'Rise of the Footsoldier' borrows too much from 'Football Factory', leaving out the good bits, demonstrating no moral ramifications of hooligan subculture or establishing empathy with the protagonist. The violence, although brilliantly shot, seems excessive and implausible because no one is around long enough for the audience to form an emotional attachment. The implication that the gangs are untouchable by the police is fair enough, but machete-wielding doormen regularly committing blatant murder in public places pushes the imagination of even the most willing viewer. The audience are left bewildered as to the relevance of many key events and developed characters that had no knock on effect on the eventual conclusion. Attempted 'gritty-realism' is further destroyed with a substance called 'Truth Serum', which the Turkish Mafia use to coax honest answers from unwilling individuals. This is NOT the genre in which to invent psychologically unrealistic drugs, and renders the interrogation almost absurd.

The actual scenes of violence (before becoming repetitive) hold some tension, spliced with rapid flashes of colour or the end of a film reel. Seamlessly choreographed brawls coupled with obligatory but effective shaky hand-held camera work saves the film, but unfortunately the plot (or lack there of) limits it to a niche demographic.

In essence, the events this film is based on aren't deservedly represented, and an adequately sequential storyline is sacrificed for stereotypical characters and an unoriginal plot. This film has a place in the market, but if you like a bit of brain with your brutality this one isn't for you.

http://www.obsessedwithfilm.com/

text: While killing time on a Saturday morning, "Looking For Lola" came on HBO. I decided to give it a shot even though the description of the movie looked pretty bad. It was even worse than I could imagine. The movie was incredibly unbelievable and there was absolutely no on-screen chemistry between the lead actors that I found myself shaking my head almost every 10 minutes. Between Mike Greenbaum (lead actor) in scenes in which he skips the bill at a fancy restaurant and where Lola (lead actress) allows him to use her boss' house to fool his parents into thinking he's rich, it was almost as bad as him "daydreaming" about people around him doing the macarena (it was HORRIBLE!) and the two actors ultimately falling in love. I kept wanting to change the channel, but I was trying to give it every chance into becoming a cute love story with a few chuckles. It never did. In fact, it became so bad that I decided to finish it just so I can claim that I watched one of the worst films ever made in it's entirety, instead of being criticized for not "giving it a fair chance". The last scene where Lola tries out for a dance part was the culmination of the movie. She comes in late after getting married (even that scene where Mike tells the priest to hurry up and then just snatches the papers away claiming that it's done was in tune with the believability of this movie), and then somehow "convinces" the judges to give her a look. The two male judges are already put-off with how late she is. But after watching her waif around the stage (ok, she dances fine, but not overly impressive), everybody joins in including Lola and Mike's families, other dancers that were there, and *cough* even the judges. Bad, horrible, terrible. It was so bad I had to write a review. Watch at your own risk.
rewritten_review: I watched "Looking For Lola" on HBO one Saturday morning, despite its bad description, and it was worse than I imagined. The movie was unbelievably unrealistic, and the lead actors had zero chemistry, leaving me shaking my head every 10 minutes. Mike Greenbaum's scenes, like skipping a restaurant bill and using Lola's boss' house to fool his parents, were as bad as his "daydreaming" of people doing the macarena. The two actors falling in love was equally implausible. I kept hoping it would turn into a cute love story with laughs, but it never did. It was so bad I finished it just to say I've watched one of the worst films ever. The last scene, where Lola, late after her wedding, "convinces" the dance judges to give her a chance, was the pinnacle of absurdity. She dances fine but not impressively, yet everyone, including the judges, joins in. Bad, horrible, terrible. Watch at your own risk.

text:
Froggie is upset that he never has a big party like all the other kids. Spanky and the gang seek to remedy that by giving him a surprise party. Unaware that all the decorations and preparations are for him Froggy sabotages everything only to find out too late that the party is for him.

Okay Our Gang comedy works in fits and starts. The bits work but I don't think it really works as a whole. Part of the problem is that we all know where this is going and since much of the humor needs to have some form of surprise for it to work the whole thing falls down. I think in a weird way the film just sort of misses. Its the type of thing that had they actually thought about it might have amounted to something more than a misfire. Worth trying if you lower your expectations
rewritten_review: Froggie is upset that he never has a big party like all the other kids. Spanky and the gang seek to remedy that by giving him a surprise party. Unaware that all the decorations and preparations are for him, Froggy sabotages everything only to find out too late that the party is for him. This premise sets the stage for an Our Gang comedy that works in fits and starts. The bits work, providing some chuckles and moments of amusement, but when you look at the film as a whole, it doesn’t quite come together as one might hope. Part of the problem is that we all know where this is going from the very beginning. The predictability of the plot undercuts the comedic potential, as much of the humor relies on some form of surprise or twist for it to work effectively. Without that element of surprise, the whole thing tends to fall down, leaving the audience with a sense of missed opportunity. I think in a weird way, the film just sort of misses its mark. It’s the type of thing that, had they actually thought about it a bit more—perhaps infusing the plot with unexpected turns or more inventive scenarios—it might have amounted to something more than a misfire. Still, it’s worth giving this film a try, especially if you lower your expectations and approach it with an open mind. There are still enjoyable moments, and for fans of Our Gang, it might provide a nostalgic trip back to familiar comedic territory. Just don’t expect it to be a seamless or groundbreaking experience. Instead, appreciate it for what it is: a collection of amusing bits that, while not fully cohesive, still manage to entertain on some level.

text:
With a humor that would appeal to an exclusive, small audience, the average viewer will find it pointless and monotonous. When Cartoon Network advertised this show, it was made to look as if it was a major drama or event, complete with a real rain scene and government officials trying to catch the Sheep.

When it came out on the air, I was disappointed at how all the characters were so one-dimensional and a totally bland animation. The only thing that put it to anything close to humor were the names of the characters like "Private Public" and "General Specific", a few vague references to cultural aspects, and how Lady Richington pummeled Sheep with her steel wig.

Slightly off topic, but I don't see why would Sheep fall in love with that ball of dirty cotton balls called "Swanky." It was hideous!
rewritten_review:
With a humor that would appeal to an exclusive, small audience, the average viewer will find it pointless and monotonous. The show seems to cater to a niche group of humor enthusiasts who appreciate its unique style, but for the general audience, it lacks the substance and engagement required to hold their attention. When Cartoon Network advertised this show, it was made to look as if it was a major drama or event, complete with a real rain scene and government officials trying to catch the Sheep. The promotional efforts suggested a grand narrative and a level of excitement that was, unfortunately, not reflected in the actual content of the show.

When it came out on the air, I was disappointed at how all the characters were so one-dimensional and a totally bland animation. The animation style didn't live up to the expectations set by the advertisements, leaving viewers longing for something more visually stimulating. Each character seemed to be cut from the same cloth, lacking depth and complexity, which made it difficult to form any real connection or interest in their stories. The only thing that put it to anything close to humor were the names of the characters like "Private Public" and "General Specific", a few vague references to cultural aspects, and how Lady Richington pummeled Sheep with her steel wig. The names provided a fleeting chuckle, and the cultural references, while present, were too obscure to be appreciated by a broader audience, leaving only Lady Richington’s comical aggression as a highlight.

Slightly off topic, but I don't see why would Sheep fall in love with that ball of dirty cotton balls called "Swanky." It was hideous! The romantic subplot between Sheep and Swanky seemed forced and unconvincing, as Swanky's appearance and personality did not seem to warrant such affection from Sheep. This aspect of the show added to the overall confusion and lack of coherence in the narrative, making it even harder to engage with the storyline.

text: This, along with "Hare Tonic," ranks as one of the best Bugs cartoons, indeed one of the best Bugs, ever. There are some comments about how Bugs in these cartoons is "basic," meaning, I guess, that he is as yet not fully developed. I actually prefer this "basic" version from the mid-40s (Chuck Jones' was the best version) who is actually more rabbit-sized and far more amusing than the eventual long-legged version who towered over Yosemite Sam and Daffy Duck. The latter-day Bugs came to be too suave and sophisticated for my liking. Also check out "Hair Raising Hare" (1946) and "Rabbit Punch" (1948) for great examples of classic Bugs and classic Chuck Jones.

text:
THE CHOKE (aka AXE in the UK) is a slasher produced supposedly as a straight-to-DVD movie. I say "supposedly" because the title of the movie does not have the "V" in brackets to indicate that it was a made for DVD movie (even though it does have the appearance of one).

The plot is simple  a band is holding a gig in a former meatpacking factory and they are killed one by one.

I think most would agree that the movie was never going to be a masterpiece, but this does not excuse the faults here. Even straight-to-DVD movies such as BACHELOR PARTY MASSACRE (which has a very low IMDb rating) have a lot of redeeming qualities and sometimes come off as being one of the so-called "so bad, they're good" movies. However, THE CHOKE falls far short of being either a serious slasher (such as HALLOWEEN) or being a "so bad it's good" movie (such as THE NAIL GUN MASSACRE).

The movie does start off good with a character killed using a drill. The blood effects were very cheesy but understandable given the very low budget. But, from there onwards, it's downhill all the way.

There are so many faults in THE CHOKE that I could spend all day talking about them. But, a few obvious ones stand out and I'll go into them.

The aforementioned gig that the band holds seems to start off with around 50 people present but after the music stops, there seems to be only around 8 people left (and yet they're all meant to be locked in!).

The characters in this movie are not likable at all. Most of the band members are aggressive foul-mouthed morons or just downright weird. No one really cares about what happens to them, and even their supposed friends forget about them when they've been dispatched. The highlight of the movie is the presence of a homeless man who seems to regard the meatpacking factory as some kind of church (seriously!). He spouts some really funny lines for no apparent reason. But sadly, even his presence can't save the movie.

There are too many scenes of people walking around and talking without any characterisation. Around 65 minutes of the film is spent watching characters walk around talking. Characters disappear for long periods of time without explanation. As in other straight-to-DVD movies such as CROCODILE and GRIM WEEKEND, the characters spend a lot of time swearing at each other aggressively without any provocation at all. There are plenty of over-the-top outbursts (mainly from the male characters) and one nearly results in a full-blown fight. In fact, the format could be said to go as follows: characters walk around--murder takes place--characters walk around--murder takes place. You get the idea.

The dialogue is terrible and it seems that few lines are spoken without the f-word being used. Perhaps this was meant to be funny, but it just comes off as sad. And more to the point, we have all seen this done a thousand times before (usually to much greater effect).

The movie is totally devoid of any suspense at all. The dead bodies serve to provide the only indication that the characters are in danger. A maniac is running around loose and yet the characters just behave like total morons. They make little attempt to get out of the factory or find a weapon with which to protect themselves. And much of the time, they don't even pretend to be scared.

In the same vein as DRIVE-IN MASSACRE, the killer is not seen at the time the murders are being committed (with the exception of the final murder when the killer's identity is revealed). A random weapon appears out of nowhere to kill the victim in question. There is no one seen stalking the characters at any time. In DRIVE-IN MASSACRE, this served to make the film funny (unintentionally of course), but here it is not funny at all.

And, as another reviewer has pointed out, the soundtrack includes music that is very bad, even for those who like punk rock. The extras look uncomfortable dancing to it. The score (at the end, there is no music at the beginning!) consists of a band of Sugarbabe wannabes singing some very bad song that is completely unrelated to the movie.

Don't misunderstand the points made in this review. This reviewer likes bad movies (such as THE NAIL GUN MASSACRE and BACHELOR PARTY MASSACRE) as much as the classics (such as HALLOWEEN and Friday THE 13TH). But, it seems that THE CHOKE tried too hard to fit into one of those categories without fitting into either. And even as straight-to-DVD movies go, this is a poor effort.

On a positive note, the film does contain some fairly good gory murder scenes. But, when the surviving characters do not take the situation seriously, these scenes lose their importance quickly as the intensity they provide disappears into oblivion.

Fans of the traditional 1980s B-movie slashers should take steps to avoid this movie. And fans of the classics such as HALLOWEEN and Friday THE 13TH should do everything in their power to avoid it!

text:
I have always wanted to see this because I love cheesy horror movies and with a title like this, I was sure "The Incredible Melting Man" would be a lot of fun.

It really wasn't. I mean, the acting was entertainingly bad, the script contained some classic bad lines and the special effects looked like someone had sneezed all over the lead actor, so I should have loved it. Unfortunately it's really draggy between these highlights. I decided to watch the last half of the movie while doing my tax return. That's how boring this film is.

Nevertheless, if you love bad movies you will enjoy the dramatic exit of the Fat Nurse, and the stellar acting of the guy who plays Dr. Ted. To be fair to the poor man, he does have to deliver some amazingly inept lines with straight face - like the conversation he has with his wife on tracking down the I M Man:

"I'll find him with a geiger counter." "Is he radioactive?" "Just a little bit."

Yes, the plot has Dr. Ted wandering about trying to find a superstrong zombie killing machine armed only with what looks like a mini-Dyson. He's a brave man. Unfortunately his plan fails when he finds a big lot of goop on a tree. "Oh god - it's his ear!" says Dr. Ted to the audience. I'm so glad he cleared that up.

I realise I'm making this movie sound rather fun. It would be if it were only 10 minutes long, but unfortunately it goes on and on, and the Incredible Melting Dude just dangles about making a sticky mess when he should be eating more people in my opinion. I think if you were truly stoned you would probably love it, just don't have pop-tarts during the movie, because the lead actor really does resemble one near the end.
