text: This is definitely an appropriate update for the original, except that "party on the left is now party on the right." Like the original, this movie rails against a federal government which oversteps its bounds with regards to personal liberty. It is a warning of how tenuous our political liberties are in an era of an over-zealous, and over-powerful federal government. Kowalski serves as a metaphor for Waco and Ruby Ridge, where the US government, with the cooperation of the mainstream media, threw around words like "white supremacist" and "right wing extremists as well as trumped-up drug charges to abridge the most fundamental of its' citizens rights, with the willing acquiescence of the general populace. That message is so non-PC, I am stunned that this film could be made - at least not without bringing the Federal government via the IRS down on the makers like they did to Juanita Broderick, Katherine Prudhomme, the Western Journalism Center, and countless others who dared to speak out. "Live Free or Die" is the motto on Jason Priestly's hat as he brilliantly portrays "the voice," and that sums up the dangerous (to some) message of this film.
rewritten_review: This update is fitting for the original, except "party on the left is now party on the right." Like the original, this film criticizes an overreaching federal government infringing on personal liberty, highlighting the fragility of political freedoms in an era of an overly powerful federal government. Kowalski symbolizes Waco and Ruby Ridge, where the government, with media cooperation, used terms like "white supremacist" and "right-wing extremists," as well as false drug charges, to violate fundamental rights with public consent. This message is so non-PC, it's surprising this film was made without government retaliation, like what happened to Juanita Broderick, Katherine Prudhomme, and others. "Live Free or Die" on Jason Priestly's hat, as he skillfully plays "the voice," captures the film's dangerous (to some) message.

text: Rosie Perez is the lead in this very engaging affair, cast as Mercedes, a young woman from Brooklyn who has resolved to become a film actress although not favoured by her circumstances, living in East Los Angeles and struggling with a series of fruitless auditions for any sort of part at all. Mercedes has hooked up with a married and washed-up actor, Harry Harrelson (Harvey Keitel), who at one time had performed in a television Western series during the 1970s, and seldom since, accepting him as her lover, in part from loneliness, and as well from a hope that film parts will be coming her way because of his "contacts", but these latter are of small consequence as Harry is simply self-delusional in his attempts at recovering what he perceives as past cinematic renown. In order to adequately support herself financially, Mercedes toils as a taxi dancer in a downtown Los Angeles Skid Row dance hall/bar while she continues carrying on her efforts to succeed at the motion picture business, and it is while there at the dance palace that a young immigrant from Mexico, Ernesto (Michael DeLorenzo), falls in love with her and the largest portion of the narrative depicts his efforts to please the object of his affections, even if they may mean losing her altogether. This essentially tradition rooted melodrama is given only a moderate budget, despite the presence of a goodly number of well-known players, including Steve Buscemi, Anthony Quinn, and Stanley Tucci, and was kept in the can for about a year before its rather desultory distribution and leaden marketing efforts on its behalf, more's the pity as its solid production characteristics are firmly complemented by Alexandre Rockwell's admirably controlled direction, a consistent virtue of his work, and on display in this film from its very opening scene, frames that form a montage behind the credits, featuring Perez at Skid Row's Fifth and Main Streets. Rockwell has often demonstrated that he operates very closely indeed with his cast, and this holds true in this instance as he allows his actors to create their roles while any ad libbing is neatened nicely via the editing process, resulting in an artistic success for the director, despite negative comments from some mainstream evaluators. The film's scoring is aesthetically spot on with a good deal of it contributed by Tito Larriva, who also plays as band boss for the taxi dancers. Acting honours here must go to the ever vital Perez, although nary a sub-par performance is turned in. A fair test for any film's quality is given when a viewer will watch it twice within a brief period. Sitting through this undervalued work will be considered a keen pleasure for many.
rewritten_review: Rosie Perez leads this engaging affair as Mercedes, a young woman from Brooklyn aspiring to be a film actress despite her challenging circumstances in East Los Angeles. Struggling with fruitless auditions, Mercedes becomes involved with Harry Harrelson (Harvey Keitel), a washed-up actor from a 1970s TV Western, hoping his "contacts" will help her. Financially, she works as a taxi dancer in a Skid Row dance hall/bar, where Ernesto (Michael DeLorenzo), a young Mexican immigrant, falls in love with her. The narrative largely focuses on Ernesto's efforts to win Mercedes, even at the risk of losing her. Despite a moderate budget and delayed distribution, the film features well-known actors like Steve Buscemi, Anthony Quinn, and Stanley Tucci. Director Alexandre Rockwell's controlled style is evident from the opening montage, and he collaborates closely with his cast, refining any ad libbing through editing. The film, despite some negative reviews, is artistically successful, with a fitting score by Tito Larriva, who also appears as the band boss. Perez shines, and all performances are strong. The film's quality is evident when viewers are inclined to watch it twice in a short period, making it a keen pleasure for many.

text: When it was announced the "King of Pop" was dead at age 50, a month before he was to start a series of live comeback shows at London's O2 Arena, it was a huge shock to millions of people around the world. He was, and will forever be one of the most talented voices and dancers in the music industry, and he will be missed terribly. I decided to remind myself how wonderful he was by watching what is considered by many to be not only Jackson's best video (and possibly song), but the greatest music video ever made, from director John Landis (An American Werewolf in London). The film opens with Michael and his Girl (Ola Ray) having their car breakdown, and after giving her a ring, the moon comes out and he turns into a werewolf. We then see Michael and his Girl watching this horror film in the cinema, she is scared and walks out, and Michael soon follows her, singing the iconic song. Soon enough the voice of Vincent Price comes on, and zombies start crawling out the earth and open coffins from the graveyard, and Michael and the Girl are obviously surrounded. She turns away, and Michael has become a zombie himself, and with all the other creatures they do the iconic dance, before he turns back into his normal self, at least for the chorus. The Girl runs into the near creepy house, blocks the doorway, but zombie Michael still manages to break through, and when he touches her she screams to see normal Michael say "what's the problem?" The film ends with him taking her home, and looking at us with evil eyes. Michael Jackson was number 14 on The 100 Greatest Pop Culture Icons, and he was number 6 on The Ultimate Pop Star, the Thriller album was number 4 on The 100 Greatest Albums, and this video was number 71 on The 100 Greatest Scary Moments, and it was number 1 on The 100 Greatest Pop Videos. Very good!
rewritten_review: When it was announced the "King of Pop" was dead at age 50, just a month before his comeback shows at London's O2 Arena, it shocked millions worldwide. Michael Jackson, one of the most talented voices and dancers, will be missed terribly. I reminded myself of his greatness by watching what many consider not only Jackson's best video (and possibly song), but the greatest music video ever, directed by John Landis (An American Werewolf in London). It opens with Michael and his Girl (Ola Ray) having car trouble. After giving her a ring, he turns into a werewolf under the moon. We then see them watching this horror film in a theater; she gets scared and leaves, and Michael follows, singing the iconic song. Vincent Price's voice comes on, and zombies rise from graves, surrounding them. She turns, seeing Michael as a zombie, and they perform the iconic dance before he returns to normal for the chorus. The Girl runs into a creepy house, blocking the doorway, but zombie Michael breaks through. When he touches her, she screams, seeing normal Michael say, "what's the problem?" It ends with him taking her home and looking at us with evil eyes. Michael Jackson was number 14 on The 100 Greatest Pop Culture Icons, and number 6 on The Ultimate Pop Star. The Thriller album was number 4 on The 100 Greatest Albums, this video was number 71 on The 100 Greatest Scary Moments, and it was number 1 on The 100 Greatest Pop Videos. Very good!

text:
It seems to me that Stephen King's "Bachman" pen-name was a way for him to put out some of the grimmer, rawer, more mean-spirited stuff that he wanted to write without 'contaminating' his 'brand name'. If you look back at the "Bachman Books" (Running Man, The Long Walk, Roadwork, Thinner) you notice they have a sealed-in feeling of airlessness and hopelessness about them that is distinct from mainstream King. I realize that we are talking about the guy whose first novel featured a humiliated, blood-covered, emotionally crippled teenage girl slaughtering everyone at her high school prom...but mainstream King always at have characters and plot elements that leaven the grimness of the proceedings a bit, and mostly have endings that offer at least a glimpse of hope and human feeling. Bachman books are just plain mean and always end badly. (BTW, "Pet Semetary" could have easily been a Bachman book if King hadn't revealed the alias by then. And "The Dark Half" seems to be at least partially about his "Bachman" persona.)

"Thinner" was the last Bachman book, and man, with its themes of class warfare, revenge, and death by starvation, it is nasty. So it should be no surprise that the movie follows suit.

What is a surprise is that the adaptation seems to be filmed at a "TV Movie Of the Week" level of talent instead of something worthy of a theatrical release. (These days, something like this would probably go directly to DVD or cable). The makeup work and the striking motif (starving to death in the midst of plenty, a metaphor for the overfed, undernourished American middle class if there ever was one) is all that keeps you watching this misfire.

What went wrong? My first thought is that the director was going for the nasty Bachman vibe, but he also somehow sucked all the interest out of the movie with poor casting choices - the actors here (with the exception of Joe Monetegna) simply can't carry the movie. And then he squished the warmth and life out of the rest of the movie with awkward pacing and scene structure. Plus he couldn't leave the plot alone, and his changes don't really help. The script and dialog ought to work, but mostly the movie just lies there. Everything is muffled, dull, airless, and no fun to watch...with the vivid exception of the spectacle of the main character getting....thinner, and thinner, and thinner.

As other have pointed out, "Thinner" is by no means the worst King movie ever made (or even the second worst). And it does have a dreadful, compelling fascination owing to the theme and the careful makeup work. But first time viewers should approach this one with lowered expectations.
rewritten_review:
Stephen King's use of the "Bachman" pen-name allowed him to explore grimmer, rawer themes without affecting his main brand. The "Bachman Books" (Running Man, The Long Walk, Roadwork, Thinner) have a distinct airlessness and hopelessness compared to mainstream King, who often includes elements that leaven the grimness and endings that offer some hope. Bachman books, however, are mean and end badly. "Pet Semetary" could have been a Bachman book if the alias hadn't been revealed, and "The Dark Half" seems partially about his "Bachman" persona.

"Thinner," the last Bachman book, is particularly nasty with themes of class warfare, revenge, and death by starvation. Surprisingly, the movie adaptation feels like a "TV Movie Of the Week" rather than a theatrical release, and would likely go directly to DVD or cable today. The makeup work and the striking motif of starving in plenty, a metaphor for the overfed, undernourished American middle class, are the only highlights.

The director aimed for the Bachman vibe but ended up with poor casting choices—except for Joe Mantegna—and awkward pacing. Changes to the plot don't help, and the script and dialog fail to engage. The movie feels muffled, dull, and airless, with the main character's transformation being the only vivid aspect. "Thinner" isn't the worst King movie, but it requires lowered expectations due to its dreadful yet compelling theme and makeup work.

text: I simply never tire of watching FREEBIRD. My husband was an extra so I was involved from the start. Have kept in touch with Jon and have helped out with promoting the film both in Cinemas and now the DVD release. Even to the extent of distributing promotional postcards on cross channel ferries and various places throughout France. FREEBIRD was expertly written and directed with the perfect combination of fun and serious moments plus choice casting. Only Phil Daniels could fit the role of Grouch. Great privilege to meet Jon and the cast at the party following the premier in January. Anything else you want doing Jon just ask, either email or phone, you know how to get me. Sue xx
rewritten_review: I simply never tire of watching FREEBIRD. My husband was an extra, so I was involved from the very start, right from the initial stages of the production. I have kept in touch with Jon and have actively helped out with promoting the film both in Cinemas during its initial release and now with the DVD release as well. Even to the extent of going the extra mile by distributing promotional postcards on cross-channel ferries and various places throughout France. FREEBIRD was expertly written and directed, with the perfect combination of fun and serious moments, plus choice casting that really brought the film to life. Only Phil Daniels could fit the role of Grouch so perfectly, capturing the essence of the character in a way that no one else could. It was a great privilege to meet Jon and the cast at the party following the premiere in January, an event that was truly memorable. Anything else you want doing, Jon, just ask; either email or phone, you know how to get hold of me. Sue xx

text:
Quite simply, Goldeneye is the single greatest N64 game to date. The learning curve is just about perfect, and you'll still be playing it with your friends months on, as the multiplayer mode is nothing short of exceptional.

The system for acquiring cheats for once requires some degree of skill, rather than simply knowing which buttons to press, and the challenge of Aztec on 00 agent level is astonishing.

All in all - it's the best game I've ever played on the N64
rewritten_review:
Goldeneye, without a doubt, stands as the single greatest N64 game to date. This game captures the essence of what makes gaming truly enjoyable and memorable. The learning curve it offers is just about perfect, striking a brilliant balance that keeps players engaged without overwhelming them. It presents an experience that is accessible to newcomers yet challenging enough for seasoned gamers to master. As you dive deeper into the game, you find yourself continuously improving, refining your skills, and discovering new strategies. 

One of the standout features of Goldeneye is its multiplayer mode, which is nothing short of exceptional. This aspect of the game ensures that you'll still be playing it with your friends months on, perhaps even years later. The multiplayer mode is cleverly designed to offer endless fun, creating countless memorable moments as you and your friends engage in intense, action-packed battles. Each session is a unique experience filled with laughter, excitement, and the kind of competitive spirit that only a truly great game can inspire. 

Additionally, the system for acquiring cheats in Goldeneye is a refreshing departure from the norm. For once, it requires some degree of skill, rather than simply knowing which buttons to press. This innovative approach adds an extra layer of challenge and satisfaction, as players must earn their rewards through skillful gameplay. The cheats become a testament to your dedication and mastery of the game, providing a sense of accomplishment that is both gratifying and motivating.

The challenge of Aztec on 00 agent level is astonishing, pushing players to their limits and testing their strategic thinking and reflexes. It represents the pinnacle of difficulty within the game, offering a formidable test that even the most experienced gamers will find demanding. Conquering this level is a triumph that requires patience, perseverance, and a deep understanding of the game's mechanics. It's a challenge that keeps players coming back, determined to overcome it and experience the thrill of victory.

All in all, Goldeneye on the N64 is a masterpiece of gaming. It's the best game I've ever played on the N64, and its impact on the gaming world is undeniable. The combination of a perfect learning curve, exceptional multiplayer mode, skill-based cheat system, and astonishing challenges makes it an unforgettable experience that has stood the test of time. This game set a new standard for first-person shooters on consoles and continues to be celebrated by fans and gamers worldwide.

text: All I have to say is one word...SUCKS!!!!. The only reason I gave this a 2 is because Josh Hartnett was in it and he's cool. Should have beat that Klein guys ass...stupid dumb and brainless. By the end of this movie you can't stand Klein and you really don't care what happens to Leelee. Hartnett was the only good thing about it.
rewritten_review: All I have to say is one word...SUCKS!!!! Seriously, this movie was a complete letdown from start to finish. The only reason I gave this a 2, instead of a 1, is because Josh Hartnett was in it, and he's undeniably cool. His presence was the only redeeming factor in this entire mess of a film. I honestly think he should have beat that Klein guy's ass because the character was just so irritating throughout the movie. Everything about him felt stupid, dumb, and brainless. By the end of this movie, you can't stand Klein, and you really don't care what happens to Leelee. Her character just didn't resonate with me at all, and it felt like she was just there without much purpose. Hartnett was the only good thing about it, and I wish the rest of the movie had lived up to his performance. It's a shame that such talent was wasted in a film that ultimately failed to deliver on any level.

text: All I can say is I really miss this show!! My wife & I just got married around the time this show started up!! Why did CBS take it off the air??? I think it was the best show for the whole family to enjoy!! It made me laugh!! It also made me cry. But when CBS took it off the air my wife & I thought CBS made a big mistake. You know what would be so great?? Have a reunion show!! That would be so cool!!!! Anybody know if it is on DVD yet?? On the last season of Promised Land, did CBS show the whole last season?? I think CBS took it off the air at mid-season. My wife & I will never forget it. The opening with that theme song was fantastic!!! This show only comes once in a life time! May we never forget Promised Land!!
rewritten_review: All I can say is I really miss this show!! My wife & I just got married around the time this show started up!! It was such a special time in our lives, and this show became a part of our routine. Why did CBS take it off the air??? I think it was the best show for the whole family to enjoy!! It made me laugh!! It also made me cry. It had everything you'd want in a show, from heartfelt moments to comedic relief. But when CBS took it off the air my wife & I thought CBS made a big mistake. We couldn't believe it! You know what would be so great?? Have a reunion show!! That would be so cool!!!! Imagine seeing all the characters together again, reliving those wonderful stories. Anybody know if it is on DVD yet?? We've been hoping to find it so we can relive those memories. On the last season of Promised Land, did CBS show the whole last season?? I think CBS took it off the air at mid-season. It was so disappointing not to see how everything wrapped up. My wife & I will never forget it. The opening with that theme song was fantastic!!! It instantly brought a smile to our faces every time we heard it. This show only comes once in a lifetime! It truly was one of a kind. May we never forget Promised Land!! It holds a special place in our hearts, and we often talk about how much joy it brought us.

text: So, Madonna isn't Meryl Streep. Still, this is one of her first films and a comedy at that. Give her a break! Sure, the movie is mediocre at best and pales in comparison to its earlier counterpart w/ Katherine Hepburn, Bringing Up Baby. For what it is, though(a piece of fluff), it's quite a bit of fun to watch. I've yet to hear anyone that slams Madonna's acting skills back it up w/ evidence or even adjectives other than "awful", "bad", or other such vague descriptive words. If you wanna see bad acting or justify the argument that singers should stick to singing, how about Whitney Houston?? She's had the most undeserved commercial success of any actress in history and couldn't act her way out of a hatbox. The American public obviously cannot discern the difference between a credible performance in a movie and star power. I think Madonna has always been at least credible in her movies. Get real people. Madonna-bashing is so 90's.
rewritten_review:
So, Madonna isn't Meryl Streep. Still, this is one of her first films and a comedy at that. Give her a break! Sure, the movie is mediocre at best and pales in comparison to its earlier counterpart with Katherine Hepburn, Bringing Up Baby. For what it is, though (a piece of fluff), it's quite a bit of fun to watch. I've yet to hear anyone that slams Madonna's acting skills back it up with evidence or even adjectives other than "awful," "bad," or other such vague descriptive words. If you want to see bad acting or justify the argument that singers should stick to singing, how about Whitney Houston?? She's had the most undeserved commercial success of any actress in history and couldn't act her way out of a hatbox. The American public obviously cannot discern the difference between a credible performance in a movie and star power. I think Madonna has always been at least credible in her movies. Get real people. Madonna-bashing is so 90's. 

It's important to remember that Madonna has been a groundbreaking artist in the music industry, and her transition into acting should be seen as an extension of her creative expression. While she may not reach the heights of seasoned actresses like Meryl Streep, it's essential to acknowledge her willingness to take risks and explore new territories. Moreover, comparing her to legendary performers like Katherine Hepburn may seem unfair, considering the vast differences in their backgrounds and experiences. Still, for those who enjoy lighthearted entertainment, Madonna's films offer a unique charm and energy that shouldn't be overlooked. Dismissing her performances without substantial critique does a disservice not only to her efforts but also to the diversity of talent in the film industry. So, let's take a step back and appreciate Madonna for the multifaceted artist she is, and perhaps reevaluate our standards of what constitutes good acting. After all, Madonna-bashing is so 90's, and it's time for a more nuanced discussion.

text:
So you're a giant mantis and you've been hanging out in the arctic for a while, and you're tired of Eskimos hitting you with snowballs. What's a giant mutant insect to do? Head for the big city, of course! See the sights, maybe catch a show on Broadway. But wait! Just when you find a nice cozy tunnel to call your own, some pesky humans start attacking you!! Argh! Time to smash!

Anyhow this movie is one step up on most other giant bug movies, because it has pretty decent FX for 1957. But that's about it. Avoid unless you really need to see another big bug smash things, or see another Perry Mason actor in a B movie.

4/10
rewritten_review:
So imagine this: you're a giant mantis, a magnificent and awe-inspiring creature, and you've been hanging out in the arctic for quite a while, enduring the relentless chill and isolation of the icy wilderness. However, you're getting pretty tired of Eskimos constantly pelting you with snowballs. It seems like every time you turn around, there's another flurry of icy projectiles headed your way. What’s a giant mutant insect supposed to do in such a situation? Well, naturally, you decide it's time for a change of scenery! Head for the big city, of course! The allure of the bustling metropolis is simply irresistible. You long to see the sights, to soak in the vibrant atmosphere, and maybe even catch a spectacular show on Broadway. The bright lights and the promise of endless adventures beckon you. But wait! Just when you think you've found a nice cozy tunnel to call your own, a perfect little retreat from the chaos of city life, some pesky humans start attacking you!! It's absolutely maddening! Argh! Time to smash! There's no other option but to unleash your mighty wrath upon these bothersome creatures who dare to disturb your peace.

Anyhow, this movie is one step up on most other giant bug movies, and that's saying something considering the genre. Why, you ask? Because it has pretty decent FX for 1957. The special effects are surprisingly well-executed for the era, adding a touch of realism to the fantastical plot. But, alas, that's about it. The film doesn't offer much beyond that. It's a classic tale of a misunderstood creature trying to find its place in a world that just doesn't understand. So, avoid it unless you really need to see another big bug smash things. Perhaps you have an insatiable craving for scenes of chaos and destruction, or maybe you have a particular interest in seeing another Perry Mason actor in a B movie. If that's the case, then this might just be the movie for you. Otherwise, you might want to look elsewhere for your entertainment needs.

4/10

text:
There are probably more people afraid of the dentist than of, let's say, little monsters or scary looking dolls. Which makes it a perfect subject for a horror movie, really.

Dr. Feinstone (Corbin Bernsen) has been a successful dentist for several years now, but when he catches his wife cheating on him with the poolguy he snaps, and he brings his anger and frustration to his work. Well, give a mad dentist a drill and a mouth, and you can probably guess what happens next...

As I said, brilliant idea but not delivered as well as it should. In particular the ending is a huge let down. Last note: watch for Mark Ruffalo (You Can Count On Me, Eternal Sunshine...) in this one.

5/10.
rewritten_review:
There are probably more people afraid of the dentist than of, let's say, little monsters or scary looking dolls. This makes it a perfect subject for a horror movie, really, as the fear of the dentist is something many people can relate to on a very personal level. The potential for fear and tension is immense when you think about the vulnerability of lying back in that dentist's chair, mouth open, with someone wielding sharp instruments above you. This scenario taps into a primal fear, which is perhaps what makes it such an intriguing concept for a horror film.

Dr. Feinstone (played by Corbin Bernsen) has been a successful dentist for several years now, building a reputable practice and presumably leading a stable life. However, his world takes a dramatic turn when he catches his wife in the act of cheating on him with the pool guy. This discovery sends him over the edge, and he snaps under the weight of betrayal and emotional turmoil. The once composed and professional dentist is now consumed by anger and frustration, emotions he tragically brings into his work environment. The office, a place meant for care and healing, becomes a setting for his unraveling.

Well, give a mad dentist a drill and a mouth, and you can probably guess what happens next. The film explores the dark side of human nature and what happens when someone in a position of trust and power loses control. The premise is chilling because it plays on the everyday fears associated with dental visits, amplifying them to nightmarish levels. The idea of a trusted professional turning rogue is terrifying, and the film taps into that fear effectively, at least in its initial setup.

As I said, the premise is a brilliant idea, but unfortunately, it is not delivered as well as it could have been. The execution falls short of its potential, leaving audiences wanting more in terms of depth and suspense. In particular, the ending is a huge letdown, failing to provide the satisfying conclusion that viewers hope for after being taken on this tumultuous journey. The resolution lacks the impact needed to leave a lasting impression, diminishing the overall experience of the film.

Last note: watch for Mark Ruffalo (You Can Count On Me, Eternal Sunshine...) in this one. His appearance adds an interesting element to the film, as he has gone on to have a successful career in various acclaimed roles. Seeing him in this context is a reminder of the diverse paths actors take in their careers. Despite its shortcomings, the film offers a glimpse into the darker side of dental horror, a niche yet intriguing subgenre. 

5/10.

text: I am a big fan of the movie, but not for the usual reasons. I think Travolta and Winger performed at higher than average rates, I think the sets were representative of the location and the era, I liked the sound track and the Charlie Daniels Band. However, I think the photography was amazing! Since the interior scenes were filmed in the actual club and Gilley's had low ceilings--perhaps 10-12 feet high and the smoke that was supposed to simulate a "smoke-filled bar" hung 2-4 feet below the ceiling. The Camera managed to get shots through the smoke and focus on the actors, the bull, the bar, the women, the dancing, the low-level of light that actually was in the bar! What a feat! Sure there was auxiliary lighting, but in order to maintain the atmosphere of the bar, it had to be low-light shots. Ray Villalobos (the camera operator) was outstanding! He got some shots he had no hope of achieving and the impact of them brought a sense of reality to the film. Thanks, Ray--Great work!
rewritten_review: I'm a big fan of the movie, but not for the usual reasons. Travolta and Winger performed exceptionally, the sets captured the location and era, and I loved the soundtrack, especially the Charlie Daniels Band. However, the photography was amazing! Filmed inside the actual club, Gilley's, with its low ceilings and smoke, the camera managed to capture shots through the haze, focusing on the actors, the bull, the bar, the women, and the dancing, all in low light. Ray Villalobos, the camera operator, did outstanding work, achieving shots that enhanced the film's sense of reality. Thanks, Ray—great work!

text:
This movie has many problem associated with it that makes it come off like a low budget class project from someone in film school. I have to give it credit on its campiness though. Many times throughout the movie I found myself laughing hysterically. It was so bad at times that it was comical, which made it a fun watch.

If you're looking for a low-grade slasher movie with a twist of psychological horror and a dash of campy ridiculousness, then pop a bowl of popcorn, invite some friends over, and have some fun.

I agree with other comments that the sound is very bad. Dialog is next to impossible to follow much of the time and the soundtrack is kind of just there.
rewritten_review:
This movie has many problems associated with it that make it come off like a low-budget class project from someone in film school. The production quality, unfortunately, leaves a lot to be desired and doesn't quite reach the level one might expect from a more polished film. However, I have to give it credit for its campiness, which adds a unique flavor to the viewing experience. Many times throughout the movie, I found myself laughing hysterically at the sheer absurdity of certain scenes. It was so bad at times that it was comical, which made it a fun watch despite its many flaws.

The plot meanders in a way that is almost endearing, as it seems to embrace its own ridiculousness. The characters, though not particularly well-developed or nuanced, contribute to the overall charm of the film. Their over-the-top performances add to the hilarity, making it a memorable watch for anyone who appreciates a good dose of campy entertainment. The film doesn't take itself too seriously, which is perhaps one of its saving graces.

If you're looking for a low-grade slasher movie with a twist of psychological horror and a dash of campy ridiculousness, then this might just be the film for you. It's the kind of movie where you can pop a bowl of popcorn, invite some friends over, and have some fun without worrying too much about plot coherence or character development. It's more about the experience of watching something so unapologetically bad that it circles back around to being entertaining.

I agree with other comments that the sound quality is very bad. Dialogue is next to impossible to follow much of the time, which can be frustrating for viewers who are trying to piece together the storyline. The soundtrack is kind of just there, lacking any real impact or memorability. Despite these issues, there's a certain charm in its amateurish execution that contributes to the overall campy vibe. The film manages to turn its shortcomings into an asset by providing a viewing experience that is as ridiculous as it is entertaining.

text:
Chilling, majestic piece of cinematic fright, this film combines all the great elements of an intellectual thriller, with the grand vision of a director who has the instinctual capacity to pace a moody horror flick within the realm of his filmmaking genius that includes an eye for the original shot, an ice-cold soundtrack and an overall sense of dehumanization. This movie cuts through all the typical horror movies like a red-poker through a human eye, as it allows the viewer to not only feel the violence and psychosis of its protagonist, but appreciate the seed from which the derangement stems. One of the scariest things for people to face is the unknown and this film presents its plotting with just that thought in mind. The setting is perfect, in a desolate winter hideaway. The quietness of the moment is a character in itself, as the fermenting aggressor in Jack Torrance's mind wallows in this idle time, and breeds the devil's new playground. I always felt like the presence of evil was dormant in all of our minds, with only the circumstances of the moment, and the reasons given therein, needed to wake its violent ass and pounce over its unsuspecting victims. This film is a perfect example of this very thought.

And it is within this film's subtle touches of the canvas, the clackity-clacks of the young boy's big wheel riding along the empty hallways of the hotel, the labyrinthian garden representing the mind's fine line between sane and insane, Kubrick's purposely transfixed editing inconsistencies, continuity errors and set mis-arrangements, that we discover a world guided by the righteous and tangible, but coaxed away by the powerful and unknown. I have never read the book upon which the film is based, but without that as a comparison point, I am proud to say that this is one of the most terrifying films that I have ever seen. I thought that the runtime of the film could've been cut by a little bit, but then again, I am not one of the most acclaimed directors in the history of film, so maybe I should keep my two-cent criticisms over a superb film, to myself. All in all, this movie captures your attention with its grand form and vision, ropes you in with some terror and eccentric direction, and ties you down and stabs you in the heart with its cold-eyed view of the man's mind gone overboard, creepy atmosphere and the loss of humanity.

Rating: 9/10
rewritten_review:
Chilling and majestic, this cinematic fright combines elements of an intellectual thriller with the grand vision of a director who instinctively paces a moody horror flick. The film features original shots, an ice-cold soundtrack, and a sense of dehumanization. It cuts through typical horror movies like a red-poker through a human eye, allowing viewers to feel the violence and psychosis of its protagonist and appreciate the seed of derangement. The unknown is terrifying, and this film leverages that fear perfectly in a desolate winter hideaway. The quietness becomes a character, as Jack Torrance's mind breeds the devil's new playground. Evil can be dormant in all of us, waiting for the right circumstances to awaken. This film exemplifies that thought.

Subtle touches like the clackity-clacks of a young boy's big wheel, the labyrinthian garden representing the mind's fine line between sane and insane, and Kubrick's editing inconsistencies create a world guided by the tangible but coaxed by the unknown. I haven't read the book it's based on, but without that comparison, I can say this is one of the most terrifying films I've ever seen. I thought the runtime could've been shorter, but I'm not one of the most acclaimed directors, so I'll keep my criticisms to myself. This movie captures attention with its grand form and vision, ropes you in with terror and eccentric direction, and stabs you with its cold-eyed view of a mind gone overboard, creepy atmosphere, and loss of humanity.

Rating: 9/10

text: This is a powerful documentary about domestic abuse in the Cameroon. The "sisters" in law are female lawyers and judges who in 2004 successfully prosecuted husbands for abusive treatment of their spouses and won one woman a divorce she desperately wanted through a Muslim council. It is rather long -- about two hours -- but fascinating in terms both of the individual plaintiffs and defendants and the lawyers who successfully represented them in court rooms presided over by female judges. It will leave you, as it left me, with many questions about exactly how this change occurred. How and when did women come to occupy positions of authority in the Cameroon? Have the several cases featured in this film had a significant effect on the treatment of women generally by their spouses? Was the granting of a divorce by a Muslim court, against the express wishes of the husband, a one time event? I'm not suggesting that the film makers could have answered these questions. They made the movie two years ago, not yesterday. And the movie they made deserves a wide audience.
rewritten_review: This powerful documentary about domestic abuse in Cameroon features female lawyers and judges who successfully prosecuted abusive husbands in 2004 and won a woman a divorce through a Muslim council. It's a fascinating two-hour film that highlights individual plaintiffs and defendants, as well as the lawyers who represented them in courtrooms presided over by female judges. It raises many questions about how women came to occupy positions of authority in Cameroon, the impact of these cases on the treatment of women, and whether the granting of a divorce by a Muslim court against a husband's wishes was a unique event. The filmmakers couldn't have answered these questions as the movie was made two years ago, but it deserves a wide audience.

text:
This Game is a good looking First Person Shooter. -----------Hang on......

But of course a story must be put around this genre, so a quite innovative plot about soldiers now driven by drugs to save the world and kill the terrorist, Nectar is the drug of choice which creates a super soldier.

Great, now just give us some fun, challenging missions, throw in some great new weapons and free terrain vehicles that can be driven at our leisure and I will be quite content.

NO!!!!

The maker's of this game decide to create a propagandish, military driven game, that tries to make sense of our fears of terrorism and embracing democracy. The game has twisted ideals that just re-enforce morals that we learned when we were in primary school, nothing new is told to us, but "Drugs are bad...mmmkay". Then pushed in a type of ....Yvan eht Nnnioooojjjjj! (join the navy) of how standing up for the common good, given rants on normality and abnormality, right and wrong....GOOOOOOOOOOD WE GET IT! LET's KILL SOMETHING!!!!

NO!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

You can't, You are forced to endure extremely long gaps of completing BULLSH!T objectives such as "Run to Helicopter"......."Go to group of Troops" .....Then once this is completed.........CINEMATIC takes over.........You sit there for at least half of the game watching little scenario's played out by the characters, one's you CANNOT skip, but sit and wait, sometimes when people aren't even talking, we sit and wait for a helicopter to land!

Bad game, by a laughable group of programmers! Don't bother making another because I will rather see the movie!

(join the navy) about standing up for the common good, with rants on normality and abnormality, right and wrong. GOOOOOOOOOOOOD WE GET IT! LET's KILL SOMETHING!!!!

NO!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

You can't. You are forced to endure extremely long gaps of completing BULLSH!T objectives such as "Run to Helicopter" and "Go to group of Troops." Then once this is completed, CINEMATIC takes over. text:
I'd give this film a zero if I could. How anyone could rate it any higher is beyond me. Until I saw Rollerball, this was my pick for worst film ever from a major studio with a real budget (claiming Mangler 2 or Leprechaun in the Hood as the worst ever isn't really saying much, those are supposed to be bad)

Tim Curry's mom must have needed surgery or something for him to agree to this non-sensical garbage. I'm really not sure what happened here. The novel was great, the director Frank Marshall had a solid track record with Alive and Arachnophobia (perhaps they should have changed the title to 'Africa'), the cast was good and the budget was there. You'd think someone would have bothered to read the script.

You'd be better off watching Battlefield: Earth again than wasting your time with. Congo makes you long for the return of MST3K
rewritten_review:
I'd give this film a zero if I could. How anyone could rate it any higher is beyond me. Until I saw Rollerball, this was my pick for worst film ever from a major studio with a real budget. Claiming Mangler 2 or Leprechaun in the Hood as the worst ever isn't really saying much, those are supposed to be bad, after all. But Congo? Congo was supposed to be something else entirely. It had all the makings of a great movie but fell spectacularly short in every conceivable way.

Tim Curry's mom must have needed surgery or something for him to agree to this nonsensical garbage. I'm really not sure what happened here, and I find myself baffled the more I think about it. The novel was great, offering a thrilling adventure that kept readers on the edge of their seats. The director, Frank Marshall, had a solid track record with films like Alive and Arachnophobia. Perhaps they should have changed the title to 'Africa' to match the disaster that unfolded on screen. The cast was good, filled with talented actors who have delivered impressive performances in other films. The budget was there, providing the financial backing to transform this story into an epic cinematic experience. Yet, despite all these promising elements, the film turned out to be a complete and utter mess. You'd think someone would have bothered to read the script and realize the catastrophe that was unfolding.

You'd be better off watching Battlefield: Earth again than wasting your time with this. Congo makes you long for the return of MST3K, where at least the agony of watching such a film is softened by the humor and wit of the commentary. It's astonishing how a project with such potential could become such a colossal failure. As I sat through the mind-numbing sequences and incoherent plot, I found myself mourning the loss of what could have been an incredible film. Instead, it stands as a testament to missed opportunities and misguided decisions. This is a film that will linger in the annals of bad cinema, a cautionary tale for filmmakers and viewers alike.

text: Let me start off by saying I love Japanese cinema, literature and culture generally. I've seen many Japanese movies and enjoyed them, but "Portrait of Hell" (aka Jigokuhen) makes itself ridiculous. The two characters who dominate the action -- the "evil lord" in his privileged bubble and the "stubborn, crazy artist" are pure types with zero subtlety or nuance, and all their actions emanate from cartoonish extremes. The film wants to show horrible scenes of violence and raw emotion but many of these scenes are so over the top they actually become laughable and the overall feeling is that of a made-for-TV movie that went off the rails. If this rarely screened movie falls in your hands or comes to your town, spare yourself and give it a pass.
rewritten_review: Let me start off by saying I absolutely love Japanese cinema, literature, and culture generally. I've seen many Japanese movies and thoroughly enjoyed them, but "Portrait of Hell" (also known as Jigokuhen) makes itself utterly ridiculous. The two characters who dominate the action -- the "evil lord" in his privileged bubble and the "stubborn, crazy artist" -- are pure types with zero subtlety or nuance. Both characters are portrayed with such lack of depth and complexity that all their actions emanate from cartoonish extremes. The film aspires to show horrible scenes of violence and raw emotion, yet many of these scenes are executed in such an over-the-top manner that they actually become laughable. The overall feeling conveyed is that of a made-for-TV movie that went completely off the rails. If this rarely screened movie happens to fall into your hands or comes to your town, do yourself a favor and spare yourself the experience by giving it a pass. The lack of nuance in the characters and the exaggerated portrayal of violence and emotion detract significantly from the film's intended impact, making it an experience that is more frustrating than fulfilling. The film's ambition to be a serious portrayal is undermined by its execution, resulting in a product that fails to deliver on its promise. So, if you come across this film, consider directing your attention elsewhere, as there are countless other Japanese films that can offer a more satisfying and enriching experience.

text: I thought it was an excellent movie. Gary Cole played the role of a military man who feels trapped and unhappy with his wife who fakes his death fabulously! Over all, I thought the movie was great, definitely not a boring plot line! It's sad to say, but I think lots of men might feel this way. I think he should have just gotten a divorce and asked to be transferred instead of the extreme he went to, but he felt there was no other way out so he faked his death. I thought it was neat that Cole's real-life wife played the wife he was unhappy with in the movie. I think what the guy did was alittle extreme, but the movie was great nonetheless! Definitely recommend it!
rewritten_review: I thought it was an excellent movie. Gary Cole played the role of a military man who feels trapped and unhappy with his wife who fakes his death fabulously! Over all, I thought the movie was great, definitely not a boring plot line! It's sad to say, but I think lots of men might feel this way. I think he should have just gotten a divorce and asked to be transferred instead of the extreme he went to, but he felt there was no other way out so he faked his death. The movie really captured the essence of feeling stuck in a situation with no apparent escape, and Gary Cole delivered a truly compelling performance. The storyline was engaging and kept me on the edge of my seat from start to finish. I thought it was neat that Cole's real-life wife played the wife he was unhappy with in the movie. It added an interesting layer to the dynamic between the characters and made the interactions even more believable. The director did an amazing job creating tension and suspense throughout the film. The pacing was just right, allowing for moments of reflection alongside the more intense scenes. The supporting cast also contributed to making this film a success, each actor bringing depth and authenticity to their roles. The cinematography was impressive, capturing both the emotional and physical landscapes beautifully. I think what the guy did was a little extreme, but the movie was great nonetheless! Definitely recommend it! The themes explored in this film are thought-provoking and shed light on the complexities of relationships and personal freedom. Overall, it's a movie that leaves a lasting impact and is well worth watching for anyone who appreciates a captivating and well-executed story.

text:
After an undercover mission in Bucharest to disclose an international gang of weapon dealers, the agent Sonni Griffith (Wesley Snipes) is assigned to protect the Romanian Nadia Kaminski (Silvia Colloca), the widow of an accountant of the Romanian Mafia. However, the CIA safe house is broken in by the criminals, and Sonni realizes that the information was leaked from inside the Agency. Alone, trusting only in his friend Michael Shepard (William Hope), Sonni fights to survive and protect Nadia.

The career of Wesley Snipes is downhill. I have just seen this flick, and it is another disappointing movie of this actor, whose career is presently very similar to Steven Segal's one. The movie has many explosions, shots and car chase associated to an awful story and horrible acting. First, the Afro-American Wesley Snipes is chased by the police of Bucharest, but they never find a black American man. I have never been in Romania, but I believe there are not many Afro-Americans in this country. His character does not like to bath, wearing the same clothes along many days. There is no chemistry between Sonni and the sexy Silvia Colloca, but she freely has sex, falls in love for him and shares her fortune with him. The boy that performs Nadia's son is horrible. My vote is four.

Title (Brazil): "O Detonador" ("The Detonator")
rewritten_review:
After an undercover mission in Bucharest to expose an international gang of weapon dealers, agent Sonni Griffith (Wesley Snipes) is tasked with protecting Romanian Nadia Kaminski (Silvia Colloca), widow of a Romanian Mafia accountant. When the CIA safe house is compromised, Sonni realizes the leak is internal. Trusting only his friend Michael Shepard (William Hope), Sonni fights to survive and protect Nadia.

Wesley Snipes' career is declining, similar to Steven Seagal's. This film is disappointing, with many explosions, shots, and car chases linked to a poor story and terrible acting. Snipes, as an Afro-American, is inexplicably never found by Bucharest police. His character oddly wears the same clothes for days. There's no chemistry between Sonni and Silvia Colloca, yet she inexplicably falls for him and shares her fortune. The child actor playing Nadia’s son is terrible. My vote is four.

Title (Brazil): "O Detonador" ("The Detonator")

text:
SPOILERS Every major regime uses the country's media to it's own ends. Whether the Nazi banning of certain leaflets, or the televised Chinese alternative of Tianamen Square, Governments have tried to influence the people through different mediums since the beginning of time. In 1925 though, celebrating the failed mutiny of 1905, the Russian Communist Government supported the creation of this film, Battleship Potempkin. A major piece of cinematic history, it remains powerful and beautiful to this very day.

Set aboard the Battleship Potempkin, the crew are unhappy. In miserable living conditions and with maggot infested food, they are angry at their upper class suppressors. Now though, after the rotten food, enough is enough. Led by Grigory Vakulinchuk (Aleksandr Antonov), the crew turn upon their masters and fight for their freedom.

As far as propaganda goes, "Battleship Potempkin" is perfect. Presenting a positive light on the first, unsuccessful, communist mutiny, the film was a useful Soviet tool. Eighty years after the films release though, and the USSR has disappeared completely off the map. The amazing thing about this film though is that whilst the country it's message was intended for has disappeared, the film remains a powerful and worthy piece of cinema.

Written and directed by Sergei Eisenstein, the film is surprisingly a joy to watch. It is true, that it is far from what we would nowadays consider 'entertainment', but the film is a beautiful piece of art.

Whether it be the scenes aboard the boat or the often talked about scene on the steps of Odessa, everything about this film is perfectly made. The music is powerful and dramatic, the lighting is flawless, even the acting, whilst slightly overdone, is perfect for the piece. Basically, there is no way to fault this film's end product.

It's impossible to know how the Russian people received this film upon it's release. Praising a country which has not existed for fifteen years, it's difficult for us to know the full spirits that the film inspires. As a piece of art though, it is magnificent. Beautiful from start to finish, it is far from an easy watch, but it is well worth the effort.
rewritten_review:
SPOILERS Every major regime uses the country's media for its own ends. From the Nazi banning of certain leaflets to the televised Chinese portrayal of Tiananmen Square, governments have influenced people through various mediums since the beginning of time. In 1925, celebrating the failed mutiny of 1905, the Russian Communist Government supported the creation of the film, Battleship Potemkin. A major piece of cinematic history, it remains powerful and beautiful to this day.

Set aboard the Battleship Potemkin, the crew is unhappy. Living in miserable conditions with maggot-infested food, they are angry at their upper-class suppressors. After the rotten food, enough is enough. Led by Grigory Vakulinchuk (Aleksandr Antonov), the crew turns on their masters and fights for freedom.

As propaganda, "Battleship Potemkin" is perfect. Presenting a positive light on the first, unsuccessful, communist mutiny, the film was a useful Soviet tool. Eighty years after its release, the USSR has disappeared off the map. The amazing thing is that while the country it's meant for has vanished, the film remains a powerful and worthy piece of cinema.

Written and directed by Sergei Eisenstein, the film is surprisingly a joy to watch. It's far from what we'd consider 'entertainment' today, but it's a beautiful piece of art. Whether it's the scenes aboard the boat or the famous Odessa steps scene, everything is perfectly made. The music is powerful, the lighting flawless, and even the slightly overdone acting is perfect for the piece. There is no way to fault this film's end product.

It's impossible to know how the Russian people received this film upon its release. Praising a country that hasn't existed for fifteen years, it's difficult to know the spirits the film inspires. As a piece of art, it is magnificent. Beautiful from start to finish, it's far from an easy watch, but well worth the effort.

text:
I and my brother are very big Asian movie fans, so when finding this movie hidden in a shop, I bought this one on DVD, because it sounded very promising and I couldn't wait to watch it. So I watched this movie with my brother and I must say, in the beginning it was very promising. Both of us really loved this brutal ball scene in the first scene. But i guess that was all. There are some interesting fights, but it is not a action movie, as it claims to be. Instead it's a love movie... with the cliché of love so extremely played over the top, even Shakespeare would vomit on this title. Sorry for my language. By the way: The characters act like being picked up from the street and given 100 for playing in this movie.

Well, I and my brother watched it to the end, because we thought, it can only become better. But, heck, it never did. This movie challenged place #1 on my and my brothers "worst movies ever seen"-list, only followed by "Fantasy mission force" - do not watch this either.
rewritten_review: My brother and I are huge Asian movie fans, so when I found this promising DVD in a shop, I had to buy it. We watched it together and, at first, it seemed promising. We loved the brutal ball scene at the start, but that was about it. There are some interesting fights, but it's not the action movie it claims to be. Instead, it's an over-the-top love story so cliché that even Shakespeare would cringe. Sorry for my language. The characters seem like they were picked off the street and paid 100€ to act. We watched it to the end, hoping it would get better, but it never did. It now challenges for the #1 spot on our "worst movies ever seen" list, only followed by "Fantasy Mission Force"—don't watch that either.

text:
You could say that the actors will make a movie, but this clearly proves that statement wrong. Most of the characters in this film lack anything to hold on to. They play the part of cardboard cut outs being moved about in predictable and uninteresting ways. The story is very simple. It could be summed up in a few words, but I'll hold back in case anyone reading does want to see this film.

I had to fast forward the parts where Jack showed us how to be an obnoxious eater. I'd have to say that 70% of this film revolved around cooking, eating, or getting ready to eat. Quite frankly, I'd rather not spend my time watching Jack chew noisily with an open mouth. Personally, I could have done without the footwear references and jokes that pepper the first half of the film too.

Outside of my own personal dementia, the film really lacked anything worth it's time. There were countless scenes and camera shots that felt like it was dragging. When something happens, the reactions of the characters are vague and dry.

Best not to look this one up.

text: The excruciatingly slow pace of this film was probably the director's express intention, in order to convey what life was like growing up as a village teen in China. However, I found the combination of the glacially slow 'plot' and the general filming style so impersonal as to be totally alienating, particularly to a western audience. At times I actually had trouble telling some characters apart, as they were filmed from such a distance. Two hours in and I was totally past caring. As someone who is not only interested in music but is also very into the history and culture of China (and is by the way no stranger to Chinese cinema), I couldn't engage with a single character and found nothing to get my teeth into. It begs the question: If I disliked it, who on earth would like it? Give me Zhang Yimou, give me Chen Kaige. Give me the work of just about any other Chinese director I've ever seen. This sorry effort just doesn't measure up at all. I'd be sorry to see Chinese cinema judged against this benchmark.
rewritten_review: The slow pace of this film was likely the director's intention to convey life as a village teen in China. However, I found the glacial plot and impersonal filming style alienating, especially for a Western audience. At times, I struggled to tell characters apart due to the distant filming. Two hours in, I was past caring. As someone interested in music and Chinese history and culture, and familiar with Chinese cinema, I couldn't engage with any character. It begs the question: If I disliked it, who would like it? Give me Zhang Yimou or Chen Kaige. This effort doesn't measure up and shouldn't be the benchmark for Chinese cinema.

text:
What a great movie this is. I found it full of the delightfully unexpected pain of being a single father of a teenage girl. And it is set in a tropical island 'paradise'as well.

Gerard Depardeiux brings his special European flair to this story about a divorced father of a teenage girl. They are on holiday together and she begins to add to the excitement on the island in many unexpected ways. But you will need to see the film for yourself to see all the hilarious situations they find for themselves.

There are a few cult classics which all teens should see. This movie should be added to the list. In addition to Dirty Dancing, Ferris Bueller's Day Off, Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure, Rocky Horror Picture Show and Animal House, My Father the Hero should be required film study. Watch it as if you had a teenage daughter and you'll be rolling with laughter. Watch it with your teenage daughter and prepare to be laughed at for months.
rewritten_review:
What a great movie this is. I found it full of the delightfully unexpected pain of being a single father of a teenage girl. And it is set in a tropical island 'paradise' as well. This film truly captures the essence of unexpected adventures and the unique challenges that come with being a single parent. It's not just a movie; it's an experience that resonates with anyone who has ever navigated the complexities of parenting, especially when dealing with a teenager. The setting of a tropical island adds a layer of beauty and intrigue to the storyline, creating a juxtaposition between the idyllic surroundings and the tumultuous father-daughter relationship.

Gerard Depardeiux brings his special European flair to this story about a divorced father of a teenage girl. His performance is both heartfelt and humorous, showcasing his ability to balance comedy and emotion seamlessly. They are on holiday together and she begins to add to the excitement on the island in many unexpected ways. Her antics and rebellious spirit lead to a series of comedic escapades that make the film a joy to watch. The chemistry between the father and daughter is palpable, and their interactions are both touching and entertaining. But you will need to see the film for yourself to see all the hilarious situations they find for themselves.

There are a few cult classics which all teens should see. This movie should be added to the list. It stands out not only for its humor but also for its insightful portrayal of the father-daughter dynamic. In addition to Dirty Dancing, Ferris Bueller's Day Off, Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure, Rocky Horror Picture Show and Animal House, My Father the Hero should be required film study. These films have defined generations, and My Father the Hero deserves a place among them for its unique blend of comedy and heart. Watch it as if you had a teenage daughter and you'll be rolling with laughter. The relatability of the situations depicted in the film will resonate with parents and teenagers alike, making it a perfect choice for family movie nights. Watch it with your teenage daughter and prepare to be laughed at for months. This shared experience will undoubtedly lead to inside jokes and fond memories that you'll cherish for years to come.

text:
I watched this because I thought there were going to be a lot of car chases and cool cars to gawk at. Guess I was lied to. This movie is very boring.

The movie starts out Kip Raines(Giovanni Ribisi) sitting outside a Porsche dealership checking to see if they have the right car. When they confirm it's the right one, Kip gets a brick out of the trunk and chucks it at the window, shattering it. He gets the Porsche while his friend gets the keys. They start up the car and take off into the night. They deliver it to a warehouse only to have been followed by the police. So, the whole crew ditches all the cars and go their separate ways. Then, we get a glimpse of Memphis Raines. He is giving a little speech to a bunch of kids at a go-kart track. Then, he is confronted by Atlee Jackson(Will Patton). Atlee tells Memphis that his brother Kip is in deep *bleep*. Memphis is known as one of the most notorious car thieves in Los Angeles. Memphis heads to a junkyard and meets Raymond Calitri(Christopher Ecclesten). This guy threatens to kill Kip if Memphis doesn't deliver 50 cars within 72 hours.

There are a few problems with this film:

1.Story: The first 48 in-movie hours take place when Cage and Duvall are looking for a crew and planning everything out. The last 12 in-movie hours are a waste!

2. The Cars: You see maybe 10 cars out of the 50 as the movie advertises. So, where are the other 40 cars? Why don't we get to see them?

3. The Chase: The chase at the end of the movie was a joke. It was not suspenseful at all.

4. The Dog: Somewhere in the movie, the dog eats the burgers and swallows three keys as well. This is impossible. The keys were flipped open. The keys would have severely damaged the dog's esophagus, stomach, and large intestines. The guys suggest giving the dog laxatives to help him poop it out. This won't work. The dog will get a lot of diarrhea but no keys. It was stated in Jackass after Ryan Dunne stuck a toy car up his rectum. Take laxatives, lots of diarrhea, but no car. Same case with the dog.

5. The Cop During The Chase: When Eleanor breaks down for a few minutes, Nicholas Cage tries desperately to start up the car. You see a police cruiser behind him who isn't looking at his car at all. But, right when Nicholas Cage starts the engine up again, the police officer jerks his head to the right, sees the car, and immediately begins to chase after him. It is stupid. So, right when he heard the engine start, and saw the car, he knew that was the car he was looking for. How does he know it's the right car? He only sees the back of it.

Overall, the movie is boring. There is no action. There are very few cars. The movie is stupid. I have never seen the original but I plan to.

I give this movie 1 star out of 10. Get The Fast and Furious instead.
rewritten_review:
I watched this because I thought there were going to be a lot of car chases and cool cars to gawk at. Guess I was lied to. This movie is very boring.

The movie starts with Kip Raines (Giovanni Ribisi) outside a Porsche dealership. He confirms it's the right car, throws a brick to shatter the window, and steals it. They deliver it to a warehouse but are followed by the police, so they ditch the cars. We meet Memphis Raines, a notorious car thief, who is told by Atlee Jackson (Will Patton) that his brother Kip is in trouble. Raymond Calitri (Christopher Eccleston) threatens to kill Kip if Memphis doesn't deliver 50 cars in 72 hours.

Problems with the film:

1. Story: The first 48 in-movie hours are spent planning, and the last 12 hours are wasted.

2. The Cars: You see maybe 10 out of the 50 cars. Where are the other 40?

3. The Chase: The final chase was not suspenseful at all.

4. The Dog: The dog swallows three keys, which is impossible without severe damage. Laxatives would cause diarrhea but not expel the keys.

5. The Cop During The Chase: A police officer only notices the car when the engine starts, which is unrealistic.

Overall, the movie is boring with little action and few cars. I give it 1 star out of 10. Get The Fast and Furious instead.

text: Normally I wouldn't go to the trouble of commenting on a horror movie sequel, because it's usually assumed that they're BAD, and if you watch them with a healthy disrespect, they can be very fun and enjoyable to taunt/laugh at. However, this chapter of the ongoing Halloween saga came close to gumbing up everything the original stood for. In the very first movie, Dr. Loomis said (very pointedly I might add), that Michael Myers was evil, and this tries to explain why (doing a bad job of it I might add). In my opinion, he was much scarier when he was just a blood hungry freak. The whole goth/cult thing was unnecessary and a desperate attempt to throw a new curve into the Halloween equation. The result was a boring, predictable movie that was not scary and not bad enough to be funny.
rewritten_review: Normally, I wouldn't go to the trouble of commenting on a horror movie sequel, because it's usually assumed that they're BAD, and if you watch them with a healthy disrespect, they can be very fun and enjoyable to taunt and laugh at. However, this chapter of the ongoing Halloween saga came remarkably close to gumbing up everything the original stood for, which is quite the feat considering the legacy of the series. In the very first movie, Dr. Loomis said (very pointedly I might add), that Michael Myers was evil, and this sequel tries to explain why, doing a bad job of it, I might add. In my opinion, he was much scarier when he was just a blood-hungry freak. The whole goth/cult thing was completely unnecessary and a desperate attempt to throw a new curve into the Halloween equation. This was a move that ultimately did not pay off and instead left audiences with a convoluted mess. The result was a boring, predictable movie that was not scary and not bad enough to be funny. The film lacked the tension and terror that made the original a classic, and instead, it offered a confusing narrative that did little to enhance the mythos of Michael Myers. It's a shame because there was potential to build on the chilling simplicity of the original, but instead, we got a mishmash of tired tropes and uninspired storytelling. Overall, it was a disappointing addition to the franchise that failed to capture the essence of what made Halloween a staple in the horror genre.

text: this film takes you inside itself in the early minutes and holds you till the end. it has a very humane story and very good selected music. The acting of Moritz Bleibtreu (Giancarlo Amato) and Barnaby Metschurat (Gigi Amato) is satisfying. Recommended to people who get bored of action films and want to see a good movie.
rewritten_review: This film has an incredible ability to draw you inside its world within the early minutes, captivating your attention and holding it firmly until the very end. It presents a deeply humane story that resonates on various levels, allowing viewers to connect with its characters and narrative in meaningful ways. The film is further enhanced by its very well-selected music, which complements the storyline beautifully and adds depth to the viewing experience. The acting performances by Moritz Bleibtreu, who plays Giancarlo Amato, and Barnaby Metschurat, who takes on the role of Gigi Amato, are truly satisfying and contribute significantly to the film’s overall impact. Their portrayals bring authenticity and depth to their characters, making the story even more engaging. This film comes highly recommended, especially for those who find themselves growing weary of the constant barrage of action films and are in search of a good movie that offers something different. It provides a refreshing alternative with its compelling narrative and strong performances, making it a worthwhile choice for anyone looking to enjoy a quality cinematic experience.

text:
Rebar is an astronaut who goes on the world's first space mission to Saturn, but of course this being a horror movie things turn ugly and he returns to earth as the only survivor. Stricken with some bizarre condition that causes him to slowly melt and lose his mind unless he regularly consumes human flesh, he kills what apparently is the only nurse in the hospital and escapes to the neighboring town to stalk more victims.

I liked the premise and the monster and gore effects are actually pretty good, but the space scenes are just pasted together out of stock NASA footage and the hospital looks curiously like a warehouse. A very weak script, little character development and overall poor acting keep this one from rising above being anything other than a mediocre slasher flick with the novelty of having a living candle as the killer, and more or less only has its gore effects to hold your interest.

4 out of 10, strictly for the most die-hard monster movie fans.
rewritten_review: Rebar, an astronaut on the first mission to Saturn, returns to Earth as the sole survivor, afflicted by a condition that causes him to melt and crave human flesh. After killing a nurse, he escapes to a nearby town to find more victims. While the monster and gore effects are impressive, the film suffers from stock NASA footage for space scenes and a hospital resembling a warehouse. The weak script, lack of character development, and poor acting make it a mediocre slasher flick. Its only appeal lies in the novelty of its melting killer and gore effects. Strictly for die-hard monster movie fans. 4 out of 10.

text:
I went to see this film because it was recommended to my wife and she wanted to go.

We were both trying to look at our watches well before the film ended, in order to see how much more we had to endure. Two hours and six minutes long, it is. It's divided roughly equally between battle scenes (about a dozen of them, all more or less interchangeable), and plot development.

One would have thought that with the subject being the son of a minor tribal chief who conquers half the world, plotting would have been relatively easy. There's a fair bit of raw material there from which to make a pretty good story. However the writers fluffed it completely. We get no real history. We get instead a Hollywood version of history.

What sustains young Temudjin through his long -- almost endless, actually, or so they seem to the viewer -- tribulations? Why, the love of a good woman, of course.

How does he get out of prison? Well, an old monk, who recognizes his innate goodness and greatness, sets out across the continent to take to this good woman a talisman that symbolises Temudjin's love for her, dropping dead just close enough to her for her to find him as he lies there, talisman in his hand. And of course she then goes and, having (inexplicably) become rich and powerful, rescues him.

How does he escape from the shackles? Well, he goes off to the shrine of the great wolf-god Tengri (or some such name) and Tengri sets him free by magic. Yeah, right.

Why does he want to become ruler of the Mongols? The wolf-god again, apparently. Off goes Temudjin to ask for guidance, and -- surprise! surprise! -- he gets it. "Laws," he says to himself. "What the Mongols need are laws. Good, simple ones." Golly, it was impressive.

And then finally, how does he win the decisive battle against his rival's more powerful forces? Better tactics, certainly, but also through the aid of the good old wolf-god again, who sends a storm at the height of the battle. All the troops cower as the thunder rolls and the lightning flashes (Mongols are scared of thunder, you see) -- but not our Temudjin. The troops, completely wowed by his bravery, acclaim him king!

I don't know what induces people to keep producing this kind of garbage. The funny thing is it's interspersed with all sorts of gritty realism: lots of slurping of milk, dirt and violence. It's as if the producers of this movie wanted to get the trivial things right so that viewers wouldn't notice how infantile some of the big stuff is.

There's heaps of violence in graphic close-up: slashings, impalings, spouts of blood, sprays of blood, clouds of blood -- the blood guys had a great time, actually. Despite the realism, it's impossible to take seriously.

I must mention the ludicrous CGI final battle scene. How anyone can think these things look realistic is beyond me. They don't. Oh, and it's all shot in the standard Hollywood style -- breathtaking panoramas for the spectacular scenery, and the super-close-up Stedicam stuff for the battle scenes. And the standard Dolby super-sound-effects of whumps and thumps and the constant low-frequency hum to sustain tension.

Tedious.

Avoid.
