Life is full of uncertainties and ambiguities, and the film captured that essence beautifully. Overall, the film was a thought-provoking experience that left a lasting impression on me, and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a movie that challenges conventional storytelling.

text: FREDDY FORSYTH has come up with a storyline which will suit the mood of the West's suspicions about Putin's Russia. Forsyth installs a nasty guy as the Ruski president who wants to return the country - not so much to Stalin's Communism but more to Hitlerian Fascism. In fact, his Political Manifesto could have come straight out of Mein Kampf rather than Marx. And, the loon has the latest weapons of biological destruction to achieve the ethnic cleansing pogrom of the Russian Federation. American mercenaries connive with the Russian Prez to realise his fanatical, genocidal dream, but then enter Dirty Dancing's Pat Swayze...and,yep,things get really down and dirty. He's a former US operative-turned-drifter,Jason Monk, who is enlisted by the British Government to see what the Russians are up to. As a corny sidebar, Swayze's character who is no Monk (!)has sired a Russian beauty Elena (played by the gorgeous Marta Kondova) on his previous missions to the former Commie state. Hardman Swayze does a passable job in setting out to defeat the evil Russians. But young unknown actress Marta Kondova steals the flick as his nubile, 18-year-old Russian daughter Elena who helps dad root out the terror threatening her beloved Mother Russia.
rewritten_review: FREDDY FORSYTH has crafted a storyline fitting the West's suspicions about Putin's Russia. Forsyth introduces a villainous Russian president aiming to revert the country not to Stalin's Communism but to Hitlerian Fascism. His manifesto echoes Mein Kampf more than Marx, and he wields the latest biological weapons for an ethnic cleansing pogrom in the Russian Federation. American mercenaries conspire with the Russian leader to fulfill his genocidal dream, but then Dirty Dancing's Pat Swayze enters. He's Jason Monk, a former US operative-turned-drifter, enlisted by the British Government to investigate the Russians. As a corny sidebar, Swayze's character, far from a monk, has a Russian beauty, Elena (played by Marta Kondova), from past missions. Swayze capably battles the evil Russians, but young actress Marta Kondova shines as his 18-year-old daughter Elena, aiding her father in defeating the threat to Mother Russia.

text: As long as you can suffer it! If you like watching people waking up, getting up, getting dressed, having a shower, preparing dinner, watching each other, having sex in the dark, then going back to bed to sleep... if you like tacky flats, narrow bedrooms and kitchens, long minutes of silence.... if you like getting bored for two hours, feeling the thrill of "real intimate false art", then you will like it. But if you don't, just try to see a good movie, there are thousands. "As long as you are here", but do we want to stay? This German movie got the award of the Torino gay film festival: Italian journalists still don't understand why the jury took such a bad decision, as the festival presented lot of talented movies. Maybe to be nice with a German, as they don't often get awards? Well, "The Lives of Others" did... but this one is excellent but not gay. So maybe it is a question of fashion. Germans are they "in" again? No matter what? Or maybe only for a hustler's glance of some directors?
rewritten_review: If you enjoy watching people wake up, get dressed, shower, cook, watch each other, have sex, and sleep; if you like tacky flats, narrow spaces, long silences, and "real intimate false art," then you'll enjoy this. Otherwise, opt for a good movie—there are thousands. "As long as you are here," but do we want to be? This German film won at the Torino gay film festival, baffling Italian journalists who saw more talented films. Was it to appease Germans, who rarely win awards? "The Lives of Others" did win, but it's excellent, not gay. Is it a fashion trend? Are Germans "in" again? Or just a nod to some directors' preferences?

text:
Robert A. Heinlein's classic novel Starship Troopers has been messed around with in recent years, in everything to Paul Verhoeven's 1997 film to a TV series, to a number of games. But none of these, so to speak, has really captured the spirit of his novel. The games are usually unrelated, the TV series was more of a spin off, and the less said about Verhoeven's film, the better. Little do most know, however, that in Japan, an animated adaptation had already been done, released the year of Heinlein's death. And, believe it or not, despite its differences, this 6-part animated series is, plot-wise, the most faithful adaptation of Heinlein's classic.

The most obvious plus to this series is the presence of the powered armor exoskeletons, something we were deprived of in Verhoeven's film. Like the book, the series focuses more on the characters and their relationships than on action and space travel, though we see a fair amount of each. While events happen differently than in the book, the feel of the book's plot is present. Rico and Carmen have a romantic entanglement, but it's only slightly more touched upon than in the book. While some may believe the dialogue and character interaction to be a bit inferior to the book (it gets a bit of the anime treatment, but what did you expect?), but it's far superior to the film. Heinlein's political views are merely excised, as opposed to the film, where they are reversed. The big payoff of the series, however, is the climatic battle on Klendathu between the troopers and the bugs/aliens, which features the kind of action from the powered armor suits we would have like to have seen in a film version.

Overall, I enjoyed this series because I wanted to see a vision closer to that of Heinlein. And I think they did pretty well with this. If you can find this series, give it a look.
rewritten_review: Robert A. Heinlein's Starship Troopers has seen various adaptations, from Paul Verhoeven's 1997 film to a TV series and games, but none have truly captured the spirit of the novel. However, in Japan, a 6-part animated series was released the year of Heinlein's death, and despite some differences, it stands as the most faithful adaptation plot-wise. The series includes the powered armor exoskeletons missing from Verhoeven's film and focuses more on character relationships than on action, similar to the book. While events differ, the feel of the book's plot is preserved. Rico and Carmen's romantic entanglement is slightly more emphasized than in the book. Although the dialogue gets an anime treatment, it is superior to the film, and Heinlein's political views are excised rather than reversed as in the film. The climactic battle on Klendathu with powered armor suits provides the action fans would have liked in a film version. Overall, this series offers a vision closer to Heinlein's and is worth a look if you can find it.

text: This is a great idea for a film but it, unfortunately, doesn't turn out to be a great movie. What starts out as a sweet and almost goofy romantic comedy about a Fluffer in love with his Fluffee spirals out of control into a bizarre combination of genres and a veritable stew of plots, with liberal borrowings from BOOGIE NIGHTS, THELMA AND LOUISE, SHOWGIRLS, FRISK, and even a curious "dash" of 400 BLOWS thrown in towards the end. (At least the director did his research!) The result is not necessarily boring but, in the end, this slick, well-produced flick doesn't quite add up to anything. However, the actors all do a game job with the material and there are a few good laughs at the behind-the-scenes world of gay porn.
rewritten_review: This is a great idea for a film but it, unfortunately, doesn't turn out to be a great movie. What starts out as a sweet and almost goofy romantic comedy about a Fluffer in love with his Fluffee spirals out of control into a bizarre combination of genres and a veritable stew of plots, with liberal borrowings from BOOGIE NIGHTS, THELMA AND LOUISE, SHOWGIRLS, FRISK, and even a curious "dash" of 400 BLOWS thrown in towards the end. (At least the director did his research!) The result is not necessarily boring but, in the end, this slick, well-produced flick doesn't quite add up to anything. However, the actors all do a game job with the material and there are a few good laughs at the behind-the-scenes world of gay porn. As you watch the film unfold, you can't help but notice how the initial premise, which is genuinely promising and intriguing, gradually becomes entangled in its own ambition to blend multiple genres and narrative threads. The director seems to have a fondness for certain cinematic influences, as evidenced by the nods to iconic films such as BOOGIE NIGHTS, THELMA AND LOUISE, SHOWGIRLS, FRISK, and even an unexpected touch of 400 BLOWS. It's as if the film attempts to pay homage to these classics while carving out its own unique space, but in doing so, it loses the coherence and charm it initially possessed. Despite its shortcomings, the film does manage to hold the viewer's attention, primarily due to the dedication and talent of the cast. The actors throw themselves into their roles with admirable gusto, bringing a sense of authenticity and energy to the screen that elevates the material. Their performances inject life into the film, providing a few genuinely funny moments that offer a glimpse into the often chaotic and humorous world of gay porn production. While the movie may not succeed in delivering a cohesive and satisfying story, it does offer an entertaining peek behind the curtains of an industry that is rarely explored with such candor and humor. Ultimately, while the film may not achieve greatness, it remains an interesting watch, if only for the curiosity it stirs and the commendable efforts of its cast. The journey from a quirky romantic comedy to a complex, genre-blending narrative might leave some viewers puzzled, but it also sparks conversations about the risks and rewards of ambitious storytelling in cinema.

text: Writer/Director/Co-Star Adam Jones is headed for great things. That is the thought I had after seeing his feature film "Cross Eyed". Rarely does an independent film leave me feeling as good as his did. Cleverly written and masterfully directed, "Cross Eyed" keeps you involved from beginning to end. Adam Jones may not be a well known name yet, but he will be. If this movie had one or two "Named Actors" it would be a Box Office sensation. I think it still has a chance to get seen by a main stream audience if just one film distributor takes the time to work this movie. Regardless of where it ends up, if you get a chance to see it you won't be disappointed.
rewritten_review: Writer/Director/Co-Star Adam Jones is undoubtedly headed for great things. That is the thought I had after seeing his feature film "Cross Eyed." Rarely does an independent film leave me feeling as good as his did, but this one certainly did. Cleverly written and masterfully directed, "Cross Eyed" keeps you involved from beginning to end, capturing your attention and holding it tightly throughout the entire experience. Adam Jones may not be a well-known name yet, but mark my words, he will be. His talent and vision are undeniable. If this movie had one or two "Named Actors," it would undoubtedly be a Box Office sensation, drawing crowds from all over. I think it still has a chance to get seen by a mainstream audience if just one film distributor takes the time to work on this movie. Regardless of where it ends up, if you get a chance to see it, you won't be disappointed. The film has a unique charm and appeal that is hard to come by, and it showcases the immense potential and creativity of its creator, Adam Jones. Keep an eye out for this film, as it is a true gem in the world of independent cinema, and don't miss the opportunity to witness the beginning of what promises to be a remarkable journey for Adam Jones in the film industry.

text: I don't think the world was ready for this film. I know I wasn't. I'd been expected a standard low-budget schlock exploitation potboiler. Instead, I got the most intelligent reworking of Shakespeare since Peter Greenaway's "Prospero's Books". This should become the definitive film version of Romeo And Juliet. It won't of course. But that's the world's loss.
rewritten_review: I don't think the world was ready for this film. I know I wasn't. I had gone into it expecting a standard low-budget schlock exploitation potboiler, something that would entertain on a surface level but not much more. Instead, I got the most intelligent reworking of Shakespeare since Peter Greenaway's "Prospero's Books". The depth and artistry of this film took me completely by surprise, challenging my preconceived notions of what a reimagined Shakespearean adaptation could be. This should become the definitive film version of Romeo And Juliet, setting a new standard for how classic literature can be interpreted on screen. It offers a profound exploration of the themes and emotions that Shakespeare originally conveyed, yet it does so with a modern sensibility that resonates deeply with contemporary audiences. It won't of course, which is a shame, because the film deserves to be recognized for its brilliance and audacity. But that's the world's loss. The world may not be ready to embrace such a groundbreaking work, but for those who are, it offers an unforgettable cinematic experience.

text:
"Clubbed" is yet another 'will-this-do?' entry into the Brit fisticuffs genre and is sure to keep punters who aren't expecting too much moderately entertained for ninety minutes after a few beers. However, for anyone seeking intelligent, quality entertainment it's really best avoided.

There are so many misnomers in the appalling script that even an actor of the calibre of Colin Salmon is left looking daft. The action is set in the 1980s, but it's never clear why, especially when they haven't been able to pull off any convincing feel for that decade - it takes more than a few 80s soul records on the soundtrack, the occasional zoot suit and a handful of 30-year-old cars. Then we see central characters studying texts such as Sun Tzu's "The Art Of War" and speaking about how violence should be a last resort, while the same characters seem only too willing to start doling out punches with all the testosterone-fuelled, unthinking abandon of a bunch of chavs fighting over a bag of chips.

Character development does not exist in "Clubbed". Nor does irony, subtlety or pathos. This is a film which trades on fond memories of Guy Richie's early gangster films, which despite their flaws certainly had much more wit, better editing, snappier dialogue and packed more emotional punch than this limp little saga. They're a decade old now, anyway - isn't it time we moved on from trying to emulate them?
rewritten_review: "Clubbed" is another 'will-this-do?' entry into the Brit fisticuffs genre, keeping punters who aren't expecting much moderately entertained for ninety minutes after a few beers. For anyone seeking intelligent, quality entertainment, it's best avoided. There are so many misnomers in the appalling script that even an actor like Colin Salmon looks daft. The action is set in the 1980s, but it's unclear why, as they fail to convincingly capture that decade—it takes more than a few 80s soul records, occasional zoot suits, and 30-year-old cars. Characters study texts like Sun Tzu's "The Art Of War," discussing how violence should be a last resort, yet they eagerly start fights like chavs over chips. Character development is nonexistent in "Clubbed." So are irony, subtlety, and pathos. The film trades on fond memories of Guy Richie's early gangster films, which, despite flaws, had more wit, better editing, snappier dialogue, and more emotional punch than this limp saga. They're a decade old now—it's time to move on from emulating them.

text: This is just a bad movie. With what seemed to be quite a nice budget it had potential to be much better. It almost were. With the heroine beautiful almost like Salma Hayek, hero fighting almost like Jackie Chan, battles and duels almost like in Crouching Tiger..., music almost like in, say, Conan... etc. Almost. But in the end it's just dull and it is hard to find anything interesting in it. Maybe apart of John Rhys-Davies flying in duel like those warriors in Hero or before-mentioned Crouching Tiger... I am really ashamed of poor old John. He is after all quite a good actor and deserves much better. So as you - so if you still have a chance just watch something else.
rewritten_review:
This is just a bad movie. With what seemed to be quite a nice budget, it had the potential to be much better. It almost were. With the heroine beautiful almost like Salma Hayek, hero fighting almost like Jackie Chan, battles and duels almost like in Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon..., music almost like in, say, Conan the Barbarian... etc. Almost. But in the end, it's just dull, and it is hard to find anything interesting in it. Maybe apart from John Rhys-Davies flying in a duel like those warriors in Hero or the before-mentioned Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon... I am really ashamed of poor old John. He is, after all, quite a good actor and deserves much better. So do you—so if you still have a chance, just watch something else. 

The movie seems to have been put together with a lot of ambition but failed to deliver on almost every front. The production values hinted at something that could have been memorable, yet the execution left much to be desired. The storyline failed to engage, and the characters never truly came to life. The heroine, while strikingly beautiful and reminiscent of Salma Hayek, lacked depth and dimension. Similarly, the hero's fighting skills, which aspired to be on par with Jackie Chan's legendary prowess, fell short, leaving action sequences that were uninspired and lackluster. 

The battles and duels, which could have been the film's saving grace, ended up being mere shadows of what they could have been, almost like the breathtaking scenes in Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon but without the same impact or artistry. Even the music, which aimed to evoke the epic scores of films like Conan the Barbarian, failed to elevate the film, leaving it without the emotional resonance and power it so desperately needed. 

John Rhys-Davies, a seasoned and talented actor, seemed out of place in this production. Watching him participate in a duel, reminiscent of the gravity-defying battles in Hero or the aforementioned Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, was a curious sight. It was a moment that could have been iconic, yet it ultimately felt misplaced and unconvincing. It is disheartening to see an actor of his caliber in such a role, and one can't help but feel a sense of regret for his involvement in this project. He deserves scripts and roles that truly highlight his abilities, not ones that leave him floundering in an uninspired film. 

In conclusion, this movie is not worth your time. Despite the initial promise suggested by its budget and the potential glimpses of greatness, it ultimately fails to deliver anything of substance. If you still have a chance, save yourself the disappointment and choose to watch something else that will truly capture your interest and imagination.

text:
It's the 1980's and the teenagers are ready to party it up in a scary old house that is rumored to be haunted by the ghost of Murder McGee. After mistakenly conjuring the dead through an unfinished conversation on an Ouija board, the kids are forced to fight to the death battling a vengeful ghost who possesses and kills all of their friends one by one. Sound familiar? It's supposed to. It's clearly marketed to pay homage to the classic 80's slashers with the tagline: "Excessive violence. Gratuitous nudity. Zero budget."

Can't get enough; It's pure entertainment! I enjoyed the humor and the way it poked fun at all the horror cliché's, but at the same time embraced what was fun about movies from this time. There is something you get with this movie you never got with the old 80's slasher films though: good acting. The entire cast was very talented and you don't see that very much in any low budget flicks, recent or otherwise. There was a lot of chemistry between the characters. I was very entertained throughout the entire film, and I am fully convinced the writer/director and cast will go a long way in their separate careers. The script was very well written, and the dialogue flowed naturally.

The effects were a bit amateur and the scenes were not lit well, but the fact that this movie admits on its cover there was practically NO BUDGET, I already know this going in. This film makes it simple to politely ignore its faults and just sit back and enjoy. Although this is not an Oscar award winning opus, it never claims to be, and props to that. It's a lot of fun. If you like slashers, you'll really appreciate this film. If you like blood and boobies, you'll appreciate it also.
rewritten_review:
It's the 1980's, and teenagers are ready to party in a haunted house rumored to be home to Murder McGee's ghost. After a mishap with an Ouija board, they must fight a vengeful spirit that possesses and kills their friends. This film pays homage to classic 80's slashers with its tagline: "Excessive violence. Gratuitous nudity. Zero budget." 

I couldn't get enough; it's pure entertainment! I loved the humor and how it poked fun at horror clichés while embracing the fun of 80's movies. Unlike old slashers, this film offers good acting. The talented cast had great chemistry, and the writer/director shows promise. The script was well-written with natural dialogue.

The effects were amateur and poorly lit, but the film admits its low budget upfront. It invites you to ignore its faults and just enjoy it. Not an Oscar contender, but it never pretends to be. It's a lot of fun. If you like slashers, blood, and nudity, you'll appreciate this film.

text:
In this horrible attempt at a Blair Witch mockumentary, a bunch of people go to Africa to investigate a creature called the Half-Caste. It's pretty obvious that there was no script to speak of, and that everything was improvised. That can work if you have good actors, which this film didn't.

This movie tries to gain points for originality by exploring a more obscure myth and an exotic culture. As a result, there are a lot of scenes out in the bush where characters do "quirky African stuff" like eating elephant dung. There is also some pretty good footage of lions eating (from a National Geographic perspective) but there's not a single scare in the whole movie.

If you've seen Cannibal Holocaust or the Blair Witch Project, this movie will hold no surprises for you, and you can probably watch better lion footage on the Discovery Channel.

Definitely a Half- Aste effort.

A note to the filmmakers: guys, do us all a favor and next time save the "How I spent my African Vacation" home movie for your family and close friends. Nobody else wants to see it.
rewritten_review: In this failed Blair Witch mockumentary, a group travels to Africa to investigate the Half-Caste creature. It's clear there was no script, relying on poor improvisation. This can work with skilled actors, which this film lacks. It tries to be original by exploring an obscure myth and culture, resulting in bush scenes with "quirky African stuff" like eating elephant dung. There is decent lion footage (from a National Geographic view), but not a single scare. If you've seen Cannibal Holocaust or Blair Witch Project, this movie offers no surprises, and better lion footage exists on Discovery Channel. A definite Half-Aste effort. A note to the filmmakers: save the "How I spent my African Vacation" home movie for family and friends. No one else wants to see it.

text:
Food always makes a good topic in movies, as "Chocolat" showed. "Babette's Feast" is the same type of thing. Babette Harsant (Stephane Audran) is a French cook who flees her native land after the repression of 1871. She moves to a very religious Danish village. The people in this village simply have no use for joy. That is, until Babette cooks them one of her exquisite meals.

It's not just that this movie deals with bringing fun to a place that has never known it. Like other Scandinavian movies (and non-Hollywood movies in general), it shows that a movie can hold your interest without the use of explosions, car chases, etc. This is one movie that you can't afford to miss.

One more thing. Do you think that the Danish word for "feast" sounds a little bit like "tastebud"?
rewritten_review:
Food always makes a good topic in movies, as "Chocolat" showed. "Babette's Feast" is the same type of thing. Babette Harsant (Stephane Audran) is a French cook who flees her native land after the repression of 1871. She moves to a very religious Danish village. The people in this village simply have no use for joy. That is, until Babette cooks them one of her exquisite meals. As she begins to prepare this extraordinary feast, the villagers are both intrigued and apprehensive, unsure of what to expect from such an extravagant event in their simple lives. The anticipation builds as the aromas fill the air, and the once somber community starts to feel a sense of curiosity and excitement that they haven't experienced before. Through Babette's culinary skills and her passionate approach to cooking, she gradually breaks down the barriers and brings a new sense of joy and appreciation for life to these people who have long forgotten the pleasures that a good meal can bring. The feast becomes a turning point for the villagers, rekindling forgotten emotions and allowing them to connect with each other in ways they hadn't imagined.

It's not just that this movie deals with bringing fun to a place that has never known it. Like other Scandinavian movies (and non-Hollywood movies in general), it shows that a movie can hold your interest without the use of explosions, car chases, etc. The film's beautiful cinematography and the subtle yet powerful performances of the actors draw you into this world, making you feel like a part of the village, experiencing the transformation alongside the characters. The story unfolds at a gentle pace, allowing you to savor every moment, much like Babette's guests savor each exquisite dish she serves. This is one movie that you can't afford to miss, as it offers a unique and enriching experience that stays with you long after the credits roll. The themes of generosity, sacrifice, and the power of art to touch lives are explored with depth and sensitivity, leaving a lasting impression on the viewer. The film's ability to convey such profound messages without relying on high-octane action sequences or flashy special effects is a testament to the strength of its storytelling and the talent of its creators.

One more thing. Do you think that the Danish word for "feast" sounds a little bit like "tastebud"? The connection is quite fitting, given the film's emphasis on the sensory pleasures of food and the way it can awaken the senses and stir the soul. The feast, in this context, becomes more than just a meal; it is a celebration of life, of community, and of the simple joys that come from sharing good food with others. This delightful linguistic coincidence adds another layer of charm to the film, inviting viewers to reflect on the universal language of taste and the bonds it can create across cultures and experiences.

text:
I have not read the novel from which the film is based on. So I cannot comment on what is missing or if there were changes made.

As I stated above, I had a wonderful experience watching THE KITE RUNNER.. I find that when I see films about other cultures than ours here in the USA,I learn how other peoples live & exist.

The actors in this movie are from Afghanistan & other countries in that area. There are 3 young children in this near epic movie in there first roles, They were marvelous.

The scenes that was supposedly in Kabul were shot in various parts of China, I assume that the area is similar to the actual places in the book.

Mark Foster directed & he did FINDING NEVRRLAND, he has created the same magic here.

All aspects of production are first rate.

I found this a better movie than those nominated & won Oscars.

The film is sub-titled , it is very clear to read. It has a proper PG-13 rating. SPOILER ALERT--- The child rape scene is very well handled.

I cannot however give this a 4 star rating as the general plot & story line we have seen many, many times, Non-the-less this is a very worthwhile movie to watch..

Ratings: ***1/2 (out of 4) 95 points (out of 100) IMDb 9 (out of 10)
rewritten_review:
I had a wonderful experience watching THE KITE RUNNER. Films about other cultures offer insight into how others live and exist. The actors, including three marvelous children in their first roles, are from Afghanistan and nearby regions. Scenes set in Kabul were shot in China, which I assume resembles the book's locations. Directed by Mark Foster, who also did FINDING NEVERLAND, the film captures similar magic. All production aspects are first-rate. I found it better than some Oscar-nominated films. The film is subtitled and easy to read, with a PG-13 rating. SPOILER ALERT—The child rape scene is well handled. I can't give it 4 stars as the plot is familiar, but it's a worthwhile watch.

Ratings: ***1/2 (out of 4) 95 points (out of 100) IMDb 9 (out of 10)

text: For those of us who are part of the real world of ballet - this film is completely ridiculous. Ivan Kirov was basically a gymnast, not a ballet dancer. Viola Essen at the time was with Ballet Theater, now American Ballet Theater, and a reasonably good dancer, but except for Dame Judith Anderson, the acting is amateurish and Checkov is completely over the top .... embarrassingly so! I saw this film at age 14 and at that time, never having seen a ballet, I was very impressed. However, later in life, long after I had completed my own career as a dancer - I purchased the video tape of it, curious as to what it was like after so many years. I couldn't believe how naive Hollywood could be about the world of ballet. But it was made in the mid 40s, before The Red Shoes or The Turning Point, the latter giving a true picture of the ballet world. The entire cast of Spectre have now passed away ... Ivan Kirov (not his real name)dying at age 79. It was his one and only film, thereafter being kept by a Chicago business man .. so the rumor goes.
rewritten_review: For those in the real world of ballet, this film is ridiculous. Ivan Kirov was more a gymnast than a ballet dancer. Viola Essen was with Ballet Theater (now ABT) and was a reasonably good dancer, but aside from Dame Judith Anderson, the acting is amateurish, and Checkov is embarrassingly over the top. I saw this film at 14 and was impressed, having never seen a ballet. Later, after my dance career, I bought the video out of curiosity and couldn't believe Hollywood's naivety about ballet. Made in the mid-40s, before The Red Shoes or The Turning Point, which gave a true picture of ballet. The entire cast of Spectre has since passed away, with Ivan Kirov (not his real name) dying at 79. It was his only film, later reportedly kept by a Chicago businessman.

text:
Well. this was not a surprise. many people will tell you this is gory. but they are all talking "shiztz" this film is very slow.

It starts off with some guy who makes a concoction to feel no pain he calls it "my son" there is some gory scenes but i found them kind of weak. you might as well skip 40 minutes of the movie and get to the eyeball scene which was surprisingly impressive and sickening. there is some really stupid scenes in this. and they dub over the hits and slaps with stupid fake slapping sound which makes me laugh! i would not recommend it. keep looking gore hounds.

check this out if you want the like 20-10 minute ending scene which still is not that amazing and has a random scene of the guy trying to like rape his mum.. yeah its weird.
rewritten_review:
Well, this was not a surprise. Many people will tell you this is gory, but they are all talking "shiztz." This film is very slow. From the very beginning, it starts off with some guy who makes a concoction to feel no pain, and he calls it "my son." There are some gory scenes, but I found them kind of weak. Honestly, you might as well skip the first 40 minutes of the movie and get straight to the eyeball scene, which was surprisingly impressive and sickening. It's one of the few moments that stands out. However, there are some really stupid scenes in this film that just don't make any sense. One of the things that made me laugh was how they dub over the hits and slaps with these stupid fake slapping sounds. It completely takes away from any seriousness the movie might have had. I would not recommend it. Keep looking, gore hounds, because this one just doesn't cut it.

If you're considering checking this film out, do it only if you want to see the 20-10 minute ending scene. Even then, it's still not that amazing. The ending has this random scene of the guy trying to, like, rape his mum. Yeah, it's weird and completely out of place. The entire movie feels like it was put together without much thought, and it just doesn't deliver on its promises of being a gore fest. The pacing is off, and the storyline is bizarre without being intriguing. The characters are not engaging, and the dialogue is lacking in depth. It’s a disappointment for anyone hoping for something memorable or impactful. Save your time and energy for something else. There are much better films out there that cater to the gore hounds and deliver a more satisfying experience. This one is just not worth it.

text: Horrible film. About an old crusty painter who hangs around with a young girl. Boring. Tatum O Neil goes through the motions in her part, and has some of the corniest lines in film history. Richard Burton looks close to death in this film, and we're supposed to believe he looks "Good for sixty". The acting is bad, as is the plot. The characters are awful, as is the story. It's really hard to feel for anyone in this film, except Larry Ewashen who plays a guy in a porno theater who hits on Tatum, he's kind of funny. This movie is really a waste of time. If you are a Tatum fan, like me - which is why I rented it in the first place - please don't see this movie. She is really bad in it, and you'll wonder if maybe PAPER MOON was a fluke. It wasn't, because of BAD NEWS BEARS and LITTLE DARLINGS it's known she can act well, but still, don't rent this movie. And if you're a fan of Burton, rent something when he was good looking, and not a fossil.
rewritten_review:
Horrible film. It's about an old crusty painter who hangs around with a young girl. Boring. Tatum O'Neal goes through the motions in her part, and has some of the corniest lines in film history. Richard Burton looks close to death in this film, and we're supposed to believe he looks "Good for sixty." The acting is bad, as is the plot. The characters are awful, as is the story. It's really hard to feel for anyone in this film, except Larry Ewashen who plays a guy in a porno theater who hits on Tatum; he's kind of funny. This movie is really a waste of time. If you are a Tatum fan, like me—which is why I rented it in the first place—please don't see this movie. She is really bad in it, and you'll wonder if maybe PAPER MOON was a fluke. It wasn't, because of BAD NEWS BEARS and LITTLE DARLINGS it's known she can act well, but still, don't rent this movie. And if you're a fan of Burton, rent something when he was good looking, and not a fossil.

This film is truly one of the worst I've ever seen, and it lingers on in the mind as an example of how not to make a movie. The dialogue is so poorly written that it often feels like a parody, yet the film seems to take itself seriously, which makes it all the more unbearable to watch. The chemistry, or rather the lack of it, between the characters is palpable, making their interactions feel forced and unnatural. It's a shame because with a cast like this, you would expect something far more engaging and memorable. Instead, what we get is a dull, uninspired effort that drags on without any sense of direction or purpose. The pacing is sluggish, making the already tedious storyline feel even longer than it actually is. There's no redemption for any of the characters, and they all come across as one-dimensional and unlikable. It's a real disappointment, especially for those who appreciate the talents of the actors involved. The setting and cinematography do nothing to elevate the film either, as they are as bland and lifeless as the plot itself. Overall, this movie fails on nearly every level, and it's best left unwatched. If you're tempted to give it a try, I highly advise you to steer clear and save yourself the agony of sitting through it. There are plenty of other films out there that showcase the talents of Tatum O'Neal and Richard Burton far more effectively. Don't waste your time on this one; it's not worth even a moment of your attention.

text:
I must say that I was disapointed with this film. I have never been a huge BNL fans, I find their songs kind of childish and obsessively nostalgic (this is me in grade 9, if i had a million dollars, shoe box of life etc). However, I have seen clips of their live show and I really like the improvisational and goofy nature of the show. I was hoping that this movie would highlight this which is, unfortunately, the most interesting part of the show because their music is well played yet somehow bland and not that compelling (there is a standup bass solo in the middle which was completely pointless and boring, despite how much Jim Creegan was digging himself). The film does not and shows only a few minutes of it (and you know they've had better moments, as in the Afgahnistan concert "Koffee Anan, he's the man in charge, my name's Steve Paige and I'm really large") .

BNL are kind of like when I went to Europe a few years ago and heard that godawfull "Blue" song by Effeil 99 or whatever every 2 minutes, I came back to Canada and then a month later that song was all over the place *again*, I nearly chewed off my own arm. BNL is like that, years ago I remember many a fond memory of sitting around campfires in Canada listening to people play "If I had a million dollars". BNL was a cult phenomenon in Canada, and much of their humour has a particular Canadian slant to it (Kraft Dinner is a staple for many students up here, and the name "Gordon" is quintessentially Canadian) a few years went by where they slipped into obscurity and I was somewhat gratefull. Then all of a sudden they become huge in States, and everyone down there thinks they are this brand new band (yeah, they're brand new, but they're all in their 30's!) while the rest of Canada is going "Oh geez, I thought those guys folded years ago, do I have to listen to 'million dollars' again?"

The concert footage is not bad, but I would have liked to have seen more of their stage routine, the shooting is not that great, and things like clips from their massive free show in Boston are glazed over much too quickly. The interviews are surprisingly dull for such a funny bunch of guys, I think they're all old and they have families and houses and stuff and have settled down a bit. There are times when they go into Spinal Tap type of material, where they deliver deadpan satire, then they break into laughs and giggles that kind of ruins it. The interviews with Moses Znaimer (a Canadian media mogule) and Terry David Mulligan (Music dude) are extremely pretentious and verge into Tap territory unintentionally.

This movie doesn't really document very much either, I mean, it's basically one show and at the start of the film, they are already huge and have a massive touring entourage, it's not like we see them rising from obscurity and "surprise" they are popular, it's a methodically planned out event, so in the end it's rather lifeless, kind of half live concert, half documentary, and not much of either.
rewritten_review:
I must say that I was disappointed with this film. I have never been a huge BNL fan; I find their songs kind of childish and obsessively nostalgic (this is me in grade 9, if I had a million dollars, shoebox of life, etc). However, I have seen clips of their live show and really like the improvisational and goofy nature. I was hoping this movie would highlight that, which is, unfortunately, the most interesting part, as their music is well played yet somehow bland and not that compelling (there's a standup bass solo that was completely pointless and boring, despite how much Jim Creegan was digging himself). The film doesn't, showing only a few minutes of it (and you know they've had better moments, like in the Afghanistan concert "Koffee Anan, he's the man in charge, my name's Steve Paige and I'm really large").

BNL is kind of like when I went to Europe and heard that godawful "Blue" song by Eiffel 99 or whatever every 2 minutes. I came back to Canada, and a month later, that song was all over the place *again*, I nearly chewed off my own arm. BNL is like that; years ago, I remember fond memories of sitting around campfires in Canada listening to "If I had a million dollars". BNL was a cult phenomenon in Canada, and much of their humor has a particular Canadian slant (Kraft Dinner is a staple for many students up here, and the name "Gordon" is quintessentially Canadian). A few years went by where they slipped into obscurity, and I was somewhat grateful. Then suddenly, they become huge in the States, and everyone down there thinks they are this brand new band (yeah, they're brand new, but they're all in their 30s!) while the rest of Canada is going "Oh geez, I thought those guys folded years ago, do I have to listen to 'million dollars' again?"

The concert footage is not bad, but I would have liked to have seen more of their stage routine. The shooting is not great, and things like clips from their massive free show in Boston are glazed over too quickly. The interviews are surprisingly dull for such a funny bunch of guys; I think they're all old, have families and houses, and have settled down a bit. At times they go into Spinal Tap-type material, delivering deadpan satire, then break into laughs that kind of ruin it. Interviews with Moses Znaimer (a Canadian media mogul) and Terry David Mulligan (Music dude) are extremely pretentious and verge into Tap territory unintentionally.

This movie doesn't really document much; it's basically one show, and at the start, they are already huge with a massive touring entourage. It's not like we see them rising from obscurity and "surprise" they are popular; it's a methodically planned-out event, so in the end, it's rather lifeless, half live concert, half documentary, and not much of either.

text: This movie was so great! I am a teenager, and I and my friends all love the series, so it just goes to show that these movies draw attention to all age crowds. I recommend it to everyone. My favorite line in this movie is when Logan Bartholomew says: "rosy cheeks", when he is talking about his baby daughter. He is such a great actor, as well as Erin Cottrell. They pair up so well, and have such a great chemistry! I really hope that they can work again together. They are such attractive people, and are very good actors. I have finally found movies that are good to watch. Lately it has been hard for me to find movies that are good, and show good morals, and Christian values. But at the same time, these movies aren't cheesy.
rewritten_review: This movie was absolutely fantastic! As a teenager, I find it refreshing to come across films that resonate with both my friends and me. It really goes to show that these movies have the incredible ability to draw attention from audiences of all age groups. I wholeheartedly recommend it to everyone, regardless of their age. One of my favorite moments in this movie is when Logan Bartholomew delivers the line: "rosy cheeks," while he's talking about his baby daughter. It's such a sweet and memorable moment. Logan Bartholomew is truly a remarkable actor, and Erin Cottrell's performance is equally impressive. They pair up so well on screen and have such a natural and compelling chemistry that makes their performances truly stand out. I really hope that they get the opportunity to work together again in the future. They are both such attractive individuals and incredibly talented actors. I feel like I have finally discovered movies that are genuinely enjoyable to watch. It seems like it's been a challenge lately to find films that are not only entertaining but also uphold good morals and Christian values. What I particularly appreciate about these films is that they manage to convey these values without coming across as cheesy or overly simplistic. It's a rare and commendable balance that they strike so well.

text:
Is this your typical women in chains navy transport love story? Maybe, hell, you know how the formula works by now, pretty woman is introduced in to a picture, someone has to fall in love with her.

I think this film does follow some typical story lines, but that doesn't say anything about the content. There are great scenes with Crispen Glover, Dennis Hopper, and Gary Busey, although short. Some things didn't make sense, such as the need to get in to random fights, but it is entertaining to watch, the fights were actually well done.

This is definitely a comedy foremost, but it does have a lot of good feel to it. The humor is well balanced, you won't hurt your stomach on this, but you will keep a smile.

There is a little bit of steamy action, so not one for the kids.
rewritten_review:
Is this your typical women in chains navy transport love story? Maybe, hell, you know how the formula works by now, pretty woman is introduced into a picture, and someone has to fall in love with her. This storyline is something we've seen numerous times, and it's familiar territory for many viewers. However, even though the film follows some typical storylines, that doesn't necessarily say anything about the content's quality or how it engages the audience. There are some truly great scenes featuring Crispen Glover, Dennis Hopper, and Gary Busey, although their appearances are relatively short. These actors bring a unique flair and charisma to their roles, adding depth and intrigue to the film. Some elements didn't make much sense, such as the seemingly random need to get into fights, but despite the lack of logic in some parts, it's quite entertaining to watch. The fights, although seemingly misplaced at times, were actually well done and choreographed in a way that keeps viewers engaged.

This film is definitely a comedy foremost, but it does have a lot of good feel to it that adds to its charm. The humor is well-balanced throughout the movie; it’s not so overwhelming that it hurts your stomach from laughter, but it manages to keep a smile on your face. The comedic timing and the delivery of lines by the actors contribute to a light-hearted atmosphere that's easy to enjoy. There is a little bit of steamy action, which adds another layer to the film's dynamic, making it more complex and intriguing for viewers, so it may not be one for the kids. This steamy action provides a contrast to the comedic elements, creating a diverse viewing experience that appeals to a wide range of audiences. Overall, while the film may not break new ground in terms of storytelling, it offers enough entertainment value and engaging performances to make it worth watching.

text:
Very touching film, a great surprise to come up from Brazil, a country that usually exports features about social themes, violence, sex... Magical realism is a very hard task, and I believe João Falcão has made it wonderfully. It seems that he really didn't intend to make a realistic film, far from that. Although many people think the film was adapted from the play, he said in his interviews that he actually based the film on the book. Another mistake is to think that Falcão has been influenced by the series "Hoje é Dia De Maria". The TV series produced by Globo was made after the film, but aired before... Unfortunately.

The negative point is the photography, by Walter Carvalho. It seems that he didn't capture or understand the concept Falcão has created. The story is captivating and universal, in spite of taking place in a tiny little city in Brazil. That could take place anywhere in the world. A great movie, I strongly recommend.
rewritten_review:
Very touching film, a great surprise to come up from Brazil, a country that usually exports features about social themes, violence, sex, and more. However, this film stands out with its unique approach and style. Magical realism is a very hard task to achieve, and I believe João Falcão has made it wonderfully, creating a film that captivates its audience with its enchanting narrative. It seems that he really didn't intend to make a realistic film, far from that, and instead, he embraced the elements of magical realism to craft a story that resonates on a deeper level. Although many people think the film was adapted from the play, he clarified in his interviews that he actually based the film on the book. This little-known fact adds an interesting layer to the film's background, showcasing Falcão's dedication to staying true to the original literary work. Another common mistake is to think that Falcão has been influenced by the series "Hoje é Dia De Maria". The TV series produced by Globo was made after the film, but it aired before, unfortunately, which led to some confusion among viewers regarding the influence and timeline of these works.

The negative point, however, is the photography, by Walter Carvalho. It seems that he didn't capture or understand the concept Falcão has created, which is a shame given the film's potential for visual storytelling. Despite this, the story remains captivating and universal, in spite of taking place in a tiny little city in Brazil. The narrative's strength lies in its ability to transcend geographical boundaries, offering a plot that could take place anywhere in the world. This universality is one of the film's greatest strengths. A great movie, I strongly recommend it to anyone looking for a film that combines magical realism with a deeply engaging story. The film's ability to surprise and move its audience is a testament to Falcão's skill as a filmmaker and storyteller.

text: In 2005,George W. Bush started with his second period as a President of the United States; North Korea announced its possession of nuclear weapons; Pope John Paul II died after a long illness; and a movie called Into the Blue appeared.The existence of this movie is not as bad as the other things that happened on that year,but the film itself was pathetic and maybe,the worst one from that year.Now,in 2009,the United States have another President,there is another Pope,new Korean nuclear weapons...and the film Into the Blue 2 : The Reef,which is better than the original one...but that's the same as saying : "getting your fingers cut is better than getting your head cut".This sequel is a really bad film which kept me tremendously bored and uninterested.The cast of Into the Blue 2 : The Reef is composed by TV-series actors who completely lack of any credibility and dramatic weight,but who are perfect for showing their bodies.Chris Carmack (The O.C.),David Anders (Heroes and Alias),Laura Vandervoort (Smallville),Marsha Tomason (Lost) and Audrina Patridge (The Hills) bring hollow and boring performances.I have liked some previous movies from director Stephen Herek (Critters and Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure specially) but on this movie,he cannot generate even the minimum level of tension,emotion or entertainment.The characters from this movie are not only badly performed,but they are also repulsive.Honestly,I wanted all of them to die.The cinematography from this movie is also lame and it seems to have been made by a technical team who makes promotional videos for Hawaiian hotels.Into the Blue 2 : The Reef is a horrible movie which is better than the original film,but that's the same as nothing,as I previously said.Avoid this crappy film at all costs.
rewritten_review: In 2005, George W. Bush began his second term as President; North Korea announced it had nuclear weapons; Pope John Paul II passed away; and the movie "Into the Blue" was released. While not as significant as other events, "Into the Blue" was a poor film. By 2009, the U.S. had a new President, there was a new Pope, more Korean nuclear news, and the film "Into the Blue 2: The Reef" was released. This sequel, though slightly better than the original, was still terrible—like saying losing fingers is better than losing a head. The cast, including TV actors Chris Carmack, David Anders, Laura Vandervoort, Marsha Thomason, and Audrina Patridge, delivered hollow performances, offering no credibility or dramatic weight but showing off their bodies. Director Stephen Herek, known for better films like "Critters" and "Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure," failed to create any tension or entertainment. The characters were poorly performed and repulsive, and I honestly wanted them all to die. The cinematography resembled a promotional video for Hawaiian hotels. "Into the Blue 2: The Reef" is a horrible movie, slightly better than the original, but that’s meaningless. Avoid this film at all costs.

text:
My Name is Modesty is a low-budget film that tells the story of the origins of Modesty Blaise. It's not that the movie is terrible, it's just not what I was expecting or hoping for. While I've been aware of the Modesty Blaise character for years, I'm not overly familiar with the comic strips or the graphic novels, so I'm coming into this movie as something as an outsider. That may be part of the reason for my disappointment. I was expecting more action and more comedy. The film is dialogue driven. I suppose I was looking for something with a little more camp value. As it is, My Name is Modesty is a deathly serious film. There are very few, if any, "light" moments. The acting, at least from Alexandra Staden, is acceptable but nothing outstanding. As others have commented, she does appear a little too frail to be completely believable in the title role. What action scenes there are in My Name is Modesty are one of the films weakest points. I never bought into the notion that this woman could handle a band of trained killers.

I really hope Quentin Tarantino goes ahead and makes the rumored a big budget film based on the Modesty Blaise character. I'm convinced the concept has a lot of potential and I would very much look forward to it.
rewritten_review: My Name is Modesty is a low-budget film about the origins of Modesty Blaise. It's not terrible, just not what I expected. I'm not familiar with the comics, so as an outsider, I found it disappointing. I was expecting more action and comedy, but the film is dialogue-driven and very serious. There are few "light" moments. Alexandra Staden's acting is acceptable but not outstanding, and she seems too frail for the role. The action scenes are weak, and I didn't believe this woman could handle trained killers. I hope Quentin Tarantino makes a big-budget film based on Modesty Blaise, as I believe the concept has great potential.

text:
First of all I hate those moronic rappers, who could'nt act if they had a gun pressed against their foreheads. All they do is curse and shoot each other and acting like cliché'e version of gangsters.

The movie doesn't take more than five minutes to explain what is going on before we're already at the warehouse There is not a single sympathetic character in this movie, except for the homeless guy, who is also the only one with half a brain.

Bill Paxton and William Sadler are both hill billies and Sadlers character is just as much a villain as the gangsters. I did'nt like him right from the start.

The movie is filled with pointless violence and Walter Hills specialty: people falling through windows with glass flying everywhere. There is pretty much no plot and it is a big problem when you root for no-one. Everybody dies, except from Paxton and the homeless guy and everybody get what they deserve.

The only two black people that can act is the homeless guy and the junkie but they're actors by profession, not annoying ugly brain dead rappers.

Stay away from this crap and watch 48 hours 1 and 2 instead. At lest they have characters you care about, a sense of humor and nothing but real actors in the cast.
rewritten_review: I hate those moronic rappers who couldn't act if they had a gun to their heads. All they do is curse, shoot, and act like cliché gangsters. The movie jumps into the warehouse scene in five minutes, with no sympathetic characters except the smart homeless guy. Bill Paxton and William Sadler are hillbillies, with Sadler's character as villainous as the gangsters. The film is filled with pointless violence and Walter Hill's signature: people crashing through windows. There's no plot, and you root for no one. Everyone dies except Paxton and the homeless guy, who deserve it. The only good black actors are the homeless guy and the junkie, not brain-dead rappers. Skip this and watch 48 Hours 1 and 2 for real characters, humor, and actual actors.

text: Really don't care that no one on here likes this movie,, i do , and that's what this review is about. Lou Diamond Phillips is great in this comedic role. that line about train a b and c is now to me an instant classic, the cg is great, yeah train looks a little fake,, but the aliens wow do they ever rock,, Todd Bridges,, where's Arnold, and Mr. Drummond,, wow he's been out of the loop , guess that's what jail does to you.. a bullet train is on it's way to Las Vegas with the Senator for him to deliver a big speech, a meteor has just hit,, and now all of a sudden we got aliens running loose aboard the train, and our hero cop has to save the day, to make matters worse his ex-wife is on board arguing with him. i just thought this movie was so wonderful,, a must see if you like action.
rewritten_review:
Really don't care that no one on here likes this movie, because I do, and that's what this review is about. Lou Diamond Phillips is absolutely great in this comedic role. That line about train A, B, and C is now, to me, an instant classic. The CG is great, and yeah, the train looks a little fake, but the aliens, wow, do they ever rock. Todd Bridges is in this movie, and it makes you wonder, where's Arnold and Mr. Drummond? Wow, he's been out of the loop for a while, and I guess that's what jail does to you.

A bullet train is on its way to Las Vegas with the Senator for him to deliver a big speech. A meteor has just hit, and now all of a sudden, we’ve got aliens running loose aboard the train. Our hero cop has to save the day, and to make matters worse, his ex-wife is on board arguing with him. I just thought this movie was so wonderful, and I would say it’s a must-see if you like action. 

The plot unfolds with such excitement that you can't help but stay glued to the screen. The combination of action and comedy is perfectly balanced, making for an entertaining watch. Lou Diamond Phillips delivers a performance that's both engaging and humorous, showcasing his versatility as an actor. The movie's unique premise, with aliens invading a high-speed train, sets it apart from other action films.

Despite some CGI that might not be flawless, the creativity and effort put into the alien designs more than make up for it. It's clear that the filmmakers aimed to deliver a fun, action-packed experience, and in my opinion, they succeeded. The inclusion of Todd Bridges adds a nostalgic touch, and it’s interesting to see how his character fits into the storyline. 

Overall, this movie offers an exciting blend of action, comedy, and sci-fi elements that fans of these genres would appreciate. It's one of those films that you can watch over and over again, finding new things to enjoy each time. If you're looking for a movie that's both thrilling and entertaining, give this one a chance. You might just find yourself agreeing that it's a hidden gem in the world of action cinema.

text:
I have mixed emotions about this film, especially as it compares to its forerunner,

"An American Werewolf In London." That film had it's funny moments, it was still more of horror tale than anything else. This updated version, now set in Paris, does not have that "edge" at all and simply isn't in the same class....but it does have some good things going for it that the first film did not have and overall it's still fun to watch.

So, "werewolf purists" aside, most of whom think this film is pure garbage compared to the London version, I'll still give it decent marks since I don't care what others think. I liked it even though I agree "London" is better and I prefer that version, too.

The first 30-40 minutes of this movie is strictly played for laughs including a hysterical scene with a "balloon" in a restaurant. It also introduces the lead female character, played by Julie Delpy. I don't see enough of this actress. She doesn't seem to make that many films, or least ones I hear about over here in America. This French actress has a face that is classic beauty, so the film got points for having her in it, and she looks great.

When the horror starts, it can get scary and the special effects are good. I also liked the lack of profanity in this film, unlike the first one: no f-words and no Lord's name in vain - amazing!

However, there are plenty of sexual remarks and there is one scene with a guy running out of bar tied to a cross which was blasphemous to me. The soundtrack is heavy metal which isn't appealing to a middle-aged guy like me, either. This film is geared a lot more toward 20-somethings, if that helps anyone.

It's entertaining.....just don't expect it to live up to the first film.

text: This cowardly and offensive film had me intrigued to begin with. The characters are the familiar dispossessed young males frequently to be seen hanging around bored in a sea side town. Robert is an outsider but he has his music which could have been his soul. Instead Clay makes Robert into a freak who embarks on a journey into cannabis and ecstasy and getting in with the wrong crowd. Clay seems to believe in "reefer madness" and Robert ends the film as a homicidal rapist. One wonders how much experience of real life this young director has. No one can save poor Robert. Clay leaves us with the message that young British men are out of control. A very unsubtle link is made to the Iraqi insurgents; during the needlessly graphic rape we are subjected to explosions and images of war. The film shows male peer group extremism pushed to it's limits. The young bombers in London draw a parallel with Clay's hateful depiction of modern male. Clay implies that men simply cannot help themselves from inflicting terrible acts of violence. It is a wonder the British film industry allows money to be invested in films which advocate such divisive propaganda, when in London we are still reeling from the recent attacks. This is Clay's first film, I would be delighted if it is his last.
rewritten_review: This cowardly and offensive film intrigued me initially. The characters are familiar dispossessed young males often seen bored in a seaside town. Robert is an outsider with music as his potential soul. Instead, Clay turns him into a freak who delves into cannabis, ecstasy, and the wrong crowd. Clay seems to believe in "reefer madness," ending with Robert as a homicidal rapist. One wonders about Clay's real-life experience. No one can save Robert, and Clay suggests young British men are out of control. A link to Iraqi insurgents is made; during a graphic rape, we see explosions and war images. The film shows male peer group extremism at its limits, paralleling London bombers with Clay's view of modern males. Clay implies men can't help but commit violence. It's puzzling the British film industry funds such divisive propaganda when London is still reeling from recent attacks. This is Clay's first film, and I'd be delighted if it's his last.

text:
The plot was not good.

The special effects weren't.

The acting was... not very good at all.

Like others, I felt there were numerous holes in the plot that you could fly, well, a space shuttle through.

I thought the ending was rather unbelievable.

By the way guys, about the "blow torch in space".

Blow torches have their own supply of oxygen (Hence the name "Oxy-Acetylene torch"). Two hoses run from the torch: One to an acetylene bottle and one to an oxygen bottle.

So a "blow torch" would work just fine in space.
rewritten_review:
The plot was not good, and it left much to be desired in terms of coherence and engagement. The special effects weren't up to par, failing to deliver the visual spectacle one might expect from a film in this genre. The acting was... not very good at all, lacking the depth and authenticity needed to bring the characters to life and make the audience care about their journey. Like others, I felt there were numerous holes in the plot that you could fly, well, a space shuttle through, which made it difficult to stay immersed in the story. I thought the ending was rather unbelievable, leaving me unconvinced and somewhat disappointed.

By the way guys, about the "blow torch in space." This has been a point of contention for some viewers, but let's clarify. Blow torches have their own supply of oxygen (Hence the name "Oxy-Acetylene torch"). Two hoses run from the torch: One to an acetylene bottle and one to an oxygen bottle. This self-contained oxygen supply means that a "blow torch" would work just fine in space, contrary to what some might assume due to the lack of atmospheric oxygen. This is a detail that, while scientifically accurate, does little to redeem the other flaws present in the film. Nonetheless, it's worth noting for those who were puzzled by its depiction in the movie.

text:
Have just seen this film, in Australia on satellite. As i have been avoiding the news more so than usual over the last week coming from the US of A regarding gunmen, well to be absolutely blunt, this film is a prescient gem. A big bravo to all involved. i had only a small idea of what the film entailed as is most often the case for good effect and this certainly came up with cinematic goods. the setting of the scene is effective in the truest sense of the word, with all the hairy confronting subjects of today's world in relation to one's own faltering family, albeit suburb. The first forty minutes sets such a professional theater i was not ready for the out loud laughs when they came. Although the cathartic moment built via comedy and character as the family and neighbors came together in an extraordinary way.

All in all a foreseeing of who and what we are. A most meaningful film and a must see.

please note the date of this review.
rewritten_review:
Certainly! Here's an expanded version of your review:

I have just seen this remarkable film in Australia on satellite, and I must say it left quite an impression on me. As someone who has been consciously avoiding the news more than usual over the past week, particularly the distressing reports coming from the United States regarding gunmen, this film felt like a prescient gem. It resonated deeply with me, and I must extend a big bravo to all involved in its creation and execution.

Before watching, I had only a small idea of what the film entailed, as is often the case when I want to preserve the element of surprise for good effect. This film certainly delivered the cinematic goods in a way that exceeded my expectations. The setting of the scene is effective in the truest sense of the word, capturing all the hairy and confronting subjects of today's world, particularly in relation to one's own faltering family, albeit set in a suburban backdrop.

The first forty minutes of the film masterfully set such a professional theater that I was not ready for the out loud laughs when they finally came. The unexpected humor was woven seamlessly into the narrative, providing a cathartic moment that was built through comedy and character development. It was fascinating to see the family and neighbors come together in such an extraordinary and unexpected way, creating a dynamic that was both entertaining and thought-provoking.

All in all, this film offers a foreseeing of who and what we are in today's complex and often challenging world. It is a most meaningful film that invites reflection and discussion, making it a must-see for anyone who appreciates cinema that goes beyond mere entertainment to touch on deeper societal themes. 

Please note the date of this review, as the timing of viewing this film added layers of relevance to my experience.

text:
In & Out is a comedy with a simple premise. It admirably succeeds in the mission of being funny and entertaining.

The comedy in this film ranges from the ridiculous to the sublime, physical comedy exists alongside dry humor, with a nice veteran turn by Bob Newhart. Kevin Kline is predictably in excellent form in this film, alongside Tom Selleck not playing to his expected "square jawed" leading man type. Mr. Selleck plays his humor well and displays a nice sense of comedic timing. The cast makes this film successful.

Not all films with homosexual themes are made to advance some sort of sinister, hidden Hollywood liberal agenda, in point of fact this film was simply made to entertain, and if any part of this films makes the viewer think, then it was a byproduct of the well-acted work by a terrific cast of professionals. Frequently tongue-in-cheek, I found myself laughing at the right moments. A solid "B."
rewritten_review:
"In & Out" is a comedy with a straightforward yet engaging premise. It admirably succeeds in its mission of being funny and entertaining, delivering laughs and enjoyment throughout its runtime. The comedy in this film is diverse and ranges from the ridiculous to the sublime, effectively combining different styles of humor. Physical comedy exists alongside dry humor, creating a balanced and varied comedic experience. The film features a nice veteran turn by Bob Newhart, who adds a touch of seasoned expertise to the ensemble. Kevin Kline is predictably in excellent form in this film, showcasing his well-known talent for comedy. He delivers his role with the skill and charm audiences have come to expect from him. Alongside him, Tom Selleck surprises by not playing to his expected "square-jawed" leading man type. Instead, Mr. Selleck embraces his role with a flair for humor, displaying a nice sense of comedic timing that adds to the film's charm. The entire cast contributes to making this film successful, each bringing their unique strengths to the table.

It is important to note that not all films with homosexual themes are made to advance some sort of sinister, hidden Hollywood liberal agenda. In point of fact, this film was simply made to entertain, and it achieves that goal splendidly. If any part of this film makes the viewer think, then it was a byproduct of the well-acted work by a terrific cast of professionals, rather than an intentional agenda-driven message. The film frequently employs a tongue-in-cheek approach, which adds a layer of cleverness to the humor. Throughout the movie, I found myself laughing at the right moments, appreciating the timing and delivery of the comedic elements. Overall, "In & Out" is a solid film that deserves a "B" for its ability to entertain and amuse its audience.

The film stands out for its ability to blend humor and entertainment without resorting to heavy-handed messages. It offers a lighthearted take on its subject matter, making it a refreshing addition to the comedy genre. The performances by the cast are noteworthy, with each actor contributing to the film's overall success. Their chemistry and comedic talents elevate the film, making it an enjoyable watch for audiences. The film's ability to make viewers laugh while also engaging them in the story is a testament to the skill of the filmmakers and actors involved. In conclusion, "In & Out" is a film that achieves its goal of being funny and entertaining, providing audiences with a delightful experience that is both humorous and engaging.

text:
Im a huge M Lillard fan that's why I ended up watching this movie. Honestly I doubt that if he wasn't in the movie i would of enjoyed it as much or even watched it but once I did watch it realize the story was pretty decent. A bad ending I must say but I did see it coming. It's a low budget movie and some of the actors weren't really good but all in all I rated this movie 7/10.

The suspense of wondering what Lillard was actually up to was what really keeped me interested in this movie.

Its a good rental!

7/10
rewritten_review:
I'm a huge M Lillard fan, and that's why I ended up watching this movie. Honestly, I doubt that if he wasn't in the movie, I would have enjoyed it as much or even watched it, but once I did watch it, I realized the story was pretty decent. The film has a bad ending, I must say, but I did see it coming. It's a low-budget movie, and some of the actors weren't really good, but all in all, I rated this movie 7/10.

The suspense of wondering what Lillard was actually up to was what really kept me interested in this movie. As a fan, seeing him in action added a layer of intrigue and excitement to the viewing experience. His performance added depth to the plot, even when other elements of the film were lacking. The character he played was mysterious, and trying to piece together his motives and intentions added an engaging dynamic to the story. His presence alone elevated the movie and held my attention from start to finish.

Despite some of the shortcomings, like the low budget and some less impressive acting from other cast members, the storyline had a decent structure. The film managed to weave in enough twists and turns to keep things interesting, even though the ending was predictable. It's always disappointing when a film doesn't quite stick the landing, but in this case, the journey was still enjoyable enough to make up for it. Watching Lillard navigate through the plot kept me engaged, and I found myself invested in the outcome, even if it was somewhat expected.

In conclusion, it's a good rental! Even if you're not a die-hard Lillard fan like me, you might still find something to appreciate in this film. It may not be a cinematic masterpiece, but it's an entertaining watch, especially for fans of Lillard. The film offers enough suspense and intrigue to keep viewers interested, and it's worth checking out if you're in the mood for something a bit different. For me, Lillard's involvement was a major highlight, and his performance alone makes it worth watching. With all its faults, I still rated this movie 7/10.

text:
This film is totally unbelievable. The only way a girl would perform this act on a dog is if she had serious mental health issues or had a long history of sexual abuse or was under duress. Yet we are asked to believe that an otherwise 'normal' healthy female just got a bit bored and 'made a little mistake' and oops had a sexual encounter with a dog. What's more it never had any detrimental affect on her ever again except when she tells someone.

Not she was raped by a dog or the dog did something she couldn't resist - she actively initiated oral sex and completed this activity with a pet dog of her own choice. She wasn't on drugs or anything she just 'felt like it'.

The rest of the film seeks to put this action in a light of 'hey it could happen to anyone she's only being honest'.

But really for this to be believed we have to believe that this is a woman who is capable of doing absolutely ANYTHING if she 'just feels like it'. Think about it - could she have considered the rights and wrongs of this action before carrying it out? If she had she would have stopped in her tracks. Human beings have instinctive boundaries for reasons. If we are now to start considering bestiality as a 'cute' little aberration, what is next? Child abuse? Yet the 'heroine' is portrayed as a hard done by, nice girl who had one moment of aberration. If she had been forced to carry out this act by an abuser - the story might have made more sense and I would have been able to accept the storyline. But there is no way that anyone carries out the prolonged activity required and referred to even once - if there is not some deep, disturbance that requires a great deal of psychiatric help. This is NO WAY a one off happening in an otherwise perfect life.

I know this is just a film, but it is through normalising behaviour such as this via the media that society becomes desensitised and more and more awful realities become possible.

I could imagine an abuser showing this to a child to persuade them that it isn't such a big deal and then moving on with their agenda. It could also be used by an abuser to underline to a child not to tell about the abuse - because look how people will react to you if you do.

This is not about truth. The director WANTS people to think it's about truth. This is about degradation and how easily people (the viewing public)can be manipulated into accepting the most appalling concepts if wrapped up in the right way. The watching public are being manipulated, degraded and laughed at.

This is a film in which the actors and the viewers are being humiliated and made fools of in a very sophisticated way by a clever but extremely disturbed film writer.

This film appears to me to be being used as a vehicle for the creator of the film to get off on the excitement of playing with your mind in an abusive manner. I don't know whether it is conscious on their part - but it is the most classic example of Mind F***k that I have ever encountered.

I hope that this doesn't offend anyone too much. But if you watched this film - I don't think there is any room left to be offended by anything any more.

It supposedly had no detrimental effect on her except when she tells someone.

She actively initiated and completed oral sex with her pet dog by choice. She wasn't on drugs; she just 'felt like it'. The film portrays this action as 'hey, it could happen to anyone; she's only being honest.'

For this to be believable, we must accept that the woman is capable of doing absolutely ANYTHING if she 'just feels like it'. Human beings have instinctive boundaries for reasons. If we normalize bestiality as a 'cute' little aberration, what's next? Child abuse? The 'heroine' is portrayed as a nice girl with one moment of aberration.
