text: If you Listen to Ween (The Pod, God/Satan), then you know what's going on with "Split" I found that watching the film under the influence of LSD helped to deal with Audio/Video tracers from fantastic editing job. The plot was only important from second to second. The acid helped to interact with the sounds, subliminal and general pace of this masterpiece. Don't bother writing about something out of your comprehension's reach...There just isn't enough of these great independent attempts at expression at it's most raw , amateur level. I dare anyone to make a movie that can equally Mess with my head and change the way I look at visual arts and the world's reality. Not to mention the many realities that haven't yet been explored by this humans mind. I love the vision of Chris Shaw. I also appreciate the texturing terroristic film "The Begotten" by E. Elias Merhige.
rewritten_review:
If you Listen to Ween (The Pod, God/Satan), then you know what's going on with "Split." I found that watching the film under the influence of LSD helped to deal with Audio/Video tracers from the fantastic editing job. The plot was only important from second to second. The acid helped to interact with the sounds, subliminal and general pace of this masterpiece. Don't bother writing about something out of your comprehension's reach because there just isn't enough of these great independent attempts at expression at its most raw, amateur level. I dare anyone to make a movie that can equally mess with my head and change the way I look at visual arts and the world's reality. Not to mention the many realities that haven't yet been explored by this human's mind. I love the vision of Chris Shaw. I also appreciate the texturing terroristic film "The Begotten" by E. Elias Merhige. 

When you delve into the realm of films like "Split," you're not just watching a movie; you're embarking on a journey that challenges the very fabric of perception and consciousness. It's a rare gem in the cinematic world, a testament to the raw, unfiltered creativity that thrives beyond the mainstream. The experience is akin to diving into an ocean of sensory stimuli, where every wave is a new dimension to explore. The way sounds intertwine with visuals under the influence creates a symphony of chaos and clarity, a paradox that only the most daring filmmakers dare to orchestrate. Chris Shaw's vision is a beacon for those who seek to transcend the ordinary, to shatter the boundaries of conventional storytelling and embrace the unpredictable nature of true artistic expression. And in the same vein, E. Elias Merhige's "The Begotten" stands as a monument to the power of texture and terror in visual storytelling, a film that doesn't just tell a story but immerses you in a visceral experience that lingers long after the screen goes dark. These are the films that redefine what it means to engage with art, pushing the limits of what we perceive as reality and inviting us to explore the uncharted territories of the mind.

text:
First: The recent campaigning of this movie is a huge hoax. Judging from the cover you'd think this was some kind of scandal movie about Kylie playing a character having sex, taking drugs and whatever. This is just a cheap market-scheme. She's barely in it and does neither of the things. The marketing here is unbelievable, and I'm surprised the filmmakers hasn't objected.

The movie itself was to me a huge disappointment. It seemed like a Sunset Beach episode directed sloppy-handed by a teenage Quentin Tarantino. And thats not meant as a compliment, mind you.

I think the weakness of the movie first of all is the story. It seems to be about nothing. Just about cool teenagers tripping around living 'on the edge'. The characters themselves does have some personality though, but the movie doesn't use its potential. As said, there's no story of any substance here. It seems to elaborate too much on cool dialog and ends up looking like a colorful MTV ad. It definitely has that feeling.

Still though, I guess some people might enjoy it, but I'd say there's far better movies like this around.
rewritten_review:
The recent campaigning of this movie is a huge hoax. Judging from the cover, you'd think it was a scandal movie about Kylie playing a character having sex, taking drugs, and whatever. This is just a cheap market scheme. She's barely in it and does none of those things. The marketing is unbelievable, and I'm surprised the filmmakers haven't objected.

The movie itself was a huge disappointment. It seemed like a Sunset Beach episode directed by a teenage Quentin Tarantino, and that's not a compliment. The movie's weakness is the story. It seems to be about nothing, just cool teenagers living 'on the edge.' The characters have personality, but the film doesn't use its potential. There's no story of substance, and it ends up looking like a colorful MTV ad.

Some people might enjoy it, but there are far better movies like this around.

text: This film is the worst film I have ever seen. The story line is weak - I couldn't even follow it. The acting is high-schoolish. The sound track is irritating. The attempts at humor are not. The editing is horrible. The credits are even slow - I would be embarrassed to have my name associated with this waste of film. Don't waste your time even thinking about this attempt at acting.
rewritten_review: This film is, without a doubt, the worst film I have ever seen in my entire life. The story line, if you can even call it that, is incredibly weak and disjointed - I couldn't even follow it from start to finish. It felt as though the writers themselves had no idea where they were going with it. The acting throughout the entire movie is reminiscent of a high school play, lacking any depth or authenticity, and it is painfully obvious that the actors are struggling to deliver their lines convincingly. The soundtrack is not only unremarkable but downright irritating, and it does nothing to enhance the film or support the narrative. The attempts at humor are completely ineffective; they fall flat every single time. The editing is absolutely horrible, with scenes awkwardly pieced together, resulting in a disjointed and confusing viewing experience. Even the credits are a disaster—they are slow and tedious to watch, and I can only imagine the embarrassment of anyone whose name is associated with this waste of film. I strongly advise you not to waste your time even thinking about this pitiful attempt at filmmaking and acting.

text:
The Italian concept of "sprezzatura" was the grace and nonchalance in social manners that led to success in love, as described in the 16th century manual "The Courtier." The film "Hitch" is worth watching for the embodiment of the "sprezzzatura" concept in the dynamic performance of Will Smith.

Smith plays the character of Alex "Hitch" Hitchens, who is a professional dating consultant to those short on luck and confidence. The best scenes are when Hitch coaches the painfully shy and maladroit Albert in his quest to win the heart of a New York socialite and in Hitch's own attraction to Sara and a surprise for her when visiting Ellis Island. In these scenes, Smith is supported with good work from Kevin James and Eva Mendes. But this film is driven by the charm and winsome personality of Smith.

From start to finish, Smith rises above the average comic script to make "Hitch" an eminently watchable and entertaining film. I do not believe there is another actor working today who is capable of delivering the charisma and the perfect timing with the comic moments like Will Smith in this film. And his secret is in the "sprezzatura"!
rewritten_review:
The Italian concept of "sprezzatura" refers to grace and nonchalance in social manners, leading to success in love, as described in the 16th-century manual "The Courtier." The film "Hitch" is worth watching for Will Smith's embodiment of "sprezzatura."

Smith plays Alex "Hitch" Hitchens, a professional dating consultant for those lacking luck and confidence. The best scenes are when Hitch coaches the shy Albert to win over a New York socialite and in his own attraction to Sara, including a surprise visit to Ellis Island. Smith is supported by Kevin James and Eva Mendes, but the film is driven by Smith's charm and winsome personality.

From start to finish, Smith elevates the average comic script, making "Hitch" an eminently watchable and entertaining film. I don't believe any other actor today can match Smith's charisma and perfect comic timing. His secret is in the "sprezzatura"!

text: Episode No. thirteen of the fanciful (excuse the incredibly gay terminology) "Supernatural" TV series relocates Sam and Dean Winchester to Missouri where they have been called upon by an old flame of Dean's to investigate a string of mysterious murders occurring in their small town. As it turns out, a large pick-up truck with an unseen driver is running down African Americans on a desolate stretch of road... While Dean attempts to rekindle his past love affair, more towns people turn up as roadkill. The cause appears to be due to a past racial incident back in the 60s, causing a frustrated redneck spirit to remain in ghostly limbo, seeking to kill black motorists. "Route 666" is another good installment (which isn't uncommon, I've noticed) which contains a few notable aspects pertaining to the pair of main characters such as Dean getting laid and Sam's admitted regret for having left college... The killer truck does't come across as the most terrifying thing in the world, though, for an hour long show, it does it's job well. Not a hands-down fantastic episode, but a solid concept with more horror movie references.
rewritten_review: In episode thirteen of "Supernatural," Sam and Dean Winchester head to Missouri, called by an old flame of Dean's to investigate mysterious murders. A large pick-up truck, with an unseen driver, is running down African Americans on a desolate road. While Dean tries to rekindle his past romance, more townspeople fall victim. The cause is linked to a racial incident from the 60s, leaving a redneck spirit in ghostly limbo, targeting black motorists. "Route 666" is a solid installment, showcasing Dean's romantic endeavors and Sam's regret over leaving college. The killer truck isn't the most terrifying, but it serves its purpose. Not a fantastic episode, but a solid concept with horror movie references.

text:
This film was okay, but like most TV series it would of been better if it just made for television. The best and most loved characters only had five minute roles, whilst the three mediocre characters were all the way through the film.

Unlike most British movies that are based on television series, this film does kick off and it seems to be on to a winner, but the pace suddenly stops when the three mediocre characters are in the real world waiting to capture the three comedians.

The film then doesn't go anywhere when Hillary in a room with the captured Steve, Lipp masquerading as Steve, and Geoff somehow writing himself in to the Medieval times. Which made me think 'hang on? How come he doesn't need a key to enter in to that world unlike the Royston Vasey characters? The medieval scene was okay but Monty Python did it a lot better and of course funnier, with cameos from Peter Kay and Simon Pegg, both didn't say anything funny, Kay had a line and Pegg just sat up on wall looking bored.

What also grated me was that they seem to forget what happened in the previous episodes such as Hillary escaped to the Caribbean in the television in series 2, but in the film he's escaped from prison, and also Lipp is a paedophile vampire which wasn't mentioned at all in the movie, which was also quite disturbing when he's left alone looking after the children.

There were lots of plot holes and unexplained situations such as how did Geoff and the Dark One escape from the Medieval times back in to Royston Vasey? Like Series 3 it started of good but as the film progressed, it slowly went downhill and had a very weak predictable ending.

They would of been better off doing what Monty Python did and remade all their best and classic sketches from Series 1-3 and the Christmas special, and turned that in to a film which would of re-introduced the characters to a whole new audience, who can't be asked to watch the series or to tight to buy the DVDs.

Best advice is save your money and wait till it's on television..... Where it belongs.
rewritten_review:
This film was okay, but like most TV series it would have been better if it was just made for television. The best and most loved characters only had five-minute roles, while the three mediocre characters were throughout the film.

Unlike most British movies based on TV series, this film starts strong but loses pace when the three mediocre characters are in the real world waiting to capture the comedians.

The film stalls with Hillary in a room with the captured Steve, Lipp masquerading as Steve, and Geoff writing himself into Medieval times, making me wonder why he doesn’t need a key to enter, unlike the Royston Vasey characters. The medieval scene was okay, but Monty Python did it better and funnier, with Peter Kay and Simon Pegg's cameos being unfunny—Kay had a line, and Pegg just looked bored.

What grated me was the seeming disregard for past episodes, such as Hillary escaping to the Caribbean in series 2, but in the film, he's escaped from prison. Also, Lipp being a paedophile vampire wasn’t mentioned, which was disturbing when he's left with children.

There were plot holes like how Geoff and the Dark One escaped Medieval times back to Royston Vasey. Like Series 3, it started well but went downhill with a weak, predictable ending.

They should have done what Monty Python did: remake their best sketches from Series 1-3 and the Christmas special into a film, reintroducing characters to a new audience who won’t watch the series or buy DVDs.

Best advice: save your money and wait till it's on television, where it belongs.

text:
Is it a perfect movie? No. It is a weird adaptation from a sci-fi book and it features vampires from space, naked beauties and the British army efficiency.

When I first saw this movie I was rather young and all I can remember is the feeling of awe for the movie and Mathilda May. Actually, if it weren't for this gorgeous lady being naked the whole movie, I probably wouldn't have rated it so high, but given her sheer magnificence, I am now actually considering voting it up!

Lucky for me I got reminded of the movie and watched it again now. Imagine Raiders of the Lost Ark or Poltergeist special effects splattered unto a rather decent sci-fi story, but with completely over the top performances. I still enjoyed the movie tremendously (as well as Mathilda May), but it was a mixture of nostalgia, comparing with the crap movies they make today and actually wanting more when it ended.

Bottom line: if you are a sci-fi fan you are not allowed to miss this movie. Oh, and did I mention Mathilda May is young, beautiful and naked?
rewritten_review:
Is it a perfect movie? No. It's a weird adaptation from a sci-fi book featuring space vampires, naked beauties, and British army efficiency.

When I first saw this movie, I was young and awed by it and Mathilda May. Her sheer magnificence, being naked the whole movie, influenced my high rating. Revisiting it now, it's like Raiders of the Lost Ark or Poltergeist effects mixed with a decent sci-fi story and over-the-top performances. I still enjoyed it, partly due to nostalgia, comparing it to today's movies, and wanting more when it ended.

Bottom line: if you're a sci-fi fan, don't miss this movie. Oh, and did I mention Mathilda May is young, beautiful, and naked?

text:
Istanbul is a big , crowded city between Europe and Asia.Too many types of people living together there for hundred years.In this documentary movie you can see how music can give description about the culture of the owner race.

You would be able to hear too many types of music including rock , hip-hop , arabesque , alternative and more. Some of the musicians are famous in Turkey , some of them are famous also in Europe. The rest are just street musicians. Their music tell viewers , different faces of a city.

Impressive !
rewritten_review:
Istanbul is a big, crowded city that uniquely straddles the continents of Europe and Asia. For hundreds of years, it has been a melting pot where many different types of people have come together to live in harmony, each contributing to the city's rich tapestry of culture. In this documentary movie, you have the opportunity to see how music serves as a powerful medium to describe and express the culture of each distinct race and ethnic group that calls this vibrant city home.

Throughout the film, you will be able to hear a wide variety of music genres, including rock, hip-hop, arabesque, alternative, and more. The documentary showcases an eclectic mix of musicians, some of whom have achieved fame within Turkey, while others have garnered recognition across Europe as well. Additionally, the film features an array of street musicians whose heartfelt performances add an authentic and grassroots perspective to the musical landscape of Istanbul. Through their melodies and lyrics, these musicians reveal to viewers the multifaceted and diverse faces of this incredible city.

The documentary captures the essence of Istanbul's music scene, highlighting how each genre and performer brings something unique to the cultural mosaic. It is truly impressive to witness how music can transcend language and geographical barriers, uniting people and providing a deeper understanding of the city's complexity and beauty. The film not only entertains but also educates, offering a window into the soul of Istanbul through its dynamic and ever-evolving musical expressions. Impressive!

text: After, I watched the films... I thought, "Why the heck was this film such a high success in the Korean Box Office?" Even thought the movie had a clever/unusal scenario, the acting wasn't that good and the characters weren't very interesting. For a Korean movie... I liked the fighting scenes. If you want to watch a film without thinking, this is the film for you. But I got to admit... the film was kind of childish... 6/10
rewritten_review: After I watched the films, I thought to myself, "Why the heck was this film such a high success in the Korean Box Office?" Even though the movie had a clever and unusual scenario, the acting wasn't that good, and the characters weren't very interesting. For a Korean movie, I liked the fighting scenes, which were quite engaging and well-choreographed. If you want to watch a film without thinking too much, this is definitely the film for you. However, I have to admit that the film was kind of childish in its approach and execution. Overall, I would rate it a 6 out of 10.

text:
This is a gem of a film, Slapstick violence a-plenty, Simon pegg and Green Spew.

A suspicious looking power plant and an incontrollable motorbike add to this stonker.

If you haven't seen this I can highly recommend it, maybe not quite as good as bottom but not far short.

If you have never seen a man impaled by the nose on two hooks then what are you waiting for buy this film.

I didn't even see the twist at the end coming when it turns out that Ritchie and Eddie are both ghosts.

Feeb - 1 boiled egg.
rewritten_review:
This is truly a gem of a film, offering an abundance of slapstick violence that will keep you entertained from start to finish. Simon Pegg and Green Spew deliver performances that are both hilarious and memorable, making this film a must-watch for fans of comedic cinema. The plot revolves around a suspicious-looking power plant and an uncontrollable motorbike, both of which add to the excitement and chaos of this stonker of a movie. 

If you haven't had the pleasure of seeing this film yet, I can highly recommend it. While it may not quite reach the heights of the classic 'Bottom,' it comes remarkably close, offering its own unique brand of humor and entertainment. One of the standout moments includes a scene where a man, in an unexpected turn of events, becomes impaled by the nose on two hooks. It's moments like these that make this film an unforgettable experience. 

The twist at the end took me completely by surprise, revealing that Ritchie and Eddie are both ghosts. This unexpected revelation adds an extra layer of intrigue to the story, leaving viewers both shocked and satisfied. 

Overall, this film is a delightful blend of humor and surprises that will keep you thoroughly entertained. Don't miss out on the opportunity to experience this fantastic piece of cinema. Feeb - 1 boiled egg.

text:
Well, I have to agree with the critics on this one, who all said "leave it alone." Why they had to make this re-make of the 1960 "Psycho," I don't know. My guess is they wanted to reach a new audience and thought color and modern-day actors were the answer, since those were the main changes. The dialog was the same and the story the same.

On one hand, I applaud them for not making this over with a lot of profanity and nudity and making it a sleazy film. Yet, if they were going to keep everything the same, why bother when you weren't going to improve on Tony Perkins, Janet Leigh and the original cast?

Did they honestly think Vince Vaughn was going to be as good or better than Perkins? Are you kidding? Ann Heche, with her short mannish-haircut, is going to be better than Leigh? I don't think so!

Yes, the colors were pretty in here but it's the black-and-white photography that helped make the 1960 version so creepy to begin with. It's perfect for the story, not a bunch of greens and pinks! Once again, I guess the filmmakers were banking on an audience that never saw the original.

This was just a stupid project that never should have gotten off the ground.
rewritten_review:
I agree with the critics who said "leave it alone." The 1960 "Psycho" didn't need a remake. The main changes were color and modern actors, aiming for a new audience. I commend them for not adding profanity or nudity, but if everything else stayed the same, why remake it without improving on Tony Perkins, Janet Leigh, and the original cast?

Did they really think Vince Vaughn could match Perkins? Or that Ann Heche, with her short haircut, would outdo Leigh? The original's black-and-white was perfect for its creepiness, unlike the remake's greens and pinks. It seems they were counting on viewers unfamiliar with the original.

This project was misguided from the start.

text: Gentle and genial film seems to have been overlooked as a triviality...and to be fair the narrative is a bit tenuous and lightweight as drama....but I feel the simple wonder and joy of the scenes depicting the first impact of a new art on an alien and sceptical society have a radiance and naturalness which capture the century long romance between cinema and audience better than any film in years. Immensely sympathetic performance from Jared Harriss (who seems to have inherited all of his fathers charisma...hopefully without poor Richards penchant for hellraising and haminess)....and charming offbeat cuteness from costar Yu Xia combine to make this a real heartwarmer. Radiant location photography (including glowingly beautiful scenes at the great wall) and sensitive direction by Ann Hu give film added impact. In short a must for anyone ever enchanted by a shadow flickering to life...and making magic in the dark.
rewritten_review:
The gentle and genial film seems to have been overlooked as a triviality, and to be fair, the narrative is a bit tenuous and lightweight as drama. However, I feel that the simple wonder and joy of the scenes depicting the first impact of a new art on an alien and skeptical society have a radiance and naturalness which capture the century-long romance between cinema and audience better than any film in years. The immensely sympathetic performance from Jared Harris, who seems to have inherited all of his father's charisma (hopefully without poor Richard's penchant for hellraising and hamminess), is truly a standout. In this film, Harris brings a depth and warmth to his character that draws the viewer in, making them feel as though they are part of this world he inhabits. His ability to convey emotion with subtlety and grace is a testament to his skill as an actor and keeps the audience engaged throughout the film.

Additionally, the charming offbeat cuteness from costar Yu Xia combines with Harris's performance to make this film a real heartwarmer. Yu Xia's portrayal brings an endearing quality to the film, adding layers of nuance and charm that enrich the overall experience. Together, Harris and Yu Xia create an on-screen dynamic that is both captivating and heartwarming, leaving a lasting impression on viewers.

The radiant location photography, including glowingly beautiful scenes at the Great Wall, adds another layer of visual splendor to this film. The cinematography captures the beauty and majesty of these locations, enhancing the story with breathtaking visuals that transport the audience to another time and place. Each frame is carefully crafted to highlight the natural beauty of the settings, adding a sense of wonder and awe to the film.

Furthermore, the sensitive direction by Ann Hu gives the film added impact. Hu's direction is both thoughtful and nuanced, guiding the narrative with a delicate touch that allows the story to unfold organically. Her ability to balance the film's dramatic elements with moments of lightness and humor is impressive, creating a well-rounded and engaging viewing experience.

In short, this film is a must-see for anyone ever enchanted by a shadow flickering to life and making magic in the dark. It captures the essence of cinema's ability to transport and transform, offering audiences a glimpse into the wonder and magic that films can bring. For those who appreciate the art of storytelling and the beauty of visual cinema, this film is a true gem that should not be missed.

text:
Oh-so-familiar comedy story about low-key nice-guy Paul (Jason Lee), who after the night of his bachelor party, wakes up in bed with Becky (Julia Stiles), an attractive blonde he met just the night before. After lying about it to his fiancée Karen (Selma Blair), he's forced to tell more and more lies to cover his tracks.

I'm sure most of us have been witness to a story like this at least once before...on film or on TV. The movie is formulaic and EXTREMELY predictable, with an ending you may see coming a mile away.

At least the cast provides some interest and keeps it watchable. Lee is just right in the lead, and Stiles is a lot of fun in a light-hearted comedic role different from the very serious roles she usually plays. Becky is a free spirit who seems to change jobs as often as other people change their clothes.

But you know, this isn't exactly well-written. At least one question is left unanswered: for WHAT, exactly, is Ray (Lochlyn Munro), Becky's brutal ex-boyfriend, being investigated by the I.A.?

And I didn't like the character of Buck (David Koechner), Paul's stepfather; he's a super-obnoxious moron who got on my nerves so quickly I was begging for somebody to punch him.

Add another debit: a gratuitous, uncredited cameo by comic/actor Larry Miller, once again playing a grouch (in this case, it's a little justified - his character is an ultra-conservative minister).

Not good at all, but as usual for me, I give it a three out of ten based on the efforts of the cast alone.
rewritten_review:
Oh-so-familiar comedy story about nice-guy Paul (Jason Lee), who after his bachelor party, wakes up with Becky (Julia Stiles), an attractive blonde he met the night before. After lying to fiancée Karen (Selma Blair), he's forced to tell more lies. We've all seen this formulaic, predictable story on film or TV, with an ending visible a mile away.

The cast keeps it watchable. Lee fits the lead, and Stiles is fun in a light comedic role, different from her usual serious ones. Becky is a free spirit who changes jobs often. But the writing lacks depth. Why is Ray (Lochlyn Munro), Becky's ex, being investigated by the I.A.?

Buck (David Koechner), Paul's stepfather, is an obnoxious moron who quickly gets on nerves. Plus, a gratuitous cameo by Larry Miller as a grouchy, ultra-conservative minister adds nothing.

Not good, but I give it a three out of ten based on the cast's efforts alone.

text:
11:11 a.k.a. Hell's Gate (2004) is another bad horror movie that tries too hard to be something it's not. A young girl has an imaginary play mate. One day whilst out in the fields playing with her friends, a couple of fugitives visit her parents and whack them off for no apparent reason. The young girl runs off and hides from the bad men. Years later, the girl grows up into a woman with problems. Losers at her school (looking like repressed homosexuals) flaunt their manhood in front of her when she rejected one of them. The girls hate her and life in general is miserable for her. A secret from her past returns to visit her. Who or what is it? Why does everyone hate her? What's her Guardian's problem with her? To find out you'll have to watch Hell's Gate.

The new title makes absolutely no sense whatsoever. I don't know why people are given money to make such bad movies. This film is not even good enough to make fun of. It's a head ache inducing mess that'l confuse anyone who tries to make some sense out of it. Not worth your time.

Not recommended.
rewritten_review:
11:11 a.k.a. Hell's Gate (2004) is another bad horror movie that tries too hard to be something it's not. A young girl has an imaginary playmate. While playing with her friends, fugitives visit her parents and kill them for no reason. The girl hides from the bad men. Years later, she grows into a troubled woman. Losers at her school flaunt their manhood when she rejects one of them. The girls hate her, and life is miserable. A secret from her past returns. Who or what is it? Why does everyone hate her? What's her Guardian's problem? To find out, you'll have to watch Hell's Gate.

The new title makes no sense. I don't know why people are funded to make such bad movies. This film isn't even good enough to mock. It's a headache-inducing mess that will confuse anyone trying to make sense of it. Not worth your time.

Not recommended.

text: The horror of this made for TV film was that it didn't end with this one. It spawned a regular weekly series that was even worse than the pilot/movie. Most films about various professions have some type of realism to them and of course are jazzed up to make it exciting. This had none of that. If the intent was to make in "Camp" then it succeeded. It resurfaced on cable a couple of years ago and failed again. Richard Jaeckels performance as the Master Chief who does it all was the only redeeming part of this film. Campier than the Batman series of the 60's.
rewritten_review: The horror of this made-for-TV film was that it didn't end with this one. Instead, it inexplicably spawned a regular weekly series that was even worse than the pilot/movie, much to the dismay of any audience who may have hoped for some improvement. Most films about various professions have some type of realism to them and, of course, are jazzed up to make it exciting and engaging for viewers. This particular film, however, had none of that. It completely lacked any semblance of authenticity or believability. If the intent was to make it "Camp," then it certainly succeeded, perhaps even beyond the creators' wildest imaginations. It resurfaced on cable a couple of years ago, only to fail again, reinforcing its reputation as a flop. Richard Jaeckel's performance as the Master Chief, who does it all with a surprising level of competence and charisma, was the only redeeming part of this film. His portrayal stood out as a beacon of talent in an otherwise lackluster production. Campier than the Batman series of the '60s, the film seemed to embrace its absurdity, yet it never quite achieved the charm or cult status that might have redeemed its glaring flaws.

text: i watched this film many years ago and have searched for it ever since in my opinion although very raw it is very educational as to what the future can hold i enjoyed the movie and to this this day rate it very high sorry to all those that disagree but a movie should always be judged each to there own and in my opinion its great give it a go with all the cloning and test tube babies that are happening today who are we to judge this film, this may be a dramatised event of what is to become but there you go. All the horrors of today are so far fetched even i laugh but this one gets me thinking and it scares me as a mother what if i was desperate,after watching this movie i would think twice sorry but i love the movie make your own mind up don't watch the movie making- just aknowledge the story and ask yourself this how far would you go for a child?
rewritten_review: I watched this film many years ago and have searched for it ever since. In my opinion, although very raw, it is very educational as to what the future can hold. I enjoyed the movie and to this day rate it very high. Sorry to all those that disagree, but a movie should always be judged each to their own, and in my opinion, it's great. Give it a go with all the cloning and test tube babies that are happening today—who are we to judge this film? This may be a dramatized event of what is to become, but there you go. All the horrors of today are so far-fetched, even I laugh, but this one gets me thinking, and it scares me as a mother. What if I was desperate? After watching this movie, I would think twice. Sorry, but I love the movie. Make your own mind up. Don't watch the movie-making—just acknowledge the story and ask yourself this: how far would you go for a child? The film presents a scenario that, while fictional, feels eerily possible in the context of today's scientific advancements. It delves into the ethical and moral dilemmas that come with the power to create life artificially. As a mother, it hits home on a very personal level, posing questions that are both uncomfortable and thought-provoking. What lengths would one go to in order to have a child? Would the potential consequences be worth the risk? These are the questions that the film pushes you to consider. It’s not just a movie; it’s a conversation starter about the future of humanity and the ethical boundaries we are willing or unwilling to cross. If you decide to watch it, try to focus on the narrative and the questions it raises rather than the production aspects. It's a film that stays with you long after the credits roll, leaving you to ponder the implications of our scientific pursuits and the nature of parenthood in a world that is rapidly changing.

text: What a waste of precious time! My 5-year-old daughter brought this home from my mother's house, and we watched it as a family. None of us liked it. This wretched little film, rife with glaring inconsistencies, overt Christian themes and horrible film quality, is not worth watching even on a dare. It felt a bit like a bad high-school drama class attempt at film making. How sad to see talented actors (Chris Atkins, Gary Busey, and company) flounder their way through this trite and insipid storyline. The only good thing I can say about this movie is that the dog is cute. The film can should have gone straight to the pound. Avoid this film - your time is better spent watching paint dry.
rewritten_review:
What a waste of precious time! My 5-year-old daughter brought this home from my mother's house, and we watched it as a family. None of us liked it. This wretched little film, rife with glaring inconsistencies, overt Christian themes and horrible film quality, is not worth watching even on a dare. It felt a bit like a bad high-school drama class attempt at film making. How sad to see talented actors (Chris Atkins, Gary Busey, and company) flounder their way through this trite and insipid storyline. The only good thing I can say about this movie is that the dog is cute. The film can should have gone straight to the pound. Avoid this film - your time is better spent watching paint dry.

The experience of watching this film was truly disheartening, given the anticipation that often comes with family movie nights. The movie's glaring inconsistencies were impossible to overlook, making it feel as though the narrative was stitched together without much thought or care. The overt Christian themes, while perhaps well-intentioned, were handled in such a heavy-handed manner that it detracted from any potential enjoyment of the storyline. The film quality itself was abysmal, resembling something closer to a poorly executed high school drama class project rather than a professional production. It's unfortunate to witness actors like Chris Atkins and Gary Busey, who have demonstrated their talents in other works, struggling to make something worthwhile out of the insipid material they were given. The storyline lacked depth, creativity, and any semblance of coherence, leaving viewers to wonder how such a film ever made it past the initial stages of production.

One might expect at least a few redeeming qualities, but this film offers little beyond the cuteness of the dog. Even that small highlight is not enough to salvage the overall experience, as it merely serves as a brief and fleeting distraction from an otherwise painful viewing. The disappointment is compounded by the realization that the film could have been much more, had there been a more thoughtful approach to its concept and execution. It's a shame that what might have been an endearing family film ended up as a disjointed and unsatisfying viewing experience. The film can, metaphorically speaking, should have gone straight to the pound, as it fails to deliver on even the most basic expectations of entertainment. In conclusion, avoid this film at all costs; your time is undeniably better spent watching paint dry.

text: This BBC series is excellent. I am no Paleontologist, but this series gives the best historical representation of dinosaurs I have ever seen. The 3D animation and animatronics are very good and make you believe you have travelled back in time. The BBC deserves a pat on the back for such a fine series as well as Tim Haines who must have spent a great deal of time getting this series to air.
rewritten_review: This BBC series is absolutely excellent. As someone who is not a Paleontologist, I must say that this series provides the best historical representation of dinosaurs I have ever seen. The attention to detail is truly remarkable, and it makes the prehistoric world come alive in a way that I've never experienced before. The 3D animation and animatronics used throughout the series are very good, adding a lifelike quality that truly immerses the viewer and makes you believe you have travelled back in time. It's as if the dinosaurs are right there in front of you, which is an extraordinary accomplishment. The BBC undoubtedly deserves a pat on the back for bringing such a fine series to life. Additionally, kudos must go to Tim Haines, who must have spent a great deal of time and effort getting this series to air. His dedication to ensuring that every detail was as accurate and engaging as possible is evident in every episode. The series is a testament to his hard work and passion for the subject matter. Overall, this series is a fantastic achievement, and it's a must-watch for anyone interested in dinosaurs or history.

text:
This movie tells the story of nine ambitious teens trying to follow their dream at the infamous New York High School For Performing Arts: Coco, the singer, Bruno, the modern Mozart, Lisa, Leroy, and Hilary, the struggling dancers, Ralph, the comedian, and Doris and Montgomery, the actors. While they all think they have what it takes to really reach their goals, they are going to need a lot more than just their talent. They will have to deal with rejection, heartbreak, education, pain, and love in order to achieve their fame.

"Fame" is one of the most entertaining, classic, and inspirational movies of all time. It has everything a teen drama/musical should have: extremely catchy, entertaining, Oscar-winning songs performed by the amazing Irene Cara, stunning dance numbers, a very attractive cast that makes you believe in the characters, and a great story, including the heartbreaking scene when Coco meets the video camera.

Like I said, the cast is awesome. Irene Cara can really act, and it's not only her singing that makes her shine here as Coco. Lee Curreri is very good as Bruno. Barry Miller brings a lot of humor to Ralph. Maureen Teefy is great as the outcast Doris, and look closely, and you'll see Paul McCrane of "ER" as Montgomery.

This is truly an amazing film. "Fame" really touched me and inspired me to keep following my dreams as an actor and singer. Any movie that moves me this much is a winner in my book. A must-see! The film really touched me and inspired me to follow my dreams as an actor and singer.
rewritten_review:
This movie tells the story of nine ambitious teens pursuing their dreams at the New York High School For Performing Arts: Coco the singer, Bruno the modern Mozart, dancers Lisa, Leroy, and Hilary, comedian Ralph, and actors Doris and Montgomery. They face challenges like rejection, heartbreak, and love to achieve fame. "Fame" is an entertaining, classic, and inspirational teen drama/musical with catchy, Oscar-winning songs by Irene Cara, stunning dance numbers, and a great story, including the poignant scene with Coco and the video camera.

The cast shines, with Irene Cara excelling as Coco, Lee Curreri as Bruno, Barry Miller bringing humor as Ralph, Maureen Teefy as outcast Doris, and Paul McCrane as Montgomery. This amazing film inspired me to pursue my dreams as an actor and singer. A must-see!

text: Ever since seeing this film as a child, over 30 years ago, I never tire of watching it. From the opening scenes in the horn factory, to the car motor running from the back seat of the car, to Ollie answering the phone and being accidentally pushed out the window by Stan, I think this was perhaps their best latter day film. After this they moved to 20th Century Fox, and while those films weren't terrible, they lacked the comic timing of this movie. Jimmy Finnlayson, their long time foil, in his last appearance with the boys, showing up as the Doctor is super! quote: " I said goat milk " his reply to Stan asking him how do you milk a ghost! Charlie Hall and even Ben Turpin show up! I'd say all in all one of my favorite L & H comedies.
rewritten_review: Ever since seeing this film as a child, over 30 years ago, I have never tired of watching it. From the very first opening scenes in the horn factory, to the unforgettable car motor running from the back seat of the car, to the hilarious moment when Ollie answers the phone and is accidentally pushed out the window by Stan, I believe this was perhaps their best latter day film. After this gem, they moved on to 20th Century Fox, and while those films weren't terrible, they lacked the impeccable comic timing of this movie. Jimmy Finnlayson, their long-time foil, makes his last appearance with the boys, showing up as the Doctor, and he is simply super! The memorable quote: "I said goat milk," is his witty reply to Stan asking him how do you milk a ghost! It's these moments that make the film so delightful. Charlie Hall and even the iconic Ben Turpin make appearances, adding to the film's charm and comedy! I'd say, all in all, this is one of my absolute favorite L & H comedies, and it holds a special place in my heart. The film's blend of humor, timing, and classic performances ensures I find joy in it every time I watch. With each viewing, it brings back fond memories and continues to entertain with its timeless humor.

text:
Only a very small child could overlook the absurdities in this bomb; the first difficulty faced by the submarine "Seaview" is what appear to be chunks of--rock? falling down through the water and crashing into its hull. But it's not rock, they're under the North Pole--it is ICE! Everybody, except possibly hitherto mentioned small children (and even some of them) know that ICE FLOATS.

Then, disaster strikes--that darn VAN ALLEN RADIATION BELT around the Earth catches fire! No one knows how this happened, we are told, which is understandable, because it is utterly impossible for radiation to "catch fire", and even if it could, there is NO AIR IN SPACE for it to burn.

There is literally no good reason to overlook science concepts basic to 2nd grade school textbooks when making a film; however, Irwin Allen manages to do it again and again; perhaps we are meant to focus on the "people" instead, which is pretty easy, as they are CARDBOARD.

The cast tries very hard not to look embarrassed in this ridiculous sub-kiddie romp, much like later episodes of his "Lost in Space" TV series, the concept of which was swiped outright from writer Ib Melchior and then rushed into production.

The sub looks pretty good, though, which is why this one gets a "2".
rewritten_review:
Only a small child could overlook the absurdities in this bomb; the submarine "Seaview" faces chunks of--rock? falling in water. But it's ICE! Everyone knows ICE FLOATS.

Then disaster strikes—the VAN ALLEN RADIATION BELT catches fire! Impossible, as radiation can't "catch fire," and there's NO AIR IN SPACE to burn.

Irwin Allen overlooks basic science repeatedly; perhaps we're meant to focus on the "people," who are CARDBOARD.

The cast tries not to look embarrassed in this ridiculous sub-kiddie romp, like "Lost in Space," swiped from writer Ib Melchior.

The sub looks good, so this gets a "2".

text:
I had to write a review for this film after I saw it last night and read some of the comments of people trying to classify the displeasure of this film go down to wfmitchell's post)). I don't fit any any of those classification. The other classification that needs to be on the list is 5) people didn't like this movie because it was not good. I found the film to be booring and forced. My wife picked it for us to see because she is a huge Kidman fan and she also likes Jude Law.

Speaking of Law, it took a long time and a huge amount of suspension of belief for me to believe his southern accent. I can't help but wonder if they didn't make his character less talkative on purpose so we would't have to hear that tortured accent so much.

As far as the movie, it took a long time for it to get interesting (about 1 or 1.5 hours), and then fell flat in it's ending. What was interesting, is that I did not know that this film was directed by Minghella. About 40 minutes into the movie, I asked my wife "this isn't going to be another English Patient is it?" It absolutely was.

As far as the battle scenes. I'm trying to think of a word to describe the opening battle scene, but I think the most descriptive word that accurately describes it is simply "dumb". It was forced, it was unbelievable, it was silly and it was dumb. (After the battle I looked at my wife and asked "was that just dumb?" to which she vigorously nodded her head).

The only bright point in the film was the performance of Zellweger. The role was a bit over acted like any decent comedy relief role, but it worked. From her speech pattern, her walk, her mannerisms and esp. her little quips (my favorite: "If you want to get 3 feet up a bull's ass all you have to do is listen to sweethearts talk to each other"), she was able to create an almost cartoon-like character who did her job extremely well.

I simply did not like this movie and I have to wonder about the kind of people who do say they like it (or the English Patient for that matter). I suspect you could categorize them in one category: 1) Soap opera fans
rewritten_review:
I had to write a review for this film after seeing it last night and reading some comments of people classifying their displeasure. I don't fit any of those classifications. Another needed category is: 5) people didn't like this movie because it was not good. I found the film boring and forced. My wife picked it because she's a huge Kidman fan and likes Jude Law.

Speaking of Law, it took a lot of suspension of belief for me to buy his southern accent. I wonder if his character was less talkative on purpose to spare us from that tortured accent.

The movie took a long time to get interesting (about 1 or 1.5 hours), then fell flat at the end. Interestingly, I didn't know it was directed by Minghella. About 40 minutes in, I asked my wife, "this isn't going to be another English Patient, is it?" It absolutely was.

As for the battle scenes, the opening was just "dumb." It was forced, unbelievable, silly, and dumb. (I asked my wife, "was that just dumb?" and she nodded vigorously).

The only bright spot was Zellweger's performance. The role was overacted like any decent comedy relief role, but it worked. From her speech pattern, walk, mannerisms, and quips (my favorite: "If you want to get 3 feet up a bull's ass all you have to do is listen to sweethearts talk to each other"), she created an almost cartoon-like character who did her job well.

I simply did not like this movie and wonder about those who do (or the English Patient for that matter). I suspect you could categorize them in one category: 1) Soap opera fans.

text: I saw Beyond Rangoon about 20 times, it was THAT GOOD. At first when I watched it, I saw the story of Laura Bowman, but later, after multiple showings, I realised that this also was a parallel documentary. It came to be in my mind, a story about Aung San Suu Kyi, and the struggles of women to remain strong in the face of uncertainty, danger, and sadness. I also would put history, and politics on the list after further viewing, since I did learn a lot about Burma's past, and present, and could only guess at it's future. This movie is not only one you will want to see, it's also one you will definitely want to own a copy of. It's a movie that could easily been seen by the whole family, although not for children under thirteen. However, the educational benefits of this movie can not, and should not be understated.
rewritten_review:
I saw Beyond Rangoon about 20 times, it was THAT GOOD. At first when I watched it, I saw the story of Laura Bowman, but later, after multiple showings, I realized that this also was a parallel documentary. It came to be in my mind, a story about Aung San Suu Kyi, and the struggles of women to remain strong in the face of uncertainty, danger, and sadness. I also would put history, and politics on the list after further viewing, since I did learn a lot about Burma's past, and present, and could only guess at its future. This movie is not only one you will want to see, it's also one you will definitely want to own a copy of. It's a movie that could easily be seen by the whole family, although not for children under thirteen. However, the educational benefits of this movie can not, and should not be understated.

The film takes you on a journey that goes beyond the initial story, delving into layers of complexity that become more apparent with each viewing. The portrayal of Laura Bowman is riveting, capturing the essence of an individual's quest for meaning in a world filled with chaos. As the movie unfolds, it subtly shifts perspective, shedding light on the parallel narrative of Aung San Suu Kyi. Her story is interwoven with themes of resilience and courage, highlighting the immense struggles that women face as they strive to remain strong amidst turmoil and adversity. This dual narrative enriches the viewing experience, offering a lens through which one can explore the broader socio-political landscape of Burma. 

The historical context presented in the film is a crucial element that cannot be overlooked. Through captivating storytelling, the film provides a window into Burma's tumultuous history, offering insights into its past and present while leaving viewers contemplating its future. This aspect of the movie is particularly enlightening, as it educates viewers on significant historical events and political dynamics that have shaped the nation. 

Beyond Rangoon is not just a cinematic experience; it is an educational tool that offers invaluable lessons. The film's ability to educate while entertaining is a testament to its quality and depth. It is a movie that resonates with audiences of all ages, though it is advisable for children under thirteen to watch with discretion due to some mature themes. The educational benefits of this movie are profound and should not be underestimated. It is a film that invites viewers to reflect, learn, and engage with important historical and political issues, making it a valuable addition to any film collection.

text:
If you cannot enjoy a chick flick, stop right now. If, however, you enjoy films that illustrate complex characters and provide extraordinary acting, read on.

Ann Grant Lord is dying. Her two daughters arrive to be at her bedside. Ann begins talking about people from her past of whom the daughters are unaware, and they question as to whether these lost acquaintances are real or imagined. They come to realize that these people from their mother's past are, indeed, real.

The story shifts, basically, between 1953 and circa 2000 with a few glimpses at Ann's life between those years. It was in 1953 that Ann met the love of her life and experienced her life's greatest tragedy.

One of Ann's two best friends from college, Lila, is being married. Ann's other best friend is Lila's brother, Buddy. Lila and Buddy are the children of a rich Newport family, whereas Ann is a cabaret singer living in Greenwich Village who wants to be a free spirit but is still bound by many of those 1950's conventions.

Soon after Ann arrives to be maid of honor at Lila's wedding, she meets the person who will become the pivotal character in the lives of the three - Harris. He is the adult son of a former servant of the family who grew up with Lila and Buddy and has gone on to become a physician in a small New England town. Ann immediately becomes enamored of Harris which adds a complication to the fact that Lila has always been in love with Harris and continues to be. Buddy, also, is in love with Harris, but being 1953, he has redirected that homosexual desire for Harris to his good friend, Ann for he cannot admit to himself that he has a sexual craving for another man. Buddy exhibits his inner frustration outwardly by being the alcoholic, wise-cracking bad boy of the family - much to the chagrin of his very proper and uptight parents.

Needless to say, all of these expressed and repressed emotions lead to tragedy - after all this is a chick flick.

In the present time, Ann's daughters have become distant from their mother and are suffering their own life realizations and doubts. Constance is working to emotional exhaustion trying to keep up her roll as perfect mother and wife. Nina, having always felt inferior, cannot maintain a relationship.

Stir all of these relationships into a span of fifty years, and you get an intriguing look at society, its values, and its effects upon the personalities and actions of the complex people involved.

All of the acting in Evening is excellent, but there are some extraordinary performances and scenes - along with two unique family relationships - that make this film so very, very special.

Claire Danes plays the 1950's Ann, and she does it in a style that clearly shows an intelligent woman of those times who is conflicted by what she is supposed to do as opposed to what she wants to do. Her performance is not easily forgettable.

Vanessa Redgrave plays the dying Ann whose mind shifts from the present, to the past, to flights of fantasy, and of course, Redgrave pulls it all off with sterling style.

Natasha Richardson - Redgrave's real daughter - plays Ann's daughter, Constance, in the film. The scenes between this real life mother and daughter playing fictional mother and daughter are an insightful treat to watch.

Toni Collette plays Ann's other daughter, Nina. Nina spends a good deal of her time being depressed and feeling sorry for herself while shutting out a good man who loves her as well as her mother and sister. Collette is perfect for a part such as this, but I have never seen her give a bad or unbelievable performance no matter what part she plays.

Mamie Gummer plays 1950's Lila and shows us a woman even more conflicted of her expected role in life than her good friend, Ann. She is very good.

Meryl Streep - Gummer's mother - plays present day Lila. What is there to say about Meryl Streep other than she always gives an insightful and rewarding performance.

Director Lajos Koltai states in the DVD extras that he sought out Glenn Close to play the relatively small part of Lila's mother because he felt she was the only actress he could think of to play one scene in the film. He certainly was right, and Close's performance in that one scene etches it in your mind. All the other scenes in which Close is Lila's very proper mother, and you get another performance to treasure.

There are three other scenes in the film, combined with the one featuring Close described above, that make the whole movie worth watching. On Lila's wedding day, Ann comes into her room and crawls into to bed with her friend to discuss Lila's misforgivings about her upcoming wedding to a man she clearly does not love. This scene is repeated fifty years later when Lila comes and crawls into bed with her dying friend Ann to talk about the lives they have lived. In this latter scene, Streep and Redgrave are enthralling.

The other memorable scene - at least to me - is when Buddy declares his love for Ann. Hugh Dancy as Buddy gives us a heartbreaking performance of a young man torn apart by his conflicting sexual feelings. His performance is superior.

Chick flick? Yes. A very special film with unbelievable acting, directing, and scenery? Definitely. I cannot recommend Evening too much.
