But MR MAGOO isn't as bad as it's hacked up to be. It's at least got some funny jokes, and it's good wholesome fun for the whole family (Nielson tried to make a "NAKED GUN" for families in MAGOO, but it's nowhere near as good as that). So see it once, you might hate it, you might love it, whatever. I personally didn't hate it, but I sure didn't like it, or even rate it "okay." 2/5 stars for MR MAGOO-

JOHN ULMER

text: What the hell of a D-Movie was that? Bad acting, bad special effects and the worst dialogues/storyline i ever came across. The only cool thing here was Coolio, who had a nice cameo as a freaked out cop. However, the rest of the film is awful and boring. It's not even so bad, you can laugh about it. Just plain crap. And whoever compares this to the Evil Dead Series might as well compare Tomb Raider to Indiana Jones (well, ok, at least there was Angelina Jolie in Tomb Raider)! 1 out of 10
rewritten_review:
What the hell of a D-Movie was that? I honestly can't believe what I just watched. It was an absolute disaster from start to finish. Bad acting, bad special effects, and the worst dialogues/storyline I have ever come across. The performances were so wooden and unconvincing that I found myself cringing at every scene. The special effects were laughably poor, lacking any kind of creativity or effort, and the storyline was just a complete mess. It was incoherent and seemed like it was thrown together without any thought or planning.

The only cool thing here was Coolio, who had a nice cameo as a freaked-out cop. His brief appearance was the only moment of relief in an otherwise unbearable film. However, the rest of the film is awful and boring. There was nothing engaging or entertaining about it. It failed to hold my attention, and I found myself constantly checking the time, hoping it would end soon.

It's not even so bad, you can laugh about it. Some movies are so bad that they become entertaining, but this wasn't one of them. It was just plain crap. There was no redeeming quality, no moments of unintended comedy that could make the experience somewhat enjoyable.

And whoever compares this to the Evil Dead Series might as well compare Tomb Raider to Indiana Jones (well, ok, at least there was Angelina Jolie in Tomb Raider)! The comparison is completely unfounded and frankly insulting to the brilliance of the Evil Dead Series. There is simply no comparison. This film lacks the charm, wit, and creativity that made the Evil Dead Series a cult classic.

In conclusion, this film is an absolute trainwreck. I would not recommend it to anyone. It's a waste of time, and you're better off watching something else. 1 out of 10.

text:
I always thought people were a little too cynical about these old Andy Hardy films. A couple of them weren't bad. Modern film critics are not ones who usually prefer nice to nasty, so goody-two shoes movies like these rarely get praise

Nonetheless, I can't defend this movie either. You can still have an dated dialog but still laugh and cry over the story. Watching this, you just shake your head ask yourself, "how stupid can you get?" This is cornier than corny, if you know what I mean. It is so corny I cannot fathom too many people actually sitting through the entire hour-and-a-half.

The story basically is "Andy" (Mickey Rooney) trying to get out of jam because he makes up some story about involved with some débutante from New York City as if that was the ultimate. People were a lot more social-conscious in the old days. You'd hear the term "social-climber" as if knowing rich or beautiful people was the highest achievement you could make it life. It's all utter nonsense, of course, and looks even more so today.

However, it's about as innocent and clean a story and series (there were a half dozen of these Andy Hardy films made) as you could find. Also, if you like to hear Judy Garland sing, then this is your ticket, as she sings a couple of songs in here and she croons her way into Andy's heart. Oh man, I almost throw up even writing about this!
rewritten_review:
I always thought people were too cynical about the old Andy Hardy films. A couple weren't bad. Modern critics usually don't prefer nice to nasty, so goody-two shoes movies like these rarely get praise.

Nonetheless, I can't defend this movie either. You can have dated dialogue but still laugh and cry over the story. Watching this, you just shake your head and ask, "how stupid can you get?" It's cornier than corny. I can't fathom many people sitting through the entire hour-and-a-half.

The story is basically "Andy" (Mickey Rooney) trying to get out of a jam because he makes up a story about being involved with a New York débutante. People were more social-conscious in the old days. You'd hear "social-climber" as if knowing rich or beautiful people was the highest achievement. It's utter nonsense, and looks more so today.

However, it's about as innocent and clean a story and series (there were a half dozen of these Andy Hardy films) as you could find. Also, if you like to hear Judy Garland sing, this is your ticket, as she sings a couple of songs and croons her way into Andy's heart. Oh man, I almost throw up even writing about this!

text: I did enjoy watching Squire Trelane jerk around the crew in this episode, though after a while the whole thing just seemed a little too long. Sure, the histrionics were kind of funny for a while, and the ending was a pretty good way to wrap the whole thing together. I think the problem was that I enjoyed seeing Trelane when he was full of bravado and fun, the fun seemed to vanish when Trelane became vindictive and nasty. Talk about a mood killer--going from the obnoxious but affable host to the guy sentencing Kirk to death! But, despite this, the episode was enjoyable and worth my time. For die-hard Trekkies, this is a must-see, for others it's just a pretty run of the mill one.
rewritten_review: I did enjoy watching Squire Trelane jerk around the crew in this episode, though after a while the whole thing just seemed a little too long. Squire Trelane, with his flamboyant antics and theatrical flair, provided an intriguing dynamic that kept me engaged for much of the episode. Sure, the histrionics were kind of funny for a while, and the ending was a pretty good way to wrap the whole thing together. The clever conclusion managed to tie up the story in a satisfying manner that left a lasting impression. I think the problem was that I enjoyed seeing Trelane when he was full of bravado and fun, the fun seemed to vanish when Trelane became vindictive and nasty. His transformation from a mischievous trickster to a menacing adversary marked a significant shift in the episode's tone. Talk about a mood killer—going from the obnoxious but affable host to the guy sentencing Kirk to death! This abrupt change in Trelane's demeanor was quite jarring and altered the overall atmosphere of the narrative. But, despite this, the episode was enjoyable and worth my time. For die-hard Trekkies, this is a must-see, as it captures the essence of what makes the series so beloved. For others, it's just a pretty run-of-the-mill one, offering entertainment that might not stand out as exceptional but still delivers a solid viewing experience. The episode's blend of humor, drama, and science fiction elements ensures that it maintains a certain level of appeal, regardless of the viewer's familiarity with the Star Trek universe.

text: Logan Lerman & Dean Collins III of Jack & Bobby Fame provide a nice touch of familiarity as friends in this even if not maybe as close as they may be on Jack & Bobby but the expressions of young students taking their stand for a good cause is very well expressed in this movie.Logan Lerman may be seemingly typecast in roles of being "different" as thusly seen from here as is seen in this as well as in Jack and Bobby.The Movie also opens up with a very nice tune coined as a lost 45 "And I'm Wondering where the lions are?"A song which I'd Always heard on the speaker @ my old Job of ChristmasTreeShops and got it played on my local radio show of The Lost45s hosted by Barry Scott but the last time of which I suggested this with this movie as it's dedication but the dedication was left out.Environmentalist demonstration is well expressed in this movie too for the protection of the ground owls as seen in this movie too.What a hoot too this movie is.Hoot,Sogive a hoot in the tradition of the Woodsey Owl Commercials of the 1970s too. Truthfully, Stephen "Steve" G. Baer a.k.a."Ste".
rewritten_review: Logan Lerman & Dean Collins III of Jack & Bobby Fame provide a nice touch of familiarity as friends in this, even if not as close as they may be on Jack & Bobby. The expressions of young students taking their stand for a good cause are very well expressed in this movie. Logan Lerman may be seemingly typecast in roles of being "different," as seen here and in Jack and Bobby. The movie opens with a nice tune coined as a lost 45, "And I'm Wondering Where the Lions Are?" A song I always heard on the speaker at my old job at ChristmasTreeShops and got played on my local radio show, The Lost45s, hosted by Barry Scott. The last time I suggested this with the movie as its dedication, the dedication was left out. Environmentalist demonstration is well expressed in this movie for the protection of the ground owls. What a hoot this movie is. Hoot, so give a hoot in the tradition of the Woodsey Owl commercials of the 1970s. Truthfully, Stephen "Steve" G. Baer, a.k.a. "Ste."

text: ...in a TV-movie 70's kind of way. It's one of those movies that show up in the wee hours, but rarely because more modern late-hour schlock movies bump it off. It has likeable performances by Graves and Wynn. Generally, it's just a harmless little piece of nothing that doesn't offend too badly. Nothing good, a lot that's mediocre.
rewritten_review:
In a TV-movie 70's kind of way, this film offers a nostalgic trip back to an era where storytelling was simpler and often a bit cheesy, yet charming in its own right. It's the kind of movie that tends to make an occasional appearance in the wee hours of the night, typically when you're flipping through channels and stumble upon it by chance. However, it doesn't show up too frequently, as it's often overshadowed by more modern late-hour schlock movies that tend to bump it off the schedule. Despite its rarity, when you do catch it, you'll find it has a certain appeal, largely due to the likeable performances by the cast, particularly Graves and Wynn. They bring a warmth to their roles that makes the film enjoyable, even if it's not particularly memorable.

Generally speaking, it's just a harmless little piece of nothing that doesn't offend too badly. There's nothing in it that stands out as particularly noteworthy or exceptional, but at the same time, there's nothing that will make you regret watching it. It's a film that sits comfortably in the realm of mediocrity, with nothing particularly good to offer, but a lot that falls squarely into the category of mediocre. It's the kind of movie you might watch while winding down at the end of the day, appreciating it for what it is—a simple, uncomplicated viewing experience that doesn't demand too much from its audience. In the grand scheme of things, it may not leave a lasting impression, but for a brief moment, it provides a gentle escape into a bygone era.

text:
Robert Carlyle excels again. The period was captured well and the soundtrack, although hearing modern techno in this period piece was a little disconcerting at first, proved to be very well chosen.

Well worth a watch.
rewritten_review: Robert Carlyle excels again in his latest performance. His ability to embody the character and bring authenticity to the role is truly commendable. The period was captured exceptionally well, with meticulous attention to detail in the costumes, settings, and overall atmosphere, which really immerses the audience in the era. The soundtrack, although initially surprising with its inclusion of modern techno music in this period piece, was a little disconcerting at first. However, as the film progressed, it proved to be very well chosen and surprisingly effective in enhancing the mood and tone of the story. The juxtaposition of the modern beats with the historical setting created a unique and intriguing experience that added an unexpected layer of depth to the film. Overall, this movie is well worth a watch, offering a compelling blend of excellent performances, a well-captured historical period, and an innovative musical score that combines to create a memorable cinematic experience.

text:
This movie describes the life of somebody who grew up in the worst of circumstances but unlike many people he actually grew up to be a respectable person. Whats more is that this is a true story.

Antwone Fisher is so innocent and yet he was abused such just because he was not white. Antwone Fisher has been married to the same women for ten years and he never fooled around with women, coke, cigars, weed, alcohol, or any of those things that are very popular in the places he was growing up.

There is not much more to say about this movie it is excellent. The only rating I can give it is a 10/10.
rewritten_review:
This movie beautifully and powerfully describes the life of an individual who grew up under the harshest and most challenging circumstances. Unlike many who face such adversity, he managed to rise above his difficulties and become a respectable and admirable person. What's even more inspiring is that this is a true story, making the film even more compelling and impactful for the audience.

Antwone Fisher is portrayed with an innocence that starkly contrasts the severe abuse he endured, often solely because of his race. His resilience and strength in the face of such adversity are truly remarkable and moving. Despite the numerous challenges he faced, Antwone Fisher has been happily married to the same woman for ten years, showcasing his commitment and loyalty. He is a man of integrity who never succumbed to the temptations that surrounded him throughout his life. He avoided the pitfalls of fooling around with women, and he steered clear of cocaine, cigars, weed, alcohol, and other vices that were prevalent in the environment where he was raised. His ability to maintain his principles in such challenging circumstances is truly admirable.

There is so much to admire and learn from in this movie that it leaves a lasting impression on its viewers. It is a powerful testament to the strength of the human spirit and the ability to overcome even the most daunting obstacles. The movie's portrayal of Antwone Fisher's life is both heart-wrenching and inspiring, providing a deep and insightful look into the struggles and triumphs of an extraordinary individual.

There is not much more to say about this movie other than it is excellent. The storytelling, acting, and direction all come together to create a truly exceptional film. The only rating I can give it is a 10/10, as it thoroughly deserves such high praise for its outstanding portrayal of an incredible true story.

text: I just discovered this obscure '70s horror movie while browsing on YouTube. For a low-budget effort, it has plenty of compelling moments in gradual pacing in leading to the surprisingly shocking finish. While there is one woman who takes off her shirt constantly, the fact that she's a nymphomaniac makes those scenes important to the story and there's one scene with the curly-haired young man as he attempts to seduce her that turned me on before his pulling back made her screaming mad. The young nurse who comes in and gets hired is alluring herself and I'm not surprised she posed for the cover of Playboy. Some characters are very irritating and some scenes do seem ridiculous. For the most part, however, Don't Look in the Basement (That's the title I saw on YouTube) provides enough drama and chills for an entertaining B-movie.
rewritten_review:
I just discovered this obscure '70s horror movie while browsing on YouTube, and I must say, for a low-budget effort, it has plenty of compelling moments in its gradual pacing, leading to the surprisingly shocking finish. The film manages to capture the essence of the era while delivering an engaging experience that keeps the audience intrigued. The atmosphere is thick with suspense, and the character development, though not perfect, adds depth to the unfolding story. The tension builds slowly, drawing viewers in with a sense of unease as the narrative progresses. 

While there is one woman who takes off her shirt constantly, the fact that she's a nymphomaniac makes those scenes important to the story, adding layers to her character and providing insight into her psyche. This element of the plot intertwines with the overall theme, creating a more cohesive narrative. There's one scene with the curly-haired young man as he attempts to seduce her that turned me on before his pulling back made her screaming mad, showcasing the film's ability to balance sensuality with psychological tension. This scene, in particular, stands out for its raw emotional intensity and the way it plays with audience expectations.

The young nurse who comes in and gets hired is alluring herself, and I'm not surprised she posed for the cover of Playboy. Her presence adds another layer of allure to the film, and her interactions with the other characters contribute to the movie's dynamic. Her character's journey adds an intriguing subplot that complements the main storyline. Some characters are very irritating, which might be intentional to heighten the sense of chaos and unpredictability within the narrative. Their presence adds to the film's unsettling atmosphere, making it difficult to predict what might happen next. 

Some scenes do seem ridiculous, but they are part of the charm that makes this B-movie memorable. These moments of absurdity provide a counterbalance to the horror, offering brief respites from the tension. For the most part, however, Don't Look in the Basement (That's the title I saw on YouTube) provides enough drama and chills for an entertaining B-movie. It stands as a testament to the creativity and resourcefulness of filmmakers working within the constraints of a limited budget, proving that a strong concept and effective storytelling can overcome financial limitations. Overall, this hidden gem from the '70s delivers a unique blend of drama and horror that is both entertaining and thought-provoking, making it well worth a watch for fans of the genre.

text:
I read comments about this being the best Chinese movie ever. Perhaps if the only Chinese movies you've seen contained no dialogue, long drawn-out far-away stares and silences, and hack editing, then you're spot on.

Complicated story-line? Hardly. Try juvenile and amateurish. Exquisite moods and haunting memories? Hardly. Try flat-out boring and trite.

This was awful. I could not wait for it to be over. Particularly when the best lines in the movie consist of "How are you? I'm fine. Are you sure? Yes." Wow! What depth of character. I guess the incessant cigarette smoking was supposed to speak for them.

As a huge fan of many Chinese, Japanese and Korean films, I was totally disappointed in this. Even Zhang's sentimentally sappy "The Road Home" was better than this.
rewritten_review:
I read comments about this being the best Chinese movie ever. Perhaps if the only Chinese movies you've seen contained no dialogue, long drawn-out far-away stares and silences, and hack editing, then you're spot on. I really wanted to enjoy this film, but it was impossible given the overwhelming flaws that seem to dominate every scene. The pacing was incredibly slow, and the lack of engaging dialogue made it feel as though the movie was dragging on forever. 

Complicated story-line? Hardly. Try juvenile and amateurish. It felt as though the plot was thrown together without any real thought or creativity. The supposed depth and intricacy were nowhere to be found, leaving me feeling frustrated and utterly disappointed. Exquisite moods and haunting memories? Hardly. Try flat-out boring and trite. The film failed to evoke any emotional response, and the attempts at creating an atmospheric experience fell flat. The characters were one-dimensional, and it was impossible to connect with them on any level.

This was awful. I could not wait for it to be over. Particularly when the best lines in the movie consist of "How are you? I'm fine. Are you sure? Yes." Wow! What depth of character. The dialogue was painfully simplistic, and I was left wondering how anyone could consider this to be a masterpiece. The film's reliance on minimal conversation and heavy silence did not contribute to any sense of mystery or intrigue. I guess the incessant cigarette smoking was supposed to speak for them. It seemed as though the filmmakers were trying to use visual cues to compensate for the lack of meaningful dialogue, but it simply did not work.

As a huge fan of many Chinese, Japanese and Korean films, I was totally disappointed in this. Even Zhang's sentimentally sappy "The Road Home" was better than this. There are so many incredible films from these regions that offer rich storytelling and captivating performances, but this was certainly not one of them. I expected so much more based on the glowing reviews, but what I got was a tedious and uninspired film that left me feeling utterly let down.

text:
First ever viewing: July 21, 2008

Very impressive screenplay and comedic acting and timing in this film. Now 40 years old, it has lost none of it's power. Neil Simon displays excellent insight into human nature and relationships as well as how to create genuine comedy from unusual situations. Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau give great comedic performances. Neil Simon was inspired by actual events in his own life to write the play this film is based on.

One of the best written and acted Hollywood comedies of all time!

Surprisingly, only nominated for 2 Academy Awards: "Best Adapted Screenplay" and "Best Film Editing". Hollywood rarely awards comedies, no matter how well they are made.
rewritten_review:
First ever viewing: July 21, 2008

Very impressive screenplay and comedic acting and timing in this film. Now 40 years old, it has lost none of its power. Neil Simon displays excellent insight into human nature and relationships as well as how to create genuine comedy from unusual situations. The ability to delve into the intricacies of human interaction and extract humor from the most unexpected circumstances is a testament to Simon's genius as a playwright and screenwriter. Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau give great comedic performances. Their on-screen chemistry is nothing short of remarkable, as they effortlessly bring to life the characters originally crafted by Simon. Their timing, expressions, and delivery are a masterclass in comedic acting. Neil Simon was inspired by actual events in his own life to write the play this film is based on. This personal connection to the material perhaps adds an extra layer of authenticity and depth to the narrative, making it resonate with audiences even decades later.

One of the best written and acted Hollywood comedies of all time! The combination of an expertly crafted script and outstanding performances makes this film a standout in the genre. Surprisingly, only nominated for 2 Academy Awards: "Best Adapted Screenplay" and "Best Film Editing". Hollywood rarely awards comedies, no matter how well they are made. It's a curious phenomenon that despite the undeniable skill and artistry required to create a successful comedy, such films often go unrecognized in major award ceremonies. This film's limited nominations serve as a reminder of the industry's historical bias against comedies, highlighting the need for a broader appreciation of the genre.

text: Beautiful film set in 1962 Hong Kong about a man (Mr. Chow) and woman (Mrs. Chan) who become close friends when they suspect their spouses are having an affair. Stylistically, the film is also beautiful. Wong Kar-Wai uses a lot of slow motion and close-ups on parts of the body (feet, hands, waist). The film itself has a reticence and properness that suggests its time period. It's sexy without showing everything. Wong Kar-Wai also doesn't allow the audience to see what the spouses look like, suggesting that Mr. Chow and Mrs. Chan should be together. Smoking is even made to look elegant with close-ups of the curls of smoke. A really lovely film. Just prepare yourself for the ending.
rewritten_review: Beautiful film set in 1962 Hong Kong about a man named Mr. Chow and a woman named Mrs. Chan who become close friends when they begin to suspect that their respective spouses are having an affair. This film, directed by Wong Kar-Wai, is stunning both in its narrative and its stylistic execution. The filmmaker employs a lot of slow motion and close-ups on parts of the body, such as feet, hands, and the waist, to create an intimate and immersive atmosphere. The film itself carries a sense of reticence and properness that perfectly suggests its time period, capturing the essence of 1960s Hong Kong with remarkable attention to detail. It manages to be incredibly sexy without overtly showing everything, relying instead on suggestion and subtlety to convey deep emotional and physical connections. Wong Kar-Wai also makes the bold choice not to allow the audience to see what the spouses look like, which cleverly suggests that Mr. Chow and Mrs. Chan are meant to be together, emphasizing their growing bond. Even smoking is made to look elegant and sophisticated, with close-ups of the delicate curls of smoke enhancing the film's aesthetic allure. The entire experience is a really lovely film that captivates the senses and the emotions. Just prepare yourself for the ending, as it is both poignant and unexpected.

text: John Water's ("Pink Flamingos"...) "Pecker" is the best movie I've seen in a while. It gives the viewer a surreal image of life in Baltimore (I live in nearby Washington, DC), with a Warhol-like use of color, exaggerated motions and emotions. Pecker becomes larger than his town can handle, and he is separated from his loved-ones (including a sexy Ricci) by his man-loving art manager. The picture left a refreshing taste in my mouth--kind of like a fresh strawberry ice cream on a hot summer day--and though this taste was rather flat and simplistic, it only made the whole thing more profound and critical. It is a celebration of life, liberty, and the right to bear arms...and everything else this country stands for. -Juan Pieczanski (jpieczanski@sidwell.edu)
rewritten_review: John Water's ("Pink Flamingos"...) "Pecker" is the best movie I've seen in a while. It gives the viewer a surreal image of life in Baltimore (I live in nearby Washington, DC), with a Warhol-like use of color, exaggerated motions and emotions. The film brilliantly captures the essence of Baltimore, showcasing its unique charm and quirks through the eyes of Pecker, a young photographer who innocently documents the world around him. Pecker becomes larger than his town can handle, and he is separated from his loved-ones (including a sexy Ricci) by his man-loving art manager. The narrative cleverly explores themes of art, fame, and the impact they have on personal relationships, all while maintaining a light-hearted and humorous tone. The picture left a refreshing taste in my mouth--kind of like a fresh strawberry ice cream on a hot summer day--and though this taste was rather flat and simplistic, it only made the whole thing more profound and critical. It is a celebration of life, liberty, and the right to bear arms...and everything else this country stands for. The film's ability to blend satire with genuine emotion is truly remarkable, offering a critical yet affectionate look at American culture and values. The characters are vividly portrayed, each adding depth and dimension to the story, making it a memorable and thought-provoking experience. -Juan Pieczanski (jpieczanski@sidwell.edu)

text:
Bizarre take on the Cinderella tale. Terribly poor script, but Kathleen Turner turns in a pretty decent evil step-mother performance.

Visually stunning in some parts, but that's about it. The period costumes range from the Elizabethan era to the 1990s. Fast forward until you see something interesting and save yourself the full 90 minutes of drivel.

If you're really in the mood for a Cinderella story - I suggest "Ever After: A Cinderella Story" or "The Glass Slipper".
rewritten_review:
Bizarre take on the Cinderella tale. Terribly poor script, but Kathleen Turner turns in a pretty decent evil step-mother performance. From the very beginning, the plot seems to be all over the place, lacking coherence and failing to capture the essence of the Cinderella story we all know and love. The dialogue, unfortunately, does not add any depth or intrigue, leaving much to be desired in terms of character development and emotional engagement. The storyline meanders through various subplots that do not contribute meaningfully to the central narrative, making it a challenge to stay invested in the unfolding events. 

Visually stunning in some parts, but that's about it. The film occasionally delivers breathtaking visuals, particularly in the grand ballroom scenes and the enchanting forest sequences, which provide brief moments of visual respite. The period costumes range from the Elizabethan era to the 1990s, creating a confusing and anachronistic aesthetic that distracts rather than enhances the viewing experience. While some costume designs are impressive and intricately detailed, others seem hastily put together, further contributing to the film's overall inconsistency. Fast forward until you see something interesting and save yourself the full 90 minutes of drivel. The pacing is uneven, with long stretches of dull and predictable scenes that fail to build momentum or suspense. The occasional sparks of creativity and innovation are overshadowed by the overwhelming mediocrity of the script and direction.

If you're really in the mood for a Cinderella story - I suggest "Ever After: A Cinderella Story" or "The Glass Slipper". These films offer a more cohesive narrative and compelling performances that stay true to the enchanting spirit of the classic fairy tale. "Ever After: A Cinderella Story" provides a refreshing and modern twist on the traditional narrative, with strong character portrayals and a well-crafted script. "The Glass Slipper," on the other hand, delivers a charming and whimsical interpretation that captures the magic and wonder of the Cinderella story. In comparison, these alternatives provide a much more satisfying and enjoyable viewing experience, ensuring that the timeless tale of Cinderella continues to captivate audiences of all ages.

text: When I first started watching this movie I was looking for some kind of subtle metaphors but it soon dawned on me that this movie was indeed about people on a train. The interactions between people are like those you can see any day on the street and when in occasion there is a slightly more interesting situation the dialogue becomes stilted and boring. Its not that I don't get how this film is trying to portray the way people interact, it's just that in this film they are very boring. If you want to see and analyse these kinds of relationships you'd be best to actually go out and buy a train ticket and look at the people on the train with you. It is realistic but you wouldn't go to a movie to watch a film about you sitting there watching the movie.
rewritten_review: When I first started watching this movie, I was looking for some kind of subtle metaphors, something that would make me think more deeply or see the world in a different light. However, it soon dawned on me that this movie was indeed just about people on a train. There was no hidden meaning or complex symbolism, just people going about their day as they traveled from one place to another. The interactions between people are like those you can see any day on the street, ordinary and mundane, lacking any real excitement or intrigue. It felt as though the film was trying to hold up a mirror to everyday life, showing us the kinds of interactions we might have ourselves or witness in passing, but without adding anything new or insightful to the mix. When, on occasion, there is a slightly more interesting situation, the dialogue becomes stilted and boring, failing to capture the emotional depth or complexity that might have been present in real life. It's not that I don't get how this film is trying to portray the way people interact; I do understand that it's aiming for realism and authenticity. Yet, in this film, they are very boring, lacking any spark or dynamism that would make their stories worth telling or watching. If you want to see and analyze these kinds of relationships, you'd be best to actually go out and buy a train ticket and look at the people on the train with you because at least then you might find some genuine moments of interest or connection. It is realistic, but you wouldn't go to a movie to watch a film about you sitting there watching the movie. You go for an experience that takes you out of the ordinary, not one that mirrors it so closely that it becomes mundane and uninteresting.

text: OK i have seen Hershall Gordon Lewis movies before but this one really takes the cake,its really gory and gross,not to mention disgusting the way the strippers are done in,I'm talking bad acting that makes plan 9 from outer space look like hamlet,the only saving grace is the late great Henny Youngman as the strip club owner,yeah take my wife..., please.the stripteasers are real sexy for 1972,i believe they used this same plot again in the Roger Corman movie;stripped to kill in 1987.i did enjoy the earlier H.G.Lewis flick 100 maniacs,which was a mini masterpiece of sorts,but bad acting,no awards here,but be aware this is a splatter movie that paved the way for Friday the 13th,and saw.in one disturbing scene a half naked stripper has her butt spanked with a meat tenderizer.ugh!morbid stuff here.H.G. Lewis strikes again. 2 out of 10.
rewritten_review: I have seen Herschell Gordon Lewis movies before, but this one really takes the cake. It's incredibly gory and gross, not to mention downright disgusting in the way the strippers are done in. I'm talking about bad acting that makes "Plan 9 from Outer Space" look like "Hamlet." The only saving grace in this film is the late great Henny Youngman as the strip club owner. Yeah, take my wife... please. The stripteasers are really sexy for 1972, and I believe they used this same plot again in the Roger Corman movie "Stripped to Kill" in 1987. I did enjoy the earlier H.G. Lewis flick "100 Maniacs," which was a mini masterpiece of sorts, but let me tell you, there's bad acting here—no awards for this one. However, be aware that this is a splatter movie that paved the way for films like "Friday the 13th" and "Saw." In one particularly disturbing scene, a half-naked stripper has her butt spanked with a meat tenderizer. Ugh! It's morbid stuff here. H.G. Lewis strikes again with his unique brand of horror. Despite the gruesome scenes and the subpar acting, you have to acknowledge its impact on the genre. Still, I can't bring myself to rate it highly. This movie gets a 2 out of 10 from me.

text:
This is probably one of the best thrillers I have ever seen. It has action, but not this bullet-flying, good guys - bad guys, van damme - stallone action, but quick, realistic and nervous action, it has a plot, cause till the very end of the movie you don't know how this is gonna end, it has characters, aidan quinn, donald sutherland and ben kingsley are just perfect, and it has suspense, this movie just won't let you go away before you've seen the end of it.

Though there are only a few characters, I didn't find it difficult to keep my attention the the story, and as for the story, it's basic (not too tom clancy-difficult, but simple and raw) and realistic.

If you're in for a movie with a good story, some action and great acting, watch this and I promise, you won't go away till you've seen the end of it. The very end of it.
rewritten_review:
This is probably one of the best thrillers I have ever seen. It has action, but not this bullet-flying, good guys - bad guys, Van Damme - Stallone action, but quick, realistic, and nervous action. The kind of action that keeps you on the edge of your seat, holding your breath with each intense moment. It has a plot that is so engaging and well-crafted that till the very end of the movie, you don't know how this is gonna end. It keeps you guessing, second-guessing, and theorizing about what might happen next, and when you think you've figured it out, it throws another curveball your way. It has characters that are so well-developed and portrayed by skilled actors like Aidan Quinn, Donald Sutherland, and Ben Kingsley, who are just perfect in their roles. They bring depth and nuance to their characters, making them feel real and relatable. And it has suspense, the kind of suspense that grips you tightly and won't let you go. This movie just won't let you go away before you've seen the end of it, it demands your attention and rewards it with a satisfying conclusion.

Though there are only a few characters, I didn't find it difficult to keep my attention on the story. In fact, the limited number of characters allows for a more focused and intimate narrative that draws you in and keeps you invested in their fates. And as for the story, it's basic in the best way possible. It's not too Tom Clancy-difficult, with overly complicated plots and subplots that are hard to follow, but simple and raw, yet effective. It's realistic, grounding the thrilling events in a believable context that makes the stakes feel all the more real.

If you're in for a movie with a good story, some action, and great acting, watch this and I promise, you won't go away till you've seen the end of it. The very end of it. It's a film that delivers on all fronts, offering a thrilling ride filled with unexpected twists, compelling characters, and a narrative that keeps you hooked from start to finish. It's a testament to the power of good storytelling and the impact of strong performances, making it a must-see for any thriller enthusiast.

text:
The Battleship Potemkin was said to have been a favourite of Charlie Chaplin. It presents a dramatised version of the mutiny that occurred in 1905 when the crew of the Russian battleship Potemkin rebelled against their officers of the Tsarist regime.

The film is a textbook cinema classic, and a masterpiece of creative editing, especially in the famous Odessa Steps sequence in which innocent civilians are mown down in the bloodshed; the happenings of a minute are drawn into five by frenzied cross-cutting. The film contains 1,300 separate shots, and in 1948 and 1958 was judged the best film ever made by a panel of international critics. The Battleship Potemkin is in the public domain, in some parts of the world.
rewritten_review:
The Battleship Potemkin, a film that has been hailed as a classic of cinema, was said to have been a favorite of the legendary Charlie Chaplin. It presents a dramatized version of the mutiny that occurred in 1905 when the crew of the Russian battleship Potemkin bravely rebelled against their officers of the oppressive Tsarist regime. This historical event was a significant moment in the lead-up to the Russian Revolution, and the film captures the spirit of rebellion and the fight for justice.

The film is not just a retelling of historical events but a textbook example of cinema as an art form and a masterpiece of creative editing. It is particularly renowned for the famous Odessa Steps sequence, a powerful scene in which innocent civilians are violently mown down during the bloodshed. This sequence is a masterclass in editing; the happenings of a single minute are drawn out into five intense and suspenseful minutes through frenzied cross-cutting. This technique heightens the emotional impact and creates a sense of chaos and urgency that has rarely been matched in cinematic history.

The Battleship Potemkin contains an impressive 1,300 separate shots, a testament to the meticulous craftsmanship of its creators. In both 1948 and 1958, the film was judged the best film ever made by a panel of international critics, a recognition that underscores its lasting significance and influence in the world of cinema.

The Battleship Potemkin is in the public domain in some parts of the world, allowing new generations to experience its groundbreaking storytelling and technical achievements. Its availability ensures that its legacy continues, inspiring filmmakers and audiences alike with its powerful depiction of courage and the struggle for freedom.

text:
This story of the troubles caused by an over-possessive, overpowering, domineering and unscrupulous mother (Laura Hope Crews) for her two grown sons, and their girls, is a strong vehicle for stellar performances by Irene Dunn (the new daughter-in-law), Joel McCrea (the number-one son), Eric Linden (the number-two son) and Frances Dee (fiance of number-two son). Here's the show of the pure tyranny of mother's jealousy and possessiveness run amok as four good people find their owns lives damaged, their plans changed and their own identities in jeopardy. Irene Dunn is stellar in her role. Joel McCrea's performance is open and clear and Laura Hope Crews is masterful as the mother.

Yet this reviewer finds Frances Dee's performance the best of all. Hers is the first character in the story to show the strength of her inner feelings. Her portrayal in her heartbreak broken-engagement scene is gut-wrenching, and even raw. Dee yanks the viewer around and drives you into her pain without even showing her face !

Frances Dee, like Laura Hope Crews, has been too long overlooked, and is now almost forgotten as the magnificent actress that she was. No actress who started in film after WWII has had anything to speak of on Frances Dee.

If you're lucky enough to see The Silver Cord, which was never released for TV, you'll find this "old fashioned drawing-room drama" to be an outstanding film that shows very well 74 years after its 1933 release because it is filled with superb performances.
rewritten_review:
This story of the troubles caused by an over-possessive, domineering, and unscrupulous mother (Laura Hope Crews) for her two grown sons and their girls is a strong vehicle for stellar performances by Irene Dunn (the new daughter-in-law), Joel McCrea (the number-one son), Eric Linden (the number-two son), and Frances Dee (fiance of number-two son). It showcases the pure tyranny of a mother's jealousy and possessiveness run amok as four good people find their lives damaged, plans changed, and identities in jeopardy. Irene Dunn is stellar in her role, Joel McCrea's performance is open and clear, and Laura Hope Crews is masterful as the mother.

Yet this reviewer finds Frances Dee's performance the best of all. Hers is the first character in the story to show the strength of her inner feelings. Frances Dee, like Laura Hope Crews, has been too long overlooked and is now almost forgotten as the magnificent actress she was. No actress who started in film after WWII has had anything to speak of on Frances Dee.

If you're lucky enough to see The Silver Cord, which was never released for TV, you'll find this "old fashioned drawing-room drama" to be an outstanding film that shows very well 74 years after its 1933 release because it is filled with superb performances.

text:
First and foremost, speaking as no fan of the genre, "The Bourne Ultimatum" is a breathtaking, virtuoso, superb action movie.

Secondly, it is a silly malarky of cartoonish super-hero stuff.

Thirdly, the film carries a complex, important point, about crime-fighters turning into criminals themselves. No reference is made to Abu Ghraib or the Executive Branch's outrageous domestic assaults on constitutional rights, none is necessary.

So, the latest in the "Bourne" series, in the hands of Paul Greengrass (of the 2004 "Bourne Supremacy" and last year's "United 93"), is a significant achievement, perhaps held back but not actually diminished by the unavoidable excesses of the genre.

"Breathtaking" above is meant both as a complimentary adjective and a description of the physical sensation: for more than an hour from the first frame, the viewer seemingly holds his breath, pushed back against the chair by the force of relentless, globe-trotting, utterly suspenseful action. There is no letup, no variation in the rhythm and pull of the film, and yet it never becomes monotonous and tiresome the way some kindred music videos do after just a couple of minutes.

Oliver Wood's in-your-face cinematography is making the best of Tony Gilroy's screenplay from Robert Ludlum's 1990 novel (which doesn't stack up well against the "Bourne Identity," written a decade earlier).

Matt Damon is once again the inevitable, irreplaceable Bourne, the deadliest of fantasy CIA agents, this time taking on the entire agency in search of his identity, his past, and the mysterious agency program that has turned him into a killing machine. Nothing like his quietly heroic Edward R. Murrow, the always-marvelous David Strathairn is the nasty top agency official, pitched against Bourne in trying to hide some illegal "take-no-prisoners" policies and brutal procedures.

Joan Allen plays what appears to be the Good Cop against Strathairn's Bad One. And, there is Julia Stiles as the agent once again coming to Bourne's aid; a combination of Greengrass' direction and Stiles acting results in a surprising impact by a mostly silent character, her lack of communication and blank expression more intriguing than miles of dialogue.

So good is "The Bourne Ultimatum" that it gets away with the old one-man-against-the-world bit, this time stretched to ridiculous excesses, as Bourne defies constraints of geography, time, gravity... and physics in general. (Can you fly backwards with a car from the top of a building? Why not - it looks great.)

All this "real-world" magic - leaping from country to country in seconds, to arrive at some unknown location exactly as, when, and how needed - outdoes special-effect and superhero cartoon improbabilities. And yet, only a clueless pedant would allow "facts" interfere with the entertainment-based ecstasy of the Bourne fantasy.

text: Need a lesson in pure, abject failure?? Look no further than "Wizards of the Lost Kingdom", an abysmal, dirt-poor, disgrace of a flick. As we all know, decent moovies tend to sprout horrible, horrible offspring: "Halloween" begat many, many bad 80's slasher flicks; "Mad Max" begat many, many bad 80's "futuristic wasteland fantasy" flicks; and "Conan the Barbarian" begat a whole slew of terrible, horrible, incredibly bad 80's sword-and-sorcery flicks. "Wizards of the Lost Kingdom" scrapes the bottom of that 80's barrel, in a way that's truly insulting to barrels. A young runt named Simon recaptured his "good kingdom" from an evil sorcerer with the help of a mangy rug, a garden gnome, a topless bimbo mermaid, and a tired-looking, pudgy Bo Svenson. Svenson("North Dallas Forty", "Inglorious Bastards", "Delta Force"), a long-time b-moovie muscleman, looks barely able to swing his aluminum foil sword. However, he manages to defeat the forces of evil, which consist of the evil sorcerer, "Shurka", and his army of badly costumed monsters, giants, and midgets. At one point, a paper mache bat on a string attacks, but is eaten by a 1/2 hidden sock puppet, pitifully presented as some sort of dragon. The beginning of the film consists of what can only politely be described as bits of scenes scooped up from the cutting-room floor of udder bad moovies, stitched together in the vain hope of setting the scene for the film, and over-earnestly narrated by some guy who never appears again. Words cannot properly convey the jaw-dropping cheapness of this film; the producers probably spent moore moolah feeding Svenson's ever expanding gullet than on the cheesy fx of this flick. And we're talkin' Brie here, folks... :=8P Director Hector Olivera("Barbarian Queen") presents this mish-mash in a hopelessly confused, confuddled, and cliched manner, destroying any possible hint of clear, linear storytelling. The acting is dreadful, the production levels below shoe-string, and the plot is one tired cliche after another paraded before our weary eyes. That they actually made a sequel(!!!) makes the MooCow's brain whirl. James Horner's("Braveheart", "Titanic","The Rock") cheesy moosic from "Battle Beyond the Stars" was lifted, screaming and kicking, and mercilessly grafted onto this turkey - bet this one doesn't pop up on his resume. Folks, you gotta see this to believe it. The MooCow says as a cheapo rent when there is NOTHING else to watch, well, it's moore fun than watching dust bunnies mate. Barely. :=8P

text:
I very nearly walked out, but I'd paid my money, and my nearly-as-disgusted friend wanted to hold out. After the endearing, wide-eyed innocence of "A New Hope" and the thrilling sophistication of "The Empire Strikes Back," I remember awaiting "Return of the Jedi" with almost aching anticipation. But from the opening scene of this insultingly commercial sewage, I was bitterly disappointed, and enraged at Lucas. He should have been ashamed of himself, but this abomination undeniably proves that he doesn't have subatomic particle of shame in his cold, greedy heart. Episode I would go on to reinforce this fact -- your honor, I call Jarjar Binks (but please issue barf bags to the members of the jury first).

From the initial raising of the gate at Jabba's lair, this "film" was nothing more than a two-plus-hour commercial for as many licensable, profit-making action figures as Lucas could cram into it -- the pig-like guards, the hokey flesh-pigtailed flunky, that vile muppet-pet of Jabba's, the new and recycled cabaret figures, the monsters, etc., etc., ad vomitum. Then there were the detestably cute and marketable Ewoks. Pile on top of that all of the rebel alliance aliens. Fifteen seconds each on-screen (or less) and the kiddies just GOTTA have one for their collection. The blatant, exploitative financial baiting of children is nauseating.

Lucas didn't even bother to come up with a new plot -- he just exhumed the Death Star from "A New Hope" and heaved in a boatload of cheap sentiment. What an appalling slap in the face to his fans. I can't shake the notion that Lucas took a perverse pleasure in inflicting this dreck on his fans: "I've got these lemmings hooked so bad that I can crank out the worst piece of stinking, putrid garbage that I could dream up, and they'll flock to the theaters to scarf it up. Plus, all the kiddies will whine and torture their parents until they buy the brats a complete collection of action figures of every single incidental undeveloped, cartoonish caricature that I stuffed in, and I get a cut from every single one. It'll make me even more obscenely rich."

There may have been a paltry, partial handful of redeeming moments in this miserable rip-off. I seem to recall that Harrison Ford managed to just barely keep his nose above the surface of this cesspool. But whatever tiny few bright spots there may be are massively obliterated by the offensive commercialism that Lucas so avariciously embraced in this total, absolute sell-out to profit.
rewritten_review:

After the endearing, wide-eyed innocence of "A New Hope" and the thrilling sophistication of "The Empire Strikes Back," I awaited "Return of the Jedi" with aching anticipation. But from the opening scene of this insultingly commercial sewage, I was bitterly disappointed and enraged at Lucas. He should have been ashamed, but this abomination proves he doesn't have a subatomic particle of shame in his cold, greedy heart. Episode I would reinforce this fact—your honor, I call Jar Jar Binks (please issue barf bags to the jury first).

From the initial raising of the gate at Jabba's lair, this "film" was a two-plus-hour commercial for as many licensable, profit-making action figures as Lucas could cram into it—the pig-like guards, the flesh-pigtailed flunky, Jabba's muppet-pet, the cabaret figures, the monsters, etc., ad vomitum. Then there were the detestably cute and marketable Ewoks. Pile on top of that all of the rebel alliance aliens. Fifteen seconds each on-screen (or less) and the kiddies just GOTTA have one for their collection. The exploitative financial baiting of children is nauseating.

Lucas didn't even bother to come up with a new plot—he just exhumed the Death Star from "A New Hope" and heaved in a boatload of cheap sentiment. What an appalling slap in the face to his fans. I can't shake the notion that Lucas took perverse pleasure in inflicting this dreck: "I've got these lemmings hooked so bad I can crank out the worst piece of stinking, putrid garbage, and they'll flock to the theaters. Plus, all the kiddies will whine until their parents buy them a complete collection of action figures, and I get a cut from every single one. It'll make me even more obscenely rich."

There may have been a paltry, partial handful of redeeming moments. I recall Harrison Ford barely keeping his nose above this cesspool. But whatever tiny bright spots there may be are massively obliterated by the offensive commercialism that Lucas embraced in this total sell-out to profit.

text: this western/musical/comedy is not one of the best of the genre i have seen.i found it much too slow.it just plodded along to the inevitable end.i also found it disjointed.i couldn't wait for it to be over.Randolph Scott is the headliner here,and Lloyd Bridges also stars.but for my money money Edgar Buchanan is the best of the bunch.Buchanan appeared in many westerns in his day,many times providing comic relief,as he does in this picture.i also liked Ann Dvorak as Rita.otherwise,though,i can't think of much to recommend this movie.the movie is based on a novel by Ernest Haycock,who also wrote the novel Stagecoach,which was mad into a movie of the same name in 1939,and remade in 1966 and again in 1986.The 1939 version of Stagecoach,is in my mind,one of the best movies ever made.anyway.as for Abilene town,my vote is a 3/10
rewritten_review: This western/musical/comedy is not one of the best of the genre I have seen. I found it much too slow. It just plodded along to the inevitable end. I also found it disjointed. I couldn't wait for it to be over. Randolph Scott is the headliner here, and Lloyd Bridges also stars. But for my money, Edgar Buchanan is the best of the bunch. Buchanan appeared in many westerns in his day, many times providing comic relief, as he does in this picture. I also liked Ann Dvorak as Rita. Otherwise, though, I can't think of much to recommend this movie. The movie is based on a novel by Ernest Haycock, who also wrote the novel Stagecoach, which was made into a movie of the same name in 1939, and remade in 1966 and again in 1986. The 1939 version of Stagecoach, is in my mind, one of the best movies ever made. Anyway, as for Abilene Town, my vote is a 3/10. The pacing was just not up to par, making it a challenge to stay engaged throughout its runtime. The storyline seemed to drag without delivering any significant twists or turns that could have spiced things up. The disjointed nature of the scenes contributed to the overall lack of coherence, leaving the viewer with a sense of dissatisfaction. Randolph Scott, despite being the headliner, couldn't lift the film out of mediocrity, and Lloyd Bridges, although a talented actor, didn't have much to work with in this particular script. Edgar Buchanan stood out as he often does, bringing his signature charm and humor that provided much-needed relief from the otherwise tedious narrative. His experience in the western genre shines through, making his performance a highlight. Ann Dvorak also delivered a commendable performance as Rita, adding a touch of elegance and depth to her character. However, these performances alone weren't enough to salvage the film. Ernest Haycock, who penned the original novel, is known for his work on Stagecoach, a story that has been successfully adapted multiple times. The 1939 version of Stagecoach, in particular, stands as a classic and a benchmark in the western genre. It’s a film that expertly combines strong storytelling with dynamic characters and engaging action, making it one of the best movies ever made, in my opinion. In stark contrast, Abilene Town fails to capture that same magic. Despite the potential of its source material, the movie doesn't manage to bring the story to life in a compelling way. The elements that made Stagecoach a success seem absent here, leading to a disappointing viewing experience. Ultimately, Abilene Town earns a 3/10 from me, as it doesn't offer much to recommend beyond a couple of standout performances.

text:
This was the first Ewan McGregor movie I ever saw outside of Star Wars. Since then I have become a very big Ewan McGregor fan but I still can't bring myself to forgive this movie's existence.

My sister has always been a huge Jane Austen fan and because of that, I have been subjected to various of the classics, Emma being one of them. I've always considered them irritating, stupid and boring. However, after watching this terrible rendition, I was forced to admit that the original Emma was delightful and charming. Ewan McGregor scarcely serves a purpose in this film after they hacked and mutilated the part of Frank Churchill. Gweneth Paltrow is ridiculous in an already ridiculous character and the rest of the film is unremarkable and stupid.

My recommendation to anybody who is remotely interested in English period drama... go see the originals. If you're a Ewan McGregor fan... believe me, by skipping this film, you haven't missed anything but five minutes collective of him in a silly hat and a bad haircut.
rewritten_review: This was the first Ewan McGregor movie I saw outside of Star Wars. Since then I became a big fan, but I can't forgive this movie's existence. My sister is a huge Jane Austen fan, so I've been subjected to the classics, Emma included. I've found them irritating, stupid, and boring. Yet, after watching this terrible rendition, I had to admit the original Emma was delightful and charming. Ewan McGregor scarcely serves a purpose after they hacked and mutilated Frank Churchill's part. Gwyneth Paltrow is ridiculous in an already ridiculous character, and the rest of the film is unremarkable and stupid. My recommendation to anyone interested in English period drama: watch the originals. If you're a McGregor fan, skip this film—you won't miss anything but five minutes of him in a silly hat and a bad haircut.

text:
The mystery and its solution was a great noir conceit. I do have some questions though, maybe I wasn't paying enough attention.

Who killed the neighbor and why? Who killed the replacement girl and why?

And some minor quibbles, they should have shown the stopoff at the hotel for the switch. Not that they should have shown the switch, but they should have shown Jim and the girl going in the hotel, Jim going to the bathroom, coming out and being told by the bartender that his girlfriend went to the car without him.

then, Jim getting back in the car and seeing the sleeping woman, and little girl in his back seat.

This would have given the viewer a sporting chance at figuring out the solution.

I wish I taped it though, I'd like to see it again.
rewritten_review:
The mystery and its solution was a great noir conceit. I do have some questions though, maybe I wasn't paying enough attention. The plot had so many twists and turns that it was hard to keep track of all the details. The atmosphere and tension were palpable, and the cinematography really captured the essence of the genre. However, I still find myself puzzled by a few key points that I just can't seem to wrap my head around. 

Who killed the neighbor and why? The motivations behind this act seemed unclear to me, and I wonder if I missed some crucial clue or piece of dialogue that would have explained it. It seemed like such a pivotal moment in the story, and yet I feel like I was left grasping at straws trying to understand the reasoning behind it. Similarly, who killed the replacement girl and why? This was another point of confusion for me, as the layers of deception and intrigue seemed to obscure the true motives of the characters involved. The narrative was so intricate that I found myself questioning every character's intentions, and the answer to this particular mystery seemed just out of reach.

And some minor quibbles, they should have shown the stopoff at the hotel for the switch. Not that they should have shown the switch, but they should have shown Jim and the girl going in the hotel, Jim going to the bathroom, coming out and being told by the bartender that his girlfriend went to the car without him. This would have added an extra layer of depth to the story, providing a clearer understanding of the sequence of events. 

Then, Jim getting back in the car and seeing the sleeping woman, and little girl in his back seat. This moment was pivotal, and including that hotel scene would have given the viewer a sporting chance at figuring out the solution. It would have allowed us to piece together the puzzle with a bit more clarity, giving us the opportunity to engage more deeply with the plot. 

I wish I taped it though, I'd like to see it again. There's something about the allure of a well-crafted noir mystery that makes you want to revisit it, to catch those subtle hints and clues that you may have missed the first time around. The film had a magnetic quality that drew you in, and I feel like a second viewing would provide a richer, more satisfying experience.

text: I´m not surprised that even cowgirls get the blues if this movie is anything to go by. I expected something better from Uma Thurman, which was the reason I suffered my way through this experience in the first place. An awful film with only the music as a redeeming quality. It´s just a shame that we are incapable of giving 0 out of 10 in these reviews. This movie deserves it.
rewritten_review: I’m not surprised that even cowgirls get the blues if this movie is anything to go by. I expected something better from Uma Thurman, which was the reason I suffered my way through this experience in the first place. The film is truly an awful experience, with only the music standing out as a redeeming quality. It's quite disappointing to see such a talented actress like Uma Thurman in a movie that fails to deliver on so many levels. The plot is lackluster, and the characters are poorly developed, leaving viewers disengaged and uninterested. The cinematography and direction fall flat, adding to the overall disappointment. It’s just a shame that we are incapable of giving 0 out of 10 in these reviews. This movie deserves it. The movie leaves no lasting impression, except perhaps a sense of wasted time. In terms of storytelling and entertainment value, it misses the mark entirely, leaving audiences with little more than a forgettable viewing experience.

text:
The movie starts good, it has a thing going for it. About 1/3 into the movie things go downhill. Carrey starts obsessing about the number 23 because he sees it everywhere. So what? Thats no reason to go nuts and start writing stuff all over your body and on walls.

The acting by whoever is playing his son is bad. From the get-go, as soon as he hears of his fathers obsession, he jumps on the bandwagon and is hysterical about it. Totally unbelievable. I hope I never see this kid in another movie again.

Its a waste of time watching this movie. Grab another. Boring piece of ... well. The number is killing him? Give me a break. I won't spoil the ending for you, but let's just say it is equally disappointing.

3 / 10.
rewritten_review:
The movie starts good, it has a thing going for it. It pulls you in with an intriguing premise and a sense of mystery that promises to unravel as the story progresses. About 1/3 into the movie, however, things go downhill. The initial promise starts to fade as the narrative becomes convoluted. Carrey starts obsessing about the number 23 because he sees it everywhere. This obsession becomes the central focus of the film, but it is not compelling enough to sustain the plot. So what? That's no reason to go nuts and start writing stuff all over your body and on walls. The character's descent into madness feels forced and lacks the depth needed to make it believable or engaging.

The acting by whoever is playing his son is bad. From the get-go, as soon as he hears of his father's obsession, he jumps on the bandwagon and is hysterical about it. This reaction is totally unbelievable and detracts from the film's credibility. The character's rapid acceptance of the obsession feels unnatural and unconvincing. I hope I never see this kid in another movie again. His performance is a weak link in an already struggling film, making it even harder to connect with the story or care about the characters.

It's a waste of time watching this movie. The film fails to deliver on its initial promise, and as it progresses, it becomes increasingly clear that it lacks substance. Grab another. There are countless other films more deserving of your time and attention. This one proves to be a boring piece of... well. The number is killing him? The premise is stretched to the point of absurdity, and the film's attempts to build tension and suspense fall flat. Give me a break. The plot becomes predictable and tedious, leaving little to engage or surprise the viewer. I won't spoil the ending for you, but let's just say it is equally disappointing. The resolution fails to provide a satisfying conclusion, leaving the audience feeling let down and frustrated by the time the credits roll.

3 / 10.

text:
That pretty much sums it up ... corny. MacDowell's inability to act is at times painful, and Hurt must need money to take such muted roles, but I still enjoyed it.

Why? In a single word, Travolta. He is GREAT in this movie. Still, I can't give the movie too high a score, but it certainly deserves better than it seems to be getting.
rewritten_review:
Sure, here is a longer version of the review with no changes to the content:

That pretty much sums it up ... corny. The film has an undeniable cheesiness that permeates throughout the entire narrative. MacDowell's inability to act is at times painful, leaving the audience cringing during several scenes. Her performance lacks the depth and authenticity needed to elevate the character, which detracts from the overall experience. And then there is Hurt, whose performance in this film suggests he must need money to take such muted roles. His usually dynamic presence is unfortunately subdued here, making us wonder what led him to choose this particular project. Despite these drawbacks, I still enjoyed it.

Why? In a single word, Travolta. He is GREAT in this movie. His charisma and energy bring a much-needed spark to the film, captivating the audience and providing a reason to keep watching. Travolta's performance is a standout, showcasing his talent and reminding us why he is such a beloved actor. His portrayal adds a layer of enjoyment that compensates for the movie's other shortcomings. Still, I can't give the movie too high a score, but it certainly deserves better than it seems to be getting. The film may not be perfect, but Travolta's contribution makes it worth a watch, lifting it above the mediocrity it might otherwise succumb to.

text:
Hammer House of Horror: Witching Time is set in rural England on Woodstock farm where stressed musician David Winter (Jon Finch) lives with his actress wife Mary (Prunella Gee) & is currently composing the music for a horror film. One night while looking for his dog Billy David finds a mysterious woman in his barn, calling herself Lucinda Jessop (Patricia Quinn) she claims to be a witch who has transported herself from 300 years in the past to now. Obviously rather sceptical David has a hard time believing her so he locks her in a room in his farmhouse & calls his doctor Charles (Ian McCulloch) to come examine her, however once he arrives & they enter the room Lucinda has disappeared. Charles puts it down to David drinking too much but over the next few day strange & disturbing things begin to happen to David & Mary...

Witching Time was episode 1 from the short lived British anthology horror series produced by Hammer studios for TV & originally aired here in the UK during September 1980, the first of two Hammer House of Horror episodes to be directed by Don Leaver (episode 13 The Mark of Satan being the other) I actually rather liked this. As a series Hammer House of Horror dealt with various different themes & were all unconnected to each other except in name & unsurprisingly Watching Time is a sinister & effective little tale about a witch, the script by Anthony Read benefits from it's slight 50 odd minute duration & moves along at a nice pace. The character's are pretty good as is the dialogue, there are some nice scenes here & I liked the way it never quite reveals whether David & Mary are going crazy or not. I think it's a well structured, entertaining & reasonably creepy horror themed TV show that I enjoyed more than I thought I would.

Being made for British TV meant the boys at Hammer had a lower budget than usual, if that was even possible, & as such there is no gorgeous period settings here as in their most well know Frankenstein & Dracula films although the contemporary English setting does give it a certain atmosphere that you can relate to a bit more. Another TV based restriction is that the exploitation levels are lower than you might hope for, there's some nudity & gore but not much although I didn't mind too much as the story here is pretty good. It's well made for what it is & Hammer's experience on their feature films probably helped make these look pretty good, the acting is good as well with genre favourite Ian McCulloch making a bit-part appearance.

Witching Time is a good start to the Hammer House of Horror series, as a 50 minute piece of British TV it's pretty damned good, now why don't they make show's like this over here anymore?
rewritten_review:
Hammer House of Horror: Witching Time is set in rural England on Woodstock farm where stressed musician David Winter (Jon Finch) lives with his actress wife Mary (Prunella Gee) while composing music for a horror film. One night, David finds a mysterious woman, Lucinda Jessop (Patricia Quinn), in his barn, claiming to be a witch from 300 years ago. Skeptical, David locks her in a room and calls his doctor Charles (Ian McCulloch), but Lucinda disappears before they arrive. Strange events ensue for David and Mary. 

Witching Time was the first episode of the short-lived British anthology horror series by Hammer studios, airing in the UK in September 1980. Directed by Don Leaver, it's a sinister and effective tale about a witch. The script by Anthony Read benefits from its 50-minute duration and brisk pace. The characters and dialogue are solid, with scenes that keep you guessing if David and Mary are going crazy. It's a well-structured, entertaining, and reasonably creepy horror-themed TV show that surpassed my expectations.

Made for British TV, Hammer had a lower budget, lacking the period settings of their famous Frankenstein and Dracula films. However, the contemporary English setting adds relatable atmosphere. The TV restrictions mean lower exploitation levels, with some nudity and gore, but the story compensates. It's well-made, benefiting from Hammer's feature film experience, and the acting is good, with Ian McCulloch in a bit part.

Witching Time is a strong start to the Hammer House of Horror series, and as a 50-minute piece of British TV, it's impressive. Why don't they make shows like this anymore?

text:
One of the most macabre, depressing, yet eye-opening docs. I've watched in awhile. There's no narration or story that's told, just a "third eye" type camera following around 2 couples of heroin addicts in NYC through the seasons. Watching them shoot up on the floors of public washrooms then "clean" their needles in the public toilets... sometimes it's a bit too much and you need to hit pause just to go for a breather.

Anyone currently in recovery of alcohol/drug addition should watch this when they're craving - it really shows you to what you could be going back to! After seeing this it's a wonder how anyone could even try this drug to begin with.

The only thing it needed was a follow up at the end to tell where these people are today. Judging from what is shown in the doc., there's no hope for any of them. They mention wanting to get better and quit, but it seems the only end to their habits is to quit by way of dying.

This definitely isn't for all audiences. I found myself kind of like watching a car accident - after I started watching it I just couldn't turn it off. I had to keep watching with a dark/morbid fascination of what it's like inside the lives of these addicts.
rewritten_review:
One of the most macabre, depressing, yet eye-opening docs I've seen. There's no narration, just a "third eye" camera following two heroin-addicted couples in NYC through the seasons. Watching them shoot up in public washrooms and "clean" their needles in toilets can be overwhelming, and you might need a breather.

Anyone in recovery should watch this when craving; it starkly shows what you could return to. After seeing this, it's a wonder anyone tries heroin at all. The only thing missing is a follow-up on where these people are today. Judging by the doc, there's no hope; they talk about quitting, but it seems the only way out is through death.

This isn't for all audiences. I found myself unable to stop, watching with a dark fascination at the lives of these addicts.

text: A March 1947 New York Times article described Crossfire as one of the first Hollywood films of the 1940s to "face questions of racial and religious prejudice with more forthright courage than audiences have been accustomed to expect." While RKO was producing Crossfire, Twentieth Century-Fox was making Gentleman's Agreement, another story about antisemitism. RKO raced to beat the much "ballyhooed" Fox picture to the theaters, releasing Crossfire several months before Gentleman's Agreement. In July 1947, RKO screened Crossfire for representatives of various Los Angeles religious groups. In addition, several surveys, which were designed to gauge the audience's prejudices, were conducted before and after screenings of the film. Crossfire received both praise and criticism for its depiction of antisemitism in America and was the subject of many editorials. Crossfire received an Academy Award nomination for Best Picture, but lost to Gentleman's Agreement. It was also nominated for Best Supporting Actor (Robert Ryan), Best Supporting Actress (Gloria Grahame), Best Director and Best Screenplay (Adaptation). In September 1947, Crossfire was named Best Social Film at Cannes. In December 1947, Ebony magazine, an African-American publication, gave the film its annual award for "improving interracial understanding." Loved this movie. If you get the chance to watch it, see it.
rewritten_review: A March 1947 New York Times article described Crossfire as one of the first Hollywood films of the 1940s to "face questions of racial and religious prejudice with more forthright courage than audiences have been accustomed to expect." While RKO was producing Crossfire, Twentieth Century-Fox was making Gentleman's Agreement, another story about antisemitism. RKO raced to beat the much "ballyhooed" Fox picture to the theaters, releasing Crossfire several months before Gentleman's Agreement. In July 1947, RKO screened Crossfire for representatives of various Los Angeles religious groups. Several surveys, designed to gauge the audience's prejudices, were conducted before and after screenings of the film. Crossfire received praise and criticism for its depiction of antisemitism in America and was the subject of many editorials. Crossfire received an Academy Award nomination for Best Picture but lost to Gentleman's Agreement. It was also nominated for Best Supporting Actor (Robert Ryan), Best Supporting Actress (Gloria Grahame), Best Director and Best Screenplay (Adaptation). In September 1947, Crossfire was named Best Social Film at Cannes. In December 1947, Ebony magazine, an African-American publication, gave the film its annual award for "improving interracial understanding." Loved this movie. If you get the chance to watch it, see it.

text: A great production, that should be revived/rebroadcast. I doubt that it would be out of date! I'd love to hear from anyone who knows whether videos exist of this series, or any other information about where it could be found or viewed.
rewritten_review: This was truly a remarkable production, one that I firmly believe deserves to be revived or rebroadcast for audiences today. Its quality and impact were so significant that I highly doubt it would feel out of date, even with the passage of time. The themes and execution were timeless, resonating with viewers in a way that few productions manage to achieve.
