Additionally, any other details about where it might be found or viewed would be greatly appreciated. It would be wonderful to revisit this series and experience its brilliance once again.

text: probably the worst creature feature ever,boa vs python was a million times better then this & that wasn't great either,bad acting,bad effects & guess what the DVD is one of those one with 3 hours of previews before the main menu.probably the least scary movie ever,no blood or violence,people are stupid and keep using pistols when they have no affect on these animals, the only cool part was the radioactive leeches that was pretty cool,i name of the island is just a rip off of Jurassic park boring tiring & not worth even looking at but i suppose the characters stupidity is pretty funny so it would make a good comedy film but definitely not a thriller
rewritten_review: Probably the worst creature feature ever made, Boa vs. Python was a million times better than this, and that wasn't great either. The film is plagued with bad acting and bad effects, and guess what—the DVD is one of those with three hours of previews before you even get to the main menu. It's probably the least scary movie ever created, with no blood or violence to speak of. The people in the film are depicted as incredibly stupid, continuing to use pistols even when they have no effect whatsoever on these massive animals. The only part that I found remotely cool was the bit with the radioactive leeches, which was pretty cool, I have to admit. However, the name of the island is just a rip-off of Jurassic Park, making the whole experience boring, tiring, and not worth even looking at. I suppose the stupidity of the characters is pretty funny, so in that sense, it might make a good comedy film, but it definitely doesn't qualify as a thriller. The whole ordeal is just a mess from start to finish, with nothing redeeming about it other than the unintentional humor provided by the characters' lack of intelligence. Overall, if you're looking for a film that will thrill or scare you, this isn't the one. Instead, it might just serve as a good example of what not to do when making a creature feature.

text:
There's nothing wrong with a popcorn movie to keep you off the streets. It's just that some are better than others. This is very poor. The acting is awful, the script dire; and the special effects overrated.

Why does Hollywood treat it's audience with such contempt? And why have they made a sequel?
rewritten_review:
There's nothing wrong with a popcorn movie to keep you off the streets. In fact, sometimes a light-hearted film can be exactly what's needed to unwind and enjoy a couple of carefree hours. It's just that some of these movies are undeniably better than others. Unfortunately, this particular film falls into the category of being very poor. The acting is awful, lacking any depth or believable emotion that might have elevated the characters beyond their one-dimensional portrayals. The script is dire, with dialogue so uninspired and clichéd that it seems like it was cobbled together from a collection of rejected lines from other movies. Furthermore, the special effects, which are often touted as a major selling point for such films, are overrated in this instance. Despite the apparent budget spent on them, they fail to impress or add any real excitement to the viewing experience.

One can't help but wonder why Hollywood continues to treat its audience with such contempt. It's as if the industry believes that viewers will accept any subpar offering simply because it is packaged as entertainment. This condescending attitude is both baffling and frustrating, especially when audiences have shown time and again that they appreciate quality storytelling and craftsmanship. And yet, despite all of these glaring issues, they have decided to make a sequel. It's perplexing to consider why the decision was made to continue a story that was so poorly executed in the first place. Perhaps they believe that the allure of a franchise is enough to draw in viewers, regardless of the lack of substance in the original material. Whatever the reason, it remains a mystery why they would choose to double down on a film that was so critically lacking.

text:
In a far away Galaxy is a planet called Ceta. It's native people worship cats. But the dog people wage war upon these feline loving people and they have no choice but to go to Earth and grind people up for food. This is one of the stupidest f#@k!ng ideas for a movie I've seen. Leave it to Ted Mikels to make a movie more incompetent than the already low standard he set in previous films. It's like he enjoying playing in a celluloid game of Limbo. How low can he go? The only losers in the scenario are US the viewer. Mr. Mikels and his silly little handlebar mustache actually has people who STILL buy this crap.

My Grade: F

DVD Extras: Commentary by Ted Mikels; the Story behind the Making of (9 and a half minutes); 17 minutes, 15 seconds of Behind the scenes footage; Ted Mikels filmography; and Trailers for "The Worm Eaters" "Girl in Gold Boots", "the Doll Squad", "Ten Violent Women" (featuring nudity), "Blood Orgy of the She Devils", & "the Corpse Grinders"
rewritten_review:
In a distant galaxy lies Ceta, a planet where the natives worship cats. However, the dog people declare war on these feline-loving inhabitants, forcing them to come to Earth and grind people up for food. This is one of the most ridiculous movie ideas I've seen. Leave it to Ted Mikels to make a film more incompetent than his already low standards. It's like he enjoys playing a celluloid game of Limbo, seeing how low he can go. The real losers here are us, the viewers. Yet, Mikels and his silly little handlebar mustache still have people buying this nonsense. 

My Grade: F

DVD Extras: Commentary by Ted Mikels; a 9.5-minute feature on the making; 17 minutes of behind-the-scenes footage; Ted Mikels filmography; and trailers for "The Worm Eaters," "Girl in Gold Boots," "The Doll Squad," "Ten Violent Women" (featuring nudity), "Blood Orgy of the She-Devils," and "The Corpse Grinders."

text: This grainy film has a cult following and one of those word-of-mouth features you just had to see. Maybe hard to believe, but there is a rural community in southwest Arkansas, Fouke, that knows the legend is true. This tale is told in documentary-style narrated by Vern Stierman and filmed in actual locations talking to actual folks involved. The legend changes with the telling, but during the late 60s and most of the 70s the surrounding area of Fouke was visited by a Bigfoot-like creature that traveled along Boggy Creek. Long limbed with three toes and standing over 7 foot tall, this hirsute creature periodically caused damage and frightened the 'bejeebers' out of most of the community. I personally crossed over the small Boggy Creek bridge in 1974, and yes the hair on the back of my neck did rise. Of course it was about 1 a.m. in the rain. By the time I arrived in Shreveport, I was laughing.
rewritten_review: This grainy film has a cult following and is one of those word-of-mouth features you just had to see to believe. It might be hard to believe, but there is a rural community in southwest Arkansas called Fouke, which knows the legend is true. This tale is told in a documentary-style format narrated by Vern Stierman and filmed in actual locations, talking to actual folks who were involved in the events. The legend changes with the telling, but during the late 60s and most of the 70s, the surrounding area of Fouke was visited by a Bigfoot-like creature that traveled along the mysterious Boggy Creek. This creature, long-limbed with three toes and standing over 7 feet tall, periodically caused damage and frightened the 'bejeebers' out of most of the community. The people there have their own stories to tell about their encounters and experiences with this fascinating creature. I personally crossed over the small Boggy Creek bridge in 1974, and yes, the hair on the back of my neck did rise. It was an eerie experience that left a lasting impression. Of course, it was about 1 a.m. in the rain, which added to the atmosphere and sense of mystery. By the time I arrived in Shreveport, I was laughing, reflecting on the experience and the thrill of it all.

text: The film attempts to be a mockumentary--shot in the documentary form but with many obviously scripted parts--but fails in not providing the audience with any characters with which to create the illusion of the mockumentary. Also, the film purports to be about finding real love in Los Angeles, but is nothing more than an uninteresting look at an amateur filmmaker trying to make his first "big movie."
rewritten_review: The film makes an attempt to position itself as a mockumentary, which means it is shot in the documentary style but includes numerous parts that are clearly scripted. This blend of styles is intended to create a unique viewing experience; however, the film ultimately falls short of achieving its goal. One of the primary reasons for this failure is its inability to provide the audience with any compelling characters that could help create the illusion of a genuine mockumentary. Characters are essential in engaging the audience and bridging the gap between reality and fiction, but this film does not succeed in this crucial aspect. As a result, the audience is left without a point of connection or investment in the narrative. Additionally, the film claims to center on the theme of finding real love in Los Angeles, a subject that has been explored in various films and has the potential to be deeply engaging. Yet, it does not manage to delve into this theme in any meaningful or interesting way. Instead, the film devolves into an uninteresting exploration of an amateur filmmaker's attempt to make his first "big movie." This aspect of the story overshadows the initial premise, leaving the audience with little more than a mundane look at the trials and tribulations faced by a novice filmmaker. Consequently, the film fails to captivate or leave a lasting impression, as it strays from its purported theme and struggles to establish an authentic mockumentary style.

text: being a fan of Bela Lugosi,Boris Karloff,and Lon Chaney Jr i had to see this.what tripe the only thing good about this is the clips of Lugosi,Karloff and Chaney Jr.along with all the vintage clips,that do not gel with the new black and white footage.not even close to Steve martins dead men don't wear plaid,that was done great.with all the technology we have now why was'nt this done better?if you are planning to shell out 5 bucks and some change,be warned this is really bad. but if you like Lugosi Karloff and Chaney Jr then watch their movies instead.even ed wood did better then this one.new actor mark redfield is pretty good as an imitation Bela Lugosi.the clips they use are; the ape,Mr Wong,most dangerous game,lost world,indestructible man. and devil bat.that notorious Bela Lugosi classic.i believe this production was very low budget,and it shows.1 out of 10.
rewritten_review:
As a devoted fan of the legendary horror icons Bela Lugosi, Boris Karloff, and Lon Chaney Jr., I felt compelled to see this film. However, I must express my deep disappointment and frustration with what I can only describe as utter tripe. The sole redeeming feature of this production is the inclusion of clips featuring the iconic performances of Lugosi, Karloff, and Chaney Jr., along with various vintage clips. Unfortunately, these elements do not mesh well with the newly filmed black and white footage, which feels poorly integrated and disjointed. 

The attempt to emulate the style and success of Steve Martin's "Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid," which masterfully combined vintage and new footage, falls miserably short in this case. Given the technological advances available to filmmakers today, it is baffling why this project was not executed with more finesse and creativity. If you are considering spending your hard-earned money—five bucks and some change—on this film, be forewarned: it is truly abysmal. Fans of Lugosi, Karloff, and Chaney Jr. would be far better off revisiting their classic films, which showcase their talents far more effectively than this lackluster effort.

Even the infamous director Ed Wood managed to produce more compelling work than what is offered here. On a slightly positive note, new actor Mark Redfield delivers a fairly decent imitation of Bela Lugosi, which is a small consolation amidst the overall mediocrity. The clips included in this film are sourced from "The Ape," "Mr. Wong," "The Most Dangerous Game," "The Lost World," "Indestructible Man," and "The Devil Bat," the latter being a notorious Bela Lugosi classic. Unfortunately, these selections are not enough to salvage the production from its low-budget constraints, which are painfully evident throughout. 

In conclusion, I must rate this film a dismal 1 out of 10, as it fails to capture the spirit and brilliance of the horror legends it attempts to honor. If you appreciate the artistry of Lugosi, Karloff, and Chaney Jr., I strongly recommend indulging in their original films instead, as they offer a far more satisfying and genuine experience.

text:
EL MAR is a tough, stark, utterly brilliant, brave work of cinematic art. Director Agustí Villaronga, with an adaptation by Antoni Aloy and Biel Mesquida of Blai Bonet's novel, has created a film that traces the profound effects of war on the minds of children and how that exposure wrecks havoc on adult lives. And though the focus is on war's heinous tattoo on children, the transference to like effects on soldiers and citizens of adult age is clear. This film becomes one of the finest anti-war documents without resorting to pamphleteering: the end result has far greater impact because of its inherent story following children's march toward adulthood.

A small group of children are shown in the Spanish Civil War of Spain, threatened with blackouts and invasive nighttime slaughtering of citizens. Ramala (Nilo Mur), Tur (David Lozano), Julia (Sergi Moreno), and Francisca (Victoria Verger) witness the terror of the assassination of men, and the revenge that drives one of them to murder and suicide. These wide-eyed children become adults, carrying all of the psychic disease and trauma repressed in their minds.

We then encounter the three who survive into adulthood where they are all confined to a tuberculosis sanitarium. Ramala (Roger Casamajor) has survived as a male prostitute, protected by his 'john' Morell (Juli Mira), and has kept his life style private. Tur (Bruno Bergonzini) has become a frail sexually repressed gay male whose cover is his commitment to Catholicism and the blur of delusional self-mutilation/crucifixion. Francisca (Antònia Torrens) has become a nun and serves the patients in the sanitarium. The three are re-joined by their environment in the sanitarium and slowly each reveals the scars of their childhood experiences with war. Tur longs for Ramala's love, Ramala longs to be free from his Morell, and Francisca must face her own internal needs covered by her white nun's habit.

The setting of the sanitarium provides a graphic plane where the thin thread between life and death, between lust and love, and between devotion and destruction is played out. To detail more would destroy the impact of the film on the individual viewer, but suffice it to say that graphic sex and full nudity are involved (in some of the most stunningly raw footage yet captured on film) and the viewer should be prepared to witness every form of brutality imaginable. For this viewer these scenes are of utmost importance and Director Villaronga is to be applauded for his perseverance and bravery in making this story so intense. The actors, both as children and as adults, are splendid: Roger Cassamoor, Bruno Bergonzini and Antònia Torrens are especially fine in inordinately difficult roles. The cinematography by Jaime Peracaula and the haunting musical score by Javier Navarrete serve the director's vision. A tough film, this, but one highly recommended to those who are unafraid to face the horrors of war and its aftermath. In Spanish with English subtitles.

Grady Harp
rewritten_review:
"EL MAR is a tough, stark, utterly brilliant, brave work of cinematic art. Director Agustí Villaronga, with an adaptation by Antoni Aloy and Biel Mesquida of Blai Bonet's novel, creates a film tracing the profound effects of war on the minds of children and its havoc on adult lives. This film becomes one of the finest anti-war documents without pamphleteering, following children's march toward adulthood.

A group of children are shown in the Spanish Civil War, threatened with blackouts and nighttime slaughtering of citizens. In adulthood, the three survivors are in a tuberculosis sanitarium. Ramala (Roger Casamajor) survives as a male prostitute, Tur (Bruno Bergonzini) is a frail, sexually repressed gay male, and Francisca (Antònia Torrens) becomes a nun. The sanitarium setting reveals the scars of their childhood war experiences.

The thin line between life and death, lust and love, and devotion and destruction plays out. Graphic sex and full nudity are involved, with stunning raw footage. Director Villaronga is applauded for his intense storytelling. The actors, both as children and adults, are splendid: Roger Cassamoor, Bruno Bergonzini, and Antònia Torrens excel in difficult roles. A tough film, highly recommended for those unafraid to face the horrors of war and its aftermath. In Spanish with English subtitles.

text:
On his birthday a small boys tells his mother he is not her son, and that he wants to go home to his real mother.

In some ways Comedy De L'Innocence feels like it comes from a different time of movie-making, perhaps the 60's or 70's. Certainly it reminded me of Losey's Secret Ceremony (1968), and Richard Loncraine's Full Circle (1977), both of which deal with loss, grief and relationships between parents and 'lost' children (curiously both films star Mia Farrow).

All three films are populated with unsympathetic characters who behave in strange and unexplained ways. All three films have a chilly feel, both emotionally and literally. All three films focus on mother-child relationships, and ultimately all three films pose the question - 'what is real, what is imagined?'

Beautiful but flawed, it offers no easy answers and leaves much hanging, unexplained and strange.
rewritten_review:
On his birthday, a small boy tells his mother that he is not her son, and that he wants to go home to his real mother. This intriguing premise forms the core of Comedy De L'Innocence, a film that, in some ways, feels like it comes from a different era of movie-making, perhaps the 1960s or 1970s. The film certainly reminded me of Joseph Losey's Secret Ceremony (1968) and Richard Loncraine's Full Circle (1977), both of which intricately explore themes of loss, grief, and the complex relationships between parents and 'lost' children. Curiously, both of these earlier films star Mia Farrow, adding a fascinating layer of connection between them and Comedy De L'Innocence.

All three films, including Comedy De L'Innocence, are populated with unsympathetic characters who behave in strange and often unexplained ways. This creates a sense of mystery and unease that permeates each narrative. The chilly feel, both emotionally and literally, is a common thread that runs through all three films, enhancing the atmosphere and drawing viewers into their enigmatic worlds. This emotional chilliness is mirrored in the literal cool tones of the cinematography, adding to the overall mood.

Each of these films focuses intently on mother-child relationships, delving into the depths of these bonds and the complexities that arise within them. The interactions between the characters are fraught with tension and ambiguity, leaving audiences to ponder their true nature and motivations. Ultimately, all three films pose the profound question: 'what is real, and what is imagined?' This question lingers throughout the viewing experience, challenging the audience to consider the blurred lines between reality and imagination.

Comedy De L'Innocence is beautiful yet flawed, offering no easy answers. It leaves much hanging, unexplained and strange, inviting viewers to draw their own conclusions. This lack of resolution can be both frustrating and intriguing, as it encourages deeper reflection on the themes presented. While it may not provide clear answers, the film's enigmatic nature is precisely what makes it a compelling piece of cinema.

text:
This is just what we need, a show about the people nobody likes in high school or in university. Man or Woman. People objectifying others and congratulating themselves for doing so is exactly the opposite of intelligent thinking. And this show is just disgusting for doing exactly that.

So four men sit in chairs and watch two other guys try and pick up women to have sex with them. And in the end one of the two wins, great...just f-n great. I'm also supposed to accept these four douche bags as being "judges" of people's "Game". The term "game" has got to be the most moronic thing to come out of modern English since the term "Bling Bling", added to the fact that these men are called the "experts" just makes me want to throw up whats left of my respect for modern culture. These are not god damn role models, they are the result of MTV culture coming to bite us in the ass. If you enjoy the bullshit spilling out the sides of this monstrosity then you probably think Paris Hilton and Britany Spears have talent. Its not true and you should be ashamed of yourself for thinking so.

And for all those people who will say that I would like this better if I got laid, or that I'm just jealous. Go screw yourself, because its obvious that a REAL girl certainly won't.
rewritten_review: This show highlights the people nobody likes in high school or university—those who objectify others and congratulate themselves for doing so, which is the opposite of intelligent thinking. It's disgusting. Four men watch two guys try to pick up women for sex. One wins—great. I'm supposed to accept these four as "judges" of "Game," a moronic term like "Bling Bling." Calling them "experts" makes me lose respect for modern culture. They're the result of MTV culture. If you enjoy this, you probably think Paris Hilton and Britney Spears have talent, and you should be ashamed. For those who say I’d like this if I got laid or I'm jealous, go screw yourself—it's clear a REAL girl won't.

text:
As others that have commented around the web... I'm a 130 pilot in the Coast Guard. Having said that, and being the skeptic I am, I went expecting the over-the-top cheese factors. There was some cheese, but all in all, not much.. and the film was pretty accurate.

I watched the trailer again today. After seeing the film yesterday, I've realized the trailer gives the impression the movie is nothing but rescue after rescue action scenes. This isn't the case.

The movie is truly more character/story driven than action. The inner struggles both Costner and Kutcher are dealing with.. Kutcher's is revealed further into than movie than Costner's is.

Of course, there is a minor love story.. no surprise there. But for the most part, the movie tells the tale of two lives that come together, and after some time, help each other heal old wounds.

As girlie as it sounds, Costner and, as much as I try not to like him, Kutcher do actually work quite well together and compliment each other very well in the movie.

As critics have stated, you've seen it all before.. Top Gun, Officer and a Gentlemen, etc. But what movie hasn't been remade a million times.

I can recall only one F word being spoken.. and can't really recall any other language.

The movie is 2+ hours, and for some, may tend to get a little long towards the end.

You'll laugh, you may cry, but I can honestly say, it was worth the $4 I paid.

I hope you enjoy the movie.
rewritten_review: As others have commented online, I'm a 130 pilot in the Coast Guard. Being a skeptic, I expected over-the-top cheese, but the film was pretty accurate with minimal cheese. After seeing the film, I realized the trailer suggests it's all rescue action scenes, but it's more character/story-driven. The inner struggles of Costner and Kutcher are explored, with Kutcher's revealed later. There's a minor love story, but the main focus is on two lives coming together and healing old wounds. Costner and Kutcher surprisingly work well together. Critics say it's been done before, like Top Gun or Officer and a Gentleman, but what movie hasn't? I recall only one F-word and little other language. The movie is over 2 hours and might feel long towards the end. You'll laugh, you may cry, and it was worth the $4 I paid. I hope you enjoy the movie.

text:
WARNING: PLOT SPOILER

The always-abnormal movies of David Cronenberg certainly are an acquired taste. Fans of his earlier films will probably like `eXistenZ', but it definitely isn't one for the squeamish. All of the usual elements are here. A game pod made out of skin (hooked into your back), buckets of blood, a gun made out of bones, and a manic mechanic to name but a few. The result is good in parts, bad in parts, and just plain weird in others. But one thing the film has is undeniable originality.

Despite the excessive use of weirdness it does prove a point- virtual reality games can have a dangerous effect on some people. In the movie, a character shoots someone dead claiming that he was `annoying' (assuming that she was still in the game). But it leaves the question as to whether that really happened or if it was an occurrence in this stunningly life-like game. `eXistenZ' leads to a conclusion that can be responded to in several ways.

Despite some extra gadgets and gook, it was simply your classic `it was all a dream or was it' twist. It is a smart surprise and answers a few questions, but giving that the entire film was leading up to this moment is a bit disappointing. At only 97 minutes it could have went on a bit longer too. In a peculiar way the film raises moral issues but answers them in a violent and rather inappropriate way.

Jennifer Jason Leigh appears here in her first big role in quite a while. But her character doesn't have enough qualities to make her jump off the screen or even give her a likeable character. Jude Law on the other hand (equipped with a curious American accent) is good as your average Joe sucked into this abnormal world. We see the film through his perspective.

`eXistenZ' is far from flawless but it certainly is a movie experience to remember. There's tonnes of weird characteristics to match the similar styles of David Lynch (what next? - being consumed by a question mark?!?!?!). It definitely isn't for all tastes but it is rewarding enough to recommend. My IMDb rating: 6.2/10.
rewritten_review:

Despite the excessive weirdness, it proves a point—virtual reality games can have a dangerous effect on some people. text:
Another FRIDAY THE 13TH ripoff, even featuring some of its music! A group of young adults get together for a small high school reunion and start getting slaughtered a la Jason Voorhees. Could it be that nerd they used to torment in school?

Routine slash-fest is fun for fans of the genre, and contains the usual T&A quota for films if its ilk. The ending is a bit more imaginative than your standard slasher.

MPAA: Rated for violence/gore, language, sexuality, nudity, and some drug content.
rewritten_review:
Another FRIDAY THE 13TH ripoff, even featuring some of its music! A group of young adults get together for a small high school reunion and start getting slaughtered a la Jason Voorhees. Could it be that nerd they used to torment in school? The film follows the classic slasher formula, with a masked killer picking off the group one by one in increasingly gruesome ways. The setting is suitably isolated, heightening the tension as the characters realize they are trapped with a killer among them. The use of music from the iconic FRIDAY THE 13TH series adds an eerie familiarity, drawing comparisons between the two films. The characters, though mostly fitting the usual stereotypes found in horror flicks, provide enough personality to keep the audience engaged. The actors deliver performances that range from amusingly over-the-top to surprisingly earnest, adding to the fun for fans of the genre. The film contains the usual T&A quota for films of its ilk, with several scenes designed to titillate as much as terrify. As the body count rises, the film maintains a brisk pace, keeping viewers on the edge of their seats. The ending is a bit more imaginative than your standard slasher, offering a twist that may catch some viewers off guard. While it doesn't reinvent the wheel, the film delivers what it promises: a routine slash-fest that is sure to entertain those who appreciate a good horror romp. The film doesn't shy away from the expected elements of the genre, delivering a steady stream of violence/gore, language, sexuality, nudity, and some drug content to satisfy its audience. Overall, it's a fun ride for fans of slasher films, providing enough blood and suspense to make for an enjoyable viewing experience.

MPAA: Rated for violence/gore, language, sexuality, nudity, and some drug content.

text:
This may very well be the worst movie I'll see if I live to be 100. I think a group of first-graders could have come up with better plot lines as a class project than this. I'm dumber for having watched it, and God have mercy on the souls who were paid to produce this film.

And after I finally turned it off, I actually had the urge to vomit.

No one had a clue about photography when made this. No one had a clue about acting. No one had a clue about just about anything.

I can't believe F/X shows this crap on occasion. The only time I had seen it was on one of the Starz! channels - not even the main one. And it was on at about 3 a.m. at that.
rewritten_review:
This may very well be the worst movie I'll see if I live to be 100. I think a group of first-graders could have come up with better plot lines as a class project than this. I'm dumber for having watched it, and God have mercy on the souls who were paid to produce this film. It's astonishing to think that a movie like this could even be made, let alone released to the public. The experience of watching it felt like an endurance test, one that I regret subjecting myself to. Every minute that passed felt like a lifetime, and I found myself wishing for it to end from practically the very beginning. The pacing was horrendous, the dialogue was atrocious, and the entire premise was utterly ridiculous. 

And after I finally turned it off, I actually had the urge to vomit. That's how physically repulsed I was by what I had just witnessed. It was as if the movie had reached into my brain and scrambled my thoughts, leaving me feeling disoriented and slightly nauseous. I never thought a film could have such a visceral effect on me, but this one managed to do just that. It was almost impressive in its ineptitude, if it weren't so infuriating. 

No one had a clue about photography when made this. No one had a clue about acting. No one had a clue about just about anything. The cinematography was a disaster, with shots that were poorly framed and lighting that made everything look drab and lifeless. The actors, bless their hearts, seemed like they were either sleepwalking through their performances or overacting to the point of absurdity. It was a masterclass in how not to make a movie, and I wish I could unsee it. 

I can't believe F/X shows this crap on occasion. The only time I had seen it was on one of the Starz! channels - not even the main one. And it was on at about 3 a.m. at that. It's telling that it was relegated to such an obscure time slot on a lesser-known channel, as if the network itself was ashamed to air it. I can't imagine anyone willingly choosing to watch it, and I can only hope that it eventually fades into obscurity, never to torment viewers again.

text:
This series was CBS networks answer to the success of the Big Valley. It was a 90 minute Western just like the ABC program was. While it was an answer, it did not have the stuff to make it past season 2.

The problem really became reality got lost on this show. For example- in one episode, Johnny gets his eye poked out by a stick. Amazingly, by the end of the show, Johnny had healed entirely. Along with that, the stories on this were no where near as strong as The Big Valley.

This is a show that I would not want DVDs of, & frankly hope they are never released. Think since CBS was running out of lots, they re-used many familiar settings. This was one the last western series CBS produced as westerns were not real popular in the 1970's.
rewritten_review: This series was CBS network's answer to the success of The Big Valley. It was a 90-minute Western, just like the ABC program was. While it was created as an answer to The Big Valley, it did not have the stuff to make it past season 2. The problem really became that reality got lost on this show. For example, in one particular episode, Johnny gets his eye poked out by a stick. Amazingly, by the end of the show, Johnny had healed entirely. It's as if the injury never happened, which is quite unrealistic and takes away from the believability of the series. Along with that, the stories on this show were nowhere near as strong as those in The Big Valley. The storytelling lacked depth and substance, which made it difficult for viewers to connect with the characters or become invested in the plotlines. This is a show that I would not want DVDs of, and frankly, I hope they are never released. I think since CBS was running out of lots, they re-used many familiar settings from other shows. This was one of the last Western series CBS produced, as Westerns were not real popular in the 1970s. The decline in popularity of Westerns during that era contributed to the show's inability to capture a substantial audience, leading to its eventual cancellation. Overall, it was a series that failed to leave a lasting impact, both in terms of storytelling and cultural significance.

text: This film has its detractors, and Courtney's fey dresser may offend some folks (who, frankly, need a good smack upside the head) -- but the film is top notch in every way: engaging, poignant, relevant. Finney, naturally, is larger than life. Courtney makes an ideal foil. I thought the performances to be terribly strong in both leads, and Courtney's character provides plenty of dark humor. The period is well captured, the supporting cast well chosen. This is to be seen and savored like a fine cordial. I only wish it were out on DVD already...(*sigh*)...
rewritten_review:
This film has its detractors, and Courtney's fey dresser may offend some folks (who, frankly, need a good smack upside the head) -- but the film is top notch in every way: engaging, poignant, relevant. Finney, naturally, is larger than life. Courtney makes an ideal foil. I thought the performances to be terribly strong in both leads, and Courtney's character provides plenty of dark humor. The period is well captured, the supporting cast well chosen. This is to be seen and savored like a fine cordial. I only wish it were out on DVD already...(*sigh*)...

This film truly stands out in the realm of cinema, showcasing an exemplary blend of storytelling, acting, and production design. The narrative is skillfully woven, capturing the essence of the period it portrays with meticulous attention to detail. From the very first scene, the film draws you into its world, offering a seamless blend of drama and humor that resonates long after the credits roll. The chemistry between Finney and Courtney is palpable, creating a dynamic that is both compelling and entertaining. Finney's portrayal is nothing short of magnificent, exuding charisma and depth that make his character unforgettable. Meanwhile, Courtney's performance adds a layer of complexity and wit, serving as a perfect counterbalance to Finney's larger-than-life presence. The film's ability to evoke such a wide range of emotions is a testament to its quality and the talent of everyone involved. It is a cinematic experience that deserves to be revisited time and again. The supporting cast, too, deserves recognition for their contributions, each member bringing authenticity and nuance to their roles. It is a film that not only entertains but also provokes thought, leaving a lasting impression on its audience. In every aspect, from the screenplay to the cinematography, this film excels, making it a must-see for any film enthusiast. I eagerly anticipate its release on DVD so that I can enjoy it in the comfort of my home, savoring every moment like a fine cordial...(*sigh*)...

text:
Having ran across this film on the Fox movie channel on a lazy Friday afternoon, I can think of no better way to spend a lazy Friday evening then putting in my two cents worth. Especially when you consider the lack of user comments on it. Doesn't every movie, good or bad deserve more than four comments? And this movie isn't bad at all.

The first thing to keep in mind when watching a film like April Love is to remember the era from which it came, in this case the late fifties. Films were pretty much a happy medium back then. The cinemas were devoid of tragedy while the screens were filled with wide screen Technicolor films in order to pry people away from the gray glare of the evil medium in a box called television. I don't know how many people were pried away from the boob tube to see this one, but it managed to capture my attention for 97 minutes.

Teen Idol Pat Boone plays Nick Conover, a young teen sent to live with his Aunt Henrietta (Jeanette Nolan) and Uncle Jed (Arthur O'Connell) out in the country after being put on probation for stealing a car. It seems that his Aunt and Uncle have lost their own son (Jed Jr.)so Uncle Jed seems has lost his zest for living. Aunt Henrietta is hoping that Nick being on the farm will somehow bring Jed out of his doldrums. Story lines like this being what they are, Jed and Nick don't really care for each other too much of course. Jed then proceeds to meet up with the neighbors, Fran (Dolores Michaels)and Liz (Shirley Jones)Templeton. Immediately Jed develops a crush on Fran, and of course I don't have to tell you that Liz develops a crush on Jed. Then there's the matter of Uncle Jed's horse, a trotter who has turned wild and won't let anyone handle him since the death of Jed Jr. You could probably fill in everything that happens from that point on your own, seeing as how there are no real surprises. Doesn't matter though, you'll enjoy yourself anyway.

Once you get over the image of squeaky clean Pat Boone, as a supposedly bad boy, you'll have no trouble with the rest of the film. Considering that, Boone does turn in a surprisingly good performance as Nick. Certainly the role doesn't require much depth, but still it's a nicely done job when you would least expect it. As Jed, Arthur O'Connell is the perfect choice for the role. In the early going, he is unreachable and cold, but as he slowly warms up to Nick, we see that he's really a pretty good guy. Jeannette Nolan is a lot of fun as Henrietta, who is constantly playing the part of mediator between Jed and Nick. Shirley Jones takes a break from Rodgers And Hammerstein and gets a few opportunities to grace us with her singing talents. As Liz, she's gorgeous to look at, great to listen to, and quite funny at times. Dolores Michaels as Fran, who is a bit more on the wild side, is equally entertaining.

The best thing about April Love, is that there is not a true mean conniving character of any sort on the screen. Not one true villain in the whole thing. Everybody is so darn likable you can't help but enjoy the film. I truthfully find it quite refreshing, sort of like putting your troubles behind you and enjoying a summer picnic with friends. Think of it as the old Andy Griffith show with musical numbers, a little more plot, and wide screen Technicolor. The songs are a mixed bag, with the title song April Love being the best of them. Another thing I really liked is that they didn't fall back on using blue screen backdrops during the horse racing sequences, and they quite a bit more entertaining and exciting because of it. As a matter of fact, you'll find the whole film beautifully photographed and it was nice to see they didn't skimp in that department. The chemistry between Jones and Boone is good. Best of all is how the dislike between Nick and Jed is portrayed as each try in some way to gain the others respect.

This movie will never be confused with great cinema. Yet, sometimes instead of going to Disneyland, one just needs a nice outing in the park, and that's what April Love is.

My Grade: B+
rewritten_review:
Having stumbled upon this film on the Fox movie channel on a lazy Friday afternoon, I can't think of a better way to spend a Friday evening than sharing my thoughts. Every movie, good or bad, deserves more than four comments, and this one isn't bad at all.

Remember, April Love comes from the late fifties, an era when films were a happy medium, filled with wide screen Technicolor to lure people away from television. Teen Idol Pat Boone plays Nick Conover, a young teen sent to live with his Aunt Henrietta (Jeanette Nolan) and Uncle Jed (Arthur O'Connell) in the country after being put on probation for stealing a car. Aunt Henrietta hopes Nick will bring Uncle Jed out of his doldrums after losing their own son. Nick meets the neighbors, Fran (Dolores Michaels) and Liz (Shirley Jones) Templeton. Fran captures Nick's interest, while Liz develops a crush on him. There's also Uncle Jed's horse, a trotter turned wild since the death of Jed Jr. While predictable, the film remains enjoyable.

Once you accept Pat Boone as a bad boy, the film becomes easy to enjoy. Boone delivers a surprisingly good performance as Nick. Arthur O'Connell is perfect as Uncle Jed, initially cold but gradually warming up to Nick. Jeannette Nolan is fun as Henrietta, the mediator. Shirley Jones, as Liz, is gorgeous, talented, and funny. Dolores Michaels, as the wilder Fran, is equally entertaining.

The best thing about April Love is the absence of a true villain. Everyone is likable, making the film refreshing, like a summer picnic with friends. Think of it as an old Andy Griffith show with musical numbers, more plot, and Technicolor. The title song, April Love, stands out. The horse racing sequences are exciting without relying on blue screen backdrops. The film is beautifully photographed, and the chemistry between Jones and Boone is good. The portrayal of the growing respect between Nick and Jed is well done.

April Love isn't great cinema, but sometimes a simple outing in the park is all you need.

My Grade: B+

text:
I saw this kung fu movie when I was a kid, and I thought it was so cool! Now I am 26 years old, and my friend has it on DVD!!!

We got a case of brew, and watched this classic! It lost NONE of it's original kung fu coolness! If you are a fan of kung fu/karate movies, this is a must see... the DVD is available. I believe this movie is also called "Pick Your Poison".

Watch it soon!
rewritten_review: I saw this kung fu movie when I was just a kid, and I thought it was incredibly cool back then! Now, here I am at 26 years old, and my friend happened to have it on DVD!!! It was such an awesome blast from the past to revisit this film that I enjoyed so much when I was younger. We decided to get a case of brew, kick back, and watch this classic together! Let me tell you, it lost NONE of its original kung fu coolness, and it was just as exciting and entertaining as I remembered. If you are a fan of kung fu or karate movies, this is absolutely a must-see film that you shouldn't miss out on... the DVD is available for you to enjoy just like we did. I believe this movie is also known by another title, "Pick Your Poison." It's such an exhilarating and action-packed film that it truly stands the test of time. Whether you're watching it for the first time or revisiting it like I did, you're in for a treat. Watch it soon and experience the timeless thrill of kung fu cinema!

text:
Writers Perry and Randy Howze crafted a very engaging little story in "Chances Are."

Using the idea of a reincarnated man who happens to return to his former wife's home many years later, the plot takes unexpected, delightful turns.

Twenty four year old Robert Downey, Jr. renders a delightful performance, ably assisted by Cybil Shepherd as the widow and Ryan O'Neal as a good friend.

This trio has just the right chemistry for this caper, playing off one another with a graceful style. I've watched this film a number of times on tv, and each time found it most enjoyable.
rewritten_review:
Writers Perry and Randy Howze crafted a very engaging little story in "Chances Are." This film presents a unique and intriguing concept using the idea of a reincarnated man who happens to return to his former wife's home many years later. The plot takes unexpected, delightful turns that keep the audience engaged and entertained throughout the entire movie. The storyline is both imaginative and charming, capturing the essence of love and destiny in a way that is both heartwarming and thought-provoking.

At the heart of this film is the twenty-four-year-old Robert Downey, Jr., who renders a delightful performance that is both captivating and memorable. His portrayal of a reincarnated man is both nuanced and compelling, bringing depth and authenticity to the character. He is ably assisted by Cybil Shepherd, who plays the widow with grace and poise. Shepherd's performance is both touching and sincere, adding layers of complexity to her character. Ryan O'Neal also stars as a good friend, bringing his own charm and charisma to the film. O'Neal's performance complements those of Downey and Shepherd, creating a dynamic trio that captivates the audience.

This trio has just the right chemistry for this caper, playing off one another with a graceful style that is both entertaining and engaging. Their interactions are seamless and natural, making the film a joy to watch. The chemistry between the actors is palpable, adding to the overall enjoyment of the movie. The film strikes a perfect balance of humor, romance, and intrigue, making it a well-rounded and enjoyable viewing experience.

I've watched this film a number of times on TV, and each time found it most enjoyable. Each viewing reveals new nuances and details that enhance the overall experience, making it a film that stands the test of time. The story's creativity, combined with the stellar performances of the cast, ensures that "Chances Are" remains a delightful and captivating film that viewers can enjoy time and time again.

text: Take a subject I didn't know much about and make it exciting, why don't you? It so happens that back about 1979, director Robert Altman said that he didn't believe he had ever made a real movie and that he expected that one of these kids riding skateboards--if he doesn't break his neck--will make the first movie. Well, I wouldn't put such an expectation on Stacy Peralta, but he is a skateboarder who has made a good movie. Of course, he was forced by the nature of the film he was making to use existing footage, and it is certainly a good thing that so much archival footage existed. Peralta edited it together well with not-your-usual talking head shots of his erstwhile colleagues as they are today. The whole effect is post-modern in the best sense, but that has been done. Altman's prediction hasn't quite come true. What Peralta has done, however, is capture enough of the energy of those heady days that we can appreciate what it must have been like when modern skateboarding was invented by the Z-Boys. This is all good. I highly recommend "Dogtown."
rewritten_review: Back in 1979, director Robert Altman speculated that the first real movie might be made by a young skateboarder. While Stacy Peralta may not fulfill that prophecy, he's crafted a compelling film. Using archival footage and creative interviews with his former colleagues, Peralta captures the spirit of the era when the Z-Boys invented modern skateboarding. Although Altman's prediction remains unrealized, Peralta's work shines with post-modern flair and energy. I highly recommend "Dogtown."

text: Identical twin sisters Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen climbed to fame in sitcoms like "Two of a Kind", I had never seen them in anything before, but I had an idea of what to expect, but it was much worse. Basically the Hunter sisters Charli (Mary-Kate) and Leila (Ashley) are in Rome for a Summer Intern Program, but not long after starting their jobs they are immediately fired for a series of mishaps. But the man who owns the company they are working in, Derek Hammond (Julian Stone), gives them their jobs back, and they they do slowly prove themselves useful assets, and talented (fashion) artists, and help stop a mean man taking over the company. Also starring Leslie Danon as Jami, Derek Lee Nixon as Ryan, Ilenia Lazzarin as Dari, Archie Kao as Nobu, Valentina Mattolini as Heidi, Michelangelo Tommaso as Paolo and Matt Patresi as Enrico Tortoni. You can tell that this film was made to go straight to video, the camera-work is completely mismatched, and it doesn't help when you want to admire the sights of Rome. In fact the background is the only good thing to watch, the twin sisters are two of the most annoying celebrities around, I knew before watching that they weren't going to interest me in any way (their not even that pretty), this is awful gush of rubbish film. Pretty poor!
rewritten_review: Identical twin sisters Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen rose to fame in sitcoms like "Two of a Kind". I had never seen them before, but I had an idea of what to expect, and it was worse. The Hunter sisters, Charli (Mary-Kate) and Leila (Ashley), are in Rome for a Summer Intern Program. After a series of mishaps, they're fired but then rehired by company owner Derek Hammond (Julian Stone). They prove themselves as talented fashion artists and help stop a mean man from taking over the company. The film also stars Leslie Danon as Jami, Derek Lee Nixon as Ryan, Ilenia Lazzarin as Dari, Archie Kao as Nobu, Valentina Mattolini as Heidi, Michelangelo Tommaso as Paolo, and Matt Patresi as Enrico Tortoni. Made to go straight to video, the camera-work is mismatched, which doesn't help when trying to admire Rome. The background is the only good thing; the twins are two of the most annoying celebrities, and I knew they wouldn't interest me (they're not even that pretty). This film is an awful gush of rubbish. Pretty poor!

text:
One has to wonder if at any point in the production of this film a

script existed that made any sense. Was the rough cut 3 hours

long and was it trimmed into the incoherent mess that survives?

Why would anyone finance this mess? I will say that Tom

Wlaschiha is a good looking young man and he does what he can

with the dialogue and dramatic (?) situations he is given. But

characters come and go for no apparent reason, continuity is

non-existent, and the acting, cinematography, and direction are (to

put it politely) amateurish. Not One Sleeps is an unfortunate

choice of title as it will probably prove untrue should anyone

actually attempt to actually watch this film.
rewritten_review: One has to wonder if at any point in the production of this film a script existed that made any sense. Was the rough cut 3 hours long and was it trimmed into the incoherent mess that survives? Why would anyone finance this mess? I will say that Tom Wlaschiha is a good looking young man and he does what he can with the dialogue and dramatic (?) situations he is given. But characters come and go for no apparent reason, continuity is non-existent, and the acting, cinematography, and direction are (to put it politely) amateurish. Not One Sleeps is an unfortunate choice of title as it will probably prove untrue should anyone actually attempt to actually watch this film. From the very beginning, you can tell that something is off, and as the film progresses, it only becomes more apparent. There are scenes that feel like they were cut and pasted from different movies, and the narrative structure, if you can even call it that, is all over the place. It's baffling how such a project could even get off the ground, let alone make it to the point of release. The lack of coherence is startling, and it almost feels as though the filmmakers were trying to fit several unrelated stories into one film. The dialogue ranges from wooden to nonsensical, leaving the actors with little to work with. Despite the efforts of Tom Wlaschiha, who does his best to navigate this chaotic landscape, the film fails to deliver any meaningful or engaging moments. The technical aspects do little to help, as the cinematography often feels uninspired and the direction lacks any clear vision or purpose. As a viewer, it becomes a struggle to stay engaged and invested in what is happening on screen. Each scene seems to stumble into the next without any logical progression, leaving the audience in a state of confusion and disbelief. It's a shame because there could have been potential in the initial concept, but it seems to have been lost in the execution. The title, Not One Sleeps, seems ironic given that staying awake through the entire experience is a challenge in itself. The film's shortcomings are so glaring that it's hard to imagine how it passed through the various stages of production without someone stepping in to address the issues. In the end, it serves as a reminder of how crucial a cohesive script and competent direction are to the success of a film. Despite some promising elements, the film ultimately falls flat, leaving viewers to wonder what could have been if more care and attention had been given to its development.

text:
I've no idea what dimwit from San Francisco came up with this stupid plot, but apparently they need to get off whatever drugs they are taking and put their analyst on danger money -- NOW.

Yeah, this is a plausible story, if you regard the alien abduction sequence in "Life of Brian" as plausible.

This film is little more than a leftist pipedream. Had the US and USSR give up nuclear weapons, the result would've been to eliminate the only real obstacle that kept the two from engaging in a war. Bad as Korea, Vietnam and other wars of the era were, they were "proxy wars" fought to keep the superpowers from a direct engagement.

This film makes me think about how realistic it was when some group of high school kids would go on a hunger strike against nuclear proliferation. As if someone would say "Mr. President, some kids at Drastic High are not eating!" and Ronald Reagan would reply "My God! I'd better revise my Defense policy!" Right.

Like this film? Wouldn't it be better if the Soviet Union would've collapsed because they could not support their massive arms build... wait, that happened!
rewritten_review: This film is a leftist pipedream. If the US and USSR gave up nuclear weapons, it would have removed the only obstacle preventing them from direct war. Despite Korea and Vietnam, these were proxy wars to avoid superpower confrontation. The film's plot is as plausible as the alien abduction in "Life of Brian." It's like high school kids thinking a hunger strike would change Reagan's defense policy. And wouldn't it be better if the Soviet Union collapsed from unsustainable arms build-ups... oh wait, that happened!

text:
This film had all the ingredients of a good adventure movie, but it revealed incompetence at almost every level.

The presence of Roger Moore in the cast list is usually a sign that the movie is not going to be anything more than mediocre, because Moore always has lead roles and he can't act. But this movie also had Ian Holm and Lee Marvin in it, and was based on a Wilbur smith book, so I thought I'd give it a chance when I saw the DVD for sale in the bargain bin...

It was a mistake. The opening scene appeared to start in the middle of a reel, with sound suddenly appearing as if the first second of the soundtrack had been truncated. The scene showed a dreadnought at sea with a German crew. This bad editing was a sign of things to come, but the scene with the dreadnought was interesting enough to keep me watching. The special effects were good, and the crew wore the proper uniforms and spoke in German, indicating that the director at least paid attention to historical detail. I was surprised.

So I kept watching, and then Moore appeared and my supicions were confirmed. Bad acting, clichéd lines, clichéd cinematography and cheap humour...but worst of all, there is a disastrous attempt to blend the light-hearted feel of the film with serious drama and tragedy. It just does not work.

The film ends as suddenly and as badly as it started  in the middle of a reel.
rewritten_review: This film had all the ingredients of a good adventure movie, but it revealed incompetence at almost every level. The presence of Roger Moore in the cast list is usually a sign that the movie is not going to be anything more than mediocre because Moore always has lead roles and he can't act. But this movie also had Ian Holm and Lee Marvin in it, and was based on a Wilbur Smith book, so I thought I'd give it a chance when I saw the DVD for sale in the bargain bin. It was a mistake. The opening scene appeared to start in the middle of a reel, with sound suddenly appearing as if the first second of the soundtrack had been truncated. The scene showed a dreadnought at sea with a German crew. This bad editing was a sign of things to come, but the scene with the dreadnought was interesting enough to keep me watching. The special effects were good, and the crew wore the proper uniforms and spoke in German, indicating that the director at least paid attention to historical detail. I was surprised. So I kept watching, and then Moore appeared and my suspicions were confirmed. Bad acting, clichéd lines, clichéd cinematography, and cheap humour, but worst of all, there is a disastrous attempt to blend the light-hearted feel of the film with serious drama and tragedy. It just does not work. The film ends as suddenly and as badly as it started—in the middle of a reel.

text: I dont know why people think this is such a bad movie. Its got a pretty good plot, some good action, and the change of location for Harry does not hurt either. Sure some of its offensive and gratuitous but this is not the only movie like that. Eastwood is in good form as Dirty Harry, and I liked Pat Hingle in this movie as the small town cop. If you liked DIRTY HARRY, then you should see this one, its a lot better than THE DEAD POOL. 4/5
rewritten_review: I don't know why people think this is such a bad movie. It's got a pretty good plot, some good action, and the change of location for Harry does not hurt either. Sure, some of it is offensive and gratuitous, but this is not the only movie like that. There are numerous films out there that have elements which some might find offensive or gratuitous, yet they still manage to deliver an engaging story and thrilling moments. Eastwood is in good form as Dirty Harry, and I liked Pat Hingle in this movie as the small-town cop. His portrayal adds a nice touch to the small-town atmosphere, giving it a layer that complements Eastwood's character well. The dynamic between the characters is interesting and adds to the overall enjoyment of the film. If you liked DIRTY HARRY, then you should see this one; it's a lot better than THE DEAD POOL. The action sequences are well-executed, and the plot keeps you engaged throughout. The film also benefits from a strong supporting cast and an intriguing setting that adds depth to the narrative. 4/5

text:
If you're a fan of Mystery Science Theater 3K, Attack of the Giant Leeches, or Pinata Survival Island, this movie might be for you.

I live in Nashville and I didn't even know of this movie's existence until the day prior to its release, when the advertising company panicked and blanketed Music Row with dozens of fliers and billboards. It barely lasted two weeks in theaters anyway.

Bad acting, bad writing, and poor production only begin to describe this embarrassment of a film. For starters, the names are a bit much: Bo Price, Angel, and Dixie? Eesh.

Toby's awkwardly slow delivery of lines makes one wonder what production assistant got stuck holding the cue cards off camera. Angel's character rapidly transitions from her city-slicker ways to a cowgirl, slipping into southern slang after two days on the ranch. Her wardrobe goes from chic to a female version of Toby's--in fact, in the final scene, their outfits are identical, making one wonder if the wardrobe assistant called in sick.

The audio is inconsistent - perhaps the most noticeable example is when Toby decides to go for a swim and his voice suddenly sounds like he's shouting in a gymnasium.

There's never quite enough explanation or character development to suffice what happens on-screen. Overacting, exasperation, grimaces, and moodiness best describes the actors' interpretation and direction of the terrible script.

This movie is best enjoyed after consuming a couple of alcoholic beverages and in the company of your wittiest friends. But that's not saying much.
rewritten_review:
If you're a fan of Mystery Science Theater 3K, Attack of the Giant Leeches, or Pinata Survival Island, this movie might be for you.

I live in Nashville and didn’t know of this movie until the day before its release, when the advertising company panicked and plastered Music Row with fliers. It barely lasted two weeks in theaters.

Bad acting, bad writing, and poor production only begin to describe this embarrassment. The names are a bit much: Bo Price, Angel, and Dixie? Eesh.

Toby's slow delivery makes one wonder what production assistant held the cue cards. Angel's character quickly shifts from city-slicker to cowgirl, adopting southern slang after two days on the ranch. Her wardrobe goes from chic to a female version of Toby's—in their final scene, their outfits are identical, suggesting the wardrobe assistant called in sick.

The audio is inconsistent—noticeable when Toby goes for a swim and his voice suddenly echoes as if in a gymnasium.

There’s never enough explanation or character development. Overacting, exasperation, grimaces, and moodiness describe the actors’ interpretation and direction of the terrible script.

This movie is best enjoyed after a couple of drinks with witty friends. But that’s not saying much.

text:
I approached this movie with the understanding that it was one of the worst flicks ever made. I sat down to watch it with this mindset, and was pleasantly surprised.

It's not great. It's not even that good; in fact, it's pretty poor. However, it's not as bad as I had been led to believe, by a long shot. It's pretty inept, and, evidently as a cost cutting measure, a lot of stock footage is pressed into service, a lot of which has no apparent relation to the narrative.

What it is, however, is an intensely personal movie made by a man who evidently did not have the skills or the funding to do his idea justice. Before you discount _Glen or Glenda?_ out of hand, examine your own artistic skills. Me, I'd love to be able to draw, but anything I try to sketch comes out like stick men. I'd love to be able to sing, but all I do is frighten young children.

Wood had an idea, and unfortunately he didn't have what it takes to make it work. However, this was an incredibly daring movie for the puritan 50s, however exploitative or incoherent it may appear at first glance.
rewritten_review: I approached this movie thinking it was one of the worst ever made, and was pleasantly surprised. It's not great, not even that good, but it's not as bad as I had been led to believe. It's pretty inept, with a lot of unrelated stock footage used as a cost-cutting measure. However, it's an intensely personal movie by a man without the skills or funding to do his idea justice. Before dismissing _Glen or Glenda?_, consider your own artistic skills. Wood had an idea and, despite not making it work, created an incredibly daring movie for the puritan 50s, regardless of its exploitative or incoherent nature.

text: This is a good film. This is very funny. Yet after this film there were no good Ernest films!
rewritten_review: This is a good film, offering plenty of entertainment and showcasing a well-crafted storyline. The humor throughout the movie is genuinely funny, with moments that will keep audiences laughing from start to finish. The comedic timing and delivery are spot-on, making it a standout in its genre. Yet, despite the success and enjoyment this film provides, it is unfortunate that after this film, there were no good Ernest films to follow. The charm and wit that made this movie so enjoyable seemed to be lost in subsequent productions. It's a shame because the potential for more quality films was certainly there, but sadly, it was never realized in the films that came after.

text: This is the most difficult movie I have ever seen...the emotional content is horrific, yet unforgetable. A woman who is accused of being a political activist is brought in for questioning. The whole movie revolves around her interrogation. Alan Rickman and Madeline Stowe have intense and powerful roles for which they deserve Oscars for their performances.
rewritten_review:
This is the most difficult movie I have ever seen, and I say that with the utmost conviction. The emotional content is nothing short of horrific, yet it remains utterly unforgettable in its impact. The story centers around a woman who finds herself accused of being a political activist, which leads to a tense and gripping scenario as she is brought in for questioning. The entire movie revolves around the intense and unyielding process of her interrogation, creating a claustrophobic atmosphere that keeps the audience on edge from start to finish.

The performances delivered by Alan Rickman and Madeline Stowe are nothing short of extraordinary. Both actors bring such depth and intensity to their roles that they truly deserve Oscars for their captivating and powerful performances. Their portrayals are so compelling and nuanced that they elevate the film to a whole new level of cinematic excellence.

As the narrative unfolds, the viewer is drawn deeper into the psychological and emotional turmoil experienced by the characters, making it an even more challenging watch. The film does not shy away from exploring the darker aspects of human nature and the complexities of political dynamics, which adds layers of complexity to the storyline. The combination of a gripping plot, masterful acting, and profound emotional content makes this film a truly unforgettable experience, despite its difficult subject matter.

text: Don't even ask me why I watched this! The only excuse I can come up with that I was sick with Bronchitis and too weak to change the channel. :) It's too terrible for words, the movie that is, not the Bronchitis. The acting is deplorable, Richard Grieco hams it up as a trigger-happy, gun-slinging serial killer with a penchant for knocking off cops. Nick Mancuso phones in a performance as the cop on his trail and Nancy Allen manages to put in the only sympathetic role in the entire film. The script is dismal, peppered with clichéd lines, "Are you ready, Pardner?" purrs Richard Grieco to every single one of his victims. Dire. Avoid.
rewritten_review: Don't even ask me why I watched this! The only excuse I can come up with is that I was sick with Bronchitis and too weak to change the channel. :) It's too terrible for words, the movie that is, not the Bronchitis. The acting is deplorable, Richard Grieco hams it up as a trigger-happy, gun-slinging serial killer with a penchant for knocking off cops. His performance is so over-the-top that it's almost hard to believe anyone could take it seriously. Nick Mancuso phones in a performance as the cop on his trail, barely mustering any energy or interest in his role, making it seem as though he simply showed up for a paycheck. Nancy Allen manages to put in the only sympathetic role in the entire film, giving the audience a brief respite from the otherwise unbearable experience. The script is dismal, peppered with clichéd lines, "Are you ready, Pardner?" purrs Richard Grieco to every single one of his victims, a phrase that quickly becomes grating and tiresome. The dialogue is uninspired and predictable, failing to offer anything fresh or original. Dire. Avoid. It's astonishing that a movie with such a premise could be executed so poorly, leaving viewers wondering how it ever got made in the first place. The direction is lackluster, with scenes dragging on longer than necessary, further testing the patience of anyone brave enough to sit through the whole thing. The film fails to deliver on any front, lacking suspense, intrigue, or any semblance of entertainment value. It's a testament to how bad movies can get when all elements fall completely flat.

text:
I'm no horror movie buff, but my wife's nieces and nephews are. So, I saw the first movie. It was gruesome, and tense, but not my taste. Still good though. For similar reasons, at this very moment, I am being exposed to a sequel.

The premise itself is beyond absurd. I can buy that disasters occur in the desert. I can buy that mutants exists. I can even buy that the events might be so weird and strange that the military may decide to get involved. It is unlikely, yes, but I'm willing to suspend my belief.

HOWEVER, under no circumstances am I willing to believe that the military squad assigned to recon such an area would be unable to fend off the mutants. Being a member of the United States Army, I can assure that while fresh recruits may lack the seasoned eyes and experience of combat soldiers, any such recruits would be integrated into a capable squad.

A squad of armed soldiers is not about to be taken out by a few mutants with knives. That's just the way it works. Squad movements, vastly superior firepower, and of course, radio support, would ensure nothing less than total victory. I'm not saying you wouldn't have casualties, but as soon as the area was verified as hostile, military training would take precedence, no-one would go off on their own even to use the bathroom.

And if it were discovered that the area was so infested with hostiles that the squad was unable to handle the danger, they would radio in for backup. And believe me, their radios would not be jammed, if there was a chance that normal radios would not do, the squad would have a military issue satellite phone. Chances are, if they were unable to check in every hour, a search would be called.

In order to accept this movie, you must accept that our soldiers are incompetent fools, with incompetent leaders, and an incompetent chain of command. While it may still be true that the most dangerous thing in the world is a lieutenant with a map and compass, our military forces are filled with intelligent, well-trained, competent soldiers. Mutants with knives are far below our ability to deal with.

With the whole execution of the movie depending solidly on the impossible to imagine, the film fails to deliver. Instead, we are expected to believe that our soldiers, sailors, and airmen are incapable of dealing with even the most mediocre threats.

As a combat veteran, I find the movie insulting.

text: I first heard of Unisol 2 when I drove past a cinema when I was on holiday in America. I really did not take much notice of it until I bought the original on DVD which led me to find out about its three sequels. I subsequently started to read about The Return on the IMDB and asked friends what they thought of it. Despite their horrific criticisms of it, I still went out of my way to see it and was on the brink of buying it until I saw it for hire on DVD. I wasn't expecting much but thought that it must have been half decent to get a theatrical release in the US, after all, how often is it that you see Van Damme on the big screen? Well, nothing could have prepared me for this. It is so bad I almost cried. What a total waste of 80 minutes and £2.50. It is hard to explain how bad this move is. Honestly. This is idiotic film making. No, it's more than idiotic. I just cannot believe how this got made. I cannot believe that someone out there has not murdered Mic Rogers. How stupid can people possibly be - firstly, Van Damme actually thinking the script and finished film was good. Secondly, the fact that Xander Berkley, of Terminator 2 and Air Force One status, commited himself to this film. I simply cannot believe the stupidity of this movie. It takes itself so seriously but comes across to the audience like a spoof. Here is an example: JCVD's daughter (yes, Luc is now a human again)- "I want my Daddy", SETH- "So do I". Oh yeah, and some guy tries to shut down SETH by pulling three huge levers with - wait for it - ON and OFF written on them. The acting all round is like playschool acting. I'm sure Mr Director modelled Luc's reporter girlfriend on April O'Neil from the cartoon Teenage Mutant Hero Turtles - she refuses to go because she '...needs her story'. I mean come on - how many cliches can a film possibly use? Please listen to me fellow IMDB users - don't touch this with a barge pole. To conclude, Universal Soldier: The Return has no relation whatsoever to the first movie. In fact, if they weren't called UniSols then you would never know it was a sequel. Luc is now a human again - what the hell!?! The only place in which he can access the internet is in a stripclub. All the new Uni Sols look like they were dragged off the street, they are that unconvincing. This is pure torture to watch, so do yourself a favour - don't torture yourself. P.S - Best part of the movie: Romeo jumps off a building and shouts 'Oh sh*t'.
