text: This is an excellent documentary, packed with racing action beautiful pictures and a great story. The IMAX Cameras give you a very wide perspective, as a DVD movie it is perfect. Your hear every speaker working almost all the time, The film is not speeded up and just gives you the natural feel of 230mph. Of course there are some sound effects added but i think they are good, they give a depth to the driving scenes...
rewritten_review: This is an excellent documentary, packed with thrilling racing action, stunningly beautiful pictures, and a captivating story that keeps you engaged from start to finish. The use of IMAX Cameras provides you with a very wide perspective that enhances the viewing experience, making you feel as if you are right there in the midst of the action. As a DVD movie, it is perfect for any racing enthusiast or anyone who appreciates high-quality documentaries. You can hear every speaker working almost all the time, ensuring that the audio experience is as immersive as the visual one. The film is not speeded up, allowing it to provide a natural feel of what driving at 230mph is truly like. Of course, there are some sound effects added, but I think they are good and well-executed. These sound effects give a depth to the driving scenes that adds to the overall excitement and intensity, making the experience even more exhilarating. The combination of the natural and enhanced sounds creates a dynamic auditory backdrop that complements the stunning visuals perfectly, ensuring that viewers are fully immersed in the high-speed world of racing. This documentary not only entertains but also educates, offering insights into the world of racing that are both fascinating and enlightening. Overall, it is a remarkable film that showcases the thrill of racing in a way that is both authentic and engaging, making it a must-watch for fans of the genre.

text: There's more to offer in the opening of The Odd Couple than in the entirety of most films. Felix Unger (the poor guy's monogram even curses him) checks into a New York hotel. A cleaning lady says "Good night." "Goodbye," he answers back. In his room he empties his pockets, then struggles to take off his wedding ring only to put the objects neatly into an envelope, addressed to his wife and beloved children. When the viewer finally puts it together  aha, he's going to off himself  we watch him struggle to open the window  oh no, he's going to jump  The poor guy injures his lower back. This is all you need to know about Felix Unger  his wife has left him, he's a compulsive cleaner and he's a hypochondriac. And all in one scene. This is the particular genius of Neil Simon's comedy  it's about situation and character. There are few obvious physical jokes  no kicks to the groin, no cheap gags  just funny characters in uncomfortable situations. And, of course, he is a master of manipulating the audience's expectations. Coming from the Swingers era, imagine what I thought in the date scene when Felix starts lamenting about the breakup of his marriage to the girls his roommate Oscar has worked so hard to get into his apartment. He's blowing it, right? Think again. The girls love his sensitivity, his ability to cry in front of them. They invite him back to their place since his meatloaf has burned because Oscar wasn't paying enough attention to it. He's in like Flynn, right? Uh, yes, but he doesn't want to go with the girls because he's feeling vulnerable. Great stuff. And it's made even greater with a style that minimizes editing and maximizes the wonderful eight-room apartment set. You've got Jack Lemmon and the slouchy, pouchy Walter Matthau for Chrissakes, why mess it up? The visual style reminded me of Breakfast at Tiffany's, in that great effect is made from a large depth of field and the interplay between the various planes of action. Particularly memorable is the scene in which Felix, fleeing from Oscar, closes a partition only to realize the partition doesn't cover the side where Oscar is coming from. You get a real sense of the layout of the apartment, and thus the proximity in which the two divorcées live. The twist here is that these two are really married  to each other. So the observations about married life that might be ignored in an ordinary romantic comedy are made all the more poignant since they are two guys.
rewritten_review: There's more to offer in the opening of The Odd Couple than in most films. Felix Unger checks into a New York hotel. A cleaning lady says "Good night." "Goodbye," he responds. In his room, he empties his pockets, struggles to take off his wedding ring, and puts the items in an envelope addressed to his wife and children. When the viewer realizes he's going to off himself, we see him struggle to open the window, only to injure his back. This scene tells us everything about Felix: his wife left him, he's a compulsive cleaner, and a hypochondriac. Neil Simon's comedy is about situation and character, with few physical jokes. Coming from the Swingers era, imagine my surprise when Felix's sensitivity charms the girls his roommate Oscar invites over, despite lamenting about his marriage. They invite him back, but he declines, feeling vulnerable. Great stuff, enhanced by a style that minimizes editing and maximizes the apartment set. With Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau, why mess it up? The visual style, reminiscent of Breakfast at Tiffany's, uses a large depth of field to emphasize the apartment's layout and the proximity in which the two divorcées live. The twist is that these two are really married—to each other. Observations about married life are more poignant since they are two guys.

text:
I almost laughed out loud when during the commentary the director said this movie is original with a strong plot line. There is not one... repeat ONE original plot line or special effect in this blah movie.

The Crows.... Hitchcock did it superbly back before CGI and even with CGI this film falls short of a well done attack scene. The creepy crawly boy... The Grudge did it and did it better. The psycho...done in Cold Creek Manor most recently, however it has been done to death. No pun intended. Disconnected/rebellious teen who no one listens to... about a dozen films have used this one right down to Beetlejuice. The oozy stuff from the basement... can you say Amnityville Horror? Doors opening unbidden... What Lies Beneath did it with much more flair. Creepy farmhouse... too numerous to mention.

The backdrop of metaphysics-- which should have been the central focus, gets lost once you figure out what is happening, which by the way is pretty early on.

One thing (of many actually) they never even try to explain in the movie is how they explain to the police that their attacker was sucked down the ooze in the basement, so they really don't have a body.

Overall... DON'T BOTHER
rewritten_review:
I almost laughed out loud when the director said this movie is original with a strong plot line. There is not one original plot line or special effect in this blah movie. 

The Crows... Hitchcock did it superbly before CGI, and even with CGI, this film falls short of a well-done attack scene. The creepy crawly boy... The Grudge did it better. The psycho... done in Cold Creek Manor and many others. Disconnected/rebellious teen... done in about a dozen films including Beetlejuice. The oozy stuff from the basement... think Amityville Horror. Doors opening unbidden... What Lies Beneath did it with more flair. Creepy farmhouse... too numerous to mention. 

The backdrop of metaphysics, which should have been the central focus, gets lost once you figure out what's happening, which is pretty early on.

They never explain to the police how their attacker was sucked down the ooze in the basement, so there's no body.

Overall... DON'T BOTHER

text:
This is simply one of the finest renditions of Dicken's classic tale. The script very accurately follows the story originally penned by Dickens, and captures a perfect balance between a film atmosphere and a play atmosphere. Viewers fond of either format will find enough of the story rooted in their presentation style of choice.

George C. Scott brings a delightfully realistic approach to the character of Scrooge, and is very convincing in the character development instigated by the visits of the ghosts. I found that he was able to win me over to the point where I sympathized with the old miser, something rarely done in other versions. The superb job done by the supporting actors add greatly to this production, which is simply the most enjoyable of all the Christmas Carol versions I have seen.
rewritten_review:
This is simply one of the finest renditions of Dickens's classic tale. The script very accurately follows the story originally penned by Dickens, and captures a perfect balance between a film atmosphere and a play atmosphere. Viewers fond of either format will find enough of the story rooted in their presentation style of choice. The attention to detail in this adaptation is impressive, ensuring that each scene is faithful to the original narrative while also bringing a fresh perspective to the timeless story. The set designs and costumes further enhance the authenticity, transporting viewers to the Victorian era with remarkable accuracy and flair. The music and sound effects are perfectly integrated, underscoring the mood of each scene and heightening the emotional impact.

George C. Scott brings a delightfully realistic approach to the character of Scrooge, and is very convincing in the character development instigated by the visits of the ghosts. His portrayal is nuanced and layered, capturing the complexity of Scrooge's transformation from a greedy, bitter miser to a compassionate and generous man. I found that he was able to win me over to the point where I sympathized with the old miser, something rarely done in other versions. His interactions with the ghosts are particularly compelling, revealing the depth of his internal struggle and eventual enlightenment. The superb job done by the supporting actors adds greatly to this production, enriching the narrative with their performances and breathing life into their characters. The ensemble cast works harmoniously to create a cohesive and engaging experience for the audience. 

In addition to the strong performances, the direction and pacing of the film are expertly handled, ensuring that the story unfolds smoothly and maintains the viewer's interest throughout. The cinematography captures the essence of the period while also highlighting the emotional journey of the characters. The careful attention to lighting and composition adds further depth to the visual storytelling. This production is simply the most enjoyable of all the Christmas Carol versions I have seen, offering a perfect blend of tradition and innovation that is sure to appeal to both purists and newcomers alike. Each viewing reveals new layers and insights, making it a truly rewarding and enriching experience.

text: "The Foreigner" is a tale of foreign intrigue with Seagal at the center as a deep cover operative who has a package which everyone wants and are willing to kill to get. The flick is uninspired with less of the usual action stuff which put Seagal on the movie map (fire fights, hand-to-hand combat, pyrotechnics, stunts, etc.) and more of a story which is convoluted, uninteresting, and full of meaningless filler. What action there is seems token and gratuitous while Seagal, looking more and more like a pork chop, meanders through this insipid flick expressionless and bored while manifesting no improvement in acting ability. Somewhere around "The Glimmer Man" or "Fire Down Below" Seagal flicks took a nose dive and "The Foreigner" is just an continuation of that trend. Nothing here worth watching except for the most die-hard Seagal fans. (C-)
rewritten_review: "The Foreigner" is a tale of foreign intrigue with Seagal at the center as a deep cover operative who has a package which everyone wants and are willing to kill to get. This flick is uninspired, with less of the usual action stuff which put Seagal on the movie map (fire fights, hand-to-hand combat, pyrotechnics, stunts, etc.) and more of a story which is convoluted, uninteresting, and full of meaningless filler. The narrative struggles to engage the audience, leaving those who watch it feeling disconnected from the plot. What action there is seems token and gratuitous while Seagal, looking more and more like a pork chop, meanders through this insipid flick expressionless and bored while manifesting no improvement in acting ability. His performance lacks the charisma and energy that once captivated audiences, resulting in a portrayal that is flat and uninspired. Somewhere around "The Glimmer Man" or "Fire Down Below," Seagal flicks took a nose dive, and "The Foreigner" is just a continuation of that trend. This downward trajectory in quality has left fans yearning for the glory days of Seagal's earlier films. Nothing here is worth watching except for the most die-hard Seagal fans, who may find some solace in his mere presence on screen. For those who hold a nostalgic fondness for Seagal, this movie might offer a brief moment of recognition, but little else. (C-)

text:
Buddy is an entertaining family film set in a time when "humanizing" animals, and making them cute was an accepted way to get people to be interested in them.

Based on a true story, Buddy shows the great love that the main characters have for animals and for each other, and that they will do anything for each other.

While not a perfect movie, the animated gorilla is quite lifelike most of the time and the mayhem that occurs within the home is usually amusing for children.

This film misses an opportunity to address the mistake of bringing wild animals into the home as pets, but does show the difficulties.

A recommended film which was the first for Jim Henson Productions.
rewritten_review:
Buddy is an entertaining family film set in a time when "humanizing" animals, and making them cute was an accepted way to get people to be interested in them. This approach to storytelling has a long history in cinema, where animals are often given human-like traits to engage audiences and create a bond between the characters and viewers. The film effectively captures this essence, making it a delightful experience for families and children alike. 

Based on a true story, Buddy shows the great love that the main characters have for animals and for each other, and that they will do anything for each other. The film delves into the deep emotional connections that can form between humans and animals, highlighting the compassion and dedication that the characters demonstrate. This aspect of the story resonates with viewers, as it emphasizes the universal themes of love and loyalty, which are central to the human experience.

While not a perfect movie, the animated gorilla is quite lifelike most of the time and the mayhem that occurs within the home is usually amusing for children. The filmmakers have done an impressive job with the animation, bringing the gorilla to life in a way that is both believable and endearing. This attention to detail enhances the film's appeal, particularly for younger audiences who are captivated by the antics and adventures that unfold within the household. The humor and chaos that ensue provide plenty of entertainment and laughter, making it a memorable viewing experience.

This film misses an opportunity to address the mistake of bringing wild animals into the home as pets, but does show the difficulties. While the narrative focuses on the lighthearted and amusing aspects of living with a gorilla, it subtly acknowledges the challenges and potential consequences of such a decision. This aspect of the story serves as a cautionary tale, albeit understated, reminding viewers of the complexities and responsibilities involved in caring for wild animals. 

A recommended film which was the first for Jim Henson Productions. As the inaugural film for this renowned production company, Buddy holds a special place in cinematic history. It showcases the creativity and innovation that Jim Henson Productions is known for, setting the stage for future projects that continue to capture the imagination of audiences around the world. Overall, Buddy is a charming and enjoyable film that offers both entertainment and a glimpse into the unique bond between humans and animals.

text: This very low budget comedy caper movie succeeds only in being low budget. Dialog is dumbfoundingly stupid, chase scenes are uniformly boring, and most of the on-screen money seems to have been saved for a series of crashes and explosions in a parking lot during the film's last five minutes (a briefly glimpsed port-a-potty early in that scene is certain to wrecked and spew crap on the film's chief villain--no prop is here without a purpose). The whole film is depressingly reminiscent of those that occasionally came out of Rodger Corman's studio when he'd give a first time director a few bucks and a camera--but without the discipline Corman would impose.
rewritten_review: This very low budget comedy caper movie succeeds only in being low budget. Dialog is dumbfoundingly stupid, chase scenes are uniformly boring, and most of the on-screen money seems to have been saved for a series of crashes and explosions in a parking lot during the film's last five minutes. It's as if all the excitement the filmmakers could muster was reserved for this final chaotic scene, hoping to leave the audience with some semblance of satisfaction, but even this attempt feels forced and uninspired. A briefly glimpsed port-a-potty early in that scene is certain to be wrecked and spew crap on the film's chief villain--no prop is here without a purpose. The film seems to stumble from one scene to the next, lacking any real sense of direction or purpose, making it an exercise in endurance rather than enjoyment. The whole film is depressingly reminiscent of those that occasionally came out of Rodger Corman's studio when he'd give a first-time director a few bucks and a camera--but without the discipline Corman would impose. The absence of such discipline means that what might have been charmingly rough around the edges instead feels like a mishmash of poorly executed ideas. The film's pacing is erratic, with moments dragging on endlessly while others rush by without leaving any impact. Characters are introduced and discarded with little regard for coherence, and the humor, which should be the film's saving grace, falls flat at nearly every turn. It's a movie that sets out to entertain but ultimately only manages to highlight its own inadequacies, leaving viewers to wonder what might have been with a more focused vision and a bit more polish.

text: What's happening to RGV? He seems to repeat himself in every movie. Has he run out of creative ideas? If he has, time to take a back seat. Went to see the movie with great anticipation - of course not once did I imagine it would be anywhere near the original. I knew it wouldn't, the promos said it all. But even then I thought it would be a great RGV treat, after all isn't he the same guy who directed Sathya and Company? Or is he? I have my doubts after watching Aag. I am not going to talk about the plot or the story, as most of it is taken from the original, if you are really dying to go and see this one, you could play a fun game with friends: identify the scenes from the original one and give ratings of your own! So Veeru becomes Heero (how corny is that?), guess Heeru wouldn't sound that great. Ajay Devgan is quite a disaster as Heero, the comedy is strained and the slurred talk that really was effective in Company sounds fake. The chemistry between Heero and Gunghroo (Nisha Kothari) doesn't exists at all. In fact the more charming Nisha tries to be the more irritating she becomes. This reaches a peak by the end. Raj is in fact not bad as compared to the others, he is a guy to watch in the future. I was really disappointed with Amitabh Bachchan as Babban, he looks like a caricature of Gabbar Singh. There is a scene where he is drinking something from a bowl all covered in a shawl, instead of inspiring fear he looks like a beggar with his bowl. The only performance that really stood out was Mohan Lal as Inspector Narasimha. I am afraid I don't have the patience to write more.

The only performance that really stood out was Mohan Lal as Inspector Narasimha. I'm afraid I don't have the patience to write more.

text: The pace of the film is ponderously slow in parts, but if you can tune into its languid speed and lengthy silences then it is a satisfying piece of courtly intrigue. The story of the first Emperor of China, his childhood sweetheart and the personal cost of power. The film is very atmospheric, the extremely mannered and polite courtly ceremony and ritual contrasted with sudden brutal violence. Filmed in a way that evokes shadows and cold spaces. Battle scenes are rare and short, the focus is on the battle within the individual on what is right to do and whether the ends justify the means. The emperor's journey from idealistic peacemaker to ruthless tyrant is aiming to be subtle, but gives little background or convincing insight into the motivation of the Emperor, indeed his actions and aims do not really change throughout, only Gong Li's attitudes to him are altered. The most interesting performances are Gong Li's and the titular Assassin as they reassess when to fight, when to retreat, when to kill. The most expensive film ever made in China at the time, the Emperor and the Assassin does not rely on hysteric emotion or big battles, but rather a brooding atmosphere of menace and inevitability. Gong Li fans will be unsurprised to hear she is as stunningly beautiful as ever, giving an understated performance.
rewritten_review: The film's pace is ponderously slow at times, but if you can tune into its languid speed and lengthy silences, it becomes a satisfying piece of courtly intrigue. It tells the story of the first Emperor of China, his childhood sweetheart, and the personal cost of power. The film is atmospheric, with extremely mannered courtly ceremonies contrasted with sudden brutal violence. It evokes shadows and cold spaces, focusing on the internal battle over what is right and whether the ends justify the means. The emperor's journey from idealistic peacemaker to ruthless tyrant aims to be subtle but lacks convincing insight into his motivations; only Gong Li's attitudes toward him change. Gong Li and the titular Assassin deliver the most interesting performances as they reassess when to fight, retreat, or kill. The most expensive film ever made in China at the time, The Emperor and the Assassin relies on a brooding atmosphere of menace and inevitability rather than hysteric emotion or big battles. Gong Li fans will be unsurprised by her stunning beauty and understated performance.

text: SHOWTIME is a mess, but it's an entertaining mess. The plot is forgettable, the satire is lightweight and the action sequences, though well-staged, aren't that exciting. But I laughed. A lot. Credit goes to the inspired pairing of De Niro and Murphy. They have great chemistry. Murphy delivers the one-liners, De Niro cracks us up with a look or grimace. This movie will get a RUSH HOUR-like reception from the critics. Don't listen to them. If you're a fan of De Niro or Murphy, you're going to enjoy this movie.
rewritten_review: SHOWTIME is quite a mess, but it's an entertaining and enjoyable mess nonetheless. The plot is pretty forgettable, the satire is quite lightweight, and the action sequences, though well-staged, aren't really that exciting. However, I laughed. A lot. Credit truly goes to the inspired pairing of De Niro and Murphy. They have great chemistry together. Murphy delivers the one-liners with perfect timing, while De Niro cracks us up with just a look or grimace. This movie will likely get a RUSH HOUR-like reception from the critics. But don't listen to them. If you're a fan of De Niro or Murphy, you're going to enjoy this movie a lot. It's a fun ride that showcases their talents and chemistry, making it worth a watch.

text:
Yet again not quite bad enough to make it enjoyable. In fact this one is just boring. It's reasonably well made, even though the script is bad, the effects are OK and the acting average. (Apart from James Mason who is always great, but in this one underused)

I suppose it is hard to write anything about this film because it didn't evoke any reaction in me what so ever.

Dull, dull, dull, dull, dull.
rewritten_review: Yet again not quite bad enough to make it enjoyable. In fact, this one is just boring. It's reasonably well made, even though the script is bad, the effects are OK, and the acting is average. The performances are lackluster at best. The cinematography doesn’t stand out, and the direction is uninspired. Even the set design lacks creativity and feels mundane. The pacing drags, making it difficult to stay engaged. The plot unfolds predictably, with no real twists or turns to keep the audience invested. It's a film that lacks any sense of urgency or excitement, failing to capture the viewer's attention in any meaningful way. The characters are one-dimensional, and their development is stunted, leaving them unrelatable and forgettable. The dialogue is uninspired, lacking wit or depth that could have added some much-needed interest. The score fails to enhance the experience, blending into the background and adding nothing to the atmosphere. Even the editing feels lackluster, with scenes that linger too long or cut away too quickly, disrupting the overall flow. (Apart from James Mason, who is always great, but in this one underused.) His talent is evident, but the script doesn’t allow him to shine as he should. I suppose it is hard to write anything about this film because it didn't evoke any reaction in me whatsoever. There’s nothing to praise, nothing to critique with passion. Dull, dull, dull, dull, dull. It’s a film that leaves no impression, neither positive nor negative, simply fading into obscurity as soon as it ends.

text: I read the novel 'Jane Eyre' for the first time back in 1986. It was round that time that I saw the BBC-version with Timothy Dalton and Zelah Clarke. It was an excellent version and very much like the book. Years later, I laid eyes on this version and was horrified. William Hurt is totally miscast as Mr Rochester. Mr Rochester is a passionate character, where as William Hurt portrays him as a block of ice. The same goes for Charlotte Gainsborough. It was like watching two zombies together. This is story about love and passion, but I couldn't see it in this version. No, back to the BBC-version. A wonderful time is guaranteed.
rewritten_review: I read the classic novel 'Jane Eyre,' written by Charlotte Brontë, for the first time back in 1986, and it left a lasting impression on me. It was around that time that I had the pleasure of watching the BBC adaptation, which featured the talented actors Timothy Dalton and Zelah Clarke in the lead roles. The adaptation was truly an excellent version and stayed very true to the essence of the book. It captured the spirit and depth of the story beautifully. However, years later, I happened to lay eyes on another adaptation of 'Jane Eyre,' and I was utterly horrified by what I saw. In this version, William Hurt was cast as Mr. Rochester, and I found him to be totally miscast in this pivotal role. Mr. Rochester is meant to be a passionate and intense character, full of depth and complexity, whereas William Hurt portrayed him as a block of ice, lacking the fiery passion that the character demands. The same disappointment goes for Charlotte Gainsborough, who played the role of Jane Eyre. Her portrayal was equally lacking in energy and emotion. It was as if I was watching two zombies together on screen. This is meant to be a story about love and passion, a tale that explores deep emotions and intense connections, but unfortunately, I couldn't see any of it in this particular version. No, for a truly immersive and emotionally engaging experience, I will always return to the BBC version. A wonderful time is guaranteed with that adaptation, as it captures the true essence of this timeless story.

text: Any film about WWII made during WWII by a British production company has no latter-day peer in my opinion, respectfully. The confluence of so many things near and dear to my heart are in At Dawn We Dive: as a descendant of Admiral Horatio Nelson and student of all aspects of World War Two and particularly naval warfare, I favor depictions of subs and action in the North Atlantic and especially those which include the German side of things. For those unacquainted with target priorities, an attack on an enemy warship is the greatest event that a submarine can hope to encounter and such a rare opportunity would develop surprisingly similarly to what we see here. The pacing is deliberate and typical of the works coming out of the Ealing, Rank and British-Gaumont studios back in the day: frankly I prefer its quieter, more cerebral approach for its humanity and realism that engages far better than any over-produced Hollywood movie ever could. This reminds me of Powell and Pressburger's The 49th Parallel thanks to the powerfully persuasive Eric Portman, a favorite of mine. John Mills receives second billing and a smaller font in the titles, so this is clearly meant to be Mr. Portman's film but the whole cast shines. As for the title sequence, am I the only one who is utterly charmed by Gainsborough Production's lovely pre-CGI Gainsborough Girl?
rewritten_review: Any film about WWII made during WWII by a British production company has no latter-day peer in my opinion. The confluence of so many things near and dear to my heart are in At Dawn We Dive: as a descendant of Admiral Horatio Nelson and student of all aspects of World War Two, particularly naval warfare, I favor depictions of subs and action in the North Atlantic and especially those which include the German side. For those unacquainted with target priorities, an attack on an enemy warship is the greatest event a submarine can hope to encounter and such a rare opportunity would develop surprisingly similarly to what we see here. The pacing is deliberate and typical of works coming out of the Ealing, Rank, and British-Gaumont studios back in the day: frankly, I prefer its quieter, more cerebral approach for its humanity and realism that engages better than any over-produced Hollywood movie. This reminds me of Powell and Pressburger's The 49th Parallel thanks to the powerfully persuasive Eric Portman, a favorite of mine. John Mills receives second billing and a smaller font in the titles, so this is clearly meant to be Mr. Portman's film, but the whole cast shines. As for the title sequence, am I the only one utterly charmed by Gainsborough Production's lovely pre-CGI Gainsborough Girl?

text:
A fun concept, but poorly executed. Except for the fairly good makeup effects, there's really not much to it. There are obvious problems; for example, after taking what seems to be weeks and weeks to get from fat to normal size, the main character seems to go from normal size to deathly thin in days... and once he's deathly thin he stays pretty much equally deathly thin for what seems to be a long time.

In any case, the movie has far worse problems than that--the cinematography is decidedly low-budget-TV-show quality and most of all the acting is pretty awful all around. Robert John Burke seems to always be trying for some kind of weird snarling Charlton Heston impersonation and is literally painful to watch... the only scary thing is that Lucinda Jenney and Kari Wuhrer are both even worse.

The only reason why I'm giving this movie as high as I am is that once the movie enters its last 1/3 or so and Joe Mantegna's character takes over, the movie develops a fun, campy 'cheesefest slaughterhouse' feel, and the gangster's crazy schemes for tormenting the totally obnoxious gypsies are somewhat fun to watch. The ending, if predictable, is also nicely mean. Avoid unless you're a King-o-Phile or are REALLY psyched up at the idea of the voice of Fat Tony from the Simpsons terrorizing a gypsy camp.
rewritten_review:
A fun concept, but poorly executed. Apart from the fairly good makeup effects, there's not much to it. Obvious problems include the main character taking weeks to get from fat to normal size, then going from normal to deathly thin in days, and staying that way for a long time.

Worse issues include low-budget-TV-show-quality cinematography and awful acting. Robert John Burke's weird Charlton Heston impersonation is painful to watch, and Lucinda Jenney and Kari Wuhrer are even worse.

I'm giving this movie a higher rating because, in the last third, Joe Mantegna's character brings a fun, campy 'cheesefest slaughterhouse' feel. His crazy schemes for tormenting the obnoxious gypsies are somewhat fun, and the predictable ending is nicely mean. Avoid unless you're a King-o-Phile or excited about the voice of Fat Tony from the Simpsons terrorizing a gypsy camp.

text:
I must say I was disappointed with this film. Although it is well acted and directed, the underlying story simply plods along too slowly.

Granted, in another mood I would have liked it better. I did chuckle a lot, but rarely laughed out loud; and there was actually a sense of suspense to discover who won. But in contrast to another movie that my wife picked up the same day (one neither of us had heard of before) this one paled in comparison.

If you see lots of movies, then by all means see this -- it's distinctly better than your average fare. But if you (like me) have limited time and want to watch only the best and most entertaining, save this for later.

[Rate: 7/10]
rewritten_review:
I must say I was disappointed with this film. Although it is well acted and directed, the underlying story simply plods along too slowly. The pacing of the narrative seemed to drag, making it difficult to stay engaged throughout the entire runtime. The performances by the cast were commendable, bringing depth and nuance to their characters, and the direction was skillful, ensuring that each scene was visually appealing and well-executed. However, despite these strengths, the story failed to maintain a consistent momentum that would keep viewers on the edge of their seats.

Granted, in another mood I would have liked it better. Sometimes, the enjoyment of a film can heavily depend on the viewer's current state of mind and expectations. On a different day, perhaps I would have appreciated the film's subtleties and slower pace more. I did chuckle a lot, but rarely laughed out loud; and there was actually a sense of suspense to discover who won. The humor, while present, was more understated than I anticipated, eliciting more smiles and quiet chuckles rather than hearty laughter. Nevertheless, there was a genuine sense of intrigue as the story unfolded, especially in trying to unravel the mystery of who ultimately came out on top.

But in contrast to another movie that my wife picked up the same day (one neither of us had heard of before) this one paled in comparison. The other film, despite being unfamiliar to us, managed to capture our attention and deliver a more engaging and memorable experience. This contrast highlighted the shortcomings of the film in question, emphasizing how it failed to leave a lasting impression despite its technical merits and talented cast.

If you see lots of movies, then by all means see this -- it's distinctly better than your average fare. For avid moviegoers who consume films regularly, this one might offer enough merit to warrant a viewing. It stands above the standard offerings available and has certain qualities that could be appreciated by those who watch a wide array of films. But if you (like me) have limited time and want to watch only the best and most entertaining, save this for later. For those with a more selective approach to movie-watching, prioritizing only the most captivating and exceptional films, it might be best to reserve this one for a time when your options are more limited or when you are in the mood for something slightly off the beaten path.

[Rate: 7/10]

text:
In Iran, women are officially banned from men's sporting events. In June 2005, the Iran's national soccer team has an important game against Bahrain in the Azadi Stadium for the qualification of the World Cup. A group of Iranian girls and lovers of soccer dresses like boys and unsuccessfully attempts to enter in the stadium being arrested.

Soccer (and Flamengo's team), beach and movies are my greatest passions; therefore I loved this little gem about a group of girls and their passion for soccer. The director Jafar Panahi, from "The White Balloon", "The Mirror" and "The Circle", shot this movie on the day that Iran defeated Bahrain and qualified to the World Cup in Germany. The dramatic and funny adventure of these Iranian girls is one of the most delightful movies I have ever seen. My vote is nine.

Title (Brazil): Not Available
rewritten_review:
In Iran, women are officially banned from men's sporting events. In June 2005, Iran's national soccer team had a crucial and important game against Bahrain in the Azadi Stadium for the qualification of the World Cup. A group of Iranian girls and lovers of soccer, driven by their passion for the sport, decided to dress like boys and made an attempt to enter the stadium. However, their attempt was unsuccessful, and they were arrested. This incident highlights the lengths to which these young women were willing to go to support their national team and be part of the electrifying atmosphere of the match. 

Soccer (and Flamengo's team), beach, and movies are my greatest passions; therefore I was absolutely captivated and loved this little gem about a group of girls and their unwavering passion for soccer. The director Jafar Panahi, renowned for his work in "The White Balloon," "The Mirror," and "The Circle," skillfully shot this movie on the very day that Iran defeated Bahrain and secured their qualification for the World Cup in Germany. This context adds a layer of authenticity and excitement to the film, as it captures the real emotions and stakes involved in that historic match. 

The dramatic and funny adventure of these Iranian girls is one of the most delightful movies I have ever seen, as it combines a poignant social commentary with humor and heart. The film effectively portrays the struggles and determination of these young women, showcasing their courage and love for the game, despite the societal constraints they face. My vote is nine, as it truly stands out as an exceptional and inspiring story. 

Title (Brazil): Not Available

text: Katharine Hepburn as a mountain woman who mixes prayer with positive thinking--and is thought by the local folk to be a witch. Kate works overly-hard trying to convince us she's a backwoods hick (named Trigger Hicks!), but you can see she doesn't even believe in this unintentionally comical scenario. Constantly-smiling Robert Young plays a foreman working on the construction of a mountain dam who becomes Trigger's first crush...but alas, he's married! No amount of white magic can resuscitate this formula, based on a play and brought to the screen by R.K.O. with too broad a hillbilly flourish. It is ungodly, and just about unwatchable. *1/2 from ****
rewritten_review: Katharine Hepburn takes on the role of a mountain woman who intriguingly combines prayer with positive thinking. However, she is thought by the local folk to be a witch. In this film, Kate puts in an overly-hard effort trying to convince the audience that she's a backwoods hick, even adopting the name Trigger Hicks. Despite her efforts, it's evident that she doesn't even believe in this unintentionally comical scenario herself. Opposite her, we have the constantly-smiling Robert Young, who plays a foreman involved in the construction of a mountain dam. He becomes the object of Trigger's first crush, but, unfortunately for her, he's already married! The plot thickens, but sadly, no amount of white magic can resuscitate this formulaic story, which is based on a play. The film was brought to the screen by R.K.O., but it suffers from an overly broad hillbilly flourish. The end result is something that feels ungodly, and, quite frankly, just about unwatchable. This film receives a rating of *1/2 from ****, reflecting its failure to engage or entertain effectively.

text: If you are a traveller, if there is a fire burning into your heart, if you'd call "home" every place on earth, but none of them can give you enough, if you are always looking for the next thing and if you believe the other part of your soul is somewhere out there, see this movie and you'll find out a little, but wonderful, piece of life sitting next to you.
rewritten_review: If you are a traveler with an insatiable wanderlust, if there is a fire burning intensely into your heart that drives you to explore the unknown, if you'd call "home" every place on earth yet find that none of them can give you enough satisfaction or fulfillment, if you are always eagerly looking for the next adventure or the next challenge and if you believe with all your heart that the other part of your soul is somewhere out there waiting to be discovered, see this movie and you'll find out a little, but wonderful, piece of life sitting right there next to you. This film offers a glimpse into the beauty of the journey and the connections we make along the way, capturing the essence of what it means to search for something greater than ourselves. It resonates with those who are perpetually on a quest for meaning and belonging, and it highlights the extraordinary moments that can be found in the most unexpected places. Watching this movie will remind you that the world is vast and full of possibilities, and that sometimes, the answers we seek are closer than we think.

text:
A friend and I went through a phase some (alot of) years ago of selecting the crappest horror films in the video shop for an evening's entertainment. For some reason, I ended up buying this one (probably v. v. cheap).

The cheap synth soundtrack is a classic of its time and genre. There's also a few very amusing scenes. Among them is a scene where a man's being attacked and defends himself with a number of unlikely objects, it made me laugh at the time (doesn't seem quite so funny in retrospect but there you go).

Apart from that it's total crap, mind you. But probably worth a watch if you like films like "Chopping Mall". Yes, I've seen that too.
rewritten_review:
A friend and I went through a phase some (a lot of) years ago of selecting the crappest horror films in the video shop for an evening's entertainment. We would spend hours browsing through the aisles, laughing at the ridiculous covers and even more ridiculous plots. For some reason, I ended up buying this one, probably because it was v. v. cheap, and I couldn't resist the urge to own a piece of cinematic history, however dubious it might be. 

The cheap synth soundtrack is a classic of its time and genre, perfectly capturing the cheesy essence of 80s horror films. It has that unmistakable, tinny sound that seems to be an obligatory feature of low-budget horror flicks from that era. There's also a few very amusing scenes that stuck with me over the years. Among them is a scene where a man's being attacked and defends himself with a number of unlikely objects. It's one of those moments that made me laugh at the time, probably more than it should have, but that's part of the charm of these movies. It doesn't seem quite so funny in retrospect, but there you go – sometimes nostalgia adds a layer of humor that wasn't intended by the filmmakers.

Apart from that, it's total crap, mind you. The acting is wooden, the plot makes little sense, and the special effects are laughable at best. But probably worth a watch if you like films like "Chopping Mall". Yes, I've seen that too, and I have to admit that there's something oddly endearing about these terrible horror movies. They have a way of bringing people together, as you marvel at how they ever got made and why anyone thought they were a good idea. So, if you're in the mood for some mindless entertainment and a good laugh, this could be just the film for you.

text:
The 2005 edition of the Royal Rumble came live from the Save Mart Centre in Fresno, California. The two top Championships of the WWE were being defended, The Undertaker was battling Heidenreich in a Casket match, Shawn Michaels was taking on Edge in a grudge match that had been building up since last October and of course the every man for himself over the top rope Royal Rumble match itself. Who was going to take the price this year? Chris Benoit? Edge? Eddie Guerrero? Edge? John Cena? Batista? Edge? Shawn Michaels? There was no shortage of contenders.

It was Batista that picked up the popular victory in the main event battle but not without controversy, or should I say, a botched finish. Batista and John Cena were the final two men in the ring. Batista was supposed to dump the young Smackdown! star over the top rope but it all went wrong and they both went toppling to the floor. The referees acted on their feet as we had an arm-raising contest similar to that of Bret hart and Lex Luger back in 1994. This brought out the chairman of the board. Vinnie Mac walked down to the ring the way only he can but injured himself badly getting into the ring. It was unusual to see Vince McMahon sitting, legs out, telling the two men to restart the match. Batista then did was he was supposed to do first time round and dumped Cena to the floor sealing his own future with a Championship match at WrestleMania 21.

The undercard for this years Royal Rumble had a very solid line up, with many of WWE's biggest stars competing in matches. Each brand had two big matches each.

Raw opened the night with the match between Shawn Michaels and Edge. This was a good technical contest. Back and fourth all the way until Edge got the pinfall. This was a smart booking decision and kept Edge as a contender to the World Heavyweight Championship.

The second match of the night was the feud ending Casket match between The Undertaker and Heidenreich. The match was not a classic, but then again have their been any classic Casket matches? It was entertaining. Especially when Snitsky got involved and then Kane popped out the casket to a great pop. The Undertaker surprised no one when he got the win, slamming the lid on Heidenreich and this mediocre feud.

The first of the two Championship matches of the night was John Bradshaw Layfields defence of the WWE Championship in a triple Threat match against both Kurt Angle and the Big Show. This match was very good. Again, not a classic but entertaining none the less. JBL took the win after pinning Kurt Angle. His celebration was short lived however when backstage teddy Long informed him at No Way Out he would defend the WWE Championship in a Barbed Wire Steel cage match against Big Show. Not a very nice way to spend a Sunday night.

And of course there is no show without Punch. Punch of course being reigning World Heavyweight Champion Triple H. His rematch from Unforgiven 2004 with Randy Orton was lot better than the original encounter. It's a pity because they just don't seem to click to well in the ring and this would be an excellent feud if they did. Orton played the concussion role very well and went down in defeat to The Game.

So the first big one of 2005 was a good one. It achieved its goals. Feuds ended and new ones began. We were now officially on the road to WrestleMania 21.
rewritten_review:
The 2005 Royal Rumble took place at the Save Mart Centre in Fresno, California. The WWE's top Championships were defended, with The Undertaker battling Heidenreich in a Casket match, Shawn Michaels facing Edge in a grudge match, and the Royal Rumble match itself. Batista won the Rumble in a controversial finish with John Cena, leading to a restart and Batista securing a Championship match at WrestleMania 21. Vince McMahon injured himself entering the ring to resolve the botched finish.

The undercard was solid, featuring top WWE stars. Raw's Shawn Michaels vs. Edge opened the night with Edge winning to remain a contender for the World Heavyweight Championship. The Undertaker defeated Heidenreich in a Casket match with interference from Snitsky and Kane. John Bradshaw Layfield defended the WWE Championship in a triple threat against Kurt Angle and Big Show, pinning Angle to win. His victory was short-lived as Teddy Long announced a Barbed Wire Steel Cage match against Big Show at No Way Out.

Lastly, reigning World Heavyweight Champion Triple H faced Randy Orton in a rematch from Unforgiven 2004. Despite not clicking well, Orton's portrayal of a concussion was convincing, and he lost to Triple H. The event achieved its goals, ending and starting feuds, officially setting the stage for WrestleMania 21.

text: The movie is a bit "thin" after reading the book, but it's still one of the greatest movies ever made. Sheryl Lee is beautiful and Nick Nolte is really "vonneguty". He makes great job expressing the feelings from the book to the film. Not many films engage the feeling of the book as well as Mother Night does.
rewritten_review: The movie is a bit "thin" after reading the book, but it's still undeniably one of the greatest movies ever made. Sheryl Lee is absolutely beautiful, and Nick Nolte is really "vonneguty" in a way that captures the essence of the author's unique style. He makes a great job of expressing the deep and complex feelings from the book to the film, which is no small feat. Not many films manage to engage the feeling of the book as well as Mother Night does, making it a rare accomplishment in the world of adaptations. It’s impressive how the filmmakers were able to translate the intricate layers of the narrative into a visual medium without losing the core essence of the story. The performances by the entire cast enhance the movie, but it is Nolte's portrayal that truly stands out, bringing to life the nuances and emotional depth that are so integral to the book. The film manages to convey the same sense of introspection and moral ambiguity that the book so powerfully explores. Despite the challenges of adapting such a complex narrative, Mother Night succeeds in delivering a cinematic experience that resonates with both fans of the book and those new to the story. This makes it not just a great adaptation, but a remarkable film in its own right.

text:
When I was over at Hollywood video I looked through their clearance out movies and there was DEMONICUS for five buckaroos plus fifty percent off! I saw it only once before and couldn't pass up this great deal! The second viewing was much better than the first. The box is so cool and the music is very good. If you haven't seen Demonicus yet I recommend that you do or if you rented and hated Demonicus do give it another chance as another viewing of it may change your mind. If you seen a copy at Hollywood Video for the price I got it for don't pass it up as it is a great deal!

Demonicus is well a very different but entertaining movie.Believe it or not is like watching a interactive video game with out playing it!It has very low budget and actors I'M sure that nobody is familiar with. We began the the video game uh I mean film with a guy and a woman some where in Italy and there is a cave that actually looks like a rail road/train track tunnel and she says don't go in there and what does he do?The normal stuff!HE DIDN'T LISTEN TO HER! He goes in there and find lots of gladiator artifacts and armor and a almost perfectly preserved body of a legendary gladiator named Tyrannous!Where did the chair come from that Tyrannous was sitting on and how did his body stay so good and where did the Cauldron Pot come from?So every cave is complete with a Caultron Pot?Tyrannous is wearing his armor,helmet,and has a weapon or two.He does the dumbest thing a person could do,he puts on the helmet and is taken over by the spirit of Tyrannous! From there he walks around just killing all of the campers near by to bring back the real Tyrannous.

Now,I said before its like a video game.Its hard to explain but it just feels like it.The music even sounds like video games.The acting is really terrible.The actors say things like why is he doing this,oh he was nuts already and Fine since he's nuts i'm going home!Also the movie also has some major errors like a guy is running and trying to find his girlfriend in the night and is still running in the day time still searching for her with out taking a break!

This movie has some errors but it isn't a classic like Werewolf but it is entertaining if you like really low budget error prone movies then you better see Demonicus!
rewritten_review:
When I was at Hollywood Video, I found DEMONICUS in their clearance movies for five buckaroos, plus fifty percent off! I saw it once before and couldn't pass up this deal! The second viewing was much better. The box is cool, and the music is very good. If you haven't seen Demonicus yet, I recommend you do, or if you rented and hated it, give it another chance as another viewing may change your mind. If you see a copy at Hollywood Video for the price I got it for, don't pass it up!

Demonicus is a very different but entertaining movie. Believe it or not, it's like watching an interactive video game without playing it! It has a very low budget and actors I'm sure nobody is familiar with. We begin the video game, uh I mean film, with a guy and a woman somewhere in Italy and there's a cave that looks like a train track tunnel. She says don't go in there, and he does the normal stuff—HE DIDN'T LISTEN! He goes in, finds gladiator artifacts and a preserved body of a legendary gladiator named Tyrannous. Where did the chair come from that Tyrannous was sitting on, and how did his body stay so good, and where did the Cauldron Pot come from? Every cave is complete with a Cauldron Pot? Tyrannous is wearing armor, a helmet, and has weapons. He does the dumbest thing—he puts on the helmet and is taken over by Tyrannous! From there, he walks around killing all the nearby campers to bring back the real Tyrannous.

I said before it's like a video game. It's hard to explain, but it feels like it. The music even sounds like video games. The acting is terrible. Actors say things like "why is he doing this," "oh he was nuts already," and "fine, since he's nuts I'm going home!" The movie has errors, like a guy running to find his girlfriend at night and still running in the daytime without a break!

This movie has errors, but it isn't a classic like Werewolf. It is entertaining if you like really low-budget, error-prone movies. You better see Demonicus!

text: Shame to see an interesting story diluted into standard "Vietnam made for TV" fare. Usually HBO movies are a substantial cut above TV. Bill Paxton was a pretty good choice for the lead role, but wasn't given much to work with.
rewritten_review: It's truly a shame to see an interesting story diluted into standard "Vietnam made for TV" fare. Typically, HBO movies are known for being a substantial cut above regular TV offerings, providing viewers with rich storytelling and high production values. However, this particular film falls short of those expectations. Bill Paxton, who was a pretty good choice for the lead role, unfortunately wasn't given much to work with. His talents seem underutilized in a film that could have been so much more. The potential for a compelling narrative was there, but somehow the execution missed the mark, leaving viewers with a sense of what could have been rather than what is. It's disappointing to see a network known for its quality productions deliver something that feels so ordinary and formulaic. The promise of an engaging and unique perspective on a Vietnam story was overshadowed by the reliance on tropes and clichés that have been seen time and time again.

text:
I accidentally caught this in the middle flipping channels. I immediately recognized almost everyone in the cast, "groovy" haircuts aside, and wondered what kind of film could attract such a cast of both past and future stars? Having not seen the original, I guessed it might be the Poseidon Adventure, since it was obviously on a ship in distress. Was I wrong! I cannot for the life of me imagine why any of these great (or promising) actors and actresses would allow their name to be associated with such trash. There is no story, the performances all looked forced, the characters a parody of the usual disaster movie roles that are suddenly brought together by an event, and start pontificating about the real meaning of life at the level of bumper sticker philosophy.

It is only worthwhile to see the unusually awful performances by such greats as Sally Field, Michael Caine, et al. They must have needed the money badly. Can we blame the director?
rewritten_review:
I accidentally caught this in the middle flipping channels. I immediately recognized almost everyone in the cast, "groovy" haircuts aside, and wondered what kind of film could attract such a cast of both past and future stars? Having not seen the original, I guessed it might be the Poseidon Adventure, since it was obviously on a ship in distress. Was I wrong! I cannot for the life of me imagine why any of these great (or promising) actors and actresses would allow their name to be associated with such trash. There is no story, the performances all looked forced, the characters a parody of the usual disaster movie roles that are suddenly brought together by an event, and start pontificating about the real meaning of life at the level of bumper sticker philosophy.

As I sat there watching, I couldn't help but feel a sense of disbelief. This was a film that seemed to have everything going for it, at least on paper. The cast was filled with actors who had either made their mark in the industry or were on the cusp of doing so. These were individuals whose work I had admired in other projects, yet here they were, struggling through a script that seemed to do them no favors. The dialogue was clunky, filled with clichés and platitudes that might have been at home on a motivational poster but felt completely out of place in a film that was ostensibly about survival and human resilience.

The ship setting, which could have provided a claustrophobic and intense backdrop for the drama, was instead underutilized. The tension that should have been palpable was instead missing, leaving a void that was filled with performances that, to put it bluntly, seemed phoned in. It's as if the actors themselves knew they were fighting a losing battle against a script that gave them nothing to work with. Instead of characters with depth, we were given caricatures, each one a shallow representation of what could have been much more nuanced and compelling roles.

The film's attempts at exploring deeper themes were laughable at best. Characters would launch into monologues about the meaning of life that were so trite and simplistic they bordered on parody. It was as though the film was trying to say something profound, but couldn't quite figure out what that was, resulting in a muddled mess of ideas that never coalesced into anything meaningful. This was not the introspective exploration of humanity that it perhaps aspired to be, but rather a collection of half-baked thoughts presented with all the subtlety of a sledgehammer.

It is only worthwhile to see the unusually awful performances by such greats as Sally Field, Michael Caine, et al. They must have needed the money badly. Can we blame the director? It seems that everyone involved, from the cast to the crew, was let down by a project that promised much but delivered little. The director, who should have been the guiding force, appears to have been unable to steer this ship away from the iceberg it ultimately collided with. For fans of the actors, perhaps there's a certain morbid curiosity in watching them flounder through this cinematic disaster, but for anyone else, this is likely a film best left adrift at sea.

text: Henry, a veterinarian (Paul Rudd), and his bossy fiancé, Kate (Eva Longoria) are looking over the last minute arrangements for their reception. It is the morning of their wedding and Kate is in a frenzy, giving the caterers an earful about her demands for food presentation. But, horror of horrors, the "angel" ice sculpture, ordered by Kate, arrives without wings. In an ensuing fight with the sculptor, the heavy "ice" maiden falls on Kate and sends her to the hereafter. Now, one year later, Henry's sister arranges for a psychic to tell the young vet that Kate would have wanted him to starting dating other ladies and move forward. Yet, the lovely medium, Ashley (Lake Bell) becomes interested in Henry herself, much to the chagrin of her catering partner (Jason Biggs). More importantly, Kate returns from the other side to create havoc for Ashley, as she has no intentions of letting another woman get her hands on Henry. Can anything be done to return Kate into heaven for good? This is an abysmal romantic comedy, one of the worst this dedicated fan has ever seen. No, its not the cast, as they try gamely to make things work. Longoria is beautiful and funny as the overbearing fiancé and Bell has an offbeat style and humor that is likewise infectious. Biggs, a funny thespian, too, is totally wasted. As for Rudd, a very gifted performer (see Anchorman, Knocked Up, or Clueless, please) he tries hardest of all and, in truth, is the main reason to see this clunker. His charm, looks, and easy wit go a long way in making the film bearable. But, nothing can turn a mindless script and terrible direction into a winner, absolutely nothing. So, if you are a dyed-in-the-wool fan of romantic comedy, think long and hard before you fork over any money for this one. Even were free tickets to fall into your lap, be warned that this movie is a near-death experience for those who adore love-and-laugh cinema.
rewritten_review: Henry, a veterinarian (Paul Rudd), and his bossy fiancé, Kate (Eva Longoria), are finalizing their wedding reception plans. On their wedding morning, Kate is frantic about food presentation and discovers their "angel" ice sculpture lacks wings. During a fight with the sculptor, the sculpture falls on Kate, killing her. A year later, Henry's sister hires a psychic to encourage him to date again. The medium, Ashley (Lake Bell), becomes interested in Henry, angering her partner (Jason Biggs). Meanwhile, Kate's ghost returns to sabotage Ashley's efforts, refusing to let another woman have Henry. Can Kate be sent back to heaven permanently? This romantic comedy is one of the worst, despite the cast's efforts. Longoria is charming as the controlling fiancé, and Bell has infectious humor. Biggs is underused. Rudd, a talented actor (see Anchorman, Knocked Up, or Clueless), is the film's saving grace with his charm and wit. However, nothing can salvage the mindless script and poor direction. Dedicated rom-com fans should think twice before spending money on this film. Even free tickets might not be worth the near-death experience for love-and-laugh cinema enthusiasts.

text:
Probably one of the most boriest slasher movies ever, badly acted and badly written.

THE PLOT Five students staying behind during the holidays closing down a dorm, but somebody has designs on them and starts killing them off one by one, the main suspect is the creepy groundskeeper John Hemmitt played by Woody Roll, or could it be one of the five characters.

ACTING Not that bad not that great either apart from Daphne Zungia who dies way too quickly and should have been the main heroine, and the rest well quite dull although Laura Lapinski the main heroine sometimes has her charm and you do feel sorry for her in the end.

THE KILLS Can't really see why they banned this, the kills look fake mostly, one guy has his hand sliced in half in the beginning which looks really fake, but the others are quite nasty like one girl gets her head run over by a car, one girl gets boiled alive and another gets burned alive.

OVERALL Not really a great slasher could have been a lot better

Probably one of the most boriest slasher movies ever, badly acted and badly written.

THE PLOT Five students staying behind during the holidays closing down a dorm, but somebody has designs on them and starts killing them off one by one, the main suspect is the creepy groundskeeper John Hemmitt played by Woody Roll, or could it be one of the five characters.

ACTING Not that bad not that great either apart from Daphne Zungia who dies way too quickly and should have been the main heroine, and the rest well quite dull although Laura Lapinski the main heroine sometimes has her charm and you do feel sorry for her in the end.

THE KILLS Can't really see why they banned this, the kills look fake mostly, one guy has his hand sliced in half in the beginning which looks really fake, but the others are quite nasty like one girl gets her head run over by a car, one girl gets boiled alive and another gets burned alive.

OVERALL Not really a great slasher could have been a lot better.

text: I caught the first screening of Driving Lessons at the Tribeca Film Festival. Rupert Grint shows he can act past Harry Potter. Laura Linney is amazing as the overbearing mother. Julie Walters is hilarious as Dame Evie Walton, with a mouth worse than a sailor. I hope that this film is picked up by an American distributor so that everyone can see it. This film is not only about Driving Lessons, but life lessons. Ben (Rupert Grint) is torn between wanting to obey his overbearing mother and vicar father and wanting to live his own life. It's an amazing film, from an amazing director whose taken his own life and put it on the screen for everyone to see, and everyone who can, should.
rewritten_review:
I caught the first screening of Driving Lessons at the Tribeca Film Festival, and I must say it was an incredible experience. Rupert Grint truly shows that he can act beyond his iconic role as Ron Weasley in the Harry Potter series. It's refreshing to see him take on a character like Ben, and he does so with remarkable skill and depth. Laura Linney is absolutely amazing in her role as the overbearing mother, bringing both intensity and nuance to the character. Her performance truly adds another layer to the film, making it even more compelling to watch.

Julie Walters is downright hilarious as Dame Evie Walton. Her character is unforgettable, with a mouth that's worse than a sailor's, delivering lines that are sure to make audiences laugh out loud. Walters' comedic timing and ability to embody such a vibrant, unapologetic character is simply fantastic. I really hope that this film is picked up by an American distributor soon so that everyone has the opportunity to see it. It's a film that deserves to be widely viewed and appreciated by audiences everywhere.

This film is not just about Driving Lessons, but it delves into life lessons as well. Ben, portrayed by Rupert Grint, is a young man who finds himself torn between his desire to obey his overbearing mother and vicar father, and his longing to live his own life and make his own choices. This internal conflict is portrayed beautifully, and it's something that many people can relate to on a personal level. The film's exploration of these themes is both poignant and thought-provoking.

It's an amazing film from an amazing director, who has taken his own life experiences and put them on the screen for everyone to see. The authenticity and heart behind the storytelling are evident, making it a truly meaningful cinematic experience. Everyone who has the chance to see it should take advantage of that opportunity, as it offers a unique perspective and a deeply engaging narrative.

text:
I have to vote this 10 out of 10 in the rare chance that she happens to see this review, takes pity on me, whisks me to Hollywood and involves me in her freaky/funny world. But in all seriousness, it was good. First episode is obviously finding it's feet, but it's got that Silverman weirdness running all the way through it. It's not a laugh out loud sort of comedy, but that's good thing, too much has a laughter-track to it, and this wouldn't be right with cues when to laugh, it's to the audience to hear their inner jester laughing at the absurdness of it all. I can easily see this as being the bizarro Drew Carey show with it's weird characters and incredibly strong central character. Well worth a watch, look forward to the following episodes. A VERY good chance from the usual comedy out there.

ps, Sarah? Call me....
rewritten_review:
I have to vote this 10 out of 10 in the rare chance that she happens to see this review, takes pity on me, whisks me to Hollywood and involves me in her freaky/funny world. But in all seriousness, it was good. First episode is obviously finding its feet, but it's got that Silverman weirdness running all the way through it. The humor is distinct, and it's not a laugh-out-loud sort of comedy, but that's a good thing. Too much has a laughter track to it, and this wouldn't be right with cues on when to laugh; it's up to the audience to hear their inner jester laughing at the absurdity of it all. The freedom to interpret the humor as one sees fit really adds to the unique experience of watching the show. Each scene unfolds with a kind of bizarre elegance that keeps you guessing and wanting more. I can easily see this as being the bizarro Drew Carey show with its weird characters and incredibly strong central character. The ensemble of quirky roles adds layers of interest to each episode and complements the main storyline seamlessly. Well worth a watch, and I look forward to the following episodes. There’s a VERY good chance this will stand out from the usual comedy out there, and it's refreshing to see something that doesn't follow the traditional comedic formula. The blend of offbeat scenarios and clever writing sets it apart, making each episode a delightful surprise.

ps, Sarah? Call me....

text: This movie was one of the most boring horror movies I have seen in a long time (and I have seen a lot). Personally I liked the piercing take on it all that was original but other than that it was pretty unwatchable. I could not stand Dee Snider as an actor nor as a singer. I seemed that he was trying with everything he said to make it a memorable quote, which they weren't. I can get movies for free and I still didn't think it was worth the time to get.
rewritten_review: This movie was, without a doubt, one of the most boring horror movies I have seen in a long time, and believe me, I have seen a lot of horror films over the years. Personally, I liked the piercing take on it all that was original, which I found to be an interesting aspect and added a small layer of uniqueness to the experience. However, other than that particular element, the movie was pretty much unwatchable for me. I could not stand Dee Snider, neither as an actor nor as a singer. It seemed that he was trying with everything he said to make it a memorable quote, but unfortunately, they weren't memorable at all, and it felt forced and unnatural. I can get movies for free, and even with that being the case, I still didn't think it was worth the time or effort to get this one. The movie simply did not capture my interest or attention in any substantial way, and I found myself disengaged and uninterested throughout most of the film. The performances, especially Dee Snider's, did not resonate with me, and the overall execution left much to be desired.

text: I admire 'Kissing on the Mouth' for its frankness  pubic hair cutting and masturbation, especially from the lead/director Joe Swanberg. They weren't afraid to show trueness to everyday "private" occurrences. Unfortunately, the film falls under the 'The Brown Bunny' realm, though with a slightly more developed plot of jealousy. Yes, it mirrors 'Bunny' with a whole lot of nothing going on, or too many cinematography shots focused (or sincerely unfocused) on absolutely nothing  feet, hands or genitals. Again, unfortunately, I can see why this film was released, and why people are renting: true life sex scenes and full frontal (equally, both male and female) nudity. Other than that, it was a complete waste of time. We quickly learn of a post-college male/female roommate pair in which the male has obvious feelings for the female that sees him as just a friend while continuously having sex with her ex-boyfriend. Other than that, we are subjected to the every-day events of their boring lives: she works for her parents; he works on an extremely uninteresting sexual awareness project on his computer. For this all to work, the dialogue has to be interesting and the acting real. Neither work and it's as boring as watching someone drive for an hour, i.e. 'The Brown Bunny.' The only actor that stands out is Kate Winterich, and even she does some questionable acting. (The DVD extra with her in front of a mike is actually worth watching/listening to.) Again, I admire the filmmakers, especially Swanberg, for baring it all and not being afraid to expose themselves or shower-habits, but overall the film falls flat. It has narrations that doesn't fit the scenes, too many boring everyday events and unconvincing acting that you wonder, other than the soft-porn factor, why you rented this.

They weren't afraid to show trueness to everyday "private" occurrences. Unfortunately, the film falls under 'The Brown Bunny' realm, though with a slightly more developed plot of jealousy. Yes, it mirrors 'Bunny' with a whole lot of nothing going on, or too many shots focused on nothing—feet, hands, or genitals. Unfortunately, I can see why this film was released and why people are renting: true-life sex scenes and full-frontal nudity. Other than that, it was a waste of time. For this to work, the dialogue has to be interesting and the acting real. Neither work, and it's as boring as watching someone drive for an hour, i.e., 'The Brown Bunny.'
