text: Aussie Shakespeare for 18-24 set.with blood ,blood and more blood.and good dose of nudity. this will not be for every one on may levels, to violent for some too cheap for most. done on low budget they try and do there best but it only works sporadically.and this macbeth just seem to be lacking ,its just not compelling. although there is some good acting on the part of most you don't get into there heads especially mecbeths. the best performance came from gary sweet and the strangest mick molly. if your into Shakespeare then see it,but if you like your cheese mature you will love it.it not a bad film but it not that good either. sam peckenpah would of loved it, that is if it was filmed as a western. i was expecting a lot from this, as i loved romper stomper. but this is was a vacant effort.
rewritten_review:
Aussie Shakespeare for the 18-24 set with blood, blood, and more blood, and a good dose of nudity. This will not be for everyone on many levels, too violent for some, too cheap for most. Done on a low budget, they try and do their best, but it only works sporadically. And this Macbeth just seems to be lacking; it's just not compelling. Although there is some good acting on the part of most, you don't get into their heads, especially Macbeth's. The best performance came from Gary Sweet, and the strangest from Mick Molloy. If you're into Shakespeare, then see it, but if you like your cheese mature, you will love it. It's not a bad film, but it's not that good either. Sam Peckinpah would have loved it, that is, if it was filmed as a western. I was expecting a lot from this, as I loved Romper Stomper, but this was a vacant effort.

The film attempts to bring Shakespeare to a younger audience, and while the intention is commendable, the execution leaves much to be desired. The production's low budget is evident in many aspects, from the set design to the special effects, which often come across as unconvincing and detract from the overall experience. The decision to incorporate so much blood and nudity seems more like a gimmick to attract attention rather than a necessary artistic choice. It feels as though the filmmakers were trying to compensate for the lack of depth in the storyline and character development by relying on shock value.

The performances are a mixed bag; while some actors manage to deliver their lines with conviction and bring a semblance of authenticity to their roles, others struggle to capture the essence of their characters. This inconsistency in acting further contributes to the film's inability to fully engage its audience. Gary Sweet stands out with his portrayal, offering a glimpse of what the film could have been with a more cohesive cast. Conversely, Mick Molloy's performance, while intriguing, feels out of place and adds to the overall disjointedness of the film.

Despite these shortcomings, there are moments where the film shows potential, hinting at what could have been a more compelling adaptation of Macbeth. These fleeting glimpses, however, are not enough to salvage the production as a whole. The film's attempt to modernize the classic play while staying true to its dark themes is admirable, but ultimately falls flat due to its uneven pacing and lack of focus.

For those who are die-hard Shakespeare enthusiasts, this film might still hold some appeal, if only for its unique take on the timeless tale. However, those looking for a thought-provoking or faithful adaptation may find themselves disappointed. It's a film that sits in the middle ground, not quite living up to its potential but not entirely devoid of merit either. The comparison to Sam Peckinpah's style is interesting and could have added an intriguing layer to the film had it been approached as a western. Unfortunately, the current iteration fails to capture that gritty, intense energy.

In conclusion, while the film has its moments and some commendable performances, it ultimately does not deliver a compelling version of Macbeth. It's an ambitious project that doesn't quite hit the mark, leaving viewers wanting more substance and coherence. If you're curious and have an appreciation for experimental takes on Shakespeare, it might be worth a watch, but temper your expectations.

text: Just had to write that one liner, but it really is. I love the gangster genre and this is the weakest entry I've seen in recent years . I have praises for everyone involved in most aspects except the most important one, the script . It is a weak story about a petty criminal. No amount of fine acting or black and white film styling can make up for a total lack of substance. I love Kevin Spacey and I hear he's gonna do another film about the general. My advice is don't waste your time.
rewritten_review: I just had to write that one-liner, but it really is the case. I absolutely love the gangster genre, and this film is definitely the weakest entry I've seen in recent years. While I have praises for everyone involved in most aspects of the production, unfortunately, there's an exception when it comes to the most important one, which is the script. The story is undeniably weak and centers around a petty criminal, which is a significant letdown. No amount of fine acting or even the stylish black and white film styling can make up for the total lack of substance in the narrative. I have always been a fan of Kevin Spacey and his work, and I hear he's going to do another film about the general. However, my advice is don't waste your time on this one.

text:
I rented the film (I don't think it got a theatrical release here) out expecting the worse. The previews made the film look awful. I was in fact very surprised, it was well worth watching; it was loosely scripted, almost like an ensemble piece of film. It had some very funny moments in it and although flawed is an effective satire on the show and the people on the show without being too scathing. It is flawed, mainly by the awful soundtrack of bludgeoning 'comedy' effects but on the whole it comes across as honest and generally true to form of the show in an altmanesque or Larry Sanders way.

At the moment it is the fashion to be critical of Jerry Springer, he is also an easy target. Springer could have made Citizen Kane and it would be proclaimed 'the worst film ever made'. I recommend this film for anybody interested in the show. A flawed but innovative and interesting piece of film.
rewritten_review:
I rented the film, which I don't think got a theatrical release here, out of sheer curiosity, fully expecting the worst. The previews made the film look absolutely awful, so my expectations were quite low. However, I was in fact very surprised by what I saw. It was well worth watching and turned out to be a pleasant surprise; it was loosely scripted, almost like an ensemble piece of film. The film had some very funny moments in it and, although flawed, it serves as an effective satire on the show and the people on the show without being too scathing in its approach. It is flawed, mainly by the awful soundtrack of bludgeoning 'comedy' effects, but on the whole, it comes across as honest and generally true to the form of the show in an Altmanesque or Larry Sanders way. The film manages to capture the chaotic and unpredictable nature of the show it is based on, bringing a sense of authenticity to its portrayal that is hard to find in other similar works.

At the moment, it seems to be the fashion to be critical of Jerry Springer, as he is an easy target for many. No matter what he does, Springer could have made Citizen Kane, and it would still be proclaimed 'the worst film ever made' by those who are quick to judge. The film, however, does not deserve such a harsh label. I recommend this film to anybody interested in the show, as it offers a unique perspective and insight into the behind-the-scenes world of the television phenomenon. It is a flawed but innovative and interesting piece of film that stands out for its daring approach and willingness to take risks. The film challenges the viewer to look beyond the surface and question the nature of entertainment and the people who create it. Despite its shortcomings, it provides a thought-provoking and entertaining experience that is worth exploring for anyone curious about the show or the themes it explores.

text: One of the last great musicals of the 60s. I was 7 years old the first time I saw this movie, and it's always been a favorite since then. The musical numbers are all memorable. In the 60s the people who were cast in musicals actually had musical talent (unlike a CERTAIN Academy Award nominated current musical based in a large midwestern city). All of the main roles were beautifully cast...Ron Moody shines as Fagin, as does Shani Wallis as Nancy. Oliver Reed was a menacing Bill Sikes (who thankfully has no musical numbers, lol), and Mark Lester as Oliver and Jack Wild as the Dodger were great too. Mark Lester comes across as an innocent waif, which was what Dickens intended when he wrote the book! Then, of course there are the dozens of dancers who perform in "consider yourself," "I'd Do Anything" "Who Will Buy" and "be Back Soon," many who were children! This is a great show for the whole family.
rewritten_review: One of the last great musicals of the 60s. I was 7 years old the first time I saw this movie, and it's always been a favorite since then. The musical numbers are all memorable and truly capture the essence of the time, with melodies and lyrics that linger in your mind long after the credits have rolled. In the 60s, the people who were cast in musicals actually had musical talent, which made such a difference in the overall quality and authenticity of the performances. It’s a stark contrast to some of the productions we see today, particularly a CERTAIN Academy Award-nominated current musical based in a large midwestern city, where the musical prowess of the cast might be called into question. All of the main roles in this 60s classic were beautifully cast, bringing a level of charisma and depth to the characters that is hard to come by. Ron Moody shines as Fagin, delivering a performance that is both captivating and nuanced. Shani Wallis equally impresses as Nancy, bringing a heartfelt and emotional depth to her role. Oliver Reed was a menacing Bill Sikes, capturing the dark and brooding nature of the character, and thankfully, he has no musical numbers, lol. Mark Lester as Oliver and Jack Wild as the Dodger were great too, each bringing their own unique charm and talent to the screen. Mark Lester comes across as an innocent waif, which was exactly what Dickens intended when he wrote the book, capturing the purity and vulnerability of Oliver's character. Then, of course, there are the dozens of dancers who perform in "Consider Yourself," "I'd Do Anything," "Who Will Buy," and "Be Back Soon," adding a layer of vibrancy and energy to the production. Many of these talented dancers were children, showcasing an incredible level of skill and enthusiasm that truly enhances the film's appeal. This is a great show for the whole family, offering something for viewers of all ages to enjoy and appreciate. The timeless nature of the story, combined with the unforgettable performances, ensures that this musical will continue to be cherished for generations to come.

text: Main theme in this Dirty Harry is that revenge is a dish best served cold. Sandra Locke is as cold in this film as she is beautiful. Locke is an "8" normally, but, with a deadly pistol in her purse, "cocked" for the bad guys, she climbs all the way up the scale to a "10". Having been gang-raped, along with her younger sister, some years ago, Locke, as Jennifer Spencer, has tried to block out the attack from her life, as best she can. Her sister, tho, is almost comatose as a result of the trauma, so the memory is never far from her mind. One day, Jennifer sees one of her attackers on the street in S.F.; she buys a pistol, follows him to a bar, lets him pick her up, then when they're alone in his Cadillac, beginning to make love, she shoots him....once in the genitals, once in the brain - - this in the opening scene!! Ya gotta love this spunky lady. She's got her priorities straight. Plus, Jennifer is a professional artist, putting all her anger on canvas UNTIL NOW. After executing her first perp, Jennifer curiously watches Det. Insp. Harry Callahan process the fresh crime scene after the body is found in the Caddy. Then, she insults some creepy teenage bucks who are hassling women on the street, visits her sister in a nursing home, then goes a'hunting in San Paolo, CA "up the coast" where the rape event took place years ago. With more bullets in her suitcase and more resolve in her mind, our heroine relives the rape inside her head with vivid recall, as she comes closer to executing each subsequent rapist. Not uncommon to us right- wingers, when it comes to sentencing or executing a violent criminal, don't be sorrowful for his own wretched humanity, we REMEMBER the CRIME and the SUFFERING he inflicted. Such recalled events steels Jennifer to pull the trigger on each of her attackers - once in the genitals, once in the brain. Throughout the movie, scenes of Jennifer's revenge are interspersed with good, IL' Dirty Harry blowing away some gangstas in a coffee shop, remember "Go ahead. MAKE my day."? Later on, he threatens to step on a punk kid (who'd just insulted Callahan) in a courthouse elevator like he'd step on dog- s**t....leaving a young female govt employee staring after Clint as if to say "I want to have your baby." My favorite scene is only about 30 minutes into the action, when Harry threatens and frightens a murderous Mafia boss named Threlkis into a fatal coronary during his granddaughter's wedding reception at the Mark Hopkins hotel. Michael Grazzo (Pantangeli in Godfather II) does a wonderful job as the sinful Mafia Don, even if he's only in one scene, dying in a most-convincing manner. However, Harry's troubles aren't over with yet! The elevator punk's gang AND Threlkis' henchmen each attempt to assassinate Harry in two close-ordered scenes, and most of them bad guys end up dying horribly. Yup, some of the gun-play comes off as uninspired screen violence....looking like Clint the Director may have been tired that day of shooting this movie. But, there's only so many ways you can dispatch a man with bullets. The punk kids die much more creatively, though, as they both burn to death and drown in S.F. Bay. Warms my heart. With so much violent intent directed at Insp. Callahan, his bosses send him to San Paolo to try to get some background on the "22 caliber vasectomy killing" as Jennifer Spencer's crime is now known, but not before Harry delivers one of his famous sermons-to-the- chowder-headed-liberals. Love that Harry. While our hero' up annoying the local cops and citizens in San Paolo, two more murders happen, same M.O., on a sleazy, lazy fisherman and on an equally-creepy hardware entrepreneur. Then Harry meets Jennifer! They find they both agree on subjects such as Law and Order, Making the Guilty Pay, etc. Could a hot, love scene be in the offing soon? We're led to believe just that. Characters abound in this Real-Man meets Real-Woman crime drama, and we get to meet a brassy bull-dyke named Raye Parkins who's both irritating and entertaining. Raye set up Jennifer's rape for her "boyfriend" years before, and she'll get hers eventually. The San Paolo Police Chief, played by reliable Eastwood co-star Pat Hingle (the Hanging Judge in 'Hang Em High'), is strangely at odds with Callahan's detective work related to the 22-cal vasectomies, until we find out that his own adolescent son was one of the gang of rapists. Much like Jennifer's sister, Chief Janning's son is now a comatose adult, but driven mad by guilt. It can't end here, though. The dyke's rapist boyfriend, Mick, now a kinky-sex jerk of a criminal, drives in from Vegas becuz Raye's dropped a dime on Jennifer, summoning him up to San Paolo to prevent more executions. Mick sleeps at Raye's house, but his timing is all wrong, and he's arrested before he can spend more time with Raye, mostly due to the fact that she's since been sent to the Island of the Eternal Lesboes by a shot from Jennifer's revolver. Psycho Mick makes bail at long last, with Jennifer gunning for him. A desperate chase ensues, as Harry tries to keep these two from killing each other. It all turns out well in the end, with the good gal and the good guy walking off into the sunset together to a beautiful Roberta Flack blues song.
rewritten_review: The main theme in Dirty Harry is that revenge is a dish best served cold. Sandra Locke, as Jennifer Spencer, is as cold as she is beautiful. Normally an "8," she becomes a "10" with a deadly pistol in her purse. Having been gang-raped years ago, along with her sister, Jennifer tries to block the attack from her life, though her sister's near-comatose state keeps the memory alive. One day, Jennifer spots an attacker in S.F., buys a pistol, and executes him in his Cadillac—once in the genitals, once in the brain. Jennifer, a professional artist, turns to vengeance, tracking down her rapists in San Paolo, CA. Her methodical revenge is interspersed with Dirty Harry's own justice, including a memorable scene where he frightens a Mafia boss to a fatal coronary. Harry faces assassination attempts from thugs but dispatches them creatively. Sent to San Paolo to investigate the "22 caliber vasectomy killing," Harry delivers a sermon to liberals. As two more murders occur, Harry meets Jennifer, sharing views on Law and Order. Could romance be brewing? Characters abound, including Raye Parkins, who set up Jennifer's rape. The San Paolo Police Chief, whose son was one of the rapists, is at odds with Harry. Mick, a rapist, arrives from Vegas but is arrested after Jennifer shoots Raye. After making bail, Mick is pursued by Jennifer, leading to a desperate chase. The film concludes with the good gal and guy walking into the sunset to a Roberta Flack song.

text: Deepa Mehta's "Fire" is groundbreaking, bold, and artistic. A masterful social commentary on the plight of the women from conservative, upper middle class Indian households, this is a film no one should miss. Shabana Azmi and Nandita Das give stellar performances by underplaying their characters as much as possible. A.R. Rahman's music is the work of the genius and almost plays the role of another character in the film. Mehta uses Rahman's score and together, they create such amazing sound montages that effectively portray the views of the world around Radha and Sita whenever they look to each other for support. This film is not about lesbianism as many have branded it. Lesbianism is just a part of the film. It is unfortunate that most people tend to write the film off calling it taboo instead of giving it a chance and looking at its real meaning.
rewritten_review: Deepa Mehta's "Fire" is groundbreaking, bold, and artistic, making it a truly remarkable cinematic experience. A masterful social commentary on the plight of the women from conservative, upper middle class Indian households, this is a film no one should miss if they are interested in thought-provoking cinema. Shabana Azmi and Nandita Das give stellar performances by underplaying their characters as much as possible, bringing a depth and authenticity to their roles that resonates with audiences. A.R. Rahman's music is the work of a genius and almost plays the role of another character in the film, adding to the emotional and narrative depth of the story. Mehta uses Rahman's score to its fullest potential, and together, they create such amazing sound montages that effectively portray the views of the world around Radha and Sita whenever they look to each other for support and understanding. This film is not simply about lesbianism as many have branded it. Lesbianism is just a part of the film, one aspect of a much larger story. It is unfortunate that most people tend to write the film off, calling it taboo instead of giving it a chance and looking at its real meaning and the broader themes it explores. By doing so, they miss out on the opportunity to engage with a powerful and meaningful narrative that challenges societal norms and encourages viewers to think critically about the world around them.

text:
Lifeforce (1985) was a Cannon funded film directed by Tobe Hooper. It's a very interesting film that deals with a pair of space vampires who are accidentally brought back down to Earth during the latest space shuttle mission. Steve Railsback stars as the sole survivor of the tragedy. But really folks the movie is a mere showcase for the natural beauty of Mathilda May. She's one smoking hot number. The director was a huge fan of Female Vampire (a.k.a. Erotikill). Miss May recreates Lina Romay's title role The film is beautifully photographed and directed. There's plenty of gore effects to keep genres fans happy.

I have to give this film a very high rating. Tobe Hooper was the man. He made three interesting films for Cannon during this time period (Texas Chainsaw Massacre II and Invaders from Mars as well). If you like science fiction/horror films, Tobe Hooper films or Mathilda May this film's just up your alley.

Highest Recommendation!

Did I mention Mathilda May is smoking hot?
rewritten_review: Lifeforce (1985), directed by Tobe Hooper and funded by Cannon, is a fascinating film about space vampires accidentally brought to Earth during a space shuttle mission. Steve Railsback stars as the sole survivor. The film is really a showcase for the natural beauty of Mathilda May, who is stunning. Hooper, a fan of Female Vampire, has May recreate Lina Romay's role. The film is beautifully photographed and directed, with plenty of gore effects for genre fans. I give this film a very high rating. Tobe Hooper was the man, creating three interesting films for Cannon at this time, including Texas Chainsaw Massacre II and Invaders from Mars. If you enjoy science fiction/horror, Tobe Hooper films, or Mathilda May, this film is for you. Highest Recommendation! Did I mention Mathilda May is smoking hot?

text:
keys to the VIP is BS.

rob cavaliere vs Justin in season two.

I went to school with rob cavaliere and Adriana Doria. you may remember her as the last girl he was "picking up". this was when the "angry girlfriend" came by, they made out and "left the club together". They were good friends at father bressani chs in woodbridge.

whether or not rob planned it or they asked him to do it, men should know that what they are seeing is not real and the guys on here are douche bags. especially that episode.

one more line to fill space.
rewritten_review:
Keys to the VIP is BS.

Rob Cavaliere vs Justin in Season Two.

I went to school with Rob Cavaliere and Adriana Doria. You may remember her as the last girl he was "picking up". This was when the "angry girlfriend" came by, they made out and "left the club together". They were good friends at Father Bressani CHS in Woodbridge. I remember seeing them interact like that quite often, and it was clear to those of us who knew them that their relationship was more akin to friendly camaraderie than any romantic entanglement. It's interesting to see how reality TV can so easily skew perceptions and create narratives that suit a more dramatic storyline.

Whether or not Rob planned it or they asked him to do it, men should know that what they are seeing is not real and the guys on here are douche bags. Especially that episode. It's a prime example of how editing and scripting can take ordinary interactions and turn them into something entirely fabricated for entertainment purposes. Those who are familiar with the real dynamics between the people on screen can easily see through the facade, but for the unaware viewer, it might seem convincing. The show thrives on such manipulation, crafting scenes that are far removed from the truth of genuine human connections. The entertainment industry often blurs the lines between reality and fiction, and shows like this are a testament to how far producers will go to captivate an audience, even if it means sacrificing authenticity. It's a reminder to take such portrayals with a grain of salt and to be more discerning of the content we're presented with.

One more line to fill space.

text: I don't know which was worse, the viewer's made dopes of, or the stars in this movie who look like dopes. Am I to believe that this woman raised this child for seven years, and never noticed the child was a bit dark ? Am I to believe her mother, her father, and her husband never once said, hmmm this child looks a bit dark ? Am I to believe when the courts ordered the mother to view the adopted parents records, that Lisa Hartman had this wow look on her face, when she told her mother, Christopher is half black ! What ! Was that for real,gee do you think so. So not only did the grandmother, and grandfather look dopey and stupid never once mentioning this, but i guess we were supposed to look surprised and say...hmmmmm omg he is half black ! Totally stupid movie, almost an embarrassment even to watch this !
rewritten_review: I don't know which was worse, the viewer's made dopes of, or the stars in this movie who look like dopes. Am I really supposed to believe that this woman raised this child for seven whole years, and never noticed the child was a bit dark? Am I to believe that her mother, her father, and her husband never once said, hmmm this child looks a bit dark? Am I to believe when the courts ordered the mother to view the adopted parents' records, that Lisa Hartman had this wow look on her face, when she told her mother, Christopher is half black! What! Was that for real, gee do you think so. So not only did the grandmother, and grandfather look dopey and stupid never once mentioning this, but I guess we were supposed to look surprised and say...hmmmmm omg he is half black! It’s just so unbelievable. Totally stupid movie, almost an embarrassment even to watch this! The whole premise is just absurd, and it’s astonishing that they thought the audience wouldn’t notice this glaring oversight. The film goes on and on expecting us to suspend disbelief on a matter that's so glaringly obvious. The writing, the acting, everything just seemed to contribute to this ridiculous plot point. It's almost as if they were trying to see just how far they could push the boundaries of plausibility, and they failed miserably. Every time I think about it, I can't help but wonder how this even got past the initial script review. The characters are written in such a way that they appear utterly clueless, and unfortunately, that extends to the audience too. I can't fathom how they expected anyone to take this seriously. The entire narrative falls apart because of this one absurdity, and it makes the whole movie difficult to watch. It's baffling that they thought this was a good idea. It's just so completely unrealistic and poorly thought out.

text:
The second alternate Gundam universe tale (G-Gundam being the first), Gundam Wing is yet another different view into the Gundam verse. The familiar elements are found but Gundam Wing is actually different then its counterparts. The biggest being the Gundams are nothing more than terrorists combating one lone organization. In truth, the series doesn't really become a show about war until episode 7 but in truth the real conflict, the Eve Wars, don't happen until the later episodes.

The greatest positives of this series are it's characters. All the main characters are fleshed out throughout the 49 episode run and you can really sympathize with each of the roles their put in. Another great plus is the fantastic character and mecha design of the series. The designs put some of it's other Gundam counterparts to shame.

One of the biggest criticism of this series is how many die hard UC fans claim rip off of the original UC saga. Why Gundam Wing gets this rap when the more apparent UC clone of Gundam Seed is out there is beyond me. True there are many moments lifted but their told in new ways and there are distinct differences as well.

Take for example, the usual comparison of Zechs Merquise and UC Icon Char Aznable. Throughout the series, Zechs is more the outcast in the Alliance and in ways OZ as well, while the Red Comet was shining symbol of Zeon. Another big difference is the fact Zechs loses a lot soldiers under his command hence the other nickname he's given in the early episodes: "Killer of his own men." Char isn't given this label.

The problems with this series isn't the philosophy mumbo jumbo but two problems. The first is the reused animation footage of the Gundams attacks. Sure it's fun seeing Heavy Arms attack tanks, MS, and planes the first time. But on it's fourth re-use scenes like this do get old.

The second problem is that the entire series is supposed to take place during an entire year. If you really think about all the events springing in the series, a lot happens in just one lone year.

But I guess you can easily dismiss this fact when ignoring the intro's first lines every so often. As it ranks, this is probably the best of the Alternate universe Gundam tales and a great introduction into the Gundam world. After all, this was the very first Gundam anime to air in the US television.
rewritten_review:
Gundam Wing, the second alternate Gundam universe tale after G-Gundam, offers a unique perspective in the Gundam verse. While familiar elements are present, Gundam Wing distinguishes itself by portraying the Gundams as terrorists fighting a single organization. The series truly becomes a war story by episode 7, with the real conflict, the Eve Wars, unfolding later.

The series' greatest strengths are its characters, who are well-developed over 49 episodes, making their roles relatable. Additionally, the character and mecha designs are exceptional, surpassing some other Gundam counterparts.

Critics often claim it copies the original UC saga, but Gundam Wing tells its story in new ways with distinct differences. For instance, Zechs Merquise is often compared to UC Icon Char Aznable, but Zechs is more of an outcast in the Alliance and OZ, while Char was a symbol of Zeon. Also, Zechs, unlike Char, is known as the "Killer of his own men" for losing many soldiers.

The series has two main issues. First, the recycled animation of Gundam attacks becomes repetitive. Second, the plot's extensive events supposedly occur within a single year, which feels unrealistic. However, these can be overlooked, and the show remains the best of the Alternate universe Gundam tales and a great introduction to the Gundam world, especially as the first Gundam anime to air on US television.

text: I can't believe I watched this expecting more. It starts out OK. This movie pushes the limits of reality way to far!! At least the first one was somewhat realistic. It rips off the first movie and even mentions the Joshua Project. Anyone who knows anything about computers will hate this movie. It does have one good message in it though, WATCH OUT FOR BIG BROTHER!!! The movie just makes it seem like Big Brother is way bigger than he actually is in reality. That was very aggravating. Even the make-up on the actors was completely bad. Some of the acting is pretty good. Some of the acting is really bad though. The script was OK at some points and completely messed up at other parts. This movie plays on convenience about every five minutes. Like I said, I can't believe I watched it expecting more. I think I am gonna pop in the original to get back to earth...Q
rewritten_review: I can't believe I watched this expecting more. It starts out OK. This movie pushes the limits of reality way too far!! At least the first one was somewhat realistic. It rips off the first movie and even mentions the Joshua Project. Anyone who knows anything about computers will hate this movie. It does have one good message in it though, WATCH OUT FOR BIG BROTHER!!! The movie just makes it seem like Big Brother is way bigger than he actually is in reality. That was very aggravating. Even the make-up on the actors was completely bad. Some of the acting is pretty good. Some of the acting is really bad though. The script was OK at some points and completely messed up at other parts. This movie plays on convenience about every five minutes. The plot just unfolds in a way that's more about convenience than substance, which is frustrating for viewers looking for something genuine. Like I said, I can't believe I watched it expecting more. I think I am gonna pop in the original to get back to earth. It's really disappointing when a sequel doesn't live up to the standards of the original. You go into it with hopes of seeing the story develop or the characters grow, but instead, it feels like a cheap imitation. I guess that's the risk with sequels, especially when the first installment sets a certain bar of quality or realism. It's like they tried to recreate the magic without really understanding what made the original special. Anyway, hopefully, revisiting the original will remind me why I liked the series in the first place.

text:
My gosh, this movie was nothing more than filmmaking by numbers. Struggling salesman can't make a go of it in New York, mentor with a heart of gold takes him under his wing, struggling salesman moves to California and makes it big, then loses it big, then bounces back with the simple life, then hits rock bottom trying to get back to the top. I don't think I can remember any part of the plot that took more than five seconds to develop. Case in point (spoiler?): When the John Kapelos character calls to say he and his girlfriend were coming to Santa Cruz to visit, and James Woods says there's practically no chance he would come, you knew with 100% certainty they were coming in the next scene or two.

On the other hand, Sean Young sure looked good.
rewritten_review:
This movie was nothing more than filmmaking by numbers. The plot follows a struggling salesman who can't seem to make a go of it in New York. Enter the mentor with a heart of gold, who takes him under his wing and gives him the guidance he desperately needs. With this newfound mentorship, the struggling salesman makes the bold move to California, where he initially finds success and makes it big. But, as expected, his success is fleeting, and he loses it all. In the typical fashion of such stories, he bounces back by embracing the simple life, only to hit rock bottom once again in his ambitious quest to return to the top. The plot unfolds with such predictability that it's almost astounding. I don't think I can remember any part of the plot that took more than five seconds to develop or surprise. Take, for instance, the scene where the John Kapelos character calls to say he and his girlfriend were planning to visit Santa Cruz. James Woods's character confidently asserts there's practically no chance they would come, and yet, with 100% certainty, you know they're going to appear in the next scene or two. Every twist and turn is telegraphed well in advance, leaving little to the imagination or expectation.

On the other hand, Sean Young sure looked good. Her presence on screen was a highlight amidst an otherwise formulaic narrative.

text: Serious HOME ALONE/KARATE KID knock off with enough bad character stereotypes to have the writer sued and then shot. You could see blatant stunt man usage in almost every scene. Oh, and the acting sucks too. Although I must say that the line: "Sorry, dude, I have to take a major dump big time" made me laugh my ass off.
rewritten_review:
Certainly! Here's a longer version of the review, maintaining the original content:

This movie is a serious knock-off of two iconic films, HOME ALONE and KARATE KID, attempting to blend the best of both worlds but failing spectacularly in the process. The plot is riddled with enough bad character stereotypes that it's surprising the writer hasn't been both sued and then, metaphorically speaking, shot for such blatant disregard for originality and sensitivity. It's almost as if they went out of their way to cram in every stereotype imaginable, without any thought to nuance or depth. 

The action sequences—which you might hope would redeem the film—are laughably executed. You can see the blatant stuntman usage in almost every scene, to the point where it becomes a game of spotting the stand-in rather than following the narrative. The stunt doubles are so obvious that it distracts from any tension or excitement the scenes might have had. It's as if the filmmakers didn't even bother to try and hide this fact, almost daring the audience to spot the differences.

Oh, and let's not forget the acting, which is uniformly terrible. The performances are so wooden and uninspired that it feels like the actors were reading from cue cards held just out of frame. Their delivery lacks any emotion or believability, making it impossible to connect with any of the characters or care about their fates. It's the kind of acting that makes you appreciate even the most mediocre performances in other films. 

And yet, despite all these glaring issues, there is one line that stands out and made me laugh my ass off—albeit for all the wrong reasons. The line: "Sorry, dude, I have to take a major dump big time," is delivered with such earnestness that it inadvertently becomes the comedic highlight of the film. It's a moment of unintentional humor that breaks through the otherwise relentless monotony of the movie. But even this moment of levity can't save the film from its own shortcomings.

text: Well, magic works in mysterious ways. This movie about 4 prisoners, trying to escape with the help of spells, written by another prisoner centuries ago was a superb occult thriller with a surprising end and lots of suspense. Even if it had something of a theater-play (almost everything happens in the cell) it never got boring and it was acted very well. In the tradition of "Cube" you felt trapped with the Characters and even if they were criminal, you developed some sympathy with some of them, only to change your mind by the twists the story takes. Some happenings catched you off guard and there was always a touch of insanity in the air. Altogether intense and entertaining and as I didn't expect anything (a friend rented it), it was a positive surprise!
rewritten_review:
Certainly! Here's a longer version of the review, maintaining all the original content:

Well, magic works in mysterious ways. This movie about four prisoners, trying to escape with the help of spells, written by another prisoner centuries ago, was a superb occult thriller with a surprising end and lots of suspense. The storyline was intriguing right from the start, and even if it had something of a theater-play feel to it (almost everything happens in the cell), it never got boring. The confined setting added a unique intensity to the film, and it was acted very well by the cast, who delivered powerful performances that drew you into their world. In the tradition of "Cube," you felt trapped with the characters, experiencing their desperation and hope as the plot unfolded. Even if they were criminals, you developed some sympathy with some of them, only to change your mind by the twists the story takes. The development of the characters was skillfully handled, allowing you to connect with them on a deeper level. Some happenings caught you off guard, adding layers of unexpected complexity, and there was always a touch of insanity in the air, which heightened the tension and unpredictability of the narrative. Altogether, it was an intense and entertaining experience, and as I didn't expect anything (a friend rented it), it was a positive surprise! The movie kept me on the edge of my seat with its clever plot and mysterious atmosphere, making it a memorable and engaging watch.

text:
Sequels have a nasty habit of being disappointing, and the best credit I can give this is that it maintains that old tradition. These three tales aren't anything as good as any from the original Creepshow.

By far the best of the trio involves a wooden idol which comes to life to take revenge on the thugs who killed its owners. The second story is about a lake monster which seems to be nothing more than a lot of floating slop, makes you wonder how anybody could possibly be scared of it. The third story includes a cameo from Stephen King as a truck driver, but other than that is a pretty unmemorable tale concerning the victim of a road traffic accident who comes back from the dead for the person who knocked him down.

Watch the original Creepshow instead, or if you already have done then be happy with that.
rewritten_review:
Sequels have a notorious reputation for being disappointing, and the best credit I can give this sequel is that it maintains that age-old tradition. These three tales aren't anything as good as any from the original Creepshow, which is a significant letdown for fans of the first film. The original had a unique charm and creativity that seems to be lacking in this follow-up. 

By far the best of the trio involves a wooden idol which comes to life to take revenge on the thugs who killed its owners. This segment stands out slightly above the others due to its intriguing premise and the way it taps into themes of justice and supernatural retribution. However, even this story doesn't quite reach the heights of the segments in the original movie. It hints at potential that isn't fully realized, leaving the viewer wanting more depth and development.

The second story is about a lake monster which seems to be nothing more than a lot of floating slop. It's a creature feature with a premise that could have been terrifying, yet it makes you wonder how anybody could possibly be scared of it. The execution of this monster falls flat, lacking the suspense and horror elements that make for a truly gripping experience. The concept of a lurking threat in a seemingly serene setting is undercut by the unconvincing portrayal of the creature. 

The third story includes a cameo from Stephen King as a truck driver, but other than that, it is a pretty unmemorable tale concerning the victim of a road traffic accident who comes back from the dead for the person who knocked him down. This segment, despite the intriguing involvement of Stephen King, doesn't manage to leave a lasting impression. The storyline feels predictable and lacks the surprise twists and eerie atmosphere that made the original Creepshow stories so engaging. 

Overall, the sequel fails to capture the spirit and innovation of its predecessor. The tales lack the creative spark and narrative drive that made the original a cult classic. For those seeking a satisfying horror anthology experience, it's best to watch the original Creepshow instead. If you already have done, then be happy with that memory and perhaps revisit it to appreciate its storytelling once more.

text: As a reviewer has already commented, this made for tv comedy is up there amongst the best football parodies ever. But....having failed to video it when it was first aired, I now find that it isn't around in any format. OK, so this has only polled 17 votes to date, but a 9+ average does seem to suggest something special. Basically, I suppose it's a case of tough luck if you missed it 'cos it's no longer available to view !! Aaaaaaaargh.
rewritten_review: As a reviewer has already commented, this made-for-TV comedy is truly up there amongst the best football parodies ever created. It's a masterful blend of humor and sports satire that really hits the mark. However, there's a significant downside to this comedic gem. Having failed to video it when it was first aired, I now find myself in a bit of a predicament. It seems that this brilliant piece isn't available in any format, anywhere. It's quite disappointing, to say the least. OK, so this has only polled 17 votes to date, but a 9+ average does seem to suggest something special, something worth watching. It speaks volumes about its quality and the impression it leaves on its viewers. Basically, I suppose it's a case of tough luck if you missed it 'cos it's no longer available to view!! It's a real shame that such a fantastic show is now out of reach for so many who would undoubtedly appreciate its unique charm and wit. Aaaaaaaargh.

text: I had no idea that Mr. Izzard was so damn funny, It really boggles the mind that he is not more well known! His command over the crowd and his timing is perfect.The monologue about Star Wars will kill ya too! If only all the stand up performers had his wit...
rewritten_review: I had no idea that Mr. Izzard was so damn funny, and it truly boggles the mind that he is not more well known! His command over the crowd and his impeccable timing is absolutely perfect. The way he engages with his audience is nothing short of masterful, drawing them in with his charismatic presence and sharp wit. It's as if he has an innate ability to read the room and deliver punchlines at just the right moment. The monologue about Star Wars will kill ya too! It's one of those performances that leaves you in stitches, with tears of laughter streaming down your face. His observations and comedic twists on familiar stories bring a fresh and hilarious perspective that is both clever and entertaining. If only all the stand-up performers had his wit, the world of comedy would be an even more delightful place. His unique style and humor set a high standard for comedians everywhere, making his performances a must-see for anyone who appreciates the art of stand-up comedy.

text: This film directed by George Fitzmaurice, who made so many excellent films, is well up to his excellent standard. It is crisp, witty, with some wonderful lines, and has the inimitable Ronald Colman in the romantic lead. Colman plays the irresistibly charming younger son of a wealthy English peer. He is financially irresponsible (spending, for instance, £15 of his last £20 in the world on a cute little terrier whom he names George), but open, wildly generous, contemptuous of lucre, irreverent in the politest possible way, and hopelessly sentimental. He is so dashing that all the women fall in love with him. His girlfriend is a star of the music halls, and hence in 1930 a denizen of the demi-monde, played with her typical svelte, narrow-eyed silkiness by the youthful Myrna Loy. Fitzmaurice was not a great user of closeups, and gals of that day had their faces half-hidden with those awful clinging hats anyway, so we do not get as good glimpses of the faces of the two heroines as we would like. The director seems more interested in the charming Colman, anyway. The romantic female lead is the youthful and fresh-faced Loretta Young, who had not yet become the proto-Julie Andrews we generally know her as, but was still a blushing girl exuding all the sweetness of a rose garden and laughing merrily and heartily the whole time. It is obvious that a character with her terrific sense of humour was needed to appreciate the snob-busting social anarchism of the refreshing aristocratic character played by Colman. The plot barely matters, as is so often the case with these light and amusing films. This is just such fun.
rewritten_review: This film, directed by George Fitzmaurice, who made many excellent films, is up to his standard. It's crisp, witty, with wonderful lines, and features the inimitable Ronald Colman in the romantic lead. Colman plays the charming younger son of a wealthy English peer—financially irresponsible, open, generous, contemptuous of lucre, irreverent, and sentimental. He's so dashing that all the women fall in love with him. His girlfriend, a music hall star, is played with svelte silkiness by Myrna Loy. Fitzmaurice wasn't a great user of closeups, and gals of that day had faces half-hidden by clinging hats, so we don't get good glimpses of the heroines. The director seems more interested in Colman. The romantic lead is Loretta Young, not yet the proto-Julie Andrews she's known as, but a blushing girl exuding sweetness and laughter. Her terrific sense of humor was needed to appreciate Colman's character's snob-busting social anarchism. The plot barely matters, as is often the case with these amusing films. This is just such fun.

text: As was mentioned by others, could there be any other reason to see this film other than to see former "Wayne's World" star Mike Myers play a serious role? The story line is interesting but lacks development and is sabotaged by loose ends and bad characters. If there was any good scenic shots of Ireland then it would give it another reason to see it. But instead it focuses on a little normal village that is obviously surrounded by the 'green pastures' of the Emerald-Isle that are often shown in Irish films. If there was any cultural 'spice' to admire the "Irish personality" it would be worth seeing, however this could have almost been shot in England. Too bad for Myers, but this one fails to please or satisfy the heart of anybody who ever wanted to visit the land of Guiness.
rewritten_review: As was mentioned by others, could there be any other reason to see this film other than to see former "Wayne's World" star Mike Myers play a serious role? The story line, while initially intriguing and promising, is interesting but ultimately lacks development and is sabotaged by loose ends and bad characters that fail to engage the audience or evoke any genuine emotion. If there was any good scenic shots of Ireland, with its breathtaking landscapes and iconic landmarks, then it would give it another reason to see it. But instead, it focuses on a little normal village that is obviously surrounded by the 'green pastures' of the Emerald Isle that are often shown in Irish films, yet fails to capture the true beauty and essence of the stunning Irish countryside. If there was any cultural 'spice' to admire the "Irish personality," with its rich history, vibrant traditions, and warm-hearted people, it would be worth seeing, however, this could have almost been shot in England. Too bad for Myers, who undoubtedly put effort into his role, but this one fails to please or satisfy the heart of anybody who ever wanted to visit the land of Guinness, with its lively pub culture and world-famous brews.

text:
- When the local sheriff is killed, his wife takes over until and is determined to clean-up the town. Not everyone in town, however, is happy with what she's doing. When the sheriff orders a curfew in town, the local saloon owner (also a woman) hires a killer to take care of the sheriff. There's no way the saloon owner could know that the sheriff and the killer would fall in love.

- Gunslinger is an example of what happens when you have a fairly interesting concept and combine it with poor execution. There's a good movie here somewhere trying to get out. In more capable hands or with a larger budget, Gunslinger might have been an entertaining look at the role of women in the Old West. As it is, Gunslinger is a sloppy mess of a movie.

- There are just so many things wrong with the movie: a supporting cast with no acting ability, stilted and unnatural dialogue, and sets that look like sets. But the biggest offender is the editing. I was amazed at how many times a scene would begin with the actors (and horses for that matter) obviously waiting for Corman to yell "Action". The best is the scene of two riders on horseback just standing beside a building. All of a sudden, they take off and come racing around the corner like they had been riding hard for several miles. Or, take the example of people who can seemingly transport themselves across town. We see a man enter a building and a second later emerge across town to mount his horse.

- It's not as if Corman didn't have a few decent actors to work with. While none were great stars, Beverly Garland, John Ireland, and Allison Hayes were all capable of turning in a good performance. But, in Gunslinger, they're not given much to work with.

- I have now seen both the MST3K and non-MST3K versions of the movie. I would strongly recommend going the MST3K route.
rewritten_review:
- When the local sheriff is killed, his wife takes over and is determined to clean up the town. Not everyone is happy with her actions. When the sheriff orders a curfew, the local saloon owner hires a killer to take care of the sheriff, not knowing the sheriff and the killer would fall in love.

- Gunslinger combines an interesting concept with poor execution. A good movie is trying to emerge, but in more capable hands or with a larger budget, it might have been an entertaining look at the role of women in the Old West. Instead, Gunslinger is a sloppy mess.

- The movie suffers from a supporting cast with no acting ability, stilted dialogue, and obvious sets. The biggest issue is the editing, with many scenes starting awkwardly, like actors waiting for "Action." There's a scene where riders suddenly race around a corner or characters who seem to teleport across town.

- Corman had decent actors like Beverly Garland, John Ireland, and Allison Hayes, but they weren't given much to work with in Gunslinger.

- I've seen both the MST3K and non-MST3K versions and strongly recommend the MST3K route.

text:
This movie really is a mixed bag. On the one hand, the story and concept of the movie are really good, tense and have some nice plot twists in it. But than again on the other hand, it all is told very slow, without style and uninvolved. Still I regard "Just Cause" as an above average thriller simply because of the fine cast.

Maybe Sean Connery was miscast in his role. I mean, he isn't really that believable as a the main 'hero' and father of a young daughter (played by a still very young Scarlett Johansson by the way) and husband of Kate Capshaw. I feel that he simply was too old for the role to be really credible in it. However Sean Connerey is of course a great actor and that is the only reason why he is still able to carry the movie as good as he does. But he of course is helped by a very solid supporting cast that consists out of actors like Laurence Fishburne, Blair Underwood, Ned Beatty, Hope Lange, Lynne Thigpen and Ed Harris. All actors are really good but some of them are highly underused at the same time, which is a real shame, as well as a missed opportunity. Especially Ed Harris is just totally great in his role as a psychopathic serial killer. He's truly chilling and acting superbly. Normally he doesn't play this ruthless, chilling sort of roles in movies, so he really surprises with his role in this one. His performance alone is already more than enough reason to watch this movie. However due to the fact that the story is told without much style and too formulaic, none of the characters in the movie really work out well because it feels all too distant.

It really is the way of storytelling that kills all the movie its fine potential. Arne Glimcher directs the movie with little style and keeps the pace too low at times. Because of this, we as viewers, never really get involved with the story or any of it's characters.

It really is too bad, for "Just Cause" had more than enough potential. A fine cast and a slick story with some unexpected twists and turns in it in which nothing is what it seems. The cast and story are the only reason why this movie is still an above average thriller, that will probably still please the fan of the genre. It however is an eternal shame that the movie is lacking in its story telling and style, or else this movie could had been a real classic in its genre.

7/10
rewritten_review:
This movie really is a mixed bag. On the one hand, the story and concept are really good, tense, and have some nice plot twists. But on the other hand, it all is told very slowly, without style, and uninvolved. Still, I regard "Just Cause" as an above-average thriller simply because of the fine cast.

Maybe Sean Connery was miscast in his role. He isn't really that believable as the main 'hero' and father of a young daughter (played by a still very young Scarlett Johansson) and husband of Kate Capshaw. He was simply too old for the role to be credible. However, Connery is a great actor and carries the movie as well as he does. He is helped by a solid supporting cast, including Laurence Fishburne, Blair Underwood, Ned Beatty, Hope Lange, Lynne Thigpen, and Ed Harris. All actors are really good, but some are underused, which is a shame and a missed opportunity. Especially Ed Harris, who is great as a psychopathic serial killer, delivering a chilling and superb performance. His role alone is reason enough to watch this movie. However, the story is told without much style and too formulaic, making the characters feel distant.

It's the storytelling that kills the movie's fine potential. Arne Glimcher directs with little style and keeps the pace too low, preventing viewers from getting involved with the story or its characters.

It's too bad because "Just Cause" had plenty of potential. A fine cast and a slick story with unexpected twists and turns. The cast and story make it an above-average thriller that can still please fans of the genre. It's a shame the movie lacks storytelling and style, or it could have been a classic in its genre.

7/10

text:
Of the Korean movies I've seen, only three had really stuck with me. The first is the excellent horror A Tale of Two Sisters. The second and third - and now fourth too - have all been Park Chan Wook's movies, namely Oldboy, Sympathy for Lady Vengeance), and now Thirst.

Park kinda reminds me of Quentin Tarantino with his irreverence towards convention. All his movies are shocking, but not in a gratuitous sense. It's more like he shows us what we don't expect to see - typically situations that go radically against society's morals, like incest or a libidinous, blood-sucking, yet devout priest. He's also quite artistically-inclined with regards to cinematography, and his movies are among the more gorgeous that I've seen.

Thirst is all that - being about said priest and the repressed, conscience-less woman he falls for - and more. It's horror, drama, and even comedy, as Park disarms his audience with many inappropriate yet humorous situations. As such, this might be his best work for me yet, since his other two movies that I've seen were lacking the humor element that would've made them more palatable for repeat viewings.
rewritten_review: Of the Korean movies I've seen, only three really stuck with me. The first is the excellent horror A Tale of Two Sisters. The second and third - and now fourth too - have all been Park Chan Wook's movies: Oldboy, Sympathy for Lady Vengeance, and now Thirst. Park reminds me of Quentin Tarantino with his irreverence towards convention. His movies are shocking, but not gratuitously so. He shows us what we don't expect, like situations radically against society's morals, such as incest or a libidinous, blood-sucking priest. He's also quite artistic with cinematography, making his films some of the most gorgeous I've seen. Thirst embodies all that, focusing on the priest and the repressed, conscience-less woman he falls for. It's horror, drama, and comedy, with Park disarming his audience through inappropriate yet humorous situations. This might be his best work for me yet, as the humor element makes it more palatable for repeat viewings compared to his other films.

text:
Aimless teens on summer break in a small Ohio town can't find any meaningful ways to fill their time. Some consider driving to Chicago; others are content to drink and bully their peers. In a random act of alcohol-fueled arrogance, the bullies rough up a homeless man and steal a strange book. The handwritten text turns out to contain archaic spells designed to summon demonic forces. A night or two later, one of them reads an incantation and is quickly possessed. He turns into a vicious killer and begins to quietly prey on his former peers.

"Demon Summer" is an amateur production with a microscopic budget. The production values are low, but the filmmakers were smart enough to not be ambitious. Little in the way of special props or shooting locations were needed. The acting is especially weak and there is virtually nothing original in the screenplay. On the positive side, the special makeup effects are surprisingly good by low budget film standards. Despite this, the gore is minimal. Makeup effects aside, there is little going for this film, even for die-hard gore-hounds. Not recommended.
rewritten_review:
Aimless teens in a small Ohio town can't find meaningful ways to fill their time. Some consider driving to Chicago; others drink and bully peers. In an alcohol-fueled act, bullies rough up a homeless man and steal a strange book with spells to summon demons. One reads an incantation and becomes possessed, turning into a killer preying on peers.

"Demon Summer" is an amateur production with a tiny budget. Production values are low but not overly ambitious. Acting is weak and the screenplay lacks originality. The special makeup effects are surprisingly good for a low budget, but gore is minimal. Besides makeup effects, there's little appeal, even for die-hard gore-hounds. Not recommended.

me and my sister saw the premiere last night... it was so good we were glued for the whole thing.. hahaha..i think I'm hooked for the season!!.... they have some really good actors in this thing.. the head coach guy and the player that likes pete were very good and the plot has already got me but i don't really understand how they'll keep it stretched for a whole season.. there will probably be some big twist tho..i cant wait till Tuesday.. finally Jeremy sumpter who is he? i can tell hes going to be big!! he was soo good we fell in love with his character right away.. cant wait for the next episode.. GO Jeremy!

'Aimee
rewritten_review:
Me and my sister saw the premiere last night, and it was absolutely incredible! We were completely glued to the screen for the whole thing, and we couldn't believe how captivating it was. Hahaha! I think I'm definitely hooked for the entire season!! The show has some really good actors in it, and they bring so much talent and depth to their roles. The head coach guy and the player that likes Pete were particularly impressive, and they really stood out with their performances. The plot has already got me on the edge of my seat, but I don't really understand how they'll manage to keep it stretched out for a whole season. There will probably be some big twist, though, and I can't wait to see what happens next. I'm so excited for Tuesday to come around!

Finally, Jeremy Sumpter—who is he? I can tell he's going to be big!! He was so good, and we fell in love with his character right away. His performance was just captivating, and I can't wait to see how his character develops throughout the season. It's clear that he has a lot of talent, and I'm sure he's going to make a huge impact. We can't wait for the next episode to air and see what happens next. GO Jeremy! We're rooting for you!

Aimee

text:
Slow but beautifully-mounted story of the American revolution. Griffith's story-telling seems a lot less heavy-handed than in his earlier historical epics and his tableaux work is fully integrated into the action. Lionel Barrymore is an utter swine, Neil Hamilton is poor but dashing and Carol Dempster is.... well, Carol Dempster is most of what is wrong with Griffith in this period, but she doesn't show up often enough to slow the pace and drama.

Note that the trivia for this movie says it came in originally at slightly more than 2 hours when first released, but that no cut exists that runs longer than 90 minutes. However, the dvd release has been presented at a slower fps rate that increases the tension and brings it back to a bit over two hours.

Far better in terms of story-telling than sound versions, such as THE PATRIOT. While not quite in the league of Griffith's best, such as WAY DOWN EAST and BROKEN BLOSSOMS, an excellent way to spend a couple of hours.
rewritten_review:
A slow but beautifully-mounted story of the American revolution. Griffith's storytelling is less heavy-handed than in earlier historical epics, with tableaux work fully integrated into the action. Lionel Barrymore is an utter swine, Neil Hamilton is poor but dashing, and Carol Dempster is... well, she embodies much of what is wrong with Griffith in this period, but doesn't appear often enough to slow the pace and drama.

Note that the trivia mentions the movie originally ran slightly over 2 hours, but no cut longer than 90 minutes exists. The DVD release is presented at a slower fps rate, increasing tension and restoring it to a bit over two hours.

Far better in storytelling than sound versions like THE PATRIOT. Not quite Griffith's best, like WAY DOWN EAST and BROKEN BLOSSOMS, but an excellent way to spend a couple of hours.

text: The centurions is one of the best cartoons ever and it needs to be put on TV and DVD so people can have younger generations enjoy such a good show that is far better than the garbage they have made in the last 14 years. I have a petition online that is at the website address Http://www.petitiononline.com/6600F/petition.html that originally was trying to get this show on five days a week but is now trying to get this show onto DVD since the TV station it was focused on has bad public relations. We all need to convince the people who own this show to put it on DVD so it can be seen by future generations. Also since now Hasbro Toys owns the toy line of this show we might want to try to convince them to make a live action movie of it just like they have done with Transformers and sometime this year G.I.Joe. We need good cartoons like this one to come back and be enjoyed by the younger generations. Please do sign this petition so we can one day have DVDs of the guys who are famous for yelling "Power Extreme!"
rewritten_review: "The Centurions" is one of the best cartoons ever and deserves to be on TV and DVD for younger generations to enjoy. I have a petition online at Http://www.petitiononline.com/6600F/petition.html, originally to air the show five days a week, but now focused on getting it on DVD due to poor public relations with the TV station. We need to convince the owners to release it on DVD for future generations. With Hasbro Toys owning the toy line, we might also encourage them to make a live-action movie, similar to Transformers and G.I. Joe. Support this petition so we can enjoy the classic "Power Extreme!" once more.

text:
What-ho! This one is jolly good. I say jolly good, ol' chap. Or should I say "ol' bean"? My mastery of British terminology is a little dusty. Anyway, my biker boots and I walked into this screening with no prior viewing experience of Wallace and Gromit. I'm happy to say that my boots and I walked out pleased to have made their acquaintance.

While not as adult-accessible as Toy Story, W & G still manages to be clever enough to provide the grown ups with a little humor that will most definitely soar over the heads of the young 'uns who are too busy guffawing at the Were-rabbit's belches to have any clue that something is amiss. I highly suggest that you pay close attention any time you see books or words on the screen because there are quick glimpses of puns that you'll miss if you aren't paying attention. My favorite is a book of monsters that refers to the Loch Ness Monster as "tourist trappus." If you've ever been known to say, "I can really relate to Kevin Federline," or if you're just illiterate then not only will you miss out on these jokes, but you probably should be spending your time learning to read instead of going to movies. Consider this a public service announcement.

The most impressive aspect about W & G is its clay animation. Thanks to the tedious process, it took FIVE YEARS to finish the film! According to the press notes, there were some days when the optimum goal was to merely accomplish 10 seconds of completed film. Folks, I sometimes have trouble finding the motivation to finish responding to a handful of emails or adding captions to pictures for my reviews (a point that is proved by a lack of pictures in this review); so I can't even imagine having the required patience for that.

I really like the rough, hands-on quality of the claymation figures. The fact that you can see fingerprints in the clay is a nice, personal touch. How can you not be impressed with clay characters that show more expression and emotion than Paul Walker and Keanu Reeves combined? The Curse of the Were-rabbit is, as director Nick Park calls it, the world's first vegetarian horror movie that should entertain both kids and adults alike. Relying on (and as a male who prides himself in his shaggy-haired, cool-bearded masculinity I hesitate to use this word) cute and (oh man, I probably shouldn't use this word either) lovable characters rather than outdated M.C. Hammer references, W & G is proof that DreamWorks can create entertaining animation when it chooses cleverness over the cheap joke.

text: This movie was exactly what I expected, not great, but also not that bad either. In my opinion PG13 movies aren't scary enough so that's why I already knew I was going to be bored throughout the entire film. Sure there were scary things going on in the hotel room, but nothing we all haven't already seen. I guess I didn't like it because I thought there were too many twists and turns happening; it got old and repetitive. I also didn't understand if all the things Cusack was experiencing in the room was real or not. There is no explanation for any of the events that occurred. The movie just drags on and when it finally does come to an end you want it to keep going because you are still waiting around for someone to tell you what the whole movie was about. What I did like was the special effects. Other than that there wasn't much enjoyment from it. Maybe its just me but I thought this was below average.
rewritten_review: This movie was exactly what I expected, not great, but also not that bad either. In my opinion, PG-13 movies aren't scary enough, so that's why I already knew I was going to be bored throughout the entire film. It's not that the film was completely devoid of merit; there were certainly elements that tried to engage the audience. However, the overall tension and fear factor just weren't up to the mark for me. Sure, there were scary things going on in the hotel room, but nothing we all haven't already seen in other films. The setting had potential, yet it felt like it was all squandered on predictable scares and overused tropes. I guess I didn't like it because I thought there were too many twists and turns happening; it got old and repetitive after a while. It seemed like the filmmakers were trying too hard to keep the audience guessing, but instead, it just became convoluted and tiresome. I also didn't understand if all the things Cusack was experiencing in the room were real or not. The ambiguity might have been intended to add to the mystery, but it ended up being more confusing than intriguing. There is no explanation for any of the events that occurred, leaving the audience in the dark about the true nature of the horror. The movie just drags on, and when it finally does come to an end, you want it to keep going because you are still waiting around for someone to tell you what the whole movie was about. The lack of resolution leaves a lingering sense of dissatisfaction. What I did like was the special effects; they were well-executed and added some visual interest to the film. Other than that, there wasn't much enjoyment from it. Maybe it's just me, but I thought this was below average. While some viewers might appreciate the style and atmosphere, I found it lacking in substance and coherence.

text:
Will and Ted's Bodacious journey is an existential trip through themes of mortality, religion, time, Heaven and Hell, man's quest for fame and his fears of the body being overcome by a soulless machine. It is the most intelligent work of fiction since Paradise Lost and references many great past works of art- Dante, Iron Maiden, Virgil, Shakespeare. This time the dudes are a famous rock band having travelled through time collecting icons from the past- Napolean, Joan Of Ark (Noah's wife), Oscar Wilde, and Charles Darwin. They took the skills they learned from each of these people, abducted a couple of Princesses, and finally learned to play their guitars and write hit songs. These songs teach the world to love again and war, hunger, evil are vanquished for eternity. We fast forward into the distant future where an evil dictator who despises good music called Simon Cow-Al wants to rule the world. He eats Rooshus (the cool guy from the first film who helps Bill Playboy Esquire and Ted Theodore Alvin) and gains the power to send two cyborgs back in time. The cyborgs are living tissue over metal exoskeleton and coated in mimetic poly alloy allowing them the survive the turmoil of time travel, and they can imitate anything they sample by physical contact. It is their job to Kill the good Biff and Fred and take over their lives by making terrible music that no-one could like. By doing this they will change the world forever- Gryll and Jed's music will never be made leaving a world of war, famine, and hatred, and more annoyingly, bland boy/girl group pop music. There is a startling twist as the good guys actually are killed and they have to work out a way to save the world, themselves, and their wives from the evil Dopplebangers inhabiting their bodies.

Penelope Spheerhead shows her knowledge of both youth culture and real culture by mixing modern day music and phrases with post modern sets and artistic references, and seeks to teach us all something by delving into our very psyche to show us ourselves. She presents the nightmares which faced the late 80s teen in a society which had abandoned them and beckons us to dissect the post structuralist jingoism, self love, and malaise of the time. Charging us with a belief that we can indeed change the world it is an inspiring message, but in order to achieve such dreams we must traverse and indeed face our nightmares. To overcome is to succeed, to defeat Death is the first step in truly living and not merely surviving. In the words of Kenneth Reeves- 'Wow!' Best Scene: For a fun game- see how many songs, bands, and albums cover references you can spot throughout the film. There are at least 6.
rewritten_review:
