text:
I'm sorry, I had high hopes for this movie. Unfortunately, it was too long, too thin and too weak to hold my attention. When I realized the whole movie was indeed only about an older guy reliving his dream, I felt cheated. Surely it could have been a device to bring us into something deeper, something more meaningful.

So, don't buy a large drink or you'll be running to the rest room. My kids didn't enjoy it either. Ah well.
rewritten_review:
I apologize for saying this, but I had such high hopes for this movie. Unfortunately, it turned out to be too long, too thin, and too weak to hold my attention throughout its duration. When I eventually realized the entire movie was indeed only about an older guy reliving his dream, I couldn't help but feel cheated. Surely, it could have been a narrative device to bring us into something deeper, something more meaningful, something with more substance and depth. 

So, just a heads-up, don't buy a large drink while watching this movie, or you'll find yourself running to the restroom at some point. My kids didn't enjoy it either, which was quite disappointing. Ah well, that's how it goes sometimes with movies.

text:
The worst movie I have seen since Tera Jadoo Chal Gaya. There is no story, no humor, no nothing! The action sequences seem more like a series of haphazard Akshay Kumar Thumbs-Up advertisements stitched together. Heavily influenced from The Matrix and Kung-Fu Hustle but very poorly executed.

I did not go a lot of expectations, but watching this movie is an exasperating experience which makes you wonder "What were these guys thinking??!!".

The only thing you might remember after watching it is an anorexic Kareena in a bikini.

The reason why I did not give a rating of '1' is that every time I think I have seen the worst, Bollywood proves me wrong.
rewritten_review:
The worst movie I have seen since Tera Jadoo Chal Gaya. There is no story, no humor, no nothing! The action sequences seem more like a series of haphazard Akshay Kumar Thumbs-Up advertisements stitched together. Heavily influenced from The Matrix and Kung-Fu Hustle but very poorly executed. The movie lacks any sense of coherence or originality, leaving viewers questioning the creative decisions made by the filmmakers. The plot, if you can even call it that, appears to be a disjointed jumble of cliched scenes and predictable moments that fail to engage or entertain the audience. The characters are underdeveloped and lack depth, making it difficult for viewers to connect with them on any meaningful level. The dialogues are uninspired, lacking wit or charm, further contributing to the overall disappointment of the film.

I did not go a lot of expectations, but watching this movie is an exasperating experience which makes you wonder "What were these guys thinking??!!". As the film drags on, it becomes increasingly clear that it is an exercise in frustration, testing the patience of even the most forgiving moviegoers. The pacing is uneven, with moments that feel unnecessarily prolonged while others are rushed through without any consideration for narrative flow. The direction is lackluster, failing to bring any sense of vision or creativity to the project. It's as if the filmmakers were content to rely solely on tired tropes and uninspired set pieces, hoping that star power alone would carry the film. Unfortunately, even the presence of well-known actors cannot salvage this cinematic disaster.

The only thing you might remember after watching it is an anorexic Kareena in a bikini. This fleeting moment is perhaps the only aspect of the film that manages to leave an impression, albeit a shallow one. It serves as a stark reminder of how the movie prioritizes style over substance, opting for superficial visuals rather than meaningful storytelling. In trying to emulate successful action films, the movie falls short of capturing the magic that made those inspirations memorable. Instead, it comes across as a hollow imitation, devoid of the creativity and innovation that made those films stand out.

The reason why I did not give a rating of '1' is that every time I think I have seen the worst, Bollywood proves me wrong. It is a sobering realization that even in the vast landscape of subpar cinema, there is always a new contender for the title of the worst movie. This film, with its myriad of flaws and shortcomings, joins the ranks of forgettable movies that fail to leave a lasting impact. It serves as a cautionary tale of how not to make a film, highlighting the importance of storytelling, character development, and originality in creating a truly memorable cinematic experience.

text:
In the wake of Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, the British film industry rapidly became swamped with bad gangster films in the late '90s-early '00s that seem even more desperate today than they did then. In one of the all-time great cases of pearls-from-swine, the producers of Rancid Aluminium brazenly plastered the quote 'The best film of the century' from one review all over the ads while omitting the rest of the sentence pointing out that that was only because, at the time of writing, it was the only film that had been released in 2000. Looking at it today it's hard to imagine how it ever got made, uniting a cast that was briefly considered the cream of Cool Britannia's Lads Mags Brigade  Rhys Ifans, Sadie Frost, Nick Moran and Joseph Fiennes  but now merely a guarantee of a turkey every time in a confused adaptation of a confused James Hawes novel. That the plot is never explained could be down to the possibility that no-one really knows what it is, or perhaps simply don't think it matters. Something to do with Ifans' businessman being set up with Steven Berkoff's homicidal Russian crime lord in a money-laundering or investment scheme (it's never clear which because no-one ever asks) by Fiennes' crooked Irish accountant, who expects the Russians to kill off Ifans so he can take over his failing company. Things get increasingly confused and underexplained from there on, Ifans alternates between shouting about how terrible his life is while juggling visits to the fertility clinic and sleeping with his secretary and Tara Fitzgerald's ludicrously accented Russian temptress, Berkoff keeps on saying "Bizniss" and "Francis Drake" and Fiennes does a decent Irish accent while proving that just because he played a great writer in Shakespeare in Love doesn't mean he's any judge of good writing when it comes to film scripts.

When the most convincing performances come from Keith Allen and Dani Behr, you know a film is in deep trouble. With Poland standing in for a Russia filled with people with Polish accents and a strange score that veers from John Barry pastiche to lounge music to Ennio Morricone spaghetti Western on a stylophone budget, it fails completely in the cool stakes it's aiming for and ends up in a curious overplotted but almost plot less limbo all its own, sitting there like a joke shop dog turd.
rewritten_review:
In the wake of *Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels*, the British film industry was swamped with bad gangster films in the late '90s-early '00s. One standout is *Rancid Aluminium*, which notoriously used the quote 'The best film of the century' from a review, conveniently omitting that it was the only film released in 2000 at the time. It's baffling how it was made, uniting a once-celebrated cast—Rhys Ifans, Sadie Frost, Nick Moran, and Joseph Fiennes—now synonymous with flops, in a muddled adaptation of a James Hawes novel. The plot is unclear, revolving around Ifans' businessman being set up with Berkoff's Russian crime lord in a vague money-laundering scheme by Fiennes' crooked accountant who hopes the Russians will kill Ifans so he can take over his failing company. Ifans oscillates between lamenting his life and juggling fertility clinic visits and affairs, while Berkoff repeats "Bizniss" and "Francis Drake," and Fiennes showcases his Irish accent, proving that playing a great writer doesn't equate to recognizing good scripts.

With the most convincing performances by Keith Allen and Dani Behr, the film is in trouble. Poland doubles as a Russia filled with Polish accents, and the bizarre score ranges from John Barry pastiche to lounge music to Ennio Morricone on a stylophone budget. It fails in its cool aspirations, landing in an overplotted yet plotless limbo, akin to a joke shop dog turd.

text: Patsy Kensit and some random Australian bloke star as a duo of wannabe tough coppers in the middle of investigating a series of art-gallery related murders, but in between they can still find the time to shoot juvenile shoplifters and suspect the brand new wife of the male cop of being adulterous. The serial killer suddenly isn't important anymore when the supposed lover of the wife (who's basically just a co-worker of hers) is found murdered and the male cop becomes prime suspect. "Tunnel Vision" is a really dull, implausible and tension-free Aussie thriller that obviously imitates popular sex-thrillers like "Fatal Attraction", "Disclosure" and "Basic Instinct". The characters are extremely one-dimensional and pretty much every good-cop/bad-cop cliché is extendedly described in the script. The struggling position of police women in a corps full of men, the shoot-first-ask-questions-later mentality, alcohol problems through stress, etc etc Even the unhealthy eating habits of cops are a running gag. Yawn! Kensit really tries her best to make this film more bearable, but she lacks the credibility and talent of a real cinema heroine. The end-twist is more or less interesting (not at all original, mind you) but, by then, you stopped caring for the characters a long time already. The scenes filmed inside the sex clubs look ludicrously fake and Clive Fleury's directing is completely uninspired. What a total waste of time
rewritten_review: Patsy Kensit and a random Australian bloke star as wannabe tough cops investigating art-gallery murders, but they still find time to shoot juvenile shoplifters and suspect the male cop's new wife of adultery. The serial killer becomes irrelevant when the wife's supposed lover, actually just a co-worker, is found murdered and the male cop is the prime suspect. "Tunnel Vision" is a dull, implausible Aussie thriller imitating films like "Fatal Attraction" and "Basic Instinct." Characters are one-dimensional, and the script is full of clichés: police women's struggles, shoot-first mentality, alcohol problems from stress, etc. Even cops' unhealthy eating habits are a gag. Kensit tries to make the film bearable but lacks the talent of a real cinema heroine. The end-twist is slightly interesting but unoriginal, and by then, you don't care about the characters. Sex club scenes look fake, and Clive Fleury's directing is uninspired. What a waste of time.

text:
The Thing has to be one of the all time great movies. Of course it was ground breaking special effects at the time of it's release that impressed me so much, back in 1982 it just blew my mind, I'd never seen anything like that! However, although the effects themselves made the movie more horrific, it was the story itself, the music score , the claustrophobic atmosphere of the Anarctic as well as the interaction and tension between the members of the doomed research station that makes it a classic.

Movies don't get any better than this! In the opening scene with the the chopper chasing this husky you just assume that it was some bored scientists from some station letting of some steam. Yet when you see them continue their chase at the US base you then think that the Norwegians are suffering from some form of advanced or extreme strain of cabin fever. Yet this is offset by the menacing opening music score that sets the tempo! You just know that something is not right! At this point it's a mystery until 'the thing' reveals itself.

However, the mystery returns because it becomes a sort of Agatha Christie "who dunnit" ( i.e. ten little Indians movie) sci-fi style as the members don't know which one of their team is really an alien. Suspicion continues to go back and forward between them all as one by one they eventually get knocked off or revealed as the alien. The mistrust between the station crew is absorbing as the movie progresses until the final showdown.

After 20 years of advances in computer graphics and film making production the special effects in "the Thing" don't carry the same weight as it did in 1982, but other than that it holds up very well all round with some great performances by the cast.
rewritten_review:
"The Thing" is one of the all-time great movies. Its groundbreaking special effects in 1982 blew my mind; I had never seen anything like it! While the effects made the movie more horrific, it’s the story, music score, claustrophobic Antarctic atmosphere, and the tension between the doomed research station members that make it a classic. Movies don't get any better than this!

In the opening scene, with the chopper chasing a husky, you assume it's bored scientists letting off steam. Yet as the chase continues at the US base, you think the Norwegians are suffering from extreme cabin fever. This is offset by the menacing opening music score that sets the tempo, making you know something is not right. It’s a mystery until 'the thing' reveals itself. 

The mystery returns as a sci-fi "whodunnit" in Agatha Christie style, with the members not knowing which one of them is the alien. Suspicion shifts among them until the final showdown. The mistrust is absorbing as the movie progresses. After 20 years of advances in computer graphics and film production, the special effects in "The Thing" don't carry the same weight as in 1982, but it holds up well with great performances by the cast.

text: When you pick a movie I hope one factor you will consider, are the actors in the movie using their fame to influence the moral fabric of our society in a positive or negative way? This is not a political statement this is a moral issue that effects are society. When a comedian/actor makes curl sexual and racist remarks about a teenager and her father we should ask ourselves (do I want to support that behavior)? In this case Mr. Foxx behavior tears at the social fabric that teaches our youth right from wrong, good behavior from bad that loving-kindness is better than hatefulness. Mr. Foxx should remember he is only entertainment and there is a lot of that out there for us to choose from. Saying sorry does not get him off the hook. It will not undue the hurt or remove the bad behavior he spreads to our youth. One way to stop this behavior is to stop being a fan of it. No longer see anything they are part of. We cannot change them but we can stop the fame we give them.
rewritten_review: When choosing a movie, consider whether the actors are using their fame to positively or negatively influence society's moral fabric. This isn't a political issue but a moral one affecting society. For instance, when a comedian/actor like Mr. Foxx makes crude sexual and racist remarks about a teenager and her father, we should ask ourselves if we want to support that behavior. Such behavior undermines the social fabric that teaches youth right from wrong and kindness over hatefulness. Mr. Foxx should remember he's merely entertainment, and there's plenty of that to choose from. Apologizing doesn't erase the harm or the bad behavior he spreads to our youth. One way to stop this is to stop being a fan and avoid supporting their work. We can't change them, but we can stop giving them fame.

text: I usually much prefer French movies over American ones, with explosions and car chases, but this movie was very disappointing. There is no way to write a spoiler because nothing really happens. This French couple has been living in Lisbon for years, and they return to Paris for a friend's wedding. They announce to another friend they are having dinner with that they are going to split. Then nothing much happens, they don't seem to know whether they want to separate or not. I don't necessarily think that their hesitations make for a bad movie, it is very human to hesitate before making such a decision for good, but this could be treated in an interesting manner, giving some flesh to their desires and their relationship, but that does not happen. One gets out of the theater unsure of why these two got together or want to split. The only piece I enjoyed was the conversation with the drunk. That was true to life.
rewritten_review:
I usually much prefer French movies over American ones, with explosions and car chases, but this movie was very disappointing. There is no way to write a spoiler because nothing really happens. This French couple has been living in Lisbon for years, and they return to Paris for a friend's wedding. They announce to another friend they are having dinner with that they are going to split. Then nothing much happens, they don't seem to know whether they want to separate or not. I don't necessarily think that their hesitations make for a bad movie, it is very human to hesitate before making such a decision for good, but this could be treated in an interesting manner, giving some flesh to their desires and their relationship, but that does not happen. One gets out of the theater unsure of why these two got together or want to split. The only piece I enjoyed was the conversation with the drunk. That was true to life. 

The overall experience left me wanting more depth and insight into their lives, their history, and what truly drives their indecision. It's as though the film skimmed the surface of a potentially rich narrative but never quite delved into the core of what makes relationships complex and compelling. The lack of development in their characters or their interactions left me disconnected from their journey. I found myself waiting for a moment of revelation or a turning point that would shed light on their emotions or motivations, but it never came. Even the setting of Paris, which can often add a layer of charm or tension, felt underutilized, as if it was simply a backdrop without influence on the narrative. 

While the premise held promise, the execution fell flat, leaving the audience with more questions than answers about the couple's past and future. The film had an opportunity to explore the nuances of love, commitment, and the challenges of long-term relationships, but instead, it meandered without direction. It's frustrating because the potential for a meaningful exploration of human connection was overshadowed by its lack of clarity and depth. I left the theater feeling unsatisfied and pondering what could have been a much more engaging and thought-provoking story.

text: Not much to say beyond the summary, save that this is an example of J. Edgar's Hoover's constant attention to maintaining a good "PR" profile. They don't make movies this bad very often, especially with the likes of Jimmy Stewart and Vera Miles in the blend. Too bad.
rewritten_review: This film serves as a prime example of J. Edgar Hoover's relentless focus on preserving a positive public relations image. It's a rare occurrence to encounter a movie of such poor quality, particularly when it features renowned talents like Jimmy Stewart and Vera Miles. It's truly unfortunate that the potential of these accomplished actors was not fully realized in this production. The film's shortcomings overshadow the performances, leaving audiences with a sense of disappointment. One might wonder what went wrong in the creative process that led to this outcome. It's disheartening to see such a missed opportunity, especially considering the caliber of the cast involved. Despite the presence of these iconic actors, the movie fails to deliver a compelling or memorable experience. Such instances of cinematic missteps do not happen frequently, making this particular film stand out for all the wrong reasons. It's a shame that the blend of Stewart and Miles, which held so much promise, did not translate into a successful film. The end result is a movie that struggles to find its footing and ultimately falls short of expectations. Too bad.

text:
A CRY IN THE DARK

A CRY IN THE DARK was a film that I anticipated would offer a phenomenal performance from Meryl Streep and a solid, if unremarkable film. This assumption came from the fact that aside from Streep's Best Actress nomination, the movie received little attention from major awards groups.

Little did I anticipate that A CRY IN THE DARK would be such a riveting drama, well-constructed on every level. If you ask me, this is an under-appreciatted classic.

The film opens rather slowly, letting the audience settle into the Chamberlain's at a relaxed pace and really notice that, at the core, they are an incredibly loving, simple family. Fred Schepisi (the director) selects random moments to capture of a family on vacation that give a looming sense of the oncoming tragedy, while also showing the attentive bliss with which Lindy (Streep) and Michael (Sam Neill) Chamberlain care for their children.

While the famous line "A Dingo Took My Baby!" has become somewhat of a punchline these days, the movie never even comes close to laughable. The actual death of Azaria is horrifyingly captured. It is subtle and realistic, leaving the audience horrified and asking questions.

The majority of the film takes place in courtrooms and focuses on the Chamberlain's continuous fight to prove their innocence to the press and the court, which suspects Lindy of murder.

The fact that it is clear to us from the beginning that they are innocent makes the tense trials all the more gripping. As an audience member, I was fully invested in the Chamberlain's plight... and was genuinely angered and hurt and saddened when they were made to look so terrible by the media. But at the same, the media/public opinion is understandable. I loved the way the media was by no means made to be sympathetic, but they always had valid reasons to hold their views.

The final line of the film is very profound and captures perfectly the central element that makes this film so much different from other courtroom dramas.

In terms of performances, the only ones that really matter in this film are those of Streep and Neill... and they deliver in every way. For me, this ranks as one of (if not #1) Meryl Streep's best performances. For all her mastery of different accents (which of course are very impressive in their own right), Streep never loses the central heart and soul of her characters. I find this to be one of Streep's more subtle performances, and she hits it out of the park. And Neill, an actor who has never impressed me beyond being charismatic and appealing in JURASSIC PARK, is a perfect counterpoint to Streep's performance. From what I've seen, this is undoubtedly Neill's finest work to date. It's a shame he wasn't recognized by the Academy with a Leading Actor nomination to match Streep's... b/c the two of them play of each other brilliantly.

More emotionally gripping than most films, and also incredibly suspenseful... A CRY IN THE DARK far exceeded my expectations. I highly recommend that people who only know of the movie as the flick where Meryl screams "The dingo took my baby!" watch the film and see just how much more there is to A CRY IN THE DARK then that one line.

... A ...
rewritten_review:
A CRY IN THE DARK

I anticipated A CRY IN THE DARK would feature a phenomenal performance from Meryl Streep and be a solid, if unremarkable, film due to its limited major awards attention outside of Streep's Best Actress nomination.

To my surprise, A CRY IN THE DARK is a riveting drama, well-constructed on every level, and an under-appreciated classic. The film opens slowly, establishing the Chamberlains as a loving, simple family. Director Fred Schepisi captures random vacation moments that hint at the impending tragedy while showing Lindy (Streep) and Michael (Sam Neill) Chamberlain’s attentive care for their children.

Despite the famous line "A Dingo Took My Baby!" becoming a punchline, the movie remains serious. Azaria’s death is subtly and realistically depicted, leaving the audience horrified and questioning. The film mostly takes place in courtrooms, focusing on the Chamberlains' fight to prove their innocence against murder suspicions.

Knowing their innocence makes the tense trials gripping. I was fully invested in the Chamberlains' plight, feeling anger and sadness at their media portrayal. Yet, the media’s perspective is understandable and not overly sympathetic, with valid reasons for their views.

The film’s final line captures its unique take on courtroom dramas. Performances by Streep and Neill are crucial, and they excel. This ranks among Streep's best performances, maintaining the heart and soul of her character. Neill complements Streep perfectly, delivering his finest work to date. It's unfortunate he wasn't recognized with an Academy nomination.

A CRY IN THE DARK is more emotionally gripping and suspenseful than most films, exceeding my expectations. I highly recommend it to those who only know the movie for the "dingo" line—there's so much more to it.

text: I don't often go out of my way to write comments, but for this I had to, just to warn anyone that might think that by watching this they will see a comedy. This doesn't come close. While the premise (change in colour/gender/whatever) is bad enough (and has been done, better, many times before)the actual transformation of two black guys into two white girls is one of the least convincing transformations ever put on screen. It would be bad enough if all that was required by the script was a change to white chicks. However the Wayans brothers are required to disguise themselves as two specific white women. As you will have guessed by now, they fail completely. I have seen drag queens without makeup make more convincing women than these two do with the best special effects and make-up people that Hollywood can provide. Its appalling. Add to the mix a basketball player built like a building, terrible dialogue and more plot holes than a golf course and this film hits a new personal low. And I like bad movies! Avoid like the plague.
rewritten_review: I don't often write comments, but I had to warn anyone thinking this is a comedy. It doesn't come close. The premise (change in color/gender/whatever) is bad enough and has been done better before. The transformation of two black guys into two white girls is one of the least convincing ever. It's bad enough if all that was required by the script was a change to white chicks, but the Wayans brothers are required to disguise themselves as specific white women, and they fail completely. I've seen drag queens without makeup make more convincing women than these two do with Hollywood's best special effects and makeup. It's appalling. Add a basketball player built like a building, terrible dialogue, and more plot holes than a golf course, and this film hits a new personal low. And I like bad movies! Avoid like the plague.

text: Like the other comments says, this might be surprise to those who haven't seen the work of Jeunet & Caro or Emir Kusturica. But have you already seen Delicatessen, there is nothing new it this film. I thought Delicatessen was great when it came out, but this film just arrive too late to be of any interest. I don't think it's a worse film than Delicatessen but it's a bore to see it now, like it probably would be to watch Delicatessen again. There is really no point to the film, nothing that really matter or stays with you. There may be a distant similarity to the films of Kusturica, but he's really in a different league, so you should rather go see his films than waste your time on Tuvalu.
rewritten_review: Like the other comments say, this might come as a surprise to those who haven't seen the work of Jeunet & Caro or Emir Kusturica. However, if you have already seen Delicatessen, there is nothing new in this film to catch your interest. I remember thinking that Delicatessen was great when it first came out, but this film simply arrives too late to be of any real interest. I don't think it's necessarily a worse film than Delicatessen, but it feels like a bore to watch it now, much like it probably would be to watch Delicatessen again after all this time. There is really no point to the film, nothing that truly matters or stays with you long after the credits roll. While there may be a distant similarity to the films of Kusturica, it's important to note that he's really in a different league altogether. Therefore, you should rather go see his films than waste your time on Tuvalu. It just doesn't hold the same weight or offer anything substantial to make it worth your while. Instead, revisiting the works of Emir Kusturica would be a far better choice. His films have a depth and creativity that this film simply lacks, and they are bound to leave a lasting impression on you.

text:
It seems that it is becoming fashionable to rip "Basic Instinct 2," to the point that a significant part of the audience (including critics) found it terrible even before it was released. It seems even more fashionable to trash Sharon Stone wholike all of usis now fourteen years older, andunlike most of usstill looks wonderful. First comments on this movie were so vicious that I had to see for myself. In my opinion, this sequel is not nearly as good as the original film, but is not as bad as most comments pretend. Michael Caton-Jones is not Paul Verhoeven, neither Henry Bean and Leora Barish are Joe Eszterhas. "Basic Instinct 2" is just an entertaining, average thriller, and besides the addition of Jerry Goldsmith original score, keeps little resemblance to its predecessor. Even Stone gives her character a different dimension, creating a lustful, devilish Catherine Trimell, who can perfectly well rank among other monsters like Hannibal Lecter. She is an intelligent actress who is not afraid of taking risks and can play with camp at her leisure. Unfortunately, she seems to be the main target for those who enjoy trashing this flick. She became too successful, too much of a main icon, and like all those actors who have reached that level, her time has arrived and she is now bound to be destroyed by Hollywood audiences.

The rest of the cast is outstanding, giving performances that are far better than the material deserves. David Morrissey is a much better actor and by far more interesting than Michael Douglas: his acting is flawless, giving a dense, complex dimension to an otherwise one dimensional character. Since he has more screen time and is the axis of the movie, he can keep your attention from beginning to end.

I am not recommending "Basic Instinct 2" as a great movie; I am just expressing my disagreement with most of the comments on this site and my conviction that agendas other than the movie itself are shaping the opinion of most spectators.
rewritten_review: "Basic Instinct 2" faced harsh criticism even before its release, with many targeting Sharon Stone, who remains stunning despite being fourteen years older. While this sequel isn't as good as the original, it's not as bad as many claim. Michael Caton-Jones isn't Paul Verhoeven, and Henry Bean and Leora Barish aren't Joe Eszterhas. It's an entertaining, average thriller with little resemblance to its predecessor, aside from Jerry Goldsmith's score. Stone adds depth to her character, creating a devilish Catherine Trimell akin to Hannibal Lecter. Despite being a talented and risk-taking actress, Stone is unfairly targeted by those who revel in criticizing her success. The rest of the cast delivers performances that surpass the material, with David Morrissey's flawless portrayal adding complexity to his character. He holds your attention throughout the film. I'm not claiming "Basic Instinct 2" is a great movie, but I disagree with many comments and believe other agendas are influencing opinions.

text: Art-house horror tries to use unconventional aesthetics to cover the fact that this is just another serial killer chiller which ultimately relies on pornographic combinations of teen sexuality and violent gore. The suburbs come across about as well as they do in every piece of Australian writing (book or film) since 1960 - surprise surprise, the suburbs have a dark underbelly - and the plot is as contrived as any you've seen. "The neighbours would never know about this guy," one of the filmmakers says about Joel Edgerton's character. "But he was completely plausible as to what he was. Serial killers don't all have patches over their eyes and scars down their cheeks. They look like the guy next door." Another trader in pornographic violence who sees a serial killer in every street. But the real insignificance of this film is in the fact that it's a genre film that nobody saw. Backed by substantial funds (including some from Film Finance - that's government), this got a run at the Underground Film Festival in Melbourne and had to rely on ACMI kindness for a *very* short release season. Q1: What is the FFC doing funding genre flicks, even if they are 'arty' and aesthetically unconventional? Q2: Why are these nasty movies (ACOLYTES; BEAUTIFUL; PUNISHMENT; NO THROUGH ROAD) being made in the first place? Richard Wolstencroft & co encourage their creators to believe they're giving the masses what they really want, as opposed to what the culture elite in government funding think they want. The truth is that these brutal and forgettable nasties earn far more critical acclaim - and win far more obscure awards - than they're due.
rewritten_review: Art-house horror often uses unconventional aesthetics to mask its nature as another serial killer chiller, relying on pornographic combinations of teen sexuality and violent gore. The suburbs are portrayed with a dark underbelly, a common theme in Australian writing since 1960, and the plot is contrived. "The neighbors would never know about this guy," one filmmaker says of Joel Edgerton's character. "Serial killers don't all have patches over their eyes and scars down their cheeks. They look like the guy next door." Another purveyor of pornographic violence who sees a serial killer in every street. The film's insignificance lies in being a genre piece that went largely unseen. Despite substantial funding, including government support, it only played at the Melbourne Underground Film Festival and had a limited release at ACMI. Q1: What is the FFC doing funding genre flicks, even if they're 'arty' and aesthetically unconventional? Q2: Why are these nasty movies (ACOLYTES; BEAUTIFUL; PUNISHMENT; NO THROUGH ROAD) being made? Richard Wolstencroft & co claim to deliver what the masses want, not what the government funding culture elite thinks they want. Yet these brutal and forgettable films earn more critical acclaim and obscure awards than they deserve.

text:
This is one of the best animated movies I've ever seen in my life. This isn't just a fun movie, or a well-made movie. This is a landmark in the art of animation and even if it weren't, just the technical skill that went into making it, would grant it a place in the history of animation.

Wladyslaw Starewicz created a stop-motion movie about the secret life of beetles. He imagined a coherent world of insects, with jobs, houses, nightclubs, movie houses, even little props like posters and bicycles and paintings.

In this movie he tells a simple tale of hypocrisy and revenge. Mr. Beetle has an affair with a dancing dragonfly, much to the chagrin of a grasshopper; but he's a cameraman and decides to shoot the fling. Mr. Beetle returns home and finds Mrs. Beetle having her own affair. Mr. Beetle chases the lover away but forgives his wife. The two make up and go out to the movies. And the movie they watch is Mr. Beetle and the Dragonfly. Described thus it sounds banal, but once seen it becomes a gripping work of cinema. Along with Emile Cohl and Jiri Trnka, Wladyslaw Starewicz pretty much invented everything that future animators would use in their work. For that reason he must not remain forgotten.
rewritten_review:
This is one of the best animated movies I've ever seen. It's not just fun or well-made; it's a landmark in animation history. The technical skill alone secures its place in animation history. Wladyslaw Starewicz created a stop-motion film about the secret life of beetles, imagining a world of insects with jobs, houses, and nightclubs, complete with props like posters and bicycles.

The movie tells a simple tale of hypocrisy and revenge. Mr. Beetle has an affair with a dancing dragonfly, upsetting a grasshopper; he films the fling. Returning home, Mr. Beetle finds Mrs. Beetle in her own affair. After chasing the lover away, he forgives his wife, and they go to the movies. Ironically, they watch Mr. Beetle's film with the Dragonfly. It sounds banal, but it's a gripping work of cinema. Alongside Emile Cohl and Jiri Trnka, Starewicz invented techniques future animators would use. He must not be forgotten.

text:
I despise horror movies, that is no secret. No plot, bad acting and gallons of blood are staples of these mistakes of cinema, and this "movie" is no exception. I cannot believe some cable stations actually run this garbage. (This particular garbage was released straight-to-video, as I recall.) As mentioning any other movie would be a great insult to that other movie, I say this: All of the Phantasm movies, all of the Jason movies, Freddy movies, Chucky movies, and most of the Michael Myers movies can be summed up in one word: TERRIBLE!!!

Rating (Phantasm III): 0.5/10
rewritten_review:
I despise horror movies, that is no secret. No plot, bad acting, and gallons of blood are staples of these mistakes of cinema, and this "movie" is no exception. I cannot believe some cable stations actually run this garbage. (This particular garbage was released straight-to-video, as I recall.) As mentioning any other movie would be a great insult to that other movie, I say this: All of the Phantasm movies, all of the Jason movies, Freddy movies, Chucky movies, and most of the Michael Myers movies can be summed up in one word: TERRIBLE!!!

These films, in my opinion, lack substance and creativity. They rely heavily on shock value and gratuitous violence rather than developing compelling storylines or complex characters. The acting in these movies often leaves much to be desired, with performances that feel forced and unconvincing. It's as if the filmmakers prioritize gore over genuine storytelling, which is incredibly disappointing to those of us who appreciate well-crafted cinema.

Moreover, the predictability of these horror franchises is frustrating. They seem to follow the same formulaic approach, with little to no innovation or originality. It's the same recycled tropes and clichés, movie after movie, making them feel stale and uninspired. As a viewer, I crave something more engaging and thought-provoking, something that challenges the genre rather than conforming to its most tired stereotypes.

In addition, the sheer volume of sequels and spin-offs these franchises churn out is overwhelming. It feels like a never-ending cycle of mediocrity, with each installment failing to offer anything new or exciting. The horror genre deserves better than this relentless barrage of subpar films that do little more than tarnish its reputation.

In summary, my disdain for these horror movies knows no bounds. They epitomize everything I dislike about the genre, and I find it baffling that they continue to find an audience. While I understand that some fans enjoy the campiness and nostalgia of these films, I personally cannot overlook their glaring flaws. For me, they remain forever trapped in the realm of the truly terrible.

Rating (Phantasm III): 0.5/10

text: Simply, I found the TV show "Mash" trite, preachy, oh ever so "politically correct", repetitious, pretentious and biggest sin of all, and that is,? that it is (was) incredibly dull. You have Alan Alda as the main lead, "(star)", who is so in love with himself and his cleverness, that it actually made me uncomfortable to even try and sit through an episode. The original series had both McLean Stevson, and Wayne Rogers, whom I'll happily admit had a certain panache and style to their character presentation. However, Harry (Henry) Morgan, and Mike Farrell, both singularly and compositely together is like eating caviar and fresh oysters with Wonder Bread. Loretta Swit, which I also found dull, also to no fault of her own wasn't a wonder to look at, and Gary Burghoff, who was good in the movie got tired looking and acting as the show wore on. Seeing one show a year showed that to me. Jamie Farr was just low brow "comedy" and is not even worth really mentioning here at all. The reason I did not give it a (one) rating, which anyone reading this by now would be wondering, is that ratings of any sort is not only a subjective call, but a relative one. Television, except for relatively few exceptions, is such crud. That relatively speaking, Mash had some production quality, (by television standards) of that era and today, and therefore it is deserved of a two. Rob Ritter
rewritten_review: I found the TV show "Mash" trite, preachy, politically correct, repetitious, pretentious, and, most of all, incredibly dull. Alan Alda, the main lead, seemed so in love with himself and his cleverness that it made me uncomfortable to watch. The original series had McLean Stevenson and Wayne Rogers, who had a certain panache and style. However, Harry Morgan and Mike Farrell together were like eating caviar and fresh oysters with Wonder Bread. Loretta Swit was dull and not a wonder to look at, while Gary Burghoff became tired-looking and acting as the show wore on. Jamie Farr's low-brow comedy isn't even worth mentioning. The reason I didn't give it a one rating is that ratings are subjective and relative. While television is mostly crud, "Mash" had some production quality for its era, deserving a two. Rob Ritter

text:
...there was "Broadcast News," and what a good thing it was. This one just plain stands up and sounds its barbaric yawp in a manner that resonates two decades later.

There are moments -- especially with respect to the cutesy score -- when this film becomes a bit too eighties, or a bit too "Sleepless in Seattle." Fortunately, they're few and far between.

One-third social satire, one-third romantic comedy, one-third drama, with three flawed but endearing people at its core, it's smart and moving and almost impossibly funny. Holly Hunter in particular may never have been more fun to watch in a comedic role. (And yes, I'm including "Raising Arizona," her other star turn from that era, in this assessment.)

A legitimate classic.
rewritten_review:
...there was "Broadcast News," and what a good thing it was. This one just plain stands up and sounds its barbaric yawp in a manner that resonates two decades later. The film manages to capture the essence of its era while still feeling relevant and insightful today, which is no small feat. The themes it tackles and the issues it raises continue to be pertinent, making it a timeless piece of cinema that appeals to both those who experienced it in its original context and new audiences discovering it for the first time. The film's ability to blend different genres seamlessly is a testament to its strong storytelling and well-crafted characters.

There are moments -- especially with respect to the cutesy score -- when this film becomes a bit too eighties, or a bit too "Sleepless in Seattle." These instances may serve as reminders of the time in which the film was made, adding a layer of nostalgia for some viewers. Fortunately, they're few and far between. The film largely avoids the pitfalls of becoming dated, maintaining a fresh and engaging quality that keeps viewers invested in the story and the characters. The soundtrack, while occasionally reminiscent of its era, ultimately complements the film's narrative and emotional beats effectively.

One-third social satire, one-third romantic comedy, one-third drama, with three flawed but endearing people at its core, it's smart and moving and almost impossibly funny. The balance of these elements is expertly handled, allowing each aspect to shine without overshadowing the others. The social satire provides sharp insights into the world of broadcast journalism and the ethical dilemmas faced by those within it, while the romantic comedy elements offer light-heartedness and warmth. Meanwhile, the drama adds depth and complexity, ensuring that the film resonates on multiple levels.

Holly Hunter in particular may never have been more fun to watch in a comedic role. Her performance is a standout, showcasing her versatility and comedic timing. (And yes, I'm including "Raising Arizona," her other star turn from that era, in this assessment.) Her portrayal adds a layer of charm and relatability to the film, making her character both memorable and endearing. The chemistry between the lead actors further enhances the film's appeal, creating a dynamic and engaging ensemble that draws the audience in.

A legitimate classic. The film's enduring popularity and critical acclaim are a testament to its quality and impact. Its influence can be seen in subsequent films and television shows that tackle similar themes or employ a similar blend of genres. The film's legacy continues to grow, solidifying its place in the pantheon of great cinematic works. Whether viewed as a product of its time or as a timeless exploration of human relationships and professional ethics, "Broadcast News" remains a compelling and entertaining film that stands the test of time.

text:
A meteorite falls in the country of a small town, bringing a jelly creature. An old farmer is attacked by the alien in his hand, and the youths Steve Andrews (Steve McQueen) and his girlfriend Jane Martin (Aneta Corsaut) take him to Dr. T. Hallen (Steven Chase). The local doctor treats carefully the blister, and asks Steve to investigate the location where they found the old man. When Steve returns, he sees the blob killing the doctor. Steve and Jane try to warn the police and the dwellers, but nobody believe on them, while the blob engulfs many people, getting bigger and bigger.

"The Blob" is a cult and classic sci-fi. It is a low budget movie, with many ham actors and actresses (with the exception of Steve McQueen), awful effects, but also delightful and very, but very funny. This is the first time that I see this classic (I had seen the 1988 remake with Kevin Dillon), and I really recommend it to fans of Steve McQueen and sci-fi B-movies from the 50s. The film subject of my review number 1,400 could not be better. My vote is seven.

Title (Brazil): "A Bolha" ("The Blob")
rewritten_review:
A meteorite falls near a small town, bringing a jelly creature. An old farmer is attacked by the alien, and youths Steve Andrews (Steve McQueen) and his girlfriend Jane Martin (Aneta Corsaut) take him to Dr. T. Hallen (Steven Chase). The doctor treats the blister and asks Steve to investigate the site. Steve returns to see the blob kill the doctor. Steve and Jane warn the police and townsfolk, but no one believes them as the blob engulfs more people, growing bigger.

"The Blob" is a cult and classic sci-fi film. It's a low-budget movie with many ham actors (except Steve McQueen), awful effects, but it's delightful and very funny. This is my first time seeing this classic (I'd seen the 1988 remake with Kevin Dillon), and I recommend it to fans of Steve McQueen and 50s sci-fi B-movies. My vote is seven.

Title (Brazil): "A Bolha" ("The Blob")

text:
I'm a dance teacher and was looking forward to some good dance routines in this film. How sad to have been subjected to such a painful experience.

I had major problems with Jennifer Beals and her character. I found Alex extremely repellent. Beals' face is so young, sweet and innocent, and this very incongruous with Alex's very disturbing lewdness, especially in that disgusting restaurant scene. She also has the temper tantrums of a toddler. It is very difficult to believe that Nick would keep coming back to such a moody teenager after her frequent rantings and ravings, especially after she opens the door of a moving car and chucks a stiletto at him, opting rather to walk home - in the middle of the road - with only one shoe!!!. And what about after her idiotic behaviour after the night at the ballet. In fact, the whole romance was very disturbing - the 30 something year old man going after a girl who looks about 16. Yuck.

As for the dancing, I'm afraid this 80s style is totally dated. What on earth was that TV dance sequence about in the club? Who was supposed to be dancing? I wasn't even sure if it was a woman or a man in drag! And even that famous final sequence is pretty disappointing, especially given the context of an audition for a ballet company. The camera shots of her leap actually ruin it's effect because you can't see what she's doing. And what on earth was she doing when she went past each of the panel pointing at them? And as many other comments have pointed out, she would NEVER get into a ballet company on the strength of that audition - perhaps that's why they don't actually say at the end whether she was successful or not, the closure is the fact that she overcame her fear in the end. Of the 'Flashdancers', I actually thought the best sequence belonged to Cynthia Rhodes (Penny in Dirty Dancing). You could see that she was a real dancer, and her acrobatics were very impressive. This is of course if you can get past her appalling costume and makeup.

There were two good bits in this film - the ballet dancers stretching when Alex goes for the first time to apply for an audition - they look so lovely and classy, and at least this helps to underline the difference between her current dance career and the one she aspires to. The other good scene was the break dancing in the street. I also liked the ice skater's parents, they were funny.

Some other random points - who was Hanna and how did Alex get to know her? What was an 18 year old doing living in a converted warehouse all alone? How did she afford that lovely barre and all the furniture?Where were her family? Was that scene in the 'nude' club really necessary? The person who wrote in their comment that it was something like a Disney film needs their head examined. And anyway, what happened to the ice skater?

Many people said the film was poor but they liked the message - don't give up hope, keep on trying, and your dreams will come true. Watch "The Little Mermaid" instead.

text:
I went into "Night of the Hunted" not knowing what to expect at all. I was really impressed.

It is essentially a mystery/thriller where this girl who can't remember anything gets 'rescued' by a guy who happens to be driving past. The two become fast friends and lovers and together, they try to figure out what is going on with her. Through some vague flashbacks and grim memories, they eventually get to the bottom of it and the ending is pretty cool.

I really liked the setting of this one: a desolate, post-modern Paris is the backdrop with lots of gray skies and tall buildings. Very metropolitan. Groovy soundtrack and lots of nudity.

Surprising it was made in 1980; seems somewhat ahead of it's time.

8 out of 10, kids.
rewritten_review:
I went into "Night of the Hunted" not knowing what to expect at all. I was really impressed with what I found, and it left a lasting impression on me. This film is essentially a mystery/thriller where this girl, who can't remember anything about her past, gets 'rescued' by a guy who happens to be driving past. Their encounter seems almost serendipitous, and from that moment on, the two become fast friends and lovers, embarking on a journey together to unravel the mystery of her lost memories. As they navigate through a series of events and uncover pieces of the puzzle, they try to figure out what is going on with her and why she can't remember anything. Through some vague flashbacks and grim memories, they eventually get to the bottom of it, solving the enigma that has been haunting her. The ending is pretty cool and wraps up the story in a satisfying way.

I really liked the setting of this one: a desolate, post-modern Paris is the backdrop for the entire film. It features lots of gray skies and tall buildings, creating a very metropolitan atmosphere that adds to the overall mood and tone of the story. The ambiance is enhanced by a groovy soundtrack that complements the scenes and heightens the emotional impact. There is also lots of nudity, which might be surprising for some viewers, but it fits the narrative and style of the film.

It's surprising that "Night of the Hunted" was made in 1980; it seems somewhat ahead of its time in terms of its themes and execution. The film manages to capture a unique blend of mystery, romance, and psychological intrigue that keeps the audience engaged from start to finish. It's an experience that stays with you long after the credits roll.

Overall, I would give it an 8 out of 10, kids. It's definitely worth a watch, especially if you're a fan of films that push the boundaries and offer something a little different from the norm.

text:
Why me? Why should I be subjected to such slaughter of what could have made an interesting plot?! At least if I can warn other people off, it will have been worthwhile.

I had to watch this horrible movie for a college course. Otherwise, I would have looked at the synopsis on the back of the thing and steered clear. The movie was slow, had PAINFULLY little character development, and centered around the idea that a creepy little white man can become cool if he hangs out with an LA-style token black man.

If you want to experience the stereotypical LA feeling of dizzying superficiality - watch the movie. Note, though, that this movie does not DEPICT what we have come to think of as an "LA lifestyle", it is a wonderful example of the products that ARISE from it.
rewritten_review: Why me? Why should I be subjected to such a slaughter of what could have made an interesting plot?! At least if I can warn other people off, it will have been worthwhile. The experience was excruciating, to say the least. I had to watch this horrible movie for a college course. Otherwise, I would have looked at the synopsis on the back of the thing and steered clear, avoiding what turned out to be a cinematic disaster. The movie was slow, painfully dragging its feet from one scene to the next, and had PAINFULLY little character development, leaving the audience grasping for any semblance of depth or connection with the characters. It centered around the idea that a creepy little white man can become cool if he hangs out with an LA-style token black man, which is an overused and tired trope that does nothing to engage or inspire. If you want to experience the stereotypical LA feeling of dizzying superficiality - watch the movie. You'll get an overload of that shallow vibe, that’s for sure. Note, though, that this movie does not DEPICT what we have come to think of as an "LA lifestyle". Instead, it is a wonderful example of the products that ARISE from it. The film stands as a testament to the kind of superficial storytelling that can emerge from such an environment, lacking in substance and depth. The entire experience was a test of endurance, and not in a good way.

text:
For those that were interested in knowing how exactly humanity came to be encased in big red pods that make me crave pomegranate, there is the duo of the "Second Renaissance" shorts. I'm not exactly sure why they are split into two parts, especially since they're credited as one on the DVD (and are these shorts viewed on any other format but the DVD?), but they're informative even if they have a few gaps.

What really makes this first part stand out, from the second part and the rest of the animations as well, is the parallels it shows between robot uprising and civil rights. Graphic homages to slavery, fascism, concentration camps, and mass graves are mixed with verbal references to the Million Man March and humanity's God-complex. In fact, "God" is never really referenced by these shorts, instead replaced by "Man's own image".

As far as the shorts go in the collection, "The Second Renaissance: Part I" is by far the most effective in bringing out emotion. It's a sorrowful and disturbing view of the potential of humanity to become "the architect of its own destruction." Some may be turned off by some of the concepts this short rips directly out of previously established science fiction literature, but then again, that's basically what most of the Matrix series has done, and it's been a driving force behind its success.

--PolarisDiB
rewritten_review:
For those interested in how humanity ended up in big red pods reminiscent of pomegranates, there's the duo of the "Second Renaissance" shorts. It's unclear why they're split into two parts, especially since they're credited as one on the DVD (are these shorts viewed on any other format but the DVD?), but they're informative despite a few gaps.

What sets this first part apart from the second and the other animations is the parallels it draws between robot uprising and civil rights. Graphic homages to slavery, fascism, concentration camps, and mass graves are mixed with verbal references to the Million Man March and humanity's God-complex. "God" is never really referenced; instead, it's replaced by "Man's own image."

Among the shorts in the collection, "The Second Renaissance: Part I" is the most effective in evoking emotion. It's a sorrowful and disturbing view of humanity's potential to become "the architect of its own destruction." Some may be turned off by concepts borrowed from established science fiction literature, but that's largely what the Matrix series has done, driving its success.

--PolarisDiB

text:
WWE Armageddon, December 17, 2006 -- Live from Richmond Coliseum, Richmond, VA

Kane vs. MVP in an Inferno match: So this is the fourth ever inferno match in the WWE and it is Kane vs. MVP (wonder why was it the first match on the card). I only viewed the ending parts where Kane sets MVP's ass on fire as they're on the apron and then MVP is running around the arena while yelling  eventually the refs put out the fire with a fire extinguisher as MVP sprawls around the entrance ramp. Funny and visually quite entertaining ending. 7/10

WWE Tag Team Championship: This was originally supposed to be William Regal & Dave Taylor vs. Brian Kendrick & Paul London (c) in a regular tag team match. However, GM Teddy Long comes to the ring and announces that it's going to be a Fatal 4-way tag team ladder match. MNM and The Hardys are thrown in and it's all chaos. One word to describe this eye-opener  wow. Man, I really can't remember how many sick spots there were in this match and words can't really do it justice. There was one particularly notable spot where The Hardys set up a ladder in a see-saw position and Jeff jumped off the top rope while Matt held MNM for the kill, and then WHAM! Nitro blew away while Mercury apparently botched it and was bleeding like hell with lacerations over his face. He had to be taken away and Nitro continued the match alone. Another spot was when Jeff powerbombed London while FLIPPING off the ladder. There were other high-flying breathtaking spots too many to remember. London finally unbuckles the belts to win this rave show-stealer. 8.5/10

The Boogeyman vs. The Miz: The two men get thrown in and around the ring until Boogeyman explodes a sit-out powerbomb for the victory and then and drools worms over The Miz's mouth as usual. 5.5/10 for this three-minute incognito.

United States championship: Chris Benoit (c) faces off Chavo Guerrero in yet another typical Guerrero match. Some good spots included a superplex off the top rope by Chavo and an unusually long chain of German suplexes by Benoit. Vicki Guerrero comes in the ring with the belt to nail Benoit but Benoit scares her off and takes a long time deciding whether to put her in a Sharpshooter or not. This allows Chavo to go for a roll-up but Benoit rolls it up once more and Chavo is locked in the Sharpshooter. Game over. Nice hard-fought battle albeit slow at times. 7/10

WWE Cruiserweight championship: Gregory Helms (c) vs. Jimmy Wang Yang for this one, in a fairly moderate-paced match. The match had some good high-flying spots  most notably Helms' moves off the top rope  but the crowd didn't seem to be into it after witnessing the ladder match, and Yang needs to get more airborne. Helms won the match after blowing Yang away with a facebuster on the knee. 7.5/10

The Undertaker vs. Mr. Kennedy in a Last Ride match: After a series of matches between these two, this time it is a Last Ride match, the second ever of its kind and the winner has to escort his opponent out of the arena in a hearse. Pretty good indeed for what these two could offer. Kennedy manhandled a good deal of Taker and even broke free of a chokeslam to throw Taker off the Armageddon set about 15 feet below; and thank God for Kennedy, otherwise it would've been brutal. Kennedy almost got the win until Taker got back up inside the hearse (I liked the camera view inside the hearse). Taker then missed a steel pipe hurl on Kennedy and broke the hearse's window instead, but then later busted Kennedy open with a chair, and followed with a consecutive chokeslam and Tombstone on the hearse's roof. Kennedy was unconscious and Taker drove him out of the arena to win. I actually found myself really interested into these guys' willingness to take/give real sick shots. 7.5/10

Santa comes into the ring, I go "what the hell?" like many of the kids in the crowd, and then the word "lingerie contest" gets in my ear. Break time.

Batista & John Cena vs. Finlay & King Booker: talk about charisma vs. technicality. This match was actually a quite good main event with the momentum rationally shifting from one team to the other and retaining good suspense. Even Finlay got some legitimate good shots on his opponents this time (I kind of doubted his strength against the champs), and him and Booker mainly didn't succeed in trying to cheat  except at one point where Booker rammed his scepter into Cena's throat. Batista hits the Bomb on Booker for the win, didn't get to see the F-U; Cena performed the 5 Knuckle Shuffle anyhow and I think he also did the STFU. This was probably the best technical match of the night and the participants did superbly indeed for what they could without a ladder 7.5/10.

Being an on-and-off WWE fan, I have to agree that Armageddon was laced up with numerous eye-catchers throughout, and the ladder match ultimately swallowed half of the show; the Last Ride match featured some fairly nerve-wrenching spots, and the main event also did very well for its category. All other matches also lived up to their billing except perhaps the Boogeyman vs. The Miz bout and the ever-useless lingerie contest. Overall Armageddon was a highly enjoyable pay-per-view and despite some big setbacks earlier in the PPV chronology, Armageddon wishes this year's goodbye respectably. PPV rating: 8/10.
rewritten_review:
WWE Armageddon, December 17, 2006 -- Live from Richmond Coliseum, Richmond, VA

**Kane vs. MVP in an Inferno match:** The fourth ever inferno match in WWE featured Kane vs. MVP. The match ended with Kane setting MVP's ass on fire on the apron, resulting in MVP running around while yelling until refs extinguished the fire. Funny and visually entertaining. 7/10

**WWE Tag Team Championship:** Originally a regular tag match, GM Teddy Long changed it to a Fatal 4-way tag team ladder match. Chaos ensued with William Regal & Dave Taylor vs. Brian Kendrick & Paul London (c) vs. MNM vs. The Hardys. Notable spots included a ladder see-saw and Jeff powerbombing London while flipping off a ladder. London unbuckled the belts to win. 8.5/10

**The Boogeyman vs. The Miz:** Boogeyman won with a sit-out powerbomb and drooled worms over Miz's mouth. 5.5/10

**United States Championship:** Chris Benoit (c) vs. Chavo Guerrero. Highlights included a superplex by Chavo and a long chain of German suplexes by Benoit. Vicki Guerrero's interference led to Chavo nearly winning, but Benoit locked in the Sharpshooter for the victory. 7/10

**WWE Cruiserweight Championship:** Gregory Helms (c) vs. Jimmy Wang Yang in a moderate-paced match. Despite good high-flying spots, the crowd was less engaged post-ladder match. Helms won with a facebuster on the knee. 7.5/10

**The Undertaker vs. Mr. Kennedy in a Last Ride match:** The second-ever Last Ride match, requiring the winner to escort the loser out in a hearse. Kennedy dominated Taker but ultimately lost after Taker's series of brutal attacks, including a chokeslam and Tombstone on the hearse's roof. 7.5/10

**Santa enters for a lingerie contest:** Break time.

**Batista & John Cena vs. Finlay & King Booker:** Charisma vs. technicality. Momentum shifted between teams, with Finlay and Booker attempting to cheat. Batista's Bomb on Booker secured the win. A well-executed main event. 7.5/10

As an on-and-off WWE fan, Armageddon was filled with eye-catching moments, with the ladder match dominating the show. The Last Ride match and main event delivered well. All matches lived up to expectations except for Boogeyman vs. The Miz and the lingerie contest. Overall, a highly enjoyable PPV that ended the year respectably. PPV rating: 8/10.

text: Do you know when you look at your collection of old, videotaped movies, and realize that there are some that you've only seen once or twice, and you can't remember if they're worth the time it takes to see them? The Alibi is/was one of those films; I found it, not long ago, and decided I might as well give it a chance. I'm not entirely sure if I'm happy with my decision... on one hand, the film is really, really bad, on the other, now I have another free tape... yeah, you get it. The plot is predictable and not in any way original. The pacing is bad. The acting is bad, but that's not really surprising, seeing as the two leads are former soap-opera stars... they're used to overact. The characters are poorly written clichés. The film even manages to screw up the easiest damn way to impress me(through film): court scenes. Even those don't elicit one single emotion for or against any of the cardboard-thin characters. The film just has no real redeeming qualities whatsoever... even the dialog is bad. The thing is, it's so full of clichés that it's laughable. And that's the one thing that lifts this above a rating of 1/10: the(albeit unintentionally so) comic relief of the many clichés and stereotypes. I didn't pay very much attention to the film, but just about every time I looked at the screen, there was something to laugh at. One final note: I considered using the line "Tori Spelling can't act" as a one line summary, but I guess everyone knows that, so I opted for the current one, seeing as it's more informative. All in all, a thoroughly bad film, but not the worst if you've got nothing else to do and if it's on TV. Good for a few laughs, if you can sit through it. 3/10
rewritten_review: When you look at your old videotaped movies and realize some you've only seen once or twice, you wonder if they're worth rewatching. "The Alibi" was one of those films for me. I decided to give it another chance, but I'm not sure if I'm happy with my decision. The film is really bad, yet now I have another free tape. The plot is predictable, the pacing is bad, and the acting is poor, with leads who are former soap-opera stars known for overacting. The characters are clichés, and even the court scenes fail to evoke any emotion. The film lacks redeeming qualities, even the dialogue is bad. However, the abundance of clichés makes it laughable, providing unintended comic relief. I didn't pay much attention, but whenever I looked at the screen, there was something to laugh at. I considered summarizing with "Tori Spelling can't act," but opted for something more informative. Overall, a thoroughly bad film, but not the worst if you're bored and it's on TV. It offers a few laughs if you can sit through it. 3/10

text: Definitely not worth the rental, but if you catch it on cable, you'll be pleasantly surprised by the cameos--Iman's appearance is especially self-deprecating. It's also an opportunity to watch all the male supporting cast members from The Sopranos typecast themselves.
rewritten_review: This movie is definitely not worth the rental, but if you happen to catch it on cable, you might find yourself pleasantly surprised by the unexpected cameos. One of the standout appearances is by Iman, whose self-deprecating humor adds an unexpected twist to the film. It's a delightful surprise that adds a layer of charm and wit to the viewing experience. Additionally, the movie serves as an interesting opportunity to watch all the male supporting cast members from The Sopranos, as they typecast themselves into roles that feel all too familiar. Their performances, while predictable, bring a sense of nostalgia for fans of the iconic television series. The film, with its blend of familiar faces and unexpected humor, manages to offer something entertaining, even if it's not worth the price of a rental. So, while it may not be a must-see, catching it on cable could turn out to be an enjoyable experience.

text:
A group of human looking aliens going to Earth to eat crash land on a planet of prehistoric beasts instead where they all eat physcedelic mushrooms and act retarded. Padded with footage from "Planet of the Dinosuars" and horrible jokes this is definitely one to miss. The acting is atrocious as well, and while this isn't as bad as "Chickboxer" (what movie can be?) This is still pretty awful repugnant stuff. It's 90 minute running time feels like an eternity and you will likely be cursing life so do yourself a huge favor and just move on, skip this crappy film, there's nothing to see here.

The film-makers try to resell this turd as a MST3K style making fun of the movie they made a decade before, and it works to an extent it's still nothing that watchable though, Ariauna Albright is hot, but Lilith Stabs has a pretty unattractive speaking voice.

My Grade: D-

DVD Extras: Joke commentary, 17 Behind the scenes featurette; 7 minute Into the black featurette; Jessica Mills reporting; Stills gallery; and original trailer
rewritten_review:
A group of human-looking aliens crash land on a planet of prehistoric beasts instead of Earth. They eat psychedelic mushrooms and act foolishly. Padded with footage from "Planet of the Dinosaurs" and filled with horrible jokes, this is definitely one to miss. The acting is atrocious, and while not as bad as "Chickboxer," it’s still awful. Its 90-minute runtime feels like an eternity, and you’ll likely be cursing life. Do yourself a favor and skip this crappy film; there’s nothing to see here.

The filmmakers try to resell this dud as an MST3K-style parody of their original movie, and while it works somewhat, it’s still not watchable. Ariauna Albright is hot, but Lilith Stabs has an unattractive speaking voice.

My Grade: D-

DVD Extras: Joke commentary, 17 Behind the scenes featurette, 7-minute Into the Black featurette, Jessica Mills reporting, Stills gallery, and original trailer.

text:
I don't know much about film-making, but good movies have to tell some sort of a story...your characters have to start and complete their journey. In Last Exit to Brooklyn they may, but its not in any satisfying way, and I'm not meaning a happy ending, just ANY ending.

Last Exit to Brooklyn, set in 1952 Brooklyn during a very brutal labor strike, sets a number of story threads in motion. Most involve some of the most unlikeable characters to ever walk across a movie screen. But Last Exit to Brooklyn fails to bring these stories to any conclusion...it leaves some of them dangling with no ending, or blasts off into some bizarre stratosphere for an "artistic" ending.

Two cases in point, and they contain spoilers.

A sad transvestite character (an important character in the film), is struck by a car and killed. And that's it for him in the movie....he's gone for good, erased from everyone's memory..no reactions from his friends, enemies, lovers....nothing.

In another thread the stupid, clueless, and secretly gay strike leader, having been rejected by labor, his gay lover, and found out by the neighborhood thugs, gets stomped by the thugs. The closing scene to the beating shows the streets of Brooklyn, and the streetlights are very, very similar to those of Nazi death camps...and the scene drags on and on and on...and the camera pans down to the body of the labor leader, and he's been crucified.....ppppuuuulllleeeeeez. And of course that's it for him too....brain erasure.....gone.

Bottom line....no matter what the reviewers originally said in 1989 about this film....this movie is a depressing piece of sludge. Avoid it. And if you don't be forewarned, it really deserves an NC-17 rating for massive amounts of physical, emotional and sexual brutality...don't even let the teenagers watch.
rewritten_review:
I don't know much about filmmaking, but good movies need to tell a story...characters have to start and complete their journey. In Last Exit to Brooklyn, they might, but not in any satisfying way—not necessarily a happy ending, just ANY ending.

Set in 1952 Brooklyn during a brutal labor strike, the film sets several story threads in motion, mostly involving unlikeable characters. However, Last Exit to Brooklyn fails to conclude these stories, leaving them dangling or opting for a bizarre "artistic" ending.

Two examples, with spoilers:

A transvestite character is struck by a car and killed. That's it—no reactions from friends, enemies, lovers—nothing.

Another thread involves a clueless, secretly gay strike leader who, after being rejected by labor, his lover, and the neighborhood thugs, gets stomped by the thugs. The scene drags on with streetlights resembling those of Nazi death camps, ending with him crucified...ppppuuuulllleeeeeez. And that's it for him too—gone.

Bottom line: No matter what reviewers said in 1989, this movie is a depressing piece of sludge. Avoid it. It deserves an NC-17 rating for physical, emotional, and sexual brutality—don't let teenagers watch.

text:
The plot of this movie is as dumb as a bag of hair. Jimmy Smit plays a character that could have been upset by the ridiculousness of the story. He is evil and a wife beater. It's a character as far from his NYPD and LA Law roles as you could possibly get.

If you've thought he had the looks and the acting chops to play the really bad boy role, her's your present.

But!!!!!!!! Mary Louis Parker wears black miniskirts and little black minidresses throughout the movie.

She has always had some of the greatest legs in the history of the movies. This makes the movie well worth it for this leg admirer.

I'd buy the DVD for this reason only if it was available.
rewritten_review:
The plot of this movie is as dumb as a bag of hair. It's really quite astonishing how nonsensical it is. Jimmy Smit plays a character that could have been upset by the ridiculousness of the story. He is evil and a wife beater. It's a character as far from his NYPD and LA Law roles as you could possibly get. The transformation in his character is stark and jarring, making you wonder how he ended up in this role. If you've thought he had the looks and the acting chops to play the really bad boy role, here's your present. It's a gift to those who have always wanted to see him in such a light.

But!!!!!!!! Mary Louis Parker wears black miniskirts and little black minidresses throughout the movie. Her wardrobe is a highlight, to say the least. She has always had some of the greatest legs in the history of the movies. This makes the movie well worth it for this leg admirer. Her presence on screen is magnetic and captivating, drawing attention away from the film's otherwise questionable plot. It's as if her wardrobe was designed specifically to make viewers forget about everything else.

I'd buy the DVD for this reason only if it was available. In fact, owning a copy just to appreciate her fashion choices would be entirely justifiable. Her style alone elevates the film to a level of interest that it otherwise might not reach.

text: MY EYES! IN THE NAME OF GOD AND ALL THAT IS HOLY MAKE ME UNSEE THIS MOVIE! what drugs are you people on! this could very well be the worst movie ever! i felt like i was on a bad acid trip the whole time, i need to call a therapist to help me deal with the trauma of this epic disaster. From start to finish glow ropes is an unholy masterpiece of satanic cinema. when i thought to watch this movie with my Jewish best friend and his family we thought "oh hey, this may be funny! it will probably be bad but still a little funny" how wrong we were, we were not prepared for how awful this movie could be. All of my friends lined up for lobotomies as soon as the film was over, and during the course of the movie, one of my friends attempted to hang himself with his belt while another tried to slit his wrists with a wooden spoon. I wish I had watched the video from The Ring instead, that way the pain and suffering would be over in only seven short days. For all who wish to see this movie, YOU ARE NOT PREPARED! you may think you are some sort of "tough guy" by renting this but this movie will break you, push you to the ground and urinate on you.

I felt like I was on a bad acid trip the whole time; I need to call a therapist to deal with the trauma of this epic disaster. Glow Ropes is an unholy masterpiece of satanic cinema.
