text: This movie was terrible...How can somebody even think that this movie was like the ones back in the "good old days" when Tim Thomerson was not even in it. And to make things worse, they used clips from old trancer movies. Thats just terrible. NO trancer movie is complete without Tim Thomerson.I love Fullmoon films, and i have been watching them since i was 4 years old. I have been through everything they have done and this movie almost made me lose it. Now i got a couple of lines to fill so i will keep going. Their way of breeding new trancers is completely stupid as well as way to send Jack back in time. What happened to the TCL Chamber. AND finally! What happened in the end of trancers 5 where lina says and i quote "Jack Has given me something special" AND her and some other broad looks at her stomach. I don't know...maybe a BABY is in there. There were so many other places of going to, but fullmoon S'd the Bed
rewritten_review:
This movie was terrible... How can somebody even think that this movie was like the ones back in the "good old days" when Tim Thomerson was not even in it. And to make things worse, they used clips from old Trancer movies. That's just terrible. NO Trancer movie is complete without Tim Thomerson. I love Fullmoon films, and I have been watching them since I was 4 years old. I have been through everything they have done, and this movie almost made me lose it. It was like watching a train wreck in slow motion, and I couldn't believe my eyes. The essence of what made the original Trancer movies so thrilling and memorable was completely lost. 

Now, I got a couple of lines to fill, so I will keep going. Their way of breeding new trancers is completely stupid as well as the way to send Jack back in time. What happened to the TCL Chamber? It was such a critical part of the original storyline, and its absence is glaring. AND finally! What happened in the end of Trancers 5 where Lina says, and I quote, "Jack has given me something special," and she and some other broad look at her stomach. I don't know...maybe a BABY is in there. There were so many other places they could have gone to, so many intriguing storylines left unexplored, but Fullmoon S'd the Bed. They had the opportunity to delve into so much rich history and character development, and instead, they opted for a shortcut that felt lazy and uninspired. The lack of continuity and disregard for the fans' attachment to the original series was disheartening. 

The movie's attempt to pay homage to the classics fell flat because it lacked the heart and dedication that went into making the originals. The decision to recycle clips from old Trancer movies instead of creating new, engaging content was frustrating. It felt like they were trying to capitalize on nostalgia without putting in the effort to create something genuinely worthy of the Trancer legacy. Fullmoon Productions, a studio I have cherished for years, somehow managed to tarnish their own legacy with this disappointing installment. 

The storyline was disjointed and lacked the coherence that made the earlier Trancer movies so captivating. The absence of Tim Thomerson left a void that couldn't be filled, and it was painfully obvious. The new characters introduced were underdeveloped and did not have the charisma or presence to carry the film forward. The narrative was riddled with plot holes and inconsistencies that were difficult to overlook. It seemed like the writers didn't even bother to rewatch the previous films to ensure continuity. 

In conclusion, this movie was a huge letdown. It was a disservice to the legacy of the Trancer series and to the fans who have supported Fullmoon for so many years. They had a chance to create something amazing, to bring new life into a beloved franchise, but unfortunately, they missed the mark by a mile.

text:
This is so blatantly a made-for-TV ripoff of Black Widow (1987) - even the insect titles are so similar.

If you want a better "marrying for money" movie, check out Black Widow, starring Debra Winger & Theresa Russell.

These movie is cheesiness at its best..! I just had to watch it entirely to see how it ended.
rewritten_review:
This is so blatantly a made-for-TV ripoff of Black Widow (1987) - even the insect titles are so similar. It's remarkable how closely it mirrors the original, down to the tiniest details. The similarities are uncanny and hard to ignore, making it feel like an imitation rather than an original production. The concept of "marrying for money" is explored in both films, but if you're seeking a superior version, I highly recommend checking out Black Widow, starring Debra Winger & Theresa Russell. Their performances bring depth and intrigue to the storyline, elevating it beyond the ordinary. 

The original film offers a masterful take on the theme, with its intriguing plot twists and captivating performances. The storyline is engaging and keeps you on the edge of your seat, providing a cinematic experience that's truly memorable. In contrast, the TV ripoff falls short, relying heavily on clichés and predictable plot points that lack the same level of sophistication. 

These movie is cheesiness at its best..! The cheesiness is so pronounced that it becomes a spectacle in itself, providing unintended humor and entertainment. I just had to watch it entirely to see how it ended. The ending, much like the rest of the film, is filled with over-the-top moments that are both amusing and bewildering. Despite its shortcomings, there's a certain charm in its unabashed embrace of melodrama, making it a guilty pleasure for those who appreciate the genre.

text:
This was the first "Walking Tall" movie I saw, I think in a $2 movie theater along Hollywood Blvd. , so I didn't have any reference to the first installment done by Joe Don Baker. I remember being shocked at the corrupted system of McNairy County and the brutality of the "redneck gangs". I was also amazed at the fact that one man decided he's not going to let it slide, and went out to do something about it. Courageous ? I thought so - to a point where it sent shivers up my spine.

I think this movie is a great story about American courage to stand up and do something about a system that's only serving its own interest. I was pretty blown away about it, and think this is still one of the best movie of the hero/anti-hero genre, which one might laugh but includes recent movies like the "The Punisher", but even more so because it's a true story. The recent remake starring the "Rock" just doesn't do any justice to the real fire in the story of Buford Pusser.

A "classic" that I'm sure will resurface again in the future.
rewritten_review: This was the first "Walking Tall" movie I saw, probably in a $2 theater on Hollywood Blvd. Without having seen Joe Don Baker's original, I was shocked by McNairy County's corruption and the brutality of the "redneck gangs." I was amazed by one man's courage to stand up against it, which sent shivers up my spine. This movie is a great story of American courage to challenge a self-serving system. I was blown away by it and think it remains one of the best hero/anti-hero films, even more impactful because it's a true story. The remake with the "Rock" doesn't capture the true fire of Buford Pusser's story. A "classic" that will surely resurface.

text: Solange is not a great Italian thriller. Get ready for the spoiler - the main suspect, the professor, didn't do it. But is it really a spoiler? No, because you know that he couldn't have been the murderer from the very beginning; he and a student witnessed the first murder. So, there is absolutely no suspense as to whether or not the professor is the killer. There is a long, tedious build up to the final explanation of the mystery. The solution is interesting, but it comes out of nowhere. The rest of the movie (and it's not a short movie) is just not exciting enough to hold your interest. Even in the tradition of "wrong man accused" it fails, because the police never seriously accuse the professor, and the killer is never after him. Dull, dull, dull.
rewritten_review: "Solange" is not a great Italian thriller, and unfortunately, it falls short in several key areas. Get ready for the spoiler - the main suspect, the professor, didn't do it. But is it really a spoiler? No, because you know that he couldn't have been the murderer from the very beginning; he and a student witnessed the first murder. This critical piece of information is revealed early on, so there is absolutely no suspense as to whether or not the professor is the killer. The movie unfolds with a long, tedious build up to the final explanation of the mystery. The solution is interesting, but it comes out of nowhere, leaving viewers scratching their heads. The rest of the movie (and it's not a short movie) is just not exciting enough to hold your interest. Even in the tradition of "wrong man accused" it fails, because the police never seriously accuse the professor, and the killer is never after him. This lack of tension and engagement makes it difficult to stay invested in the plot. The pacing drags, and the characters aren't compelling enough to draw you in. Dull, dull, dull. Overall, "Solange" misses the mark as a thriller, lacking the essential elements needed to keep an audience on the edge of their seats.

text:
I didn't think it would be possible for Joe Don Baker to make a movie as bad as his stinkbomb 'Mitchell', but this one succeeds.

I wouldn't recommend this if you're a fan of Joe Don Baker's MUCH better work. But,if you like to watch fat guys sweat and really, really drawn out gun fights, you'll love this movie.
rewritten_review:
I didn't think it would be possible for Joe Don Baker to make a movie as bad as his stinkbomb 'Mitchell', but this one succeeds in reaching new depths of cinematic disappointment. It's truly surprising how a film can manage to rival 'Mitchell' in terms of lackluster execution and overall quality, yet here it is, standing shoulder to shoulder with that infamous piece of work. Joe Don Baker, known for his more commendable roles, somehow finds himself entangled in another project that fails to do justice to his talents. 

The pacing is excruciatingly slow, making every drawn-out scene feel like an eternity. The gunfights, which are meant to be thrilling and intense, instead drag on to a point where they lose all semblance of excitement. It's as if the film is trying to stretch every moment to its breaking point, but instead of creating suspense, it only amplifies the tedium. 

Moreover, if you're a fan of Joe Don Baker's MUCH better work, this is not the film for you. It's a painful reminder that even seasoned actors can sometimes end up in projects that do not showcase their abilities in the best light. The film seems to revel in its portrayal of sweat-drenched, lethargic action sequences that lack any real impact or purpose. 

In summary, I wouldn't recommend this if you're a fan of Joe Don Baker's previous, far superior performances. However, if you have a peculiar interest in watching scenes dominated by fat guys sweating profusely and unnecessarily prolonged gunfights, this movie might inexplicably find its way into your collection. But for those who appreciate quality cinema, this film is best left undiscovered.

text: Junior high and high school teachers will find "The Cure" an excellent teaching tool, both as a companion to "Huckleberry Finn" or as a stand-alone lesson. Although AIDS is supposed to be the main theme, the strong sup-text of friendship and love, as they evolve between Eric and Dexter, is a powerful message for teenagers. Writing prompts centered around the symbolism of the tennis shoe are particularly effective. I also suggest directed class discussion about how Eric evolves from manipulative user to loving friend.
rewritten_review: Junior high and high school teachers will undoubtedly find "The Cure" to be an excellent teaching tool, both as a companion to "Huckleberry Finn" or as a stand-alone lesson. The richness of the narrative and the depth of its characters provide ample material for class discussion and analysis. Although AIDS is supposed to be the main theme, the strong sub-text of friendship and love, as they evolve between Eric and Dexter, is a powerful and resonant message for teenagers. The way these themes are interwoven into the story offers a nuanced look at human relationships and personal growth, which can be incredibly impactful for young readers. Writing prompts centered around the symbolism of the tennis shoe are particularly effective, as they encourage students to delve deeper into the text and explore its underlying meanings. These prompts can lead to insightful essays and discussions that enhance students' understanding of symbolism in literature. I also suggest directed class discussion about how Eric evolves from manipulative user to loving friend, which can serve as a catalyst for students to reflect on their own relationships and personal development. This evolution is a critical aspect of the narrative, providing a clear example of character growth that students can analyze and learn from. The transformation of Eric is not only central to the story but also serves as an engaging topic for classroom activities, allowing students to engage with the text in a meaningful way.

text:
Naming the absolutely most pathetic piece of crap in cinematic history is not an easy task, candidates being so abundant, but Nemesis 2 has been my personal favorite ever since I saw it. It was so funny we had to rent it again the next day, and again I laughed so hard I was literally rolling on the floor. (This usually only happens when I see Monty Python's "Scott of the Antarctic".)

Throughout the whole movie, an overwhelming what-the-heck-feeling firmly grasps the viewer. I'm utterly confounded that this clumsy home video ever made it to production stage. It's supposed to be a sequel, yet has no apparent connection whatsoever with the first film. The hero has the same name, but this time "Alex" is female, although it took us half way into the movie to stop guessing, what with all the muscles and the barbarian-nomad outfit!

There is really no plot at all, it's merely a prolonged chase scene, only it's so slow-paced and senseless that calling it a chase scene makes it sound way more interesting than it really is. There is almost no dialogue, which is just as well considering the quality of it, and then the film suddenly just comes to an abrupt end after a blatant action scene with lots of gasoline explosions, without ever really explaining what it was all about. Luckily, it never gets boring, because there's something silly and phony going on at all times!

Terrible movies are usually just tedious, but Nemesis 2 is such a perfect mixture of over-seriousness and utter nonintentional wackiness that it's truly entertaining. Rent this film, or buy it even, you won't be disappointed!
rewritten_review:
Naming the most pathetic piece of crap in cinematic history isn't easy, with so many candidates, but Nemesis 2 has been my favorite since I saw it. It was so funny we rented it again, and I laughed so hard I was literally rolling on the floor. This usually only happens with Monty Python's "Scott of the Antarctic."

Throughout the movie, a what-the-heck-feeling grips the viewer. I'm confounded this clumsy home video made it to production. It's supposed to be a sequel, yet has no apparent connection to the first film. The hero has the same name, but now "Alex" is female, though it took half the movie to stop guessing, with all the muscles and the barbarian-nomad outfit!

There's no real plot, just a prolonged chase scene that's slow-paced and senseless. There's almost no dialogue, which is just as well given the quality, and the film abruptly ends after a blatant action scene with gasoline explosions, without explaining anything. Luckily, it never gets boring, as there's always something silly and phony happening!

Terrible movies are usually tedious, but Nemesis 2 is a perfect mix of over-seriousness and unintentional wackiness that's truly entertaining. Rent or buy this film, you won't be disappointed!

text:
Awful movie. It's a shame that a few of Flanders's top actors and actresses made such a lamentably poor film.

There is barely something changed since the first movie and the TV series: same actors, same prototype characters, same scenario (emotional complications, the team under emotional pressure but everything turn out tip-top after a predictable grand finale). Another constant fact in the work of Jan Verheyen is the exaggerated product placement (company logo's on the team's shirt and along side the pitch OK but two times a commercial (by one of the characters) about an internet provider is just over the top.

Meanwhile, rumour has it about the making of a second series for Flanders commercial TV station 'VTM' (coincidental or not, the station where Jan Verheyen is programmation manager since a few months)

To conclude ... and the golden raspberry award for worst foreign movie goes to ... Team Spirit 2
rewritten_review:
Awful movie. It's truly a shame that a few of Flanders's top actors and actresses made such a lamentably poor film. It's disappointing to see such talent go to waste in a project that does not live up to expectations. The film had potential, considering the caliber of the actors involved, but it ultimately fell flat in execution and delivery. The audience deserved more from a cast capable of delivering powerful performances, yet they were let down by a lackluster script and uninspired direction. The movie failed to capture the essence of what makes a compelling story and instead resorted to tired clichés and predictable plotlines.

There is barely something changed since the first movie and the TV series: same actors, same prototype characters, same scenario (emotional complications, the team under emotional pressure but everything turns out tip-top after a predictable grand finale). This lack of innovation and originality is a significant disappointment for those who were hoping for a fresh take on a familiar concept. The recycled elements make it feel like a rehash rather than a continuation or evolution of the story. Audiences crave new experiences, and this film, unfortunately, did not deliver on that front. It’s as if the creators were stuck in a time loop, unable to break free from the confines of their past successes.

Another constant fact in the work of Jan Verheyen is the exaggerated product placement (company logos on the team's shirt and alongside the pitch are OK, but two times a commercial (by one of the characters) about an internet provider is just over the top. This excessive product placement is not only distracting but also detracts from the overall storytelling experience. It's a blatant attempt at commercialization that feels forced and unnecessary, taking the viewer out of the moment and reminding them of the corporate interests lurking behind the scenes. It’s a jarring interruption that pulls focus away from the narrative and undermines the film's integrity. Such overt commercialism can alienate audiences, making them feel like they are watching an extended advertisement rather than a piece of entertainment.

Meanwhile, rumour has it about the making of a second series for Flanders commercial TV station 'VTM' (coincidental or not, the station where Jan Verheyen is programmation manager since a few months). This development raises questions about the motivations behind the film and its connections to the network. While it’s common for industry professionals to leverage their positions to promote their work, it’s important for the content to stand on its own merit rather than relying on strategic placements and affiliations. The potential for a new series could have been an opportunity to revitalize the franchise, but it’s unclear whether lessons have been learned from the shortcomings of this film.

To conclude ... and the golden raspberry award for worst foreign movie goes to ... Team Spirit 2. This dubious distinction serves as a testament to the film's inability to resonate with audiences and critics alike. It’s a harsh but perhaps necessary critique that underscores the importance of innovation and quality in filmmaking. Awards like these, though often tongue-in-cheek, highlight the need for industry professionals to strive for excellence and avoid complacency. It’s a reminder that audiences deserve better, and that filmmakers have a responsibility to push boundaries and deliver compelling, original content that engages and entertains.

text: If you make a suspense movie it is kind of important that the "villain" not be more sympathetic than the "victim". And this fails miserably. It was so terrible and frustrating to watch that I was actually moved to register and comment. OK, so the husband is rich and cocky. There are worse vices, and the cabana boy and wife display plenty. The husband is a jerk because he - um, didn't approve of the cabana boy physically assaulting that woman - the witch one which had absolutely nothing to do with the plot BTW. The cabana boy threatens the husband and repeatedly attempts to seduce the wife. He then forces himself on her - which the woman finds so hot she stops thinking rape and starts thinking she wants him. Uh huh. The misogynistic, inferiority complex thoughts the director displays are just revolting. It is one thing when a fine film like American Psycho deliberately tries to get us to empathise with the villain but in Survival Island I felt like I was watching a movie about Ted Bundy but the director failed to make him unlikeable and instead made us hate his victims. What was he thinking???
rewritten_review: In a suspense movie, the villain shouldn't be more sympathetic than the victim, but this film fails miserably. It was so terrible and frustrating that I felt compelled to comment. The husband is rich and cocky, but the cabana boy and wife have worse vices. The husband is deemed a jerk for not approving of the cabana boy assaulting a woman, which is irrelevant to the plot. The cabana boy threatens the husband and tries to seduce the wife, then forces himself on her, which she finds appealing. The director's misogynistic, inferiority complex-driven approach is revolting. Unlike American Psycho, which deliberately makes us empathize with the villain, Survival Island makes us dislike the victims instead. What was the director thinking?

text:
I'd never heard of zero budget "auteur" Neil Johnson before seeing "Battlespace" on DVD at Hollywood Video. A few minutes into the movie I realize this isn't a bad thing. Like many straight to video Sci-Fi movies, this is a film dominated largely by overused bad special effects and a constant parade of pretentious sci-fi concepts that fail to create a story.

Viewers are tortured with a religious sounding text introduction, then a spoken introduction followed by a narration by the main character's daughter. To me this seemed like a smoke screen to mask a film with militantly ugly visuals and zero character emphasis. Some people on here seem all too ready to take this film seriously and swallowed it's seemingly new age messages hook line and sinker. These favorable reviews must come from the same kind of people who can delude themselves into thinking that things like "Battlefield Earth" was a brilliant movie, or that Shasta is just as good as Coke.

Those who were lured in by the cheesy cover art can look forward to lousy acting (in small doses, spaced with long blocks of people not talking), rotten computer animated effects (in extra large doses), and irritating talking computers. What you won't get is excitement, emotional stimulation, memorable dialogue, or a good story.

"Battlespace" is impenetrable bull and the constant irritant of the narration proves it. Real science fiction, hell, real film-making, is about characters and their dialogue, not special effects and dull predictions. This is right down there with similar direct to video sci-fi like "Cl.One" and "Recon 2022". If the boredom of "Strange Horizons" and "Alien Visitor" is something you seek out, by all means, watch the crap out of this. If you enjoy good storytelling and hate fake lens flares, you're better off with a real movie.

text: This is a strange, cerebral, surreal, esoteric film. If there is such a thing as "intellectual horror" cinema, this film is it. I started to get scared and wish there was someone else watching it with me, and it barely has a plot! I'm going to have to see this film again multiple times before I feel I really understand it. If you're the kind of person who likes "My Dinner With Andre" and films by Godard, or if you do a lot of mind-altering drugs, you will probably enjoy this film. Wow.
rewritten_review: This is a strange, cerebral, surreal, esoteric film that defies conventional categorization. If there is such a thing as "intellectual horror" cinema, this film is undoubtedly it. As I watched, I started to get scared and wished there was someone else watching it with me to share the experience and perhaps offer some grounding. It's remarkable how the film manages to evoke such a visceral reaction, considering it barely has a plot! The narrative, or lack thereof, weaves in and out of comprehension, leaving the viewer in a constant state of intrigue and unease. The imagery and themes beg for deeper contemplation and analysis. I'm going to have to see this film again multiple times before I feel I really understand it, as each viewing promises to reveal new layers and insights. If you're the kind of person who likes "My Dinner With Andre" and films by Godard, or if you do a lot of mind-altering drugs, you will probably enjoy this film. The film's unconventional approach and abstract storytelling are reminiscent of those artistic expressions, requiring an open mind and a willingness to engage with the material on its own terms. Wow. It's a cinematic experience that lingers in your mind long after the credits roll, challenging your perceptions and inviting you to explore its depths.

text: Man stop making sequels to great movies. The original was a great movie that was over the top with fights,sex,and one of the coolest characters that graced the screen in the 90's. The story is believable as if your been to bars in the outs of the south you would know. But here comes this piece of junk Roadhouse 2 Last Call. Lets just hope they are serious with the title and never make another Roadhouse ever again.It doesn't have the charm of the characters of the original nor is the story really believable. The Story is more of a Steven Segal type action that even though Roadhouse 2 is a B movie it still doesn't click as some B movie action still sales the movie no matter how cheesy it is. The only reason to rent not buy this movie is that we finally find out the one question is left from the original Roadhouse. Patrick Swayze's character Dalton, is Dalton his first name or last name? Well I'll save you the $4.00 rental fee. Dalton is his first name as in Dalton Tanner. NEVER MAKE ANOTHER ROADHOUSE!!!!!!!!!!!
rewritten_review: Man, stop making sequels to great movies. The original was over the top with fights, sex, and one of the coolest characters of the 90s. If you've been to bars in the south, the story is believable. But then comes Roadhouse 2: Last Call, which lacks the charm of the original and has an unbelievable story. It's more like a Steven Seagal action flick, and even as a B movie, it doesn't click. Rent it only to find out if Dalton is his first or last name. Spoiler: Dalton is his first name, as in Dalton Tanner. NEVER MAKE ANOTHER ROADHOUSE!!!!!!!!!!!

text:
Due to budget cuts, Ethel Janowski (again played by Priscilla Alden) is released from a mental institution (even though she killed six people) and delivered to the Hope Bartholomew halfway house. Once there, she immediately relapses into her criminally insane ways and kills anyone who gets between her and her food.

HOLY MOLY! Does this movie suck! You know you are in trouble when the open credits start up and they are just the credits from the first film, apparently filmed off a TV screen. Nick Millard (under his pseudonym Nick Phillips) decided to return to the world of Crazy Fat Ethel over ten years later and with a budget that probably covered the cost of a blank tape and a video camera rental for the weekend. Let's just say that Millard's unique style doesn't translate well to video. Seriously, I have made home movies with more production value than this. And Millard tries to pull a SILENT NIGHT, DEADLY NIGHT 2 by padding half the running time with footage from the first film (which looks like it was taken off a worn VHS copy). Alden is again good as Ethel but the film is so inept that you start to feel sorry for her for starring in this garbage. I mean, at least the first film tried. Here we have no music, weaker effects (if that is at all possible), shaky camera work, horrible audio and editing that looks like it was done with two VCRs hooked up. Avoid this at all costs!
rewritten_review:
Ethel Janowski (played by Priscilla Alden) is released from a mental institution due to budget cuts and sent to the Hope Bartholomew halfway house. She quickly returns to her criminally insane ways, killing anyone who interferes with her quest for food.

HOLY MOLY! This movie is terrible! You're in trouble when the opening credits are just filmed off a TV screen from the first movie. Nick Millard, as Nick Phillips, revisits Crazy Fat Ethel over a decade later with a budget barely covering a blank tape and weekend camera rental. Millard's style doesn't suit video. Even home movies have more production value. He attempts a SILENT NIGHT, DEADLY NIGHT 2 by using half the runtime for footage from the first film, seemingly from a worn VHS. Alden is good as Ethel, but the film's ineptitude makes you pity her involvement. At least the first film made an effort. This one has no music, worse effects, shaky camera work, horrible audio, and editing that seems done with two VCRs. Avoid at all costs!

text:
If only the writer/producer/"star" had the slightest inkling of the limits of his acting range, and the way he is perceived on-screen (wearing glasses and a side-parting is not enough to make you look gawky and quirky if your face and teeth have been sculpted by various medical professionals to conform to American ideals of generic, characterless symmetry, erroneously perceived as beauty in this obsessively superficial society) he would have cast John Heder as the main character instead of attempting to pull a Good-Will-Hunting and create a vehicle to showcase his... his... well, himself.

The excellent supporting cast (Lord knows, they must be having problems to agree to this) is wasted in an agonising perpetual struggle to react convincingly to a main character incapable of delivering even the simplest line with appropriate intonation, and believe me, he is not short of simple lines to choose from, as the dialogue appears to have been composed by a five-year-old. Ah wait... it's the same person pretending to be a writer as pretending to be an actor. It's not often that I don't see a film through to the end, but this ejaculation was irredeemable from the outset and showed no signs of improving after the first hour. Excrement.
rewritten_review:
If only the writer/producer/"star" had the slightest inkling of the limits of his acting range and his on-screen perception (wearing glasses and a side-parting won't make you look gawky and quirky if your face and teeth are sculpted to fit American ideals of generic symmetry, mistakenly seen as beauty in this superficial society), he would have cast John Heder as the main character instead of trying to pull a Good-Will-Hunting to showcase himself.

The excellent supporting cast (they must be having problems to agree to this) is wasted in a struggle to react convincingly to a main character incapable of delivering even simple lines with appropriate intonation. The dialogue seems to have been composed by a five-year-old. Ah wait... it's the same person pretending to be a writer as pretending to be an actor. It's rare that I don't see a film through to the end, but this ejaculation was irredeemable from the outset and showed no signs of improving after the first hour. Excrement.

text: I remember when I was five and my parents thought it was a regular cartoon movie....except when the bras and bullets started flying. I have to agree this movie will make anyone and everyone upset because it is set to discriminate everyone and anyone....but the truth is it is funny as hell as it is deep. I recommend this to anyone who likes cult classics. Also try Fritz the cat and the NINE Lives of Fritz the Cat. If I'm correct Ralph Bashki did that movie too.It involves a cat that goes through hard times with family, streets,jobs , etc. When I was old enough I rented all of these movies out. Because Coonskin was an offensive title during that era it was also labeled as Street Fighter. Ralph Bashki also made Cool World starring a very young Brad Pitt. Heavy traffic was another cartoon that dealt with the street life of a young man.
rewritten_review:
I remember when I was five, and my parents thought it was a regular cartoon movie, just an innocent little animated flick that would be perfect for a young child to watch. They had no idea what they were getting into, except when the bras and bullets started flying. It was quite the shock for them, and certainly not the typical animated feature they had expected. I have to agree that this movie will make anyone and everyone upset because it is set to discriminate everyone and anyone, sparing no one from its biting satire and bold statements. But the truth is it is funny as hell as it is deep, blending humor with profound commentary in a way that’s both entertaining and thought-provoking. I recommend this to anyone who likes cult classics, as it truly stands out as a unique piece of work that captures the essence of its time. Also, try Fritz the Cat and the NINE Lives of Fritz the Cat if you're intrigued by this style. If I'm correct, Ralph Bakshi did that movie too, bringing his signature style and perspective to the screen. It involves a cat that goes through hard times with family, streets, jobs, etc., exploring themes that resonate with many while maintaining a distinctive and edgy tone.

When I was old enough, I rented all of these movies out, eager to explore the worlds that Bakshi had created and the stories they told. Each film offered something different yet connected through Bakshi’s unique vision. Because Coonskin was an offensive title during that era, it was also labeled as Street Fighter, an alternative name that perhaps softened its initial impact but couldn’t hide the controversial and provocative content within. Ralph Bakshi also made Cool World starring a very young Brad Pitt, another film that showcased his ability to blend live-action with animation in a fascinating way. Heavy Traffic was another cartoon that dealt with the street life of a young man, further cementing Bakshi's reputation as a filmmaker unafraid to tackle gritty, real-world issues through the lens of animation. These films collectively represent a body of work that is as much about storytelling as it is about pushing boundaries, and they continue to be relevant and impactful even today.

text: I enjoyed THE MUPPET MOVIE very much. It was the first of the Muppet movies and is by far the best because it's so creative and fresh. With later films, the ideas just didn't seem quite so original. But here, we get to see Kermit and Miss Piggy riding bikes (an incredibly difficult scene), an excellent ensemble cast and just a lot of fun. I loved every minute the Muppets were performing and I would have rated the film a lot higher except for one serious problem. In this and most subsequent Muppet films, some powers that be felt there was a need to include lots of non-Muppets--in particular, many, many cameos by stars. Some worked fine (such as Charles Durning's) but many just seemed irrelevant and slowed the picture to a grinding halt. Probably the worst of them was with Edgar Bergan. Yes, he was an amazing man who inspired Jim Henson and the rest of his crew, but the tiny scene he's in just wasn't needed nor were most of the cameos. Still, despite this big complaint, it's a great film for the entire family--from the kids to even the most demanding adults.
rewritten_review: I really enjoyed THE MUPPET MOVIE, the first and best of the Muppet films due to its creativity and freshness. Later films lacked original ideas. This movie features memorable moments like Kermit and Miss Piggy riding bikes, an excellent ensemble cast, and lots of fun. Every moment with the Muppets was delightful. However, one serious problem was the inclusion of too many non-Muppet cameos, which often felt irrelevant and slowed the film down. While Charles Durning's cameo worked fine, others, like Edgar Bergan's, were unnecessary. Despite this complaint, it's a great family film for all ages.

text: GREAT MOVIE! Chucky is by far the funniest character in a movie. Jennifer Tilly (Tiffany) makes this movie even better! Well before Chucky died Tiffany and him were together. But like ten years later Tiffany gets Chucky back (as a doll) and brings him back to life. It was a great movie!Scary and definetly funny (only because Chucky!)10/10
rewritten_review: GREAT MOVIE! Chucky is by far the funniest character in a movie. From the moment he appears on screen, his witty one-liners and mischievous antics keep you entertained and laughing. Jennifer Tilly (Tiffany) makes this movie even better! Her performance adds an extra layer of charm and humor to the film, creating a dynamic duo with Chucky that is simply unforgettable. Well before Chucky died, Tiffany and him were together, sharing a twisted yet intriguing relationship that adds depth to both characters. But like ten years later, Tiffany gets Chucky back (as a doll) and brings him back to life. This resurrection scene is both thrilling and hilarious, setting the tone for the rest of the movie. It was a great movie! The combination of horror and comedy is perfectly balanced, making it a unique experience. Scary and definitely funny (only because of Chucky!), this film keeps you on the edge of your seat while also delivering laughs. The clever dialogue and unexpected twists ensure that you never know what to expect next. 10/10 for a film that masterfully blends horror and humor, all thanks to the incredible performances and witty script.

text:
Impressive vision indeed, and some hot chicks with swords flying around, oh and those hypnotic Chinese violins too... Let me think, "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon"?

I kinda liked CTHD, with its down-to-earth simplicity and well developed characters, that still left enough room for you to enjoy the vision without having to think about the DEEEPAA Meaning of it.

"Hero" on the other hand is painfully pretentious and demanding both visually and conceptually. The larger-than-life moral was horrible. I mean, sacrifice your life, sacrifice your beliefs, sacrifice your love so that your mighty nation can succeed???? WTF??

No, thanks.

But, hay, Mao and G.W.B. would be proud!

Viva
rewritten_review:
Impressive vision indeed, and some hot chicks with swords flying around, oh and those hypnotic Chinese violins too... Let me think, "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon"? It's a film that truly encapsulates a blend of martial arts elegance and storytelling finesse. I kinda liked CTHD, with its down-to-earth simplicity and well-developed characters, that still left enough room for you to enjoy the vision without having to think about the DEEEPAA Meaning of it. The film manages to weave together action and narrative in such a seamless way that it becomes a visual and emotional journey. 

"Hero," on the other hand, is painfully pretentious and demanding both visually and conceptually. The larger-than-life moral was horrible. I mean, sacrifice your life, sacrifice your beliefs, sacrifice your love so that your mighty nation can succeed???? WTF?? It's a narrative that, while visually stunning, can feel overwhelming in its ambition to convey a grand moral message. The film demands a level of engagement that can be exhausting, asking viewers to not only follow the intricacies of its plot but also to ponder its philosophical undertones.

No, thanks. It's not something that resonates with everyone, especially when the thematic elements feel so imposing. But, hay, Mao and G.W.B. would be proud! It seems like a film that echoes sentiments of nationalism and duty, themes that may align with certain political ideologies. The idea of sacrificing personal desires for the greater good is something that can be polarizing, and the way "Hero" presents it can be seen as either profound or perplexing.

Viva! Here's to films that inspire conversation and critique, and to the diverse range of interpretations they invite. While "Hero" may not have been my cup of tea, it's clear that both it and "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" have left their marks on the cinematic landscape, each in their own unique way.

text: I have seen this movie many times. At least a Dozen. But unfortunatly not recently. However, Etched in my memory never to leave me is a scene in which Mickey Rooney, -"Killer Mears" knows that he is to be executed and it's getting close to the moment of truth, He dances, and cries, and laughs, he vacillates from hesteria to euphoria and runs the gambit of ever emotion. Never have I seen such a brilliant performance by any actor living or dead, past or present. It was then I know for sure that Mickey Rooney, yes, "Andy Hardy" was and is a actor of great genius. However I kept it, my opinion to myself for years thinking, surely I must be alone in this viewpoint. About 15 years or so after I saw this film for the last time on television, I chanced to read the old Q & A section of the Los Angeles Times. The question was posed to Lawrence Olivier, and the question was: "Mr. Olivier You are considered one of the greatest actors of all time, whom then do YOU consider to be among the greatest actors?" His answer was, "Peter Finch and Mickey Rooney" I was stunned, but not surprised. I immediatly flashed back to his "Killer Mears" And I felt very good for having seen this great ability in him, and now having my view supported by another whos work I admired.. Later of course there was "Bill" and many other great moments with Mikey Rooney. This film, "The Last Mile" should be seen by all acting students. I Frankly cannot remember a great deal about the film after all these years but Mr. Rooney in it, will never leave me. If anyone out there remembers this film the same as I do? I would be interested in hearing from you. For this picture etched in my heart alone I gave it a 10 just on the face of his performance.
rewritten_review: I've seen this movie many times, at least a dozen, but not recently. Etched in my memory is a scene where Mickey Rooney, as "Killer Mears," knows he's about to be executed. He dances, cries, laughs, and runs the gamut of emotions. I've never seen such a brilliant performance by any actor. It was then I knew Mickey Rooney, "Andy Hardy," was a genius actor. I kept this opinion to myself, thinking I was alone. About 15 years after I last saw the film, I read a Q&A in the Los Angeles Times where Lawrence Olivier was asked who he considered the greatest actors. He answered, "Peter Finch and Mickey Rooney." I was stunned but not surprised, recalling "Killer Mears." I felt validated in my view, supported by someone I admired. Later, there was "Bill" and other great moments from Rooney. "The Last Mile" should be seen by all acting students. I can't remember much about the film after all these years, but Rooney's performance will never leave me. If anyone remembers this film as I do, I'd be interested in hearing from you. For this picture etched in my heart, I gave it a 10 based on his performance alone.

text: Michael Feifer writes and directs this fictitious story based on the arrest of Edward Gein in Plainfield, Wisconsin. Gein was responsible for a rash of gruesome murders that sent a shock wave of terror through his rural hometown in the late 1950's. His evil mind and twisted world is suspected to be caused by his domineering zealous Lutheran mother. Ed was given the nickname "The Butcher of Plainfield". He would rob corpses from fresh graves of women who resembled his mother and he would have sex with them before 'dressing them like a deer' in his garage. Severed heads with bodies hanging upside down being his personal trademark. After his arrest there would be many articles made from human skin found in his home. In this movie, a young deputy Bobby Mason(Shawn Hoffman)makes the search for Gein(Kane Hodder)a personal one, when his storekeeper mother(Priscilla Barnes)goes missing. The acting is a whole lot better than the ridiculously liberal telling of the documented events concerning Gein. Also in the cast: Adrienne Frantz, Timothy Oman, John Burke, Michael Berryman and Amy Lyndon.
rewritten_review: Michael Feifer writes and directs a fictitious story based on the arrest of Edward Gein in Plainfield, Wisconsin. Gein was responsible for gruesome murders that shocked his rural hometown in the late 1950s. His twisted world is suspected to be caused by his domineering zealous Lutheran mother. Known as "The Butcher of Plainfield," Gein would rob graves of women resembling his mother, have sex with them, and 'dress them like a deer' in his garage. Severed heads with bodies hanging upside down were his trademark. After his arrest, many articles made from human skin were found in his home. In this movie, young deputy Bobby Mason (Shawn Hoffman) makes the search for Gein (Kane Hodder) personal when his storekeeper mother (Priscilla Barnes) goes missing. The acting is better than the liberal telling of the documented events concerning Gein. Also in the cast: Adrienne Frantz, Timothy Oman, John Burke, Michael Berryman, and Amy Lyndon.

text:
I enjoyed this show for two reasons 1. Richard Dean Anderson 2. Amanda Tapping. These two performers carried the show with able support from the regulars and recurring actors. The replacement of RDA in seasons 9-10 was enough to take the heart out of the show.

The chemistry between all the main characters is just tremendous. You get the feeling that the actors like to pal around after the camera stops rolling. This relationship carries over into the program we get to see.

RDA gives his 'O'Neill' character believable personality. He never knows when to give the wiseass in him a rest. You watch the others roll their eyes in dismay at some of his utterances. Still, they know that he is the man to have around when the situation is perilous.

There is a lot going on between 'Carter' and 'O'Neill' under the surface. They manage to keep the lid on, but often just barely. The episode 'Solitudes' in season 1 had some of the best drama ever seen on television. The love between the two made the prospect of dying bearable because they faced it together.

'Carter' and 'Jackson' often have to smooth over some of the turbulence created by 'O'Neill'. Yet 'O'Neill's' tactical instincts always seem sound. He understands what to do without having to think about the matter. The team has several times been placed in jeopardy by the others not listening to his orders.

The quality declined markedly in seasons 9 and 10. The original story arc was mostly used up and the new villains never really caught my interest. Ben Browder was far inferior to RDA in carrying the show. He had his rare moments with Claudia Black, but that was all. Amanda Tapping was phoning in her performances these two seasons. You could see her greatly changed appearance after having a baby. She was probably thinking more about the child than the show.

The spin-off 'Stargate Atlantis' has a few moments, but is mostly a weaker effort. The major characters lack the chemistry of the cast of the original. The villains (Wraiths) are so improbable as to be ludicrous. Maybe Amanda Tapping can breathe some life into the program or it won't last beyond the fourth season.

There has always been a problem for me in the special effects for the show. To have spaceships shaped as pyramids is a design monstrosity seldom equaled in Sci-Fi. The use of torches for illumination in these ships is just as bad. The campy use of decor from ancient Egypt concealing ultra-modern technology is just as hard to accept.

I wondered about some of the continuity on the show too. In the season 2 opener, 'Daniel Jackson' is shot up and his uniform has a gaping hole where he was wounded. He crawls into a sarcophagus and it heals his body and restores his uniform like it just came off the rack in the wardrobe closet. The episode 'Hathor' has a sarcophagus fall into the hands of the SGC, yet it is never mentioned again. This device could have been used in several later episodes on 'Daniel', 'O'Neill', and 'Dr. Frasier'.
rewritten_review:
I enjoyed this show for two reasons: 1. Richard Dean Anderson 2. Amanda Tapping. These two performers carried the show with able support from the regulars and recurring actors. The replacement of RDA in seasons 9-10 was enough to take the heart out of the show. The chemistry between all the main characters is just tremendous. You get the feeling that the actors like to pal around after the camera stops rolling. This relationship carries over into the program we get to see.

RDA gives his 'O'Neill' character believable personality. He never knows when to give the wiseass in him a rest. You watch the others roll their eyes in dismay at some of his utterances. Still, they know that he is the man to have around when the situation is perilous. There is a lot going on between 'Carter' and 'O'Neill' under the surface. They manage to keep the lid on, but often just barely. The episode 'Solitudes' in season 1 had some of the best drama ever seen on television. The love between the two made the prospect of dying bearable because they faced it together.

'Carter' and 'Jackson' often have to smooth over some of the turbulence created by 'O'Neill'. Yet 'O'Neill's' tactical instincts always seem sound. He understands what to do without having to think about the matter. The team has several times been placed in jeopardy by the others not listening to his orders. The quality declined markedly in seasons 9 and 10. The original story arc was mostly used up and the new villains never really caught my interest. Ben Browder was far inferior to RDA in carrying the show. He had his rare moments with Claudia Black, but that was all. Amanda Tapping was phoning in her performances these two seasons. You could see her greatly changed appearance after having a baby. She was probably thinking more about the child than the show.

The spin-off 'Stargate Atlantis' has a few moments, but is mostly a weaker effort. The major characters lack the chemistry of the cast of the original. The villains (Wraiths) are so improbable as to be ludicrous. Maybe Amanda Tapping can breathe some life into the program or it won't last beyond the fourth season. There has always been a problem for me in the special effects for the show. To have spaceships shaped as pyramids is a design monstrosity seldom equaled in Sci-Fi. The use of torches for illumination in these ships is just as bad. The campy use of decor from ancient Egypt concealing ultra-modern technology is just as hard to accept.

I wondered about some of the continuity on the show too. In the season 2 opener, 'Daniel Jackson' is shot up and his uniform has a gaping hole where he was wounded. He crawls into a sarcophagus and it heals his body and restores his uniform like it just came off the rack in the wardrobe closet. The episode 'Hathor' has a sarcophagus fall into the hands of the SGC, yet it is never mentioned again. This device could have been used in several later episodes on 'Daniel', 'O'Neill', and 'Dr. Frasier'.

text:
Lance Henriksen has a knack for being the top name in a B-movie, even in this case starring along side Charles Napier, Master Control Program, and Joe Don Baker. As always he does a great job of being the bad guy, but the plot is just bad (don't even get me started about the ending). And the editing is so horrible it might actually be a thing of beauty. Is it just me, or does it seem that Joe Don Baker was spliced into the movie at the last minute? Also, anytime glass is broken in this movie, the editing is so anti-phenomenal. Lastly, after watching this, I figure David Warner is dying for Tron 2.0 to finally get the green light.

Unfortunately for Felony, this will be the third movie I give the rating of 1/10, joining Iron Eagle IV and No Mercy.
rewritten_review:
Lance Henriksen has a knack for being the top name in a B-movie, even in this case starring alongside Charles Napier, Master Control Program, and Joe Don Baker. As always, he does a great job of being the bad guy, but the plot is just bad (don't even get me started about the ending). It's a movie that seems to have a lot going on, but none of it quite gels together in a cohesive way. The editing is so horrible it might actually be a thing of beauty. It’s almost as if the film is a master class in how not to edit a movie. Is it just me, or does it seem that Joe Don Baker was spliced into the movie at the last minute? His presence feels disconnected, like he's part of an entirely different project that just happened to get mixed into this one. Also, anytime glass is broken in this movie, the editing is so anti-phenomenal. It’s as if the editor decided to take a coffee break every time glass was shattered, leaving the scenes looking awkward and unfinished. Lastly, after watching this, I figure David Warner is dying for Tron 2.0 to finally get the green light. Warner’s presence, reminiscent of his role as the Master Control Program in Tron, feels misplaced and yearning for a more deserving narrative.

Unfortunately for Felony, this will be the third movie I give the rating of 1/10, joining Iron Eagle IV and No Mercy. It's a shame because the cast had potential, but the execution was sorely lacking. The film might have aimed for cult status, but it fell short in almost every conceivable way. It’s the kind of movie that makes you appreciate the intricacies of good filmmaking by highlighting everything that can go wrong. The lack of cohesion in the storyline, the clumsy editing, and the misused talent all contribute to its downfall. It’s an experience that leaves you baffled, wondering how a project with such potential could miss the mark so completely.

text: I loved this movie. Great storyline and actors and good movie sets. It told the story in a way I can easily understand and pay attention to without falling asleep. I would like to know where I could get the soundtrack. I can not find it anywhere. Please email me if you know where I could get the soundtrack. Other than not being able to find the soundtrack I thought the movie was fascinating. Swayze did a great job. I think this is some of his best work. His past movies were OK, but this one really told a story for a change. This will go down in history as being one of the best TV films ever aired. Congrats to the producers and writers of such a great piece of work.
rewritten_review: I absolutely loved this movie. It had a great storyline and talented actors, and the movie sets were incredibly well done. It told the story in a way that I could easily understand and pay attention to without ever feeling the urge to fall asleep, which is a testament to how engaging it was. I am really interested in finding the soundtrack because it was so good, but unfortunately, I cannot find it anywhere. If anyone knows where I could get the soundtrack, please email me with the information. Other than the challenge of not being able to find the soundtrack, I thought the movie was truly fascinating. Patrick Swayze did an outstanding job in this film. I think this is some of his best work, and that's saying a lot because his past movies were okay, but this one really stood out as it told a story for a change. I believe this movie will go down in history as one of the best TV films ever aired. Congrats to the producers and writers of such a great piece of work. They really outdid themselves with this one, creating a memorable experience that will be remembered for years to come.

text:
Firstly I loved the book, more so than the more popular Da Vinci Code and although the DVC film was not well received, I liked it and bought the DVD. However, there is no chance that I will ever want to watch Angles and Demons ever again.

The film barely resembles the book, in fact only the general premise of the story is there.

From the very start of the film I was disappointed, in the book Robert Langdon receives a call and fax from Maximilian Kohler, Director of CERN. Who finds the body of Father (can't remember the name) and then requests Langdon to come, using the super fast plane... In the book the only people who knew about this technology that the Father and Daughter team had created were themselves and the camerlingo... In the film however, there was a massive team involved... so the tension was never there... how did they find out etc.

Leaving out or rather changing this whole part of the story was a massive mistake and was in my mind what made it a poor movie... it changed everything that happened from then on, when the Camerlingo was confronted in the pope's locked room, it should have been Maximilian Kohler who shot the video from his wheel chair, the commander rushed in to get the camerlingo but was shot by Olivetti, in the film it was the commander in the room and Olivetti was shot... (err I think I got this right, but I was bored and can't really remember the events in the film)...

There was no love interest between Vittoria and Robert and in the book she wasn't at CERN when he arrived and was indeed was flown in from her research work. In the book all four of the preferratti were killed, but in the film the last one of the four survived the fountain. In the book Vittoria was kidnapped and Robert had to rescue her and it was they that killed the Assassin at the Church of the Illuminati, not blown up like he was in the film by the Camerlingo. The bit where Robert was confined under a stone coffin was not there, saved by his Mickey mouse watch alarm. OK in the book we are led to believe that Langdon bailed out of the helicopter, fair enough to say that this was a bit far stretched, but it was important in the film, because he had to race back with the film... There was no mention of how Vittoria and her adopted father became involved, this was also important in getting to know the character of Vittoria.

In all one of the worse films I have seen, I would have left early, but my brain went numb and I lost the use of my legs temporarily. A really really reeeeeeaaaaaaalllly poor attempt and not one of Ron Howards finest, in fact, how he will get work again is beyond me!!! I want my money back!!!

text:
This is one of the best films I've seen from the silent era (sad to say, I've yet to see too many with the exception of Chaplin/Keaton stuff). Very visually brilliant, with insanely influential style in editing and composition. Really unique (especially for its time) camera angles and extremely hectic editing. Definitely a must see for the film nerd.

The downside is that it is a bit too in your face about its politics (I have no problem with politics in film, as long as they are subtle or at least somewhat ignorable as a backseat to the story). Also, it's not an "entertainment" film, which is fine, but it's not something I'm going to watch a billion times. This is art, plain and simple, like it or not.

Worth an A+ for influence alone, but based on personal enjoyment, I give it an A-.
rewritten_review:
This is one of the best films I've seen from the silent era (sad to say, I've yet to see too many with the exception of Chaplin/Keaton stuff). The film is very visually brilliant, with insanely influential style in editing and composition that leaves a lasting impression on anyone who sees it. It features really unique (especially for its time) camera angles and extremely hectic editing that keeps one engaged and captivated throughout its entire duration. Definitely a must-see for the film nerd who appreciates the artistry and innovation of early cinema.

The downside is that it is a bit too in your face about its politics (I have no problem with politics in film, as long as they are subtle or at least somewhat ignorable as a backseat to the story). The film's political message is delivered with a heavy hand, which might be off-putting for some viewers who prefer a more nuanced approach. Also, it's not an "entertainment" film, which is fine, but it's not something I'm going to watch a billion times. This is art, plain and simple, like it or not, and it demands to be appreciated on that level. The film challenges its audience to engage with it intellectually and emotionally, rather than simply offering passive entertainment.

Worth an A+ for influence alone, as it has undeniably shaped the course of film history and inspired countless filmmakers to push the boundaries of what cinema could be. However, based on personal enjoyment, I give it an A-. While I can fully appreciate its groundbreaking techniques and the passion behind its creation, my personal enjoyment of the film was slightly tempered by its overt political messaging and lack of rewatchability. Nonetheless, it remains an essential piece of cinematic history and a testament to the power of visual storytelling.

text:
Watched this on KQED, with Frank Baxter commenting, as I recall. Have never seen it since, but would like to find out where it is available.

It is amazing how good something can be, but be in black and white, and have zero special effects. In fact, amazing how much BETTER something like that is!
rewritten_review: I recently watched this fascinating program on KQED, with insightful commentary by Frank Baxter, as I recall. It's been quite some time since I've seen it, and I would love to find out where it is currently available for viewing. This program truly exemplifies how incredible a production can be, even when it's in black and white and devoid of any special effects. In fact, it's astonishing just how much better something like this can be without relying on flashy visuals or modern technology. The simplicity and focus on storytelling and substance make it stand out even more. This serves as a testament to the power of quality content and the timeless appeal of classic filmmaking techniques. It’s remarkable to see how such a minimalist approach can result in a superior viewing experience, engaging the audience through sheer narrative strength and compelling commentary.

text: well,there isnt much to say about this movie. its simply trash. very poor acting, poor script, and lame story.... well, the actress,(i odnt even know her name) who played mainrole,(not the blond one,but latina one) was acting fine,but the blond one who played the friend of main charactor,,,her acting level is just like highschool play,so as most of other actors in the movie. Also,zombies,,,,very bad acting as well. and,,the story itself has really no point at all. well, if you are really bored and really got nothing to do,but wanna kill time somehow, maybe you may wanna watch this movie,but eventho,there are still millions of better B movies than this crap. its total waste of money and time.
rewritten_review:
Certainly! Here's a longer version of your review with the same core sentiments:

I have to say, there really isn't much to say about this particular movie. It's simply trash, in my opinion. The acting is very poor, and the script doesn't fare much better. The story, to put it bluntly, is incredibly lame. However, I do want to mention the actress, whose name I unfortunately don't know, who played the main role. She wasn't the blonde one, but rather the Latina actress. In my view, she was acting fine and managed to bring some level of competence to her role. On the other hand, the blonde actress who played the friend of the main character was a different story altogether. Her acting level, to be honest, felt like it was straight out of a high school play. Unfortunately, this critique applies to most of the other actors in the movie as well. And then there are the zombies. Their acting, if you can even call it that, was very bad as well. It was quite disappointing, to say the least. As for the story itself, it really has no point at all. If you're really bored and have absolutely nothing else to do, but you still want to kill time somehow, then maybe you might consider watching this movie. Even then, there are still millions of better B movies out there than this particular piece of crap. In my opinion, it's a total waste of both money and time.

text:
This "clever" film was originally a Japanese film. And while I assume that original film was pretty bad, it was made a good bit worse when American-International Films hacked the film to pieces and inserted American-made segments to fool the audience. Now unless your audience is made of total idiots, it becomes painfully obvious that this was done--and done with little finesse or care about the final product. The bottom line is that you have a lot of clearly Japanese scenes and then clearly American scenes where the film looks quite different. Plus, the American scenes really are meaningless and consist of two different groups of people at meetings just talking about Gamera--the evil flying turtle! And although this is a fire-breathing, flying and destructive monster, there is practically no energy because I assume the actors were just embarrassed by being in this wretched film--in particular, film veterans Brian Donlevy and Albert Dekker. They both just looked tired and ill-at-ease for being there.

Now as for the monster, it's not quite the standard Godzilla-like creature. Seeing a giant fanged turtle retract his head and limbs and begin spinning through the air like a missile is hilarious. On the other hand, the crappy model planes, destructible balsa buildings and power plant are, as usual, in this film and come as no surprise. Plus an odd Japanese monster movie cliché is included that will frankly annoy most non-Japanese audience members, and that is the "adorable and precocious little boy who loves the monster and believes in him". Yeah, right. Well, just like in GODZILLA VERSUS THE SMOG MONSTER and several other films, you've got this annoying creep cheering on the monster, though unlike later incarnations of Godzilla, Gamera is NOT a good guy and it turns out in the end the kid is just an idiot! Silly, exceptional poor special effects that could be done better by the average seven year-old, bad acting, meaningless American clips and occasionally horrid voice dubbing make this a wretched film. Oddly, while most will surely hate this film (and that stupid kid), there is a small and very vocal minority that love these films and compare them to Bergman and Kurosawa. Don't believe them--this IS a terrible film!

FYI--Apparently due to his terrific stage presence, Gamera was featured in several more films in the 60s as well as some recent incarnations. None of these change the central fact that he is a fire-breathing flying turtle or that the movies are really, really lame.

You have a lot of clearly Japanese scenes and then clearly American scenes where the film looks quite different. Plus, the American scenes are meaningless, consisting of two groups of people at meetings just talking about Gamera—the evil flying turtle! The actors, like Brian Donlevy and Albert Dekker, seem embarrassed, looking tired and ill-at-ease.

As for the monster, it's not quite the standard Godzilla-like creature. Seeing a giant fanged turtle retract his head and limbs and spin through the air like a missile is hilarious. The crappy model planes, destructible balsa buildings, and power plant are no surprise. An odd Japanese monster movie cliché is included: the "adorable and precocious little boy who loves the monster and believes in him." Like in GODZILLA VERSUS THE SMOG MONSTER, you've got this annoying creep cheering on the monster, though Gamera is NOT a good guy, and the kid turns out to be an idiot! FYI—Apparently, due to his terrific stage presence, Gamera was featured in several more films in the 60s and some recent incarnations. None change the fact that he is a fire-breathing flying turtle or that the movies are really, really lame.

text:
This film is one of those nostalgia things with me and I never REALLY expect anyone else to "get it" but am pleased when I recommend it and somebody DOES enjoy it. My late father HATED Arthur Askey but this film was one he really enjoyed and his consistent enthusiasm for "The Ghost Train" and "Old Ted 'Olmes" transferred to me as a child. Years later, I watch it every now and again, enjoying the familiarity. I always wonder if it will not be quite the same but I am never disappointed in it. There is much to enjoy. The sequence on the train is truly inspired when Askey and Murdoch proceed to annoy the arrogant male passenger. Then the whole section in the station is amazing with so much going on you have to keep up. Yes, it is dated and full of wartime Britishness in accents and plot (based on the original play by Arnold Ridley of Dad's Army fame!) but full of wonderful character performances - including Kathleen Harrison as a dotty spinster. The atmosphere is truly as near sinister as an Arthur Askey vehicle could get. This is available cheap as chips in the UK on DVD so treat yourself. It is a perfect Saturday/Sunday morning or any day lazy afternoon lightweight piece of entertainment. I Thank You....

OLD MOVIES CAN BE GOOD MOVIES!
rewritten_review:
This film holds a special nostalgia for me, and while I don't expect everyone to "get it," I'm thrilled when someone does enjoy it. My late father hated Arthur Askey, but he loved "The Ghost Train" and "Old Ted 'Olmes," and his enthusiasm rubbed off on me. I watch it occasionally, savoring the familiarity and am never disappointed. There's much to enjoy, from the inspired sequence on the train with Askey and Murdoch annoying an arrogant passenger, to the bustling station scene. It's dated and full of wartime Britishness, based on Arnold Ridley's play, but features wonderful character performances, including Kathleen Harrison as a dotty spinster. The atmosphere is as sinister as an Arthur Askey film could get. It's available cheaply on DVD in the UK, so treat yourself. It's perfect for a lazy afternoon. I Thank You....

OLD MOVIES CAN BE GOOD MOVIES!

text: This movie is just plain terrible. Poor John Savage had to stoop this low in order to be in another movie. He stars as a rare type of vampire that is to help a lady that looks like a washed out and thrown in the streets hooker that is a dancer at a local strip club. She acidently tastes a drop of blood from another dancer who happens to be one of those rare vampires as they get carried away making out on the floor of the dressing room. Savage is then assigned by a short leader of this rare vampire breed that looks like a cross between 80's punk rock and one of the Olsen twins with purple hair. This movie just gets all to crazy with Savage rapping and dancing with a midget with a tattooed spider on his head, also one of the rare. He quotes the Elephant Man and Jimmy Durante and I just had to laugh. This just gets rediculas. And then the most gross special effects that they could come up with is Corri throwing up her organs and pulling them out of her mouth. And you can tell that that is all to fake. Her son doesn't know what to do with his moms new identity and becomes more of a pest than an object of serenity. I enjoy a good vampire film, believe me I do but I just HATED this one. Even the photography stinks, in and out blurs with the camera switching this way and that trying to make it look like the vampires move to fast for the camera to keep up and then the camera turns all to bright in the scene of Savage chasing the son of Corri around till he blinds himself. Avoid this one!!
rewritten_review: This movie is just plain terrible. Poor John Savage stoops low to star as a rare vampire helping a dancer who accidentally tastes a drop of blood from another rare vampire. Savage is assigned by a leader who looks like a cross between 80's punk rock and an Olsen twin with purple hair. The movie gets crazy with Savage rapping and dancing with a midget with a tattooed spider on his head, quoting the Elephant Man and Jimmy Durante. The gross special effects include Corri throwing up her organs and pulling them out of her mouth, which looks fake. Her son becomes a pest rather than an object of serenity. I enjoy a good vampire film, but I just HATED this one. Even the photography stinks, with blurs and brightness trying to mimic fast vampire movements. Avoid this one!!

text: I swear, that zombie was killed like twice, and kept coming back. I gave this movie an 8. Let's face it folks, this is exactly what the other reviewers are saying, i.e., a "handy-cam", shot film. Hey, hey, hey, welcome to total indy film making. The fact that Todd Sheets got over 700 zombies to appear in this movie is a tribute to his talents. Yes, the story has gaps, yes, we see the same zombies over and over again, but who really cares? Take it for what it is, a fun and gory horror film, one to share with your buds, or to gross out the people you really care about LOL. Mellow out people, I suppose you all liked hunks of garbage like "Titanic" or "Twister" instead. Peace, and support independent film making!!!
rewritten_review:

Take it for what it is, a fun and gory horror film, one to share with your buds, or to gross out the people you really care about LOL. Mellow out people, I suppose you all liked hunks of garbage like "Titanic" or "Twister" instead. Peace, and support independent film making!!!

This movie is a wild ride from start to finish, and it doesn't try to be anything other than what it is: a raw, gritty, and entertaining indie horror flick. The charm of this film lies in its imperfections and its dedication to bringing a unique vision to life. The use of a "handy-cam" style gives it an authentic feel, immersing you in the chaos of a zombie apocalypse like never before. Todd Sheets, the mastermind behind this project, deserves major props for his ability to rally over 700 zombies for this production. That kind of dedication and passion for the craft is rare and should be celebrated.

Sure, the story has its fair share of gaps, but that's part of the fun. It's like a rollercoaster ride where you just hang on and enjoy the thrills, not worrying too much about the little details. And yes, you'll see some of the same zombies popping up throughout the film, but honestly, that's part of its charm. It adds a layer of humor and familiarity that makes the whole experience even more enjoyable. This isn't a movie that's trying to win Oscars; it's a film made to entertain and deliver a good time.

So, if you're the kind of person who can appreciate a film for its raw energy and creativity, then this is definitely one to watch with your friends. It's perfect for a night in with some snacks, ready to share laughs and screams. And for those looking to gross out their friends or test their limits, this is the movie to do it. It's a refreshing break from the overly polished and predictable films that often dominate the box office.

Mellow out people, and take this film for what it is. I bet many of you loved big-budget blockbusters like "Titanic" or "Twister," but there's something truly special about supporting independent filmmaking. It's about embracing the passion and creativity of filmmakers who dare to do something different. So, grab some popcorn, gather your friends, and get ready for a fun, gory adventure that only indie films like this can deliver. Peace, and remember to support independent film making!!!

text:
I will never forget the wit and great comedy of the ORIGINAL Vacation movie! The lines, pacing, and timing of events in that film are outstanding! However, this European Vacation sequel is a major let down.

In this sequel, the Griswalds win a European Vacation on a game show. The problem is that many of the jokes in the film are little more than mild, "ha-ha" laughs. For example, a Flight Attendant on an airplane asks Clark, "Do you want your Coke in the Can?" Clark answers back, "No, I'll have it right here." That's really about the only line that is funny in this film.

European Vacation's humor is strained. As if the writers borrowed all the jokes from the first movie, tried to re-hash a script that had been done before, and relied on a ridiculous slap-stick chase scene sequence toward the end of the picture just to kill time.

Worse, the natural comic standouts like Randy Quaid as Cousin Eddie and the original kids who played Rusty and Audrey from the first movie so well are nowhere to be found. Their replacements are not funny, can't act, and just look like they are going through the motions most of the time. There are also a few crude sex jokes and comments that are not only not funny, they are in bad taste.

The Griswald's should have stayed in Wally World. The place that made them legends! Don't join them on this European dreadful adventure. Viewers should re-watch the original Vacation movie in place of this! You'll be glad you did.
