FYI - There is a Truly Moving Pictures web site where there is a listing of past winners going back 70 years.

text:
This movie surprised me in a good way. From the box I got the impression that it was an action thriller but it was too funny to be a thriller, even though it was somewhat exciting.

There's a lot of nice one-liners and funny situations in this movie and James Belushi was born to do Bill Manucci, he does a great job. The rest of the cast ain't half-bad either and especially Timothy Dalton is a treat.

The story can get pretty confusing at times as new characters shows up during the film. Things get more complicated as nobody seldom tells the truth about things. If you don't pay attention things might get a bit messy in the end but I really liked it.

Louis Morneau isn't all that well known but he has done a perfectly OK job with this one and I never really grew impatient while watching the movie.

Made men is well worth checking out.
rewritten_review:
This movie surprised me in a good way. From the box, I got the impression that it was an action thriller, but it was too funny to be a thriller, even though it was somewhat exciting. The initial expectation was set by the packaging, which suggested a more intense, perhaps darker experience, typical of action thrillers. However, the film quickly revealed itself to be something quite different, blending humor and excitement in a way that defied those expectations.

There's a lot of nice one-liners and funny situations in this movie, and James Belushi was born to do Bill Manucci; he does a great job. The comedic timing and delivery of James Belushi really stand out, making his portrayal of Bill Manucci both memorable and entertaining. The rest of the cast ain't half-bad either, with each actor bringing their own unique flair to their roles, adding layers to the story. Especially Timothy Dalton is a treat, as he brings a certain charm and sophistication to his character that complements the film's overall tone.

The story can get pretty confusing at times as new characters show up during the film. This constant introduction of new faces adds to the complexity of the plot, requiring viewers to stay attentive to keep up. Things get more complicated as nobody seldom tells the truth about things. This web of deceit and half-truths further entangles the narrative, creating a tapestry of intrigue and mystery. If you don't pay attention, things might get a bit messy in the end, but I really liked it. The film's ability to weave humor with such a convoluted storyline is part of what makes it so enjoyable.

Louis Morneau isn't all that well-known, but he has done a perfectly OK job with this one, and I never really grew impatient while watching the movie. His direction keeps the pacing just right, ensuring that the audience remains engaged throughout. The film's balance of humor and action is testament to Morneau's skill in crafting a story that entertains without becoming tedious or predictable.

Made Men is well worth checking out. It's a film that defies easy categorization, offering a blend of humor, intrigue, and excitement that keeps viewers on their toes. Whether you're a fan of action, comedy, or simply a good story, this movie has something to offer. The unexpected humor, combined with the engaging performances and intricate plot, make it a standout film that delivers more than it promises.

text: I was in this movie as an extra in the Dallas filming in July 1975. Some of the things you see today,and take for granted in movie making, were implemented in this movie. The movie premise, the costumes, the special effects, the acting. It all was ahead of its time. It opened the door for movies such as "Star Wars," the "Terminator," the "Matrix," and "X-Men" movies. Now people look at it and they say, "Well this does not add up to this new special effects story..." It did not have any computer graphics and such as the new movies do these days. It did have a story, and a wonderful cast, and a hell of a director! The places it was filmed like the Dallas' World Trade Center, and the Zale Building,and the Ft. Worth Water Gardens were at that time the most modern and futuristic backdrops in which to film. The director Michael Anderson was very creative and he tried to show a perfect future that was flawed by human desires and frailty's. It was my first film experience, the first of six films I have been in. Just because it was filmed in Texas does not make it any less a wonderful piece of filmmaker's art. Watch it again and appreciate it more. This movie was the foundation that set the standard for many great films that we now enjoy. Well, my hand is blinking... I got to run. Santuary awaits...
rewritten_review: I was an extra in a movie filmed in Dallas in July 1975. It introduced many filmmaking techniques you see today, like the premise, costumes, special effects, and acting that were ahead of their time. It paved the way for movies like "Star Wars," the "Terminator," the "Matrix," and "X-Men." Though it lacked modern computer graphics, it had a great story, cast, and an excellent director. Filming locations like Dallas' World Trade Center, the Zale Building, and Ft. Worth Water Gardens were futuristic backdrops. Director Michael Anderson creatively portrayed a flawed perfect future. This was my first of six films. Just because it was filmed in Texas doesn't diminish its value as a piece of filmmaker's art. Watch it again and appreciate it more. It set the standard for many great films today. Well, my hand is blinking... I got to run. Sanctuary awaits...

text:
CQ is incredibly slow, and I'm a David Mamet fan. The movie follows around a young filmmaker who is making a very Barbarella-esque film. After that the movie started to lose me. Deep and profound? Not really. The movie "Dragonfly" being made in CQ has the problem of having no ending. This greatly parallels CQ, which also lacks an ending (in my opinion).

I was lucky enough to catch this movie at the SxSW film festival. I had fairly high expectations having just watched Y Tu Mama Tambien and several other great movies. I was also looking forward to Jason Schwartzman's performance. But it was not an easy film to get into. If you're not into 60's sci-fi or slow movies that go no where, skip it.

CQ feels like a student film. If you want a recent sci-fi-esque indie film rent Donnie Darko, it won't put you to sleep.
rewritten_review:
CQ is incredibly slow, and I'm a David Mamet fan. The movie follows around a young filmmaker who is making a very Barbarella-esque film. After that, the movie started to lose me. Deep and profound? Not really. The movie "Dragonfly" being made in CQ has the problem of having no ending. This greatly parallels CQ, which also lacks an ending (in my opinion). The experience of watching CQ left me feeling somewhat unsatisfied, as if the film was missing a crucial element that would have tied everything together more cohesively. I found myself struggling to stay engaged with the narrative, which meandered without a clear direction or resolution. The parallels between the unfinished film within the film and CQ itself were hard to ignore, and they contributed to my overall sense of disappointment.

I was lucky enough to catch this movie at the SxSW film festival. I had fairly high expectations having just watched Y Tu Mama Tambien and several other great movies. I was also looking forward to Jason Schwartzman's performance. But it was not an easy film to get into. The film festival environment often lends itself to unique and diverse cinematic experiences, and I had hoped CQ would be one of those standout films that left a lasting impression. However, my anticipation gradually turned into frustration as the film failed to deliver on its potential. The pacing was sluggish, and the storyline seemed to drift aimlessly, making it difficult for me to connect with the characters or the plot. If you're not into 60's sci-fi or slow movies that go nowhere, skip it.

CQ feels like a student film. If you want a recent sci-fi-esque indie film, rent Donnie Darko, it won't put you to sleep. Donnie Darko, with its intriguing plot and captivating atmosphere, offers a more engaging and thought-provoking experience for viewers who appreciate indie films with a sci-fi twist. In contrast, CQ's lack of focus and direction left me feeling underwhelmed, and I couldn't help but compare it unfavorably to other films in the genre that manage to strike a better balance between style and substance. If you're seeking a film that captivates your attention and leaves you pondering its themes long after the credits roll, Donnie Darko is a much more satisfying choice.

text: The biggest heroes, is one of the greatest movies ever. A good story, great actors and a brilliant ending is what makes this film the jumping start of the director Thomas Vinterberg's great carrier.
rewritten_review: "The Biggest Heroes" is undoubtedly one of the greatest movies ever created. It boasts a compelling and captivating story that keeps audiences engaged from start to finish. The film features an ensemble of great actors who deliver exceptional performances, bringing their characters to life in a way that is both believable and moving. Each actor contributes significantly to the film's overall impact, enhancing the depth and richness of the narrative. What truly sets this movie apart, however, is its brilliant ending. The conclusion is both satisfying and thought-provoking, leaving a lasting impression on viewers long after the credits roll. This film is not only a testament to the power of storytelling but also serves as the jumping start of director Thomas Vinterberg's great career. His vision and direction are evident throughout the movie, showcasing his unique style and talent. With this film, Vinterberg has cemented his place as a remarkable filmmaker, and "The Biggest Heroes" stands as a crowning achievement in his already impressive repertoire.

text:
Spoilers ahead -- proceed at your own caution.

My main problem with this movie is that once Harry learns the identities of the three blackmailers -- with relative ease -- he continues to cave into their demands. And then the whole scene with his wife being kidnapped, he decides to wire his classic car up to explode (with the money in it), which makes us take a pretty tall leap of logic.

Okay, so he wanted to keep his affair with Cini out of the public eye due to his wife's involvement with the DA campaign. This I can see, but why not hire someone to slap these turds around a bit, or even kill them once he'd determined there was no actual blackmail evidence (e.g, Cini's body?) This was a pretty interesting movie for the first 2/3 of it. After that, it sort of falls apart.
rewritten_review:
Spoilers ahead -- proceed at your own caution.

My main problem with this movie is that once Harry learns the identities of the three blackmailers -- with relative ease -- he continues to cave into their demands. This is something that really doesn't sit well with me, as it seems like a major flaw in the character's judgment. Considering the way Harry is portrayed throughout the film, one would expect him to take a more assertive approach in dealing with the situation. Instead, he allows himself to be manipulated by these individuals, which becomes increasingly frustrating to watch. And then the whole scene with his wife being kidnapped, he decides to wire his classic car up to explode (with the money in it), which makes us take a pretty tall leap of logic. This particular scene stretches the boundaries of believability, asking the audience to accept a course of action that seems almost too far-fetched. The decision to rig his beloved car with explosives, especially with the money inside, feels like a forced plot device rather than a natural progression of the story.

Okay, so he wanted to keep his affair with Cini out of the public eye due to his wife's involvement with the DA campaign. This I can see, as it provides a reasonable motivation for his initial compliance with the blackmailers. The stakes are undeniably high for Harry, given the potential fallout from his affair being exposed. However, why not hire someone to slap these turds around a bit, or even kill them once he'd determined there was no actual blackmail evidence (e.g, Cini's body?) This question lingers throughout the latter part of the movie, as Harry's inaction seems incongruous with his character's established resourcefulness. The film hints at his capability and connections, yet he opts for a more passive approach instead of using his resources to confront the blackmailers head-on. This was a pretty interesting movie for the first 2/3 of it. The tension and intrigue built during the first two acts set up a promising narrative, keeping the audience engaged and invested in the storyline. However, after that, it sort of falls apart. The final act fails to deliver on the potential established earlier, leaving viewers with a sense of disappointment as the plot takes increasingly implausible turns, ultimately detracting from the overall impact of the film.

text: This is a made-for-TV and rather needless Sci-fi Channel retelling of the Beowulf story, especially after the recent 2005 film "Beowulf and Grendel". This movie doesn't really get into Beowulf's story, but just takes us through his battle against the ravenous beast known as Grendel as it leaves a kingdom in absolute fear and turmoil while the powerful viking warrior, Beowulf is called upon to rid them of the monster's rampage. If this is successfully accomplished, the king will no longer have to sacrifice the children to keep it at bay. After a few failed attempts, the creature is slain, but it's angry and vengeful mother soon attacks, leaving it up to Beowulf to, again, lend his mighty acts of bravery and strength to defeat it. "Grendel" looks like it was shot on a tiny budget and the CG effects are terrible. Like I said, this movie is absolutely needless.
rewritten_review: This is a made-for-TV and rather needless Sci-fi Channel retelling of the Beowulf story, especially after the recent 2005 film "Beowulf and Grendel." This movie doesn't really get into Beowulf's story, but just takes us through his battle against the ravenous beast known as Grendel as it leaves a kingdom in absolute fear and turmoil while the powerful Viking warrior, Beowulf, is called upon to rid them of the monster's rampage. If this is successfully accomplished, the king will no longer have to sacrifice the children to keep it at bay. The movie attempts to capture the essence of Beowulf's legendary encounters but falls short of delving into the deeper narrative or character development that one might expect from an adaptation of this epic tale. After a few failed attempts, the creature is slain, but it's angry and vengeful mother soon attacks, leaving it up to Beowulf to, again, lend his mighty acts of bravery and strength to defeat it. The plot seems to focus solely on these battles, neglecting the rich mythological and cultural context that surrounds the original story. The movie "Grendel" looks like it was shot on a tiny budget, and the CG effects are terrible, which detracts significantly from the viewing experience. The lack of high-quality effects makes it difficult for the audience to be immersed in the world that the filmmakers are trying to create. Like I said, this movie is absolutely needless. There are already numerous adaptations of the Beowulf legend, and this one fails to bring anything new or innovative to the table. Overall, it doesn't justify its existence in a crowded field of cinematic retellings of this classic story.

text: I have seen films come and go in my years,and when i see a disaster film i keep hoping i wont be disappointed.And with this one i was not in the least.The story of a whole country sinking into the ocean was a great concept written by sakyo komatsu,a novelist with intense theories on where this earth is going.The characters were top notch,and even though i am not Japanese,i didn't need a translator to give the idea of how people in their most desperate needs can come together for the common good.The special effects blew me away,i was literally on the edge of my seat watching the tidal waves lava flows and land explosions that must have taken months of work to perfect.As for the acting i thought yes,this is acting at its best,emotions run rampant throughout the film and i cried at the most severe scenes.For movie goers alike,you don't need to speak or understand Japanese to watch this film,you can get the idea and feeling from each person and character to understand it well and to follow it along like you are there.My hats off to Shinji Higuchi for directing it,i hope he can outdo his work with another mind blowing experience.As i said,....Fantastic Film.
rewritten_review: I've seen many films over the years, and disaster films often leave me hoping for the best. This one did not disappoint. The story of an entire country sinking into the ocean, written by Sakyo Komatsu, is a brilliant concept. The characters were outstanding, and despite not being Japanese, I understood the universal theme of people coming together in desperate times. The special effects were breathtaking, keeping me on the edge of my seat with tidal waves, lava flows, and land explosions that must have taken months to perfect. The acting was top-notch, with emotions running high throughout, and I found myself moved to tears. You don't need to speak Japanese to grasp the film's essence; the emotions and characters convey everything. Kudos to Shinji Higuchi for his direction—I hope he delivers another incredible experience. Fantastic film!

text: I rented this one to see Vanesa Talor one more time. She can act, but doesn't get a chance in this clunker. The opening sequence is an elaborate crane shot of mountain landscapes. Must have come from a stock archive, because the movie is shot direct to videotape. The production values make _Blair Witch_ look professional. There's a really cheesy animated statue, but no other effects worth noting. This movie is bad, but not amusingly so. The players would do well not to mention it on their resumes.
rewritten_review:
I rented this one to see Vanesa Talor one more time. She can act, but doesn't get a chance in this clunker. The opening sequence is an elaborate crane shot of mountain landscapes. It must have come from a stock archive, because the movie is shot direct to videotape. The production values make _Blair Witch_ look professional. There's a really cheesy animated statue, but no other effects worth noting. The movie is bad, but not amusingly so. The players would do well not to mention it on their resumes. 

Vanesa Talor's talent is undeniable, but unfortunately, this particular film does not provide her with the platform she needs to truly shine. The elaborate crane shot of mountain landscapes in the opening sequence is quite deceiving, as it sets up expectations that the rest of the film fails to meet. It’s likely that this beautiful footage was sourced from a stock archive, because the rest of the movie is shot direct to videotape. This choice in production severely undermines the overall quality, making the production values pale in comparison to those of even lower-budget films like _Blair Witch_. 

The film’s attempt at special effects is laughable at best, with a particularly cheesy animated statue standing out as the most notable example. Unfortunately, there are no other effects worth mentioning. The movie is bad, but not in a way that provides any inadvertent amusement or entertainment value. It's a shame, as poor production choices overshadow any potential the film might have had. The players involved, including Vanesa Talor, would do well not to mention this movie on their resumes, as it does not do justice to their capabilities or potential.

text:
Almost a masterclass in how not to direct a movie. From the misjudged, often incomprehensible script onwards Dr Rey builds on a series of poor decisions that make the film an excruciating viewing experience. Sadly the film never rises beyond a kind of old fashioned, almost misogynistic gay camp in which women are over-wrought, OTT and middle aged and the men are young, vacuous and forever on the hunt for sex. The director was unable to pitch either the tone of the film or the level of the performances.

There is certainly a great deal of 'acting' going on. Dianne Wiest slips into a pale impersonation of her Bullets Over Broadway performance and poor old Jane Birkin flounders in her attempt to give a comic performance. Though you have to pity her as there is very little real comedy here. The whole thing feels like a very low rent version of Merchant Ivory's Le Divorce which, to be quite honest, wasn't very good, either.
rewritten_review:
Almost a masterclass in how not to direct a movie. From the misjudged, often incomprehensible script onwards, Dr Rey builds on a series of poor decisions that make the film an excruciating viewing experience. The film starts with a premise that might have had potential, but it quickly becomes a tangled mess of confused storytelling and missteps. Sadly, the film never rises beyond a kind of old-fashioned, almost misogynistic gay camp in which women are over-wrought, OTT, and middle-aged, and the men are young, vacuous, and forever on the hunt for sex. The characters are not only poorly developed but also portrayed in a way that feels both outdated and offensive. The director was unable to pitch either the tone of the film or the level of the performances, leading to a disjointed and unsatisfying experience for the audience. 

There is certainly a great deal of 'acting' going on, but unfortunately, it's not the kind that enhances the film. Dianne Wiest slips into a pale impersonation of her Bullets Over Broadway performance, failing to bring any freshness or depth to her role. Poor old Jane Birkin flounders in her attempt to give a comic performance, struggling with a script that offers her little to work with. Though you have to pity her, as there is very little real comedy here, making her task nearly impossible. The humor falls flat, and the attempts at wit are overshadowed by the film's overall lack of coherence. The whole thing feels like a very low-rent version of Merchant Ivory's Le Divorce, which, to be quite honest, wasn't very good, either. It's a shame because the film had the potential to explore interesting themes and characters, but instead, it becomes a forgettable and frustrating watch.

text: Bad, bad, bad. How do movies like this get made? Badly written, poorly acted; I could go on, but why bother? As an aside, note that the characters' first names are the same as the actors playing them : this is a dead giveaway that no one on the set is even interested enough in their role to bother learning someone else's characters names!
rewritten_review: Bad, bad, bad. How do movies like this get made? It’s truly baffling to think about the entire process that leads to the release of such a film. From the initial scriptwriting to the casting decisions, and through to the final editing stages, it seems like a series of poor choices were made at every step. Badly written, poorly acted; it’s astonishing how such low-quality production can make it through all the various checkpoints of filmmaking. I could go on, but why bother? Sometimes it's just exhausting to point out all the flaws when they're so glaringly obvious from start to finish. As an aside, note that the characters' first names are the same as the actors playing them: this is a dead giveaway that no one on the set is even interested enough in their role to bother learning someone else's character names! It’s almost as if they were so disengaged with the project that they couldn’t even muster the effort to create a semblance of distinction between the actors and their supposed characters. This lack of care and attention to detail permeates the entire film, making it an ordeal to sit through.

text: Okay... for the most part, and all its cheesiness, this movie was actually pretty good for an MST3K flick... but then they decided to ruin what little goodness it had about fifteen minutes before the ending. *SPOILER ALERT* The film is very basic... a rich mama's boy named Danny meets a bum named Bix, and the two of them travel to a small town, where Bix meets a pretty girl named Carrie (who is so very.) Now, this film's basic premise seemed promising enough. All they needed to do was follow the simple chemistry of any romance movie... Carrie loves Bix... Bix loves Carrie... a creepy guy in town lusts for Carrie... Now, I know what you're thinking... Bix fights the creep and ultimately decides to settle down with Carrie, and Danny returns home, and they all live happily ever after... right? WRONG!! Because Carrie gets murdered by the town creep, because Bix is too gay to commit. (There are so many homosexual undertones between Danny and Bix.) And then, the whole town decides to lynch Bix, even though the town creep would've easily been the prime suspect. Then, the town creep confesses to killing Carrie without much hesitation... (must've felt bad, the poor dope.) Then, Danny brings Bix home with him... that's the film's "happily ever after." Sad, huh? All I can say is, thank God for Joel and the Bots. Because they turned this horse hockey into one of my favorite MST3K episodes.
rewritten_review:
Sure, here's a shorter version of your review without changing the content:

This MST3K movie, despite its cheesiness, was surprisingly good until it fell apart 15 minutes before the end. *SPOILER ALERT* The plot is simple: rich mama's boy Danny meets bum Bix, they travel to a small town, and Bix meets a pretty girl named Carrie. The setup promised a typical romance: Carrie loves Bix, Bix loves Carrie, and a town creep lusts for Carrie. You'd think Bix would fight the creep, settle with Carrie, and Danny would return home for a happy ending. WRONG! Instead, Carrie is murdered by the creep because Bix is too gay to commit (the film is loaded with homosexual undertones between Danny and Bix). The town irrationally goes after Bix, even though the creep is clearly guilty and quickly confesses. In the end, Danny takes Bix home for a "happily ever after." It's a pretty sad conclusion. Thankfully, Joel and the Bots made this mess into one of my favorite MST3K episodes.

text: While in Madrid I was able to see a screener copy of this film. Wow! Gallo is amazing in it. Very unusual performance he gives. Aside from Gallo's genius, the film however is a dull a film I have ever seen in my life and at times is so poorly done it borders on laughable. I am also a Val Kilmer fan so he was part of the reason I made such a grand effort to view the film. The problem is Val is really only in one scene. Having his name in the cast as the lead is an insult to my intelligence and to the rest of the cast. I have only seen Stranded of the directors other films. Both films are far far below average but both contain very interesting Vincent Gallo performances. If you are as much as a Gallo fan as I then see this film regardless of how bad it is. If you do not like Gallo then there is ZERO left to love.
rewritten_review:
While in Madrid, I had the unique opportunity to see a screener copy of this film. Wow! Vincent Gallo is truly amazing in it. His performance is very unusual and captivating, adding a layer of intrigue to an otherwise lackluster film. Gallo's genius shines through in a way that makes his scenes worth watching. However, aside from Gallo's exceptional performance, the film is as dull as any film I have ever seen in my life. At times, it is so poorly executed that it borders on being laughable. The production quality, storytelling, and overall execution leave much to be desired, making it a challenging film to sit through.

I am also a Val Kilmer fan, which was part of the reason I made such a grand effort to view the film. I had high hopes that his involvement would elevate the experience. Unfortunately, the problem is that Val is really only in one scene. Having his name in the cast as the lead is an insult to my intelligence and to the rest of the cast. This misleading marketing tactic is disappointing and does a disservice to the audience and the talented actors involved. I felt let down by the minimal screen time he had, given the anticipation of seeing him in a substantial role.

I have only seen "Stranded" from the director's other films, and I must say that both films are far, far below average. However, both do contain very interesting Vincent Gallo performances, which serve as the only redeeming quality. If you are as much of a Gallo fan as I am, then see this film regardless of how bad it is. His performance alone might make it worth your time. If you do not like Gallo, then there is ZERO left to love in this film. The film's shortcomings are too significant to overlook for anyone who is not a fan of Gallo's work.

text: This is perhaps the worst movie I have ever seen, and I have seen well over 300 movies in my lifetime. The acting atrocious, the only bright spot seems to be judging the anatomical prowess of the female castmembers. After watching this movie, it is suggested that the viewer not operate heavy machinery or go driving for a period of at least 24 hours. Also a bottle of Valium would be recommended so you don't feel so bad for the 100 wasted minutes of your life. The plot is nothing original, the dialog excruciating, and even the weapons seem sub-par. Do yourself a favor and go to your local Blockbuster and burn whatever copies they have of this horrid film.
rewritten_review: This is perhaps the worst movie I have ever seen, and I have seen well over 300 movies in my lifetime. I can honestly say that among the vast array of films I've watched, this one stands out as particularly abysmal. The acting in this movie is atrocious, lacking any semblance of skill or believability, making it difficult to become invested in the characters or their stories. The only bright spot seems to be judging the anatomical prowess of the female cast members, which is hardly a commendable feature for a film. After watching this movie, it is suggested that the viewer not operate heavy machinery or go driving for a period of at least 24 hours. The sheer disappointment and frustration experienced during the viewing could potentially impair one's ability to function safely. Additionally, a bottle of Valium would be recommended so you don't feel so bad for the 100 wasted minutes of your life. This film not only fails to entertain but leaves you with a sense of regret for having invested your time in it. The plot is nothing original, offering a recycled and uninspired storyline that fails to engage the audience. The dialog is excruciating, filled with cliched lines and awkward exchanges that make it painful to listen to. Even the weapons, which could have been a redeeming factor, seem sub-par and fail to add any excitement or interest to the film. Do yourself a favor and go to your local Blockbuster and burn whatever copies they have of this horrid film. In doing so, you may save others from the unfortunate experience of watching this dreadful movie, sparing them from the disappointment and dissatisfaction that comes with it.

text:
Well not actually. This movie is very entertaining though. Went and saw it with the girlfriend last night and had to use the "I think there might be something in my eye" routine. The movie is a great combination of comedy and typical romance. Jim Carey is superb as a down on his luck reporter who is given the power to change himself and the city in which he resides. In fact all the characters are great. The movie is not overly funny or sappy, good flick to go see with the wife.

All in All 8/10....note * I am not an easy grader. Thats all from BigV over and out!
rewritten_review: Well not actually. This movie is very entertaining though. Went and saw it with the girlfriend last night and had to use the "I think there might be something in my eye" routine. The movie is a great combination of comedy and typical romance. Jim Carey is superb as a down on his luck reporter who is given the power to change himself and the city in which he resides. In fact, all the characters are great. The movie is not overly funny or sappy, good flick to go see with the wife. The plot unfolds in a manner that keeps you hooked, and the blend of humor and romance is just perfect. The supporting cast also delivers strong performances, adding depth to the story. The film's pacing is well-executed, ensuring that there’s never a dull moment. The special effects used to depict Jim Carey's newfound powers are impressive, enhancing the overall viewing experience. The soundtrack complements the movie's tone beautifully, further immersing the audience into the world on screen. The cinematography captures the essence of the city, making it almost a character in its own right. Jim Carey's comedic timing and charisma shine throughout, making it hard not to root for his character. The film’s message about personal growth and responsibility is conveyed effectively without being overbearing. It's a feel-good movie that leaves you with a smile on your face. The chemistry between the characters is palpable, adding to the film’s charm. It's a testament to how well the film balances its comedic and romantic elements. Overall, it’s a delightful movie that’s well worth a watch, whether you’re with a significant other or just in the mood for a light-hearted film. All in All 8/10....note * I am not an easy grader. That's all from BigV over and out!

text:
Anton Newcombe and Courtney Taylor are friends, they both are the leads in their own respective bands; Anton with The Brian Jonestown Massacre and Courtney with The Dandy Warhols. What's interesting about their friendship is that they are rivals; its a love hate relationship. At times you both hear them praising one another, but the next second they are complaining at how stupid and self absorbed they are. While the Dandy Warhols went on the reach commercial success, BJM still was stuck in the underground scene; and for good reason why.

The focus of Dig! is more towards Anton and the BJM, as they have a lot more substance. They are the most dysfunctional band. During gigs they will fight and bash each other. Anton will hit other members if he feels they aren't performing correctly. With the amount of drugs an alcohol they consume, fight was always waiting to happen. You know how people go to car races just to see if a huge car crash happens; that's why people would go to their gigs, for the fights.

Anton is very unstable. Always thinking himself as a music messiah, he wants to change music and create a revolution, but he could never get out of the underground. He is a very talented musician, its amazing how many instruments he can play and with such skill. But his draw back is he cant escape the world he created; a prolific musician stuck in a black hole drugs, alcohol and depression. On the other side, the Dandy Warhols were having their own troubles. They didn't find much success with their first album and were constantly fighting with their record label. But they found huge success in Europe. But Courtney keeps being sucked back into the world of Anton. Its interesting that both Anton and Courtney both had what the other needed. Courtney always wanted to be musically talented as Anton, though Anton wouldn't say it, he needed the commercial success that the Dandy's had, to make his revolution.

Over the seven year course the film crew followed these two bands, there is a lot of footage. There is never a dull moment in Dig!. It is constantly moving along as it doesn't have time to slow down as it has to much to say, seven years of story telling in the 1h 45mins is a hard job. Ondi Timoner has done a great job of piecing together one of the best music documentaries that makes you always wanting more. Even if you don't like the bands it still deserves viewing; it transcends the music to reveal a great story of a successful failure.

You wont be disappointed.
rewritten_review:
Anton Newcombe and Courtney Taylor are friends and rivals, leading The Brian Jonestown Massacre and The Dandy Warhols, respectively. Their love-hate relationship is intriguing, with moments of praise followed by complaints about each other's flaws. While The Dandy Warhols achieved commercial success, BJM remained in the underground scene for good reason.

Dig! focuses more on Anton and BJM, highlighting their dysfunction. Their gigs were notorious for fights, fueled by drugs and alcohol, drawing audiences like spectators at a car crash. Anton is unstable, viewing himself as a music messiah aiming for revolution but unable to escape his self-created world of addiction and depression. Despite his talent, he's trapped. Meanwhile, Dandy Warhols struggled initially but found success in Europe. Courtney, though, was continually drawn back to Anton. Ironically, each possessed what the other needed: Courtney craved Anton's musical talent, and Anton needed the commercial success the Dandys enjoyed.

Over the seven years captured on film, Dig! is never dull. It moves briskly, compressing a lengthy story into a 1h 45min documentary. Ondi Timoner expertly pieces together a compelling narrative, making it a must-watch even if you're not a fan of the bands. It transcends the music, presenting a captivating story of a successful failure. You won't be disappointed.

text: The movie 'Gung Ho!': The Story of Carlson's Makin Island Raiders was made in 1943 with a view to go up the moral of American people at the duration of second world war. It shows with the better way that the cinema can constitute body of propaganda. The value of this film is only collection and no artistic. In a film of propaganda it is useless to judge direction and actors. Watch that movie if you are interested to learn how propaganda functions in the movies or if you are a big fun of Robert Mitchum who has a small role in the film. If you want to see a film for the second world war, they exist much better and objective. I rated it 4/10.
rewritten_review: "Gung Ho!": The Story of Carlson's Makin Island Raiders is a film that was made in 1943 with the primary intention of boosting the morale of the American people during the tumultuous period of the Second World War. This film serves as an excellent example of how cinema can be used as a tool for propaganda. The value of this film lies solely in its historical significance and its role as a piece of propaganda rather than any artistic merit it might possess. When evaluating a film that is primarily focused on propaganda, it is often futile to critique elements such as direction and acting, as these are not the central focus of the production. However, if you are interested in understanding how propaganda operates within the medium of film, or if you are an avid fan of Robert Mitchum, who appears in a minor role, this movie might be worth your time. For those who are looking to watch a film about the Second World War, there are many other films that offer a much better and more objective portrayal of the events. As for my personal rating, I would give it a 4/10.

text:
I watched the Canadian videotape of this movie as "The Witching" which somehow made its way to New York State. Audio was quite bad, I had to raise it to about 7/8 just to hear it and the soundtrack often was overwhelming the dialog. Orson Welles was a mumbler, worse than usual, and some of his dialog and of others was run through an echo chamber. A ghostly figure who keeps reappearing had her voice distorted. Some closed captions would really have helped!

A group of witches or satanists (the end credits say the group was not meant to represent any real group!) have a ritual in which they get naked and cause a miscarriage by stabbing a doll. The woman who had the miscarriage and her husband move to a town named "Lilith," where he's been offered a job at a toy factory. Despite one of the AKAs of this movie apparently being "The Toy Factory," we never see it, and it's only occasionally referred to at all.

On the way to Lilith, her husband gets impatient with some of her questions about what his new boss Mr. Cato wanted to know about their religious persuasion. He drives aggressively, and causes another car to go off the road and blow up. After the police arrive, she takes a doll that fell out of the car, the second of many handmade dolls in the movie.

It turns out Mr. Cato and all the townspeople are witches, and that they are the ones who caused her miscarriage, though she doesn't realize it. They want her because she has an innate talent for necromancy, of which she was not really aware.

Some images in the movie have some impact, but on the whole the movie is not very involving. The movie does seem a bit of a mess, and this is no doubt largely due to its re- editing and the addition of new footage. The original version, according to the end credits, was called Necromancy - A Life for a Life. The magic of DVD could let us see both versions on one disc, but re-releasing this movie probably isn't a priority.

text:
What an atrocity. I am not one to demand total verisimilitude from a movie, but the plot and screenplay of "Killing Zoe" are so artless that I found myself wincing through the entire (mercifully short) ninety minutes of the film.

Readers of these reviews will by now have figured out the plot: Zoe, a call girl who falls in love with American safecracker Zed, is also an employee at the bank that Zed will help rob in a high-stakes Bastille Day heist.

The film strains one's credibility from the get-go. Zed and Zoe's night of magic is highly prosaic, and Zoe's claims to have experienced the orgasm of a lifetime would seem to reflect the screenwriter's lingering teenage fantasies more than any actual on-screen chemistry. Zed's complete indifference when his friend Eric throws Zoe out of the hotel room hardly sets the stage for their later strong attachment.

In act two, Eric's band of bohemians--drug-addled losers leading a marginal life of petty crime--prepare for their big heist with a night on the town. Here Roger Avary's main goal seems to be to prove that he knows something about drugs. A secondary thread involves convincing us (by endless repetition) that Eric is really, REALLY glad to see his old friend Zed again. Really glad. Eric's devil-may-care, over-the-top flamboyance and affection for Zed isn't even remotely believable--check out, for example, his phony bemusement at discovering a dead cat in his apartment building. Development of the characters who will accompany us through the rest of the film is an afterthought.

The heist is a disaster--understandable, since the plan is laughable and the criminals are complete amateurs. This is where Avary continues to pay tribute to his idol Quentin Tarantino by showing that he can be more violent than violent. In reality, though, he's just more boring than boring. To build up the excitement, there is an extra security guard hidden inside the main safe. This was boring in video games, and it's boring now.

Zoe is taken hostage during the heist but despite our expectation that she'll play a pivotal role, she just sits pretty. Or more precisely, Avary fails to do anything with her. In literally the last five minutes she springs to life, breaks the hostage situation and saves the grateful, but still dazed Zed from suffering any consequences of his crime. Why she doesn't mind his involvement in the crime--or why she gives a damn about him at all--is impossible to tell. After all, she's had no chance to see that he's any more decent than the rest of the gang.

Throughout, the dialogue is stilted and phony. Much of it is in French. As a native speaker, I can certify that it doesn't ring even remotely true. Eric's sugary-sweet discourse, rapidly alternating with tough-guy boasting, is meant to be at turns charming and scary, but is instead just grating. Meanwhile his scaredy-cat accomplices are more Scooby-Doo than Thomas Crown. When Eric is gunned down in a ludicrous example of excessive force, we can all breathe a sigh of relief: like the bank hostages, we will soon be freed from this miserable ordeal.

text:
This is a new approach to comedy. It isn't funny.

The joke is that this, in and of itself, is supposed to be funny.

The story is based on a French short story, located in Paris, and the characters have French names. Louis Aubinard, for example ... played by ... Bob Hoskins? The movie also stars the equally French Jeff Goldblum and Natasha Richardson. The situations are similar to and the characters perform as if in those Carry-On movies from years back.

I believe these are also jokes - to cast these actors who make no attempt to act French in any way, to have them cavort in the manner of broad English dance hall comedy, and to leave the whole bloomin' mystery unexplained to the audience.

In the humour department, this is practically the Algonquin Round Table, isn't it?

The movie tries to be charming and quirky, and I guess these characteristics are sort of funny. Not as funny as Duck Soup or Love and Death, perhaps, but funnier than The Deer Hunter or The Battleship Potemkin.

It is an example of personal filmmaking. It makes no real effort to reach out and share with the audience, but stays true to its premise and its internal logic. Although all the situations are unbelievable, they are logical within the film's own bizarro world.

I generally like this kind of eccentric movie, but I found this one to be paced too slowly, to be dull-witted, tedious, and to provide too few pleasurable surprises or genuine wit. It just kind of meanders in predictable and sophomoric ways, and wastes some wonderful talents along the way. It has to be the low point in the career of each of the major stars, who are all otherwise distinguished players. I found it to be the biggest waste of talent since The Betsy, and I wish I had never seen Goldblum and Hoskins in this thing.

So, call it an interesting miss, and pass on it as a rental unless you really have a lot of time to kill.

text: I admit I have a weakness for alternate history stories, from ITS A WONDERFUL LIFE to GROUNDHOG DAY to 12:01. Among those greats is this little gem. It's pretty difficult to get through MR. DESTINY without giving a nod of appreciation to each and every cast member, from the goodhearted James Belushi to the murderous Courtney Cox. This movie lacks the gravitas and scale to make it a great film, but it's a fine cheer-up on a rainy afternoon. It's also a great rental for an inexpensive date.
rewritten_review: I admit I have a weakness for alternate history stories, from ITS A WONDERFUL LIFE to GROUNDHOG DAY to 12:01. These films have always managed to capture my imagination and offer a fascinating glimpse into the endless possibilities of "what if." Among those greats is this little gem, MR. DESTINY. It's pretty difficult to get through MR. DESTINY without giving a nod of appreciation to each and every cast member, from the goodhearted James Belushi to the murderous Courtney Cox. The performances in this film truly stand out, as each actor brings a unique charm and energy to their roles, making the story all the more engaging and entertaining. This movie lacks the gravitas and scale to make it a great film, but it's a fine cheer-up on a rainy afternoon. It's the kind of movie that doesn't take itself too seriously, yet it manages to leave an impression with its heartfelt moments and comedic flair. It's also a great rental for an inexpensive date. Whether you're watching it for the first time or revisiting it after many years, MR. DESTINY offers a delightful escape into a world where small changes can lead to significant differences in one's life. It's a testament to how sometimes, the simple pleasures in cinema can bring unexpected joy and warmth, making it the perfect choice for a cozy, relaxed evening.

text:
i was given the book version of Kazaam for my 8th birthday, and people always say the book versions are always better than the movie, but this time they were wrong. At least with the movie it's over soon.

The acting in this is terrible, which i expected from a film with Shaq who plays a magical rapping genie that comes out of an old ghetto blaster (which there was probably a good reason he was trapped in there). The kid in the film that plays Max is whiny and a terrible actor. He's bullied by neighborhood kids, which i don't blame them because he's a little douche bag.

The story is just plain stupid and extremely cliché. About a boy who's father is always working and never around who finds a new friend who makes his life better and eventually helps him reconnect with his father.

Even at 8 years old i thought this was a stupid idea. It's a surprise any of the people whom worked on this film had careers after wards because it's an embarrassment and should have never been made. i could ramble on even more about how this movie sucks, but you should already know just by reading the plot.
rewritten_review:
I got the book version of Kazaam for my 8th birthday, and while people say books are better than movies, this time they were wrong. At least the movie ends quickly.

The acting is terrible, as expected from a film where Shaq plays a magical rapping genie from an old ghetto blaster (probably for a good reason). The kid playing Max is whiny and a terrible actor. He's bullied by neighborhood kids, and I don't blame them because he's a little douche bag.

The story is stupid and cliché. It's about a boy with an absent father who finds a friend that makes his life better and helps him reconnect with his father.

Even at 8, I thought this was stupid. It's surprising anyone involved had a career after this embarrassment. I could say more, but you should already know how much this movie sucks just from the plot.

text:
Five-year-old Michael sees his mother getting axed to death by his serial killer father "The Highwayman," who later commits suicide. "20 years later" grown Mike (Gordon Currie, from PUPPET MASTER 4 and 5) invites seven of his friends to his secluded grandparents home to "master their own fears" at a Halloween night costume party. Morty, a life-size wooden doll kept in the attic by the Indian handyman, becomes possessed by the dead father's spirit and kills them off using their phobias. Characters are thrown out a window, drowned in a toilet, eaten by rats, blown up, etc. Morty morphs into the dad and a tree, walks around and makes stupid wisecracks. After finding a girl chopped up and stuffed in a cardboard box, the characters remain in the house, act cheerful, crack jokes and have sex.

The Morty design is good and Betsy Palmer (Mrs. Voorhees from the original Friday THE 13TH) is surprisingly delightful as the grandmother, but this thing is even more senseless and confusing than the original and is full of false scares, bad acting, brain-dead characters, repeat flashback footage and annoying distorted camera-work. Plus the only two minority characters (the Indian and a half-black girl) are the first to die. BLAH!
rewritten_review:
Five-year-old Michael witnesses his mother being axed to death by his serial killer father, "The Highwayman," who later commits suicide. "20 years later" grown Mike (Gordon Currie, from PUPPET MASTER 4 and 5) invites seven friends to a secluded grandparents' home to face their fears at a Halloween costume party. Morty, a wooden doll in the attic kept by the Indian handyman, becomes possessed by the dad's spirit, killing them using their phobias. Characters are thrown out a window, drowned, eaten by rats, blown up, etc. Morty morphs into the dad and a tree, walks around making wisecracks. After a girl is found chopped up in a box, the group stays, cracks jokes, and has sex.

The Morty design is good, and Betsy Palmer (Mrs. Voorhees from Friday THE 13TH) is delightful as the grandmother, but it's more senseless and confusing than the original, full of false scares, bad acting, brain-dead characters, repeat flashback footage, and annoying distorted camera-work. Plus, the only two minority characters (the Indian and a half-black girl) die first. BLAH!

text:
Adam Jones has a brilliant sense of humor. There is nothing i didn't like about this film. Cross Eyed was beautifully shot. Adam does a great job of, not only developing the main characters, but also the minor characters.

Cross Eyed gives hope to every low budget film out there. That you don't have to spend a lot to create something worth watching. There is something to like for everyone. If you've had a terrible roommate. if you've ever picked on a dork in high school. if you've ever parked anywhere in the city. if you have any type of sense of humor at all you will love this film. This is the type of film that will be around for a long time and ends up resurfacing again once Adam makes a bigger name for himself. I look forward to Adam's future projects.
rewritten_review:
Adam Jones has a brilliant sense of humor. There is absolutely nothing I didn't like about this film. Cross Eyed was beautifully shot, capturing every scene with a unique flair that draws the audience in. Adam does a great job of, not only developing the main characters, but also the minor characters, giving each one a depth that is rarely seen in films today. The attention to detail in the character development is something that truly sets this film apart from others. 

Cross Eyed gives hope to every low budget film out there. It proves that you don't have to spend a lot to create something worth watching. There is something to like for everyone in this film. If you've ever had a terrible roommate, you'll find a scene or a dialogue that resonates with your own experiences. If you've ever picked on a dork in high school, you'll see moments that might make you reflect. If you've ever parked anywhere in the city, you'll appreciate the humor and relatability of those frustrating moments. If you have any type of sense of humor at all, you will love this film. 

This is the type of film that will be around for a long time. It's the kind of movie that ends up resurfacing again and again, especially once Adam makes a bigger name for himself in the industry. The way he brings the story to life is truly exceptional, and I look forward to Adam's future projects with great anticipation. His ability to combine humor, relatable scenarios, and compelling characters is truly a gift, and I am excited to see what he will come up with next.

text:
For the record, the 1949 version of "The Blue Lagoon" is not the original film, as many have stated.

This story was filmed in Great Britain, in 1923, just after the novel was written. As much as I'd love to see the 1949 version, I'd thoroughly enjoy an opportunity at seeing the true original release of this story on film.

Granted, the 1980 film with Christopher Atkins, Brooke Shields, and the two youngsters was filmed with beautiful cinematography. The acting didn't seem all that great when I first viewed this film, but after having viewed this a few times.... it becomes obvious that two children growing up on an island without adult guidance, would indeed have a simplistic way of approaching life.... whether it be in their language, appearance, or daily activities.

Although some have been fortunate enough to view the 1949 "Blue Lagoon", I cannot help but wonder if there is anyone living who can remember the 1923 release of this story to film.
rewritten_review: The 1949 version of "The Blue Lagoon" is not the original film. The story was first filmed in Great Britain in 1923, shortly after the novel was written. I'd love to see the 1949 version, but I'd especially enjoy seeing the true original release. The 1980 film with Christopher Atkins and Brooke Shields features beautiful cinematography. Initially, the acting seemed lacking, but repeated viewings reveal that children growing up on an island without adult guidance would indeed have a simplistic approach to life, reflected in their language, appearance, and activities. While some have seen the 1949 "Blue Lagoon," I wonder if anyone remembers the 1923 release.

text:
"They were always trying to get me killed," Alec Guinness once wrote of The Man In the White Suit's technicians. "They thought actors got in the way of things." He went on to describe how he'd been given a wire rope to climb down and, assured it was safe, narrowly avoided serious injury when it suddenly snapped mid-descent.

"People get in the way of things" might be a maxim tailor-made for White Suit inventor Sidney Stratton (fittingly played blank slate-fashion by Alec Guinness) in Alexander Mackendrick's definitive Ealing film of 1951. Certainly, he cares only about his work, its realisation - and sod the consequences. And similarly, with the exception of a couple of peripheral characters, there's almost nobody to root for in this chilly satire on capital and labour.

Told in flashback, the film concerns Stratton's invention of a dirt-resistant, everlasting fibre (fashioned into the white suit of the title), and subsequent attempts by the clothing industry and its unions to suppress it.

While the industry fears the bottom will drop out of the market, the shop floor stewards worry about finding themselves out of a job. Abduction and bribery attempts follow, with both money and an industry chief's daughter on offer (Daphne, the delectable, 4-packs-a-day-voiced Joan Greenwood), to the tragi-comic end.

"What's to become of my bit of washing when there's no washing to do?" bemoans Stratton's landlady near the close. A notion Stratton hadn't even considered - and has disregarded again by the movie's ambiguous coda.

A superior, if decidedly downbeat comedy, expertly performed - and pretty much answering the oft-raised question of whatever happened to the everlasting light bulb and the car that ran on water...

text: You know when you're on the bus and someone decides to tell you their life-story, and you sit there with a pathetic smile on your face when all you really want to do is slap the fool and walk off? Well I had a similar sensation while watching this film. Okay, I did actually choose to go and see Aprile, and I knew about Nanni Moretti's taste for making himself the one and only star from Caro Diario, but after about half an hour of this latest installment from his memoirs I wanted to give Moretti the madre of all slaps. Caro Diario was funny, unusual, and at least a couple of other characters managed to get a word in edgeways. In Aprile, however, Moretti has exclusive rights to the dialogue, so that all you hear for an hour and a half is a high-pitched whine going on about how his politics are best, or what quirky piece of popular culture is tickling his fancy at the moment. He also finds time to slag off films that he doesn't like, something I thought was reserved for losers like me. Surely being in a position like his you'd think he'd try and make a point about cinema a little more intelligently than this. By making a proper film perhaps, one with some ideas and a decent structure, or maybe one that isn't completely dominated by his annoying voice. And when he started fawning over his newborn baby, I just wanted to go and be in the company of someone normal, preferably not a self-obsessed film director with a strange penchant for tacky music. The next time someone you don't know tries to tell you their life-story, give them a slap from me. Every blow will be a small victory in the fight against Morettiism.
rewritten_review: You know when you're on the bus and someone tells you their life story, and you sit there with a pathetic smile when all you really want to do is walk off? That's how I felt watching Aprile. I chose to see it, knowing Nanni Moretti's tendency to make himself the star, but after half an hour, I wanted to give him the madre of all slaps. Caro Diario was funny and unusual, with other characters getting a word in. In Aprile, Moretti hogs all the dialogue with his high-pitched whine about his politics and quirky popular culture interests. He even slags off films he doesn't like. Surely, he'd want to make a point about cinema more intelligently, maybe with a proper film that isn't dominated by his annoying voice. When he fawned over his newborn, I wanted normal company, not a self-obsessed director with a taste for tacky music. Next time someone tells you their life story, give them a slap from me. Every blow is a victory against Morettiism.

text: After watching Stop-Loss, I find myself against disappointed in Hollywood for making such a stinker. Gone are the days of glory of the films of the 1940's that made one proud to be an American, fighting the evilness that desires conquest abroad and death at home. What we are left with is dribble frothing at the mouth of rabid anti-Bush radicals. The story tells of three young men who return home from the war. One descends into out-of-control madness, culminating in his death. The main protagonist deserts his country at a time of war, and destroys his best friends relationship with his fiancé at the same time. The third truly is the hero of the story, electing to continue the fight that was brought to our shores nearly eight years ago. What makes this movie bad, is not the acting, but the premise behind it. We are lead to believe that decorated soldiers are in fact haters of our country. Desertion is akin to treason in a time of war, and the main protagonist flirts with it throughout the movie. This paradox is designed to weaken the audience's reaction to the central act of the movie. We are not supposed to find fault with King, since he wears medals, but his actions don't just merit it, but cry out for it. He is not an anti-hero. In order to accept the movie, the audience must accept the correctness of desertion because the story paints King as nothing else short of a hero. I cannot accept that, since it is like asking me to call the sky yellow on a clear blue day. Furthermore, derision for the real hero is heaped upon, the man who re-enlists and continues to serve his country. I would only recommend this stinker to someone who needs convincing of the decay of Hollywood, as it is a clear example of it. No wonder it fared poorly in the box office.
rewritten_review: After watching Stop-Loss, I'm once again disappointed in Hollywood for making such a stinker. Gone are the days of the 1940s films that made one proud to be an American, fighting evil abroad and death at home. Now, we get dribble from rabid anti-Bush radicals. The story follows three young men who return from war. One descends into madness and dies, the main protagonist deserts his country at a time of war, and destroys his best friend's relationship with his fiancée. The third is the true hero, choosing to continue the fight brought to our shores nearly eight years ago. The movie's failure isn't in the acting, but the premise. It suggests decorated soldiers are America-haters. Desertion is akin to treason, yet the protagonist flirts with it throughout the movie, making it hard to fault King because he wears medals. He's not an anti-hero. To accept the movie, one must accept desertion, painting King as a hero. I can't accept that; it's like calling the sky yellow on a blue day. The real hero, who re-enlists, receives derision. I'd only recommend this stinker to someone who needs convincing of Hollywood's decay, as it exemplifies it. No wonder it fared poorly at the box office.

text:
Here's yet another blasphemous European story in which they blast the religion of their country. (These atheist filmmakers are relentless.) Here we see a brutal blasting of Catholics and/or the Catholic clergy (and I am not Catholic).

This won actually won an Academy Award for bes foreign film. That's probably because the story made Catholics and religious belief in general look extremely weak. One of the main characters is a priest and he cares more about food than anything else. He's portrayed as nothing but an idiot. No wonder the secular- dominated Academy loved this movie.

Also, there is some overacting fool who plays a guy who renounces his religion so he can marry one of the four daughters featured in the story. The daughters take turns seducing the "seminary" student (who states he studied for six years but says he's an agnostic!). I mean, how blasphemous IS this film??!!!

This is a disgrace and another excellent example of the secular-progressive bigotry of the film business, worldwide (not just Hollywood).
rewritten_review:
This is yet another European story attacking the religion of their country. These atheist filmmakers are relentless. Here we see a brutal portrayal of Catholics and/or the Catholic clergy (and I'm not Catholic). This even won an Academy Award for Best Foreign Film, likely because it made Catholics and religious belief look extremely weak. One main character, a priest, cares more about food than anything else and is portrayed as an idiot. No wonder the secular-dominated Academy loved it.

There's also an overacting fool who renounces his religion to marry one of the four daughters in the story. The daughters take turns seducing the "seminary" student, who claims to have studied for six years but says he's an agnostic. How blasphemous is this film?!

This is a disgrace and an excellent example of the secular-progressive bigotry of the film industry worldwide (not just Hollywood).

text: This film has "haunted" me since I saw it when I was about 8 years old. I didn't know what it was called so am so pleased to have tracked it down finally. I remember being quite scared, because I'd just been to a tin mine in Cornwall when I watched it, so could imagine it all. Fortunately I didn't see any ghosts of dead children there, but I found this film really quite disturbing and scary when I was much younger. I've certainly never forgotten it, even though I couldn't find it anywhere. I seem to remember The Children's Film Foundation films being generally good, but they don't show them at all any more. I also remember programmes like The Children Of Green Knowe in the same era on BBC - equally unsettling in its own way.
rewritten_review: This film has "haunted" me since I saw it when I was about 8 years old. I didn't know what it was called, so I am so pleased to have tracked it down finally after all these years. I remember being quite scared, because I'd just been to a tin mine in Cornwall when I watched it, so I could really imagine it all unfolding right before my eyes. Fortunately, I didn't see any ghosts of dead children there, but I found this film really quite disturbing and scary when I was much younger. It made such a strong impression on me that I've certainly never forgotten it, even though I couldn't find it anywhere for the longest time. I seem to remember The Children's Film Foundation films being generally good, entertaining, and sometimes thought-provoking, but they don't show them at all anymore, which is such a shame. I also remember programmes like The Children Of Green Knowe that aired in the same era on BBC - equally unsettling in its own unique way. Those kinds of films and shows really had a knack for sticking with you long after you'd seen them.

text: Greatly enjoyed this 1945 mystery thriller film about a young woman, Nina Foch,(Julia Ross) who is out of work and has fallen behind in her rent and is desperate to find work. Julia reads an ad in the local London newspaper looking for a secretary and rushes out to try and obtain this position. Julia obtains the position and is hired by a Mrs. Hughes, (Dame May Witty) who requires that she lives with her employer in her home and wants her to have no involvement with men friends and Julia tells them she has no family and is free to devote her entire time to this job. George Macready, (Ralph Hughes) is the son of Mrs. Hughes and has some very strange desires for playing around with knives. This was a low budget film and most of the scenes were close ups in order to avoid the expense of a background and costs for scenery. This strange family all live in a huge mansion off the Cornwall Coast of England and there is secret doors and plenty of suspense.
rewritten_review: I greatly enjoyed this 1945 mystery thriller film about a young woman, Nina Foch, who plays the character Julia Ross. Julia is out of work and has fallen behind in her rent, making her desperate to find employment. The film begins with Julia reading an advertisement in the local London newspaper, which is seeking a secretary. Eager to secure a job, Julia rushes out to try and obtain this position. Fortunately, she successfully obtains the position and is hired by a woman named Mrs. Hughes, portrayed by Dame May Witty. Mrs. Hughes has specific requirements for her new secretary; she insists that Julia lives with her employer in her home and demands that she has no involvement with any men friends. Julia, having no family, assures Mrs. Hughes that she is free to devote her entire time to this job. The plot thickens as we are introduced to George Macready's character, Ralph Hughes, who is the son of Mrs. Hughes. Ralph has some very strange desires, particularly an unsettling fascination with playing around with knives, which adds to the suspense and intrigue of the film. Despite being a low-budget film, it cleverly utilizes most of the scenes as close-ups to avoid the expense of elaborate backgrounds and costs for scenery. This strange family resides in a huge mansion located off the Cornwall Coast of England, adding an element of isolation and mystery to the setting. The mansion is filled with secret doors, contributing to the film's atmosphere of suspense and intrigue, as Julia navigates through this eerie and enigmatic environment. The film's ability to build tension and maintain suspense throughout, combined with the strong performances of the cast, makes it a captivating watch for fans of the mystery thriller genre.

text:
Times are tough for Angel Town, gangs rule with an iron fist and for reasons mostly unknown (Mainly due to embarrassing writing) the gangs want a street kid, Martine to join the gangs, so they beat him up everyday. However due to the presence of an Olympic kick-boxer (Olivier "World's lamest actor" Gruner) named Jacques, hope is on the way. Angel Town is seriously one of the most inept message movies ever made (And I've seen my share) it seems to consist of the idea that all gang infested neighborhoods need, are French kick-boxers who can't act. Worst of all there are so many awkward moments it's just truly hilarious. Best of all comes from the exchange between Gruner and Aragon which basically sums up how ridiculous this thing is. To Wit: "You like the fighting? (Olivier grabs his Asian best friend in a headlock) I could kill him right? When I want him dead he dies! The reason why I don't want him dead is because i'm afraid of him, and I know that if I kill him his son and wife will kill me, that's why he doesn't die!"

Of course the fact that it's wrong to kill someone, let alone your best friend is of course left out of the equation. Odd.

However don't let me make this sound that I hated this movie, far from it, it's so terrible it's priceless. The biggest laughs come at the end in the disastrous finale which sees Grunner going one on one with gang-members who (the film's biggest logic gap)decline the use of pistols. Also a handicapped Vietnam vet helps out by shooting his machine gun at the gangs, while Gruner kick-boxes the rest. All of this set to the sound of horrible "Mexican" accents and surreal energy that make this one memorable for fans of cinematic trash such as this.

The other treat about this movie, is that for some reason Olivier Gruner never attends college despite that's the main reason he's here in the states and not in France getting it on with his girlfriend (In a graveyard in the film's awkward beginning) Angel Town is without a doubt a failure on all conceivable levels but if you laugh at moronic martial arts movies with insane levels of action that make no sense on any level, this is the perfect movie for you. On the other hand make sure to down tequila, like the laughable opening song details "Ain't no mercy in Angel Town"

* out of 4-(Bad)
rewritten_review:
Times are tough for Angel Town, where gangs rule and inexplicably target street kid Martine, beating him up daily. Enter Jacques, an Olympic kick-boxer played by Olivier "World's lamest actor" Gruner, bringing hope. This film is a masterclass in ineptitude, suggesting gang-infested neighborhoods need French kick-boxers who can't act. The film is filled with awkward moments, highlighted by a ridiculous exchange between Gruner and Aragon: "You like the fighting? (Olivier grabs his Asian best friend in a headlock) I could kill him right? When I want him dead he dies! The reason why I don't want him dead is because I'm afraid of him, and I know that if I kill him his son and wife will kill me, that's why he doesn't die!" The moral implications of killing your best friend are conveniently ignored.

Despite its flaws, the movie is so terrible it's priceless, with the biggest laughs in the finale where Gruner fights gang-members who illogically refuse to use pistols. A handicapped Vietnam vet joins in, shooting a machine gun while Gruner kick-boxes, all set to awful "Mexican" accents and surreal energy. Oddly, Gruner never attends college, despite it being his reason for being in the U.S., instead of France with his girlfriend. Angel Town fails on all levels but is perfect for fans of nonsensical martial arts movies with insane action. Just make sure to have tequila on hand, as the laughable opening song suggests, "Ain't no mercy in Angel Town."

* out of 4 - (Bad)

text: If you are studying Welles and want to see just how far he fell after Citizen Kane, this film will prove it. The cheap excuse of making the protagonist a self-admitted dummy to explain how he might fall into such a half-baked scheme fails to explain the absurd courtroom theatrics and ridiculous plot twists that eventually ensue. Don't be taken in by the high rating of this film in the db as I was; all I can guess is that there are a lot of die hard old Welles and Hayworth fans out there.
rewritten_review: If you are studying Welles and want to see just how far he fell after Citizen Kane, this film will prove it. The cheap excuse of making the protagonist a self-admitted dummy to explain how he might fall into such a half-baked scheme fails to explain the absurd courtroom theatrics and ridiculous plot twists that eventually ensue. It is quite disappointing to witness how a filmmaker of Welles' caliber could be associated with such a film, especially after the masterpiece that was Citizen Kane. The narrative lacks coherence, and the characters, despite their potential, feel underdeveloped and unconvincing. Don't be taken in by the high rating of this film in the db as I was; all I can guess is that there are a lot of die hard old Welles and Hayworth fans out there. The film seems to rely heavily on the star power of its leads, rather than focusing on delivering a compelling story. This reliance on star appeal, rather than substantial content, might explain why some viewers hold it in higher regard than it deserves. It is perplexing how the film has managed to garner such a high rating, and it raises questions about the criteria and standards by which it is judged. Nevertheless, for anyone interested in the trajectory of Welles' career, this film serves as a stark reminder of the challenges and missteps that can occur even for the most talented filmmakers.

text:
When I was seventeen I genuinely believed Elvis to be the king of rock and roll, and not only did I wish to see all 31 of his "character" movies, but it was my ambition to own them, too. What an exceptionally poor excuse for a seventeen-year-old I must have been. Thankfully sense prevailed and Live A Little, Love A Little is the only Elvis film I own.

The spotlight has fallen on this one recently since a remixed version of top song A Little Less Conversation has been released as a single. (His first to reach the UK top ten in 22 years  his first UK No.1 in 25) Even when I was seventeen and in serious need of psychiatric help I realised that the songs for this movie weren't exactly first rate. However, A Little Less Conversation - rollnecks and 60s grooving aside - is a real standout. Finding a lesser-known song that only a relatively small few are aware of promoted into the mainstream produces a mixture of emotions. It's nice to finally see faith in a song vindicated, but it's also saddening to see the disintegration of your own private cult. (And what chauvinistic lyrics, too. Though what other Elvis song contains the word "procrastinate"?)

But what really bothers me about this film is not A Little Less Conversation but the 84 minutes that surround it. Actually based on a novel (Kiss My Firm But Pliant Lips - what kind of lame novel would that be?) this one sees a bored Elvis holed up with a "comedy" dog and a nympho. Within 90 seconds of meeting him, Michele Carey asks "would you like to make love to me?" Quite a fast mover by any standards I'm sure you'll agree.

I do seem to recall that some of Elvis's early movies - most notably Jailhouse Rock and King Creole - weren't too bad, but this is just identikit hillbilly cobblers. Being fired from a newspaper job can lead to a five minute karate fight with a couple of gingernuts, causing a motorway pile up is good for a laugh, and models dress as pink mermaids. There's even a dream sequence for God's sake. Maybe the only dumb stereotype it doesn't conform to is in not having all that many songs. With just four to choose from, including the credits number, you're waiting an average of 22 minutes between tracks. Some movies would become vapid by having too many tunes, but here they might have helped to have numbed the pain. Of the remaining three tracks, then The Edge of Reality isn't actually that bad, though Elvis's dance to it must surely have been called "The Bear Trap".

In one sense, for a PG certificate film from 1968 then this is shockingly high on sexual content. Sadly, however, with talking dogs, Middle America sitcom values and the stiffest dancing you'll ever see, Elvis's dignity is obliterated by this movie.
