Red is a risky color in modern times; it challenges our perceptions of the wearer and at the same time makes the wearer vulnerable. Yet red carries an enormous weight of history and mysticism, as the earliest members of Cro-Magnon man buried their dead in red ochre and indeed the first man named in the Torah, Adam, is named after the Hebrew word for red. Red also has an anachronistic flavor, looking back on the past where red (and by association a less self-driven attitude towards life) was more accepted. So when we encounter the red-filled room (the mysterious frieze covered walls complete with a red accented menorah and a red painting of a Whirling Dervish!) of Irene's mother, "good" characters Maria Clara and Aurelio wearing resplendent outfits of red, and finally the painting of Irene's mother in a formal red gown we can see where Ozpetek's sympathies lie.

A word or two about the soundtrack, I found the original musical themes to be excellently suited to the story. The quasi-baroque theme that signified Irene was great for it's monotony and feeling of restive malaise (the absolute best use of a constantly repeated baroque theme such a this would have to be in Kubrick's Barry Lyndon, with it's masterful repetitions of an 8-bar sarabande attributed to Handel). One absolutely inspired choice was a couple of seconds of an opera aria we hear as the power is flickering while Irene is chasing Benny through the house. It is of the famous aria "Ebben? ... Ne andrò lontano" from Catalani's opera "La Wally". The aria is sung by the lead soprano who is leaving home forever. As Irene's mother was a dramatic soprano, we can guess that this is a recording of her singing and that she is saying a poignant farewell to her daughter, as in the movie Irene is soon destined to never again see Benny alive. I just have one minor question of the soundtrack, why include the famous tango Yo Soy Maria? I love the song and personally could hear it all the time, but it didn't really fit here.

text:
Fully deserving its prestigious Hollywood award nomination, this is an entertaining little gem with lots of pizazz and some delightful surprises. Outstandingly funny scenes include an hilarious shoot (and re-shoot) of a WW1 trench scene with Australian comedian Clyde Cook as an optimistic non-com and the hapless McDoakes as a Boyer/Colman messenger  all under the beady eye of Ralph Sanford's delightfully irascible Anguish; a lost McDoakes guided and re-guided by equally perplexed Jack Carson; assistant director Chandler rejoicing in a McDoakes-sent opportunity: "I'm going to be a director!"

Ace comic O'Hanlon has a dual role, playing both McDoakes and himself playing McDoakes! Oddly, Richard L. Bare who does play himself in one or more other entries in the series, has turned down that opportunity here. In real life, Bare's a youngish, six-foot Rock Hudson lookalike, but here he's impersonated by veteran actor (over 500 movies!), Jack Mower.
rewritten_review:
Fully deserving its prestigious Hollywood award nomination, this is an entertaining little gem with lots of pizazz and some delightful surprises. The film truly captivates the audience with its unique blend of humor and charm, making it a standout piece that is hard to forget. Outstandingly funny scenes include an hilarious shoot (and re-shoot) of a WW1 trench scene with Australian comedian Clyde Cook as an optimistic non-com and the hapless McDoakes as a Boyer/Colman messenger — all under the beady eye of Ralph Sanford's delightfully irascible Anguish. The interplay of the characters in these scenes brings about a kind of comedic magic that is rare to find, showcasing the talents of the actors involved. A lost McDoakes guided and re-guided by equally perplexed Jack Carson adds another layer of comedy, displaying a wonderful chemistry between the actors that keeps the audience thoroughly entertained. Assistant director Chandler rejoicing in a McDoakes-sent opportunity: "I'm going to be a director!" adds to the film’s charm, providing an additional humorous twist to the storyline. 

Ace comic O'Hanlon has a dual role, playing both McDoakes and himself playing McDoakes! This clever casting choice adds depth and an intriguing level of complexity to the film, making it even more engaging for viewers. Oddly, Richard L. Bare who does play himself in one or more other entries in the series, has turned down that opportunity here. It’s an interesting decision that adds an element of mystery to the production, sparking curiosity among fans. In real life, Bare's a youngish, six-foot Rock Hudson lookalike, but here he's impersonated by veteran actor (over 500 movies!), Jack Mower. This substitution is both surprising and delightful, bringing a unique flavor to the film that is sure to be appreciated by audiences. The film, with its exceptional cast and captivating storyline, truly stands out as a remarkable piece of cinema, fully deserving of its prestigious Hollywood award nomination.

text: This production has absolutely no storyline. The acting is embarrassing. The promising Dutch television Sophie Hilbrand star should not add this movie to her CV. Her acting is far from flawless and personally I think she has crossed boundary of professional decency; relating to the way she exposes herself in this movie. This movie contains too much unnecessary nudity, vulgar sexual scenes and rude language. It also shows a wrong image of the Netherlands (as most movies do). Do not bother to watch this movie: a waste of time, a waste of money and an embarrassing record for Hilbrand, who has proved to be better with her close on on the screen.
rewritten_review: This production has absolutely no storyline whatsoever. The acting is nothing short of embarrassing. The promising Dutch television star Sophie Hilbrand should not add this movie to her CV under any circumstances. Her acting is far from flawless, and personally, I think she has crossed the boundary of professional decency in this role; this is particularly evident in the way she exposes herself in this movie. This film contains far too much unnecessary nudity, vulgar sexual scenes, and rude language. It also portrays a wrong image of the Netherlands, as most movies tend to do. Do not bother to watch this movie: it is a complete waste of time, a waste of money, and an embarrassing record for Hilbrand. She has previously proved to be much better with her clothes on when appearing on the screen. This movie fails on multiple levels, and it's unfortunate to see someone with such potential be associated with this kind of project. The lack of a coherent storyline makes it difficult to engage with the film on any meaningful level, and the attempts at drama or humor fall flat due to poor execution. The overemphasis on explicit content seems to serve no purpose other than to shock, rather than contribute anything of substance to the narrative. It's disappointing to see the Netherlands depicted in such a clichéd and negative manner, which does a disservice to the country's rich culture and vibrant communities. In conclusion, this movie is not worth your time or money, and it stands as a regrettable entry in Sophie Hilbrand's otherwise promising career.

text: I really enjoyed watching this movie about the Delany sisters. I knew of them, but that was all. This movie opened my eyes to their bravado and courage. What a pair. What sacrifices they made to live life on their own terms. This is not only a movie for African Americans, but for all Americans. It is sort of a history lesson and a documentary rolled into one and combined with an entertaining movie biography. The acting was superior by all included and we really do get a glimpse of the hardships these two sisters went through for many years. Both sisters are quite different from each other. They came from a very loving and very strict family with high, maybe even impossible standards of perfection. It is sad to see how Sadie's father refused to allow his daughter to continue to see her boyfriend due to a possible misunderstanding. I thoroughly recommend this movie and I am glad I caught it on television the other day.
rewritten_review: I really enjoyed watching this movie about the Delany sisters. Before watching it, I knew of them, but that was all. This movie opened my eyes to their extraordinary bravado and courage. What a pair these sisters are! What sacrifices they made to live life on their own terms, despite the many challenges they faced. This is not only a movie for African Americans, but for all Americans, as it offers a universal message of resilience and determination. It is sort of a history lesson and a documentary rolled into one and combined with an entertaining movie biography. The way it blends these elements makes it a truly unique viewing experience. The acting was superior by all included, and we really do get a glimpse of the hardships these two sisters went through for many years. It's remarkable how the film captures their spirit and perseverance. Both sisters are quite different from each other, adding depth to their story. They came from a very loving and very strict family with high, maybe even impossible, standards of perfection. The film does an excellent job of portraying the complexity of their upbringing and the expectations placed upon them. It is sad to see how Sadie's father refused to allow his daughter to continue to see her boyfriend due to a possible misunderstanding. This moment was particularly poignant and highlighted the difficult choices they had to make. I thoroughly recommend this movie and I am glad I caught it on television the other day. It left a lasting impression on me and is a testament to the strength and resilience of the Delany sisters.

text:
If vampire tales are your cup of blood, then this Goth-fest based on the Anne Rice Vampire Chronicles should prove to be a satisfying experience. A veritable consortium of the undead in a contemporary setting, `Queen of the Damned,' directed by Michael Rymer, is a story of shadows and darkness, and of the unfortunate souls who dwell therein for eternity.

The vampire Lestat (Stuart Townsend), bored with a world that no longer excites him, has been `asleep' for many years; but suddenly, the sounds of that world he hears from his extended slumber change, and liking what he hears, he ventures forth to investigate. What he finds is a world filled with new sounds, a new kind of music-- driving and penetrating-- sounds that assault the senses and make him feel alive and welcome. And he knows that at long last his time has come, that it is time for him and those like him to come out into the open and face the world on their terms. Toward that end he becomes the front man for a band-- a singer and performer unlike any the world has ever known. He presents himself as a vampire, and very quickly amasses a following that extends far beyond London (where it all begins), and will ultimately take him to Death Valley, California, where he plans to give a concert that promises to be beyond anything anyone has ever seen or experienced.

Lestat is powerful, without question, but there are those of his kind who do not take favorably to the fact that he has revealed them, one of whom is Marius (Vincent Perez), a vampire powerful in his own right-- the vampire, in fact, who `made' Lestat so many years before-- and they are gathering, coming together and making their plans to meet Lestat at the concert. And they are not going for the music. But there is something else, as well: At one point Lestat has inadvertently awakened the `Mother' of them all, the most powerful of all the vampires, Akasha (Aaliyah), who is about to make her presence known to all, and especially to the one she has chosen to rule by her side as her King: Lestat. And at the concert, rest assured, Akasha will be in attendance, without fail.

Make no mistake, this is Lestat's story, and Rymer presents it amid a setting rich with atmosphere and with some exquisite moments, though his film has less bite to it than say, `Interview With the Vampire,' or `Bram Stoker's Dracula.' He sets a good pace, and there are some scenes that provide some real thrills, but overall the film isn't as soaked in menace as it could be, or as much as one might expect. In the final tally, in fact, the amount of flesh that is incinerated wins out over actual blood-letting, though there is more than a taste of gore, and more than a fair share of lips and mouths dripping with the red stuff. There's some good F/X on hand, too, especially in the sequences that accentuate the speed of the vampires, as they move and hurtle through the air faster than the naked eye can discern. It's a decent job by Rymer, but he could have put more teeth into it had he played up the alienation hinted at by Lestat; as it is, you get a sense of his detachment, but not enough to get you totally involved.

In `Interview With the Vampire,' Tom Cruise brought some charismatic star power to the role of Lestat, but Townsend is even more effective, with a look and an attitude that captures Lestat perfectly. He plays him with a sense of acceptance, and under closer scrutiny you may even find a hint of remorse and longing. It's a good performance, and one that sells his character convincingly.

As Marius, Vincent Perez does a nice job, too-- he is, in fact, one of the strengths of the film-- though his character is a bit ambiguous; that, however, has more to do with the way he was written than with Perez's performance, which is quite good.

Turning in noteworthy performances, as well, are Marguerite Moreau, as Jesse, a young woman too curious for her own good; and the gorgeous Lena Olin as Maharet, Jesse's Aunt, who ultimately plays a pivotal role in the outcome of the drama involving Lestat and Akasha.

And as Akasha, Aaliyah is an absolutely riveting presence. What more can one say about her other than she is a gifted performer, with tremendous talent and beauty. And, tragically, she has left us much too soon.

The supporting cast includes Paul McGann (David), Christian Manon (Mael), Claudia Black (Pandora), Bruce Spence (Khayman), Matthew Newton (Armand), Tiriel Mora (Roger) and Megan Dorman (Maudy). With a much stronger story than the usual offerings of this particular genre, Anne Rice fans, especially, will be pleased with `Queen of the Damned,' a film nicely crafted and delivered by director Rymer and his engaging cast. By focusing attention on the drama of the story-- and the way it's presented-- rather than concentrating on merely providing some cheap thrills, Rymer has succeeded in turning out a true horror film that is definitely a cut above, and one that just may whet your appetite for more of the same. And that's the magic of the movies. I rate this one 7/10.

text: Talk about creepy. If you really want to sit down and watch this episode where the girl who was in Firefly later on gets kidnapped there's entertainment for you, but only if you like this sort of thing. I don't so I thought, to be frank, this episode was appalling. Thankfully it's one of a few duff episodes in Season 3, and the only Charles Grant Craig episode, so you don't get much of this sort of thing in Season 3. So, overall verdict? Just read the summary at the top. This is a strong contender (Hell Money says hi!) for worst episode of Season 3. To be honest though, I hadn't really expected much. I wish I could Oubliette this episode altogether. That's one thing they got right: the title.
rewritten_review: Talk about creepy. If you really want to sit down and watch this episode where the girl who was in Firefly later on gets kidnapped, there's entertainment for you, but only if you like this sort of thing. Personally, I don't, so I thought, to be frank, this episode was appalling. The unsettling theme and disturbing storyline didn't sit well with me at all. Thankfully, it's one of a few duff episodes in Season 3, and the only Charles Grant Craig episode, so you don't get much of this sort of thing in Season 3. The rest of the season generally maintains a higher standard of storytelling, with more engaging plots and better character development. So, overall verdict? Just read the summary at the top. This is a strong contender (Hell Money says hi!) for worst episode of Season 3. The sheer lack of compelling narrative and the off-putting nature of the episode makes it stand out for all the wrong reasons. To be honest though, I hadn't really expected much. My expectations were low, and yet, the episode still managed to disappoint. I wish I could Oubliette this episode altogether. It's a shame because the series has had many high points, but this certainly wasn't one of them. That's one thing they got right: the title.

text: "FULL HOUSE," in my opinion, is an absolute ABC classic! I'm not sure if I've never seen every episode, but I still enjoyed it. One of my favorite episodes is where Jesse (John Stamos) and Rebecca (Lori Loughlin) get married. If you want to know how what made it so funny, you'd have to have seen it for yourself. It was a two-parter, so you'd have to have seen both parts. Another one of my favorite episodes is where Jesse, Stephanie (Jodie Sweetin), and Michelle (Mary Kate & Ashley Olsen) get locked in a gas station on Michelle's birthday. You'd also have to have seen it for yourself if you want to know how and why that happened. I have many other ones that I like, too. Everyone always gave a good performance, the production design was spectacular, the costumes were well-designed, and the writing was always very strong. In conclusion, even though it can be seen in syndication now, I strongly recommend you catch it just in case it goes off the air for good.
rewritten_review: "FULL HOUSE," in my opinion, is an absolute ABC classic! The show has a charm that resonates with audiences of all ages, and its timeless appeal makes it a staple of family television. I'm not sure if I've ever seen every single episode, but I still enjoyed it whenever I had the chance to watch. One of my favorite episodes is where Jesse (John Stamos) and Rebecca (Lori Loughlin) get married. This particular storyline was beautifully crafted, and the chemistry between the actors made it a memorable viewing experience. If you want to know what made it so funny and heartwarming, you'd have to have seen it for yourself. It was a two-parter, which means you'd have to have seen both parts to fully appreciate the humor and emotion that unfolded. Another one of my favorite episodes is where Jesse, Stephanie (Jodie Sweetin), and Michelle (Mary Kate & Ashley Olsen) get locked in a gas station on Michelle's birthday. The premise of this episode was both hilarious and touching at the same time. You'd also have to have seen it for yourself if you want to know how and why that happened. The comedic timing and the way the situation was handled added a unique touch to the episode's storyline. I have many other ones that I like, too, each bringing its own special moments and life lessons. Everyone always gave a good performance, bringing their characters to life in a way that was relatable and endearing. The production design was spectacular, capturing the essence of a warm, loving home. The costumes were well-designed, reflecting the personalities of the characters and the era in which the show was set. The writing was always very strong, with scripts that were both entertaining and meaningful. In conclusion, even though it can be seen in syndication now, I strongly recommend you catch it just in case it goes off the air for good. The show continues to be a beloved classic that has left a lasting impact on its viewers, and it's definitely worth watching if you haven't already.

text: I'll bet I watch this film 4 or 5 times a year, and will do so more often, now that the Hollyweird moguls have seen fit to put it on DVD, because it's a Classic with a capital "C"! This film is timeless! How can people pay $10.00 nowadays to see the JUNK that comes out of Hollyweird with movies like THE Egyptian; THE TEN COMMANDMENTS; BEN HUR; CAPTAIN NEWMAN MD on tape; DVD; and cable movie channels; I could go on forever, but this film is so great, and for a relative unknown, Edmund Purdom carries the movie like Atlas carried the world. The story is wonderful, the acting is first-rate, and the graphics at the end are so powerful, you sit in your seat for a few minutes, just trying to let the words sink in! Really a knockout of a film. I'd give this one 15 stars if they'd let me! They don't make them like this anymore, But they should!!!!!
rewritten_review:

Really a knockout of a film. I'd give this one 15 stars if they'd let me! They don't make them like this anymore, But they should!!!!!

This film has a special place in my heart and I will always cherish the moments I spend watching it. The performances are truly captivating and the storyline is incredibly engaging. I find myself completely immersed in the world it creates every single time I watch it. The cinematography is breathtaking and the music score elevates the film to another level. Each scene is crafted with such care and attention to detail that it becomes a visual masterpiece. The dialogue is sharp and memorable, leaving a lasting impression long after the credits roll.

The film's impact is undeniable, and it resonates with audiences of all ages. It stands as a testament to the artistry and creativity that defined an era, and it continues to inspire filmmakers today. The emotional depth of the characters and the complexity of the plot make it a timeless classic that never fails to captivate viewers. It's a film that I can watch repeatedly and still discover new layers and nuances with each viewing.

The legacy of this film is enduring, and it serves as a reminder of what cinema can achieve when it combines talent, vision, and passion. It transports you to another time and place, allowing you to experience the magic of storytelling in its purest form. This film is a treasure that deserves to be celebrated and remembered for generations to come. Its brilliance is unmatched, and it remains a shining example of the golden age of cinema.

Every time I watch this film, I am reminded of why I fell in love with movies in the first place. It rekindles my appreciation for the art of filmmaking and reinforces the power of storytelling to touch our hearts and minds. The film is a masterpiece that stands the test of time, and I am grateful to have the opportunity to experience its beauty and brilliance over and over again. It is truly a cinematic gem that will continue to hold a special place in my heart for years to come.

text:
I've always enjoyed Kenneth Branagh's versions of the Shakespeare classics, as he always does a very good job, but in this movie, the one who lifts the whole movie, is none other than "the-always-great-actor" Laurence Fishburne. Surely he has made some poor choices in films, even though he's a wonderful actor, but in this one we're truly given the real Othello: the passion, the intensity of jealousy as it grows stronger alongside with Fishburne's well portrayed paranoia and, furthermore, we're finally given a black Othello!

I don't think they could have chosen a better Othello. Who else could have given him that blend of sympathy/antipathy, love/hatred and, not to forget, those fiery eyes...? Branagh is good as always, but not at his peak, Iréne Jacob's Desdemona is fairly good but a bit bleak, whilst Laurence Fishburne truly lifts it and makes it a very interesting and enjoyable movie. Do watch it.
rewritten_review:
I've always enjoyed Kenneth Branagh's versions of the Shakespeare classics, as he always does a very good job, bringing the timeless works of the Bard to life with his unique touch and deep understanding of the material. His adaptations are a treat for anyone who appreciates Shakespearean drama, and they never fail to capture the essence of the plays. But in this movie, the one who lifts the whole movie, is none other than "the-always-great-actor" Laurence Fishburne. Surely he has made some poor choices in films, even though he's a wonderful actor, capable of delivering powerful performances across a range of genres, but in this one we're truly given the real Othello: the passion, the intensity of jealousy as it grows stronger alongside with Fishburne's well portrayed paranoia and, furthermore, we're finally given a black Othello! This is significant, as it adds an important layer of authenticity and relevance to the portrayal of the character, staying true to Shakespeare's original depiction while resonating with contemporary audiences.

I don't think they could have chosen a better Othello. Who else could have given him that blend of sympathy/antipathy, love/hatred and, not to forget, those fiery eyes that seem to burn with the intensity of Othello's internal struggles...? Branagh is good as always, maintaining his usual standard of excellence, but not at his peak, Iréne Jacob's Desdemona is fairly good but a bit bleak, bringing a subtle grace to her role that, while commendable, doesn't quite match the vibrancy of Fishburne's portrayal, whilst Laurence Fishburne truly lifts it and makes it a very interesting and enjoyable movie. His presence on screen is magnetic, drawing viewers into Othello's world and making them feel every moment of his tragic journey. Do watch it, as it is a film that offers a rich and compelling experience, showcasing the talents of its cast and the enduring power of Shakespeare's storytelling.

text:
Six students at a convent do the unthinkable - kill a nun who was overbearing. Now, eighteen years later, the nun's spirit is back and getting revenge for her murder.

Yea, basically that's the short of it. There's more to it than that, but I still have no clue what it is. The only really cool thing is the effects on the spiritual nun, as I was pretty impressed for being a more low-budget flick. I'm also confused as to whether or not it's in English. Most of the actors are Italian, and even the title here is in Italian, yet they spoke English in the film (I think, or it might've been dubbed, I still can't tell).

Anyway, the real premise of the film is pretty idiotic, and the ending not only doesn't make sense, it...well...doesn't make sense.
rewritten_review:
Six students at a convent do the unthinkable - kill a nun who was overbearing. Now, eighteen years later, the nun's spirit is back and getting revenge for her murder. This is the basic premise of the film, and while it sounds intriguing at first glance, there's a lot more to it than just this. However, despite this additional depth, I still have no clue what it is. The narrative seems to be shrouded in mystery, leaving the viewer scratching their head as they try to piece together the story. 

One of the standout elements, though, is the special effects used for the spiritual nun. I must say, I was pretty impressed with how they managed to pull it off, especially considering it appears to be a more low-budget flick. The effects really added a layer of eeriness and suspense that was quite effective, making it one of the more memorable aspects of the film. 

Another point of confusion for me was the language. I'm still not entirely sure whether the film is in English. Most of the actors are Italian, and even the title here is presented in Italian, yet they spoke English in the film, at least I think they did. It might have been dubbed, but I still can't tell for sure. This added another layer of complexity, as it was a bit jarring trying to follow the dialogue while being uncertain about the language.

Anyway, the real premise of the film, when you get down to it, is pretty idiotic. The plot stretches the bounds of believability, and the ending not only doesn't make sense, it...well...doesn't make sense. It's as if the film builds up to a climax that it can't quite deliver on, leaving viewers bewildered rather than satisfied. Despite the intriguing setup and impressive effects, the film struggles to tie everything together in a coherent way, resulting in an experience that is more confusing than captivating.

text: Cooley High is considered one of my best all time movies. It certainly reminds me of days of my youth growing up in the cities of Cleveland and Chicago during the early, mid, and late 1960's. What ever happened to Brenda and Pooter? Some one need's to track those two down. Brenda for her beauty and Pooter for his innocent wit. They both deserve to be recognized even 31 years after this film was debuted. I think a lot of the fans of this movie would like to find out what happened to them as well as others who acted in this fun filled movie. I certainly think this movie should be entered into some type of MOVIE HALL OF FAME. All of the cast of this movie was great. My opinion is of " Cooley High " is turn back the hands of time, those were the fun years.
rewritten_review:
Cooley High is considered one of my best all-time movies. It certainly reminds me of the days of my youth growing up in the cities of Cleveland and Chicago during the early, mid, and late 1960s. The film captures the essence of that era so beautifully, and it resonates with me on a deeply personal level. The characters, the setting, and the storyline all come together to create a cinematic experience that is both nostalgic and timeless. The friendships and the adventures portrayed in the movie are reminiscent of the fun and carefree days of my own youth. It truly is a masterpiece that stands the test of time.

Whatever happened to Brenda and Pooter? Someone needs to track those two down. Brenda, with her beauty and grace, was a standout character, and Pooter, with his innocent wit and charm, added so much depth and humor to the story. They both deserve to be recognized even 31 years after this film was debuted. Their performances were unforgettable, and their characters left a lasting impact on the audience. I think a lot of the fans of this movie would like to find out what happened to them as well as others who acted in this fun-filled movie.

I certainly think this movie should be entered into some type of MOVIE HALL OF FAME. It is a film that has touched the hearts of many and continues to do so with each new generation of viewers. The authenticity and relatability of Cooley High make it a strong contender for such an honor. All of the cast of this movie was great. Each actor brought something unique and special to their role, contributing to the overall magic of the film. My opinion of "Cooley High" is to turn back the hands of time; those were the fun years. The memories it evokes and the emotions it stirs are priceless, and it will always hold a special place in my heart as one of the greatest films of all time.

text:
Oh, brother...after hearing about this ridiculous film for umpteen years all I can think of is that old Peggy Lee song..

"Is that all there is??" ...I was just an early teen when this smoked fish hit the U.S. I was too young to get in the theater (although I did manage to sneak into "Goodbye Columbus"). Then a screening at a local film museum beckoned - Finally I could see this film, except now I was as old as my parents were when they schlepped to see it!!

The ONLY reason this film was not condemned to the anonymous sands of time was because of the obscenity case sparked by its U.S. release. MILLIONS of people flocked to this stinker, thinking they were going to see a sex film...Instead, they got lots of closeups of gnarly, repulsive Swedes, on-street interviews in bland shopping malls, asinie political pretension...and feeble who-cares simulated sex scenes with saggy, pale actors.

Cultural icon, holy grail, historic artifact..whatever this thing was, shred it, burn it, then stuff the ashes in a lead box!

Elite esthetes still scrape to find value in its boring pseudo revolutionary political spewings..But if it weren't for the censorship scandal, it would have been ignored, then forgotten.

Instead, the "I Am Blank, Blank" rhythymed title was repeated endlessly for years as a titilation for porno films (I am Curious, Lavender - for gay films, I Am Curious, Black - for blaxploitation films, etc..) and every ten years or so the thing rises from the dead, to be viewed by a new generation of suckers who want to see that "naughty sex film" that "revolutionized the film industry"...

Yeesh, avoid like the plague..Or if you MUST see it - rent the video and fast forward to the "dirty" parts, just to get it over with.
rewritten_review:
Oh, brother...after hearing about this ridiculous film for years, all I can think of is that old Peggy Lee song... "Is that all there is??" I was an early teen when this smoked fish hit the U.S., too young to get in the theater. Then a local film museum screening beckoned—finally, I could see this film, except now I was as old as my parents were when they saw it!

The ONLY reason this film wasn't forgotten was due to the obscenity case sparked by its U.S. release. MILLIONS flocked to this stinker, expecting a sex film... Instead, they got closeups of gnarly Swedes, bland mall interviews, asinine political pretension, and feeble simulated sex scenes with saggy actors.

Cultural icon, holy grail, historic artifact... whatever it was, shred it, burn it, stuff the ashes in a lead box! Elite esthetes still scrape for value in its pseudo-revolutionary spewings. Without the censorship scandal, it would've been ignored.

The "I Am Blank, Blank" title got repeated endlessly, a titillation for films like I Am Curious, Lavender, or I Am Curious, Black. Every ten years, it rises for a new generation of suckers wanting to see the "naughty sex film" that "revolutionized the industry."

Yeesh, avoid like the plague. Or if you MUST see it, rent the video and fast forward to the "dirty" parts, just to get it over with.

text:
A holiday on a boat, a married couple, an angry waiter and a shipwreck is the reason to this films beginning.

I like boobs. No question about that. But when the main character allies with whoever happens to have the most fish at the moment, mostly by having sex with them and playing the role of the constant victim, my anger just rises to a whole new level. Take two guys (a husband and another man), put a pure bombshell woman in the middle of them, ad a deserted island, subtract all her moral issues, ad a whole bunch of moral issues to the men and mix it in a big bowl of arguments, fish and a zippo lighter and you will come up with a piece of junk movie like this.

The acting is, I would say, good. There are some bloopers but not many as far as i could see. The main female character makes me sick. This is due to her lack of moral values. The man with the most fish get's her attention. Even though one of them is her husband, she sees no problem with being unfaithful with (Manuel) the other man because "I must do it to survive". How can you justify having sex with another man for fish when your husband is 30feet away? And he won't even benefit from it? The female character has absolutely no problems to justify anything that she does. If she doesen't get approval for her actions, she's a victim.

I recommend everyone to see this movie. This is the kind of movie that will make just about everything else you see this year a pleasant movie experience.

The acting is good. There are some bloopers, but not many as far as I could see. The main female character makes me sick due to her lack of moral values. How can you justify having sex with another man for fish when your husband is 30 feet away? And he won't even benefit from it? The female character has no problems justifying anything she does. If she doesn't get approval for her actions, she's a victim. I recommend everyone see this movie. This movie will make just about everything else you see this year a pleasant movie experience.

text: This was a silly movie with a predictable storyline and dreadful acting!! Willy Nelson was as stiff as his braids. The movie just seemed like a very long advert for the bright red lipstick that Jessica Simpson wore - especially as there were so many close-ups on her face. The premise was not amusing and as I said - soooooooo predictable. Whatever money was spent on making this movie was a shameful waste. Any allusions to other old Marilyn Monroe movies did not enhance the viewing of Blonde Ambition at all. It was also so unbelievable - Jessica Simpson being able to step into an executive secretary position at the drop of a hat - that was laughable!!!
rewritten_review: This was an incredibly silly movie with a completely predictable storyline and utterly dreadful acting!! Willy Nelson was as stiff as his braids throughout the entire film. The movie just seemed like a very long advert for the bright red lipstick that Jessica Simpson wore - especially as there were so many close-ups on her face that it was impossible not to notice. The premise was not in the least bit amusing and as I previously mentioned - it was soooooooo predictable. Whatever money was spent on making this movie was a shameful waste, and it truly baffles me how much was likely invested in such a lackluster production. Any allusions to other old Marilyn Monroe movies did not enhance the viewing of Blonde Ambition at all, and in fact, they only served to highlight the stark contrast in quality. It was also so unbelievably far-fetched - Jessica Simpson being able to step into an executive secretary position at the drop of a hat - that was absolutely laughable!!! The storyline lacked depth and originality, making it difficult to engage with on any meaningful level. It simply felt like a series of clichés strung together without any real effort to create something unique or entertaining. The acting was consistently flat, failing to bring any of the characters to life in a way that was remotely convincing or relatable. Overall, this film was a huge disappointment in every aspect, from the narrative to the performances, and it ultimately left a lot to be desired.

text: Insignificant and low-brained (haha!) 80's horror like there are thirteen in a dozen, yet it can be considered amusing if you watch it in the right state of mind. The special effects are tacky, the acting atrocious and the screenplay seems to miss a couple of essential paragraphs! "The Brain" takes place in a typical quiet-American town setting, where every adolescent works in the same diner and where the cool-kid in high school flushes cherry bombs down the toilet. It is here that a TV-guru named Dr. Blake and his adorable pet-brain begin their quest for nation-wide mind controlling. Under the label of "independent thinkers", a giant cheesy brain sends out waves through television sets and forces innocent viewers to kill! How cool is that? Now, it's up to the Meadowvale teen-rebel to save the world! The funniest thing about the plot is that it never explains where Dr. Blake and his monstrous brain actually come from. There are obvious references towards extraterrestrial life but that's about it. Meh, who needs a background in a movie like this, really? There's not that much bloodshed unfortunately and the "evil" brain looks like an over-sized sock-puppet. The only more or less interesting element for horror buffs is taking a look at the cast and crew who made this movie. Director Ed Hunt and writer Barry Pearson are the same men who made "Bloody Birthday" (guilty pleasure of mine) and "Plague". Both those are much better movies and they wisely decided to resign the film industry. The most familiar face in the cast unquestionably is the great David Gale, whom horror fans will worship forever for his role in Re-Animator. A girl named Christine Kossak provides the nudity-factor and she's obviously a great talent She has exactly 3 movies on her repertoire of which THIS is her "masterpiece". In her debut, she was credited as 'runaway model' and in "3 men and a baby", her character is referred to as 'one of Jack's girls'. I really wonder how she feels about her career as an actress

"The Brain" takes place in a typical quiet-American town where every adolescent works in the same diner and the cool-kid in high school flushes cherry bombs down the toilet. text:
The plot of Corpse Grinders 2 is very much similar to the original Corpse Grinders, what is left that is different from the other film consists of weird aliens.

It is my belief that this film would be the #1 worst film on IMDb - if anyone had actually watched it. The plot is disconnected and, in several (way too many) instances, makes absolutely no sense whatsoever. The real wonder here is why in the world was this sequel created to such an unsuccessful and horrendous (but still somewhat better) film.

I would highly recommend this film if you enjoy watching terrible movies for a good laugh.
rewritten_review: The plot of Corpse Grinders 2 is very much similar to the original Corpse Grinders, what is left that is different from the other film consists of weird aliens. It is my belief that this film would be the #1 worst film on IMDb - if anyone had actually watched it. The plot is disconnected and, in several (way too many) instances, makes absolutely no sense whatsoever. The real wonder here is why in the world was this sequel created to such an unsuccessful and horrendous (but still somewhat better) film. The original Corpse Grinders already set a very low bar for quality, and yet, somehow, this sequel managed to dive even deeper into the realm of cinematic absurdity. From the very beginning, viewers are subjected to a series of nonsensical plot twists and turns that defy any semblance of logic or coherence. It's as if the filmmakers threw together a collection of random scenes without any regard for storytelling or structure. In several instances, the film seems to actively challenge the audience to make sense of its bewildering narrative choices. The introduction of weird aliens serves only to further confuse and complicate an already tangled storyline. It's almost impressive how the film manages to sustain such a level of absurdity throughout its entire runtime. Despite these glaring issues, or perhaps because of them, Corpse Grinders 2 holds a certain charm for those who revel in the art of watching truly terrible movies. There's a kind of misguided ambition in its execution that makes it a fascinating train wreck to behold. It's difficult to fathom why anyone would greenlight a sequel to an already unsuccessful and horrendous film, yet here it is, existing in all its bizarre glory. For those who appreciate the art of the "so-bad-it's-good" genre, this film is a treasure trove of unintentional comedy and head-scratching moments. I would highly recommend this film if you enjoy watching terrible movies for a good laugh.

text:
This movie answers the question, how does a relationship survive when your girlfriend is codependent, clinging, needy, jealous .. and has powers and abilities far beyond those of mortal women?

Without spoiling the movie, I can safely assure you it does not, but there's great fun to be had along the way. Uma Thurman is perfect as the mercurial super-heroine, an uber-babe, mysteriously named G-Girl, who unlike most in her sisterhood, is not *always* dedicated to truth, justice, and the American Way.

Thurman is also believable as the thoroughly daft, yet somehow still fetching, curator Jenny. When she is dumped for a less endowed but more emotionally secure and well adjusted rival, G-Girl goes ballistic, and what follows is not pretty. It's funny, but it's not pretty ..

It's a delightful premise, hell hath no fury like a super-heroine scorned, and those involved don't altogether carry it off, but it has its moments, and I think I'll get the DVD.

I liked this movie ..
rewritten_review: This movie explores how a relationship survives when your girlfriend is codependent, clingy, needy, jealous, and has powers beyond mortal women. Without spoiling it, I can assure you it doesn't, but there's great fun along the way. Uma Thurman is perfect as the mercurial superheroine, G-Girl, who isn’t always dedicated to truth, justice, and the American Way. Thurman is also believable as the daft yet fetching Jenny. When she's dumped for a more emotionally secure rival, G-Girl goes ballistic, and it's funny but not pretty. The premise is delightful, hell hath no fury like a scorned superheroine, and while not perfectly executed, it has its moments. I think I'll get the DVD. I liked this movie.

text: Cinderella In my opinion greatest love story ever told i loved it as a kid and i love it now a wonderful Disney masterpiece this is 1 of my favorite movies i love Disney. i could rave on and on about Cinderella and Disney all day but i wont i ll give you a brief outline of the story. When a young girl's father dies she has to live with her evil step mother and her equally ugly and nasty step sisters Drusilla and Anastasia. Made to do remedial house chores all day poor Cinderella has only the little mice who scurry around the house and her dog Bruno as friends. When one day a letter is sent to her house telling all available women to attend a royal ball. Cinderellas evil step mother and step sisters try to prevent her attendance Cinderella finally gets her dream and wish and is able to attend her captive beauty , Genorisity and beautiful nature help her win her prince.
rewritten_review:
Cinderella, in my opinion, is the greatest love story ever told. I loved it as a kid, and I love it now. A wonderful Disney masterpiece, this is one of my favorite movies. I love Disney. I could rave on and on about Cinderella and Disney all day, but I won't. I'll give you a brief outline of the story. When a young girl's father dies, she has to live with her evil stepmother and her equally ugly and nasty stepsisters, Drusilla and Anastasia. Made to do remedial house chores all day, poor Cinderella has only the little mice who scurry around the house and her dog, Bruno, as friends. When one day a letter is sent to her house telling all available women to attend a royal ball, Cinderella's evil stepmother and stepsisters try to prevent her attendance. Cinderella finally gets her dream and wish and is able to attend. Her captive beauty, generosity, and beautiful nature help her win her prince.

Cinderella's story is truly enchanting. The way she endures all the hardships with grace and kindness is inspiring. Despite the cruelty of her stepmother and stepsisters, Cinderella never loses her gentle spirit. Her friendship with the little mice and her dog, Bruno, adds a touch of warmth and humor to the story, showing that even in difficult times, true friends can make a world of difference. The arrival of the royal ball invitation marks a turning point in Cinderella's life. Her determination to attend the ball, despite the obstacles thrown her way, is a testament to her resilience and hope. The magical transformation by her fairy godmother is a moment of pure wonder, symbolizing the idea that dreams can come true with a little bit of faith and magic.

At the ball, Cinderella captivates everyone with her beauty and grace, especially the prince. Their connection is immediate and undeniable, a true fairy tale moment. The love story that unfolds is timeless and heartwarming, reminding us of the power of love and kindness. Even when the clock strikes midnight, and Cinderella must leave, the memory of her beauty and spirit lingers with the prince. The search for the mysterious girl who stole his heart leads to a joyful and satisfying conclusion, proving that true love will always find a way.

Cinderella's tale is a celebration of hope, resilience, and the belief that love conquers all. It's a story that has resonated with audiences for generations, and its timeless message continues to inspire. Disney's adaptation beautifully captures the magic and wonder of this classic tale, making it a beloved masterpiece for all ages. Cinderella's journey from rags to riches, from hardship to happiness, is a testament to the enduring power of love and the triumph of the human spirit.

text:
Jenny Lewis plays an awkward girl called Jade. She smokes and drinks. She doesn't have a lot of friends and she has a nagging mother(Beverly D'Angelo). Jade finds herself growing closer to her mom's boyfriend Billy(Rob Estes), maybe she is attracted to him. Of course, I don't need to tell you what happens after that.

This is probably my favorite TV movie. This movie shows that sometimes everyone is to blame. This movie also has the best acting that I have seen in TV movies. Beverly D'Angelo does a really nice job as a sweet and loving but neglectful and blind mother. She couldn't see what was going on under her own roof. Rob Estes is at his best here as the sleazeball. Jenny Lewis is the standout. She seems to be exactly like her character.

Everyone seems to love this movie!
rewritten_review:
Jenny Lewis plays an awkward girl called Jade in this captivating TV movie. Jade is a character who smokes and drinks, embodying the struggles of a young girl navigating a challenging phase of her life. She doesn't have a lot of friends, which adds to her sense of isolation and vulnerability. Her relationship with her mother, played by Beverly D'Angelo, is complex—her mother is portrayed as nagging, yet there's a deeper layer of emotional neglect. Beverly D'Angelo does an exceptional job of bringing this sweet and loving but neglectful and blind mother to life. Jade finds herself growing closer to her mom's boyfriend, Billy, played by the talented Rob Estes. There is a subtle tension that builds as Jade grapples with her feelings, and perhaps she is attracted to him. Of course, I don't need to tell you what happens after that, but the storyline takes intriguing turns that keep viewers engaged.

This is probably my favorite TV movie, and for good reason. It explores intricate family dynamics and personal struggles, painting a vivid picture of how sometimes everyone is to blame for the ensuing chaos. This movie stands out not only for its compelling narrative but also for the outstanding performances by the cast. The movie showcases some of the best acting that I have seen in TV movies, which elevates its impact significantly. Beverly D'Angelo delivers a nuanced performance, capturing the essence of a mother who is loving yet blind to what is happening under her own roof. Her performance adds depth to the story, making the audience sympathize with her character's plight.

Rob Estes is at his best here, portraying the sleazeball character of Billy with convincing ease. He brings complexity to his role, making it both believable and engaging. However, Jenny Lewis is the true standout in this film. She seems to embody her character, Jade, with such authenticity that it's as if she becomes Jade. Her portrayal adds an emotional weight to the film, making her character's journey all the more compelling and relatable.

Everyone seems to love this movie, and it's easy to see why. It strikes a chord with audiences through its powerful storytelling and remarkable performances, ensuring it remains a memorable and impactful viewing experience.

text: This is so exciting! After I saw "La Roue" this afternoon, a short, light-hearted little movie, I consider this one a real treat! This is absolutely delightful and one of the most charming pictures I saw this year. It is the more amazing since it is an early talkie and puts some great pictures of the 30's to shame due to its innovative use of sound in cinema. It's simply filled with music and an adorable mood that's really upbeat and, bottom line, it made me happy! Obviously it wouldn't be so difficult to retrieve the lottery ticket the male lead was looking for, but the pace is so exhilarating and the movie is so spectacularly entertaining that I didn't even think of it twice. The comedy is many times hilarious and I think it is even superior to the Marx Brothers, possibly the biggest comedic force of the time. This is rather perfect.
rewritten_review: This is so exciting! After I saw "La Roue" this afternoon, a short, light-hearted little movie, I consider this one a real treat! This is absolutely delightful and one of the most charming pictures I saw this year. It is the more amazing since it is an early talkie and puts some great pictures of the 30's to shame due to its innovative use of sound in cinema. It's simply filled with music and an adorable mood that's really upbeat and, bottom line, it made me happy! The way the film combines its elements is nothing short of a cinematic ballet, each scene flowing seamlessly into the next with a rhythm that keeps you engaged and entertained throughout its entire duration. The characters are vibrant and full of life, each contributing to the overarching sense of joy and whimsy that permeates the film. Obviously it wouldn't be so difficult to retrieve the lottery ticket the male lead was looking for, but the pace is so exhilarating and the movie is so spectacularly entertaining that I didn't even think of it twice. The comedy is many times hilarious and I think it is even superior to the Marx Brothers, possibly the biggest comedic force of the time. The dialogue is snappy and clever, the kind that makes you chuckle with delight as you hang on every word, while the physical comedy is executed with such precision and flair that it elevates the entire film to another level. This is rather perfect.

text: I bought this DVD as part of a set of 50 "historic classics." It's hardly a classic, and as the plot was updated to the time of its release, is not historic either. The actual title on the DVD is "Indecent," and additionally subtitled "The Private Life of Becky Sharp." Myrna Loy is not very convincing, although in her defense she is saddled with an awful script and trite dialogue. As with many early talkies, and especially ones made by smaller studios, there is little skill demonstrated by the cast and crew. Loy does wear a few gowns that are quite stylish, but her costumes and make-up in the later scenes are overdone. The one saving grace is a tolerable performance by Billy Bevan, who plays one of her many suitors
rewritten_review: I bought this DVD as part of a set of 50 "historic classics." It's hardly what one might consider a classic, and as the plot was updated to the time of its release, it doesn't fit the description of being historic either. The actual title on the DVD is "Indecent," and it is additionally subtitled "The Private Life of Becky Sharp." Myrna Loy is not very convincing in her role, although in her defense she is saddled with an awful script and trite dialogue throughout the film. As with many early talkies, and especially ones made by smaller studios, there is little skill demonstrated by both the cast and crew. Loy does wear a few gowns that are quite stylish and eye-catching, but unfortunately, her costumes and make-up in the later scenes are overdone and detract from the overall presentation. The one saving grace in this film is a tolerable performance by Billy Bevan, who plays one of her many suitors. His performance stands out as a slight beacon of hope in an otherwise lackluster production.

text: First off, the title character is not even the main character of the movie. He is the sidekick of the cult leader. The actor who portrays Igor believed that screaming loud, laughing hysterically, and having a crooked smile while bugging out your eyes would be an excellent way to scare people. Igor also had the annoying habit of yelling (because he never actually just spoke) in a high pitched voice. He would also say idiotic one-liners. For example when the cult leader murders one of his followers with a buzz saw, Igor upon seeing this, yells out "Paul! No Paul! Why'd you do it? I could have cut her clean! So clean!" In another scene Igor tells a victim that she would have to 'get her own tools for surgery because right now, it was his time to operate.' Aside from the bad acting, the ending did not make sense because while the story builds up what little steam it has towards the climax, which is Igor getting a crossbow arrow to the head and the rest of his lunatic buddies being killed, he shows up again two more times to kill the remaining 'good guys'. The movie offers no explanation of this, only telling the viewer that Igor escaped from the mental hospital. What??? Bottom line is do not waste your time watching this movie. I wish I could get back the moments I lost watching this.
rewritten_review: The title character isn't even the main character. He's the sidekick of the cult leader. The actor playing Igor thought screaming, laughing hysterically, and having a crooked smile while bugging out his eyes would be scary. Igor yelled in a high-pitched voice and spouted idiotic one-liners. For example, when the cult leader murders someone with a buzz saw, Igor yells, "Paul! No Paul! Why'd you do it? I could have cut her clean! So clean!" In another scene, Igor tells a victim to 'get her own tools for surgery because it's his time to operate.' Besides the bad acting, the ending made no sense. The story builds towards Igor getting a crossbow arrow to the head and his lunatic buddies being killed, yet he shows up two more times to kill the remaining 'good guys.' The movie offers no explanation, only stating Igor escaped from the mental hospital. What??? Bottom line, don't waste your time on this movie. I wish I could get back the moments I lost watching this.

text:
Hello, this little film is interesting especially for an artist, film-maker or music creator or a visual artist, for:

One can feel and examine David's touch/style straight out of a short piece of relative simplicity.

You can see the rhythmic spacing of the shots, the pans and the sound elements.

Even as simple film, this creation is multy-layer. For example, there are some sounds that drone all along, while others appear (though subtle), at certain points to support certain shots.

One can see also several types of pans: some go up and down in a gentle back-forth way. There is diagonal pan. Zooms also go back and forth sometimes.

The lightning and the composition/disposition of elements in the space is, as usual and obviously, work of a painer/artist. This can be felt even in this crappy room. This is to say: one can make exquisite art already by the simple art of placing the look/view and composing the scene. Then comes the forcelines of the visuals: like digonales, parallels, etc. The light's degradées and the colours, although without too much research for textures as in big productions, are fine too. This is an artist's sketch of a sort...

All this is not calculated but done with inner feeling and this feel gives the David's touch/feel to it, as with any true artist.
rewritten_review: This little film is particularly interesting for artists, filmmakers, music creators, or visual artists. One can immediately recognize David's touch/style, even in a simple piece. The rhythmic spacing of shots, pans, and sound elements create a multi-layered experience. Continuous droning sounds are complemented by subtle ones at specific moments, enhancing certain shots. Various pans, including gentle back-and-forth, diagonal, and zooms, enrich the visual language. The lighting and composition reveal the work of a painter/artist, even in a simple setting. The art of placing the view and composing the scene demonstrates exquisite creativity. Visual force lines like diagonals and parallels, along with fine light gradients and colors, contribute to this artistic sketch. It's done with an inner feeling that gives it the distinct David touch, characteristic of any true artist.

text: This movie was so poorly written and directed I fell asleep 30 minutes through the movie. The jokes in the movie are corny and even though the plot is interesting at some angles, it is too far fetched and at some points- ridiculous. If you are 11 or older you will overlook the writing in the movie and be disappointed, but if you are 10 or younger this is a film that will capture your attention and be amazed with all the stunts (which I might add are poorly done) and wish you were some warrior to. The casting in this movie wasn't very good, and the music was very disappointing because it was like they were trying to build up the tension but it didn't fit at all. On a scale of 1-10 (10 being excellent, 1 being horrible) the acting in this movie is a 4. Brenda Song is talented in comedy, but with this kind of movie, in some of the more serious scenes, her acting was laughable. When she made some of her "fighting" poses, I started laughing out loud. I think the worst thing about this movie is definitely the directing, for example, the part where her enemy turns out to be the person the evil villain is possesing, how her voice turns dark and evil, I think that was incredibly stupid, and how Wendy's (Brenda Song)teachers were all her teachers at school being possessed by monks, that was pretty ridiculous to. So to sumamrize it all, a disappointing movie, but okay if you're 10 or under.
rewritten_review: This movie was so poorly written and directed I fell asleep 30 minutes in. The jokes are corny, and the plot, while interesting at times, is too far-fetched and ridiculous. If you're 11 or older, you'll overlook the writing and be disappointed, but if you're 10 or younger, you'll be amazed by the stunts (poorly done) and wish to be a warrior too. The casting wasn't good, and the music was disappointing, trying to build tension but not fitting at all. On a scale of 1-10, the acting is a 4. Brenda Song is talented in comedy, but in serious scenes, her acting was laughable. Her "fighting" poses made me laugh out loud. The worst part is definitely the directing; for example, when her enemy is possessed by the villain, and her voice turns dark and evil, it was incredibly stupid. Wendy's teachers being possessed monks was ridiculous too. To summarize, a disappointing movie, but okay if you're 10 or under.

text:
At the 2005 Phoenix Film Festival, it was no secret which film ranked at the top of everyone's viewing list. Checking Out (2004)brought crowds of film lovers to Scottsdale's Harkins Cine-capri. Festival attendees who waited in line for hours, were turned away at the door, despite the two-theater screening capacity.

Checking Out (2004) is a beautifully-made moving picture; an inspiring comedy for a wide-range of audiences to enjoy. The director, Jeff Hare, blends traditional film technique with a new twist of creativity, capturing Peter Falk at his greatest and most sentimental moments (usually shown in intimate close-up shots) on the silver screen.

With its uplifting mix of witty humor and narrative plot development, Checking Out (2004) is a landmark independent film, well-deserving of your attention.
rewritten_review:
At the 2005 Phoenix Film Festival, it was no secret which film ranked at the top of everyone's viewing list. Checking Out (2004) brought crowds of film lovers to Scottsdale's Harkins Cine-capri. Festival attendees who waited in line for hours, were turned away at the door, despite the two-theater screening capacity. This overwhelming demand for the film speaks volumes about its impact and the anticipation that surrounded its screening at the festival. It was a testament to the film's ability to draw in audiences from all walks of life, eager to experience its unique charm and storytelling.

Checking Out (2004) is a beautifully-made moving picture; an inspiring comedy for a wide-range of audiences to enjoy. The director, Jeff Hare, blends traditional film technique with a new twist of creativity, capturing Peter Falk at his greatest and most sentimental moments (usually shown in intimate close-up shots) on the silver screen. The film's ability to balance humor with heartfelt moments is a testament to the director's skill and vision. Jeff Hare's direction brings out the best in Peter Falk, allowing audiences to connect with the character on a deeper level and appreciate the nuances of his performance. The film's cinematography further enhances these moments, drawing viewers into the emotional core of the story and leaving a lasting impression.

With its uplifting mix of witty humor and narrative plot development, Checking Out (2004) is a landmark independent film, well-deserving of your attention. The film's script is cleverly written, providing a perfect blend of comedy and drama that keeps audiences engaged from start to finish. Its narrative structure is both innovative and accessible, making it a standout piece in the world of independent cinema. The film not only entertains but also prompts reflection, resonating with viewers long after the credits roll. Its ability to engage and move audiences is a testament to its quality and the dedication of everyone involved in its creation. The film's success at the Phoenix Film Festival is a reflection of its universal appeal and the joy it brings to those who watch it.

text: I would watch this movie every time it was on cable and it never got old. Who can forget some of the best lines in film history? --- JOHNNY'S FAT BOY BURGERS!! JOHNNY'S FAT BOY BURGERS!! and LOOK BETWEEN THE GIANT MELONS! I used to wish I could run all over the city in a treasure hunt as fun as this. It's an all-time fave and I'm happy to hear that it's out on video! I'm positive that this is where MTV got its original premise for the Road Rules series.
rewritten_review:
I would watch this movie every time it was on cable and it never got old. It's one of those films that, no matter how many times you see it, always brings back a sense of nostalgia and excitement. Who can forget some of the best lines in film history? They are iconic and have become etched in my memory. --- JOHNNY'S FAT BOY BURGERS!! JOHNNY'S FAT BOY BURGERS!! The enthusiasm and energy in that line are just unmatched. And then there's LOOK BETWEEN THE GIANT MELONS! Such a classic moment that never fails to make me laugh. These lines have become part of my movie-watching lexicon, and they always bring a smile to my face when I think about them.

I used to wish I could run all over the city in a treasure hunt as fun as this. The idea of embarking on such a wild and adventurous journey always seemed so thrilling and exhilarating. It's like a dream come true for anyone who loves adventure and excitement. The way the movie captures that sense of adventure is truly remarkable, and it makes you want to be a part of it. It's an all-time fave and I'm happy to hear that it's out on video! Having the ability to watch it whenever I want is such a treat. The film has a timeless quality to it, and it's one of those movies that you can watch over and over again without ever getting tired of it.

I'm positive that this is where MTV got its original premise for the Road Rules series. The similarities are undeniable, and it's fascinating to think about how this movie might have inspired such a popular and long-running show. The impact it has had on pop culture is evident, and it just goes to show how influential this film has been.

text:
Vanaja (2006), written and directed by Rajnesh Domalpalli, is an extraordinary film from South India. Mamatha Bhukya plays 15-year-old Vanaja, who lives in a rural area with her loving but alcoholic father. If she is going to succeed in life, she will have to overcome the liabilities of low caste and poverty.

I went to the film expecting the depiction of an wretched girl who is crushed by society. This isn't what "Vanaja" shows us. The young woman is attractive, intelligent, and ambitious. She won't accept her fate with tears or simple resignation. She wants to succeed, and it's never clear that she won't succeed, despite the odds.

The acting that Mr. Domalpalli draws forth from his cast of amateurs is miraculous. Mamatha Bhukya is outstanding in the title role, and Urmila Dammannagari does an exceptional job as Mrs. Rama Devi, the wealthy landowner who is a formerly famous classical dancer.

In the film Vanaja learns South Indian classical dance, as she did in real life. I couldn't tell how good Vanaja's dancing was by Indian standards, but the many dance scenes were spellbinding. (Don't think Bollywood--this is classical dance. It's also very different from ballet, because in ballet the dancer lifts her heels away from the floor. In Sound Indian dance, the heel is the primary contact point.)

This is a movie that is not to be missed. It will work on DVD, but will be better on a theater screen because the dancing will be shown to better advantage. However, if DVD is your only option, then see it that way. Just be sure to see it.
rewritten_review:
Vanaja (2006), written and directed by Rajnesh Domalpalli, is an extraordinary film from South India. Mamatha Bhukya plays 15-year-old Vanaja, who lives with her loving but alcoholic father. To succeed in life, she must overcome the challenges of low caste and poverty.

I expected a depiction of a wretched girl crushed by society, but "Vanaja" shows a young woman who is attractive, intelligent, and ambitious, refusing to accept her fate. The acting from the amateur cast is miraculous. Mamatha Bhukya is outstanding, and Urmila Dammannagari excels as Mrs. Rama Devi, a wealthy landowner and former classical dancer.

Vanaja learns South Indian classical dance, as she did in real life. The dance scenes are spellbinding, distinct from Bollywood and ballet, with the heel as the primary contact point in South Indian dance.

This movie is not to be missed. It works on DVD but is better on a theater screen for the dancing. If DVD is your only option, see it that way—just be sure to see it.

Well.. we can all see that he not only failed, but he fell aaall the way down. rewritten_review: I saw this movie a time ago, because some of my friends wanted to rent it, and I got voted down. I remember feeling a bit hesitant about watching it, but I decided to go along with my friends' choice. I tried as best I could to get the story, because some moviemag had said that this would be a movie that would be for Rob Lowe, that Pulp Fiction had been for John Travolta. I was intrigued by this comparison and thought maybe there was something special about it. Well, we can all see that he not only failed, but he fell aaall the way down. Over the years, I've come across many movies that didn't quite hit the mark, but this one truly stands out in terms of how poorly it was executed. It's just not even worth seeing for free on TV. Even if you find yourself with nothing else to watch, I would suggest finding literally anything else to view, because this film was just a complete letdown from start to finish.

text: So it starts with a beautiful old house in the country. You have a group of people who get asked to come to this house and (not surprisingly) the caretakers always lock the gates at night for no apparent reason. Anywhoo, the people laugh, joke etc. This Dr tells them a spooky story of this woman and some kids. They get scared, they start to feel stuff. Oh no, a girl see's s ghost. Some more talking then this huge ghost comes and etc etc. This girl finds out that this ghost killed little kids and that she must free their souls, yeah yeah, blah blah. She does but, oh no, she dies as she does. And goes to heaven whilst this evil ghost goes to hell. Two people survive and escape the house. The script is terrible because a guy gets his head chopped off and Elanor (the one who dies saving the kids) says "oh no". The acting is wooden, the effects are crap and the set is a couple off rooms used over and over again. Basically if you like laughing at badly made films watch it, but if your looking for a scare then definitely give this film a miss. I was extremely disappointed when I watched this. A very big let down. My sister (who gets sacred very easily) got bored in this film it is appalling.
rewritten_review: The film starts with a beautiful old house in the country. A group of people are invited, and the caretakers lock the gates at night for no reason. They laugh and joke until a Dr. tells a spooky story about a woman and some kids. They get scared, and a girl sees a ghost. More talking, then a huge ghost appears. The girl learns the ghost killed kids and must free their souls. She does, but dies in the process, going to heaven while the evil ghost goes to hell. Two people survive and escape. The script is terrible; a guy gets his head chopped off, and Elanor (who dies saving the kids) says "oh no." The acting is wooden, effects are poor, and the set is reused rooms. It's a laughably bad film, not scary at all. I was extremely disappointed. Even my sister, who scares easily, got bored. It's appalling.

text:
Wow, I think the overall average rating of this film on this site is incredibly low. There's really no reason to dislike this film. "Michael" is a simple, but fairly original, and easily enjoyable romantic comedy. The plot involves a group of reporters/experts going to examine the mysterious appearance of an angel (John Travolta) in the midwest. The angel proves to be less saintly and more worldly than we would expect, and that's what makes it entertaining. His interest in women and the Beatles takes a new spin on the angel thing. The romantic side of this film involves Michael the angel trying to get Andie MacDowell and William Hurt together. The two of them may not have the all-time greatest on-screen chemistry, but they certainly have enough to make it work well. Everyone who has rated this film so low (a 5.4??), come on! The film is not that bad. In fact, I found it quite funny and memorable. Sure, it's not the best thing you'll ever see, but it's still good. This is a film I feel has been remarkably underrated. It's fun, romantic, and recommended by me.

*** out of ****
