text: I thought that Ice Age was an excellent movie! As a woman of 30, with no children, I still seem to really enjoy these humorous, witty animated movies. Sid is the best character I have seen in some time, better than Bartok in Anastasia (although he was really humorous, and I did not think that his character could be matched or even beaten) and even more humorous than Melman in Madagascar. I have seen the movie at least 15 times (I own it obviously) and I quote the movie at work (on many occasions...yes,still). My favourite scene is the part where Sid says "Oh, oh, oh, I love this game!" and Sid and Manny continue to figure out what the squirrel is trying to tell them about the "tigers"..."Pack of wolves, pack of bears, pack of fleas, pack of whiskers, pack of noses, pack a derm?, pack of lies, pack of troubles, pack a wallop, pack of birds, pack of flying fish..." or however that part goes! That is THE funniest part about the whole movie, although I also really enjoyed the humour behind "putting sloths on the map" and many other parts as well. The only animated movie that can remotely compare to Ice Age is "Brother Bear".
rewritten_review: I thought Ice Age was an excellent movie! As a 30-year-old woman with no children, I still really enjoy these humorous, witty animated movies. Sid is the best character I've seen in some time, even better than Bartok in Anastasia and more humorous than Melman in Madagascar. I've seen the movie at least 15 times (I own it) and quote it at work. My favorite scene is when Sid says "Oh, oh, oh, I love this game!" as he and Manny try to figure out what the squirrel is saying about the "tigers." That is the funniest part, though I also enjoyed the humor behind "putting sloths on the map." The only animated movie that can compare to Ice Age is Brother Bear.

text: This is a long lost horror gem starring Sydney Lassick ("Carrie" and others) and Barbara Bach. It is sometimes difficult to locate a copy of this film but it's worth it. This film is creepy yet cheesy at the same time. It seems that 3 young newswomen (Karen, Vicky, and Jennifer) travel to the small city of Solvang, California to cover a festival when a mix-up occurs involving their hotel room and they seek refuge at the home of Earnest Keller (Lassick) and his strange wife Virginia. Vickie stays behind, feeling ill, as the other 2 are off to film their story. She is soon murdered at the house, in a VERY cheesy way by some unknown force hiding in the ventilation system (she is decapitated by the closing cover of the vent as it comes crashing down on her while she is being tugged through and into the basement). Soon Karen returns and she is murdered in an even more brutal fashion by having her face rammed through the vent cover. Jennifer is fighting with her (ex?)lover in a rather boring sub plot and when she returns home, her hosts (whom by now we have discovered are brother and sister and that whatever it is that is in the basement is their son) devise a plot to try to murder her as well. Virgina does not totally agree with Earnest's plan to murder Jennifer but she is tricked into going into the basement where she meets Junior. Here the film turns almost comic as Junior (portrayed hysterically by Stephen Furst) is a deformed, mentally deficient, manchild whose actions and motions will cause a few chuckles even though it's supposed to be scary. This is where the pace of the film picks up and the ending is well done. The actors/actresses do a terrific job with the material especially Lassick, Furst, and Bach and although it's not the most horrifying film ever made it is highly entertaining!
rewritten_review: This long-lost horror gem stars Sydney Lassick and Barbara Bach. It's a creepy yet cheesy film that can be hard to find but is worth the effort. Three young newswomen—Karen, Vicky, and Jennifer—travel to Solvang, California, for a festival. A hotel mix-up leads them to stay with Earnest Keller (Lassick) and his strange wife Virginia. Vicky, feeling ill, stays behind and is soon murdered in a cheesy way by an unknown force in the ventilation system. Karen returns and is killed brutally by having her face rammed through the vent cover. Jennifer, dealing with a subplot involving her (ex?) lover, returns to find the hosts plotting her murder. Virginia is reluctant but is tricked into the basement, where she meets Junior, their son. The film turns almost comic as Junior, played hilariously by Stephen Furst, is a deformed, mentally deficient manchild. The pace picks up, and the ending is well done. The cast, especially Lassick, Furst, and Bach, do a terrific job with the material. Though not the most horrifying film, it is highly entertaining!

text: Vanaja is a film of superlatives. It has an exceptionally well thought-out cast with Mamatha being the crowning jewel, a superb production and possibly pre-production with Rajnesh at the helm, a fantastic journey of rural Southern India through the eyes of a 15 year old, a remarkable mixture of song and dance, traditional and modern, blended perfectly, and a beautiful backdrop of lush color of the flora and fauna that make up the magnificent experience. What a towering achievement for a debut director!! The casting was absolutely dead-on. I wish India would come out with more of such films. This film will remain as one of my top favorites for my entire life. 9/10.
rewritten_review:
"Vanaja" is a film of superlatives, a cinematic gem that stands out in every aspect. It has an exceptionally well thought-out cast, with Mamatha being the crowning jewel, bringing a depth and authenticity to her role that captivates the audience from start to finish. The film boasts a superb production and possibly pre-production, with Rajnesh at the helm, guiding the film with a visionary touch that is rarely seen, especially in debut directors. The narrative takes us on a fantastic journey through rural Southern India, seen through the eyes of a 15-year-old, offering a perspective that is both enlightening and heartwarming.

The film is a remarkable mixture of song and dance, seamlessly blending traditional and modern elements. This blend is executed so perfectly that it enhances the storytelling, adding layers of cultural richness and emotional depth. The musical sequences are not just interludes but integral parts of the narrative, highlighting the characters' emotions and the story's progression.

Adding to the film's allure is the beautiful backdrop of lush color provided by the flora and fauna, creating a visual experience that is truly magnificent. The cinematography captures the essence of the rural landscape, making it a character in its own right, and providing a stunning setting for the unfolding drama.

What a towering achievement for a debut director! Rajnesh has not only crafted a compelling story but has also paid meticulous attention to every detail, ensuring that the film resonates with authenticity and passion. The casting was absolutely dead-on, with each actor delivering performances that are both convincing and memorable. Mamatha's portrayal is particularly noteworthy, as she brings a nuanced performance that anchors the film.

I wish India would come out with more of such films, as "Vanaja" sets a high standard for storytelling and artistic expression. This film will remain as one of my top favorites for my entire life, a testament to its enduring impact and the emotional connection it fosters with its audience. It is a cinematic experience that leaves a lasting impression, deserving of every accolade it receives. 9/10.

text:
I'm glad I didn't pay to see 'The Wog Boy'.

I sat there hopefully waiting for something original and/or funny to happen.

It reminded me very much of those predictable English comedies of the 1970s.

I won't bother with a synopsis of the plot, I suggest you do something else for 90 minutes
rewritten_review: I'm glad I didn't pay to see 'The Wog Boy'. I sat there hopefully waiting for something original and/or funny to happen, but unfortunately, it never did. It reminded me very much of those predictable English comedies of the 1970s, which often relied on formulaic humor and clichéd situations. The experience left me feeling underwhelmed and disappointed, as I had anticipated a more engaging and entertaining film. I won't bother with a synopsis of the plot, because I genuinely feel it's not worth delving into the details. Instead, I suggest you do something else for 90 minutes that might be more rewarding or enjoyable. There are countless other activities or films that would likely offer a better use of your time. Whether it's reading a book, taking a walk, or watching a different movie, there are many alternatives that could provide a more satisfying experience. While I had hoped for a different outcome, sometimes it's best to acknowledge when something isn't worth the investment of time or money.

text: Basically an endearingly chintzy and moronic $1.50 version of the nifty early 80's subterranean creature feature favorite "The Boogens," this entertainingly schlocky cheapie centers on a nasty, squirmy, wriggling monster who makes an instant meal out of any unfortunate souls foolhardy enough to go poking around the notoriously off limits Gold Spike Mine. Your standard-issue motley assortment of intrepid boneheads -- hectoring hard-nosed mine boss, cute, but insipid blonde babe, feisty lady geologist, boozy, inexplicably Aussie-accented (!) seasoned old mine hand, charmless doofus, hunky, jolly guy, and, arguably the most annoying character of the uniformly irritating bunch, a nerdy bespectacled aspiring writer dweeb who's prone to speaking in flowery, melodramatic utterances -- trek into the dark, uninviting cave in search of gold. Naturally, these intensely insufferable imbeciles discover that the allegedly abandoned mine is the home of a deadly, ugly, multi-tentacled beast who in time honored hoary B-flick fashion proceeds to gruesomely bag the group one at a time. Directed, co-written, co-produced and co-edited with dumbfounding maladroitness by Melanie Anne Phillips, acted with dismaying flatness by a rank no-name cast, further marred by lethargic pacing, a drably meandering narrative, murky, under-lit, eye-straining cinematography, a shivery, redundantly thudding pseudo-John Carpenter synthesizer score, and a cruddy, herky-jerky stop motion animation wormoid thingie that's only quickly glimpsed at the very end of the movie, this extremely clunky, amateurish and hence quite delectably dreadful would-be scarefest commits all the necessary bad film missteps to qualify as a real four-star stinkeroonie.
rewritten_review: An endearingly chintzy and moronic $1.50 version of the nifty early 80's creature feature "The Boogens," this schlocky cheapie centers on a squirmy monster who devours anyone foolish enough to explore the off-limits Gold Spike Mine. A motley crew of boneheads -- the hectoring mine boss, insipid blonde, feisty geologist, boozy Aussie-accented old hand, charmless doofus, hunky guy, and a nerdy writer prone to melodrama -- search for gold. Naturally, they discover the mine houses a deadly, multi-tentacled beast that gruesomely bags them one by one. Directed, co-written, co-produced, and co-edited with maladroitness by Melanie Anne Phillips, acted flatly by a rank no-name cast, further marred by lethargic pacing, a meandering narrative, murky cinematography, a shivery pseudo-John Carpenter score, and a cruddy stop motion wormoid glimpsed only at the end, this clunky scarefest commits all the necessary bad film missteps to qualify as a four-star stinkeroonie.

text: After losing his cattle herd to a dishonest lawman, a trail boss winds up in the Yukon gold fields with a bad reputation and small chances of being able to return to the states. While there his fortunes take a turn for the best until a bad luck specter from the past comes calling. Good western with many favorite old faces in the lineup.
rewritten_review: After the unfortunate incident of losing his entire cattle herd to a deceitful and dishonest lawman, a seasoned trail boss finds himself navigating the rugged and challenging Yukon gold fields. This new environment presents not only physical challenges but also societal ones, as he now carries a tarnished reputation and faces limited opportunities to return to the states. Despite these daunting circumstances, his fortunes take an unexpected and remarkable turn for the best, offering him a glimmer of hope and a chance to rebuild his life. However, just as things begin to look up, a specter of bad luck from his past emerges, threatening to disrupt his newfound success and stability. This captivating western tale is made even more engaging by the presence of many favorite old faces in the lineup, bringing depth and familiarity to the story. With its rich narrative and well-loved characters, this film promises an entertaining experience for fans of the genre.

text:
Dictated by thin experience (of both life and industry) and no cash Sofia Coppola's early short is almost by necessity an observational piece set on a high school campus. The cast are rather weak and do not benefit from being shot in b&w (it's difficult to tell the characters apart). The sound editing does little to help a simple story of fickle teenage allegiance.

Yet there are one or two things to note. Inamongst the inconsistent editing the high school campus is filmed with a balance of aspirant wide and intimate close-up shots. The editing-to-music also creates an interest and momentum (without descent into the netherworld of the Music Video). Coppola clearly made an attempt to vary the pace of the film. The dramatic turn is cut fast and to-the-point and the second act is almost non-existent; we recognise it's actually been played out in tandem with the first, which is the point of the narrator-on-crutches trope (who is an otherwise curiously appended character in that first act).

Despite these notes it's an awkward short. 2/10
rewritten_review: Dictated by thin experience (of both life and industry) and no cash, Sofia Coppola's early short is almost by necessity an observational piece set on a high school campus. The cast are rather weak and do not benefit from being shot in b&w (it's difficult to tell the characters apart). The sound editing does little to help a simple story of fickle teenage allegiance. Yet there are one or two things to note. Inamongst the inconsistent editing, the high school campus is filmed with a balance of aspirant wide and intimate close-up shots. The editing-to-music also creates interest and momentum (without descent into the netherworld of the Music Video). Coppola clearly made an attempt to vary the pace of the film. The dramatic turn is cut fast and to-the-point, and the second act is almost non-existent; we recognise it's actually been played out in tandem with the first, which is the point of the narrator-on-crutches trope (who is an otherwise curiously appended character in that first act). Despite these notes, it's an awkward short. 2/10

text:
The beginning of this movie is excellent with tremendous sound and some nice humor, but once the film changes into animation it quickly loses its appeal.

One of the reasons that was so, at least for me, was that the colors in much of the animation are too muted, with too little contrast. It doesn't look good, at least on VHS. Once in a while it breaks out and looks great, but not often Also, the characters come and go too quickly. For example, I would have liked to have seen more of "Moby Dick." When the film starts to drag, however, it picks up again with the entrance of the dragon and then the film finishes strong.

Overall, just not memorable enough or able to compete with the great animated films of the last dozen years.
rewritten_review: The beginning of this movie is excellent with tremendous sound and some nice humor, but once the film changes into animation it quickly loses its appeal. The initial scenes are captivating and engaging, drawing you in with their superb audio and clever comedic elements. However, this promising start doesn't maintain its momentum throughout the entire film. One of the reasons that was so, at least for me, was that the colors in much of the animation are too muted, with too little contrast. It doesn't look good, at least on VHS. This lack of vibrancy in the color palette makes the scenes feel somewhat dull and lifeless, which is unfortunate because the potential for stunning visuals is clearly there. Once in a while it breaks out and looks great, but not often. These rare moments of visual brilliance are fleeting and leave you wishing there were more of them scattered throughout the film. Additionally, the characters come and go too quickly. For example, I would have liked to have seen more of "Moby Dick." The rapid introduction and departure of characters make it difficult to form any real connection with them or to fully appreciate their roles within the story. When the film starts to drag, however, it picks up again with the entrance of the dragon and then the film finishes strong. The dragon's entrance injects some much-needed energy into the narrative, reigniting interest and excitement. This shift in pace helps to salvage the latter part of the film, allowing it to end on a more positive note. Overall, just not memorable enough or able to compete with the great animated films of the last dozen years. While there are elements within this movie that are commendable, they aren't sufficient to elevate it to the level of the truly great animated films we've seen in recent years.

text:
Pierre Jolivet plays a Don Quixote character, unable to speak, living in a world incompatible with modern life. He trusts to his homemade weaponry - helmet, sleeves, and spear - made out of hubcaps, seat cushions, and discarded office furniture. Just as Don Quixote rode Rocicante, "The Man" rides his contraption (literally) transcending the lost lives caught up the harsh and demeaning modern world - soaring above the earth, away from the plight of modern man. Both characters ride in search of adventure in an effort to right the wrongs of the world. Both characters are guardian knights of values unfamiliar to most of the other characters in the story.

Unlike Cervantes's tale, in this movie we identify more directly with the anachronistic ideals of the main character. We can only compare this alien and forbidding landscape to the lush and beautiful world we live in. Our frame of reference is the fantasy realm which the lone knight perhaps remembers. Our vision would be one which expects the main character to triumph, to vanquish, to change his world (for the better) back into a world of plenty that no longer exists.

We look at this movie and see a true knight among a world of humans-as-animals. Don Quixote considered himself a true knight among animals.

With Cervantes's tale we can only see the dreamer, without really understanding the scope of his anachronistic displacement. In Besson's and Jolivet's tale we see the new world from the eyes of Don Quixote, because we value the same visions and ideals as the crusading main character.
rewritten_review:
Pierre Jolivet plays a Don Quixote character, unable to speak, living in a world incompatible with modern life. He trusts his homemade weaponry—helmet, sleeves, and spear—crafted from hubcaps, seat cushions, and discarded office furniture. Like Don Quixote rode Rocinante, "The Man" rides his contraption, transcending the lost lives caught in the harsh, demeaning modern world—soaring above the earth, away from the plight of modern man. Both characters seek adventure to right the world's wrongs, acting as guardian knights of values unfamiliar to most other characters.

Unlike Cervantes's tale, we identify more directly with the main character's anachronistic ideals. We compare this alien, forbidding landscape to the lush, beautiful world we live in. Our frame of reference is the fantasy realm the lone knight perhaps remembers. We expect the main character to triumph, vanquish, and change his world back into a world of plenty that no longer exists.

We see a true knight among a world of humans-as-animals. Don Quixote considered himself a true knight among animals. With Cervantes's tale, we see the dreamer without understanding his anachronistic displacement. In Besson's and Jolivet's tale, we see the new world from Don Quixote's eyes, valuing the same visions and ideals as the crusading main character.

text:
This film is about the complicated friendship, romance and deceit between two men and two women during the World War II.

A lot of effort has been put to make "The Edge of Love"look the right period. However, I find this effort too excessive, particularly in terms of the tone of the colours. Most of the first half of the film is processed so much to have a strong bluish tone. It's hard to make out who's who in this tone.

Another detrimental point is the fancy use of image splitting lens. There are many scenes that have three or four images of the same thing, such as three Keira Knightley smiling face or four pairs of arms in embrace. That simply makes the film confusing and hard to follow, instead of being artistic.

As for the plot, it is plain boring. The way the story unfolds is not engaging at all. Sienna Miller's unstable character is annoying. In fact all the main characters are annoying and unlikeable. Keira Knightley's accent is impossible to understand, making it a further impediment to understanding the plot.

I strongly advise avoiding "The Edge of Love", unless you watch a film only to appreciate great costumes, nice sets and lighting.
rewritten_review: This film explores the complicated friendship, romance, and deceit between two men and two women during World War II. While "The Edge of Love" puts a lot of effort into capturing the period, the excessive bluish tone makes it difficult to distinguish characters. The fancy use of image splitting lenses, showing multiple images of the same thing, adds confusion instead of artistry. The plot is plain boring, and the way the story unfolds is not engaging. Sienna Miller's unstable character and the unlikeable main characters, coupled with Keira Knightley's incomprehensible accent, further hinder understanding. I strongly advise avoiding "The Edge of Love" unless you're interested in costumes, sets, and lighting.

text: The plot has something about white hunters captured by a tribe of white women in the African jungle/ plains.Its a turkey and the some. What it really is is wildly mismatched footage from early sound and silent films mixed with badly shot recent(to the release) footage of men on a safari. There are scenes of a man in a gorilla suit, south seas natives at sea (used to represent people in the middle of Africa), women in bikini's, horrible narration and a guy in a loin cloth with make up all over his body (racially insensitive I think so). This is a movie to sit and make fun of- but only with lots of alcoholic drinks and witty friends. At any other time this is going to be a chore to get through. Its a bad bad bad movie. Beyond that I'm speechless
rewritten_review:
The plot has something about white hunters captured by a tribe of white women in the African jungle/plains. It's a turkey and then some. What it really is is wildly mismatched footage from early sound and silent films mixed with badly shot recent (to the release) footage of men on a safari. There are scenes of a man in a gorilla suit, south seas natives at sea (used to represent people in the middle of Africa), women in bikinis, horrible narration, and a guy in a loincloth with makeup all over his body (racially insensitive, I think so). This is a movie to sit and make fun of—but only with lots of alcoholic drinks and witty friends. At any other time, this is going to be a chore to get through. It's a bad, bad, bad movie. Beyond that, I'm speechless.

The film's plot is so thin and bizarre that it almost defies description. Imagine white hunters, who seem to have wandered into the wrong continent entirely, finding themselves captured by a tribe of white women who, for some inexplicable reason, have made their home in the African jungle or plains. It's a turkey, and then some. What the movie really is is a chaotic mishmash of mismatched footage, cobbled together from early sound films and silent films. This is then mixed with poorly shot recent footage, or at least recent at the time of its release, showing men on a safari. The scenes are so disjointed that it's hard to believe they were intended to be part of the same narrative. For example, there is a man in a gorilla suit, inexplicably thrown into the mix, as well as scenes of south seas natives at sea, inexplicably used to represent people supposedly in the middle of Africa. The absurdity doesn't end there; women in bikinis pop up randomly, adding to the hodgepodge of unrelated visuals. The narration is atrocious, adding yet another layer of comedy, albeit unintentionally. There's also a guy in a loincloth, his body covered in makeup that seems racially insensitive, to say the least. This movie is the kind of cinematic disaster that's best watched in the company of friends who are ready to provide witty commentary and plenty of alcoholic drinks. Without that, trying to get through this film is likely to be an exercise in patience and endurance, as it is, without a doubt, a bad, bad, bad movie. Beyond that, I'm speechless.

text:
This movie starts out great, and sucks you in. Most acting is good until Patrick Swayze (with his Texas Twang- everyone else sounds British-like even the Muslim) shows up, and proves that he can't act. You can live with that until the first fight scene where all they all fall to pieces. Why does Patrick Swayze fight baddies with an ax when he just stuck his sword into the ground 5 minutes ago.

There's further misplacing of swords a few minutes later, and people knowing about other people they shouldn't know about. Other reviewers mentioned "Troubled Production" and it shows.

At the end I just didn't even care about the fight scenes, sure, the CGI Dragon was weak, but the storyline was the biggest letdown.
rewritten_review:
This movie starts out great, and really sucks you in with its intriguing premise and captivating opening scenes. It manages to hold your attention with strong performances from most of the cast. The majority of the acting is genuinely good, and it keeps you engaged until Patrick Swayze makes his entrance. His character, complete with a Texas Twang that feels out of place, is a stark contrast to the rest of the cast, who sound distinctly British-like—even the Muslim character fits this tone. This disparity in accents is jarring and unfortunately highlights that Patrick Swayze, in this particular role, can't quite deliver a convincing performance. Despite this, you might be willing to overlook it until the first fight scene, where things take a turn for the worse. 

In this scene, everything seems to fall to pieces. The choreography is lacking, and the execution leaves much to be desired. It's puzzling why Patrick Swayze chooses to fight the baddies with an ax, especially considering he had just dramatically stuck his sword into the ground a mere five minutes earlier. This inconsistency is frustrating for viewers who are trying to follow the logic of the action sequences. 

A few minutes later, the film presents further confusion with the misplacing of swords, which occurs again, adding to the disjointed feeling of the narrative. Characters inexplicably seem to have knowledge about other people they shouldn't be aware of, which disrupts the story's coherence. Other reviewers have mentioned "Troubled Production," and this aspect is evident throughout the film. The lack of continuity and logical progression detracts from the overall experience. 

As the movie progresses, the storyline becomes increasingly muddled, and by the end, I found myself not even caring about the fight scenes, which should have been a highlight. The CGI Dragon, which could have been a redeeming feature, was unfortunately weak and did little to enhance the film. Ultimately, the storyline proved to be the biggest letdown, overshadowing any potential the movie had at its outset. Despite its promising start, the film fails to deliver a satisfying conclusion, leaving viewers disappointed.

text:
RKO Radio Pictures made a real classic in 1947 and even managed to get it nominated for the Best Picture Academy Award. The acting, script, continuity, et cetera, are all just about perfect; and the story is well worth the viewer's 82 minutes. Although the picture soft-petals the true life story by making the murder victim a Jew rather than a homosexual, most viewers will see the victim as a Jewish homosexual -- such disguises never work, perhaps weren't intended to.

I could nit-pick about a few details, but just for fun. There was no all-night movie house in Washington, DC in 1947 --- and if there was I wish Robert Mitchum and his pal wouldn't talk through the show. There weren't any bars where a GI could pick up a pretty blonde. NONE! If Robert Ryan wanted to read the latest murder scoop he ought to have bought the Daily News; not the Times-Hearald, Evening Star and certainly not the know-nothing Washington Post. But these little things take nothing away from this classic.

The film benefits a lot from the absolute lack of a musical score, except during the credits. I've only seen this done in a few films.

On the negative side, since 1995 it comes with a TMC introduction where some liberal blabs about what the public was "ready for" in 1947... blah, blah, blah! As if this fool has any business judging his betters. I'd say the ex-GI's in 1947 -- the Greatest Generation -- were much smarter --and had better values -- than some commentator, film historian, or other wise-mouth in 1995. Put a sock in it!
rewritten_review:
RKO Radio Pictures created a real classic in 1947, earning a Best Picture Academy Award nomination. The acting, script, and continuity are nearly perfect, and the story is engaging throughout its 82 minutes. While the film softens the true story by making the murder victim a Jew instead of a homosexual, viewers may perceive him as both.

I could nit-pick details for fun. There was no all-night movie house in Washington, DC in 1947, and if there was, I wish Robert Mitchum and his pal wouldn't talk through it. No bars existed where a GI could pick up a pretty blonde. NONE! Robert Ryan should have bought the Daily News to read the latest murder scoop, not the Times-Herald, Evening Star, or Washington Post. However, these details don't detract from this classic.

The film benefits from the absence of a musical score, except during the credits, a rarity in film. On the negative side, since 1995, it includes a TMC introduction with a liberal discussing what the public was "ready for" in 1947. As if this commentator has any business judging his betters. I'd argue the ex-GI's in 1947—the Greatest Generation—were much smarter and had better values than a commentator or film historian in 1995. Put a sock in it!

text: The ruins is to Turistas as Deep Impact was to Armageddon, a worse version of a mildly entertaining movie, except much much worse. One of the characters is supposed to be going to medical school, so why are they all retards? "you can't keep cutting." -best line form this movie. This is an awful movie. I like horror movies, but fully appreciate that most of them are terrible, but had a bit of high hopes for this movie after seeing the reviews on IMDb. The situation they are in is stupid and how they handle it makes them stupid. It is awful, the one thing that makes it somewhat palatable is its cool Australian backdrop, despite the fact that they spend the vast majority of the movie in one place.

text:
The movie is more about Pony than Grey Owl. It's also about aboriginals, Canada, the English, Grey Owl's aunts and the North Bay Nugget. Excellent story.

This is an excellent movie, more like a book, that raises interesting questions about cultural identity and values. The key scene is Grey Owl admitting his imposture to Pony and her reaction.

A few observations on the user ratings. Note that the user ratings are bi-polar clustering at 5 and 7; it's not for everyone, but has a strong following. This movie is underrated and overlooked but will be noticed for years to come. Also, few women have watched the movie but they rate it more highly than men. Has it been marketed properly?
rewritten_review:
The movie is more about Pony than Grey Owl. It's also about aboriginals, Canada, the English, Grey Owl's aunts, and the North Bay Nugget. Excellent story. This film delves deeply into the intricate dynamics of its characters and their surroundings, weaving a narrative that is as complex as it is engaging. In exploring these themes, it provides a rich tapestry of interactions and conflicts that drive the story forward, making it an unforgettable cinematic experience.

This is an excellent movie, more like a book, that raises interesting questions about cultural identity and values. The narrative structure allows for a profound exploration of these issues, encouraging viewers to reflect on the nature of identity and the values that define us. The key scene is Grey Owl admitting his imposture to Pony and her reaction. This pivotal moment encapsulates the film's central themes, offering a poignant commentary on authenticity and self-discovery. It is a scene that resonates deeply, leaving a lasting impression on the audience.

A few observations on the user ratings. Note that the user ratings are bi-polar clustering at 5 and 7; it's not for everyone, but has a strong following. This movie is underrated and overlooked but will be noticed for years to come. The stark contrast in ratings highlights the film's polarizing effect, suggesting that while it may not appeal to everyone, it has garnered a dedicated following among those who appreciate its unique approach and storytelling. Also, few women have watched the movie but they rate it more highly than men. This discrepancy raises questions about its marketing strategy and whether it has been effectively targeted to reach its potential audience. Has it been marketed properly? The film's marketing efforts may need to be reassessed to ensure it reaches a wider audience, particularly among those who are likely to appreciate its thematic depth and cultural significance.

text: The House of the Spirits is a gripping tale of family intrigue, South American politics and super-natural powers. Meryl Streep, Glenn Close and Jeremy Irons bring Isabel Allende's novel to life with all its passion and suspense. This, in my view, is one of the best films of the 1990s. Jeremy Irons as Esteban Trueba ages and mellows very believably, while Meryl Streep in the role of Clara maintains her gentle, loving warmth throughout her relatively short life. Winona Ryder and Antonio Banderas make a handsome couple struggling for family acceptance in a racist culture. Glenn Close, as Esteban's sister, gives a very moving performance. The countryside of Portugal is a reasonable substitute for a non-tropical Latin American country. Settings of Clara's home and Esteban's ranch are effective and the period US cars add nicely to the post-war atmosphere.
rewritten_review: "The House of the Spirits" is a gripping and captivating tale of family intrigue, South American politics, and supernatural powers. Meryl Streep, Glenn Close, and Jeremy Irons bring Isabel Allende's renowned novel to life with all its passion and suspense. This film, in my view, stands out as one of the best films of the 1990s. Jeremy Irons as Esteban Trueba ages and mellows very believably, creating a character arc that is both compelling and realistic. Meanwhile, Meryl Streep, in the role of Clara, maintains her gentle, loving warmth throughout her relatively short life, delivering a performance that resonates with grace and emotion. Winona Ryder and Antonio Banderas make a handsome couple, struggling for family acceptance in a racist culture, adding depth and complexity to the narrative. Glenn Close, as Esteban's sister, gives a very moving performance, embodying the struggles and emotions of her character with finesse. The countryside of Portugal serves as a reasonable substitute for a non-tropical Latin American country, providing a picturesque and authentic backdrop to the story. The settings of Clara's home and Esteban's ranch are effective, immersing the audience in the time and place of the narrative. Additionally, the period US cars add nicely to the post-war atmosphere, enhancing the film's historical context and authenticity. Overall, "The House of the Spirits" is a masterful adaptation that captures the essence of Allende's novel, brought to life by a talented cast and a meticulously crafted setting.

text:
I went into this film expecting it to be similar to The Matrix or Pi. Boy, was I wrong. Yes, there is a poorly written, poorly acted plot in the movie (with CG animated cells and peptides to boot). However, the real focus of the film are the "expert" talking heads spewing out new age feel-good hogwash in between plot segments.

Sure, it stars off innocently enough. There is a little bit of real quantum physics in the beginning. It states, for example, that electrons exist as both particle and wave, and that an atom is mostly empty space. However, the movie takes a giant (and unscientific) leap, saying that sub-atomic quantum effects happen on large scales as well. The talking heads take it even further. According to them, the following are true:

-When Columbus arrived in the Caribbean, the natives were unable to see his ships because their minds were incapable of perceiving something so different. -Meditation can reduce the murder rate. -With positive thought, you can walk on water. -Your thoughts can change the formations of ice crystals in bottles of water.

And hey, that's only in the first 40 minutes!

Watching the movie was torture. This film felt like a movie they would show you to get you to join a cult. After doing my homework, I realized that it basically is just that.

On the other hand, this could be seen as a campy comedy (albeit one that's not funny).

Save your time and money: don't see this movie.

text:
i really in enjoyed watching this movie. like most of the people that watched it. i wasn't sure that i was getting. Whoopi Goldberg is a very funny comedian and she has done a lot of funny movies; i.e. sister act.

however this was not really comedy. it is a drama with comedic moments. so if your looking for a laugh riot then keep looking.

this movie is about a black family moving up from a nice neighborhood in the city to an upper middle class neighborhood. i would say more but it think it would spoil the movie. this movie does not just deal with race relations between whites and blacks, but also about relations with in the black community. i do think that it is worth a chance. if your not really interested in see another movie about race relations then this movie isn't for you
rewritten_review:
I really enjoyed watching this movie, like most of the people who watched it. Initially, I wasn't sure what I was getting into. Whoopi Goldberg is a very funny comedian, and she has done a lot of funny movies, such as Sister Act, which is a classic comedy that many people love. Her comedic timing and ability to bring characters to life in a humorous way have always been a highlight of her career.

However, this was not really a comedy. It is a drama with comedic moments interspersed throughout, so if you're looking for a laugh riot, then you might want to keep looking elsewhere. The film has its humorous parts, but its core is more serious and thoughtful, exploring themes that are deeper and more reflective.

This movie is about a black family moving up from a nice neighborhood in the city to an upper middle class neighborhood. The transition they experience is central to the story, and it brings about a mix of emotions and challenges that the family must navigate. It is a journey that delves into their experiences and growth as they adapt to their new environment. I would say more about the plot, but I think it would spoil the movie for those who haven't seen it yet.

The movie does not just deal with race relations between whites and blacks, which is a significant theme, but it also explores relationships within the black community itself. This dual focus adds layers to the narrative and makes it a richer experience. The film examines how these relationships evolve and the complexities that arise within different social contexts.

I do think that it is worth giving this movie a chance. It offers a perspective that is engaging and thought-provoking. However, if you're not really interested in seeing another movie about race relations, then this movie might not be for you. It addresses these issues in a meaningful way, but for those seeking a different kind of story, it might not align with their interests. Overall, it's a film that presents a blend of drama and comedy, with a focus on important social themes.

text: This was a very funny movie, not Oscar-worthy, but definately the best dollar I've ever spent at Blockbuster! Rupert Penry Jones is a shining star, and very well might be the new Jude Law! So, if you're in the mood for a British Teen Flick- RENT IT!!
rewritten_review: This was a very funny movie, not Oscar-worthy, but definitely the best dollar I've ever spent at Blockbuster! I found myself pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed it. The film had a certain charm that really resonated with me. Rupert Penry Jones is a shining star, and his performance truly stands out as one of the highlights of the movie. His charisma and talent make him a joy to watch on screen, and he very well might be the new Jude Law! The way he carries the film with his presence is remarkable. So, if you're in the mood for a British Teen Flick, this is one you should definitely consider renting. It's a lighthearted and entertaining movie that provides a good escape. The humor is spot on, and it's a film that doesn't take itself too seriously, which is refreshing. RENT IT!!

text: I happened to catch this movie on cable one afternoon. I have to admit that I've never been a big baseball fan, but I can sometimes get into a good sports-related movie. What I found more interesting was the depiction of the foster family system. As a therapist who has seen both the good and the bad of the community mental health and foster system, I though it was rather refreshing to see a movie that showed both the ups and downs of this system: people jumping from family to family, biological parents not always taking an active involvement, and transitions that can be but heart-wrenching and heart-melting. Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Danny Glover are the anchor of this film, and both bring very believable performances. Maybe it was just my emotional state, but I did find myself shedding a tear at the end of the film.
rewritten_review: I happened to catch this movie on cable one afternoon, and it turned out to be quite an unexpected delight. I have to admit that I've never been a big baseball fan, as it's not really a sport that has ever captured my interest. However, I can sometimes get into a good sports-related movie, especially when it offers more than just the game itself. What I found more interesting and captivating about this film was its depiction of the foster family system, which was portrayed with a surprising amount of depth and sensitivity. As a therapist who has seen both the good and the bad of the community mental health and foster system, I thought it was rather refreshing to see a movie that showed both the ups and downs of this system. The film didn't shy away from the reality of people jumping from family to family, a situation that is all too common in the foster system. It also touched upon the often painful truth of biological parents not always taking an active involvement in their children's lives, which can lead to feelings of abandonment and hurt. Furthermore, the movie captured the transitions that can be both heart-wrenching and heart-melting, offering a balanced view that felt honest and genuine. Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Danny Glover are the anchor of this film, and both bring very believable performances that lend authenticity and warmth to the story. Their portrayals were nuanced and heartfelt, making the characters relatable and sympathetic. Maybe it was just my emotional state at the time, but I did find myself shedding a tear at the end of the film. The combination of the emotional storyline and the strong performances really struck a chord with me, leaving a lasting impression. Overall, it was a movie that not only entertained but also provided a thoughtful exploration of the foster care system, making it a worthwhile watch.

text:
First off, Mexican Werewolf in Texas' title is misleading as many others have pointed out. It is actually about El Chupacabra, which is a similar creature to a werewolf, but by no means the same.

The production and editing just plain suck. When it was over, I probably wouldn't be able to give a very accurate description of what exactly the Chupacabra looked like, for whenever it was in a scene(despite one or two exceptions) the camera turned all shaky and you could only see the monster's face clearly. The special effects were laughably bad, but that has to be expected from a low budget horror movie.

Along with the terrible production comes the bad actors. Now a couple give fairly plausible performances(Erika Fay and Martine Hughes), but then there were the bad actors(everybody else), who seemed to have no emotions whatsoever when people died. Then there's the absolutely terrible actor(Sara Erikson), who gives one of the 2 worst performances I've ever seen in a movie. I mean my god, she was indescribably bad.

The plot was very simple. Basically, a Chupacabra is in a small Texan town killing off local residents and a group of teens look to stop it. However, even with the plot being this simple, a few plot holes managed to leak through.

Anyways, horrible movie. However, if you are looking for a movie to make fun of and laugh at with your friends one night, this would be a pretty good one. My friends and I had a good time watching this. Probably the 2nd worst movie I've ever seen, 1/10. Awful.
rewritten_review:
The title "Mexican Werewolf in Texas" is misleading, as it's actually about El Chupacabra, not a werewolf. The production and editing are poor. It's hard to describe the Chupacabra because the camera gets shaky, and you only see its face clearly in one or two scenes. The special effects are laughably bad, which is expected from a low-budget horror movie.

The acting is also subpar. Erika Fay and Martine Hughes give plausible performances, but the rest of the cast lacks emotion, even during death scenes. Sara Erikson, in particular, delivers one of the worst performances I've ever seen.

The plot is simple: a Chupacabra is killing residents in a small Texas town, and a group of teens tries to stop it. Despite the simplicity, there are plot holes.

Overall, it's a horrible movie. However, if you want something to make fun of with friends, this could be entertaining. My friends and I enjoyed laughing at it. It's probably the second worst movie I've ever seen, 1/10. Awful.

text: I sat through almost one episode of this series and just couldn't take anymore. It felt as though I'd watched dozens of episodes already, and then it hit me.....There's nothing new here! I've heard that joke on Seinfeld, I saw someone fall like that on friends, an episode of Happy Days had almost the same storyline, ect. None of the actors are interesting here either! Some were good on other shows (not here), and others are new to a profession they should have never entered. Avoid this stinker!
rewritten_review: I sat through almost one entire episode of this series and just couldn't take anymore. It felt as though I'd watched dozens upon dozens of episodes already, and then it hit me.....There's simply nothing new here at all! I've heard that exact joke on Seinfeld, I saw someone fall just like that on Friends, and an episode of Happy Days had almost the exact same storyline, etc. None of the actors are interesting here either! Some of these actors were good on other shows (but definitely not here), and others are new to a profession they should have never entered. This is just one of those shows you should avoid at all costs! Avoid this stinker!

text:
Now this show looks like most of the other shows of it's type from the mid-90's, but the only thing is about this one is that it's different, they use a lot of comedy and action in this one and maybe a little bit of drama too. I personally thought it was a good show, I can't understand why would they cancel it. The good thing is that the fan base of this show is still alive ever since 1997 up to date.

My hopes is that the WB bring back the show or even do a movie, which I know is gonna be impossible to do, but hey it doesn't hurt to dream, doesn't it?

Anyway, I would recommend if you hadn't seen it to find the DVD of all 13 episodes, because the characters are great, the story lines are good, the comedy is good and well the whole show is just great.
rewritten_review:
Now this show looks like most of the other shows of its type from the mid-90s, but the only thing about this one is that it's different. They use a lot of comedy and action in this one, and maybe a little bit of drama too. I personally thought it was a good show, and I can't understand why they would cancel it. The good thing is that the fan base of this show is still alive ever since 1997 up to date. It's truly remarkable how a show can leave such a lasting impression on its viewers and maintain a dedicated following for so many years. The mix of comedy, action, and a touch of drama created a unique experience that resonated with many people.

My hopes are that the WB brings back the show or even does a movie, which I know is gonna be impossible to do, but hey, it doesn't hurt to dream, does it? Imagining a revival or a film adaptation brings a sense of excitement and nostalgia, even if it seems unlikely. Fans like me continue to hold onto the hope that one day, somehow, this beloved show might make a comeback in some form. The thought of seeing the characters and stories we love return to the screen is a dream worth holding onto, no matter how slim the chances.

Anyway, I would recommend, if you hadn't seen it, to find the DVD of all 13 episodes because the characters are great, the storylines are good, the comedy is good, and, well, the whole show is just great. Watching it again or discovering it for the first time can be a delightful experience. The charm of the characters and the cleverness of the storylines make it a series that deserves appreciation. Whether you're revisiting it or seeing it anew, the blend of humor, action, and drama offers something for everyone, making it a timeless series that continues to entertain. So, if you get the chance, grab the DVD and immerse yourself in the greatness of this show.

It seems like there is a lack of appreciation for the art form, and that’s something that truly saddens me. "Padurea Spanzuratilor" stands as a testament to what Romanian cinema can achieve, yet it feels as though it remains unrecognized by many. This film embodies everything a movie should be. The attention to detail in every frame, the depth of the script, and the clarity and quality of the picture are unrivaled, even after so many years. It’s a piece of art that has stood the test of time, and it continues to exemplify the pinnacle of cinematic achievement in our country. It’s disheartening to see that many do not share this sentiment or take the time to truly appreciate such artistry. I urge everyone to broaden their cinematic horizons and explore films that offer substance and quality. There’s a world of cinema out there that deserves to be seen and appreciated, and I hope one day the voters will recognize this and make more informed choices. Until then, I’ll keep hoping for a brighter future for Romanian cinema. KuDos, and I will see you later.

text:
Alain Resnais directs three parallel stories that have to do with fantasy and imagination in the adult world. In one of them is a sort of Operatic bordello story where a rejected architect attempts to manipulate a group of people into throes of happiness--only his attempt misses it's only real target, the woman that he pines after. In the same unfinished château he built, a group of teachers search for love in a more modern story, as one woman believes ineffably in the role of romance and the cynical anthropoligist tries to teach her a lesson by setting her up with the biggest jerk in the group. Meanwhile, a bunch of kids fantasize a George Melies-like adventure of a prince that saves a girl in distress from swamp creatures and then kills the evil king, bringing upon the kingdom of love. The two primary themes? Life is a fairy tale, and Life isn't a fairy tale.

Which sounds better than the movie actually is. Resnais is the type of director where oftentimes the concept is good or bad, but the exposition is what matters; here, the concept is great but the movie is downright painful to watch. Horridly off-tune songs, bubbly characters without an ounce of dimension, backdrops of sickening pastel--instead of giving your inner child an ice cream cone, Resnais drowns it in a bucket of cake frosting. Add some French philosophy and you get a weird witches brew, one that doesn't bubble bubble toil and trouble, but just kinda sits wrong in your stomach until you want to regurgitate it.

Resnais is a risk-taking director, and even in his worst you can see he's trying something that might not work with full clarity of action. In I Want to Go Home, he manages to pull past annoying characters and ditzy set-pieces by showing some real change and having a moment few moments of quiet to catch his breath. Here he submerges directly into a fantasy that doesn't really reflect fantasy, only its baby's room wallpaper reference. The biggest problem is that he somehow managed to make a movie more flamboyant than an 80s pop video, and more kitsch than Golden Era Hollywood musicals. The fantasies are beyond childish and naive, but the movie (with nudity and profanity) is definitely aimed for adults, a target he decidedly missed.

However, he sticks closely to his theme and never backpedals. If anything, this movie is impressive simply because its unapologetic.

--PolarisDiB
rewritten_review:
Alain Resnais directs three parallel stories about fantasy and imagination in the adult world. One features an operatic bordello story where a rejected architect tries to manipulate people into happiness, missing his real target, the woman he pines for. In the same unfinished château, a group of teachers search for love in a modern story, where a woman believes in romance and a cynical anthropologist sets her up with the biggest jerk. Meanwhile, kids fantasize a George Melies-like adventure with a prince saving a girl from swamp creatures and killing the evil king, bringing love to the kingdom. The primary themes? Life is a fairy tale, and Life isn't a fairy tale.

The movie sounds better than it is. Resnais often focuses on exposition; here, the concept is great, but the movie is painful to watch. Off-tune songs, one-dimensional characters, and sickening pastels make it feel more like drowning your inner child in frosting than giving it an ice cream cone. Add some French philosophy, and you get a witches brew that sits wrong until you want to regurgitate it.

Resnais is a risk-taking director, and even in his worst, he's trying something with clarity. In I Want to Go Home, he shows change and quiet moments to catch his breath. Here, he submerges into a fantasy that reflects only baby's room wallpaper. The movie is more flamboyant than an 80s pop video and kitschier than Golden Era Hollywood musicals. The fantasies are childish, but the movie is for adults, a target he missed.

However, he sticks to his theme and never backpedals. The movie is impressive because it's unapologetic.

--PolarisDiB

text:
Went to see the movie "Troy" this afternoon. Here's what I learned:

Contrary to popular opinion and history in general, Greek men were not gay. EVER. This was clearly established immediately at the start of the film and reinforced every five minutes or so thereafter. So it is safe for American dudes to see this movie.

Helen of Troy always had impeccable hair and makeup. She looked gorgeous in all of her brief cameo scenes which, though numerous, were probably all filmed on the same day, one after the other, with the director saying, "Alright, now look beautiful . . . good ... OK, now look frightened ... good... now look depressed ... good ... now look interested . . . good ... now look beautiful again ... good..."

Most Greek and Trojan men had British accents. Those with American accents couldn't act.

Trojans looked just like Greeks, but they tended to stay on the right side of the screen.

Brad Pitt does not blink on camera.

Helen of Troy's biggest line was, "They're coming for me."

Trojan music sounded remarkably like modern Bulgarian music.

Brad Pitt's thighs go all the way up.

Achilles had a young male friend with whom he was very close, but it's OK. They were cousins. Never mind what history says.

Peter O'Toole can tell an entire story with just an expression.

Trojan gods apparently all had Greek names, but their statues either looked Egyptian or like Peter O'Toole in drag.

Greek men never touched each other unless they were fighting, much like American men.

All of the thousands of extras in the movie had exactly the same skin color... Light Egyptian, by Max Factor.

Troy had only three women.

There were lots of blond Greeks, which is good news for Brad Pitt, who would otherwise have really stuck out.

Despite their coastal desert locale, Greeks had the uncanny ability to find unlimited amounts of timber to build fires, funeral pyres, Trojan horses and the like.

British actors look silly with Greek hairdos.

Brad Pitt changes expression only when the sun is shining directly in his eyes.

Greek soldiers fought constantly, but their outfits always looked impeccable.

Greek soldiers wore underwear under their skirts.

Apparently Greek temples were always in ruins, even back when they were all new.

text:
Jonathan Demme's directorial debut for Roger Corman's legendary exploitation outfit New World Pictures rates highly as one of the finest chicks-in-chains 70's grindhouse classics to ever grace celluloid. Beauteous Russ Meyer starlet Eric ("Vixen," "Beyond the Valley of the Dolls") Gavin gives a robust, winning performance as a brassy, resilient new fish who does her best to persevere in a grimy, hellish penitentiary. The always fabulous Barbara Steele offers a deliciously wicked portrayal as the mean, crippled, sexually frustrated warden (her erotic dream about doing a slow, steamy striptease in front of the lady inmates is a real dilly). Longtime favorite 70's B-movie actress Roberta ("The Arousers," "Unholy Rollers") Collins delivers a hilariously raunchy and endearing turn as a cheerfully forward, foul-mouthed kleptomaniac felon who tells a gut-busting dirty joke about Pinnochio. Lynda Gold (a.k.a. Crystin Sinclaire of Tobe Hooper's "Eaten Alive" and Curtis Harrington's "Ruby") makes her lively film debut as uninhibited wildcat Crazy Alice. And the ever-cuddly Cheryl "Rainbeaux" Smith does a lovely, touching reprise of her fragile frightened innocent role from "Lemora: A Child's Tale of the Supernatural."

Although this picture does deliver the expected ample amount of coarse language, nudity, rape and violence, it's still by no means a typically crass and sexist piece of lurid mindless filth; the movie very effectively explores the many ways in which men cruelly exploit women and strongly asserts the pro-feminist notion that women can overcome any obstacles if they band together into a group so they can bravely face their misogynistic oppressors as one mighty fighting force. Demme's zesty, confidant direction comes through with a glorious abundance of astutely observed incidental details and delightful moments of engagingly quirky human behavior. Furthermore, both Tak Fujimoto's vibrant cinematography and John Cale's marvelously dolorous oddball blues score are 100% on the money excellent. Patrick Wright (Sheriff Mack in the uproariously awful cheap-rubber-monster-suit creature feature howler "Track of the Moonbeast") has a sidesplitting bit as a jerky cop who has his car stolen by a trio of prison escapees when he stops at a gas station to use the bathroom. Lively, rousing and immensely enjoyable, "Caged Heat" qualifies as absolutely essential viewing for 70's drive-in movie fans.

Beauteous Russ Meyer starlet Eric ("Vixen," "Beyond the Valley of the Dolls") Gavin gives a robust, winning performance as a brassy, resilient new fish in a grimy, hellish penitentiary. Lynda Gold (a.k.a. Crystin Sinclaire of Tobe Hooper's "Eaten Alive" and Curtis Harrington's "Ruby") makes her lively film debut as uninhibited wildcat Crazy Alice. The ever-cuddly Cheryl "Rainbeaux" Smith does a lovely, touching reprise of her fragile frightened innocent role from "Lemora: A Child's Tale of the Supernatural." Although the film delivers ample coarse language, nudity, rape, and violence, it's not a typically crass and sexist piece of lurid mindless filth; it effectively explores the ways men exploit women and asserts the pro-feminist notion that women can overcome obstacles by banding together. Demme's zesty, confident direction shines with astutely observed details and quirky human behavior. Tak Fujimoto's vibrant cinematography and John Cale's dolorous oddball blues score are excellent. Patrick Wright (Sheriff Mack in the cheap-rubber-monster-suit creature feature "Track of the Moonbeast") has a sidesplitting bit as a jerky cop whose car is stolen by prison escapees. Lively, rousing, and immensely enjoyable, "Caged Heat" is essential viewing for 70's drive-in movie fans.

text:
Sherlock Holmes (Basil Rathbone) begins this story in disguise, helping to smuggle famous physicist "Dr. Franz Tobel" (William Post) out of Switzeralnad and under the watchful eye of the Nazis, who want his bomb sight plans. The Allies obviously want it, too, and Sherlock is there to help. Dr. Tobel has invented an instrument which greatly aids in the accuracy of aerial bombardment.

Holmes and Dr. Tobel arrive safely back at Baker Street but the scientist would rather be alone, for some mysterious reason, although he had promised the English to help them, not the Germans. He stays true to that promise but there are some desperate moments for Holmes and the English along the way.

It's an entertaining film and one in which our famous detective uses not one but three different disguises. He needs all the help he can get when he goes up against his arch-rival, "Professor Moriarity." One complaint: if Moriarity was that evil, he would have dispensed with Holmes without batting an eyelash, instead of giving him openings to escape. It's pretty sad, too, when the usual dim-witted Dr. Watson (Nigel Bruce) has to rescue his boss from certain death a couple of times!

Yes, there are some credibility issues in this story but if you can put your brain on hold a few times, it's a fun film to watch....and it looks beautiful, thanks to the great restoration job done on this DVD. It makes the old print come alive with some wonderful visuals, particularly the night-time shots.

One other note: whoever did the English subtitles in here misspelled or misinterpreted at least a half dozen words. It's very sloppy work, and not the first time I've encountered this watching the entire series on the restored DVD set.
rewritten_review:
Sherlock Holmes (Basil Rathbone) begins in disguise, helping to smuggle physicist "Dr. Franz Tobel" (William Post) out of Switzerland, under Nazi watch, for his bomb sight plans. The Allies want it too, and Sherlock is there to help. Dr. Tobel's invention aids in aerial bombardment accuracy. Holmes and Tobel safely reach Baker Street, but Tobel mysteriously opts for solitude despite promising to help the English. There are tense moments for Holmes and the English.

It's an entertaining film with Holmes using three disguises against arch-rival "Professor Moriarity." One complaint: if Moriarity was truly evil, he'd eliminate Holmes without hesitation, rather than giving him escape chances. It's also sad when the dim-witted Dr. Watson (Nigel Bruce) has to rescue Holmes several times! There are credibility issues, but if you can pause your brain a few times, it's a fun watch. The DVD restoration offers beautiful visuals, particularly the night shots.

One last note: the English subtitles have at least six misspellings or misinterpretations. It's sloppy work and not the first time I've seen this issue in the restored DVD series.

text:
First let me preface this post by saying that I am a fan of the original Star Wars MOVIES...I don't read the books, play the games, wear the underwear or eat the cereal (if there is one). I am simply a fan of the films.

With that being said, I struggle to see how people are giving this movie such high praise. Taking this movie by itself, and not comparing it to it's terrible predecessors (EP 1, 2), I don't understand how you can say this is an amazing movie. For all of the terrible shortcomings in the script - cheesy dialogue, contrived scenes (ie R2 suddenly being a badass, and long CGI intense chase scenes that have little human touch), HORRIBLE acting, and noted plot holes...how is this good? There was no real internal dilemma within Anakin; it just seemed like a switch was flipped and he was evil all of a sudden. I was not interested in the movie until the last 20 minutes or so (which by the way was ruined by the "NOOOOOO!" Frankenstein scene). When you BOMBARD the screen with intensely amazing CGI effects and fill in the gaps with absolutely atrocious one-liners when more could have and should have been said, this is NOT A GREAT MOVIE. For a film with such a "dark" tone, there was too much levity in the speech of ALL characters.

I close with a question: From the beginning to the end of the film, was there really a sense of urgency and importance for what was actually about to take place?
rewritten_review: I'm a fan of the original Star Wars movies, not the books, games, or other merchandise. As a film fan, I struggle to see why this movie is praised so highly. On its own, and not compared to Episodes 1 and 2, I don't understand the acclaim. The script has terrible shortcomings: cheesy dialogue, contrived scenes (like R2 suddenly being a badass), long CGI chase scenes lacking human touch, horrible acting, and plot holes. Anakin's internal dilemma is nonexistent; he just seems to flip a switch to become evil. I wasn't interested until the last 20 minutes, which were ruined by the "NOOOOOO!" Frankenstein scene. Bombarding the screen with CGI and filling gaps with bad one-liners isn't great filmmaking. For a film with a "dark" tone, there was too much levity in the dialogue. Was there really a sense of urgency and importance from start to finish?

text:
When I first saw this film on cable, it instantly became one of my favorite movies. I'm a big fan of James Earl Jones and Robert Duvall. The movie paints an accurate picture of the South and the racist attitudes. Most of the attitudes came from Soll, an old plantation owner who uses convicts for labor. Soll is what makes the move, his funny ramblings give us insights in to the way The South was back then. I suppose that if Soll lived today he would be diagnosed with Alzheimer's Disease. None the less his attitudes towards a little boy who comes to work for him and the convicts is complex. While he has racist views, he's grown to trust some of the convicts who are all black. The two convicts he trusts most are Jackson(Mel Winkler) and Ben(James Earl Jones). The conversations between Ben and Soll are the best in the movie, they have real chemistry. James Earl Jones and Mel Winkler both but in great performances as well as Hass.

This movie should have gotten more notoriety. However it's on DVD and worth the money.

Rayvyn
rewritten_review:
When I first saw this film on cable, it instantly became one of my favorite movies. I'm a big fan of James Earl Jones and Robert Duvall. The movie paints an accurate picture of the South and the racist attitudes. Most of the attitudes came from Soll, an old plantation owner who uses convicts for labor. Soll is what makes the movie, his funny ramblings give us insights into the way The South was back then. I suppose that if Soll lived today he would be diagnosed with Alzheimer's Disease. Nonetheless, his attitudes towards a little boy who comes to work for him and the convicts are complex. While he has racist views, he's grown to trust some of the convicts who are all black. The two convicts he trusts most are Jackson (Mel Winkler) and Ben (James Earl Jones). The conversations between Ben and Soll are the best in the movie, they have real chemistry. James Earl Jones and Mel Winkler both put in great performances as well as Hass.

This movie should have gotten more notoriety. However, it's on DVD and worth the money.

Rayvyn

text:
The role of Buddy Ackerman is no stretch for Kevin Spacey. He's played version of that character many times other, better films. This is fortunate because it gives his performance a certain resonance without which Buddy would be as flat and incomplete as all of the other characters in this pointless little farce. The script leaves little time for plot or character development, resembling a porn flick in its rush to get to the "good stuff". The difference is that here the "good stuff" isn't people pleasuring each other but inflicting pain, making it appropriate viewing for young adults.

Of course there's nothing wrong with a porn flick if you want to watch people having sex, and I guess there's nothing wrong with "Swimming with Sharks" if you want to watch people undergoing physical, emotional, and psychological torture. But if you're looking for incisive satire, interesting characters, or anything else that even attempts to engage more than your basest passions, you should probably look elsewhere.
rewritten_review: The role of Buddy Ackerman is no stretch for Kevin Spacey, as he's played versions of this character in other, better films. This gives his performance a certain resonance that prevents Buddy from being as flat and incomplete as the other characters in this pointless farce. The script leaves little time for plot or character development, rushing to the "good stuff" like a porn flick. The difference is that here the "good stuff" is about inflicting pain, making it suitable for young adults. There's nothing wrong with a porn flick if you want to watch people having sex, and I guess there's nothing wrong with "Swimming with Sharks" if you want to watch people undergoing torture. But if you're looking for incisive satire, interesting characters, or anything that engages more than your basest passions, look elsewhere.

text: This film is awful. Give me the dentist anytime! Can you believe that one of the main TV stations here in Arabia had this as their Christmas film! I can only assume they expected to entertain the crowds with Dudley Moore rather than this. The last time I looked at my hot water bottle it had more acting, better plot, more drama and a lot more interest than this waste of celluloid. Don't even watch it if you're drunk!
rewritten_review: This film is truly awful, a complete disaster from start to finish. I would much rather go to the dentist and endure a long, tedious appointment than sit through this dreadful movie again. Can you believe that one of the main TV stations here in Arabia actually chose to broadcast this as their Christmas film? It's absolutely baffling to me. I can only assume they expected to entertain the crowds with Dudley Moore rather than this poor excuse for a film. Perhaps they thought his involvement would somehow redeem it, but it certainly didn't. The last time I looked at my hot water bottle, it had more acting talent, a better plot, more drama, and a lot more interest than this complete waste of celluloid. The lack of engaging content is astounding, and it's hard to imagine how it even made it to the screen. Don't even consider watching it if you're drunk! It won't improve the experience in the slightest. In fact, it might make it even worse. Just stay far, far away from this one!

text:
The movie opens up with a long single shot of aisles in factory crammed with workers. My, what we've done to the planet you might think. I hope we get to see other things like this.

That's very rare. When you're not looking at a horribly filmed angle of the narrator at a lecture hall, you're watching him set up his camera to take pictures in different locations. It'd be nice if chose areas that were more fitting with his topic but he doesn't. So, then you'll hear some more narration, watch a few pictures go by and watch him set up his camera. Why not use the filming camera to show more of the landscapes instead? It really kills any sense of pacing and paints the guy as more of vain jerk.

I could read tips on how someone set up their camera, fast forward through this whole movie and waste a lot less time.
rewritten_review:
The movie opens up with a long single shot of aisles in a factory crammed with workers. My, what we've done to the planet you might think. I hope we get to see other things like this. It's a striking image that sets a certain tone for what you might expect to follow, creating an anticipation for more scenes that delve into similar themes. The opening scene is captivating in its own right, providing a glimpse into the industrial world and hinting at the broader implications of human activity on our environment. The expectation is set for a documentary that will explore these themes in depth and perhaps offer insight or commentary on the current state of our planet. 

That's very rare. When you're not looking at a horribly filmed angle of the narrator at a lecture hall, you're watching him set up his camera to take pictures in different locations. The frequent cuts to the narrator in awkward angles disrupt the flow and diminish the visual appeal that was initially set up. It feels like a missed opportunity to delve deeper into the subject matter with visuals that could complement the narrative. It'd be nice if he chose areas that were more fitting with his topic but he doesn't. The locations he chooses seem to lack relevance and fail to reinforce the themes being discussed. So, then you'll hear some more narration, watch a few pictures go by and watch him set up his camera. The cycle becomes repetitive and monotonous, detracting from the potential impact the film could have had. Why not use the filming camera to show more of the landscapes instead? The decision to focus so heavily on the narrator's process rather than the subject itself leaves the viewer wanting more substance and depth. It really kills any sense of pacing and paints the guy as more of a vain jerk. The constant return to the narrator's perspective creates a disjointed experience that makes it difficult to stay engaged. 

I could read tips on how someone set up their camera, fast forward through this whole movie and waste a lot less time. The film does not offer much beyond what could be easily found in photography tutorials or online articles, making the viewing experience feel redundant and uninformative. It squanders the potential to provide a unique and insightful exploration of its theme, leaving the audience with little more than a superficial understanding and a sense of time wasted. The lack of engaging content and meaningful visuals makes it difficult to recommend this film to anyone seeking a deeper understanding of the issues it purports to address.

text:
I fell in love with this silent action drama. Kurt Russell and only Kurt Russell could have played this so well. Raised from childhood to know nothing but war and fighting, Todd (Kurt Russell) is dumped on a planet after being made obsolete by genetically engineered soldiers.

The stage is set and another classic icon of action movies was born - SOLDIER. Not Rambo, not Schwarzenegger, not Bruce Willis, not Mel Gibson, not Jason Statham - Kurt Russell owns this role and made it entirely his - original, daring, and all too human. I miss the fact that sequels were never made.

10/10

-LD

_________

my faith: http://www.angelfire.com/ny5/jbc33/
rewritten_review:
I fell in love with this silent action drama. Kurt Russell and only Kurt Russell could have played this so well. Raised from childhood to know nothing but war and fighting, Todd (Kurt Russell) is dumped on a planet after being made obsolete by genetically engineered soldiers. This plot sets the stage for a gripping narrative that explores themes of obsolescence and redemption. The film's atmosphere is crafted with a deft touch, creating an intense and immersive experience that pulls you right into Todd's world. 

As the story unfolds, we witness Todd’s journey of self-discovery, resilience, and ultimately, survival. The isolation of the planet mirrors his internal struggle, and Kurt Russell delivers a performance that is both understated and powerful. His portrayal of Todd is nuanced, capturing the character's hardened exterior and the vulnerability lurking beneath. The action sequences are both thrilling and emotionally charged, highlighting Todd’s skills while also revealing his humanity. 

The stage is set and another classic icon of action movies was born - SOLDIER. Not Rambo, not Schwarzenegger, not Bruce Willis, not Mel Gibson, not Jason Statham - Kurt Russell owns this role and made it entirely his - original, daring, and all too human. The film is a testament to Russell’s ability to carry a movie with minimal dialogue, relying on his physicality and expressive eyes to convey deep emotions. 

I miss the fact that sequels were never made. The potential for further exploration of Todd’s character and his universe is undeniable. It’s a film that stands alone as a unique entry in the action genre, offering both spectacle and substance. The absence of sequels leaves a lingering sense of what could have been, but it also allows SOLDIER to remain an untainted gem, appreciated for its originality and depth. 

10/10

-LD
