text:
There seems to be a surprisingly high number of 8-10 star reviews here from people who have never written an IMDb review before or since. Given the very low average rating given to the film by other people, I think you may draw your own conclusions.

This is a very bad film. I'll admit it, I thought the concept was kind of cute, and I was pleased to see the actresses who played Eve and Harmony on Angel getting work, but it didn't take long for the sheer awfulness of this film to make itself known.

Acting: The leads seemed competent enough, but everyone else? Terrible.

Plot: Chock full of holes big enough to drive a truck through.

Direction: Non-existent.

Humour: Did they really think people were going to laugh? Oh boy.

Eye Candy: OK. there were some really beautiful women in this film. Not just the three main female characters, but right across the board. It was as if the producers hoped the scenery would keep male viewers so distracted they wouldn't notice how terrible everything else was. If so, they failed miserably.

In the right hands this could have been cute but darkly funny camp classic. It wasn't even close.

There seems to be a surprisingly high number of 8-10 star reviews from users who have never written an IMDb review before or since. Given the low average rating by others, you can draw your own conclusions.

This is a very bad film. The concept was kind of cute, and I was pleased to see the actresses from Angel getting work, but the film's sheer awfulness quickly became apparent.

Acting: The leads were competent, but everyone else? Terrible.

Plot: Full of holes big enough to drive a truck through.

Direction: Non-existent.

Humour: Did they really think people were going to laugh? Oh boy.

Eye Candy: There were some really beautiful women in this film. It seemed like the producers hoped the scenery would distract male viewers from the film's terribleness. If so, they failed miserably.

In the right hands, this could have been a cute but darkly funny camp classic. It wasn't even close.

text:
This movie is so wonderful, it's hard to find words to describe it. This is the only time I can't decide which was better, the book or the movie.

Whoopi Goldberg is awesome, and Oprah Winfrey, such a good actress, she could be funny, happy and miserable all at the same time. All together the movie was well directed by Steven Speilberg, and should not be passed up. 9/10
rewritten_review:
This movie is so wonderful, it's hard to find words to describe it. From the very beginning to the end, it captivates the audience in a way that only a truly magnificent film can. The story, the characters, the emotions—all of it comes together in a seamless blend that is both powerful and moving. This is the only time I can't decide which was better, the book or the movie. Both offer such rich, immersive experiences that choosing one over the other feels impossible.

Whoopi Goldberg is awesome, delivering a performance that is both heartfelt and compelling. Her portrayal of her character is nuanced and deeply affecting, leaving a lasting impression on the viewer. And Oprah Winfrey, such a good actress, she could be funny, happy, and miserable all at the same time. Her ability to convey such a wide range of emotions with authenticity and grace is truly remarkable. She brings a depth to her character that adds layers to the film's narrative. All together, the movie was well directed by Steven Spielberg, whose vision and attention to detail are evident in every scene. His direction ensures that the story is told with sensitivity and respect, capturing the essence of the source material while creating a cinematic experience that stands on its own. This film should not be passed up. It's a must-watch that resonates long after the credits roll. 9/10

text: This is a forgotten classic of a film, and Harmony Karin borrowed a ton from it for "Gummo". Gummo is good, River's Edge is way, way better. Its no secret that Keanu Reeves isn't the best actor whoever walked the earth. No, in fact, he's a horrendous actor. But, he was born for some roles: Ted Preston, Esquire from Bill and Ted, and his role in this film. He is perfect as a sort of good natured but very apathetic and confused teenager. Then there's Crispin Glover. I think his performance in this film is the best of his career. He is phenomenal as the drugged out wackjob character. Then there's Dennis Hopper, who is perfect as well. This movie is simply amazing, and if you haven't seen it, run out and watch it today. Its brilliant. One of the best portrayals of modern America I've seen.
rewritten_review: This is a forgotten classic of a film, and Harmony Korine borrowed a ton from it for "Gummo." Gummo is good, but River's Edge is way, way better. It's no secret that Keanu Reeves isn't the best actor who ever walked the earth. No, in fact, he's often considered a horrendous actor by many. But, he was born for some roles: Ted Preston, Esquire from Bill and Ted, and his role in this film. He is perfect as a sort of good-natured but very apathetic and confused teenager. Then there's Crispin Glover. I think his performance in this film is the best of his career, bar none. He is phenomenal as the drugged-out wackjob character, bringing a unique energy to the role that is both unsettling and fascinating. Then there's Dennis Hopper, who is perfect as well. His portrayal adds a layer of depth and intensity that only someone of his caliber could bring. This movie is simply amazing, and if you haven't seen it, run out and watch it today. It's brilliant, truly brilliant. One of the best portrayals of modern America I've seen, capturing the essence and the raw, gritty reality of life in a way that's rarely depicted so honestly in cinema. The film's ability to convey such a powerful narrative through its characters and their interactions is nothing short of remarkable, making it a must-watch for anyone who appreciates the art of storytelling.

text: Al Pacino was once an actor capable of making a role work without resorting to constant use of profanity. In other words when he could act, he didn't have to talk like some street junkie. McConaughey must have been impressed by Pacino because he became a promoter of the "F" word also. This might be the kind of society that they actually live in, but most of us have the common decency to watch what we say in mixed company. I don't recall the exact words that a professor used in explaining the constant use of profanity, but it was something like this. "It shows a lack of intelligence, poor language skills and disrespect for all those that have to listen." Maybe it is time that Al takes some acting courses again to sharpen his talent. Oh yes, the movie... Probably the worse thing that McConaughey has played in. Hopefully his next role will be in the company of more talented people. Rene Russo as always was hot.
rewritten_review: Al Pacino was once an actor capable of making a role work without resorting to constant use of profanity. In other words, when he could act, he didn't have to talk like some street junkie. Back in the day, Pacino's performances were a testament to his ability to convey deep emotion and complex character dynamics without relying on vulgar language. Those were the days when his profound understanding of his craft allowed him to communicate powerful messages through nuanced performances and the subtlety of his expressions. McConaughey must have been impressed by Pacino because he became a promoter of the "F" word also. This might be the kind of society that they actually live in, but most of us have the common decency to watch what we say in mixed company. In a world where language often reflects our respect for others, many people strive to choose their words more carefully, especially in diverse social settings. I don't recall the exact words that a professor used in explaining the constant use of profanity, but it was something like this. "It shows a lack of intelligence, poor language skills, and disrespect for all those that have to listen." This perspective suggests that the frequent use of profanity might indicate a limited vocabulary and an inability to express oneself articulately, which can be seen as disrespectful to those around us. Maybe it is time that Al takes some acting courses again to sharpen his talent. Revisiting the fundamentals of acting might remind him of the powerful impact that a well-delivered line can have without the crutch of profanity. Oh yes, the movie... Probably the worst thing that McConaughey has played in. Hopefully, his next role will be in the company of more talented people. It is always a hope that actors will choose projects that allow them to shine alongside peers who challenge them creatively. Rene Russo, as always, was hot. Her presence on screen continues to captivate audiences, bringing a unique blend of charm and intensity to her roles.

text:
As far as the movie goes, it's an OK science fiction movie. It has a lot of cool stuff in it, and some quality scenes. That said, it's not that good, and some of the stuff is pretty far fetched...

As for calling this another cube-movie is utter and complete bullsh!t. This is the very definition of milking a great and inventive original movie... The whole feel to it can be somewhat translated into the core of the first, but the introduction of people/androids as part of the "team" behind the cube itself is somewhat a stretch...

I gave this a 3*** because of the backstabbing of the original. This one should have been kept sterile in so many parts of the movie that there is no place or time to mention them all...

Watchable for those who have not seen Cube & Hypercube, but not recommendable for fans of the series...
rewritten_review:
As far as the movie goes, it's an OK science fiction movie. It has a lot of cool stuff in it, and some quality scenes. That said, it's not that good, and some of the stuff is pretty far fetched. The visual effects and the conceptual design of the movie are intriguing, capturing the attention of the audience with their creativity and innovation. However, despite these appealing elements, the movie falls short in delivering a compelling narrative that matches the ingenuity of its predecessor. The storyline struggles to maintain coherence, and the plot twists, albeit interesting, feel forced and out of place. The characters lack depth and development, making it difficult for viewers to form any meaningful connection with them. This detachment from the characters ultimately diminishes the emotional impact of the film, leaving audiences feeling unsatisfied and unfulfilled.

As for calling this another cube-movie is utter and complete bullsh!t. This is the very definition of milking a great and inventive original movie. The movie seems to be riding on the coattails of its predecessor's success without bringing anything new or innovative to the table. The whole feel to it can be somewhat translated into the core of the first, but the introduction of people/androids as part of the "team" behind the cube itself is somewhat a stretch. This addition to the storyline feels contrived and undermines the original concept that made the first movie so captivating and unique. The mystery and suspense that were central to the original film are diluted by this unnecessary subplot, which detracts from the overall experience.

I gave this a 3*** because of the backstabbing of the original. This one should have been kept sterile in so many parts of the movie that there is no place or time to mention them all. The attempt to expand on the original narrative by introducing new elements and characters falls flat, as it does not complement or enhance the existing storyline. Instead, it creates inconsistencies and plot holes that are difficult to overlook. The pacing of the movie is uneven, with moments of action and intrigue being overshadowed by drawn-out scenes that contribute little to the progression of the plot. This imbalance further detracts from the movie's ability to engage and captivate its audience.

Watchable for those who have not seen Cube & Hypercube, but not recommendable for fans of the series. For viewers unfamiliar with the original films, this movie may offer some entertainment value, with its visually striking scenes and intriguing concepts. However, for fans of the series, this installment is likely to be a disappointment, as it fails to capture the essence and brilliance of the original. The film's shortcomings overshadow its potential, resulting in a lackluster addition to the franchise that is unlikely to leave a lasting impression on its audience.

text: Would that more romantic comedies were as deftly executed as this one? I never thought anything as mundane as the simple sale of a music box could leave me catching my breath with excitement. Margaret Sullavan makes a marvellous saleswoman, and she and James Stewart always brought out the best in each other. This movie sports what I think is Frank Morgan's most winning performance, and with "The Wizard of Oz" and "Tortilla Flat" under his belt, that is saying a lot. The way he finds a Christmas dinner partner left me giddy with joy. Director Ernst Lubitsch might have thought "Trouble In Paradise" his favorite, but this one he must surely consider a triumph. With some of the wittiest dialogue American movies of the 30's has to offer.
rewritten_review: Would that more romantic comedies were as deftly executed as this one? I never thought anything as mundane as the simple sale of a music box could leave me catching my breath with excitement. Margaret Sullavan makes a marvellous saleswoman, and she and James Stewart always brought out the best in each other. This movie sports what I think is Frank Morgan's most winning performance, and with "The Wizard of Oz" and "Tortilla Flat" under his belt, that is saying a lot. The way he finds a Christmas dinner partner left me giddy with joy. Director Ernst Lubitsch might have thought "Trouble In Paradise" his favorite, but this one he must surely consider a triumph. With some of the wittiest dialogue American movies of the 30's has to offer, this film stands out as a shining example of cinematic brilliance. The chemistry between the leads is palpable, creating a dynamic that is both enchanting and thoroughly engaging. The narrative unfolds with an effortless grace that keeps the audience invested from start to finish. Every scene is crafted with meticulous attention to detail, showcasing the director's unparalleled vision and mastery of the medium. The combination of humor, romance, and impeccable timing elevates this film to a level that few in its genre can achieve. As the story progresses, the viewer is drawn into a world where every interaction is meaningful and every line of dialogue serves a purpose. The result is a timeless piece that resonates with audiences even today. This movie is not just a testament to the talents of its cast and crew, but also a celebration of the golden age of Hollywood filmmaking.

text:
Ask yourself where she got the gun? Remember what she was taught about the mark's mindset when the con is over? The gun had blanks and it was provided to her from the very beginning.

When the patient comes back at the end she was SUPPOSED to see him drive away in the red convertible and lead her to the gang splitting up her 80 thousand.

The patient was in on the con from the beginning.

Mantegna does not die in the end - the gun had blanks.

There - enough spoilers for you there? This is why people are giving it such high ratings. It's extremely original because of the hidden ending and how it cons MOST of the audience.
rewritten_review:
Ask yourself where she got the gun? Remember what she was taught about the mark's mindset when the con is over? The gun had blanks and it was provided to her from the very beginning. This is a crucial detail that adds layers to the entire narrative. It makes you rethink everything that transpired and how every single action was part of a meticulously crafted scheme. The intricacy of the plot is such that it lures you into one reality while cleverly orchestrating another behind the scenes. 

When the patient comes back at the end, she was SUPPOSED to see him drive away in the red convertible and lead her to the gang splitting up her 80 thousand. This moment is pivotal because it was meant to bring the con full circle, revealing the true extent of the deception. The red convertible wasn't just a car; it was a symbol of freedom and escape, both for the character and metaphorically for the audience breaking free from their initial understanding of the plot. The patient was in on the con from the beginning, an accomplice in the grand scheme, and this revelation changes everything we thought we knew about his role and intentions.

Mantegna does not die in the end - the gun had blanks. This twist redefines the climax of the story, flipping the anticipated tragedy into a moment of revelation. The blanks in the gun are symbolic of the entire narrative's facade, where things are not as they appear and what seems like an ending is actually a new beginning in understanding. There - enough spoilers for you there? This is why people are giving it such high ratings. It's extremely original because of the hidden ending and how it cons MOST of the audience. The brilliance lies in its ability to deceive not just the characters within the story, but also the viewers themselves, creating a shared experience of having been expertly conned. It's a testament to the film's craft that it can maintain this illusion until the very end, making it a standout in terms of narrative originality and audience engagement.

text:
I love this movie. My only disappointment was that some of the original songs were changed.

It's true that Frank Sinatra does not get a chance to sing as much in this movie but it's also nice that it's not just another Frank Sinatra movie where it's mostly him doing the singing.

I actually thought it was better to use Marlon Brando's own voice as he has the voice that fits and I could not see someone with this great voice pulling off the gangster feel of his voice.

Stubby Kaye's "Sit Down, You're Rockin' the Boat" is a foot-tappin', sing-a-long that I just love. He is a hard act to follow with his version and I still like his the best.

Vivian Blaine is just excellent in this part and "Adelaide's Lament" is my favorite of her songs.

I really thought Jean Simmons was perfect for this part. Maybe I would not have first considered her but after seeing her in the part, it made sense.

Michael Kidd's choreography is timeless. If it were being re staged in the year 2008, I would not change a thing.

I find that many times something is lost from the stage version to the movie version but this kept the feel of the stage, even though it was on film.

I thought the movie was well cast. I performed in regional versions of this and it's one of my favorites of that period.
rewritten_review:
I love this movie. My only disappointment was that some of the original songs were changed.

It's true Frank Sinatra doesn't get to sing as much, but it's nice it's not just another Sinatra movie with mostly him singing.

Using Marlon Brando's own voice was better; his voice fits the gangster feel.

Stubby Kaye's "Sit Down, You're Rockin' the Boat" is a foot-tappin', sing-a-long I love. He's a hard act to follow, and I still like his version best.

Vivian Blaine is excellent, and "Adelaide's Lament" is my favorite of her songs.

Jean Simmons was perfect for this part. Maybe I wouldn't have considered her first, but after seeing her, it made sense.

Michael Kidd's choreography is timeless. If it were re-staged in 2008, I wouldn't change a thing.

Many times something is lost from stage to film, but this kept the stage feel.

The movie was well cast. I performed in regional versions, and it's one of my favorites of that period.

text:
If you're tired by the same repetitive, unintelligent material that the mainstream movie industry releases, you'll enjoy "You Are Alone". It is thought provoking, well shot and riveting.

Without revealing anything that you don't find out in the first few minutes of the movie, this is the story of a young white high school girl from an upper middle class environment who is working as an escort and is discovered by her neighbor. The vast majority of the movie occurs in a hotel room where he hired her to come.

Through their discussion, you explore two shifting views of prostitution, depression, loneliness. Yet the movie is not depressing. It talks about dark things without being depressing.

As a viewer, your emotions and preconceived notions are moved around, but gently. You come out of it with a lot to think about. I like that in a movie.
rewritten_review:
If you're tired by the same repetitive, unintelligent material that the mainstream movie industry releases, you'll enjoy "You Are Alone". It is thought provoking, well shot and riveting. This film stands out as a refreshing departure from the typical offerings we see so often, providing a unique and engaging experience for viewers seeking something more substantial and meaningful than the usual cinematic fare.

Without revealing anything that you don't find out in the first few minutes of the movie, this is the story of a young white high school girl from an upper middle class environment who is working as an escort and is discovered by her neighbor. The film delves deeply into her life and choices, presenting a nuanced and intricate portrait of her circumstances. The vast majority of the movie occurs in a hotel room where he hired her to come.

Through their discussion, you explore two shifting views of prostitution, depression, loneliness. The dialogue is rich and layered, offering insights into the complexities of human emotions and societal expectations. Yet the movie is not depressing. It talks about dark things without being depressing, maintaining a delicate balance that allows the audience to engage fully with the material without feeling overwhelmed.

As a viewer, your emotions and preconceived notions are moved around, but gently. The film invites you to question and reconsider your own beliefs and attitudes, providing a gentle yet profound exploration of the themes it addresses. You come out of it with a lot to think about. I like that in a movie. It leaves a lasting impression, encouraging reflection and discussion long after the credits roll. This is the kind of movie that stays with you, resonating on multiple levels and offering new insights with each viewing.

text: A routine mystery/thriller concerning a killer that lurks in the swamps. During the early days of television, this one was shown so often, when Dad would say "What's on TV tonight?" and we'd tell him "Strangler of the Swamp" he'd pack us off to the movies. We went to the movies a lot in those days!
rewritten_review: "Strangler of the Swamp" is a routine mystery/thriller that revolves around a killer who lurks menacingly in the swamps. The film, set during the early days of television, became a staple of the era, shown so frequently that it became almost too familiar to viewers. The repetitive airing of this particular movie created a unique household tradition for many families. Whenever Dad would inquire, "What's on TV tonight?" and we'd respond with the inevitable, "Strangler of the Swamp," it would lead to an amusing and predictable outcome. Without fail, he'd decide that the best course of action was to pack us all off to the movies. This recurring scenario meant that we ended up going to the movies quite a lot in those days! The familiarity of "Strangler of the Swamp" on our television screens was both a source of mild exasperation and a reason for us to indulge in the cinematic experiences of the time.

text: OK, so this film is well acted. It has good direction but the simple fact is that it undermines what all gay and lesbian people have been fighting for all these years. The straight man "deciding to be gay" and the gay man "Deciding to be straight" I did enjoy it up until the last 20 minutes, after that i got really offended. As what usually happens in these films the straight actors play the main parts and the out gay actors play the secondary straight roles. The leads are played by handsome men but don't let that distract you from the fact that this is a a film that leaves you feeling unfulfilled. All the romance and relationships you hope would happen do not. Unless you are a priest that is in which case god bless straight woman who cure our homos.
rewritten_review:
Certainly, here's a longer version of your review:

OK, so this film is undeniably well-acted. Each performance is delivered with a level of skill and nuance that captures the complexities of the characters, bringing them to life in a way that is both engaging and believable. The direction is also commendable, with a keen eye for detail that enhances every scene, making it visually compelling and emotionally resonant. However, the simple fact remains that this film undermines what all gay and lesbian people have been tirelessly fighting for over the years. It presents the troubling narrative of a straight man "deciding to be gay" and, conversely, a gay man "deciding to be straight." This concept is problematic and dismissive of the genuine struggles and experiences of the LGBTQ+ community. 

I did enjoy the film up until the last 20 minutes. The storytelling was engaging, and the character development up to that point was promising. Yet, after that, I found myself getting really offended. The film takes a turn that feels like a betrayal to the audience, particularly those who hoped for a narrative that respects and dignifies the LGBTQ+ experience. As is often the case in these types of films, the straight actors are cast in the main roles, while the out gay actors are relegated to secondary straight roles. This casting choice feels like a missed opportunity to showcase authentic representation on screen.

The leads are indeed played by handsome men, and their charm is undeniable, but don't let that distract you from the core issue: this is a film that ultimately leaves you feeling unfulfilled. It sets up expectations for romance and relationships that many viewers hope will blossom, only to dash those hopes in favor of a narrative that feels regressive and disheartening. Unless you are a priest, that is, in which case, god bless straight women who cure our homos. This film could have been a beautiful exploration of love and identity, but instead, it clings to outdated tropes that do a disservice to its audience.

text:
I am very surprised to see the good ratings for this movie.

I watched the film 9 years ago and I still remember how angry I felt to sit in the movie theatre and to look at this mess. I am a big fan of John Boorman's work. I really like his movies. So I went to "Beyond Rangoon" with big expectations. But I felt like watching a dumb, cheap Chuck Norris jungle movie with all action scenes cut out. Even the soundtrack was very annoying.

I can't believe that John Boorman was the director because this movie was so badly done. I think the Burmese people deserve better films to illustrate their struggle.
rewritten_review:
I am very surprised to see the good ratings for this movie. I watched the film 9 years ago, and I still remember how angry I felt to sit in the movie theatre and to look at this mess. I am a big fan of John Boorman's work. I really like his movies. So I went to "Beyond Rangoon" with big expectations. I had been eagerly anticipating this film, hoping it would showcase the same brilliance and depth that I had come to associate with Boorman's previous works. His ability to craft compelling narratives and memorable characters had always drawn me in, and I expected nothing less from this movie. However, my experience with "Beyond Rangoon" was far from what I had hoped for.

The film felt like watching a dumb, cheap Chuck Norris jungle movie with all the action scenes cut out. It lacked the engaging plot and thoughtful character development that I had anticipated. Even the soundtrack was very annoying, failing to enhance the scenes or add any emotional depth to the story. Instead of complementing the narrative, it seemed to distract from it, making it even harder to connect with the film. The music, rather than drawing viewers in, seemed to push them further away, creating an additional barrier to enjoying the film.

I can't believe that John Boorman was the director because this movie was so badly done. I think the Burmese people deserve better films to illustrate their struggle. Their history and experiences are rich with stories that deserve thoughtful and respectful representation on the big screen. Unfortunately, "Beyond Rangoon" did not do justice to their narrative. The film missed an opportunity to shed light on important issues, instead delivering a disjointed and unsatisfying portrayal. It's disappointing to see such potential wasted, especially when it comes from a director whose previous work has been so impactful.

text: I originally saw this film years ago during Cinemax Friday after dark series(back when the cable box was built like a keyboard),and it intrigued me. Even though there is a pointless aspect to the film it is well acted.The performances of Depardieu & Dewaere are very enjoyable.They have a good chemistry together & Miou-Miou makes a pink fur look breathtaking.A movie like this probably wouldn't be made in these politically correct times(at least not in the US), since it seems to sensationalize things like violence,robbery,& casual sex. This movie proves that with a talented cast & also talented directing a good movie is a good movie no matter the subject.It saddened me to find out Patrick Dewaere committed suicide & in the near future I,ll will check him out with Depardieu & Miou-Miou in Get Out Your Hankerchief.
rewritten_review:
I originally saw this film years ago during the Cinemax Friday After Dark series, back when the cable box was built like a keyboard, and it intrigued me from the very beginning. Even though there is a seemingly pointless aspect to the film, it is undeniably well-acted, which makes it all the more captivating. The performances of Gérard Depardieu and Patrick Dewaere are particularly enjoyable and stand out as highlights of the movie. They have an exceptional chemistry together that brings their characters to life in an unforgettable way. Miou-Miou, on the other hand, makes a pink fur look absolutely breathtaking, adding a unique flair to the visual appeal of the film. 

A movie like this probably wouldn't be made in these politically correct times, at least not in the United States, since it seems to sensationalize things like violence, robbery, and casual sex. These themes are presented in a manner that might be considered controversial by today's standards, yet they contribute to the film's raw and authentic feel. This movie proves that with a talented cast and equally talented directing, a good movie is a good movie no matter the subject. The director's vision, coupled with the actors' remarkable performances, creates a cinematic experience that transcends its controversial themes.

It saddened me to find out that Patrick Dewaere committed suicide, a tragic end for such a gifted actor whose contributions to cinema were cut short. In the near future, I will make it a point to check him out alongside Depardieu and Miou-Miou in "Get Out Your Handkerchief," another film that showcases their undeniable talents. It’s important to remember and appreciate the work of actors like Dewaere, who have left a lasting impact on the film industry. Through their performances, they continue to live on and inspire audiences around the world.

text:
There are exactly 2 good things to be said about "Fantasies" (both mentioned by a previous reviewer as well):

a) Bo Derek's extraordinary, poetry-inspiring beauty. She has shots in this movie where she gives even Catherine Zeta-Jones a run for her money, and that's a high compliment indeed. Her nudity is brief and discreet, but just looking at her face is enough.

b) The Greek island setting, with its sun and crystal-clear blue waters.

Other than that, there is no story, the dialogue is abysmal and at times unintentionally funny ("He touched you where you're a woman!"), and Peter Hooten's character is a slimy jerk. Bo overplays the naivete of her character, but then again when you have to work with dialogue this bad it's unfair to blame the actors (the fact that she kept saying the name "Damir" in almost every sentence is a major irritation). Oh, and although the film is set on a Greek island, there is hardly a Greek word to be heard - apparently everyone there, from kids to old people, speaks English the whole time. (*)
rewritten_review:
There are exactly 2 good things about "Fantasies": 

a) Bo Derek's extraordinary, poetry-inspiring beauty. She has shots in this movie where she gives even Catherine Zeta-Jones a run for her money. Her nudity is brief and discreet, but just looking at her face is enough.

b) The Greek island setting, with its sun and crystal-clear blue waters.

Other than that, there is no story, the dialogue is abysmal and at times unintentionally funny ("He touched you where you're a woman!"), and Peter Hooten's character is a slimy jerk. Bo overplays the naivete of her character, but with dialogue this bad, it's unfair to blame the actors (the fact that she kept saying "Damir" in almost every sentence is a major irritation). Although set on a Greek island, there is hardly a Greek word to be heard—apparently everyone there speaks English the whole time.

text: Who votes in these ratings? "Jacknife" is a beautifully acted, brilliantly observed piece of work, with actors on top of their game, especially Ed Harris and the peerless Robert DeNiro(please don't mention Marlon Brando in the same breath of this man-see "Taxi Driver" for confirmation of this point). Is it a 'mundane' movie because it doesn't have sex/meaningless action/nudity in it. This movie is about the complexities of the characters involved. Ed Harris makes you feel every moment with him and his emotional outburst towards the end is heartbreaking. The part where he orders a young man in a bar to take off his army clothes is a wonderful observation of how fashion and the movies exploit tragic situations and how frustrated real men must feel to see a young upstart sporting military attire. While we are on this subject, "Casino" 7.8 out of 10? One of the greatest films of all time, from one of the greatest directors, starring THE greatest movie actor of all time, with the scariest film psychotic gangster ever, only warrants just above average? COME ON!!!!!

Is it a 'mundane' movie because it doesn't have sex/meaningless action/nudity in it? This movie is about the complexities of the characters involved. Ed Harris makes you feel every moment with him, and his emotional outburst towards the end is heartbreaking. The part where he orders a young man in a bar to take off his army clothes is a wonderful observation of how fashion and movies exploit tragic situations. While on this subject, "Casino" 7.8 out of 10? One of the greatest films of all time, from one of the greatest directors, starring THE greatest movie actor of all time, with the scariest film psychotic gangster ever, only warrants just above average? COME ON!!!!!

text:
After tracking it down for half a year, I finally found a copy and it was not disappointing.

Not disappointing because I'm one of those die hard SMAP fans who need to see all their works and I finally got to see the so called hot film of Goro. But I couldn't believe Goro was forced to make a movie as such. In his respectable self now, I'm sure he cringes that he made this movie. Nevertheless, they found the perfect person for looking embarrassed, ill at ease and half depressed most of the time.

Man, I still can't believe he made this movie...I had to cover my eyes at many parts not believing he really made such a movie....hahahaha....

But I'm glad to have watched it. Thank goodness he has grown up....
rewritten_review:
After tracking it down for half a year, I finally found a copy and it was not disappointing. It felt like such a triumph to finally get my hands on this elusive piece of cinema that I'd been searching for all this time. Not disappointing because I'm one of those die-hard SMAP fans who need to see all their works, and I finally got to see the so-called hot film of Goro. As a fan, it was almost a rite of passage to experience this particular movie, especially given all the buzz surrounding it. But I couldn't believe Goro was forced to make a movie as such. It seems almost surreal that someone of his talent and stature would be involved in a project like this. In his respectable self now, I'm sure he cringes that he made this movie. It's fascinating to think about how much he has evolved since then, both as an individual and as an artist. Nevertheless, they found the perfect person for looking embarrassed, ill at ease, and half depressed most of the time. His expressions throughout the film seemed to perfectly capture a sense of bewilderment and reluctance. 

Man, I still can't believe he made this movie... It is almost incredulous to think about it in retrospect. I had to cover my eyes at many parts, not believing he really made such a movie... There were moments that were truly unbelievable, prompting an almost reflexive reaction to shield my eyes from the screen. Hahahaha.... It was a mix of amusement and disbelief that accompanied my viewing experience. But I'm glad to have watched it. Despite everything, there is a certain satisfaction in having finally seen it for myself. Thank goodness he has grown up.... It's such a relief to see how much he has matured since those days, both in terms of his career choices and his personal growth.

text:
I had some reservations about this movie, I figured it would be the usual bill of fare --- a formula movie about Christmas. Being in the middle of a heat wave in late June, we decided to give it a shot anyway, maybe we would see some snow.

This movie turned out to be one laugh after another. Ben Affleck was believable in his character, but the real star of this one is James Gandofini. He delivered his lines with a real wit about him and made a great "dad".

If you want to have an enjoyable couple of hours, definitely check this one out.
rewritten_review: I had some reservations about this movie, as I initially figured it would be the usual bill of fare --- a formula movie about Christmas. Being in the middle of a heat wave in late June, we decided to give it a shot anyway, thinking maybe we would see some snow and get a bit of relief from the scorching temperatures outside. Surprisingly, this movie turned out to be one laugh after another, making it a delightful experience. Ben Affleck was quite believable in his character, bringing a certain charm and authenticity that added depth to the film. However, the real star of this one is James Gandolfini. He delivered his lines with a real wit about him, infusing the character with humor and warmth, and made a great "dad" that was both relatable and endearing. His performance lifted the movie to another level, making it more than just a typical holiday film. If you want to have an enjoyable couple of hours, definitely check this one out. It's a refreshing take on the Christmas movie genre that will leave you smiling and entertained from start to finish.

text: The Finnish version of Robert Altman's "Short Cuts", set in the small rural town of Äänekoski. The episodes present a kaleidoscope of the eternal events, problems and emotions of human life: joy and love, deception and disillusionment, hopelessness and death. I was particularly impressed by two episodes. The first is the story of the young waitress, who tries to stir up a romance for his co-workers: she radiates an overwhelming joy of love and life. The other episode presents and old man dying in a hospital and his wife trying to help him die with dignity. Particularly striking is the way the old couple have to fight their way against the humiliating practices of the hospital and their loneliness contrasted with the "routines" of the hospital crew (despite the signs of occasional empathy). Compared with Altman's classic, this movie is perhaps less professional, but it is definitely a great piece of art.
rewritten_review:
The Finnish version of Robert Altman's "Short Cuts," set in the small rural town of Äänekoski, presents a captivating and mesmerizing kaleidoscope of the eternal events, problems, and emotions of human life: joy and love, deception and disillusionment, hopelessness and death. Each episode unfolds with a unique perspective, painting a vivid tapestry of life's complexities and intricacies. The narrative weaves together various stories, each touching upon the universal themes that resonate deeply with the audience. Among the many compelling episodes, I was particularly impressed by two that stood out for their emotional depth and resonance.

The first is the touching story of a young waitress who is filled with an infectious and overwhelming joy of love and life. She brings a vibrant energy to her workplace, trying tirelessly to stir up a romance among her co-workers. Her enthusiasm and zest for life are palpable, and she radiates a sense of optimism that is both refreshing and inspiring. Her character embodies a spirit that is both hopeful and endearing, reminding us of the simple yet profound power of love and human connection. Her story is a testament to the enduring hope and joy that love can bring, even in the most mundane of settings.

The other episode that left a lasting impression on me presents the poignant tale of an old man dying in a hospital, with his devoted wife by his side, trying fervently to help him die with dignity. Their journey is marked by a profound sense of love and resilience as they navigate the challenges posed by the hospital's often impersonal and humiliating practices. Despite the occasional signs of empathy from the hospital staff, the couple's struggle against loneliness and the cold routines of the hospital is heart-wrenching. The stark contrast between the couple's intimate struggle and the detached routines of the hospital crew highlights the universal quest for dignity and respect in the face of mortality.

The film, when compared with Altman's classic, may appear less professional in its execution, but it is undeniably a great piece of art. It captures the essence of human experience with a raw and unfiltered honesty that is both moving and thought-provoking. The Finnish version of "Short Cuts" offers a unique and compelling perspective on life, artfully exploring the intricate tapestry of human emotions and experiences. It is a film that resonates deeply, leaving a lasting impact on its audience, and reminding us of the timeless truths of life, love, and the human condition.

text: Hi! I'm Sheena, an African (yet white!) jungle tribal princess who possesses the incredible ability to transform into the cheapest, unscariest monster in the world (think 60s Star Trek aliens) by rolling seductively in mud! When I first found myself in this horrible position, I took the only logical action: I made myself a torn-apart jungle bikini in which to perform my badly-acted antics. I enjoy romance novels and tearing apart the occasional unimpressive African warlord. And I would be remiss if I did not mention my (white, of course) sidekick Mr. Cutter, an American ex-military man who seems to have fled the U.S. after his divorce. Can you say "ducking alimony"? Anyway, he provides the occasional distraction from my difficult life. I mean, how many idiot blonds do you know who are also an endangered species of flesh-rending monster? Despite my many hardships (acting is so hard! *whine*), I haven't given up, and after much soul-searching, I have finally discovered my role in life: to terrorize insomniatic late-night television viewers who are so unfortunate as to not have cable or satellite.
rewritten_review: Hi! I'm Sheena, an African (yet white!) jungle tribal princess with the ability to transform into the cheapest, unscariest monster (think 60s Star Trek aliens) by rolling seductively in mud! Stuck in this position, I made a torn-apart jungle bikini for my badly-acted antics. I enjoy romance novels and tearing apart the occasional unimpressive African warlord. I must mention my (white, of course) sidekick Mr. Cutter, an American ex-military man who fled the U.S. after his divorce. Can you say "ducking alimony"? He provides occasional distraction from my difficult life. I mean, how many idiot blonds are also an endangered species of flesh-rending monster? Despite my hardships (acting is so hard! *whine*), I haven't given up. After much soul-searching, I've found my role: to terrorize insomniac late-night TV viewers unfortunate enough to not have cable or satellite.

text: "Visitor Q" is a failed attempt at black comedy which focuses on what might be the world's most dysfunctional family including physical abuse from beatings to murder to incest to sodomy to necrophilia to a lactating mom who nurses her husband and adult daughter, etc. The film is so outrageous it garnered some critical praise and established a small cult following. However, with home video quality and a slapdash production, "Visitor Q" just doesn't hold up even as a curiosity. Genitals are blurred out and sanitary appliances clearly visible, make-up is awful, and everything else is amateurish at best. A waste of time. (C-)
rewritten_review: "Visitor Q" is a failed attempt at black comedy which focuses on what might be the world's most dysfunctional family, including physical abuse from beatings to murder to incest to sodomy to necrophilia to a lactating mom who nurses her husband and adult daughter, etc. The film is so outrageous it garnered some critical praise and established a small cult following. However, with home video quality and a slapdash production, "Visitor Q" just doesn't hold up even as a curiosity. Genitals are blurred out, and sanitary appliances are clearly visible, making it difficult to take any of the scenes seriously. The make-up is awful, lacking any semblance of professionalism or attention to detail, and everything else about the film is amateurish at best. The acting feels forced and unnatural, which further detracts from any potential enjoyment. The narrative itself seems disjointed and lacks coherence, leaving viewers confused and disengaged. The editing is choppy, making transitions jarring and uncomfortable to watch. Even the soundtrack fails to enhance the experience, instead becoming a distracting element that adds to the overall sense of disarray. Ultimately, "Visitor Q" is a waste of time. The film's attempt to shock and provoke falls flat, as the execution is so poor that it renders any intended impact ineffective. The premise might have had potential if handled with more care and expertise, but sadly, this is not the case here. Viewers looking for dark humor or insightful commentary on family dynamics will find themselves sorely disappointed. (C-)

text:
The Three Stooges has always been some of the many actors that I have loved. I love just about every one of the shorts that they have made. I love all six of the Stooges (Curly, Shemp, Moe, Larry, Joe, and Curly Joe)! All of the shorts are hilarious and also star many other great actors and actresses which a lot of them was in many of the shorts! In My opinion The Three Stooges is some of the greatest actors ever and is the all time funniest comedy team!

One of the most hilarious Three Stooges shorts is Men in Black. In this short are Bud Jamison, Jeanie Roberts, Phyllis Crane, Dell Henderson, 'Little Billy' Rhodes, Billy Gilbert, and Ruth Hiatt The acting by these actors are good especially by Jamison and Roberts. There are many funny scenes here that I think most Three Stooges fans will love! In My opinion this one of the most different Three Stooges shorts. I recommend this one to all!
rewritten_review:
The Three Stooges has always been some of the many actors that I have loved. I love just about every one of the shorts that they have made. I love all six of the Stooges (Curly, Shemp, Moe, Larry, Joe, and Curly Joe)! Their comedic style, slapstick humor, and impeccable timing have made them timeless icons of comedy, and their work continues to bring laughter to audiences of all ages. All of the shorts are hilarious and also star many other great actors and actresses which a lot of them was in many of the shorts! In my opinion, The Three Stooges is some of the greatest actors ever and is the all-time funniest comedy team! Their unique ability to create chaos and humor in every situation they find themselves in is truly unmatched, and their legacy in the world of comedy is unparalleled. 

One of the most hilarious Three Stooges shorts is "Men in Black." This short is a classic and showcases the Stooges at their comedic best. In this short are Bud Jamison, Jeanie Roberts, Phyllis Crane, Dell Henderson, 'Little Billy' Rhodes, Billy Gilbert, and Ruth Hiatt. The ensemble cast adds an extra layer of entertainment to the short, making it a must-watch for fans of classic comedy. The acting by these actors are good especially by Jamison and Roberts. Their performances complement the Stooges' antics perfectly, creating a seamless blend of humor and talent. There are many funny scenes here that I think most Three Stooges fans will love! From the slapstick gags to the witty dialogue, every moment is crafted to elicit laughter and enjoyment. In my opinion, this is one of the most different Three Stooges shorts. Its unique storyline and setting set it apart from many of their other works, offering a refreshing take on their usual comedic style. I recommend this one to all! If you're a fan of classic comedy or simply looking for a good laugh, this short is sure to deliver. Whether you're a longtime fan of the Stooges or new to their work, "Men in Black" is a perfect example of why they remain beloved figures in the world of comedy.

text: When a movie called Hell Ride comes out you expect a certain amount of biker cliché. With character names like "Pistolero", "Comanche" and "The Gent" I braced myself for the worse and was punch in the face by just that. The dialogue, soundtrack and shooting style are standard for biker movies. Dusty desert blurred from the heat as bikes coming tearing down the road while "CC Rider" plays and they talk about sex and violence. Yawn! The three leads were just ridiculous and unbelievable. Seeing old men like Bishop and Madsen (in a freaking ruffled shirt) riding down a dusty strip of desert highway reminded me of two men trying desperately to relive their youth. Poor Eric Balfour tried his best but with such poor material it got lost. Even an appearance by Dennis Hopper in full Easy Rider swing, couldn't save it. And let's talk about the store bought tans shall we? Many have compared this to Tarantino's work. It is not even close. What makes Tarantino's work so brilliant is he knows it's over the top so he just goes balls out and takes it as far over the top as possible. Bishop took this film so seriously that it became nothing more than a poor copy of the exploitation genre.
rewritten_review: When a movie called Hell Ride comes out, you expect biker clichés. With character names like "Pistolero," "Comanche," and "The Gent," I braced myself for the worst and got just that. The dialogue, soundtrack, and shooting style are standard for biker movies: dusty desert, bikes tearing down the road to "CC Rider," and talk of sex and violence. Yawn! The three leads were ridiculous and unbelievable. Seeing old men like Bishop and Madsen (in a ruffled shirt) riding down a dusty desert highway felt like watching two men desperately trying to relive their youth. Poor Eric Balfour tried his best, but the poor material lost him. Even Dennis Hopper in full Easy Rider swing couldn't save it. And let's talk about the store-bought tans, shall we? Many have compared this to Tarantino's work; it's not even close. Tarantino knows his work is over the top and takes it as far as possible. Bishop took this film so seriously it became a poor copy of the exploitation genre.

text:
I wish I had something more positive to say about Devil Fish, but I honestly can't seem to come up with much. I can't even come up with many of those "so bad, it's good" kind of moments. Devil Fish is just plain old bad. The plot is completely derivative (Jaws, anyone?), the acting is wooden, the characters are uninteresting, the special effects are beyond bad, and the score is annoying. Add to that the seemingly inept direction of Lamberto Bava and you've got one stinker of a movie. I think, however, that the film's biggest sin is its lack of a budget. It doesn't appear that Bava had much to work with. By 1984, the Italian film industry was in full decline  especially as far as genre films go. The funding available to Bava was most probably very meager. Film's like Devil Fish that rely on special effects just never had a chance to be good. It's not the only Italian film to suffer this fate. There are a number of Italian movies made in the mid-80s whose ideas and concepts far exceeded what anyone could realistically have expected given their budgetary limitations.

However, having said all that and noting the film's many weaknesses, I can't bring myself to rate Devil Fish lower than a 3/10. I've even considered rating it higher but can't because I realize how bad a movie it is. Why don't I rate it lower? Well that's hard to explain. Despite the many problems found in the movie, there's something about Devil Fish that I inexplicably enjoy. It could be as simple as my love for low-budget, cheesy, Italian movies. Maybe my taste in movies is horribly skewed, but I enjoy what I enjoy.

The Mystery Science Theater 3000 treatment of Devil Fish is actually very enjoyable. I rate Devil Fish a 4/5 on my MST3K rating scale. The guys do a fine job of poking fun at the movie's many flaws. One very astute observation comes very early in the commentary when Tom Servo notes, "Just because you can edit, doesn't mean you should"  highlighting yet another of the many weaknesses to be found in Devil Fish.
rewritten_review:
I wish I had something more positive to say about Devil Fish, but I honestly can't come up with much. It's not even "so bad, it's good." Devil Fish is just plain bad. The plot is derivative (Jaws, anyone?), the acting is wooden, the characters are uninteresting, the special effects are beyond bad, and the score is annoying. Add in the inept direction of Lamberto Bava, and you've got one stinker of a movie. The film's biggest sin is its lack of budget. By 1984, the Italian film industry was in decline, especially genre films. Bava's funding was likely meager, and films like Devil Fish that rely on special effects never had a chance. Many Italian movies from the mid-80s suffered this fate, with concepts exceeding their budgetary limitations.

Despite these weaknesses, I can't rate Devil Fish lower than a 3/10. I've even considered rating it higher but can't because I realize how bad it is. Why don't I rate it lower? It's hard to explain. Despite its many problems, I inexplicably enjoy Devil Fish. It could be my love for low-budget, cheesy, Italian movies. My taste might be skewed, but I enjoy what I enjoy.

The Mystery Science Theater 3000 treatment of Devil Fish is very enjoyable. I rate it 4/5 on my MST3K scale. The guys do a fine job poking fun at its flaws. A notable observation comes early when Tom Servo says, "Just because you can edit, doesn't mean you should," highlighting another weakness of Devil Fish.

text: RAINBOW BRITE AND THE STAR STEALER, in my opinion, is an excellent masterpiece. I felt all warm and tingly when Rainbow Brite (voice of Bettina) and Krys (voice of David Mendenhall) set out to get revenge on the princess (voice of Rhonad Aldrich). If you ask me, the princess was absolutely bitchy and diabolical. To me, she deserved to have Rainbow Brite and Krys seek revenge on him. However, I liked her castle as well as the rest of the setting. In addition, I thought that Lurky (voiec of Pat Fraley) and Murky (voiec of Peter Cullen) were diabolical. Before I wrap this up, I'd like to say that everyone was perfectly cast, the direction was flawless, and Disney has scored a big hit. In conclusion, I highly recommend this excellent masterpiece to everyone who hasn't seen it, especially die-hard fans of the TV series. I guarantee you you'll enjoy it.
rewritten_review: RAINBOW BRITE AND THE STAR STEALER, in my opinion, is an excellent masterpiece. As I watched the film, I felt all warm and tingly when Rainbow Brite (voice of Bettina) and Krys (voice of David Mendenhall) set out to get revenge on the princess (voice of Rhonad Aldrich). If you ask me, the princess was absolutely bitchy and diabolical. To me, she deserved to have Rainbow Brite and Krys seek revenge on him. The storyline was engaging and kept me hooked from start to finish. However, I liked her castle as well as the rest of the setting. The visuals were stunning and added to the overall enchantment of the film. In addition, I thought that Lurky (voiec of Pat Fraley) and Murky (voiec of Peter Cullen) were diabolical. Their presence added another layer of excitement and intrigue to the story. Before I wrap this up, I'd like to say that everyone was perfectly cast, the direction was flawless, and Disney has scored a big hit with this film. The animation was top-notch, and the soundtrack was perfectly suited to the magical atmosphere. In conclusion, I highly recommend this excellent masterpiece to everyone who hasn't seen it, especially die-hard fans of the TV series. I guarantee you you'll enjoy it. It’s a delightful adventure that captures the essence of the beloved characters and brings them to life in a vibrant and captivating way. Don't miss out on experiencing the wonder and joy that is RAINBOW BRITE AND THE STAR STEALER!

text:
Well, This was my first IMAX experience so I was pretty blown away about that, primarily; although with hindsight, I can't help wishing that it had been some other (less monochrome)film.

Magnificent Desolation very much had the "Programme for Schools" feel the way it listed all the astronauts and this made it feel a LOT like reading National Geographic Magazine in 3D. Weirdly it actually had a very two dimensional quality that only occasionally exploded into reality and a lot of time it felt like some PowerPoint Presentation. There was a moment in the film when an unnoticed abyss opens; seemingly at your feel, that had a bit of a WOW factor but to be honest, that may have had more to do with me being an IMAX virgin.

The commentary, provided by Tom Hanks, I personally found very, (what's a nice way to put it??) "flag-wavingly nationalistic" which didn't go down too well in central London, judging by remarks overheard as we left.

Over all, I loved the IMAX experience, but dearly wish a different film had been on on that day. The Moon isn't a particularly colourful subject and to be honest, a lot of the 3D effects were lost in the monochrome scenery. All that would have been well, were it not for the documentary inserts and distractions like the interviews with American schoolchildren which spoiled it a bit
rewritten_review: Well, this was my first IMAX experience, so I was pretty blown away by that, primarily. With hindsight, I wish it had been a different, less monochrome film. Magnificent Desolation had a "Programme for Schools" feel, listing all the astronauts, making it feel like reading National Geographic in 3D. It weirdly had a two-dimensional quality that only occasionally exploded into reality, often feeling like a PowerPoint Presentation. A moment in the film featured an unnoticed abyss opening at your feet, creating a WOW factor, but that might be due to my being an IMAX virgin. The commentary by Tom Hanks felt very "flag-wavingly nationalistic," which didn't go down well in central London, judging by remarks overheard as we left. Overall, I loved the IMAX experience but wished for a different film that day. The Moon isn't particularly colorful, and many 3D effects were lost in the monochrome scenery. The documentary inserts and distractions, like interviews with American schoolchildren, spoiled it a bit.

text:
William Shakespeare's plays are classified as comedy, tragedy, or history. Some of his most memorable --and most often read -- creations provide us with wistful humor, gentle poetry and hilarious slapstick. Some of them survive as unforgettable dramas of compelling depth and gravity. Regardless, he was able to write with unparalleled skill and inventiveness, contributing greatly to our young language. So in what category lies The Merchant of Venice ? I was very surprised to find it is one of Shakespeare's comedies. I had never before read it nor seen it, but after watching this most recent film version I have decided it is neither and it is both. This is one of many questions the viewer must try to answer when coming to terms with what is clearly a perplexing and deeply troubling moral tragedy.

The players are introduced quickly, and simply. One of them, firstly, is Venice itself; director Michael Radford filmed the Venetian scenes in the actual city, creating an impressively vibrant, bustling backdrop to the play's proceedings. To this scenery enters the youthful Bassanio (Joseph Fiennes), returning to Venice to see a dear old friend, Antonio (Jeremy Irons). It seems the poor Bassanio has heard of a princess whose father has died and has left to any potential suitors a lottery of sorts. Waiting at the fair lady's island estate are three small trunks,

only one of which contains "images of the princess". He who can guess the right one, using only blind intuition and the cryptic teasers written upon them, will be bestowed the father's huge fortune for life. Oh, and his daughter and her eternal love in marriage, I forgot to mention. Here the light comedy of Shakespeare takes over the movie. This farcical plot element drives the story and also fills up much of the film's screen time, as a number of painfully eager opportunists arrive at the island, humorously vying for and failing to earn this very wealthy hand in marriage. But before any of this occurs Bassanio, very much lacking in finances, entreats Antonio to loan him three thousand ducats to pay for the lengthy journey he must take to have his shot at the prize.

Antonio, himself nearly penniless, must reluctantly embrace humility by seeking the financial aid of Shylock (Al Pacino), one of countless Jewish usurers who keep the sagging economy afloat yet are scorned and persecuted to no end by the city's zealously Christian majority. Thus they dwell in society's underbelly, and it is here the two borrowers must go. Shylock does not hesitate to remind the two men of a certain incident where Antonio insulted and spat on him in the city market, and he proudly rebukes this man who frankly has a lot of nerve now coming to ask for help. But help him Shylock does. He even erases any kind of interest on the loan, most likely feeling he has no reason to be concerned if Antonio will be able to repay him within three months. Still, Shylock's one contractual demand is a pound of Antonio's flesh, should he renege on their agreement. This is an unsettling request, to be sure, for Antonio and Bassanio as well as for us. But it appears that despite his justifiable pride Shylock does not really anticipate seeing such a gruesome act occurring.

So here the dramatic groundwork has been laid. And while the film goes off to explore its gentler side with its love lottery and mistaken identities, there still looms the gloomy prospect of the loan itself. In the end, what will become of this ominous agreement? Meanwhile we are left at turns to explore the true central character of Shylock. Al Pacino has ample dramatic weight to carry here, and he does so with convincing grit and passion. There are times when he is given room for the theatrics we have come to expect from such a colorful actor. But his most impressive scenes are the ones where he internalizes this energy, showing a conflicted personality: honest, sincere, and proud, yet brooding, vengeful and entirely remorseless. This is one of Pacino's most heartfelt performances to date. And while the rest of the cast play their roles creditably and convincingly, it is Pacino who really owns the film -- especially toward the end, when Shakespeare upends this seeming romantic comedy with a wallop of a third act.

I shall not reveal much here; all I can say is that it involves the initial loan -- a mighty shoe one expected would drop sooner or later. And does it ever. By the end Shakespeare has raised a host of dilemmas for his audience: seemingly unresolvable questions of faith, morality, law, and mercy are thrown before us through the final scenes, and while by curtain's close the playwright's position may seem clear to some, we are left completely at odds. There are winners and losers in this one, but have the winners earned their spoils with good reason, or have they in a larger sense ended out losing as well? Has virtue been rewarded, or simply flouted? Has justice in fact this time been just? By the play's finish some fates are painfully clear, and unequivocally sealed. But the audience are to be the ones who really decide the verdict for all of those involved. And for some the verdict is still out for the play as well. Comedy or tragedy? The author has cunningly veiled the intense courtroom finale with an ending of light mirth and pat romantic resolutions. Is he saying that all is well that ends well, or is this his final, ironic condemnation? The play's humor serves to set us up nicely for such a heavy crash. And while it is also what unfortunately keeps The Merchant of Venice from achieving the greatness of so many of Shakespeare's other works, it is still engaging, amusing, and thought-provoking beyond measure.
rewritten_review:

So in what category lies The Merchant of Venice? I was surprised to find it is one of Shakespeare's comedies. After watching the most recent film version, I decided it is neither and it is both. The humor sets us up for a heavy crash.
