text:
The first part, Che in Cuba, is about that portion of his life. It contains too many indistinguishable battles and Che ministering to too many indistinguishable wounded (remember that Che was a physician). It ends as Castro wins the revolution; Che never gets to Havana. The second part, Che in Bolivia, is about guess what. It contains too many indistinguishable battles and Che ministering to too many indistinguishable wounded.

When I realized this was supposed to be an "epic" (I never knew *anything* but the title before it started), I naturally thought of the greatest epic of them all, David Lean's Lawrence of Arabia. More of that later.

Not to be a racist, but aside from what I've already mentioned is the fact that there are too many characters who are, well, indistinguishable -- unknown Hispanic actors who look alike, especially considering they all wear "Che" beards and all wear Che fatigues. This results in the viewer not being able to identify with anyone other than Che, Benicio del Toro (even Fidel has a very minor role). While del Toro's terrific, think of "Lawrence" with Peter O'Toole as the only discernible character: no Alec Guinness, no Omar Sharif, no Anthony Quinn, etc. You get the idea.

Because the other characters are interchangeable, this results in a loss of reference. When top aides of Che are killed, you feel no remorse since you don't know who they are. Even when Che is killed (I don't think that's a spoiler), there's no empathy from the audience -- he's just killed.

He's too one-dimensional to relate to as a human being. Aside from being a revolutionary and second only to Jesus in moral rectitude, the only thing we learn about Che is that he's married with five children (he tells another character that near the end). What was his motivation? A complete enigma.

Maybe Soderbergh is purposely aping Lean. Like Soderbergh's Che, Lean never lets us know anything about Lawrence, the mystery man of Arabia. But at least Lawrence had a friend (Sharif) and associates (Guinness, Quinn). He was as courageous as he was insecure -- i.e., had human qualities. Che is like a machine, about as warm as The Terminator.

Earlier this year there was another war epic, Mongol. Che makes Mongol look like It's a Wonderful Life.
rewritten_review:
The first part, Che in Cuba, details Che's life with too many indistinguishable battles and wounded (Che was a physician). It ends as Castro wins the revolution; Che never reaches Havana. The second part, Che in Bolivia, is similar with indistinguishable battles and wounded.

Realizing this was an "epic," I thought of David Lean's Lawrence of Arabia. More on that later.

Not to be a racist, but there are too many indistinguishable characters—unknown Hispanic actors who look alike, all wearing "Che" beards and fatigues. This makes it hard to identify with anyone other than Che, played by Benicio del Toro. Even Fidel's role is minor. While del Toro's terrific, imagine "Lawrence" with Peter O'Toole as the only discernible character: no Alec Guinness, no Omar Sharif, no Anthony Quinn.

Because characters are interchangeable, there's a loss of reference. When Che's top aides die, there's no remorse—you don't know them. Even when Che dies, there's no audience empathy—he's just killed.

Che is too one-dimensional to relate to. Aside from being a revolutionary and morally upright, we only learn he has a family near the end. His motivation is an enigma.

Maybe Soderbergh is aping Lean. Like Soderbergh's Che, Lean never reveals much about Lawrence. But Lawrence had a friend (Sharif) and associates (Guinness, Quinn). He was courageous and insecure—human qualities. Che is like a machine, as warm as The Terminator.

Earlier this year, Mongol, another war epic, made Che look like It's a Wonderful Life.

text: Jason Connery is not an actor; he is the son of an actor. His Macbeth is the worst I have ever seen. Oh yes, he murders king Duncan, but he also kills William Shakespeare. His wife is even worse. Please, give me Polanski's version on DVD, so I can forget this monster. Jon Finch, Orson Welles, Laurence Olivier, there you have ACTORS!
rewritten_review: Jason Connery is not an actor; he is the son of an actor. He may have acting in his blood, but it seems to have skipped a generation in terms of talent. His Macbeth is the worst I have ever seen. It is truly a performance that leaves much to be desired. Oh yes, he murders King Duncan, fulfilling the basic plot requirements of the play, but he also kills William Shakespeare in spirit, with his lackluster portrayal. His wife, in this rendition, is even worse, dragging down every scene she is in with her performance. Together, they fail to capture the essence of the tragic characters they are meant to embody. Please, give me Roman Polanski's version on DVD, so I can forget this monster. Jon Finch, Orson Welles, Laurence Olivier, there you have ACTORS! Those are the performers who truly bring the characters to life, delivering the complexity and depth that Shakespeare intended. Their portrayals are leagues ahead, and they set a standard that this version fails to meet.

text: I originally saw this very dark comedy around 2000 or so on cable TV. What a surprise and delight! Everyone is covertly armed in this movie! Dreyfuss plays the "mental" don (remember the New York don who was supposed to be schizophrenic? Art imitates life or vice-versa?). Diane Lane and Ellen Barkin are at their most beautiful and NOT to be toyed with! Thus proving that beauty and toughness DO go together! Then there is the great "bullshit" scene between Barkin and Jeff Goldblum (Rita and Mickey) where they verbally play off the world "bullshit." This film is both subtle and bald. For all the shooting, it can be a very quiet film. And, you have the opportunity to see several actors in their final or near final roles. Joey Bishop. Richard Pryor. Henry Silva. It is not a film for everyone. But, if you like a film that has a lot of word play and keeps moving without blowing up everything in sight, this is the film for you. Roger Ebert dumps on this film. He's flat wrong. THIS is a fine, fine film! Maybe just not one for Ebert. I consider it as a 10 because of how well it is done and how funny the script can be, while not really being a straight comedy kind of film. I like it so well that I bought it on DVD because it just doesn't get shown very much on cable TV. Now, it's all mine!
rewritten_review: I first saw this dark comedy around 2000 on cable TV and was pleasantly surprised! Everyone is covertly armed in this movie! Dreyfuss plays the "mental" don, reminiscent of the New York don who was supposedly schizophrenic. Diane Lane and Ellen Barkin are stunning and tough, proving beauty and toughness go together! The "bullshit" scene between Barkin and Jeff Goldblum is a highlight. The film is subtle yet bold, quiet despite the shooting. It features actors like Joey Bishop, Richard Pryor, and Henry Silva in final roles. It's not for everyone, but if you enjoy wordplay and action without constant explosions, this film is for you. Roger Ebert was wrong to dump on it; it’s a fine film! I rate it a 10 for its execution and humor, even though it's not a traditional comedy. I loved it so much I bought it on DVD since it's rarely on cable. Now, it's all mine!

text: I recently viewed Manufactured Landscapes at the Seattle International Film Festival. I was drawn to the movie as a photographer because I'm both familiar and a fan of Burtynsky's work. While I believe the movie does a good job getting it's message across, I couldn't help but feel that it was made as a complete afterthought to the photographs and subsequent popular book by Burtynsky. Obviously one reason for this is the extensive use of still photographs featuring zooms and pans across them. While this is a good effect when used economically, I felt like 75% of the movie was just stills from Burtynsky's book (which I already own). That's probably an exaggeration, but that's how I felt. If you own the book or are familiar with his work you might be better off skipping this one.
rewritten_review: I recently viewed Manufactured Landscapes at the Seattle International Film Festival. I was drawn to the movie as a photographer because I'm both familiar and a fan of Burtynsky's work. While I believe the movie does a good job getting its message across, I couldn't help but feel that it was made as a complete afterthought to the photographs and subsequent popular book by Burtynsky. Obviously, one reason for this is the extensive use of still photographs featuring zooms and pans across them. While this is a good effect when used economically, I felt like 75% of the movie was just stills from Burtynsky's book (which I already own). That's probably an exaggeration, but that's how I felt. If you own the book or are familiar with his work, you might be better off skipping this one. The film, while visually captivating, seems to lack a certain depth or originality beyond what the book already offers. The experience of seeing those images on a larger screen, with the added motion of zooms and pans, doesn't quite capture the same intrigue or novelty that you may expect if you are already well-acquainted with Burtynsky's powerful photographs. The documentary presents itself as a cinematic journey, yet it misses the mark in providing a new or enriched perspective beyond the stills that many fans, including myself, have already seen and appreciated in the book. It may be worth watching for those who are new to Burtynsky's work, but for those who have spent time immersed in his photography, the film might not offer much more than what they have already experienced through his printed work. Given this, I would suggest that if you own the book or are familiar with his work, you might be better off skipping this one and perhaps revisiting the book itself to relive the impact of his photography in a format that feels more intimate and impactful.

text: Anand is one of those low-budget but well taken movies. It's a "cup of coffee" entertainment, with no violence, blood or "jump out of your seat" excitement which most telugu films have. However, it does have some massala of it's own. Roopa is a headstrong and down-to-earth young woman who is not afraid to confront any sort of situation, even her offensive mother-in-law's distaste for her. She even backs out of the wedding because her fiancé doesn't stand up for her. However, her air of confidence and independence is enough to make Anand, a rich young gentleman living in the city, aspire to be her new husband. His father accidentally kills her parents in a car crash anyways, so why not pay her back? But Roopa is not the kind who will fall for charming smiles and polite behavior, she puts him through a bunch of situations, continuing to be rude and a pain. It's not until he stands up for her and saves her life that she understands she loves him too. But complications ensue
rewritten_review: Anand is a low-budget yet well-crafted movie, offering "cup of coffee" entertainment without the typical violence or excitement found in many Telugu films, though it has its own masala. Roopa is a strong, grounded woman unafraid to face challenges, including her offensive mother-in-law. She even cancels her wedding when her fiancé fails to support her. Her confidence captivates Anand, a wealthy city gentleman, who aspires to marry her, especially since his father accidentally killed her parents in a car crash. However, Roopa isn't swayed by charm alone and tests him through various trials. It's only when he defends her and saves her life that she realizes her love for him. But complications follow...

text:
I hadn't planned on seeing this movie, however I wasn't disappointed when a friend dragged me along. Although there are no real surprises here, the guys do reasonably well with their obviously modest budget.

If you've seen the trailer you probably know what to expect from this type of movie and there's a pretty constant stream of jokes here, with a couple of classic moments, with the highpoint probably being an excellent flashback to what the guys were like in the 1980's. Also, I've read elsewhere that the ending was a disappointment, but I found it refreshingly different from what I had expected from this genre.

Overall, this movie wont change your life, but it's got enough laughs there to keep you entertained throughout.
rewritten_review: I hadn't planned on seeing this movie at first, however, I wasn't disappointed when a friend dragged me along to see it. Although there are no real surprises here, the guys do reasonably well with their obviously modest budget. The film presents a familiar setup that doesn't stray too far from what one might anticipate, yet it manages to hold your attention. If you've seen the trailer, you probably know what to expect from this type of movie. There's a pretty constant stream of jokes here, with a couple of classic moments that stand out. The highpoint is probably an excellent flashback to what the guys were like in the 1980s, which adds a nostalgic and humorous touch. This scene alone is worth the watch as it captures the essence of the era with a comedic twist. Also, I've read elsewhere that the ending was a disappointment for some viewers, but I found it refreshingly different from what I had expected from this genre. It took a turn that diverged from the typical formula, which was a pleasant surprise and added a unique element to the film's conclusion. Overall, this movie won't change your life or redefine the genre, but it's got enough laughs there to keep you entertained throughout its runtime. It's a light-hearted experience that doesn't demand much from the audience, providing an enjoyable escape for a couple of hours. So, if you're in the mood for a fun, easygoing film with some good laughs, this might just be the right pick for you.

text: It is amazing to me what passes for entertainment today. maybe I am a dinosaur from the fifties, and I am out of touch with todays movie going generation, and apparently that is the case with regards to this movie, since so many people loved it. I found it foul and vulgar. I haven't said that about many movies in my life but this one fits the bill. The humor is sophomoric and crude. I am not a politically correct person, and even I found the gay jokes, not only not funny but downright offensive ( I'm not gay). The main character in the movie is not even a likable person, just pathetic. When the movie was finally over i heard a number of people comment on how disappointed they were in what they had just pay good money to see.
rewritten_review: It is truly amazing to me what passes for entertainment today. Perhaps I am a dinosaur from the fifties, and maybe I am completely out of touch with today's movie-going generation, and apparently, that is indeed the case with regards to this particular movie, since so many people seemed to have loved it. However, I found it to be foul and vulgar, and I haven't said that about many movies in my life, but this one definitely fits the bill. The humor throughout the film is sophomoric and crude. I am not someone who considers themselves to be politically correct by any stretch of the imagination, and even I found the gay jokes to be not only not funny but downright offensive (and I should note that I'm not gay). The main character in the movie is not even a likable person; instead, they come off as just pathetic. When the movie was finally over, I heard a number of people around me commenting on how disappointed they were in what they had just paid good money to see. It seems that I was not alone in my sentiments, as there were others in the audience who shared my sense of dissatisfaction with the film.

text:
Wendigo is a pretty good psychological thriller, the film has some great drama between the characters and some good creepy scenes. The acting is good, the characters act like a normal family. The Wendigo effects are good, the Deer Form reminded me a little of the Rabbit in Donnie Darko.

The film sees a family going to stay at a house for a while but accidental hit a deer, a group of hunters arrives and one of the hunters named Otis starts to argue with the Dad George, after the car is lifted they drive off to the house. The Son Miles is a little shook up about the Deer but his Parents try to tell him that it's natural for things like that to happen. That night while he's in bed he starts to see weird things in bedroom, the next day they go into to town and Miles meets a man at the counter who gives him a little statue of the Wendigo, when Miles shows Kim the statue and tells her that a man at the counter gave it him the owner says the she only works there. Once returning home George takes his son sledding and while there sledding he's knocked off the board and Miles is chases by the wind, after gaining conciseness they go looking for George, they find him outside the house where he tells them he was shot, in the Hospital Kim tells the Sheriff that Otis may have shot him, the Shrieff goes to Otis's place where he's bashed over the head with a hammer, as Otis drives down the road he finds that the Wendigo is after him.

Wendigo is a pretty good thriller that has some chilling moments. Check this out. 10/10
rewritten_review:
Wendigo is a pretty good psychological thriller with great drama between the characters and some creepy scenes. The acting is good, and the characters act like a normal family. The Wendigo effects are good, with the Deer Form reminiscent of the Rabbit in Donnie Darko.

The film follows a family staying at a house, but after accidentally hitting a deer, they encounter a group of hunters. One hunter, Otis, argues with the dad, George. After their car is lifted, they drive to the house. The son, Miles, is shaken by the deer incident, but his parents reassure him. That night, he sees weird things in his bedroom. The next day in town, Miles receives a Wendigo statue from a mysterious man. When he shows it to Kim, the owner claims she only works there. Back home, George and Miles go sledding, but Miles is chased by the wind. They find George outside the house, shot. At the hospital, Kim suspects Otis. The sheriff visits Otis, but is attacked. Otis then encounters the Wendigo.

Wendigo is a solid thriller with chilling moments. Check it out. 10/10

text: Years ago I saw The Godfather and it made a lasting impression on me, the atmosphere of the movie was first class, the acting memorable and the storyline a classic. Recently I bought the Trilogy and after watching Part 1 again I looked eagerly to viewing Part 2...... I was so pleased to realize early on into Part 2 that here was a fitting follow on to the great Godfather movie, again everything was just about perfect and I could not wait to see Godfather III ........ WRONG!, I wish I'd stopped at II. The storyline was not good, it seemed to me like a story made up just to have a story, the characters were weak especially the daughter. Pacino's protege was a weak character that would have been eaten alive in Godfather 1 or 2. Then scenes such as, Corleone being invested with all the trappings of the Catholic Church with full choir, the assassin on horseback riding away into the sunset, the unseen helicopter machine gunning of the meeting (where the 'goodies' get away and everyone else is shot),daughter and 1st cousin rolling bits of pasta across a board, the pathetic shooting on the steps ..... Corleone stuffing sweets down him with orange juice for diabetes (a man of his intelligence and guile isn't ready for an emergency?)... NO it was not good and with the best will in the world I wont be able to watch it again. But I'll watch 1 & 2 many times down the years.
rewritten_review: Years ago I saw The Godfather, and it made a lasting impression on me. The atmosphere, acting, and storyline were exceptional. After buying the Trilogy, I eagerly watched Part 2 and was pleased to find it a fitting follow-up to the original. Everything was almost perfect, and I couldn't wait for Godfather III. WRONG! I wish I'd stopped at II. The storyline felt forced, and the characters were weak, especially the daughter. Pacino's protege was feeble compared to characters in the first two films. Scenes like Corleone's Catholic Church ceremony, the horseback assassin, the helicopter machine-gunning, and the cousin romance were disappointing. Corleone's lack of readiness for a diabetes emergency was implausible. It wasn't good, and I won't watch it again, but I'll revisit 1 & 2 many times over the years.

text: This is a great story and was just the beginning of equality in the United States. (We are still working on it too.) However despite the fact this is true, it's still a movie and this is a movie site. I realize independent films have a hard time getting good actors, but wow. The only one even mediocre is the excellent Ossie Davis. But even he couldn't make up for all the actors (including the one playing him as a young man) absolutely atrocious acting. Granted the script was terribly cliché, but even then you have got to get some decent actors! I wouldn't recommend this to anybody because it is so poorly done in every category. Read some books about the true story of the U.S.S Mason, because they give these men the respect they deserve.
rewritten_review: This is a great story and was just the beginning of equality in the United States. (We are still working on it too.) However, despite the fact that this is true, it's still a movie, and this is a movie site where we discuss films in detail. I realize independent films have a hard time getting good actors, but wow, this was a challenge to watch. The only one who even managed to be mediocre is the excellent Ossie Davis. But even he couldn't make up for all the other actors, including the one playing him as a young man, whose performances were absolutely atrocious. Granted, the script was terribly cliché, but even then, you have got to get some decent actors to deliver those lines! The lack of talent across the board was painfully obvious and detracted from what could have been a powerful narrative. I wouldn't recommend this to anybody because it is so poorly done in every category, from the acting to the directing to the overall production quality. It's unfortunate because the story of the U.S.S Mason is incredibly important and deserves to be told with the dignity and respect that these men earned. I strongly encourage anyone interested in this piece of history to read some books about the true story of the U.S.S Mason, because they give these men the respect they deserve and provide a far more accurate and compelling account of their experiences. The film, unfortunately, falls short in every way possible and does not do justice to the bravery and legacy of the crew.

text:
Oh, what fun there is here!

Amy Heckerling has a flair for directing comedy (Fast Times at Ridgemont High, Look Who's Talking) but here it looks like she told the actors to go out and have fun. Micheal Keaton breezes through the role of Johnny, easily his best screen performance. Joe Piscopo is great as the appropriately named Danny Vermin, what a shame directors didn't pick up on this. And I have even mentioned Richard Dimitri playing Moronie and the character's unique vocabulary. I don't think it's an accident that the bulk of the character's name is spelled MORON.

Good lines are sprinkled throughout the movie, with Peter Boyle, Griffit Dunne.Maurren Stapleton, Merilu Henner given good lines. Even actors with minor roles like Dick Butkus and Alan Hale get in a good lines.

recommend it to a friend.
rewritten_review:
Oh, what fun there is here! Amy Heckerling has a flair for directing comedy (Fast Times at Ridgemont High, Look Who's Talking) but here it looks like she told the actors to go out and have fun, embracing the whimsical and carefree nature of the film. Micheal Keaton breezes through the role of Johnny, easily delivering his best screen performance to date. His charisma and comedic timing are impeccable, making Johnny a memorable and endearing character. Joe Piscopo is great as the appropriately named Danny Vermin, showcasing his talent for physical comedy and witty dialogue, and it's truly a shame that directors didn't pick up on this potential sooner. And I haven't even mentioned Richard Dimitri playing Moronie and the character's unique vocabulary. The creative choice to infuse the character with such a distinctive way of speaking adds an extra layer of humor, and I don't think it's an accident that the bulk of the character's name is spelled MORON, hinting at the satirical nature of his persona.

Good lines are sprinkled throughout the movie, with Peter Boyle, Griffit Dunne, Maurren Stapleton, and Merilu Henner all given good lines that they deliver with perfect comedic timing. Their performances add depth and richness to the film's comedic landscape, ensuring that every scene is filled with laughter and entertainment. Even actors with minor roles like Dick Butkus and Alan Hale get in some good lines, proving that every character, no matter how small, contributes to the overall hilarity of the film. The attention to detail in the script and the performances of the entire cast make this movie a delightful experience from start to finish.

I wholeheartedly recommend it to a friend, confident that they will appreciate the humor, the performances, and the overall joy that this film brings. It's a comedy that stands the test of time, with its clever writing, talented cast, and the unmistakable touch of Amy Heckerling's direction. Whether you're in the mood for a lighthearted comedy or simply want to enjoy the brilliance of Michael Keaton and the ensemble cast, this movie is a must-watch that will leave you with a smile on your face.

text:
Judging by some of the comments in IMDB, I was expecting an action movie - perhaps a dramatic one or a stupid one or a simple one or a comicy one, but essentially an action movie.

Whatever it is that I watched, it certainly didn't feel like a movie. The story is simple and straightforward (even though the prologue tries to make it seem complicated). Take three interest groups: 1) the government 2) the rebels 3) a group of assassins.

Now subtract the first (they never appear in the movie). Then simply let one of the assassins, the princess, become a rogue on a revenge trip. Add in a rebel love-interest with a guilty conscience. And you've got the ingredients.

But they still did not manage to turn it into a story or a movie. Between some random action sequences and some odd visuals trying to be Sci-Fi on a low budget, what you're left with is a feeling of emptiness. The movie just does not feel like a movie, but a weird, incoherent, boring dream.

Avoid.

2/10
rewritten_review:
Judging by some comments on IMDB, I expected an action movie - dramatic, stupid, simple, or comicy, but essentially action.

Whatever I watched didn't feel like a movie. The story is simple and straightforward (despite the prologue's attempt to complicate it). Take three interest groups: 1) the government 2) the rebels 3) a group of assassins.

Subtract the first (they never appear). Let one assassin, the princess, go rogue on a revenge trip. Add a rebel love-interest with a guilty conscience. And you've got the ingredients.

But they didn't manage to turn it into a story or a movie. Between random action sequences and odd visuals trying to be low-budget Sci-Fi, you're left with emptiness. The movie feels more like a weird, incoherent, boring dream.

Avoid.

2/10

text: Lucio Fulci's "Don't Torture a Duckling" paints an exceptionally unflattering portrait of small-town Sicily plagued by series of brutal murders of young boys.This surprisingly well-directed film(especially in comparison to later Fulci's gorefests)is distinguished by overall atmosphere of perversity,nastiness and two truly grotesque scenes of brutal violence.The soon-to-be-dead children are depicted as casually cruel and budding peeping toms;Bruno's near-seduction by the naked Patrizia(Barbara Bouchet)really has to be seen to be believed.Highly recommended-especially in pair with my another cult favourite "House with the Windows That Laugh"(1976).
rewritten_review: Lucio Fulci's "Don't Torture a Duckling" paints an exceptionally unflattering portrait of small-town Sicily plagued by a series of brutal murders of young boys. This surprisingly well-directed film (especially in comparison to later Fulci's gorefests) is distinguished by an overall atmosphere of perversity, nastiness, and two truly grotesque scenes of brutal violence. The film manages to delve deep into the dark underbelly of a seemingly quaint and quiet village, exposing the raw and unsettling truths that lie beneath the surface. The soon-to-be-dead children are depicted as casually cruel and budding peeping toms; their portrayal adds an additional layer of discomfort and moral complexity to the narrative. Bruno's near-seduction by the naked Patrizia (Barbara Bouchet) really has to be seen to be believed, as it challenges the boundaries of propriety and viewer expectations, further deepening the film's provocative nature. Highly recommended—especially in pair with my other cult favorite "House with the Windows That Laugh" (1976). Together, these films offer a chilling exploration of human depravity and the macabre, making for an unforgettable viewing experience that is sure to linger in the minds of its audience long after the credits roll.

text: Of course the plot, script, and, especially casting are strong in the film. So many fine things to see. One aspect I liked especially is the idea of the antagonist--Luzhini's (Turturro's)--ex-mentor working his evil on the sidelines. His chess opponent--an Italian dandy in three piece and cane--turns out to be a real gent, and a truly fine chess player. To his credit the "opponent" nobly goes along with the plan at the end to complete the final game for the championship posthumously (Luzhin has taken a flyer out a window--sad, but so releasing to him)by way of the unstable genius' widow (Emily Watson.) In death, then, because of the gallantry of an honorable chess master, Luzhin's defence (which he worked out in a late moment of lucidity) is allowed to be played. The Italian gent commends the play and calls it brilliant. Talk about a dramatic "end game!"
rewritten_review: Of course, the plot, script, and, especially casting are strong in the film. So many fine things to see and appreciate throughout the entire cinematic experience. One aspect I liked especially is the idea of the antagonist—Luzhini’s (Turturro’s)—ex-mentor working his evil on the sidelines, subtly influencing events in a way that heightens the tension and drama of the storyline. His chess opponent—an Italian dandy in three-piece suit and cane—turns out to be a real gent, and a truly fine chess player, exhibiting both skill and class. To his credit, the "opponent" nobly goes along with the plan at the end to complete the final game for the championship posthumously. This is necessary because Luzhin has taken a flyer out a window—sad, but so releasing to him in a way that resonates deeply with the audience, capturing the tragic essence of his character. By way of the unstable genius' widow (Emily Watson), the game is allowed to continue, adding a layer of emotional complexity to the proceedings. In death, then, because of the gallantry of an honorable chess master, Luzhin’s defense (which he worked out in a late moment of lucidity) is allowed to be played, showcasing the brilliance of his troubled yet genius mind. The Italian gent commends the play and calls it brilliant, a testament to the respect and admiration that transcends rivalry. Talk about a dramatic "end game!" The conclusion of the film leaves viewers reflecting on the nature of genius, madness, and the thin line that often separates the two, as well as the enduring human qualities of honor and respect that can shine through even in the most competitive of arenas.

text:
I think this movie was probably a lot more powerful when it first debuted in 1943, though nowadays it seems a bit too preachy and static to elevate it to greatness. The film is set in 1940--just before the entry of the US into the war. Paul Lukas plays the very earnest and decent head of his family. He's a German who has spent seven years fighting the Nazis and avoiding capture. Bette Davis is his very understanding and long-suffering wife who has managed to educate and raise the children without him from time to time. As the film begins, they are crossing the border from Mexico to the USA and for the first time in years, they are going to relax and stop running.

The problem for me was that the family was too perfect and too decent--making them seem like obvious positive propaganda instead of a real family suffering through real problems. While this had a very noble goal at the time, it just seems phony today. In particular, the incredibly odd and extremely scripted dialog used by the children just didn't ring true. It sounded more like anti-Fascism speeches than the voices of real children. They were as a result extremely annoying--particularly the littlest one who came off, at times, as a brat. About the only ones who sounded real were Bette Davis and her extended American family as well as the scumbag Romanian living with them (though he had no discernible accent).

It's really tough to believe that the ultra-famous Dashiel Hammett wrote this dialog, as it just doesn't sound true to life. The story was based on the play by his lover, Lillian Hellman. And, the basic story idea and plot is good,...but the dialog is just bad at times. Overall, an interesting curio and a film with some excellent moments,...but that's really about all.
rewritten_review:
I think this movie was probably more powerful when it first debuted in 1943, though nowadays it seems a bit too preachy and static to elevate it to greatness. The film is set in 1940--just before the entry of the US into the war. Paul Lukas plays the very earnest and decent head of his family. text:
The story of this film is truly remarkable. A virus cut loose and only 1% of the human race survived. The only thing we know now is that animals rule the land above and there are posters everywhere that say, "The Twelve Monkeys did it." Thats right, the human race had to hide underground from the sickness that had killed over 500 Billion people. Apparently animals do not contract this disease. Day by day the present scientist try to discover what type of sickness had caused this; how it was created; if nature did it or a mere human being had created it. All they know is that there is are a bunch of animals running around a city above them, the deaths began during 1996-1997, and twelve monkeys have something to do with it. (Or at least thats what the poster says.) So a current convict named James Cole (Bruce Willis) is sent as a "volunteer" to get some samples from above. After he does his "volunteer" work, he is asked to be sent back in time to the year 1996 to figure out what happened to the world. Cole accepts and the story of the Twelve Monkeys begin.

Throughout the story the time machine gets the dates wrong quite a few times, from 1990, to some time during the 1950's. (In a middle of a war.) Throughout the time traveling back and forth, it starts to mess James up in the head and that twist the story up. The whole story is very well done and I would of gave it a higher grade if it wasn't for the ending. I personally didn't like the ending of the movie and I was very disappointed. I just was expecting a more explaining ending then what had happen, but it isn't everyone who thinks this way. So I gave it a 8, but if everyone had the same opinion as me I would give it a 6 or 7.

For the whole acting of the film, I give it a A+. Bruce Willis is great for this role and he acts good, but Brad Pitt is completely 100% excellent. His acting is so great, he gets into the character so well. I never really cared for Brad Pitt in till I saw him in this and Fight Club. There characters or similar in this film, he is just a little more... insane in this film. So overall I think this film is completely worth checking out. For most people it's a great science fiction film, I just don't think it is a masterpiece.
rewritten_review:
The story of this film is remarkable. A virus wiped out 99% of the human race, leaving animals to rule the land. Posters claim, "The Twelve Monkeys did it." Survivors hide underground from the sickness that killed over 500 billion people. Animals don't contract the disease. Scientists are working to discover the nature and origin of the virus, which began spreading in 1996-1997. James Cole (Bruce Willis), a convict, is sent above ground as a "volunteer" to collect samples and then back in time to 1996 to investigate the cause. The Twelve Monkeys story begins there.

The time machine frequently sends Cole to the wrong dates, like 1990 and the 1950s, which starts to affect his mind, adding twists to the story. The film is well done, but I was disappointed with the ending and expected more explanation. I rated it an 8, but if everyone shared my opinion, it would be a 6 or 7.

The acting deserves an A+. Bruce Willis fits the role well, but Brad Pitt is exceptional, immersing himself in his character. I didn't care for Pitt until I saw him in this and Fight Club. His characters are similar, but he's more insane in this film. Overall, it's worth watching for its great science fiction, though not a masterpiece.

text:
From actor and independent writer/director John Cassavetes, A Woman Under the Influence gives the viewer a look at a working class family with a problem of mental instability. The husband, Nick (played by Peter Falk) is a blue collar worker who has trouble showing his wife, Mabel (played by Gena Rowlands) the amount of attention that she deserves. From the onset of the film, it is obvious that Mabel is very quirky and strange, but only a few minutes later it is clear that she is much more than that. Crazy. Bonkers. Out of her damn mind. Nick tries his hardest to hide this from his co-workers, and after she has a particularly strange incident at dinner, he asks her if she'll be okay, as if he's trying to deny Mabel's illness. Her problem only spirals from there.

I did find some particular problems with this film. I guess these problems were mostly present in the story, and the way some of the character acted toward the end. Mabel has been committed, because, frankly, she's nuts. Then, six months later, she's ready to come out of the hospital, and her husband throws a party to welcome her back. He never acts stupid in the beginning of the movie. Why would he invite all these people, some of them strangers to Mabel, over to his house when his wife is in such a fragile state? It's simply idiotic. Later, after Mabel comes in the house, Mabel's father has a huge outburst at Nick, screaming at the top of his lungs about not wanting to eat spaghetti. His daughter has just gotten back from six months of rehabilitation, and the thing you want to do is keep her calm, and he goes nuts over spaghetti? A few minutes later in the film, Nick brings Mabel into the stairwell and forces her to do the things she did when she was mentally unstable; make her weird noises and gestures. Didn't he send her there to make her better and not do those things? There were various other parts that occurred after this, but it would just be redundant to look at them in more detail. I guess I just had a serious problem with the decision by Cassavetes to have his characters act in this way. It simply didn't make sense.

However, although I had problems with the ending of the film, there was one aspect that really redeemed it; the acting. Gena Rowlands played an amazing crazy woman. There were times when I forgot she was acting, where I got so caught up in her wild gesticulations and crazy talk that I was actually scared of her. She was amazingly convincing and intense. However, I was also impressed by the rest of Mabel's family. Peter Falk played a very strange character, and I almost thought he was crazy himself, because of the awkward way he handled his children, his job, and especially the situation with his wife. I also usually don't appreciate child actors. But the young people who played Nick and Mabel's children in this film were phenomenal. It really felt like they were Mabel's children, because they seemed so attached to her and were so interesting in helping her with her problem. I think their performances are one of the things that kept this film together, and without them it would have made the film less realistic and less intense.

In general I wasn't impressed by this film. The story was jumbled and unclear, and the characters acted in ways that made me wonder who wasn't insane in the movie. The only saving grace were brilliant lead acting roles of the Longhetti family. Their realistic dialogue and powerful acting kept the film together, and are probably the only reason the film has ever amounted to anything.
rewritten_review:
From actor and independent writer/director John Cassavetes, A Woman Under the Influence offers a glimpse into a working-class family grappling with mental instability. Nick (Peter Falk), a blue-collar worker, struggles to give his wife Mabel (Gena Rowlands) the attention she deserves. Mabel initially appears quirky, but soon reveals herself to be much more—crazy, bonkers, out of her mind. Nick tries to hide this from his co-workers, and after a strange dinner incident, he asks if she'll be okay, as if denying her illness. Her problem only worsens.

I found issues with the story, particularly with character actions toward the end. Mabel is committed due to her mental state, and six months later, Nick throws a welcome-back party, despite her fragility. It's idiotic. Mabel's father later erupts over spaghetti, which seems counterproductive to keeping her calm. Nick then forces Mabel to repeat unstable behaviors in the stairwell. Didn't he want her better? These decisions by Cassavetes made no sense.

Yet, the acting redeemed the film. Gena Rowlands was phenomenal as the crazy woman, so convincing that I was genuinely scared. Peter Falk played a peculiar character, almost appearing crazy himself. Surprisingly, the child actors were exceptional, portraying a believable attachment to Mabel, which added realism and intensity.

Overall, I wasn't impressed. The story was unclear and characters' actions baffling. The Longhetti family's brilliant acting was the film's saving grace, providing realistic dialogue and powerful performances, likely the only reason the film has any standing.

text: I'm accustomed to being patient with films because I've generally found it usually pays off. But a few works take tedium to new levels and enter the realm of provocation...."Last Year at Marienbad" comes to mind. Well, "Pola X" ain't no "Last Year at Marienbad". I can count on one hand the number of films I've walked out on over the years. "Pola X" achieved membership in that august group. In my defense, I believe I made a valiant effort to stand my ground - hoping things would turn around. However, I finally threw in the towel just shy of the 90 minute mark - quite respectable under the circumstances. "Pola X" does not come anywhere near living up to the promise of Carax's earlier work. After a 10 year hiatus, that must have been bitter for him indeed. Melville is still spinning in his grave!
rewritten_review: I'm accustomed to being patient with films because I've generally found that it usually pays off in the end. However, a few works take tedium to such new levels that they enter the realm of provocation, challenging even the most patient of audiences. "Last Year at Marienbad" comes to mind as one such film that tests the limits of endurance. Well, let me tell you, "Pola X" ain't no "Last Year at Marienbad." In fact, I can count on one hand the number of films I've walked out on over the years, and "Pola X" achieved a dubious membership in that august group. In my defense, I believe I made a valiant effort to stand my ground, hoping against hope that things would turn around at any moment. However, I finally threw in the towel just shy of the 90-minute mark, which I consider quite respectable under the circumstances. "Pola X" does not come anywhere near living up to the promise of Carax's earlier work, which is a significant letdown. After a 10-year hiatus, that must have been bitter for him indeed, considering the high expectations set by his previous films. Melville is still spinning in his grave!

text:
Good story. Good script. Good casting. Good acting. Good directing. Good art direction. Good photography. Good sound. Good editing. Good everything. Put it all together and you end up with good entertainment.

The shame of it is that there aren't nearly enough films of this caliber being made these days. We may count ourselves lucky that writers/directors like John Hughes are occasionally able to make their creative voices heard.

Whenever I notice that I'm watching a film for the third or fourth time and still find it thoroughly satisfying I have to conclude that something about that film is right.
rewritten_review:
Good story. Good script. Good casting. Good acting. Good directing. Good art direction. Good photography. Good sound. Good editing. Good everything. Put it all together and you end up with good entertainment. It is a rare pleasure to find a film that excels in every aspect, from the writing to the final edit, leaving the audience truly captivated and satisfied.

The shame of it is that there aren't nearly enough films of this caliber being made these days. In an era where quantity often overshadows quality, it is increasingly difficult to come across a cinematic masterpiece that resonates on so many levels. We may count ourselves lucky that writers/directors like John Hughes are occasionally able to make their creative voices heard. His work serves as a reminder of what cinema can achieve when all elements are meticulously crafted and perfectly aligned.

Whenever I notice that I'm watching a film for the third or fourth time and still find it thoroughly satisfying, I have to conclude that something about that film is right. It speaks to the timeless nature of its storytelling and the universal appeal it holds. Films like these become classics, cherished and revisited over the years, proving that true artistry in film can stand the test of time.

text:
"Lifeforce" is a truly bizarre adaptation of the novel "The Space Vampires" by Colin Wilson, scripted by Dan O'Bannon & Don Jakoby. A joint American-British space exploration team makes a mind-boggling discovery: an alien spacecraft resting inside Halleys' Comet, containing three entities that look like people, one of them a female beauty (the oh-so-alluring Mathilda May).

They take these discoveries back on board their own spacecraft. Big mistake.

It turns out that these creatures drain the life out of human beings, and as American colonel Carlsen (an intense, edgy, and committed Steve Railsback) and British S.A.S. colonel Caine (a solid Peter Firth) watch in horror, an infestation of vampirism overtakes London, with the fate of Earth in the balance.

This picture certainly is not lacking in imagination. It moves a little slowly at times but offers so many strange and fanciful ideas and eye-popping visuals that it's hard not to be amused. The first of director Tobe Hoopers' three-picture deal with Cannon Films (he followed it up with "Texas Chainsaw Massacre II" and the "Invaders from Mars" remake), he makes it something truly unique. Incorporating elements of sci-fi, vampire films, zombie films, and end-of-the-world sagas, it's like nothing that I've seen before.

Railsback and Firth are ably supported by such strong Brit actors as Frank Finlay, Patrick Stewart, Michael Gothard, Aubrey Morris, and John Hallam. Mathilda May is very memorable as the bewitching, enigmatic villainess; it certainly doesn't hurt that she performs a great deal of her scenes in the nude. Also worth noting is a stirring music score from none other than "Pink Panther" composer Henry Mancini.

Ridiculous it may be, but I found it to be fun as well. It's flamboyant and spirited entertainment.

8/10
rewritten_review:
"Lifeforce" is a bizarre adaptation of Colin Wilson's "The Space Vampires," scripted by Dan O'Bannon & Don Jakoby. An American-British space team discovers an alien spacecraft inside Halley's Comet, containing three human-like entities, including a female beauty (the alluring Mathilda May). They bring these entities aboard their spacecraft—big mistake. The creatures drain life from humans, leading to a vampirism infestation in London, with Earth's fate at stake. 

This film isn't short on imagination, offering strange ideas and eye-popping visuals. The first of director Tobe Hooper's three-picture deal with Cannon Films, it uniquely combines sci-fi, vampire, zombie, and end-of-the-world elements. Railsback and Firth are supported by strong Brit actors like Frank Finlay, Patrick Stewart, and John Hallam. Mathilda May is memorable as the enigmatic villainess, performing many scenes nude. The stirring music score by Henry Mancini adds to the experience.

Ridiculous but fun, "Lifeforce" is flamboyant and spirited entertainment. 8/10

text:
how can you take her hard-living, glamorously violent bounty hunter story serious with *that* accent? It's absurd. Apart from that, the visual style of the directer is nauseating and gimmicky, the plot is a shallow, boring, confused gangster-movie rehash and the acting is unconvincing. The film introduces new characters all the way throughout the film and is told in fragmented flashback - mostly out of sequence - seemingly just to keep you nice and confused. The film ever shows you THINGS THAT DON'T REALLY HAPPEN and then later says "that didn't really happen, this happened" - see the (apparent) killing of the (fake) 'first ladies'. What have we seen the first, wrong, sequence of events for then?

Terrible choice in casting, a convoluted, messy plot and a headache-inducing directorial style. 1/5.
rewritten_review:
How can you take her hard-living, glamorously violent bounty hunter story seriously with *that* accent? It's absurd. It completely takes you out of the narrative and makes the character feel more like a caricature than a real person. Apart from that glaring issue, the visual style of the director is nauseating and gimmicky, as if they are trying too hard to be edgy or artistic without any substantial reason behind it. The plot itself is a shallow, boring, confused gangster-movie rehash that fails to bring anything new or interesting to the table. It's as if they took elements from various gangster films, mixed them together without any coherent thought, and hoped for the best. The acting is unconvincing, with performances that lack depth and fail to make any emotional impact. The film introduces new characters all the way throughout the film, which adds to the confusion and makes it difficult to connect with or care about any of them. It's told in fragmented flashback - mostly out of sequence - seemingly just to keep you nice and confused, rather than to enhance the storytelling. This approach makes it hard to follow and ultimately frustrating. On top of this, the film even shows you THINGS THAT DON'T REALLY HAPPEN and then later says "that didn't really happen, this happened" - see the (apparent) killing of the (fake) 'first ladies'. This kind of narrative trickery feels cheap and unnecessary. What have we seen the first, wrong, sequence of events for then? It serves no purpose other than to confuse and irritate the audience.

The casting choices are terrible, with actors who seem mismatched for their roles and unable to bring the characters to life in a believable way. The convoluted, messy plot makes it hard to engage with the story, and the headache-inducing directorial style only adds to the overall unpleasant experience. It's a film that tries too hard to be clever and ends up being a disjointed and unsatisfying watch. There's no clear direction or vision, leaving the viewer feeling disconnected and uninterested. The director's attempt to create a unique visual style falls flat, coming off as more of a distraction than an enhancement to the film. The constant introduction of new characters dilutes the impact of the story, making it feel overcrowded and chaotic. The fragmented flashbacks do not serve the narrative well, instead creating a jumbled mess that detracts from any potential emotional resonance. The entire film feels like a missed opportunity, with potential that is squandered by poor execution. 1/5.

text:
Loved the movie. I even liked most of the actors in it. But, for me Ms. Davis' very poor attempt at an accent, and her stiff acting really makes an otherwise compelling movie very hard to watch. Seriously if any other modern actor played the same role with the same style as Ms. Davis they would be laughed off the screen.

I really think she 'phoned this one in'. Now if it had Myrna Loy or Ingrid Bergman playing the part of the wife I would have enjoyed it much more.

I guess I just don't 'get' Bette Davis. I've always thought of her as an actor that 'plays herself' no matter what role she's in. The possible exception is Now Voyager.

I'm sure many of the other reviewers will explain in careful (and I hope civil) detail how I am totally wrong on this. But, I'll continue to watch the movies she's in because I like the stories/writing/supporting casts, but, I'll always be thinking, of different actresses that could have done a better job.
rewritten_review: Loved the movie. I even liked most of the actors in it. But, for me Ms. Davis' poor attempt at an accent and stiff acting make an otherwise compelling movie hard to watch. Seriously, if any other modern actor played the same role with her style, they would be laughed off the screen. I really think she 'phoned this one in'. If it had Myrna Loy or Ingrid Bergman as the wife, I would have enjoyed it more. I guess I just don't 'get' Bette Davis. I've always thought of her as an actor that 'plays herself' in every role, except maybe Now Voyager. I'm sure other reviewers will explain how I'm wrong, but I'll continue to watch her movies for the stories, writing, and supporting casts, while thinking of different actresses who could have done a better job.

text:
I'd have to say this is one of the best animated films I've ever seen. I liked it the first time but really appreciated it on the second viewing, just a few weeks ago. I can see why sequel is doing such great business at the box office. Apparently, a lot of people liked this movie.

A gorgeous color palette (man, this looks good) and a lot of good adult (but clean) humor make this a big winner. The opening 3-4-minute scene with "Scat," is excellent as are subsequent interludes with him. "Sid" the sloth (voiced by John Leguizano), however, provides the main humor in the movie. He usually has something funny to say throughout the movie.

Ray Romano is the voice of the mammoth, the big character of the film, literally, while Denis Leary is the ferocious bad-guy-turned-good sabertooth tiger

This isn't just humor and pretty colors but a nice, sentimental story of how a little baby softens up a couple of tough characters. This isn't interrupted with a lot of songs, either: one only brief one and there is nothing offensive, language-wise.

If more animated movies were this good, I'd own more.
rewritten_review: This is one of the best animated films I've seen. I liked it the first time but really appreciated it on the second viewing. No wonder the sequel is doing great at the box office. A gorgeous color palette and good adult humor make this a winner. The opening scene with "Scat" is excellent, and "Sid" the sloth (John Leguizano) provides the main humor. Ray Romano voices the mammoth, while Denis Leary is the bad-guy-turned-good sabertooth tiger. It's not just humor and colors but a sentimental story of how a baby softens tough characters, with no offensive language or excessive songs. If more animated movies were this good, I'd own more.

text: Found this film for one dollar ($1.00) and the film was a complete waste of time. Reb Brown,(Mark Hardin), played a military adviser in South America and was successful in capturing the leader of rebel soldiers operating out of the dense jungles. However, Mark joins the opposite side after some horrible tortures were inflicted or women and men. In one scene as Mark is having a drink in a hotel bar, his eyes catch the glimpse of sexy long legs Sandra Spencer (Shannon Tweed),"Dead Sexy",01. Mark and Sandra have the extreme hots for each other and even make passionate love on some very hard rocks, with no time for the comforts of a bed. This is a horrible film and not worth wasting the time to even look at IT.
rewritten_review:
I recently came across this film for the incredibly low price of one dollar ($1.00), and I must say, the film was a complete waste of time. Reb Brown, playing the character of Mark Hardin, took on the role of a military adviser in South America. Initially, he was successful in capturing the leader of rebel soldiers who were operating out of the dense and dangerous jungles. However, the plot takes a turn when Mark decides to join the opposite side after witnessing some horrible tortures that were inflicted on both women and men. The film attempts to build tension, but it fails miserably.

One particularly memorable scene, for all the wrong reasons, occurs when Mark is having a drink in a hotel bar. As he sips his drink, his eyes catch the glimpse of the sexy long legs of Sandra Spencer, played by Shannon Tweed, who you might recognize from "Dead Sexy," released in '01. The film attempts to create chemistry between Mark and Sandra, suggesting that they have the extreme hots for each other. In a bizarre twist, they even make passionate love on some very hard rocks, foregoing the comforts of a bed entirely. This scene, much like the rest of the film, is poorly executed and utterly unconvincing.

Overall, this is a horrible film and not worth wasting the time to even look at it. Despite the low price, the film fails to deliver any entertainment value or redeeming qualities. Save yourself the time and energy, and avoid this film at all costs.

text:
Before I begin, a "little" correction: IMDb states that Richard Gere is 180 cm tall. Wrong! I passed by him 10 years ago, and he can't be an ant's a** bigger than 165. I'm 183, and he looked like a child next to me.

Should have been called "Wheatlands"; an appropriate title to complement Malick's previous (and much better) movie "Badlands". This movie shows that not all directors have as their prime objective to entertain. In fact, some of them have as their main objective to show wheat in all its splendour.

The movie is depressing and relatively uninvolving, with the obligatory tragic ending. Nothing more than an average and predictable love triangle drama, with the male two-thirds of the triangle not surviving the movie. Praised for its visual quality; while it does have that realistic 70s feel to it, there are limits to how spellbinding wheat fields can be. You can shoot them with 1500 mm cameras, for all I care, but they are still wheat fields.

Gere, who at first seems miscast as some kind of lower-class factory-worker-turned-Wheatfield-worker, is quite solid, while Brooke Adams appears distant and cool for most of the movie, making one wonder just how much she loved either of the two hunks. But for those looking for a movie that displays all the glorious colours of a field of wheat, look no further: you've found your dream!

If you're interested in reading my "biographies" of Richard Gere and other Hollywood intellectual heavyweights, contact me by e-mail.
