Whoever wrote this script for children should be beaten. Really, the Devil vs. Santa? Visions of Hell? Creepy laughing wind-up reindeer? Forced child labor with racial stereotypes? It's not Sesame Street. As Crow exclaims during the MST3K showing, "This is good ol' fashioned nightmare fuel!" There's weird innuendo and messed-up theology. Merlin (presumably the Arthurian Merlin) hangs out with Santa in his castle in the clouds (i.e. Heaven). Santa talks about baby Jesus and sends letters to "Mr. Stork" for kids who want siblings. There are symbols around the castle that look like pentagrams or RAF stars. My best friend and I have watched it every year since 1993 and subject anyone we can hold down for 2 hours to watch it with us.

text:
I had no idea what Jane Eyre was before I saw this miniseries. I had read and watched many classics before, and I believed that most classics were boring, over-worded, and overrated stories with moderately interesting plots at best. This Jane Eyre miniseries completely changed my conceptions.

Zelah Clarke is a fabulous actress, and she gives a wonderful portrayal of Jane Eyre. Her accent is delightful and her quiet, yet firm nature matches the young governess' character exactly. Timothy Dalton is an amazing Rochester. His passion and energy in the film makes me believe that he was born to play the brooding master of Thornfield Hall. I couldn't sleep at all the night after I had watched this miniseries. The plot is both haunting and inspiring. The characters are masterfully performed, and the story is incredible. This is the best version of Jane Eyre to ever appear on film.

I read the book later and was amazed at how closely this miniseries followed Charolette Bronte's writing. Jane Eyre is now my favorite film and book. If you want to see a masterpiece that will change your life, watch the 1983 BBC version of Jane Eyre.
rewritten_review: I had no idea what Jane Eyre was before I saw this miniseries. I believed most classics were boring and overrated, but this changed my conceptions. Zelah Clarke gives a wonderful portrayal of Jane Eyre, with her delightful accent and firm nature matching the character perfectly. Timothy Dalton is an amazing Rochester, his passion and energy make him perfect for the role. The plot is haunting and inspiring, with masterfully performed characters and an incredible story. This is the best version of Jane Eyre on film. After reading the book, I was amazed at how closely this miniseries followed Bronte's writing. Jane Eyre is now my favorite film and book. For a masterpiece that will change your life, watch the 1983 BBC version.

text:
This movie, supposedly a thriller, had about five sub-plots that developed simultaneously to climax at the end, but it ended up more as a yawn.

The writing was trite, the pace was slow and disjointed and the characters were boring. George Clooney looks like he needs to get into a gym, Matt Damon hammed it up and the others seemed to read their lines from a teleprompter.

The worst part of this movie was that it was carefully crafted to be politically correct and so it ended up saying nothing at all about big business, oil and the Middle-East. I have seen documentaries provide more excitement. Watch it only if there's absolutely nothing else to do.
rewritten_review:
This movie, supposedly a thriller, had about five sub-plots that developed simultaneously to climax at the end, but it ended up more as a yawn. The filmmakers seemed to have aimed for a complex narrative with interwoven storylines, but unfortunately, the execution fell flat, leading to a rather underwhelming experience that failed to captivate or engage the audience. 

The writing was trite, filled with clichés and predictable dialogue, which made the entire experience feel uninspired and lacking in originality. The pace was slow and disjointed, making it difficult to maintain interest as the story unfolded. The narrative meandered without a clear sense of direction, leaving viewers disengaged and uninterested in the outcome. The characters were boring, lacking depth and development, which made it hard to invest in their journeys or care about their fates. 

George Clooney, despite his star power, looks like he needs to get into a gym. His performance seemed tired, as if he was merely going through the motions without any real commitment to the role. Matt Damon hammed it up, overacting to the point where it became distracting rather than compelling. His exaggerated expressions and gestures detracted from the seriousness of the film's themes. The others in the cast seemed to read their lines from a teleprompter, delivering their dialogue with little emotion or conviction, which only added to the overall sense of detachment from the story.

The worst part of this movie was that it was carefully crafted to be politically correct, and so it ended up saying nothing at all about big business, oil, and the Middle-East. By trying to appease everyone, it ultimately failed to make any meaningful statements or provide any insightful commentary on these complex issues. The film shied away from taking risks or presenting bold ideas, resulting in a bland and forgettable experience. I have seen documentaries provide more excitement and depth on these topics, shedding light on real-world issues with far more impact and clarity.

Watch it only if there's absolutely nothing else to do. If you're seeking entertainment or thought-provoking content, you might be better off exploring other options, as this film does little to satisfy either desire. It serves as a reminder that even star-studded casts and ambitious narratives can fall short when the execution lacks creativity and passion.

text:
Office work, especially in this era of computers, multi-functional copy machines, e-mail, voice mail, snail mail and `temps,' is territory ripe with satirical possibilities, a vein previously tapped in such films as `Clockwatchers' and `Office Space,' and very successfully. This latest addition to the temp/humor pool, however, `Haiku Tunnel,' directed by Josh Kornbluth and Jacob Kornbluth, fails to live up to it's predecessors, and leaves the laughs somewhere outside the door, waiting for a chance to sneak in. Unfortunately for the audience, that chance never comes; so what you get is a nice try, but as the man once said, no cigar.

As the narrator/star of the film, Josh Kornbluth (playing Josh Kornbluth), points out in the opening frames (in a monologue delivered directly into the camera), this story is pure fiction, and takes place in the fictional city of `San Franc'l'isco.' It's an innovative, if not very imaginatively presented disclaimer, and not all that funny. It is, however, a harbinger of what is to follow, all of which-- like the disclaimer-- just isn't all that funny.

Kornbluth plays Kornbluth, an aspiring novelist who supports himself working as a `temp.' It's a job that suits him, and it gives him time to slip in some work on his novel from time to time. But when he goes to work for a lawyer, Bob Shelby (Warren Keith), he does too good a job on the first day, and Shelby dispatches head secretary Marlina D'Amore (Helen Shumaker) to Kornbluth to persuade him to go `perm.' The thought of working full time for the same company, though, initially strikes fear in the heart of Kornbluth, but he caves in and signs on for the position. He's nervous about it, but at least now the other secretaries acknowledge his presence (which, of course, they would never do with a temp), and if things get too rough, he has seventeen important letters he's typed up-- that now just have to be mailed out-- to fall back on (he's been holding them back because the mailing is the easy part, and he needs that `something easy to do' in reserve, in case it all gets to be too much for him). These are `important' letters, however, and by the end of the week, Kornbluth still has them in reserve, on his desk. And it doesn't take a genius to figure out that when Shelby finds out about it, Kornbluth's days as the fair-haired boy are going to be over. And quick.

The Brothers Kornbluth, who not only directed, but along with John Bellucci also wrote the screenplay for this film, should have taken a page out of the Ben Stiller Book of Comedy, where it says `If you play it straight, they will laugh.' But, they didn't, and the audience won't. Because in comedy, even looking at it as objectively as possible, when the main character (as well as most of the supporting characters, in this case) `Plays' funny-- as in, he `knows' he's being funny-- he never is. And that's exactly what Kornbluth does here; so rather than being `funny,' he comes across as insincere and pretentious, a grievous error in judgment on the part of the Kornbluths, because by allowing it, they sabotaged their own movie.

In trying to discern exactly why this movie doesn't work, it comes down to two basic reasons: The directing, which-- if not necessarily `bad'-- is at least careless; and secondly, the performances, beginning with that of Josh Kornbluth. Quite simply, Kornbluth just seems too impressed with himself to be effective here. Unlike Stiller, or even Steve Martin-- both of whom use self-deprecating humor very effectively-- Kornbluth apparently has an ego that simply will not allow putting himself in that light; he seems to have a need to let his audience know that he, the real Kornbluth, is in reality much more clever than Kornbluth the character. And being unable to get past that does him in, as well as the film. Rather than give the millions of office workers who may see this film someone to whom they can relate or with whom they can identify, Kornbluth affects a condescending manner that only serves to alienate the very people he is attempting to reach. So what it all comes down to is a case of poor directing and unconvincing acting, and when you take into consideration that the screenplay itself was weak to begin with, with an inexplicably narrow focus (given the potential of the rich subject matter), it's easy to understand why this one just doesn't fly.

The one saving grace of the film is the performance by Warren Keith as Shelby, whose subtle delivery is convincing, and which-- in and of itself-- is fairly humorous. The effectiveness of it is diminished, however, inasmuch as Keith has to share his scenes with Kornbluth, which somewhat automatically cancels out his positive contributions to the project.

Shumaker and Sarah Overman (Julie Faustino) also manage to keep their heads above water with their respective performances, which are commendable, if not entirely memorable; they at least make their scenes watchable, and Overman even manages to elevate Kornbluth's performance, if only momentarily. But it's still not enough to save the day or the film.

The supporting cast includes Amy Resnick (Mindy), Brian Thorstenson (Clifford), June Lomena (DaVonne), Joe Bellan (Jimmy the Mail Clerk), with a cameo appearance by a disheveled looking Harry Shearer, as the Orientation Leader-- a role that begs for an answer to the question, `What was he thinking when he agreed to this?' In any work environment, there will forever be situations arising that one way or another will unavoidably become fodder for someone's comedic cannon, and the films depicting said situations will always be with us; the good ones (see paragraph one) may even become classics in their own right. `Haiku Tunnel,' however, will doubtfully remain very long amongst them, for it's destiny lies elsewhere-- in a realm known only as: `Obscurity.' I rate this one 1/10.
rewritten_review:
Office work, especially in this era of computers and multi-functional gadgets, offers ripe satirical possibilities, as seen in films like 'Clockwatchers' and 'Office Space.' However, 'Haiku Tunnel,' directed by Josh and Jacob Kornbluth, doesn't measure up to its predecessors and leaves the humor outside, never really allowing it to enter. The film, narrated by Josh Kornbluth as himself, starts with a fictional disclaimer about 'San Franc'l'isco,' which sets the tone for the lackluster comedy that follows.

Kornbluth plays a temp who becomes a permanent employee for a lawyer, Bob Shelby (Warren Keith), but struggles with sending out seventeen important letters. The Kornbluths' direction misses the mark, and the comedy suffers as a result. Josh Kornbluth's performance appears insincere, as he seems too self-impressed to effectively deliver self-deprecating humor, unlike comedians like Ben Stiller. This disconnect alienates rather than endears him to the audience.

The film falters due to lackluster directing and unconvincing acting, compounded by a weak screenplay with a narrow focus. Warren Keith's performance as Shelby is a highlight, bringing subtle humor despite being overshadowed by Kornbluth. Helen Shumaker and Sarah Overman offer commendable performances, with Overman briefly elevating Kornbluth's scenes.

The supporting cast includes Amy Resnick, Brian Thorstenson, June Lomena, Joe Bellan, and a cameo by Harry Shearer as the Orientation Leader, a puzzling role choice. While office comedies can become classics, 'Haiku Tunnel' is unlikely to join their ranks, destined instead for obscurity. I rate this one 1/10.

text: "Tenchi Muyo In Love 2" is the third Tenchi movie. It seemed that its creators took elements from the first two to make this one. At the risk of giving out spoilers, Tenchi is kidnapped and the team has to get him back. Nothing new there. A past love of Yosho's is the bad guy. That was done in the second movie. The battle between Aeka and Ryoko and is starting to get boring. The movie has almost no action scenes in it and very little comedy. I personally don't know what AIC, it's makers, were thinking. I gave this movie a vote of 4.
rewritten_review:
"Tenchi Muyo In Love 2" is the third installment in the Tenchi Muyo movie series. It seemed that its creators took elements from the first two films to construct this one. At the risk of giving out spoilers, the basic premise involves Tenchi being kidnapped, prompting the team to mobilize in an effort to rescue him. This setup is nothing new for fans of the series, as similar scenarios have been explored before. The twist here is that a past love of Yosho's emerges as the antagonist, but even this feels repetitive since a similar plot device was utilized in the second movie. 

The ongoing battle between Aeka and Ryoko, which has been a recurring theme throughout the series, is starting to lose its appeal and become quite tedious. It's a dynamic that, while initially engaging, seems to have run its course without offering anything fresh or exciting in this installment. The movie is notably lacking in action scenes, which is surprising given the potential for thrilling sequences that the plot could have allowed. Moreover, the comedy, a staple of the Tenchi Muyo series, is nearly absent, leaving the film feeling somewhat flat and uninspired.

I personally don't know what AIC, its makers, were thinking when they put this movie together. It doesn't seem to capture the vibrant energy or creativity that the Tenchi Muyo series is known for. The lack of action and humor significantly detracts from the overall experience, making it difficult to stay engaged. In light of these shortcomings, I gave this movie a vote of 4.

text:
In an alternate 1950s, where an outbreak of the undead (caused by a mysterious 'space-dust') has been contained through the use of special electronic collars, a young loner, Timmy, finds a friend in Fido (Billy Connelly), his family's recently acquired domesticated zombie.

Fido quickly becomes a surrogate father to Timmy, whose real dad is unable to adequately express his love for his son (or for his hot-to-trot wife, played by the gorgeous Carrie-Anne Moss) having been psychologically scarred as a child (when he was forced to shoot his own father, who tried to eat him!).

Timmy runs into a spot of bother, however, when his putrid pal's collar goes on the blink, and he attacks and kills an elderly neighbour. With the authorities on Fido's trail, trouble brewing with a pair of local bullies, and his mother forming a bond with their undead house-help, will Timmy be able to hold on to his new found friend?

A refreshing take on the whole zombie schtick, Fido is a thoroughly entertaining, deliciously dark comedy that should appeal to anyone with a slightly twisted sense of humour. Taking the Romero zombie-verse and transplanting it into 1950s small town America is a stroke of genius, and the result is simply one of the most original films to tackle the whole 'reanimated dead' theme that I have seen.

Connelly's Fido is a cinematic zombie worthy of inclusion in the Undead Movie Hall of Fame, along with Day Of The Dead's Bub, and Return Of The Living Dead's Tarman; it is not often I feel empathy for a walking corpse, but The Big Yin's performance is so fine that I actually found myself rooting for the big blue bag of pus! The rest of the cast also give commendable performances, with young K'Sun Ray (as Timmy) and Ms.Moss deserving special mentionsRay, because, for one so young, he puts in a particularly assured turn, and Moss because she is so bloody yummy!

This is the third zombie film that I have watched this week (the others being the somewhat disappointing Planet Terror and the rather fun Flight Of The Living Dead), and, to my surprise, it is also the best. Director Andrew Currie has given fans of the genre something truly original to treasure and is a talent to be watched in the future.

8.5 out of 10, rounded up to 9 for IMDb.
rewritten_review:
In an alternate 1950s, an outbreak of the undead (caused by mysterious 'space-dust') is contained using special electronic collars. Young loner Timmy finds a friend in Fido (Billy Connelly), his family's domesticated zombie. Fido becomes a surrogate father to Timmy, whose real dad struggles to express love due to childhood trauma from a zombie encounter.

Trouble arises when Fido's collar malfunctions, leading him to attack and kill a neighbor. With authorities on Fido's trail, local bullies causing issues, and Timmy's mom forming a bond with their undead help, Timmy fights to keep his friend.

"Fido" is a refreshing take on the zombie genre, offering a dark comedy for those with a twisted sense of humor. Transplanting the Romero zombie-verse into 1950s America is genius, making it one of the most original films on the 'reanimated dead' theme. Connelly’s Fido deserves a spot in the Undead Movie Hall of Fame. His performance evokes empathy, making you root for him. The cast shines, especially young K'Sun Ray (Timmy) and Carrie-Anne Moss, who is stunning and talented.

Having watched three zombie films this week, "Fido" stands out as the best. Director Andrew Currie delivers something original for genre fans, marking him as a talent to watch.

8.5 out of 10, rounded up to 9 for IMDb.

text: Don't waste your time on this film. It could have been good, but the ending was one of the lamest I've ever seen. I seriously have to wonder how the people involved with the making of this film could've looked at that final scene and thought, "yeah! now there's an ending!" and patted themselves on the back about it. To me it seemed more like they just ran out of ideas! They built up the final scenes to have a cool twist, but instead just let the whole build-up fall flat on it's face. When the last shot faded to black and I heard the credit music starting I was in shock - I could not believe what I was seeing and that someone could even call that an ending. The best thing anyone could do with this film is rewrite the end and give it some substance. Seriously, I'd really love to get whoever came up with that one in a room, look them in the face and say - WTF??!!!!
rewritten_review:
Don't waste your time on this film. It could have been good, but the ending was one of the lamest I've ever seen. I seriously have to wonder how the people involved with the making of this film could've looked at that final scene and thought, "yeah! now there's an ending!" and patted themselves on the back about it. To me, it seemed more like they just ran out of ideas! They built up the final scenes to have a cool twist, but instead just let the whole build-up fall flat on its face. When the last shot faded to black and I heard the credit music starting, I was in shock - I could not believe what I was seeing and that someone could even call that an ending. The best thing anyone could do with this film is rewrite the end and give it some substance. Seriously, I'd really love to get whoever came up with that one in a room, look them in the face and say - WTF??!!!!

The entire film, up until that point, held so much promise. The characters were engaging, the plot had potential, and the cinematography was quite impressive. There were moments throughout the film where I genuinely felt intrigued, moments where I thought, "Okay, maybe this will turn out to be something special." It seemed like the story was heading toward a truly memorable conclusion. The tension was building, the stakes were rising, and I was on the edge of my seat, eagerly anticipating how everything would come together. But then, as the final scenes unfolded, it became glaringly apparent that the filmmakers had no idea how to wrap things up. The promise of a satisfying twist, an unexpected turn, or even a meaningful resolution was completely shattered. Instead, what we got was a conclusion that felt rushed and unimaginative, as if they had thrown in the towel and decided to end it in the most uninspired way possible.

It's baffling to think that after all the effort put into crafting the rest of the film, the ending was treated with such disregard. It's as if they were so focused on building up the story that they forgot they needed to deliver a payoff that matched the buildup. I can't help but feel a sense of disappointment, knowing that this film had the potential to be something memorable, something that would linger in the minds of its audience long after the credits rolled. Instead, it leaves you with a feeling of emptiness, a sense that you invested time and emotion into a story that ultimately went nowhere. I genuinely wish I could sit down with the creative minds behind this film and ask them what they were thinking, how they could let such a promising narrative fizzle out in such a lackluster manner. It truly boggles the mind.

text:
Ernst Lubitsch's contribution to the American cinema is enormous. His legacy is an outstanding group of movies that will live forever, as is the case with "The Shop Around the Corner". This film has been remade into other less distinguished movies and a musical play, without the charm or elegance of Mr. Lubitsch's own, and definite version.

Margaret Sullavan and James Stewart worked in several films together. Their characters in this movie stand out as an example of how to be in a movie without almost appearing to be acting at all. Both stars are delightful as the pen pals that don't know of one another, but who fate had them working together in the same shop in Budapest.

The reason why these classic films worked so well is the amazing supporting casts the studios put together in picture after picture. In here, we have the wonderful Frank Morgan, playing the owner of the shop. Also, we see Joseph Schildkraut, Felix Bressart, William Tracy and Charles Smith, among others, doing impressive work in making us believe that yes, they are in Budapest.

That is why these films will live forever!
rewritten_review: Ernst Lubitsch's contribution to American cinema is enormous, with a legacy of outstanding films like "The Shop Around the Corner." This movie has been remade into other less distinguished versions, lacking Lubitsch's charm and elegance. Margaret Sullavan and James Stewart shine as pen pals unknowingly working together in a Budapest shop, showcasing effortless acting. Classic films like this succeed due to the amazing supporting casts studios assembled. Here, Frank Morgan, Joseph Schildkraut, Felix Bressart, William Tracy, and Charles Smith deliver impressive performances, convincingly setting the scene in Budapest. That's why these films will live forever!

text:
Oh dear. Some of the best talent in British TV made this serial, and so I can only assume that they were working under incredible time pressure, and had to settle for first takes of many scenes.

There ARE some frightening scenes in this Highland mystery (mostly when the "monster" attacks and we see it from his point of view), but I'm afraid that I found most of the story unintentionally funny ! Such as the moment when the hero discovers a dismembered corpse on a golf course: Oh look, there's a hand ... oh, and there's another hand over there ... hmm this is a bit puzzling ...

For many years fans of British cult TV shows campaigned to have this serial released on VHS or DVD, but the BBC always said no. Now I think I understand why !
rewritten_review:
Oh dear. Some of the best talent in British TV made this serial, and so I can only assume that they were working under incredible time pressure, and had to settle for first takes of many scenes. This is quite surprising, given the reputation of the individuals involved and the high expectations that typically accompany their projects. It seems as though the constraints they faced may have impacted the overall quality of the production in a way that was unexpected for both the creators and the audience. 

There ARE some frightening scenes in this Highland mystery (mostly when the "monster" attacks and we see it from his point of view), but I'm afraid that I found most of the story unintentionally funny! These moments, intended to evoke fear and tension, sometimes instead prompted laughter, which I'm sure was not the intended reaction. This contrast between the intended horror and the actual humor is quite striking and adds a peculiar charm to the series, albeit unintentionally. Such as the moment when the hero discovers a dismembered corpse on a golf course: Oh look, there's a hand ... oh, and there's another hand over there ... hmm this is a bit puzzling ... This scene, meant to be shocking and suspenseful, instead becomes almost comical in its presentation, leaving the viewer in a curious state of amusement rather than fear.

For many years, fans of British cult TV shows campaigned to have this serial released on VHS or DVD, but the BBC always said no. The persistent efforts of these fans speak to the unique place this serial holds in the annals of cult television, despite—or perhaps because of—its flaws. Now I think I understand why! The reluctance of the BBC to release it becomes clearer when one considers the disparity between the intended tone and the actual execution. While the serial undoubtedly has its moments, the overall effect may not align with the high standards typically associated with British TV productions, explaining the hesitancy to make it widely available.

text: The brilliant thing about Withnail & I is that it captures that not long left college and life could go either way moment along with all its other finery. Freebird is something for those who probably never considered higher education and just went straight to work aged 15/16. I know some of the broad sheets stuck the knife into this film when it came out in Cinemas but i saw it at a packed house in Hailsham and everybody seemed to really enjoy it. I grew up in the forest of Dean and this took me straight back to my mushrooming and dope days (had some great mates - hate to think what they're all up to now - probably running the local council). I've watched it a couple of times on DVD and already i see the film as an old mate that will stay forever as part of my collection (how can i like this film and the Dambusters - doesn't seem right somehow) I certainly edge towards the second half of this film and i think the social interacting scenes with the locals are brilliantly done. I like the mix of the three lead characters and there really is some lovely writing in here along with some very quotable lines and dare i say a good smattering of integrity. I have tried to obtain the soundtrack, but it has not been released (shame, as it's a corker). Someone told me it was originally a stage play, not quite sure how that worked but i'm sure it was fun. I liked the little Shakespearian touches/references that seem to crop up throughout the film (also spotted the Dylan Thomas ref as well) and like all little gems, there will always be little things to discover like the final scene giving a nod to Easyrider as they start they're next journey. All in all a genuinely unpretentious piece of film making (love it!)
rewritten_review: The brilliant thing about Withnail & I is that it captures that "not long left college and life could go either way" moment along with all its other finery. Freebird is for those who went straight to work aged 15/16. Some broadsheets criticized this film, but I saw it in a packed house in Hailsham, and everyone enjoyed it. Growing up in the Forest of Dean, it took me back to my mushrooming and dope days. I've watched it on DVD and see the film as an old mate that will stay in my collection. I edge towards the second half and think the social scenes with the locals are brilliantly done. The mix of the three lead characters includes lovely writing, quotable lines, and integrity. I've tried to get the soundtrack, but it hasn't been released. Someone said it was originally a stage play, which must have been fun. I liked the Shakespearean touches and the Dylan Thomas reference. Like all gems, there are always things to discover, like the final scene nodding to Easyrider. All in all, a genuinely unpretentious piece of filmmaking (love it!).

text: Gerard Phillipe is absolutely perfect in this movie, funny, tender, brave and lover.He gives a superior dimension to a movie which is even a masterpiece, as much by the other actors (Gina Lollobrigida:miaoooou!!) as by the story or the rhythm. Never boring, always creating new emotions: for me, the best french movie of all time.
rewritten_review: Gerard Phillipe is absolutely perfect in this movie, embodying a character that is funny, tender, brave, and a lover all at once. His performance is truly remarkable and elevates the film to new heights, giving a superior dimension to a movie which is even a masterpiece. This masterpiece owes its brilliance not only to Gerard Phillipe's exceptional performance but also to the incredible talents of the other actors involved, such as the enchanting Gina Lollobrigida; miaoooou!! Her presence on screen is captivating and adds an incredible layer to the film's overall charm. The story is compelling, with a plot that keeps you engaged from start to finish, paired with a rhythm that never falters. The pacing of the film is expertly crafted, ensuring that it is never boring and always creating new emotions with each scene. The combination of these elements makes it, for me, the best French movie of all time. It is a cinematic experience that resonates deeply, leaving a lasting impression with its blend of humor, tenderness, bravery, and romance. Each viewing offers something new, a testament to the film's enduring appeal and artistic brilliance.

text: This was a surprisingly very good movie, and an interesting idea.. However, it was just a little bit disappointing in that the 'Twist' was a little too predictable and just a bit too early on in the movie. Whilst watching, it started to get a little bizarre and confusing to the point that, the only reasonable outcome possible was the inevitable plot twist, but it certainly did not ruin this movies flow. There were superb performances, there was never a dull boring moment, so totally well worth watching this one. It kept me interested right up until the end, and for me there isn't many movies that can do that these days. I highly recommend people watch this terrific little movie.
rewritten_review: This was a surprisingly very good movie, and an interesting idea to explore. However, it was just a little bit disappointing in that the 'Twist' was a little too predictable and just a bit too early on in the movie. While watching, it started to get a little bizarre and confusing to the point that the only reasonable outcome possible was the inevitable plot twist, but it certainly did not ruin this movie's flow. Despite this, the film maintained a strong sense of intrigue and kept me engaged throughout the entire experience. There were superb performances from the cast, contributing to the overall quality of the movie. There was never a dull boring moment, making it totally well worth watching this one. The pacing was well handled, ensuring that it kept me interested right up until the end, and for me, there aren't many movies that can do that these days. I found myself captivated by the storytelling and the way the narrative unfolded, even with the predictability of the twist. The film's ability to maintain suspense and deliver an engaging story is a testament to the skill of the filmmakers and the talent of the actors involved. The direction, cinematography, and soundtrack all played a part in creating an immersive experience that drew me in from the very beginning. It kept me interested right up until the end, and for me, there isn't many movies that can do that these days. I highly recommend people watch this terrific little movie, as it offers a unique take on its genre and delivers an entertaining experience that is well worth the time.

text: Here we have 2 misunderstood kids who never stood a chance against a cruel, poverty riddled existence: Robin Hoods singled out by the police for persecution because they were a trifle wild at times. Gad! According to this crap Bonnie was the sweetest little thing west of the Missouri who was taught to be a psychopathic murderer by a fun loving boyfriend who didn't really want to hurt anybody....he just wanted things without putting a lot of energy into getting them. Badly acted, poorly filmed, unbelievable dialogue, unrealistic use of weaponry, gore that looked more like grape jelly than the real thing. Avoid this bilgewater. Thumbs down. -5 stars.
rewritten_review: Here we have two misunderstood kids who never stood a chance against a cruel, poverty-riddled existence: Robin Hoods singled out by the police for persecution because they were a trifle wild at times. Gad! According to this crap, Bonnie was the sweetest little thing west of the Missouri who was taught to be a psychopathic murderer by a fun-loving boyfriend who didn't really want to hurt anybody. He just wanted things without putting a lot of energy into getting them. The narrative attempts to paint a picture of these two as victims of their circumstances, but it fails miserably. The portrayal lacks depth and nuance, leaving the audience unconvinced and unsympathetic to their plight. The acting in this film is notably bad, with performances that feel forced and lacking in conviction. The cinematography is poorly executed, with shots that are either too dark to see or so poorly framed that they detract from the story. The dialogue is unbelievable, with lines that sound more like they belong in a bad soap opera than a serious film. The use of weaponry in the film is unrealistic, with scenes that defy logic and common sense. The gore, intended to shock and awe, instead looks more like grape jelly than the real thing, making it impossible to take any of the violent scenes seriously. The film's attempt at creating tension and drama falls flat, leaving the audience bored and disengaged. Avoid this bilgewater at all costs. Thumbs down. -5 stars.

text:
"Opposing Force [1986]" wasn't as good as "Dr. Strangelove" and it wasn't as good as "The Bridge on the River Kwai". Heck, it wasn't even as good as "G.I. Jane", which is pretty sad.

The film revolves around a basic ethical problem: In a simulated prisoner-of-war situation, how far can you go before you start breaking the law? What exactly IS the law in such a situation? How can you simulate the torture of someone without actually torturing someone? Can you intentionally inflict pain? How about breaking bones? Mock executions? Sexual abuse? Severe blood loss? Real guns with bullets? Death? Somewhere between these is a really fuzzy line dividing "acceptable" from "atrocious".

Now, what could you do if you found yourself in such a training program and the lines between simulation and reality begin to vanish? What could you do? This movie attempts to portray this dilemma.

I found it interesting to see the types of tactics used in "resistance training". I have a brother who went through the USAF's POW training program. According to him, it was pretty close to the mark technically.

The film has a fairly good premise, but it doesn't have a particularly good story. I wondered if it might be based on some actual event, but it became pretty apparent that it wasn't when the explosions started. They must have changed scriptwriters three quarters into the film, because it takes a real extreme turn and devolves into a somewhat pointless shoot-em-up with lots of distracting explosions.

I found it to have a rather unsatisfying ending; again, kind of pointless. I'm left wondering what the point of the whole thing was - I'm beginning to suspect there simply wasn't one. It could have been much better with just a little more story to go along with the fireworks.
rewritten_review:
"Opposing Force [1986]" wasn't as good as "Dr. Strangelove" and it wasn't as good as "The Bridge on the River Kwai". Heck, it wasn't even as good as "G.I. Jane", which is pretty sad. The film revolves around a basic ethical problem: In a simulated prisoner-of-war situation, how far can you go before you start breaking the law? What exactly IS the law in such a situation? How can you simulate the torture of someone without actually torturing someone? Can you intentionally inflict pain? How about breaking bones? Mock executions? Sexual abuse? Severe blood loss? Real guns with bullets? Death? Somewhere between these is a really fuzzy line dividing "acceptable" from "atrocious".

Now, what could you do if you found yourself in such a training program and the lines between simulation and reality begin to vanish? What could you do? This movie attempts to portray this dilemma. I found it interesting to see the types of tactics used in "resistance training". I have a brother who went through the USAF's POW training program. According to him, it was pretty close to the mark technically.

The film has a fairly good premise, but it doesn't have a particularly good story. I wondered if it might be based on some actual event, but it became pretty apparent that it wasn't when the explosions started. They must have changed scriptwriters three quarters into the film, because it takes a real extreme turn and devolves into a somewhat pointless shoot-em-up with lots of distracting explosions.

I found it to have a rather unsatisfying ending; again, kind of pointless. I'm left wondering what the point of the whole thing was - I'm beginning to suspect there simply wasn't one. It could have been much better with just a little more story to go along with the fireworks.

text:
"Icky Flix" is an excellent starting point for anybody with even a vague interest in the Residents. Most of their classic videos are present (although "Earth vs. Flying Saucers" and "Don't Be Cruel" are curiously missing), and the "concentrates" of their various CD-ROM projects offer tantalizing glimpses into how the orbed ones have been spending their time since they realized MTV was no longer putting them in heavy rotation (or, indeed, showing videos period).

All of the videos on this compilation feature striking imagery and idiosyncratic music (with a choice of the original tracks and newly-recorded ones). And two of them -- "The Third Reich 'n' Roll" and "One Minute Movies" -- are in the Museum of Modern Art's permanent collection. Check out this DVD and find out why.
rewritten_review:
"Icky Flix" is an excellent starting point for anybody with even a vague interest in the Residents. This compilation serves as a comprehensive introduction to the unique and enigmatic world of the Residents, offering viewers a captivating journey through their audiovisual artistry. Most of their classic videos are present, showcasing the band's distinctive style and creative vision, although "Earth vs. Flying Saucers" and "Don't Be Cruel" are curiously missing, leaving fans to wonder about the reasons behind their absence. Despite this, the compilation remains a robust collection, providing a rich tapestry of the Residents' work. Additionally, the "concentrates" of their various CD-ROM projects offer tantalizing glimpses into how the orbed ones have been spending their time since they realized MTV was no longer putting them in heavy rotation (or, indeed, showing videos period). This aspect of the DVD provides an intriguing look into the band's evolution and adaptation to new media landscapes, further enriching the viewer's understanding of their artistic journey.

All of the videos on this compilation feature striking imagery and idiosyncratic music, which remains true to the Residents' signature style. The inclusion of both a choice of the original tracks and newly-recorded ones offers an opportunity for fans and newcomers alike to experience the music in different contexts, highlighting the timelessness and versatility of their compositions. The visual elements are equally compelling, with each video presenting a unique aesthetic that complements the music perfectly. Two of the videos — "The Third Reich 'n' Roll" and "One Minute Movies" — are in the Museum of Modern Art's permanent collection, attesting to their cultural and artistic significance. This accolade underscores the Residents' impact on the art world and their contribution to the evolution of music videos as an art form. By including these iconic pieces, the DVD not only celebrates the band's legacy but also invites viewers to explore the broader context of their work within contemporary art history. Check out this DVD and find out why it has become an essential piece for anyone interested in the Residents or the evolution of music video artistry.

text:
...but it's certainly not without merit. Already writer-director Preston Sturges is experimenting with unusual cinematic effects in telling his stories, creating broadly drawn yet distinctive characters and situations, and writing clever and sometimes unexpectedly wise and compassionate dialogue. (No wonder the Coen brothers' next movie is going to be an homage to Sturges.)

The major problem is that the plot's not all the way there yet; it lacks surprise, the unexpected plot twists and sudden changes of fortune that keep viewers guessing. The coffee slogan is a lousy thing to hang the plot upon, and the ending is thoroughly predictable. Frank Capra does this sort of thing much better.

If you're new to Preston Sturges, check out "The Lady Eve" or "Sullivan's Travels" or "The Miracle of Morgan's Creek" first. If you've seen these already, then go ahead and watch this one.
rewritten_review:
...but it's certainly not without merit. Already writer-director Preston Sturges is experimenting with unusual cinematic effects in telling his stories, creating broadly drawn yet distinctive characters and situations, and writing clever and sometimes unexpectedly wise and compassionate dialogue. Sturges' ability to weave humor with insight demonstrates a creative genius that few filmmakers of his time could match. His work often reflects a deep understanding of human nature, and his clever dialogue is both entertaining and thought-provoking. (No wonder the Coen brothers' next movie is going to be an homage to Sturges.) His influence is evident in the way modern filmmakers approach storytelling, blending comedic elements with serious undertones. Sturges' films remain timeless, with their wit and charm continuing to captivate audiences even today.

The major problem is that the plot's not all the way there yet; it lacks surprise, the unexpected plot twists and sudden changes of fortune that keep viewers guessing. This results in a narrative that feels somewhat predictable, as if it follows a formula without the innovation that typically characterizes Sturges' work. The coffee slogan is a lousy thing to hang the plot upon, serving as a weak anchor for the storyline that fails to engage the audience fully. It's a device that seems forced rather than organic, detracting from the overall effectiveness of the film. The ending is thoroughly predictable, leaving viewers with a sense of déjà vu rather than the satisfaction of a well-crafted conclusion. Here, the film falls short of the standard set by Sturges' other works. Frank Capra does this sort of thing much better, with a deftness and emotional resonance that Sturges, in this instance, does not quite achieve.

If you're new to Preston Sturges, check out "The Lady Eve" or "Sullivan's Travels" or "The Miracle of Morgan's Creek" first. These films showcase the director at his best, with narratives that are both engaging and thought-provoking. His ability to create memorable characters and craft stories that resonate with audiences is on full display in these works. If you've seen these already, then go ahead and watch this one. While it may not reach the heights of Sturges' masterpieces, it still offers moments of brilliance and serves as an example of his evolving style and approach to filmmaking. It's worth watching for those who appreciate cinematic history and the development of film as an art form.

text:
Anna Christie (1931)

On its own terms, this version of Garbo's Anna Christie, shot a year later in German with a whole new cast, is just toned down and refined enough to work better than the English version (both are American MGM productions). Garbo is if anything more commanding (or more beautiful as a screen presence) and her acting is more restrained. And she seems frankly more at ease, probably for a lot of reasons, but we can speculate that she was no longer making her first talking picture, so had adjusted quickly.

Without comparing always one film to the other, this Anna Christie is still the same O'Neill play with too many words. His themes of a woman wanting love without losing her independence are here, but it comes off as oddly old fashioned anyway. There are some scenes missing--the Coney Island section is shortened and isn't as good--but overall it's a direct echo of the first film. The director, Jacques Feyder (Belgian-French), is simply redoing what was done already, which I assume must be a frustrating experience.

It's interesting to see both films in succession because they are blocked out exactly the same way (not only the sets, but the shots, are all the same). There is an occasional scene lifted from the earlier film--some of the storm, understandably, but also a brief scene where Marie Dressler (from the English language version) is walking with her friend on a plank over a canal, drunk as can be. But they are just silhouettes, and when the next scene shows their faces, we see the German actors taking their parts. There is no replacing Dressler, for sure, but for me the German father is more believable and honest in his performance.

Clearly the themes--immigration, wayward fathers, daughters turning to prostitution, and the troubles of finding true love--have strong currents back then, especially with European threads (Garbo, appropriately, plays a Swedish young woman).
rewritten_review:
Anna Christie (1931)

This version of Garbo's Anna Christie, shot a year later in German with a new cast, is more refined than the English version, both being American MGM productions. Garbo appears more commanding and at ease, likely due to no longer making her first talking picture.

Without constant comparisons, this Anna Christie remains O'Neill's play with its wordiness. Themes of a woman's desire for love without sacrificing independence are present but feel dated. Some scenes, like the Coney Island section, are shorter, yet the film echoes the original. Director Jacques Feyder is essentially redoing what was already done, likely a frustrating task.

Watching both films in succession is intriguing as they share identical blocking, sets, and shots. Occasionally, scenes from the earlier film are used, such as the storm and Marie Dressler's silhouette. The German father offers a more believable performance.

The themes of immigration, wayward fathers, daughters in prostitution, and the pursuit of true love resonate strongly, especially with European elements, as Garbo fittingly portrays a Swedish woman.

text:
A film starring Salma Hayek and Colin Farrell, two respected and talented actors, sounds like a great idea. An independent film sounds even better. The studios will control less of the content allowing the actors and writers and director more creativity.

But then why is this movie so bland? Ask the dust.

This film assumes right off the bat that we are deeply invested in the characters. No one is given a proper back story, so we don't ever know why the characters act the way they do.

Explanations for physical and emotional scars are left to our imagination, if you still have one left at the end of this movie.

I told a friend that I went to see this film, and that I thought it was awful.

Her question: "Not even Colin Farrell could save it?" My response: "Not even Colin Farrell's ass could save it."
rewritten_review:
A film starring Salma Hayek and Colin Farrell, two respected and talented actors, sounds like a great idea. An independent film sounds even better. The studios will control less of the content allowing the actors and writers and director more creativity. With the freedom of an independent production, one might expect a more innovative and compelling narrative, where the unique talents of both Salma Hayek and Colin Farrell could truly shine. The anticipation for such a collaboration could naturally run high, given the caliber of both actors and the promise of a film not bound by typical studio constraints.

But then why is this movie so bland? Ask the dust. As the film unfolds, it becomes increasingly clear that it doesn't meet the expectations set by its potential. The narrative seems to falter, lacking the depth and engagement one might hope for. This film assumes right off the bat that we are deeply invested in the characters. It plunges into the story without establishing a solid foundation for the audience to connect with. No one is given a proper back story, so we don't ever know why the characters act the way they do. The absence of this crucial element leaves viewers at a loss, unable to fully comprehend or empathize with the characters' motivations and actions.

Explanations for physical and emotional scars are left to our imagination, if you still have one left at the end of this movie. Instead of weaving these explanations into the storyline, the film seems to gloss over them, expecting the audience to fill in the gaps without sufficient context. This approach can be frustrating, as it leaves the viewer with unanswered questions and a sense of detachment from the characters' journeys. The potential for a rich, character-driven narrative is overshadowed by this lack of development.

I told a friend that I went to see this film, and that I thought it was awful. I shared my disappointment, hoping for a discussion that might shed new light on the experience, but the reaction was telling. Her question: "Not even Colin Farrell could save it?" This question encapsulates the high expectations placed on an actor of Farrell's stature to elevate the material. My response: "Not even Colin Farrell's ass could save it." This response, though lighthearted, underscores the extent of the film's shortcomings. Even the presence of such talented actors couldn't redeem the overall experience, leaving audiences wanting more from a film that had so much promise.

text: In my case I liked this movie because when I saw it I found more than I expected. I mean, this is one of the few animated movies that made me think about its themes even long after I finished. It talks about death, vengeance and hell in such a way that it gets to you like a punch in your face, even reaching to suffer with the dream sequence in the mid-point of the film. That's what makes this movie so good: the ability, unique in Don Bluth (director), to play with the people's feelings and make them love or hate a character in no time. That, and the fact that it has so many good characters like Charlie and Ann-Marie, that in the sad but happy ending you have to say "I have something in my eye" to hide the others that you cried. All I've said are just only some of the good points of this movie. As for the rest, you have to see them for yourself in a film extremely honest. Don Bluth, thank you.
rewritten_review:
In my case, I liked this movie because when I saw it, I found more than I expected. I mean, this is one of the few animated movies that made me think deeply about its themes even long after I finished watching it. It talks about death, vengeance, and hell in such a profound way that it gets to you like a punch in your face, even reaching the point where you suffer with the dream sequence in the mid-point of the film. That's what makes this movie so exceptionally good: the ability, unique in Don Bluth (director), to play with the audience's feelings and make them love or hate a character in no time at all. That, and the fact that it has so many good characters like Charlie and Ann-Marie, that in the sad but happy ending, you have to say "I have something in my eye" to hide from the others that you cried. All I've said are just only some of the good points of this movie. As for the rest, you have to see them for yourself in a film that is extremely honest and genuine. Don Bluth, thank you for creating such a masterpiece.

The film's exploration of these heavy themes is intertwined with a narrative that keeps you engaged and invested in the characters' journeys. The complexity of emotions portrayed in this movie is something that resonates with viewers of all ages, making it a timeless piece of art. Don Bluth's direction brings a unique touch that is rarely seen in animated films, allowing audiences to experience a rollercoaster of emotions, from laughter to tears, within a single viewing.

Moreover, the characters are crafted with such depth and personality that they become memorable in their own right. Charlie's charisma and Ann-Marie's innocence create a dynamic duo that captures your heart, making the story even more compelling. Their development throughout the film adds layers to the narrative, ensuring that viewers remain connected to their plight and root for their success.

In conclusion, this movie is a testament to Don Bluth's unparalleled ability to create a cinematic experience that lingers long after the credits roll. It challenges viewers to reflect on profound themes while enjoying a beautifully animated story filled with heart and soul. If you haven't seen it yet, I highly recommend experiencing this film for yourself to truly appreciate all the elements that make it a remarkable and honest work of art. Don Bluth, thank you for this unforgettable contribution to the world of animation.

text: If you're in the mood to laugh at a truly bad movie (bad in the way only Ken Russell at his worst can be), you must try this one. It succeeds in making you feel like you just landed in a .25 porn-booth, and you can just about smell the urine on the floor. Kathleen Turner struts around in a blond wig, getting her kicks from "pretending" to be a two-bit hooker (she really has a good solid job in the clothing industry and has been hurt so badly by men that this is the only way she can connect), and Tony Perkins plays a hysterical "priest" who is out to maybe murderer her (yet another movie that ends with Tony Perkins in drag). Annie Potts shows up and is not allowed to provide an ounce of her usual wit, which is reason enough to hate this movie. The kinky will love the sex scenes, so rent the UNrated version in the RED box so you can see Turner give a cop a taste of his billy club (I had to pause the VCR until we stopped laughing).
rewritten_review:
If you're in the mood to laugh at a truly bad movie—bad in the way only Ken Russell at his worst can be—you must absolutely try this one. It succeeds in making you feel like you just landed in a .25 porn-booth, and you can just about smell the urine on the floor. The atmosphere is so vividly unpleasant that it almost becomes a character in itself, adding to the layers of absurdity. Kathleen Turner struts around in a blond wig, getting her kicks from "pretending" to be a two-bit hooker. It's a bizarre role, especially considering that she really has a good solid job in the clothing industry and has been hurt so badly by men that this is the only way she can connect. Her portrayal is simultaneously intriguing and cringe-worthy, a mix that only adds to the film's nonsensical charm.

Meanwhile, Tony Perkins plays a hysterical "priest" who is out to maybe murder her—adding yet another movie to the list that ends with Tony Perkins in drag. His performance is over-the-top, embodying the chaotic spirit of the film. The way he navigates his character's questionable motives and erratic behavior is something that has to be seen to be believed. Annie Potts shows up and is not allowed to provide an ounce of her usual wit, which is reason enough to hate this movie. It's a true shame, as her comedic timing and charisma could have added a much-needed layer of levity to the proceedings.

The kinky will love the sex scenes, which are executed with a flair that only Ken Russell could achieve. So, for those curious or brave enough, rent the UNrated version in the RED box so you can see Turner give a cop a taste of his billy club. This scene is so outrageously executed that I had to pause the VCR until we stopped laughing. The film is a rollercoaster of bizarre choices and questionable artistic directions, making it a perfect candidate for those who appreciate the "so bad it's good" genre.

text: The Fiendish Plot of Dr. Fu Manchu (1980). This is hands down the worst film I've ever seen. What a sad way for a great comedian to go out.
rewritten_review: "The Fiendish Plot of Dr. Fu Manchu" (1980) is, in my opinion, the worst film I've ever seen. It's truly unfortunate and disappointing to witness such a lackluster production, especially considering the talent involved. The movie fails on numerous levels, from its weak script to its uninspired direction. The humor falls flat, and the pacing is incredibly sluggish, making it a tedious experience overall. There are so many elements that just don't come together, resulting in a disjointed and unsatisfying final product. It’s quite a sad way for a great comedian to go out, ending an illustrious career on such a low note. The film's attempt at comedy feels forced and outdated, and it lacks the charm or wit that one might expect. It's truly a letdown, especially for fans who were hoping for one last memorable performance. Instead, what we get is a movie that is hard to sit through and offers little in terms of entertainment or enjoyment. The potential for something much better was certainly there, but unfortunately, it was never realized.

text:
This is a voice of a person, who just finished watching the second season of Rome, almost at one go, and grabbed the opportunity to see "what happened next" - this film conveniently takes off where Rome ends. If you find Rome an abomination, a foul mouthed screw-fest of little historical accuracy, then you might enjoy Imperium: Augustus. But, if you feel Rome is a good thing, if you enjoy the complicated intrigue, the ambiance of decadence and the work of the actors, then Imperium will obviously appear to you as an overly timid, superfluous and tedious soap opera with not many redeeming factors.

There are some actors who for my taste look somewhat better than these in Rome. I especially disliked Rome's image of Cleopatra as a drug-soaked sex addict. There must have been a great deal of strength and dignity in that woman, and the actress in Imperium suits the part much better. O'Toole and Rampling are good, and so are some others. But then... If you have come to know - and love - Atia as the super cool bitch, you'll find the depiction of her in Imperium - as a tear-jerking mother goose in an apron - absolutely ridiculous. There are supposed to be some bitchy characters in Imperium, but these actresses rely heavily upon staring at the men and nothing much more. You'll find no interesting female characters in this epic. There's also the painfully comic Maecenas, whom we see as a screeching drag queen, even though there is little historical evidence that he was such (he's once referred to as "being effeminate in his pleasures" in the annals).

The interiors are rather meager and rely on clichés upon clichés. Cleopatra's big hall looks like something out of a computer game or a children's play room in an Egyptian theme park. There's a looooooooot of really poor 3D graphics, not up to 2003 standards.

The action is presented as a series of flashbacks the aged Augustus is reliving. So we get a quick look at some historical events, some of which are presented well, whereas some are not. An disproportional amount of time is wasted to show Livia as the "eternal flame" of Augustus. This affair doesn't sizzle for even a moment, the dialog is superlame and everything is seasoned with tacky tear-inducing musical score. Whatever amount of reality the show aims to capture, every last shred of it is destroyed by the dry synchronized dubbing (most of the actors are non English speakers).

Everything is lukewarm in this epic. True, there are more historical accuracies than in Rome, but dramatically speaking, it's plain boring. The characters lack depth and the dialog sharpness. Camera-work is often reduced to static shots, and lighting offers nothing to please your eye.

There's really no-one to love and no-one to hate in Imperium. Regardless of whether you liked or disliked Rome, there are much better films and miniseries around. Ancient Rome: The Rise and Fall of an Empire would be one thing I recommend.

But, if you feel Rome is a good thing, if you enjoy the complicated intrigue, the ambiance of decadence and the work of the actors, then Imperium will obviously appear to you as an overly timid, superfluous and tedious soap opera with not many redeeming factors.
