text:
I only went to see this movie because I have always liked Kevin Costner. I felt that Ashton did a great job in the Butterfly Effect. Unfortunately, even though these two actors were/are capable of good if not great acting moments some of that was missing here. Some of the scenes were just not believable and didn't have enough story line support.

Though the movie claims influence from the hurricane Katrina aftermath, there was very little (none) to that effect in the movie.

Overall, I liked the fact that the movie brought forward some of what goes into saving lives from a water perspective.

The special effects were pretty good and more than a little intimidating. Not sure I'll ever go deep sea fishing again...

I expected a little more emotion in the film than what was presented.

Definitely a movie that could've been seen on DVD.
rewritten_review:
I only went to see this movie because I have always liked Kevin Costner. I've been a fan of his work for a long time, and I find his performances to be consistently engaging. I felt that Ashton did a great job in the Butterfly Effect, which was a film that showcased his acting abilities in a different light. His portrayal in that movie really impressed me, and I was hoping to see more of that kind of depth in this film. Unfortunately, even though these two actors were/are capable of good if not great acting moments, some of that was missing here. There were moments where their talent shone through, but overall, it felt like some of their potential wasn't fully realized. Some of the scenes were just not believable and didn't have enough story line support, which was disappointing because it took away from the overall experience.

Though the movie claims influence from the hurricane Katrina aftermath, there was very little (none) to that effect in the movie. I was expecting the film to delve more deeply into the impact and aftermath of such a significant event, but it seemed like the connection was more of a surface-level mention rather than a substantial part of the plot. This was a missed opportunity, as exploring this theme could have added another layer of depth and relevance to the story.

Overall, I liked the fact that the movie brought forward some of what goes into saving lives from a water perspective. This aspect of the film was intriguing, and it highlighted the bravery and dedication of those involved in rescue operations. The depiction of the challenges faced in these situations was both educational and eye-opening, providing viewers with a glimpse into the complexities of such missions.

The special effects were pretty good and more than a little intimidating. The visual elements of the film were impressive, and they successfully conveyed the power and unpredictability of the ocean. Not sure I'll ever go deep sea fishing again after seeing some of those intense scenes. The filmmakers did a commendable job in creating a sense of danger and urgency through the special effects, which added to the overall impact of the film.

I expected a little more emotion in the film than what was presented. Given the nature of the story and the potential for emotional depth, it felt like there were missed opportunities to really tug at the heartstrings and create a more moving narrative. The emotional moments that were present didn't always resonate as strongly as they could have, which was a bit of a letdown.

Definitely a movie that could've been seen on DVD. While it had its moments, it wasn't necessarily a film that required a big-screen viewing to appreciate. Watching it in the comfort of one's home would still provide an enjoyable experience without losing much of the film's impact.

text:
I think I laughed twice. The line where the main character says something about being from the streets. And then I forget the other time I laughed. It was probably in the beginning.

This has to be one of the thinnest movies ever. Doesn't Hollywood realize that this kind of humor is degrading and sad, really. You can only insult yourself so many times.

2/10
rewritten_review:
I think I laughed twice during the movie. The line where the main character says something about being from the streets was one of those moments. It caught me off guard and was genuinely funny. And then I forget the other time I laughed. It was probably in the beginning, when the scenes were still fresh and held some potential for humor. But beyond those two instances, the movie really didn’t offer much in terms of comedic value. 

This has to be one of the thinnest movies ever. The plot seemed almost nonexistent, and the characters lacked depth. It felt as though the writers were relying solely on clichés and tired jokes to carry the entire film. Doesn't Hollywood realize that this kind of humor is degrading and sad, really? It’s a shame because there was potential to explore more meaningful themes, yet it was squandered in favor of cheap laughs. The reliance on such humor makes it difficult to connect with the characters or care about their journey.

You can only insult yourself so many times before it loses its impact. It’s as if the movie was trying too hard to be edgy or provocative, but it came across as more desperate than anything else. The humor wasn’t clever or original, and it did little to enhance the story or characters. Instead, it left a sense of disappointment and missed opportunities. I couldn’t help but feel that the creators underestimated their audience, assuming that this type of humor would suffice in place of a well-crafted narrative. 

In the end, the film felt like a hollow shell of what it could have been. There was so much potential to explore deeper, more engaging content, yet it was overshadowed by an over-reliance on humor that didn’t land. It’s frustrating to see how a lack of creativity and depth can lead to such an unsatisfying experience. 2/10

text:
I didn't even knew this movie existed until shortly after seeing Blade: Trinity, I was messing around on the Trinity board when I saw some user mention how the Wes Craven series is a lot better then the 'crap' that's Blade, So I did my quick research: Checked the scores on IMDb & RottenTomatoes for Dracula: Ascension, and somewhere along the search I found out that this is a sequel to Dracula 2000. I also noticed that within the Wes Craven Dracula boards there was a real strong following for this movie which is a big contradiction to the scores I was seeing.

Now let's take a quick personal recap here. I remember seeing Dracula 2000, and I remember not liking it at all, and then seeing the scores of Dracula: Ascension just lowered my expectations even more, but then again, I'm the type of person that truly needs to watch the movie myself (any movie) so that I can form my own opinion.

A couple of things I went in knowing when I started watching this movie was that it's low budget, so because of that, I'm going to have to ignore a lot of the v/fx and just figure it's going to compensated by story & acting, I was also slightly impressed by some of the casting in this movie (Jason London, Roy Schieder & Jason Scott Lee)

Oh geez This movie was CHEESY! But cheesy can be entertaining at least, I found it pretty fricken laughable, the bad audio synch from the re-recording of dialogue in a FEW scenes, the stupidity of the characters in this movie. Sure they all knew about vampires and some of the basic things, Luke even had a book on it, but did it prevent them from wanting to purposely get 'infected'? Nope, this is worst then slasher flicks where the girl has to get out of the shower and check out the noise she hears with nothing more than a towel on.

I also must've blinked at some point, because I'm not sure how 'Dracula' got clothes on his body, especially since he's big wild and angry & I figure if I was in that situation, I wouldn't want to be the one dressing him.

So the movie ends like any middle movie of a trilogy it doesn't, instead it's a 'Cliff Hangar' where I now get to wait for the 3rd installment 'Legacy'. Oh the entertainment value of Cheesy movies.
rewritten_review:
I didn't even know this movie existed until shortly after seeing Blade: Trinity. I was on the Trinity board when I saw someone mention how the Wes Craven series is better than the 'crap' that's Blade. So I did some quick research: checked scores on IMDb & Rotten Tomatoes for Dracula: Ascension, and found out it's a sequel to Dracula 2000. I noticed a strong following for it on the Wes Craven Dracula boards, which contradicted the scores I was seeing.

I remember not liking Dracula 2000, and seeing the scores for Dracula: Ascension lowered my expectations. But I'm the type who needs to watch a movie to form my own opinion. I went in knowing it was low budget, so I planned to ignore the v/fx and hope the story & acting made up for it. I was slightly impressed by the casting (Jason London, Roy Scheider & Jason Scott Lee).

Oh geez… This movie was CHEESY! But cheesy can be entertaining. I found it laughable, with bad audio synch and stupid characters. They knew about vampires, but it didn’t stop them from wanting to get 'infected'. This is worse than slasher flicks where the girl checks out a noise with just a towel on.

I must've blinked because I'm not sure how 'Dracula' got clothes on. The movie ends like any middle movie of a trilogy… it doesn't. Instead, it's a 'Cliff Hangar', and now I get to wait for the 3rd installment 'Legacy'. Oh, the entertainment value of cheesy movies.

text:
If I wouldn't have had any expectations of this film, it might have received a 5 or 6. As it stands, I give it a 3. The acting is poor, the factual accuracy of the drugs it discusses is lacking, and I feel no empathy whatsoever for the characters.

I watched 'Adam & Paul' immediately before watching this film, and I both laughed and cried on several occasions. This film did not strike even a similar chord. The directors of 'Human Traffic' may have some off-hand experience of ecstasy, but there is no demonstration of actual drug-related semantic knowledge here. In fact, I find it rather offensive and contraproductive to the strife of making current drug laws less politically oriented.

Watch 'Requiem for a Dream' if what you're looking for is an amazing, touching film about drugs.
rewritten_review:
If I wouldn't have had any expectations of this film, it might have received a 5 or 6. As it stands, I give it a 3. The acting is poor, the factual accuracy of the drugs it discusses is lacking, and I feel no empathy whatsoever for the characters. From start to finish, the film failed to engage me on any meaningful level. The characters felt flat and unrelatable, and the storyline, which should have been gripping and intense given its subject matter, was instead dull and uninspired. The lack of depth in the characters made it difficult to connect with them or care about their journeys. The film seemed to promise an insightful exploration of drug culture, but it fell short in delivering any genuine insight or emotional depth.

I watched 'Adam & Paul' immediately before watching this film, and I both laughed and cried on several occasions. This film did not strike even a similar chord. 'Adam & Paul' managed to capture the raw and poignant reality of its characters' lives, evoking both humor and sorrow, whereas this film left me feeling indifferent and unmoved. The directors of 'Human Traffic' may have some off-hand experience of ecstasy, but there is no demonstration of actual drug-related semantic knowledge here. The portrayal of drug culture was superficial and lacked authenticity, failing to reflect the complexities and nuances that surround such a topic. In fact, I find it rather offensive and contraproductive to the strife of making current drug laws less politically oriented. By oversimplifying and misrepresenting drug use, the film does a disservice to the ongoing conversation about drug policy and reform.

Watch 'Requiem for a Dream' if what you're looking for is an amazing, touching film about drugs. In contrast to this film, 'Requiem for a Dream' offers a powerful and harrowing depiction of addiction, with strong performances and a compelling narrative that leaves a lasting impact. It serves as a reminder of what a truly captivating and thought-provoking film about drugs can achieve, making it a much more worthwhile viewing experience.

text:
You're using the IMDb.

You've given some hefty votes to some of your favourite films.

It's something you enjoy doing.

And it's all because of this. Fifty seconds. One world ends, another begins.

How can it not be given a ten? I wonder at those who give this a seven or an eight... exactly how could THE FIRST FILM EVER MADE be better? For the record, the long, still opening shot is great showmanship, a superb innovation, perfectly suited to the situation. And the dog on the bike is a lovely touch. All this within fifty seconds.

The word genius is often overused.

THIS is genius.
rewritten_review:
You're using the IMDb. You've given some hefty votes to some of your favourite films. It's something you enjoy doing. And it's all because of this. Fifty seconds. One world ends, another begins. How can it not be given a ten? I wonder at those who give this a seven or an eight... exactly how could THE FIRST FILM EVER MADE be better? For the record, the long, still opening shot is great showmanship, a superb innovation, perfectly suited to the situation. And the dog on the bike is a lovely touch. All this within fifty seconds. The word genius is often overused. THIS is genius.

The experience of watching this film is unlike any other. There's a certain magic in knowing that you are witnessing the birth of a new art form, something that has forever changed the landscape of storytelling and entertainment. As the seconds tick by, you can't help but feel a sense of awe and appreciation for the groundbreaking work that was put into this creation. The simplicity of the narrative, combined with the technical prowess displayed, makes it nothing short of a masterpiece. Each frame is meticulously crafted, and the attention to detail is evident throughout the entire fifty-second runtime.

Moreover, the film's ability to convey a compelling story in such a brief duration is a testament to the filmmakers' incredible skill and vision. It captures the essence of cinema, distilling it into its purest form. The fact that it was the first of its kind only adds to its significance and allure. When you reflect on the impact this film has had on the industry and how it paved the way for countless others, it becomes clear that it truly deserves the highest praise. So, how could anyone possibly rate it anything less than a ten? The artistry and innovation displayed in this short piece are unparalleled, and it stands as a monumental achievement in the history of film.

In conclusion, this film is a true testament to the power of creativity and imagination. It serves as a reminder of the limitless possibilities that cinema offers and the enduring legacy of those who dare to dream and push the boundaries of what is possible. This is why it deserves nothing less than a perfect score. The genius behind this work is undeniable, and it will continue to inspire generations of filmmakers and film lovers alike.

text:
I was very curious about Anatomy (aka Anatomie) and if I was going to see it, I was going to have to buy it since no video stores in my area carried the film. Since it was not a low-priced DVD, I did take a chance and thought I'd take a peek at other comments on IMDb. Many of the comments didn't give me enough hope of forking out lots of bucks for a film I had never seen nor had any clues about. I basically got the idea it was a sexy youth-oriented romp being compared to many cookie-cutter teen thrillers. Well, something in the back of my mind told me to ignore those types of comments and buy it! I did, and was I pleasantly surprised!

If it is going to be compared to any other films, I would say it's a variation of Coma and Extreme Measures. I couldn't see any comparison to films like Scream, Urban Legends, et al. Yes, the cast is young (that's because they're med students! At least they aren't the increasingly boring high school type characters), and yes, some are lusty (basically the character played by Anna Loos is, and it is handled quite tastefully in the German language version), but Anatomy is well constructed, there is a tense mood throughout, the sets are amazing, the makeup effects are a wow, and Franka Potente is very credible in her role. I found myself enjoying all of it despite a few gaping holes in the plot! The story of a student discovering a sort-of secret society doing autopsies on still-living patients is a rather creepy scenario and what happens to those patients afterwards is quite clever. Sure, you could ask why didn't she just GET OUT OF THAT TOWN? Okay, but then the film would be over within a half hour.

This was the first effort from the German part of Columbia Pictures, and it's actually quite an impressive one. There was a bit of care in the production and to actually offer some genuine thrills is an accomplishment. It is a bit mature in mind, as it doesn't resort to constant opportunities for sexual encounters(a breast fest) or juvenile drug jokes. Anna Loos' character, while often making sexual remarks and looking for some fun, was actually a nice touch--having a character that was a woman more intelligent than any of the men in the school. She found that sex was really just a distraction for her and the men rather lacking.

THE IMPORTANT STUFF: Watching this film in the original German language with English or French subtitles is the BEST way to enjoy it. I saw the theatrical trailers dubbed in English and was disgusted by the change it made in the film's tone. I have never seen a properly dubbed film in my life--they never can find voices that suit the film's actors or characters. Sure enough, I tried to watch some of Anatomy dubbed in English and the intelligence level of it dropped severely, making it seem more like a comedy. A good example is when one guy was freaked out at being cut open and screamed to be sewn back up--hearing it in German he sounded frantic, but dubbed in English he sounded like a comedian. Frankly, I'm sick of hearing people say they can't handle reading subtitles or watch a "letterboxed" film. Anatomy comes off as silly with dubbed voices that seem octaves too high for any of the people you see in the film, and Anna Loos' sexual comments then just sound like awful remarks right out of Fast Times At Ridgemont High. I wonder if the negative comments about Anatomy are from people who watched it dubbed, it just doesn't seem like the same film at all! This is not a cheap horror film and deserves to be viewed as it was created. Interesting to note that some of the English subtitles are different in scenes in the feature and the "making of" supplement.

As it turns out, I gambled and won with Anatomy. It's a competent thriller with likeable characters and doesn't try to go for cheap thrills.
rewritten_review:
I was curious about Anatomy (aka Anatomie) and decided to buy it since no stores in my area carried the film. Despite mixed reviews on IMDb, I took a chance and was pleasantly surprised! Unlike cookie-cutter teen thrillers, Anatomy is more akin to Coma and Extreme Measures. The cast is young because they're med students, not high schoolers, and the story is well-constructed with a tense mood, amazing sets, and impressive makeup effects. Franka Potente is credible in her role, and despite a few plot holes, the film is enjoyable. The creepy scenario of a secret society performing autopsies on living patients is clever. While you might wonder why the protagonist doesn't just leave, that would end the film too soon. 

This is the first effort from the German part of Columbia Pictures and is quite impressive. It offers genuine thrills without resorting to constant sexual encounters or juvenile jokes. Anna Loos' character adds depth, showing a woman more intelligent than the men around her. Watching it in the original German with subtitles is the best experience, as dubbing changes the film's tone, making it seem comedic. Dubbing often fails to match the original actors' voices, reducing the film's intelligence level. For example, a frantic scene in German sounds comedic when dubbed in English. Negative comments may stem from those who watched the dubbed version, which doesn't do the film justice. Anatomy is a competent thriller with likeable characters, deserving to be viewed as it was created. I gambled with Anatomy and won, finding it a competent thriller with likeable characters that doesn't go for cheap thrills.

text: Having seen "Triumph of the Will," I can only say this movie is ghastly, even measured against the historically low "standards" of the time. Naturally it's all totally fabricated and prejudicial. This is what one would expect of 1930's German propaganda. Unfortunately, the quality of the presentation, itself, is hackneyed and cheap. It's also so blatantly ridiculous that even contemporary Germans must've left the theater holding their noses. In a genre renowned for its base appeal, lack of originality and unapologetic wrong-headedness, this film doesn't even qualify as "bad." It would have to improve significantly to attain that status!
rewritten_review: Having seen "Triumph of the Will," I can only say this movie is ghastly, even when measured against the historically low "standards" of the time. It is a film that leaves a lasting impression for all the wrong reasons. Naturally, it's all totally fabricated and prejudicial. This is exactly what one would expect of 1930's German propaganda, a time when films were often used as tools for manipulation and spreading ideologies. Unfortunately, the quality of the presentation, itself, is hackneyed and cheap, lacking any sense of artistic integrity or creativity. It's also so blatantly ridiculous that even contemporary Germans must've left the theater holding their noses, bewildered by the absurdity that unfolded on the screen. In a genre renowned for its base appeal, lack of originality, and unapologetic wrong-headedness, this film doesn't even qualify as "bad." It would have to improve significantly to attain that status! The filmmakers seem to have made no effort to bring any subtlety or nuance to their work, resulting in a piece that is as transparent as it is offensive. The overall execution leaves much to be desired, failing to capture any sense of reality or truth. Instead, it serves as a glaring reminder of the dangerous power of propaganda when wielded with such blatant disregard for factual accuracy or moral responsibility.

text:
Despite what the title may imply, "Pigs Is Pigs" does not star Porky Pig. Rather, it features a young swine with an appetite more insatiable than John Belushi's character in "Animal House". His mother repeatedly scolds him, but it does no good. So much so that he goes to another house where a deranged scientist force-feeds him more than any mere mortal can handle (but there's a surprise at the end).

I would mostly say that this cartoon seemed like a place holder in between the really great cartoons (Daffy Duck debuted three months after this came out). But make no mistake about it, they do some neat things here. The whole force-feeding sequence looks more relevant today, given the obesity epidemic overtaking our country.

Anyway, not the greatest cartoon, but worth seeing.
rewritten_review:
Despite what the title may imply, "Pigs Is Pigs" does not star the beloved Porky Pig, who is a staple in many classic animations. Rather, it features a young swine, one with an appetite more insatiable than John Belushi's character in "Animal House," which is quite a feat considering the gluttony displayed in that iconic film. This pig's voracious hunger knows no bounds, and it becomes a central theme of the cartoon. His mother, in her attempts to control his eating habits, repeatedly scolds him. However, her efforts do no good, as he continues to indulge in his excessive eating habits. The humor in this dynamic is evident, yet it portrays a deeper commentary on indulgence and self-control.

This insatiable hunger eventually leads him to another house, where the plot thickens as he encounters a deranged scientist. This character adds an intriguing twist to the narrative, as he force-feeds the young swine more than any mere mortal can handle. The sequence is both comical and slightly unsettling, as it pushes the boundaries of what might be considered reasonable consumption. However, there's a surprise at the end that adds a layer of intrigue and unexpected resolution to the story.

I would mostly say that this cartoon seemed like a placeholder in between the really great cartoons, as Daffy Duck, one of the most beloved characters in animation history, debuted just three months after this came out. The timing of this release places it in a unique spot within the context of animation history. But make no mistake about it, they do some neat things here that are worth noting. The whole force-feeding sequence, for instance, looks more relevant today, given the obesity epidemic overtaking our country. This particular scene resonates with contemporary issues, making the cartoon seem somewhat ahead of its time in its inadvertent social commentary.

Anyway, while not the greatest cartoon ever produced, it is certainly worth seeing for its unique storyline and the interesting elements it brings to the table. The cartoon offers a blend of humor and social reflection, making it an intriguing watch despite its shortcomings in comparison to later, more iconic animations.

text: An American Werewolf in Paris wasn't really that good compared to the original.The original didn't use computer effects for the werewolf and they looked more realistic .The werewolf effects in this film looked too cartoonish.most of all,the movie did not have enough for me for a horror film to enjoy.
rewritten_review: "An American Werewolf in Paris" wasn't really that good compared to the original, which set a high standard for werewolf movies. The original didn't use computer effects for the werewolf, and instead relied on practical effects that looked more realistic and convincing. The werewolf effects in this film, on the other hand, looked too cartoonish and detracted from the overall experience. The CGI lacked the tangible, gritty feel that made the original so memorable and impactful. Moreover, the storyline and character development in "An American Werewolf in Paris" fell short of expectations, failing to engage me as much as I had hoped. It seemed to lack the depth and intrigue that the original had, which made it such a classic. Most of all, the movie did not have enough elements for me to enjoy it as a horror film. It didn't capture the eerie atmosphere or the suspenseful tension that I look for in a good horror movie. Overall, it didn't deliver the same level of fear or enjoyment that the original offered, leaving me somewhat disappointed.

text:
Dark Angel is a futuristic sci-fi series, set in post-apocalyptic Seattle, centering on Max (Jessica Alba), a genetically enhanced young woman, on the run from her creators.

The Dark Angel universe is absorbing, (not as much as say Buffy, but absorbing nonetheless) with an interesting and believable set of characters. Certainly, it is not for everyone, but those who give it time will find themselves watching one of the most enjoyable series out there. Dark Angel is criminally overlooked, and under-rated, and was unfortunatly canceled after only 2 series. Which was a great shame, as this had the potential to become a great series, although its 42 episodes are only 10 shy of long running BBC sci-fi comedy Red Dwarf. As it is Dark Angel remains unfinished, so seek it out, and if you want more, lobby Fox to make another series.
rewritten_review: Dark Angel is a captivating futuristic sci-fi series set in the post-apocalyptic landscape of Seattle. It centers around the character of Max, portrayed by Jessica Alba, who is a genetically enhanced young woman on the run from the very people who created her. The Dark Angel universe is incredibly absorbing—perhaps not as much as Buffy, but absorbing nonetheless—with a compelling and believable set of characters that draw you into their world. It’s important to note that this series may not be for everyone, but for those who give it the time and attention it deserves, it becomes one of the most enjoyable series out there. Dark Angel is criminally overlooked and under-rated, which is a real shame, especially considering it was unfortunately canceled after only two series. This cancellation was a significant disappointment, as the show had the potential to become a truly great series. Despite its untimely end, the series managed to deliver 42 episodes, which is only 10 shy of the long-running BBC sci-fi comedy Red Dwarf. As it stands, Dark Angel remains unfinished, leaving fans wanting more. It’s worth seeking out this series to experience its unique charm, and if you find yourself wanting more, joining others in lobbying Fox to produce another series could be worthwhile.

text:
tries to be funny and fails miserably. The animation is just terrible, looks like a 2 year old threw it together in his sleep. Plot is dull and cliched. IF you have a young child, maybe rent it. but don't waste hard earned money to pay to see it.

1/10
rewritten_review:
The movie tries to be funny and fails miserably at every turn. The animation is just terrible, looking as if a 2-year-old threw it together in his sleep without any sense of coherence or artistic vision. It's hard to believe that anyone could put such a lackluster effort into the visual aspects of a film in this day and age. The plot is dull and cliched, offering nothing new or exciting for the audience to engage with. It's as if the creators went out of their way to include every possible trope and predictable twist, leaving viewers with a story that's entirely uninspired and unimaginative. If you have a young child, maybe rent it as a last resort to keep them entertained for a brief moment. However, don't waste your hard-earned money to pay to see it because it's simply not worth the expense or the time. You'd be better off exploring other entertainment options that provide genuine value and enjoyment. The film's shortcomings are evident from start to finish, and it's a struggle to find any redeeming qualities. Overall, it's a disappointing experience that leaves much to be desired. Save yourself the frustration and opt for something else. It's safe to say that this is one cinematic experience you'll want to skip. 

1/10

text: Overall this movie is dreadful, and should have never been made. One of the problems with this movie is that there is no link to the audience and the characters, for example, if she is about to be attacked, you want to feel, "Oh My God, No!", but you don't in this case, you don't care because there is no link that has been made to know the character. In the trailer, it seemed as though the movie would be great, yet there is no suspense what so ever really. There could have been maybe some mystery but there is not. "All she has is a toolbox." was said on the DVD's back, you would think that it was carefully planned this movie, and cleverly made, but it is not, The ending, was just awful, very straight forward, and pointless too. The acting is either average or below average, maybe even lower. In my opinion it was a waste of an hour of my life. The "Special Effects" and sets were average too, nothing special what so ever. There is not much gore, or bloody violence, not much blood is shown. This movie was advertised to make it sound quite amazing, yet really, its not even worth looking for, I do not recommend this to anyone, unless they are easily satisfied, by a few fights and a boring story.
rewritten_review: This movie is dreadful and should never have been made. There is no connection between the audience and the characters. For example, if she is about to be attacked, you don't care because there's no link to know the character. The trailer made it seem great, but there is no suspense or mystery. The DVD's back says, "All she has is a toolbox," suggesting a carefully planned movie, but it isn't. The ending is awful, straightforward, and pointless. The acting is average or below, maybe lower. It was a waste of an hour of my life. The "Special Effects" and sets are average, nothing special. There's not much gore or bloody violence. The movie was advertised as amazing, but it's not worth seeking out. I don't recommend it unless you're easily satisfied by a few fights and a boring story.

text: One would think that a film based on the life of the Japanese author Yukio Mishima would be a daunting if not impossible task. However Paul Schrader has indeed made a film "about" Mishima that is both superb & complex. While it is not a literal biography, Schrader & his co-screenwriter Leonard Scharder (his brother) have taken several incidents from his life, including his sucide and crafted what can best be described as incidental tableaus that are visually sparse and stunning. Mishima's homosexuality is almost not there, due to legal threats from his widow, but in spite of this, the film is still terrific, and one of the best films I saw in 1985. I should also mention the important contribution of Philip Glass who did the score, which adds an additional texture to the film, and is superior to the one he did for Scorsese's Kundun. Also notable is John Bailey's fine crisp beautifully colored cinematography and the great production design & costumes by Eiko Ishioka who went on to do the memorable costumes for Coppola's Dracula for which she received a well deserved Oscar. Hopefully this film will soon be available on DVD.
rewritten_review: Creating a film about Japanese author Yukio Mishima seems daunting, yet Paul Schrader's "Mishima" is superb and complex. Not a literal biography, Schrader and his co-writer Leonard Schrader depict incidents from Mishima's life, including his suicide, as visually sparse and stunning tableaus. Mishima's homosexuality is barely addressed due to legal threats from his widow, but the film remains terrific and was one of the best I saw in 1985. Philip Glass's score adds exceptional texture, surpassing his work for Scorsese's Kundun. John Bailey's crisp cinematography and Eiko Ishioka's production design and costumes, later earning an Oscar for Coppola's Dracula, are remarkable. Hopefully, this film will soon be on DVD.

text: What a surprise; two outstanding performances by the lead actresses in this film. This is the best work Busy Phillips has ever done and the best from Erika Christensen since Traffic. This film certainly should be in Oscar contention. See this movie!
rewritten_review: What a surprise; two outstanding performances by the lead actresses in this film. Busy Phillips delivers the best work of her career in a role that truly showcases her talent and depth as an actress. Her portrayal is nuanced and captivating, leaving a lasting impression that resonates long after the credits roll. Not to be outdone, Erika Christensen gives her finest performance since her remarkable work in Traffic. She brings a powerful presence to the screen, capturing the complexity and intensity of her character with incredible skill. The chemistry between Phillips and Christensen elevates the film to new heights, making it a compelling and unforgettable experience. This film certainly should be in Oscar contention, as both actresses deserve recognition for their extraordinary performances. The direction, screenplay, and overall execution of the film also contribute to its success, creating a cinematic masterpiece that draws the audience in from the very beginning. See this movie and witness the exceptional talent on display!

text:
I gave this 9 stars out of a possible 10. If it had had just a teensy weensy bit more plot line I would have given it 10.

Nonetheless it is a highly interesting film.

Judith Ivey, playing a likable old floozy, should have been given the Oscar for her performance.

Emily Grace (portraying Alice), whom I had never seen before, also does an excellent job and has THE sexiest body I think I've ever seen on film.

In a beat to heck old car, Alice has lit out from the n.e. for Florida where she has a friend (or maybe it's her sister, I'm not sure, and that's my fault, not the film's), and high hopes of going to college, which she and her family can't really afford.

She seems rather vulnerable out there on the road alone, and sure enough she encounters some slightly rough looking characters and shortly after that it's discovered there's a hole in one of her tires.

She is at a rest stop at the time and is assisted by a woman named Sandra and her husband, Bill, an older couple who are traveling in an RV.

They're going south, to Florida, and take her under their wing, but is everyone quite the way they're presenting themselves? Flashbacks and paranoia enter the story as our young heroine learns some new lessons about life.
rewritten_review: I gave this 9 stars out of 10. With a bit more plot, it would have been a 10. Nonetheless, it's a highly interesting film. Judith Ivey, playing a likable old floozy, deserved an Oscar for her performance. Emily Grace (as Alice) does an excellent job and has the sexiest body I've ever seen on film. In a beat-up car, Alice heads from the n.e. to Florida, hoping to attend college, which she and her family can't afford. Vulnerable on the road alone, she encounters rough characters and discovers a hole in her tire. At a rest stop, she's helped by Sandra and Bill, an older couple in an RV, heading south. But is everyone as they seem? Flashbacks and paranoia unfold as our young heroine learns new life lessons.

text: I must preface this comment with a sort of admission: I suppose I just have a soft spot for the original 60s-70s TV series. I think the filmmakers here blew it from the get-go as far as casting: in a supposed remake, audiences would look for reflections of the hip, athletic Linc (Clarence Williams III), or the cool, with-it Michael Cole, and so forth. Instead, we get Giovanni Ribisi as a poor-little-white rich boy who comes off as just pathetic, like he is in all his roles (in the office I used to work in, I amused myself once by creating a fake movie poster, casting various actors as members of the office staff; guess who I cast as the dorky son of the company President?). Danes does OK as the new Julie, but none of the characters have much to do, as the story just sort of sits there, mired in conventionality. So it's quite forgettable, besides. What was I talking about?
rewritten_review: I must preface this comment with a sort of admission: I suppose I just have a soft spot for the original 60s-70s TV series. I think the filmmakers here blew it from the get-go as far as casting: in a supposed remake, audiences would look for reflections of the hip, athletic Linc (Clarence Williams III), or the cool, with-it Michael Cole, and so forth. Instead, we get Giovanni Ribisi as a poor-little-white rich boy who comes off as just pathetic, like he is in all his roles. In the office I used to work in, I amused myself once by creating a fake movie poster, casting various actors as members of the office staff; guess who I cast as the dorky son of the company President? It was Giovanni Ribisi, of course, because he always seems to embody that kind of character. Danes does OK as the new Julie, but none of the characters have much to do, as the story just sort of sits there, mired in conventionality. There is no real development or engaging plot to pull the audience in or make them care about what happens next. So it's quite forgettable, besides. It's a shame because there was potential to bring something fresh and exciting to the concept, but unfortunately, that was not realized. What was I talking about? It's easy to forget because there wasn't much substance to hold on to in the first place.

text:
Just got back from a free screening and I'm very glad I didn't pay to see this very sub-par film. The theater was full and the crowd was a mix of kids and adults. It seemed like it was just the kids who were laughing at all the slap-stick and fart jokes though (good god they loved to hit these poor mice in the crotch a lot!). The movie is pretty juvenile, unintelligent, predictable, and mostly annoying. The characters just seem to be thrown together to fill in empty space and the relationships between them all seemed very forced with no charm at all.

Visually, the film is about average with nothing that really stands out. They did a decent job of mimicking the clay look from Wallace and Gromit, but other than that it's very forgettable imagery.

Although I was really bored throughout the whole film, I chuckled a couple times. It's not an absolute failure, but I most definitely would not want to watch it again. If you're a parent with kids (and you don't care that your kids see mindless cheap-jokes) then feel free to take them to see it, but everyone else shouldn't waste their money.
rewritten_review:
Just got back from a free screening, and I'm glad I didn't pay for this sub-par film. The theater was full, with a mix of kids and adults. It seemed like only the kids laughed at the slapstick and fart jokes (they loved the crotch hits on the mice!). The movie is juvenile, unintelligent, predictable, and mostly annoying. The characters seem thrown together to fill space, with forced and charmless relationships.

Visually, the film is average, with nothing standout. They mimicked the clay look from Wallace and Gromit decently, but the imagery is forgettable. I was bored throughout, though I chuckled a couple of times. It's not a total failure, but I wouldn't watch it again. Parents with kids who don't mind cheap jokes can take them to see it, but everyone else shouldn't waste their money.

text:
You know the people in the movie are in for it when king-sized hailstones fall from a clear blue sky. In fact, the weather stays pretty bad throughout this atmospheric thriller, and only lawyer Chamberlain has the answer. But he's too much the European rationalist, I gather, to get in touch with that inner being that only reveals itself through dreams.

Darkly original mystery heavy on the metaphysics from director-writer Peter Weir. Already he had proved his skill at flirting with other dimensions in Picnic at Hanging Rock (1975). Here it's the arcane world of the Australian Aborigines that confronts that the tightly ordered world of the predominant whites. Something strange is going on inside the Aborigine community when they kill one of their number for no apparent reason. Yuppie lawyer Chamberlain is supposed to defend them in a white man's court. But the more he looks into things, the more mysterious things get, and the more interested a strange old Aboriginal man gets in him. And then there're those scary dreams that come and go at odd times.

Well structured screenplay deepens interest throughout. One reason the movie works is the background normalcy of Chamberlain's wife and little daughters. Audiences can readily identify with them. And when their little world runs into forces beyond the usual framework, the normalcy begins to buckle, and we get the feeling of worlds beginning to collide. Chamberlain underplays throughout, especially during the underground discovery tour where I think he should have shown more growing awareness than he does. After all, it's the picking up of the mask that holds the key (I believe) to the riddle, yet his reaction doesn't really register the revelation.

Of course, the notion of nature striking back has a certain resonance now, thirty years later. In the film, the notion is wrapped in a lot of entertaining hocus-pocus, but the subject itself remains a telling one. One way of bringing out a central irony in the movie is the symbolism of the opening scene. A big white SUV barrels past an aboriginal family, leaving them in the historical dust. The terrain looks like an interior tribal reservation of no particular importance to the coastal fleshpots where industry dwells. Yet, it's also a region most likely to survive anything like a destructive last wave. Perhaps there's something about past and future to think about here.

Anyway, this is a really good movie that will probably stay with you.

text:
This low-budget film about a writer who goes to work in a London casino has an awful script, wooden performances, and not much to recommend it. Of course it will appeal to highbrows for whom "mainstream" is a curse word, and who automatically add 20 IQ points when they hear a British accent (apologies to Jeff Foxworthy).

The script is full of holes (has he written a book yet, or not?), cliches (relationship trouble: she works days, he works nights), and provides so little insight into such basics as character motivation that it requires a voice-over narration just to move the story along.

In an attempt to keep the audience from dozing off, it includes a street fight scene that is about as realistic as a high school production of Julius Caesar.

If your idea of scintillating dialogue is "I'll see your ten, and raise you twenty", then RUN to see this movie. Otherwise, save your money.
rewritten_review: This low-budget film about a writer who goes to work in a London casino has an awful script, wooden performances, and not much to recommend it. Of course, it will appeal to highbrows for whom "mainstream" is a curse word and who automatically add 20 IQ points when they hear a British accent (apologies to Jeff Foxworthy). The script is full of holes (has he written a book yet, or not?), clichés (relationship trouble: she works days, he works nights), and provides so little insight into such basics as character motivation that it requires a voice-over narration just to move the story along. The script leaves much to be desired in terms of coherence and depth, as it is riddled with inconsistencies and overused tropes that fail to engage the viewer on a meaningful level. The narrative lacks any semblance of originality or creativity, relying heavily on predictable plot devices that do little to capture the audience's imagination or interest. In an attempt to keep the audience from dozing off, it includes a street fight scene that is about as realistic as a high school production of Julius Caesar. This particular scene is so poorly executed that it borders on the absurd, with choreography and acting that lack any sense of authenticity or believability. The fight scene, much like the rest of the film, is devoid of any genuine tension or drama, leaving the audience feeling detached and uninvested in the outcome. If your idea of scintillating dialogue is "I'll see your ten, and raise you twenty," then RUN to see this movie. Otherwise, save your money. The dialogue throughout the film is uninspired and lacks any wit or charm, failing to deliver the kind of engaging exchanges that would make the film worth watching. The interactions between characters are stilted and unconvincing, further contributing to the overall lack of engagement and entertainment value. In summary, this film is an exercise in mediocrity, with its lackluster script, uninspired performances, and predictable plot offering little to no redeeming qualities. Save your money and time for something more worthwhile and engaging, unless you find joy in the mundane and predictable.

text:
DIRTY WAR

Aspect ratio: 1.78:1

Sound format: Stereo

Emergency services struggle to cope when Islamic terrorists detonate a so-called 'dirty bomb' in the middle of London.

Daniel Percival's frightening movie uses all available evidence to dramatize the possible effects of a radioactive explosion in the heart of the UK capital, using the kind of documentary-style realism which has distinguished this particular subgenre since the 1960's. In essence, the film reveals a catalogue of flaws in the British government's current strategy for dealing with such terrorist outrages, and Percival's carefully-honed script (co-written by Lizzie Mickery) vents its spleen against mealy-mouthed politicians who would rather maintain the economic status quo than tackle this issue head-on. The film covers all necessary bases, and makes the salient point that this kind of terrorism is practised by a tiny handful of fanatics who have tarnished the Islamic faith with their reckless disregard for human life, though viewers won't be reassured by the subsequent scenes of devastation and horror. Not merely a drama, the film acts as a warning against complacency. Either that, or its just another post-9/11 scaremongering tactic. YOU be the judge...
rewritten_review:
DIRTY WAR

Aspect ratio: 1.78:1

Sound format: Stereo

Emergency services struggle when Islamic terrorists detonate a 'dirty bomb' in London.

Daniel Percival's frightening movie dramatizes the possible effects of a radioactive explosion in the UK capital, using documentary-style realism. The film reveals flaws in the British government's strategy for dealing with such terrorist outrages, with Percival's script (co-written by Lizzie Mickery) criticizing politicians who prioritize the economic status quo over tackling this issue. It highlights that this terrorism is practiced by a small group of fanatics tarnishing the Islamic faith, though viewers won't be reassured by the scenes of devastation. More than a drama, the film warns against complacency, or perhaps it's just post-9/11 scaremongering. YOU be the judge...

text:
Xiao Chen Zhi Chun is a great movie, not only in the year it was shot but also now. It's an art movie which is not outdated even in 21st century. The director maintained a good narrative skill and thus made the story so smooth!

The movie reminds me of the later French new wave movie: Francois Truffaut's "Femme d'a cote" which is of the similar topic.
rewritten_review:
Xiao Chen Zhi Chun is undoubtedly a great movie, not only in the year it was shot but also now, standing the test of time with remarkable grace and poise. It's an art movie, a true masterpiece, which is not outdated even in the 21st century, continuing to captivate audiences with its timeless beauty and profound storytelling. The director displayed an extraordinary ability to maintain a good narrative skill, weaving a tale that resonates deeply with viewers, and thus made the story so smooth and engaging from start to finish. 

The movie reminds me of the later French New Wave masterpiece: Francois Truffaut's "Femme d'a cote," which is of the similar topic, exploring the complexities and nuances of human emotions and relationships with a deft touch. Both films share a profound understanding of the human condition, capturing the intricacies of love and longing with an authenticity that is truly rare. The parallel between these two works highlights the universal themes they explore, bridging cultures and eras with their compelling narratives.

text:
This Stan Laurel comedy short is a cute little parody of the Valentino film BLOOD AND SAND. If you've seen BLOOD AND SAND, then you'll probably appreciate this film and laugh at a few of the scenes that mock the Valentino film. However, if you have not see that movie and just watch this film, you'll probably not be very impressed--though I really liked the title cards, us the word "bull" was used repeatedly in very funny ways.

Stanly plays "Vaselino" a bullfighter who seems pretty dim-witted and wins only because the bulls seem to lazy and non-aggressive. Even the bull at the end of the film who has supposedly killed ten men is obviously just a domesticated bull.

Not a great film by any stretch of the imagination, but still a cute and harmless film.
rewritten_review:
This Stan Laurel comedy short is a cute little parody of the Valentino film BLOOD AND SAND. If you've seen BLOOD AND SAND, then you'll probably appreciate this film and laugh at a few of the scenes that mock the Valentino film. However, if you have not seen that movie and just watch this film, you'll probably not be very impressed—though I really liked the title cards, as the word "bull" was used repeatedly in very funny ways. The clever use of the word added an extra layer of humor that might be missed if you weren't familiar with the original film. 

Stanley plays "Vaselino," a bullfighter who seems pretty dim-witted and wins only because the bulls seem too lazy and non-aggressive. His character is portrayed in such a way that he's both endearing and comically inept. Even the bull at the end of the film, who has supposedly killed ten men, is obviously just a domesticated bull. This twist adds to the humor because the audience is led to expect a formidable opponent, yet what they get is just the opposite. 

Not a great film by any stretch of the imagination, but still a cute and harmless film. Despite its simplicity, the film manages to entertain with its lighthearted approach and playful jabs at a more serious film genre. Its charm lies in its ability to poke fun without malice, making it an enjoyable watch for those who appreciate classic comedy. Even though it may not leave a lasting impression, it offers a delightful glimpse into Stan Laurel's early comedic style.

text:
Travis and Sandy(Ben Johnson and Harry Carey, Jr.)are horse traders coerced into selling their animals to a Mormon group and guiding them across the frontier to a settlement. What they do not expect is to encounter the notorious Clegg murderers, with their wounded leader Uncle Shiloh(Charles Kemper). Ward Bond portrays Elder Wiggs, the main voice for the Mormon group moving the wagon train to the Lord's destination. Along the way, they also encounter "Doctor" A Locksley Hall and his "Hoochey Koochey Wagon" and lend them help.

Lovingly directed by Ford who pays close attention to detail with realistic problems any group would encounter during a rugged wagon trail. The film has a wonderful cast made up of character actors with nary a true star in the film which is actually a blessing to see, if just not for a change of pace. Young Johnson and Carey, Jr. come off real well, but this is Bond's film to shine as he has the best lines. Johnson is the one who seems to understand ruffians and brutes like Shiloh and will certainly come in handy when certain conflict might develop as the Clegg boys ride along side them a piece.

I'd have to say this is one of his best and most least appreciated westerns and seems to flow very well.
rewritten_review:
Travis and Sandy (Ben Johnson and Harry Carey, Jr.) are horse traders coerced into selling their animals to a Mormon group and guiding them across the frontier to a settlement. They unexpectedly encounter the notorious Clegg murderers, with their wounded leader Uncle Shiloh (Charles Kemper). Ward Bond portrays Elder Wiggs, the main voice for the Mormon group moving the wagon train to the Lord's destination. Along the way, they also encounter "Doctor" A Locksley Hall and his "Hoochey Koochey Wagon" and lend them help.

Lovingly directed by Ford, who pays close attention to detail with realistic problems any group would encounter during a rugged wagon trail. The film has a wonderful cast made up of character actors with nary a true star, which is a refreshing change of pace. Young Johnson and Carey, Jr. come off well, but this is Bond's film to shine as he has the best lines. Johnson is the one who understands ruffians like Shiloh, which will be handy when conflict develops as the Clegg boys ride alongside them.

I'd say this is one of his best and most underappreciated westerns and flows very well.

text: This is definitely one of the weaker of the series of Carry On films. It lacks the usual fun and sparkle and even the cast seem embarrassed by the poor dialogue. By the time this came out, the series was in terminal decline and boy does it show! If you're coming fresh to this series, avoid this one till near the end.
rewritten_review: This is definitely one of the weaker entries in the series of Carry On films. It lacks the usual fun and sparkle that fans have come to expect from these comedic masterpieces. Even the cast, who are usually vibrant and full of energy, seem embarrassed by the poor dialogue they have been given to work with. By the time this particular installment came out, the series was in terminal decline, and boy does it show in every scene and every line. If you're coming fresh to this series, it's best to avoid this one till near the end, when you've already developed a fondness for the characters and the humor style. The lack of charm and wit in this film is quite noticeable, making it one that is easily forgettable compared to its predecessors. It's almost as if the magic that made the earlier films so enjoyable and entertaining has vanished, leaving behind a hollow shell of what the Carry On series used to represent. The decline in quality is evident, and it's a shame because the series had so much potential and brought so much joy to audiences over the years. So, if you're new to the Carry On films, save this one for later when you've had a chance to appreciate the better, more vibrant films in the series.

text:
This movie is a muddled mish-mash of clichés from recent cinema. There are some promising ideas in there, but while the director was clearly aiming to wind up with a hauntingly ambiguous film, what he ended up with was a confusing mess. Lead actor Daniel Wu does a fair job but with no central theme it seems as though he doesn't have much to work with. Furthermore, the movie is largely devoid of scares (although, in fairness, there are some creepy moments amid the drudgery).

*MILD SPOILERS*

We have the mysterious death of an estranged twin, diabolical librarians, ghostly love interests, identity confusion, death by savage monkeys, oedipal conflict, abusive stepfathers, sublimated homosexuality, and crime gang connections. The only real commonality these elements share seems to be that they cause the protagonist to express a vague sense of confusion and discontent.

Perhaps the most disappointing aspect to this film is that despite the brother's death by monkeys being strongly featured on the DVD cover, the act itself is never directly portrayed. Instead, director Julian Lee uses what appears to be stock footage of monkeys - not very scary.

*END SPOILERS*

Avoid this one. For an excellent psychological, ambiguous horror tale, check out the Korean film A Tale of Two Sisters (2003).
rewritten_review:
This movie is a muddled mish-mash of clichés from recent cinema. There are some promising ideas, but while the director aimed for a hauntingly ambiguous film, it ended up a confusing mess. Lead actor Daniel Wu does a fair job, but with no central theme, he doesn't have much to work with. The movie is largely devoid of scares, though there are some creepy moments amid the drudgery.

*MILD SPOILERS*

We have the mysterious death of an estranged twin, diabolical librarians, ghostly love interests, identity confusion, death by savage monkeys, oedipal conflict, abusive stepfathers, sublimated homosexuality, and crime gang connections. These elements only share a vague sense of confusion and discontent in the protagonist.

Perhaps the most disappointing aspect is that despite the brother's death by monkeys being featured on the DVD cover, the act is never directly portrayed. Instead, director Julian Lee uses what seems to be stock footage of monkeys - not very scary.

*END SPOILERS*

Avoid this one. For an excellent psychological, ambiguous horror tale, check out the Korean film A Tale of Two Sisters (2003).

text: This is a masterful piece of film-making, with many themes simmering and occasionally boiling over in this warts and all study of the poet's bohemian, self-indulgent wartime years that span the aerial bombardments of London and the outward tranquillity of a Welsh coastal retreat - the borderlines between friendship, lust and love, dedication to art and experience versus practical concerns, jealousy, rivalry, cowardice and egotism versus heroism and self-sacrifice and more. A mature, subtle script that suggests and occasionally brings into dramatic focus the underlying tensions is well served by perfect performances (apart from the odd inappropriate smiling that Keira Knightley is prone to, though perhaps under direction this time as the other characters themselves often mention it). But above all the exquisite visual composition of each moment, with inventive and elegant use of close-up, camera angle and lighting, including pointillistic faux home movie footage, is a wonder and joy to behold. It's as continuously beautiful to look at as a Bertolucci, but the relationships here are more convincing and the narrative more engaging than some of that master's work. A very rare type of film these days - it holds the attention and stirs the emotions without abandoning artistic integrity and succumbing to manipulative, superficial shortcuts.
rewritten_review: This masterful film captures the poet's bohemian, self-indulgent wartime years amidst London's aerial bombardments and a tranquil Welsh retreat. It explores themes of friendship, lust, love, art versus practicality, jealousy, rivalry, cowardice, egotism, heroism, and self-sacrifice. A mature, subtle script brings underlying tensions into focus, complemented by perfect performances (despite Keira Knightley's occasional inappropriate smiling, likely directed). The exquisite visual composition, with inventive use of close-up, camera angles, and lighting, including faux home movie footage, is a joy to behold. Continuously beautiful like a Bertolucci, the relationships are more convincing, and the narrative more engaging. This rare film captivates and stirs emotions without sacrificing artistic integrity or resorting to superficial shortcuts.

text:
I saw the movie in 1972, and like other people who have commented on it here ... I went back many more times to see it over and over ... I think 9 times in all. Just great is how I would describe it ... I was taken by the sound track, the beautiful panoramas of the south of France, the life style the kids began on their own. An ideal way to live is what they had set up ... of course the powers that be have to intercede, but when I forget that part I find myself wanting to be in the movie and live like that! So good that it is available on DVD now ... it was not around for years!

TLW
rewritten_review: I saw the movie in 1972, and like other people who have commented on it here, I went back many more times to see it over and over. I think 9 times in all. Just great is how I would describe it, truly remarkable and captivating. I was taken by the sound track, which was nothing short of mesmerizing, and the beautiful panoramas of the south of France, which were simply breathtaking. The lifestyle the kids began on their own was intriguing and inspiring. An ideal way to live is what they had set up, crafting a world that seemed almost utopian in its simplicity and beauty. Of course, the powers that be have to intercede, but when I forget that part, I find myself wanting to be in the movie and live like that, embracing the freedom and the endless possibilities that their world seemed to offer. It’s so good that it is available on DVD now, especially since it was not around for years! The availability of the DVD allows for a whole new generation of viewers to experience what I did back in 1972, and it brings back such fond memories for those of us who watched it back then. TLW

text:
This movie is somehow showing 6.2 stars, It seems inconceivable that the director has that many relations. I am at a loss to explain this.

Avoid this movie at all costs. You have only a certain number of hours on the Earth, don't waste 1&1/2 of them on this retarded steaming heap of Guano!!!

There is no story as apparently the director "wrote" (and I'm guessing with a blunt orange crayon) the next day's script at the completion of the day's shooting. The "story" has been called whimsical, no it is aimless, there is maybe enough "story" to fill a commercial. Don't you hate ads?

Now while both leads can act they obviously decided not to here. And similarly the writer/director can actually both write and direct as evidenced by his next work "Toy Love"

So to recap, even if you get this movie for free, even if you're paid to watch it avoid it.

To paraphrase Monty Python's Search for the holy Grail, "Run flee!"
rewritten_review:
This movie is somehow showing 6.2 stars, which seems inconceivable. Avoid this movie at all costs. You have only a certain number of hours on Earth; don't waste 1&1/2 of them on this retarded steaming heap of Guano!

There is no story, as apparently the director "wrote" the next day's script at the completion of the day's shooting. The "story" has been called whimsical, but it is aimless. There is maybe enough "story" to fill a commercial. Don't you hate ads?

While both leads can act, they obviously decided not to here. Similarly, the writer/director can actually both write and direct, as evidenced by his next work "Toy Love."

To recap, even if you get this movie for free, even if you're paid to watch it, avoid it. To paraphrase Monty Python's Search for the Holy Grail, "Run flee!"

text: doesn't mean this movie is good. i was really frustrated by it on many levels. it's kind of the tip of the hat to bukowski. hey, i've read that guy in college--let's see what matt dillon does with him. and i like matt dillon. i thought he came close to looking a little like hank, but mostly just the ruddy cheeks. i have to care about a character, though, and there just wasn't much here to care about. i think time might be cruel to bukowski, and that bothers me a lot, because the writing was solid in a sort of post counter culture time. hard to sit through, scenes that went nowhere, and a soundtrack that made me want to vomit. i ask for very little, got less.
rewritten_review: This movie, despite its potential, doesn’t mean it's good. I was really frustrated by it on many levels, and it’s kind of the tip of the hat to Bukowski. Hey, I’ve read that guy back in college—let’s see what Matt Dillon does with him. And I like Matt Dillon. I genuinely thought he came close to looking a little like Hank, but mostly just the ruddy cheeks. I have to care about a character, though, and there just wasn’t much here to care about. I think time might be cruel to Bukowski, and that bothers me a lot, because the writing was solid in a sort of post-counterculture time. It was hard to sit through, with scenes that went nowhere, and a soundtrack that made me want to vomit. I ask for very little, got less. The film seemed to struggle in capturing the essence of the original material, and I couldn’t help but feel disappointed as a viewer. The narrative felt disjointed, and there was a lack of cohesive storytelling that made it difficult to engage with the plot or the characters. Despite the potential for a compelling adaptation, the movie fell flat, leaving me feeling underwhelmed and unsatisfied. I found myself yearning for a deeper connection to the narrative and the characters, but unfortunately, the film didn’t deliver. The missed opportunities in developing the story and characters left a lingering sense of frustration, and I couldn’t shake the feeling that something essential was missing from the adaptation. The overall experience was underwhelming, and I couldn’t help but feel that the film failed to capture the complexity and depth of Bukowski’s work. The disappointing execution made it a challenging watch, and I was left hoping for more than what was ultimately delivered.

text: I can't believe I bought this movie on DVD. I don't even remember it being shown on TV last year. Why in the world couldn't they have just done a real sequel to one of the best Christmas movies ever made? Damn and Randy Quaid looks like he's been on the same drugs as Jerry Lewis. I didn't know about this movie until I bought it tonight and thought I would check it out on IMDb and see how it was rated. Boy did I make a mistake. If your reading this review be warned stay away from it and just stick to the first Christmas Vacation. Well at least I didn't pay more then 10 bucks for it. Maybe I can trade it in and get half of that back at Tower Records. Then again maybe not. PS I still haven't watched it yet, my DVD player went on the fritz tonight watching another wonderful movie, The Chronicles of Riddick (Unrated Director's Cut) woo freaking hoo.
rewritten_review: I can't believe I bought this movie on DVD. I don't even remember it being shown on TV last year. Why in the world couldn't they have just done a real sequel to one of the best Christmas movies ever made? Damn and Randy Quaid looks like he's been on the same drugs as Jerry Lewis. I didn't know about this movie until I bought it tonight and thought I would check it out on IMDb and see how it was rated. Boy did I make a mistake. If you're reading this review be warned, stay away from it and just stick to the first Christmas Vacation. Well, at least I didn't pay more than 10 bucks for it. Maybe I can trade it in and get half of that back at Tower Records. Then again, maybe not. PS I still haven't watched it yet, my DVD player went on the fritz tonight watching another wonderful movie, The Chronicles of Riddick (Unrated Director's Cut) woo freaking hoo. Honestly, I feel like I just wasted my money on something that I didn't even know existed until tonight. It's almost like this movie appeared out of nowhere, and now I'm regretting this spontaneous purchase. The thing is, I have a special place in my heart for the original Christmas Vacation, and I just can't understand why they couldn't make an actual sequel that lives up to the brilliance of the first one. But instead, I ended up with this DVD that seems to be universally panned. Randy Quaid, oh my goodness, what happened? He looks like he's been on the same drugs as Jerry Lewis, and that's saying something. I don't even know what to expect from his performance in this film. It's frustrating because I really wanted to enjoy a good Christmas movie, and now I'm stuck with this. Maybe if I ever get my DVD player working again, I'll finally give it a watch, but honestly, I'm not in any rush. For now, I'm just going to remember the joy of the first Christmas Vacation and try to forget that this one even exists. If only I had checked the reviews before buying it. Lesson learned, I guess. At least I have The Chronicles of Riddick to keep me entertained, even though my DVD player decided to quit on me right in the middle of it. What a night.

text:
I was absolutely blown away by John Cassavetes's Opening Night. It's the first movie of his that I've seen that seems to be on a bigger scale, thus it feels more mainstream, but it still doesn't feel as if he grounded himself any more than he has in his previous films. That is perhaps what makes it so intense. There is also something undoubtedly cathartic about watching this movie.

It's about what in fact Cassavetes has made a staple of his career, an ideal that he has expressed behind the camera throughout his career as a director and is here expressing it in front. Rowlands's character, middle-aged stage actress Myrtle Gordon, cannot bring herself to play her role in the upcoming production as written so she uncalculatedly follows impulse after impulse, resulting in what appears to be chaos on stage, until she finds the right one. It's a daringly abstract premise.

This is a movie that does not fail to capture the innate steering that one goes through during an emotional cleansing. No one understands why Myrtle does many of the things she does, and it is seen and even portrayed as something destructive, yet it just might be the best thing for her. It may be a cleansing rather than a breakdown. A withdrawal, a cocoon, a rebellion, it all culminates into a meltdown. Cassavetes gives her character a brutally real touch, which is that early on, she is ardently arguing that she has nothing in common with her character, yet she is in quiet but emotionally corroding fear that the opposite is true.

The last scene, the climactic performance that Myrtle shares with a character painfully estranged from her who is acting with her, is one of the most interesting, hilarious, hard-hitting, enlightening, and enjoyable moments I've ever seen in a movie.

It's the first movie of his that I've seen that seems to be on a bigger scale, thus it feels more mainstream, but it still doesn't feel as if he grounded himself any more than he has in his previous films. That is perhaps what makes it so intense. There is also something undoubtedly cathartic about watching this movie. The last scene, the climactic performance that Myrtle shares with a character painfully estranged from her who is acting with her, is one of the most interesting, hilarious, hard-hitting, enlightening, and enjoyable moments I've ever seen in a movie.

text:
In the seedy streets somewhere in New York City, a lonely punk named Tromeo ( Will Keenan) has little friends but all they ever do is get tattoos, piercing and just party all the time. He does fall for a beautiful rich girl named Juliet ( Jane Jenson) whom is also troubled as her father is being quite an abusive son of a you know what, but as our title characters meet and fall for each other things start becoming quite magical for them. Unfortunately their fathers are at each other as Juliet's dad wants to take over Tromeo's dad's movie studio, but could love really conquer them all and stop this feud?

Hilarious and gross horror comedy drama satire from the wacky and disgusting people at Troma is a wonderful modern day take on William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet. This was released in theaters in 1997 and got some good reviews for this is a dark humored satire of the legendary story that started it all, it's got some good laughs, piercing, graphic violence and gore such as a head being smashed on a fire hydrant. For me this is the third best Troma movie next to the immortal "Toxic Avenger" and "Troma's War" being second, yes the acting can be a little bad like some Troma flicks but the stuff above makes it up for that and this is a must see movie if you like horror comedies, Peter Jackson, and Troma or if you wanna see a comical version of a beloved story, BTW also look for a couple of amusing appearances by The Toxic Avenger and SGT. Kabukiman NYPD.

Also recommended: "The Toxic Avenger", "Meet The Feebles", "Ichi The Killer", " Re-Animator", "Terror Firmer", "Class of Nuke'Em High", "Romeo and Juliet ( 1968 and 1996)", " Pieces", " Troma's War", " Citizen Toxie: The Toxic Avenger 4", "Basket Case", " Riki-Oh: The Story of Ricky", " Demons", "New Nightmare", " Freddy Vs. Jason", " Cabin Fever", "Nightmare on Elm Street", " Battle Royale", " Pink Flamingos", " Perfect Blue", " Rabid Grannies", "Surf Nazis Must Die", " Hostel", " Evil Dead II", "Serial Mom", " Dead Alive ( a.k.a. Braindead)", " Street Trash".
rewritten_review:
In the seedy streets of New York City, a lonely punk named Tromeo (Will Keenan) has few friends, who spend their time getting tattoos, piercings, and partying. He falls for a beautiful, troubled rich girl named Juliet (Jane Jenson), whose father is abusive. As Tromeo and Juliet meet and fall in love, their world becomes magical. Unfortunately, their fathers are at odds, with Juliet's dad wanting to take over Tromeo's dad's movie studio. Can love conquer all and stop this feud?

This hilarious and gross horror comedy-drama satire from Troma is a modern take on Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet. Released in theaters in 1997, it received good reviews as a darkly humorous satire of the legendary story. It features laughs, piercings, graphic violence, and gore, such as a head being smashed on a fire hydrant. Despite some bad acting typical of Troma films, it remains a must-see for fans of horror comedies, Peter Jackson, and Troma. Look for amusing appearances by The Toxic Avenger and SGT. Kabukiman NYPD.

Also recommended: "The Toxic Avenger," "Meet The Feebles," "Ichi The Killer," "Re-Animator," "Terror Firmer," "Class of Nuke'Em High," "Romeo and Juliet (1968 and 1996)," "Pieces," "Troma's War," "Citizen Toxie: The Toxic Avenger 4," "Basket Case," "Riki-Oh: The Story of Ricky," "Demons," "New Nightmare," "Freddy Vs. Jason," "Cabin Fever," "Nightmare on Elm Street," "Battle Royale," "Pink Flamingos," "Perfect Blue," "Rabid Grannies," "Surf Nazis Must Die," "Hostel," "Evil Dead II," "Serial Mom," "Dead Alive (a.k.a. Braindead)," "Street Trash."

text:
I'm not ruining anything when I inform you that you get to see a woman have sex with a goat in this movie. If that is your thing, then your movie has arrived.

A woman and her husband go to see her estranged sister in the family mansion in the woods. Her sister is a creepy lady to say the least, and she seems to have interests that go beyond family love. On the side a group of unsavory characters show up and begin enacting all kinds of pagan rituals.

The plotting is pretty weak and the characters are pretty dumb. The woman sticks around even after her husband starts turning into a jerk and hanging out with the pagans, even continues the have sex with him. On the exploitative side of things, there is much bared flesh and a couple of kinky couplings, but nothing that hasn't been better somewhere else. Oh, and the aforementioned goat-sex scene.

Most viewers won't make it to the end. Exploitation fans will ride it out, but will be left wanting more.

4/10
