text:
A solid B movie.

I like Jake Weber. His understated delivery is refreshing in a time of over the top performances. I liked the relationship between the father and son. I liked the family dynamics. The Wendigo looks silly, but it is a representation of the kid's toy and the dead deer. It's an amalgamation like, see? This is a psychological story, not a Freddy slash em up instant gratification flick. Watch it and reflect on your inner child and what the movie might have to say to you and you'll be fine.

Nice work.
rewritten_review: A solid B movie, and one that I found to be quite engaging and enjoyable. I like Jake Weber, who delivers a performance that is both captivating and nuanced. His understated delivery is refreshing in a time of over-the-top performances that often dominate the screen. It's nice to see an actor who can convey so much with subtlety and restraint, bringing a depth to his character that is often lacking in similar films. I liked the relationship between the father and son, which felt authentic and well-explored throughout the movie. The way their bond is portrayed adds a layer of emotional depth that resonates with the audience. I also liked the family dynamics, which are central to the storyline and provide a rich backdrop for the unfolding drama. The Wendigo, while it may look silly to some, is actually quite an interesting element of the film. It serves as a representation of the kid's toy and the dead deer, creating an amalgamation that is both symbolic and thought-provoking. See, this is a psychological story, not a Freddy slash-em-up instant gratification flick that relies on cheap thrills and gore. Instead, it invites the viewer to delve deeper into the narrative and explore the underlying themes. Watch it and reflect on your inner child and what the movie might have to say to you, and you'll be fine. It's a film that encourages introspection and offers more than just surface-level entertainment. Nice work from everyone involved in bringing this story to life. The film successfully combines elements of horror and psychological drama to create a unique viewing experience that stands out in the genre.

text:
Liongate has yet to prove itself. Every single movie from lionsgate has been abysmal. i've tried and tried to give them more opportunities and they just keep slapping me over and over again. And Cabin Fever is definitely no exception.

I couldn't even pay attention to most of this movie it was so frustrating and bad.

here's the plot. Guy cuts up dead dog for some reason. Gets infected by random virus, transfers it to kids at a camp, kids start to get infected and die, town finds out about it and rather than help them, kills them. then the water is infected and everyone dies. the end.

Seriously, that's the whole movie.

all the characters are completely retarded, you don't care for any of them, and the one kid should have stuck with boy meets world. Me and my friend found that talking about how fat and bitchy our one classmate was to be far more enjoyable than paying attention to this movie. We did manage to make it all the way to the end while screaming bulls$@t, because this film will make you do that.

and i'm still confused by the random slow motion karate moves of the one random kid and how apparently everybody out in the country is completely retarded and hickish. And again, why did this dog attack the girl? why did the kid the hicks were trying to kill sit in a chair waiting for them to kill him? that was part of the two of their's plan? wow. best plan ever. i cannot believe this movie got a theatrical release. i could barely stomach the DVD, let alone have to sit in a theater not moving for an hour and a half. It wasn't scary, or funny, or cool, or anything. it's just a waste of 90 minutes that you could be using to...i don't know, plant a tree or something. it's more productive than this piece of garbage. The acting, special effects, and script are a joke. don't ever pick this up.

Cabin fever gets one nasty leg shaving scene, out of 10
rewritten_review:
Liongate has yet to prove itself. Every single movie from Lionsgate has been abysmal, and Cabin Fever is no exception. I couldn't even pay attention to most of this movie; it was so frustrating and bad.

Here's the plot: Guy cuts up a dead dog, gets infected by a virus, transfers it to kids at a camp, kids get infected and die, town kills them instead of helping, water gets infected, everyone dies. The end. Seriously, that's the whole movie.

All the characters are completely unrelatable, and you don't care for any of them. The one kid should have stuck with Boy Meets World. My friend and I found talking about our classmate more enjoyable than this movie. We managed to make it to the end while screaming bulls$@t because this film will make you do that.

I'm still confused by the random slow-motion karate moves of one kid and why everyone in the country seems so hickish. And why did the dog attack the girl? Why did the kid sit in a chair waiting to be killed? That was their plan? Wow. Best plan ever. I can't believe this movie got a theatrical release. It wasn't scary, funny, cool, or anything. It's just a waste of 90 minutes. The acting, special effects, and script are a joke. Don't ever pick this up.

Cabin Fever gets one nasty leg shaving scene out of 10.

text:
Every James Bond movie has its own set of rules. Just like every Indiana Jones movie has ITS own set of rules. And the fact that screenwriters don't break these rules maintains the integrity of the characters. With a completely unnecessary plot twist, the integrity of both Ocean films plummets somewhere between Airplane 2 and a Roadrunner cartoon.

Imagine what would happen, while teetering on the rope bridge outside of the Temple of Doom, if Indy told Shorty and Willie not to worry because throughout the entire first two movies he's secretly had super powers and can fly them both to safety.

Entertaining? Sure, for a Roadrunner cartoon. But Spielberg would never have done that because it would have destroyed the integrity of the film. More importantly, it would have ANGERED the audience. They'd already sat on the edge of their seats through 3 hours worth of Indiana Jones movies and they were counting on Indiana to get them off that bridge in a believable way. If he were to fly off? People would have walked out of the theaters the same way people did during Ocean's 12.

SPOILERS

1. Julia Roberts'character, Tess, infiltrates a museum by disguising herself as...Julia Roberts?!? A clever twist? By breaking the fourth wall three hours after we've been introduced to these characters? Is this the Naked Gun 33 and 1/3? It's a textbook example of how a cheap laugh can ruin an entire film. But wait...just in case you haven't walked out yet...

2. The suspense builds throughout the last hour of the movie -- how will they pull off the heist -- there are only 10...8...5...2 DAYS LEFT! And then in the last 12 minutes of the film, the ONLY entertaining part of this movie, we see that the heist was made days earlier and took Matt Damon all of 30 seconds to pull off. The past 10 days? A complete waste of your time.

BACK TO INDIANA JONES ON THE ROPE BRIDGE..."Just relax, Willie! I stole the REAL stones back about a month ago! Besides, I convinced them you were Kate Capshaw!"

If you haven't already seen it, cut your losses and go see the Polar Express. I don't want to ruin the ending for you, but there really is a Santa Claus. Most importantly, you won't feel cheated leaving the theater.
rewritten_review:
Every James Bond movie has its own set of rules, just like every Indiana Jones movie. Screenwriters maintain character integrity by not breaking these rules. However, with an unnecessary plot twist, the integrity of both Ocean films plummets somewhere between Airplane 2 and a Roadrunner cartoon.

Imagine if, on the rope bridge outside the Temple of Doom, Indy told Shorty and Willie not to worry because he secretly had superpowers and could fly them to safety. Entertaining? Sure, for a Roadrunner cartoon. But Spielberg would never do that because it would destroy the film's integrity and anger the audience. They'd feel cheated, just like during Ocean's 12.

SPOILERS

1. Julia Roberts' character, Tess, disguises herself as...Julia Roberts?! Breaking the fourth wall after three hours with these characters ruins the film with a cheap laugh. But wait...

2. The suspense builds for the heist with only days left! But in the last 12 minutes, we see the heist was done days earlier and took Matt Damon 30 seconds. The past 10 days? A waste of time.

BACK TO INDIANA JONES ON THE ROPE BRIDGE..."Just relax, Willie! I stole the REAL stones a month ago! Besides, I convinced them you were Kate Capshaw!"

If you haven't seen it, cut your losses and see the Polar Express. There really is a Santa Claus, and you won't feel cheated leaving the theater.

text: This movie was an excellent acted, excellent directed and overall had an excellent story. Ive had real life experiance with a boy like 'Radio'. At the football program in my town, weve had a mentally challenged boy every year practice, travel, and have fun with the football team. This movie is really true and i can identify with it 100%. A boy like 'Radio' just needs to feel like they belong to something; they need to feel like their life is worth living. Thats how 'Radio' feels and thats why that type of program is set up at my high school. This is a very touching movie that im glad has been brought to the big screen. My dad and I loved it and i will always remember this for being a movie that tells a riveting story of the goodness and kindness of man!
rewritten_review:
This movie was an excellently acted, excellently directed and overall had an excellent story that truly resonated with me on a deep level. I've had real-life experience with a boy like 'Radio,' which made the film all the more meaningful and impactful for me. At the football program in my town, we've had a mentally challenged boy every year who would practice, travel, and have fun with the football team just like any other member. This movie is really true to life, and I can identify with it 100% because I've seen firsthand how important it is for a boy like 'Radio' to feel included and part of something bigger than themselves. They need to feel like they belong to something; they need to feel like their life is worth living and that they have a place in the world. That's precisely how 'Radio' feels, and that's why that type of program is set up at my high school, to foster inclusion and community spirit.

This is a very touching movie that I'm genuinely glad has been brought to the big screen, as it highlights these important themes and experiences. The narrative is incredibly powerful and heartwarming, showcasing the positive impact that kindness, understanding, and acceptance can have on individuals and communities. My dad and I loved it, and it was such a heartening experience for us to watch it together. I will always remember this film for being a movie that tells a riveting story of the goodness and kindness of man, reminding us of the potential for compassion and empathy in human relationships. It's a story that not only entertains but also inspires and encourages us to be better, more understanding people.

text: This movie seems to send the wrong message. There can be morality without using Christ. Poeple of other religions, I believe, can get into heaven. I am a Catholic who goes to church every week, but I do not agree with such Christian arrogance. This is the worst time travel movie I have ever seen and I've seen Timeline.
rewritten_review:
This movie seems to send the wrong message, and it's quite disappointing on multiple levels. The story appears to be pushing a narrative that suggests morality is solely tied to the use of Christ, which I find to be a rather narrow viewpoint. It's important to recognize that people of other religions, I firmly believe, can indeed achieve a place in heaven. Morality and righteousness are not exclusive to one faith or belief system. As a Catholic who diligently attends church every week, I feel strongly about my faith, but I do not agree with such Christian arrogance that this film seems to endorse. It's disheartening to witness this kind of portrayal, especially when the world is so diverse and filled with varying beliefs that all deserve respect and understanding.

Moreover, when it comes to the movie's genre, I have to say that this is the worst time travel film I have ever seen, and I've seen Timeline, which is saying a lot. Time travel movies have a unique potential to explore fascinating concepts and ideas, but this one falls flat in its execution. It's unfortunate that the filmmakers chose to focus on such a limited perspective rather than embracing a more inclusive and imaginative approach to storytelling. Overall, the film's message and execution left me feeling frustrated and disappointed.

text: This movie was like a bad train wreck, as horrible as it was, you still had to continue to watch. My boyfriend and I rented it and wasted two hours of our day. Now don't get me wrong, the acting is good. Just the movie as a whole just enraged both of us. There wasn't anything positive or good about this scenario. After this movie, I had to go rent something else that was a little lighter. Jennifer Tilly is as usual a very dramatic actress. Her character seems manic and not all there. Darryl Hannah, though over played, she does a wonderful job playing out the situation she is in. More than once I found myself yelling at the TV telling her to fight back or to get violent. All in all, very violent movie...not for the faint of heart.
rewritten_review: This movie was like a bad train wreck, and as horrible as it was, you still had to continue to watch. My boyfriend and I rented it and unfortunately wasted two hours of our day on it. Now don't get me wrong, the acting is good. Just the movie as a whole just enraged both of us. There wasn't anything positive or good about this scenario at all. After this movie, I had to go rent something else that was a little lighter to cleanse the palate. Jennifer Tilly is, as usual, a very dramatic actress. Her character seems manic and not all there, which can be quite unsettling to watch. Darryl Hannah, though her role seemed overplayed at times, she does a wonderful job playing out the situation she is in. More than once, I found myself yelling at the TV, telling her to fight back or to get violent. It was frustrating but also engaging in a strange way. All in all, very violent movie...not for the faint of heart. It is definitely not something I would recommend if you're looking for something uplifting or positive. It's a film that leaves you with a lot of emotions, mostly negative, and makes you question why you continued watching it in the first place. The storyline, though intense, just didn't sit well with me, and I found myself thinking about it long after it was over, which is not something I necessarily wanted. If you decide to watch it, just be prepared for an emotional roller coaster that might leave you feeling more drained than entertained.

text: My god this movie is awfully boring. I am a big fan of Gina Gershon, when I rented this movie I expected a romantic drama, and some great performance from Gershon. Gershon is great as always, but she is not right actress for this role, she is too good for Rade Serbedzija. The romance between Gershon and Serbedzija's characters is too unconvincing. And I absolutely hated Serbedzija's character (a wonman organizer), he is not charming in anyway in the movie. How did Dr. Lauren Graham (Gershon) is beyond my comprehension. Maybe Sean Connery, Robert DeNiro or Harrison Ford would have done a better job on this role, but they don't have the European-ish looking I guess. Any way, I was so bored druing the movie. If you are looking for a good Gina Gershon movie, check out Bound, her best film so far. If you are looking for a romantic film about a younger woman and an older man, try some Harrison Ford or Sean Connery movies. Gina Gershon is so underrated, and she deserves better chance than this, I wish her to make better choice in the future.
rewritten_review: This movie is awfully boring. I'm a big fan of Gina Gershon, and when I rented this movie, I expected a romantic drama with a great performance from her. Gershon is great as always, but she's not the right actress for this role; she's too good for Rade Serbedzija. The romance between their characters is unconvincing, and I absolutely hated Serbedzija's character (a woman organizer). He's not charming in any way. How Dr. Lauren Graham (Gershon) falls for him is beyond me. Maybe Sean Connery, Robert DeNiro, or Harrison Ford would have done better, but they don't have the European-ish look, I guess. I was so bored during the movie. If you want a good Gina Gershon movie, check out Bound, her best film so far. For a romantic film about a younger woman and an older man, try Harrison Ford or Sean Connery movies. Gina Gershon is underrated and deserves better roles. I hope she makes better choices in the future.

text:
The films of the Science Fiction Channel ( Sci-Fi Channel ) have become boringly predictable. The seem low on budget, originality, and plot.

In this creation the government is out to get a bunch of telekinetics and recruits a poor soul by devious means to help. There is plenty of over worked recycled twists on evil government organization theme. black coats, shadows, short meaningless lines make these one dimensional cartoons.

Daniel Dae Kim stands out as a good actor in a small role. He brings a bit of the style of his "Angel" character to the role. It is hard to miss the link that his "Crusade" character was a telepath and this is a film on telekinetics. Was this a Sci-Fi casting move to try and draw fans from the other show? Who knows. Thankfully he is a decent actor and a pleasure to watch.

The movie is definitely low budget. It reflects The Sci-Fi Channels current model of Canadian location, few well known characters, few effects, and woefully terrible plot and character development. One would think they believe science fiction fans will view anything labeled "scifi."

If you want a good telekinesis movie, check out "the Fury" ( 1978).
rewritten_review:
The Science Fiction Channel's films have become predictably boring, lacking in budget, originality, and plot. This one features a government targeting telekinetics, using a manipulated individual to assist. It includes tired twists on the evil government theme, with black coats, shadows, and one-dimensional characters.

Daniel Dae Kim shines in a small role, bringing a bit of his "Angel" character's style. It's hard to ignore the connection to his telepathic "Crusade" character. Was this casting meant to attract fans from that show? Who knows. Thankfully, he's a decent actor and a pleasure to watch.

The movie is decidedly low budget, reflecting The Sci-Fi Channel's current model: Canadian locations, few well-known actors, minimal effects, and terrible plot and character development. They seem to think science fiction fans will watch anything labeled "scifi."

For a good telekinesis movie, check out "The Fury" (1978).

text: full of surprises, beautiful, cruel at times. just like life itself. leaves one asking for more. the best parts are of course the action scenes and chases. have to really wonder how much work these guys put into making some scenes (whale chases, polar bear hunts, etc). it is a wonderful experience and not to be missed by anyone who dives, surfs, or goes to the beach once in a while. the music is enticing and the narration is superb and extremely well paced. definitively one of the best documentaries ever made and worth not less than a very respectable 10 (for its kind). some of the footage is very cruel and might not be recommended for people with weak stomachs (every killer whale footage is cruel).
rewritten_review: Full of surprises, beautiful, cruel at times—just like life itself. This documentary leaves one asking for more with its breathtaking visuals and compelling storytelling. The best parts are, of course, the action scenes and chases that are both thrilling and captivating. One has to really wonder how much work these talented filmmakers put into crafting some of the scenes, such as the mesmerizing whale chases and the intense polar bear hunts, among others. It is truly a wonderful experience and should not be missed by anyone who enjoys diving, surfing, or even just visiting the beach once in a while. The music throughout the documentary is enticing, drawing viewers in and enhancing the overall experience. Meanwhile, the narration is superb and extremely well paced, guiding the audience through the various scenes with expertise and clarity. This is definitively one of the best documentaries ever made, deserving nothing less than a very respectable 10 for its kind. Some of the footage is very cruel and might not be recommended for people with weak stomachs, as every killer whale footage is particularly cruel and intense. Nonetheless, this documentary stands out as a remarkable achievement in filmmaking, offering a glimpse into the raw and untamed beauty of nature while also highlighting its sometimes harsh and unforgiving aspects. The dedication and effort that went into creating such a masterpiece are evident in every frame, making it an unforgettable journey for viewers of all kinds. Whether you are an avid nature enthusiast or simply someone who appreciates well-crafted cinema, this documentary is sure to leave a lasting impression.

text: Mario is invited to Princess Peach's castle for cake. When Mario gets there, he finds out that Bowser has kidnapped her! Mario must save the day again. Unlike the 2-D games, Mario can explore anything he wants to. He can just roam around, climb trees trying to look for 1-Ups, find secrets in levels, and more. You can spend four hours in one level. No time limits. There are 16 worlds, with a number of stages, and there are star doors, which you need a certain number of stars to get into. Once you get in these star doors, you must go through a stage and fight Bowser at the end of the stage. To get to certain worlds, you need a number of stars to get in. You enter the world by going through a painting. There is so much stuff to do and so many hours of gameplay, I don't see how anyone could dislike this game. It's great. This launch title is the game that insured gamers that the N64 would have a good life. Every 3D plat-form game we know of has something in common with SM64. Banjo Kazooie and Banjo Tooie are examples that are commonly used. Super Mario 64 is one of the greatest games in the history of 3D games. 10 out of 10. If you have an N64, buy this game. It's hard to find used, because no one's selling this baby for 5 bucks at the pawn shop. A perfect 10.
rewritten_review: Mario is invited to Princess Peach's castle for cake. When he arrives, he discovers Bowser has kidnapped her! Mario must save the day again. In this 3D adventure, Mario can explore freely, climbing trees for 1-Ups and finding secrets. You can spend four hours in one level without time limits. There are 16 worlds, each with stages and star doors requiring a certain number of stars to enter. Inside these doors, you go through a stage and fight Bowser. To access certain worlds, you need stars, and you enter by going through a painting. With so much to do and hours of gameplay, it's hard to dislike this game. It was the launch title that ensured the N64's success. Every 3D platform game has something in common with SM64, like Banjo Kazooie and Banjo Tooie. Super Mario 64 is one of the greatest 3D games ever. 10 out of 10. If you have an N64, buy this game. It's hard to find used, as no one's selling it for 5 bucks at the pawn shop. A perfect 10.

text: And it got it in France ! Why not in the rest of the world while the studios keep churning out expensive post-Grisham trash (Will anyone remember him as a fine writer, and not the most betrayed-by-the-screen author this side of Stephen King ?) this one has it all. Okay, the situations are not always original, has minor plot holes and it has a tendency to be too clever some (brief) times for its own sake, but it actually delivers and is obviously a work of love. I'd be curious to know what the budget was. AND. for once, this is not a cheap Tarantino copy ! (Well, film noir didn't started with Tarantino, you know.) Will it once again be saved by Europe, like John Dahl's movies were, so Mr Guttierez can make another one like this ? If you ever read this, Mr Guttierez, thank you and se
rewritten_review:
And it got it in France! Why not in the rest of the world while the studios keep churning out expensive post-Grisham trash? Will anyone remember him as a fine writer, and not the most betrayed-by-the-screen author this side of Stephen King? This one has it all. Okay, the situations are not always original, has minor plot holes, and it has a tendency to be too clever some (brief) times for its own sake, but it actually delivers and is obviously a work of love. I'd be curious to know what the budget was. AND. For once, this is not a cheap Tarantino copy! (Well, film noir didn't start with Tarantino, you know.) Will it once again be saved by Europe, like John Dahl's movies were, so Mr. Guttierez can make another one like this? If you ever read this, Mr. Guttierez, thank you and see

In France, it genuinely resonated and captured the audience's attention! It's perplexing why it hasn't achieved the same recognition in the rest of the world, especially considering that many studios keep churning out those expensive post-Grisham adaptations that often miss the mark. It's a wonder if anyone will remember Grisham for his writing prowess, rather than as the most betrayed-by-the-screen author this side of Stephen King. This particular piece, however, truly has it all. Sure, the situations don't always break new ground and there are minor plot holes. It does have moments where it tries to be a bit too clever for its own good, albeit briefly. Nonetheless, it delivers in a way that is both satisfying and evident of being a genuine labor of love. The budget is something I'd be incredibly curious to know more about. AND. In a refreshing twist, this is not just another cheap Tarantino copy! (Let's not forget, film noir didn't originate with Tarantino, you know.) One wonders if, like John Dahl's movies, this too will find salvation in Europe, allowing Mr. Guttierez the opportunity to craft yet another film with this kind of impact. If you ever happen to read this, Mr. Guttierez, thank you and see

text:
I for one was glad to see Jim Carrey in a film where being over the top wasn't the goal. His character is like all of us. Wanting more - better things to happen to us and expecting God to deliver.

Morgan Freeman made a great God. With a sense of humor and a genuine sense of love for each of us yet ready to take a little vacation when the opportunity presents itself.

I thought Jennifer Aniston's character was a little too vulnerable and understanding towards Carry's basically self-centered TV anchorman wanna-be but that's the way it was written.

I think the previews ruined several potentially very funny scenes because everyone who saw them knew what was coming before it happened.

I have read a number of the reviews and it seems some people are looking a little too deep. This is a summer comedy and is not meant to solve the problems of the world although there are a few messages we could all take to heart.

A funny film.
rewritten_review:
I was glad to see Jim Carrey in a film where being over the top wasn't the goal. His character is like all of us, wanting more and expecting God to deliver.

Morgan Freeman made a great God, with humor and love for each of us, yet ready to take a vacation when possible.

Jennifer Aniston's character was a bit too understanding towards Carrey's self-centered TV anchorman wannabe, but that's how it was written.

The previews ruined several funny scenes because everyone knew what was coming.

Some people look too deep into this; it's a summer comedy, not meant to solve world problems, though it has a few messages we could all take to heart.

A funny film.

text:
Although released among a flock of revenge-minded action flicks (KILL BILL VOL. 2; THE PUNISHER; WALKING TALL), MAN ON FIRE works as well as it does thanks in large part to the always-watchable Denzel Washington, one of the best actors around today.

In MAN ON FIRE, based on A.J. Quinnell's 1980 novel (first filmed in 1987, with Scott Glenn), Washington plays a down-on-his-luck ex-mercenary who has now stooped to drinking from a flash of Jack Daniels, until his old partner (Christopher Walken) offers him a chance at redemption. He is hired on as a bodyguard to the 10 year-old daughter (Dakota Fanning) of a Mexican businessman (Marc Antony) and his American-born wife (Radha Mitchell). While he and Fanning work like oil and water first (not mixing very well), he really gets to form a bond with her, encouraging her to do better at swimming, while he at the same time attempts to deal with the demons of the past. It is that very bond that will force Washington back into his old line of work when Fanning is kidnapped and held for a $10 million ransom, and he is nearly killed. With almost any other stock action hero (Schwarzenneger; Segal, etc.), the subsequent bloodbath would be the same repetitive schlock we've seen a million times before. But Washington's character, though he's killing for a reason, does not particularly enjoy doing what he does. Still, he gets help from a very intrepid Mexican newspaper reporter (Rachel Ticotin) out to expose "La Hermanidad" (The Brotherhood), the kidnap gang responsible for Fanning's abduction.

MAN ON FIRE is flawed to some extent because of the hyper camera work, nearly headache-inducing montage editing, and various film stocks that are par for the course of its director Tony Scott (TOP GUN; CRIMSON TIDE), but which are not necessarily unique to him (witness Oliver Stone's use of montage in JFK or Sam Peckinpah's in his classic 60s and 70s films). Still, Scott gets a very good performance from Washington, as well as Fanning, who comes across as far more than a typical movie-brat kid. Harry Gregson-Williams' south-of-the-border Spanish guitar score is enhanced by soundtrack splashes of Chopin, Debussy, and even Linda Ronstadt's classic 1977 country-rock version of "Blue Bayou." Although the film overall is quite violent, it is no worse than most action films of the last ten years, and overall it is much better than most.
rewritten_review:
Despite being released among a slew of revenge-driven action films (KILL BILL VOL. 2; THE PUNISHER; WALKING TALL), MAN ON FIRE stands out largely due to the compelling performance of Denzel Washington, one of today's top actors.

In MAN ON FIRE, based on A.J. Quinnell's 1980 novel (first adapted in 1987 with Scott Glenn), Washington portrays a down-and-out ex-mercenary who drowns his sorrows in Jack Daniels until his old partner (Christopher Walken) offers him a chance at redemption. He's hired as a bodyguard for the 10-year-old daughter (Dakota Fanning) of a Mexican businessman (Marc Antony) and his American wife (Radha Mitchell). Initially clashing, Washington and Fanning eventually bond, with him encouraging her swimming while confronting his own past demons. This bond propels Washington back into action when Fanning is kidnapped for a $10 million ransom, leaving him nearly dead. Unlike typical action heroes (Schwarzenegger; Seagal, etc.), Washington's character, while lethal, does not relish the violence. He is aided by a determined Mexican reporter (Rachel Ticotin) aiming to expose "La Hermanidad," the gang behind Fanning's kidnapping.

MAN ON FIRE has its flaws, notably the frenetic camera work, montage editing, and diverse film stocks typical of director Tony Scott (TOP GUN; CRIMSON TIDE), reminiscent of Oliver Stone's JFK or Sam Peckinpah's classics. Nonetheless, Scott draws excellent performances from Washington and Fanning, who transcends the typical movie-brat role. Harry Gregson-Williams' Spanish guitar score is complemented by Chopin, Debussy, and Linda Ronstadt's "Blue Bayou." Though violent, the film is on par with most action movies of the last decade and is ultimately superior to many.

text: Due to the fact that in 1976 there were no CGI I felt that the movie was quite watchable. The studio productions were very good and very elaborate. The background effects were very believable and always appeared as if they were part of the whole set. The actors did OK considering the premise of the film being set in a type of Jules Vern atmosphere where imagination and possibilities of future exploration were at most improbabilities. Had I watched this film in 1976 I probably would have been in awe of the ability of man to build a machine that could travel to the earths core. I still wonder to this day why we are not all flying around in our cars but I digress. McClure and Cushing have their funny moments, mostly from their facial expressions toward each other which of course makes the film somewhat campy which I loved. The 'monsters' left something to be desired but the story had a good premise although I feel as though some other sort of 'thing' could have been more believable under those circumstances. All in all quite watchable for its time and fun now.
rewritten_review: In 1976, without CGI, the movie was quite watchable. The studio productions were elaborate, and the background effects were believable, blending well with the set. The actors did well, considering the film's Jules Verne atmosphere, where future exploration seemed improbable. If I had watched it in 1976, I'd have been in awe of a machine traveling to the Earth's core. I still wonder why we're not flying in cars, but I digress. McClure and Cushing had funny moments, mostly from their facial expressions, adding a campy charm I loved. The 'monsters' were lacking, but the story had a good premise, though something else might have been more believable. Overall, it was quite watchable for its time and fun now.

text: Simply, one of the funiest movies i've ever seen. It's a parody of crime-life, parody of everything that represents the Chicago 1930.- There is no realy need to underestimate this movie because rating is under 5. Its a opinion of a mass, and mass is hypnotized. Who decide to watch it - it will regret, Who decide not to watch it - will regret more.
rewritten_review: Simply put, this is one of the funniest movies I've ever seen in my entire life. It's a brilliant parody of crime-life, a parody of everything that represents the Chicago 1930s era. There is no real need to underestimate this movie just because the rating is under 5. It's an opinion of a mass, and the mass is hypnotized. Those who decide to watch it will not regret it, while those who decide not to watch it will regret it even more. The humor is spot-on, and the way it captures the essence of that time period is truly remarkable. Every scene is crafted with such precision and wit that it's hard not to be impressed. From start to finish, it keeps you entertained, and you'll find yourself laughing out loud more often than not. It's a hidden gem that deserves more recognition than it gets. So, I urge you not to let the rating fool you; give it a chance and experience the joy that comes with watching this cinematic masterpiece. The characters, the setting, and the storyline all come together to create an unforgettable viewing experience. Trust me, it's worth it.

text:
This is a fine drama and a nice change of pace from today's more hectic and loud films. It is another solid based-on-a-true store, which still means much of it could be made up for dramatic purposes. Frankly, I don't know but I liked the story.

The story is about a young man back in the Fifties who gets interested in rocketry and wants to enter that field instead of working in the coal mines as everyone else, including his father, does in this West Virginia town. The big problem is the conflict it causes between the boy and his father, which I think was overdone. I would like to have a little less tension between the two.

The young man, still a boy, is played by Jake Gyllenhaal, one of his first staring assignments, I think. He's likable, as are his school buddies in here. It's nice to see nice kids in a modern-day film. The two other key actors in the movie are Chris Cooper (the dad) and Laura Dern (the kid's teacher who encourages him all the time.)

The cinematography is decent the 1950s soundtrack is fun to hear. Once again: I wish there more of these kind of films made today.
rewritten_review: This fine drama offers a refreshing change from today's hectic and loud films. Based on a true story, it still leaves room for dramatic liberties, but I enjoyed the narrative. The story follows a young man in the Fifties who becomes interested in rocketry, aspiring to enter that field instead of working in the coal mines like everyone else, including his father, in this West Virginia town. The conflict between the boy and his father felt overdone, and I would have preferred less tension there. The young man, played by Jake Gyllenhaal in one of his first starring roles, is likable, as are his school buddies. It's refreshing to see nice kids in a modern film. Other key actors include Chris Cooper (the dad) and Laura Dern (the encouraging teacher). The cinematography is decent, and the 1950s soundtrack is enjoyable. I wish more films like this were made today.

text: This movie is a perfect example of an excellent book getting ruined by a movie. Jacob Have I Loved is quite possibly the worst film that I have ever seen. There is no storyline, plots disappear, and the editing is awful. To top it all off, the music is straight from a synthesizer and sounds unbelievably terrible. Bridget Fonda's acting is decent, but everyone else's acting is totally amateur. I would suggest this movie to someone who is studying to be a producer as a study on how not to produce a movie as it is chock full of bad cut-scenes, bad transitions and acting that should have been re-shot! Read the book and don't waste your time with this film.
rewritten_review:
"Jacob Have I Loved" is a perfect example of an excellent book getting completely ruined by a movie adaptation. I can't emphasize enough how disappointing this film is. It is quite possibly the worst film that I have ever seen, and I don't say that lightly. From start to finish, there is no coherent storyline to follow, and any semblance of a plot seems to disappear into thin air. It's as if the filmmakers had a checklist of what not to do and decided to implement every single item. The editing is downright awful, leaving viewers confused and disengaged. 

To top it all off, the music is a complete disaster. It's straight from a synthesizer and sounds unbelievably terrible, as if it was created as an afterthought with no regard for how it would fit the scenes. It fails to add any depth or emotion to the film, making it even more unbearable to watch. Bridget Fonda's acting is decent, which is one of the very few redeeming qualities of this movie, but unfortunately, everyone else's acting is totally amateur and lacks any real conviction or authenticity. 

I would suggest this movie to someone who is studying to be a producer, but only as a study on how not to produce a movie. It is chock full of bad cut-scenes, bad transitions, and acting that should have been re-shot! The technical aspects alone are a masterclass in what to avoid when making a film. It’s truly a missed opportunity to bring a beloved book to life on the screen. My advice is to read the book and don't waste your time with this film. It simply doesn't do justice to the source material and fails to capture the essence and depth of the story. Save yourself the disappointment and stick to the pages of the novel.

text:
If you loved the early-60's version of "The Time Machine", don't waste your time; as with last year's "The Planet of the Apes", this has been "reimagined", and not for the better. And, just as with "Planet...", its lead actor is woefully miscast and leaden; Guy Pearce, a terrific actor of great range, is all wrong for this role, giving a one-note performance that elicits zero sympathy; he's so dour and serious, and lacking in awe of the (supposedly) amazing things he sees that you don't believe for a moment that he's experiencing them. Worse yet, whose idea was it for him to resemble the love child of David Spade and Calista Flockhart?? A handsome actor, here he is sickeningly gaunt, which is, believe it or not, a major distraction. Frankly, the man looks gravely ill and is photographed cruelly. He shares absolutely NO chemistry with anyone on the screen, a direct result of a performance that is out of sync with anyone else's. Sadly, even with a proper leading man this movie doesn't stand a chance for it is fatally burdened with both a totally inept director - whole scenes go nowhere and are poorly realized - and a screenplay that is utterly inferior, scattered and at times incoherent - not for a single moment do you care about anyone in this film, for the single fact that there is NOTHING in the way of character development! In the original, you got to KNOW the Eloi, so therefore you felt for them, and felt their terror of the Morelocks; here, as the movie stresses several times, they are nothing but sheep and act accordingly. Unless you're a member of PETA, scared sheep are HARDLY the stuff of entertainment!

Samantha Mumba does as well as possible, in her movie debut, but, like everyone else in this mess, most especially Jeremy Irons (if he's the leader of the Morelocks [who look like rejects from "The Mummy Returns"], why then does HE look like Edgar Winter's long-lost brother?) is COMPLETELY WASTED. Also wasted was the money spent on the endless 'special' effects, which belie the $70M spent on the film; they are uniformly lackluster, obvious and unconvincing. And then there's the look of the film: poorly photographed, its art direction and sets are just "there" and its costumes are typical in design. There isn't an original thought or idea expressed behind or on the screen. Most of all, it isn't even fun! (The filmmakers use the now-ubiquitous Orlando Jones as "comic relief" but, as usual, Jones is irritating, and just HOW does his electrically-driven character survive in a world seemingly devoid of electricity?)

All in all, this is an empty, lifeless, dull, sterile and confused affair: didn't they ALREADY REMAKE "Planet of the Apes"??? (At least THAT had the fortune of some strong performances!)

*SPOILER!* The final insult (beyond a head-shakingly terrible, not to mention convenient, ending)? Not only do they BARELY feature the changing dress-store figures, they make even the time machine itself an anachronistic, gaudy glass-n-chrome bore! (If "The Sopranos" had a time machine, THIS is exactly what it would look like.) Pathetic...
rewritten_review: If you loved the early-60's version of "The Time Machine," don't waste your time on this reimagining, which, like last year's "The Planet of the Apes," is not for the better. Guy Pearce, a terrific actor, is miscast, giving a one-note performance that elicits zero sympathy. He's so dour and serious, lacking awe for the amazing things he supposedly sees, that you don't believe he's experiencing them. Worse, he resembles a gaunt mix of David Spade and Calista Flockhart, which is distracting. He shares no chemistry with anyone on screen, a result of a performance out of sync with others. Even with a proper lead, this film is doomed by an inept director—scenes go nowhere—and a scattered, incoherent screenplay lacking character development. In the original, you got to know the Eloi and felt their terror of the Morlocks; here, they're nothing but sheep. Samantha Mumba does her best, but like everyone else, she's wasted, especially Jeremy Irons, who looks like Edgar Winter's long-lost brother. The $70M special effects are lackluster, and the film's look is poorly photographed with uninspired art direction and sets. There's nothing original or fun here. Orlando Jones is used for comic relief but is irritating, and his electrically-driven character survives in a world devoid of electricity. This is an empty, lifeless, dull, sterile, and confused affair. Didn't they already remake "Planet of the Apes"? At least that had strong performances. *SPOILER!* The final insult is the terrible, convenient ending. They barely feature the changing dress-store figures, and the time machine is a gaudy glass-n-chrome bore. Pathetic.

text:
So after years and years I finally track this film down! I was dying to see how it lived up to my memories. I distinctly remembered the shots of the ghost boy running down the mine, then waiting behind two planks of wood crossed in the mineshaft, just staring out with a pale white face. This single shot was probably the most chilling shot of my childhood, I remember chills running down my spine. Watching it now, its obviously nowhere near as scary, but quite subconsciously strange to see the same images again. If anyone wants a copy, private message me.

The story itself is fairly standard BCFF stuff. Its strange though that the message is pretty unclear this time around - there is no real moral as such (except that 'ghosts are here to help us?' or 'don't be prejudiced against ghosts!') There wasn't even a greed/capitalist angle in terms of wanting to profit from the mine. However, a massive act of irresponsibility from the captain, encouraging the two kids to actually follow the vague implications of a ghost not only into a mine, but into a new mine hole, which is totally dangerous. The captain then encourages the children to climb down a huge ladder, deep into the mines, simply because he thinks the ghost wants them too. Its also a bit odd that the ghost chooses the boy to help the trapped adults, and not just help the trapped adults direct. Oh well.
rewritten_review:
After years, I finally tracked this film down! I was eager to see if it lived up to my memories. I distinctly remembered the ghost boy running down the mine and waiting behind two crossed planks, just staring with a pale face. This shot was the most chilling of my childhood, giving me chills. Watching it now, it's not as scary but strangely nostalgic. If anyone wants a copy, PM me.

The story is standard BCFF stuff, but the message is unclear—no real moral, maybe "ghosts are here to help us" or "don't be prejudiced against ghosts!" There's no greed/capitalist angle about profiting from the mine. The captain irresponsibly encourages the kids to follow a ghost into a dangerous new mine hole. He even has them climb a huge ladder deep into the mines, just because he thinks the ghost wants it. It's odd that the ghost chooses the boy to help the trapped adults instead of helping them directly. Oh well.

text: One of the most underrated comedies. Dan Akroyd is hilarious in this over the top role; Charles Grodin gives a performance nearly as good as in "Midnight Run;" and Walter Matthau gives a superb comedic performance in this sometimes subdued, sometimes wacky film. Akroyd and Matthau have great chemistry together....
rewritten_review: One of the most underrated comedies out there, this film truly shines with its unique blend of humor and wit. Dan Aykroyd is absolutely hilarious in this over-the-top role, showcasing his exceptional comedic timing and ability to bring larger-than-life characters to the screen with ease. His performance alone makes this film worth watching, as he effortlessly embodies his character with a perfect mix of charm and absurdity. Charles Grodin, on the other hand, delivers a performance that is nearly as good as his iconic role in "Midnight Run," solidifying his reputation as a master of deadpan humor. His subtle expressions and impeccable delivery are a testament to his comedic genius, and he plays off Aykroyd beautifully, creating a dynamic and engaging on-screen duo. And then there's Walter Matthau, who gives a superb comedic performance in this film that is sometimes subdued and sometimes wonderfully wacky. Matthau's seasoned expertise in comedy is evident in every scene, as he navigates the intricacies of his character with finesse and an understated brilliance that elevates the entire film. Aykroyd and Matthau have great chemistry together, their interactions filled with a natural rhythm and camaraderie that makes their scenes a joy to watch. The film's humor ranges from clever and subtle to laugh-out-loud funny, providing a perfect balance that keeps viewers entertained from start to finish. It's a gem of a comedy that deserves far more recognition than it receives, with a cast that delivers unforgettable performances and a storyline that is both engaging and delightfully absurd. This film is a testament to the power of great comedic acting and the magic that happens when talented performers come together to create something truly special.

text: I watched, entranced and mesmerized, by the vocal and physical acting. The roles each character played were done with excellence.The lyrics,the words, every gesture, the sunrise, told it all.The movie spoke to me. It enlightened me to a different perception of a person who believes in mankind. Who believes in peace and gentle behavior. I was also held in disbelieve, by the sacrifices and human dignity was portrayed. Power without grace, is demented and without feelings. To want power at the cost of mankind, is so unbelievable. This movie made me so afraid for the people who are no longer in this world. And, it is with sadness that I think of them. I like this movie for the conversations and face expressions to it all. May this movie be blessed.
rewritten_review:
I watched, entranced and mesmerized, by the vocal and physical acting. The roles each character played were done with excellence. The lyrics, the words, every gesture, the sunrise, told it all. The movie spoke to me. It enlightened me to a different perception of a person who believes in mankind. Who believes in peace and gentle behavior. I was also held in disbelief, by the sacrifices and human dignity was portrayed. Power without grace is demented and without feelings. To want power at the cost of mankind is so unbelievable. This movie made me so afraid for the people who are no longer in this world. And, it is with sadness that I think of them. I like this movie for the conversations and face expressions to it all. May this movie be blessed.

The way the actors embodied their characters was truly a sight to behold. Each scene was meticulously crafted, and every detail contributed to an overwhelming sense of immersion. I found myself drawn into the story, feeling as though I was a part of the world being depicted on screen. The profound messages conveyed through the dialogue and the emotional depth of the performances were astonishing. The themes of hope, sacrifice, and human dignity resonated with me on a deep level, and I couldn't help but reflect on the state of the world and the people who are no longer with us. This movie serves as a poignant reminder of the importance of compassion and empathy, and it left a lasting impression on my heart. The cinematography was breathtaking, capturing the essence of every moment with precision and artistry. The combination of visual storytelling and powerful performances made for an unforgettable cinematic experience. I hope that this movie continues to reach and move audiences, inspiring them to strive for a better, more peaceful world. May this movie be blessed, and may its message echo through generations to come.

text: I first saw this movie in a queer film festival. 10 minutes after the movie ended a gay couple walked up to me and asked me whether I needed help - I was still sitting, crying like a maniac. The movie is cheesy, it's bizarre, it's over the top, it's gay - but it is amazing. I do think that every character is plausible. Everett's character is mean to a woman who only tries to help, he brutally throws his (terrible) friends out, he does have a temper, he can harm a fly, the "fly" that killed the love of his life, doubly so. Bates is a miracle, she is perfect, just like a role. A woman whose love and admiration is so strong that she even loves the homosexual lover of her idol is to me the essence of true love. I even understand Max (the husband), he is bored with his life, he's got a midlife crisis. He moves out, tries to lead an exciting life, only to realise a) that he's the really boring part in the relationship and b) that he loves his wife. I love the fact that she comes back to him in the end because I think that it gives the film the right balance between dream and reality. For in the end he's her husband and he might not be as exciting as Victor but he's real, he is the man she loves in a very down to earth way. I've watched it about 50 times and I do love this film, everything about it unconditionally. BTW, just read Rupert Everett's autobiography and UL is the only film that he talks of as one of the best films he ever made. To me it's the best film he ever made.
rewritten_review: I first saw this movie at a queer film festival. Ten minutes after it ended, a gay couple approached me as I was still sitting, crying like a maniac. The movie is cheesy, bizarre, over the top, and gay—but it is amazing. I believe every character is plausible. Everett's character is mean to a woman who only tries to help, he brutally throws his (terrible) friends out, he has a temper, and he can harm a fly, especially the "fly" that killed the love of his life. Bates is a miracle, perfect for her role. A woman whose love and admiration are so strong that she even loves the homosexual lover of her idol is the essence of true love. I understand Max (the husband); he is bored, experiencing a midlife crisis. He moves out to lead an exciting life, only to realize a) that he's the boring part of the relationship and b) that he loves his wife. I love that she comes back to him in the end, giving the film the right balance between dream and reality. In the end, he's her husband, and while he might not be as exciting as Victor, he's real, and she loves him in a down-to-earth way. I've watched it about 50 times and love everything about this film unconditionally. BTW, I just read Rupert Everett's autobiography, and UL is the only film he mentions as one of his best. To me, it's the best film he ever made.

text: Personally, I disdain The Jerry Springer Show, however, I found "Ringmaster" to be the funniest movie I've seen this year. The never-ending satire of Jerry Springer "guests" starting in the opening scene keeps you laughing throughout the movie. Despite a brief scene in which Jerry Springer makes a feeble attempt at justifying his existence, I definitely recommend this movie for sheer entertainment value.
rewritten_review: Personally, I disdain The Jerry Springer Show. However, I found "Ringmaster" to be the funniest movie I've seen this year. The never-ending satire of Jerry Springer "guests," which starts right in the opening scene, keeps you laughing throughout the entire movie. The film does an incredible job of capturing the outlandish and often absurd nature of the show, making it a hilarious watch from start to finish. Despite a brief scene in which Jerry Springer makes a feeble attempt at justifying his existence, the movie does not lose its momentum or comedic value. The humor is relentless and refreshingly unapologetic, making it a standout in the comedy genre. I definitely recommend this movie for sheer entertainment value. It's a film that doesn't take itself too seriously and invites the audience to do the same, ensuring a fun and engaging viewing experience.

text:
Vijay Krishna Acharya's 'Tashan' is a over-hyped, stylized, product. Sure its a one of the most stylish films, but when it comes to content, even the masses will reject this one. Why? The films script is as amateur as a 2 year old baby. Script is king, without a good script even the greatest director of all-time cannot do anything. Tashan is produced by the most successful production banner 'Yash Raj Films' and Mega Stars appearing in it. But nothing on earth can save you if you script is bland. Thumbs down!

Performances: Anil Kapoor, is a veteran actor. But how could he okay a role like this? Akshay Kumar is great actor, in fact he's the sole saving grace. Kareena Kapoor has never looked so hot. She looks stunning and leaves you, all stand up. Saif Ali Khan doesn't get his due in here. Sanjay Mishra, Manoj Phawa and Yashpal Sharma are wasted.

'Tashan' is a boring film. The films failure at the box office, should you keep away.
rewritten_review:
Vijay Krishna Acharya's 'Tashan' is a heavily over-hyped, stylized product that unfortunately falls short of expectations. Sure, it's one of the most stylish films in recent times, but when it comes to content, even the masses will reject this one. Why, you may ask? Well, the film's script is as amateur as a 2-year-old baby's first attempt at storytelling. It's a well-known fact in the film industry that the script is king, and without a good script, even the greatest director of all time cannot do anything to salvage the movie. 'Tashan' is produced by the most successful production banner, 'Yash Raj Films,' and features Mega Stars appearing in it. However, nothing on earth can save you if your script is bland and uninspired. Therefore, this film gets a thumbs down from me! 

When it comes to performances, let's start with Anil Kapoor. He is a veteran actor with a long list of remarkable performances under his belt. But the question remains, how could he okay a role like this? Akshay Kumar is a great actor, known for his versatility and ability to breathe life into any character he portrays. In fact, he is the sole saving grace of this film. Kareena Kapoor has never looked so hot on screen. She looks absolutely stunning and leaves you mesmerized, causing everyone to stand up and take notice. However, Saif Ali Khan doesn't quite get his due in this film, which is unfortunate given his talent. Meanwhile, talented actors like Sanjay Mishra, Manoj Phawa, and Yashpal Sharma are completely wasted in their roles, adding to the film's overall disappointment.

In conclusion, 'Tashan' is a boring film that fails to captivate its audience. The film's failure at the box office is a clear indication of its shortcomings, and it's a film that you should probably keep away from if you're looking for quality entertainment. With its lackluster script and wasted potential, 'Tashan' is a missed opportunity that leaves much to be desired.

text:
Disclaimer: During my ventures into foreign cinema, I have taken a liking to a wide variety of movies that span different genres that include horror, action, drama, comedy, and romance, to name a few. Thus, I have enjoyed the thoughtful, serious tone of dramas as well as the mindless, popcorn fun of action films. With a wide array of Chinese, Japanese, and Korean movies under my belt, I am confident in my ability to recognize bright spots in movies to appreciate and complement. Unfortunately, Ashes of Time has nothing to recognize. It is one of the worst Chinese movies I have ever seen.

To start off, this overrated swordplay epic showcases the infamous "slideshow" action sequence throughout, which is nothing more than an ultra-cheap and pathetic form of action choreography. One simply needs to show a series of close-up pictures of grimising faces, swords, legs and/or arms, and then a dead body. Bravissimo! You now have an action sequence for Ashes of Time. The problem lies not only in its poor quality but also in the fact that the scenes are so chaotic and disjointed that the viewer has no idea what the hell is going on.

The dramatic element of this film is nonexistent, as it relies on the characters telling the viewer that they love someone or hate someone instead of actually developing and showing such elements on screen, which renders all characters generic and colorless, leaving the viewer completely indifferent to their actions. In fact, the storyline itself is an absolute disaster, introducing way too many characters way too quickly with way too many plot devices. Plot complexities in films can be used very advantageously (i.e., A Tale of Two Sisters), but Ashes of Time becomes exploitative trash when it does nothing more than convolute a very simple plot for no apparently good reason.

In fact, this entire movie acts like a series of smokescreens to cover up its deficiencies. Horrible action choreography is covered up by "slideshow" tricks and chaotic camera movements. Non-existent character development is covered up by the characters overtly saying how they feel. And a thoughtless storyline is covered up by confusing the viewer with convolution.

As if this weren't bad enough, this movie was extremely boring, seeming more like 150 minutes instead of the actual 95.

Rating = A rarely given 0/5 Stars.
rewritten_review:
Disclaimer: During my ventures into foreign cinema, I have taken a liking to a wide variety of movies spanning different genres like horror, action, drama, comedy, and romance. I've enjoyed both serious dramas and mindless action films. With many Chinese, Japanese, and Korean movies under my belt, I'm confident in recognizing bright spots in films. Unfortunately, Ashes of Time has none. It's one of the worst Chinese movies I've ever seen.

This overrated swordplay epic features the infamous "slideshow" action sequence, a cheap form of choreography. It shows close-ups of grimacing faces, swords, and limbs, followed by a dead body. The scenes are chaotic and disjointed, leaving viewers confused.

The dramatic element is nonexistent, relying on characters telling viewers their feelings instead of showing them. This renders characters generic and colorless. The storyline is a disaster, introducing too many characters and plot devices too quickly. Plot complexities can be advantageous (i.e., A Tale of Two Sisters), but Ashes of Time convolutes a simple plot for no good reason.

The movie uses smokescreens to cover its deficiencies. Horrible action is masked by "slideshow" tricks and chaotic camera work. Non-existent character development is covered by characters overtly stating their feelings. A thoughtless storyline is hidden by confusing convolution.

The movie was extremely boring, feeling like 150 minutes instead of 95.

Rating = A rarely given 0/5 Stars.

text: I'm really tempted to reward "The Case of the Scorpion's Tail" with a solid 10 out of 10 rating, but that would largely be because I think Italian horror cinema of the 1970's is SO much better than the cheesy crap I usually watch. But even without an extra point for nostalgia, this is STILL a genuine masterwork and earning a high rating for its excellently convoluted story, uncanny atmosphere, blood-soaked killing sequences and superb casting choices. In my humble opinion this is actually Sergio Martino's finest giallo, and that has got to mean something, as "The Strange Vice of Mrs. Wardh", "All the Colors of the Dark", "Torso" and "Your Vice is a Locked Room and only I have the Key" are all top-notch genre achievements as well. But this film is just a tad bit superior with its ultra-compelling plot revolving on an insurance fraud gone madly out of control. Following her husband's peculiar death in a plane explosion (!), Lisa Baumer promptly becomes the suspicious owner of one million dollars and she's eager to leave the country as soon as possible. Due to the bizarre circumstances, the insurance company puts their best investigator Peter Lynch on the case and he follows her to Greece. There, Lisa becomes the target of many assaults and the case's mysteriousness increases when it turns out several people are hunting for the money. I'm always overly anxious when briefly summarizing gialli because I don't want to risk giving away essential plot elements. In "The Case of the Scorpion's Tail", the events take an abrupt and totally unexpected turn before the story is even halfway, and I certainly don't want to ruin this for you. Many red herrings follow after that, but Sergio Martino always succeeds to stay one step ahead of you and, even though not a 100% satisfying, the denouement is at least surprising. It's also a very stylish film, with imaginative camera-work and excellent music by Bruno Nicolai. Everyone' s favorite giallo muse Edwige Fenech oddly didn't make it to this cast (she stars in no less than 3 other supreme Martino gialli), but Anita Strindberg ("Lizard in a Woman's Skin", "Who Saw Her Die?") is a more than worthy replacement for her. The charismatic and hunky George Hilton is reliable as always in his role of insurance investigator and  duh  ladies' man deluxe. If you're a fan of giallo, don't wait as long as I did to WATCH THIS FILM!!!!

Even without an extra point for nostalgia, this is STILL a genuine masterwork, earning a high rating for its excellently convoluted story, uncanny atmosphere, blood-soaked killing sequences, and superb casting choices. In my humble opinion, this is actually Sergio Martino's finest giallo, which means a lot, as "The Strange Vice of Mrs. Wardh," "All the Colors of the Dark," "Torso," and "Your Vice is a Locked Room and only I have the Key" are all top-notch genre achievements. But this film is just a tad bit superior with its ultra-compelling plot revolving around an insurance fraud gone madly out of control. Due to the bizarre circumstances, the insurance company puts their best investigator, Peter Lynch, on the case, and he follows her to Greece. There, Lisa becomes the target of many assaults, and the case's mysteriousness increases when it turns out several people are hunting for the money. Everyone's favorite giallo muse, Edwige Fenech, oddly didn't make it to this cast (she stars in no less than three other supreme Martino gialli), but Anita Strindberg ("Lizard in a Woman's Skin," "Who Saw Her Die?") is a more than worthy replacement. text:
Publicity for this film suggests that it is shocking and sensational. Well, we opera lovers see some strange sights in opera houses so we are not shocked by the Duke of Mantua urinating during his reprise of La Donna è Mobile, nor is it sensational to see Gilda sing Caro Nome in the bath. It is just crass and boring. What stands out about this film is its lack of imagination. Director Corina Van Eijk sets the Duke's palace in a seedy swimming pool. In fact, he is not the Duke, he is just a character named Duka, so it's difficult to see why he has lots of hangers-on and his own jester, Rigoletto. Rigoletto lives in a council flat that is furnished with the orange sofa and decorated in the spotted wallpaper that is de rigeur among avant-garde directors.The Duke's, sorry Duka's heavies ride around on motor scooters (Yawn).

Concepts imposed on an opera like this can produce unexpected, and unintentional humour. What can we make of the fact that Gilda has a maid, even though she lives in a council flat.? When the call goes out that Monterone is being taken to prison we see him being marched out of the swimming pool by two attendants in pink shorts. One imagines that he is going to be charged with urinating in a public swimming pool.

It was common for opera films to be lip-synced 20 years ago but there is just no excuse for it today. A dubbed opera is like soft porn. You don't believe in what is happening because the performers are not making enough effort. The actress in Gilda's role does not seem to have learned her lines properly. She barely moves her lips when she is supposed to be singing. When she sings Caro Nome in the bath she lies back with her legs slightly parted. It is difficult to tell which orifice the sound is supposed to be emanating from. The Duke, later caps this by singing while engaging in cunnilingus with Maddalena, giving a new meaning to the phrase yodelling in the canyon.

The ambiance of the sound never seems right with the orchestra sometimes sounding as though it is being played through a transistor radio. Fairly slow, rumpity-tumpity tempi are preferred so that the overall effect is of a karaoke in your local pub.

This is a film of a production by Opera Spanga. Spanga is a village in Friesland in the Netherlands. They normally perform in a tent in a field. If I had been watching this performance in a tent in a field in Friesland I would have been fairly indulgent. By filming this production and giving it a worldwide audience, the villagers also hold themselves open to worldwide ridicule.
rewritten_review:
Publicity for this film suggests it's shocking and sensational, but opera lovers are not surprised by the Duke of Mantua urinating during La Donna è Mobile or Gilda singing Caro Nome in the bath—it's just crass and boring. The film lacks imagination, with director Corina Van Eijk setting the Duke's palace in a seedy swimming pool. The Duke, now just Duka, inexplicably has hangers-on and a jester, Rigoletto. Rigoletto's council flat is furnished with an orange sofa and spotted wallpaper, typical of avant-garde directors. Duka's heavies ride motor scooters (Yawn). 

Imposed concepts can be unintentionally humorous. Gilda has a maid despite living in a council flat. Monterone is marched from the pool by attendants in pink shorts, seemingly charged with public urination. Lip-syncing in opera films is outdated and unconvincing. The actress playing Gilda barely moves her lips, and during Caro Nome in the bath, the sound's source is questionable. The Duke sings while engaging in cunnilingus with Maddalena, redefining "yodelling in the canyon."

The sound ambiance is off, with the orchestra often resembling a transistor radio. Slow, karaoke-like tempi dominate. This film from Opera Spanga, a village in Friesland, Netherlands, typically performed in a tent, invites worldwide ridicule by reaching a global audience.

text: I really liked this movie. I have seen several Gene Kelly flicks and this is one of his best. I would actually put it above his more famous American in Paris. Sometimes it seems the story gets lost in Gene Kelly movies to the wonderful dance and song numbers, but not in this movie. It is definitely worth renting.
rewritten_review: I really liked this movie. I've had the pleasure of watching several Gene Kelly flicks over the years, and I must say, this one stands out as one of his best. It's a true gem in his filmography. In fact, I would actually put it above his more famous film, An American in Paris, which is quite a statement considering the acclaim that movie has received over the years. One of the things I often notice in Gene Kelly movies is how sometimes the story seems to get lost amidst the wonderful dance and song numbers. However, that's not the case in this movie. The narrative is engaging and complements the musical elements beautifully, making it a well-rounded cinematic experience. It's a film where the storytelling and the musical performances are perfectly balanced, allowing viewers to appreciate both aspects fully. It is definitely worth renting, as it offers not just entertainment but also a showcase of Gene Kelly's incredible talent in both dance and acting. If you're a fan of classic musicals or simply looking for a delightful movie to watch, this one is a must-see.

text:
Why oh why do people take good material and feel the need to change it some how? Having read the book on which this film is allegedly based a couple of years ago, I can say that there is little if anything from the original book. I went into this film with low expectations - i knew it would have a crappy telemovie feel to it - but it even failed to meet these.

This is not a prequel - the only relationship it has with the original is the name. This is not the story of Carlito Brigante, it is the story of a totally different character who's been given the same name. They have just totally spat in the face of every Carlito's Way fan out there; adding insult to injury by casting Luis Guzman, who plays a crucial character in the original movie, in a different role.

What's most disappointing is that now that this film has been made no other film will be made addressing the original, untouched material of the book Carlito's Way - something I really would have liked to have seen. I felt the same way about Chopper - they have four books as well as interviews worth of fantastic non-fictional material and could have made a brilliant biography of Australia's most feared underworld figure, instead they made a ho-hum film about a deranged but strangely pathetic small time crook (though Eric Bana's performance was spot-on). Now we will never get to see Carlito's real initial rise and fall.

The three stars is because, looking at it purely as a stand-alone flick, it is not so appalling - there are some decent performances (Jay Hernandez is no Carlito but he could be good in other roles) and the story is not too bad. Even Puffy Combs suits his role. But they totally misunderstand the nature of the underworld at that time (I am a bit of a crime-non-fiction buff)- something which the original film and the books got right (having been written by then attorney and now judge Edwin Torres).

The fact is though, it's not a stand alone - it's perhaps the most disappointing prequel ever filmed.
rewritten_review:
Why do people feel the need to change good material? Having read the book on which this film is allegedly based, I can say there's little from the original book. I went into this film with low expectations, knowing it would have a crappy telemovie feel, but it even failed to meet these.
