They've spat in the face of every Carlito's Way fan, adding insult by casting Luis Guzman, who plays a crucial character in the original movie, in a different role.

What's most disappointing is that now no other film will be made addressing the original, untouched material of the book Carlito's Way—something I'd have liked to see. I felt the same about Chopper: they had fantastic non-fictional material and could have made a brilliant biography, but made a ho-hum film instead. Now we won't see Carlito's real rise and fall.

The three stars are because, as a stand-alone flick, it's not appalling—there are decent performances (Jay Hernandez is no Carlito, but could be good in other roles) and the story isn't too bad. Even Puffy Combs suits his role. But they misunderstand the nature of the underworld at that time—something the original film and books got right.

The fact is, it's not a stand-alone—it's perhaps the most disappointing prequel ever filmed.

text: From start to finish, this 1926 classic two reeler from the Hal Roach Studios seems to sum up what was fun about the 20's. It stars the now forgotten comic genius, Charley Chase and was directed by the legendary Leo McCarey, who was unknown then but would earn his keep with Roach and graduate to greener pastures in the 30's and 40's. Recently released onto video and disc, this is one of the ten best examples of silent screen comedy and should be seen by audiences of all ages. Although today his star has virtually diminished, Charley Chase was considered the leader in the short subject comedy field in the waning years of the silents. He helped the careers of Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy before they were brought together as a team, Leo McCarey and a host of other talents. It is a shame that he is all but remembered today. Check out this little gem of a film. Once you do, you will be seeking out other films from this classic comic. He had his hand in over 300 films and many of them survive. Rediscover this lost giant of a film from a bygone era and its giant star.
rewritten_review: This 1926 classic two-reeler from Hal Roach Studios captures the fun of the 20's, starring the now forgotten comic genius Charley Chase and directed by the legendary Leo McCarey. Recently released on video and disc, it is a top example of silent screen comedy for all ages. Although largely forgotten today, Charley Chase was a leader in short subject comedy during the silent era, helping the careers of Stan Laurel, Oliver Hardy, Leo McCarey, and others. It's a shame he's barely remembered now. Watch this gem of a film, and you'll want to discover more from this classic comic. Chase was involved in over 300 films, many of which survive. Rediscover this lost giant of a film and its star.

text:
I am not so much like Love Sick as I image. Finally the film express sexual relationship of Alex, kik, Sandu their triangle love were full of intenseness, frustration and jealous, at last, Alex waked up and realized that they would not have result and future.Ending up was sad.

The director Tudor Giurgiu was in AMC theatre on Sunday 12:00PM on 08/10/06, with us watched the movie together. After the movie he told the audiences that the purposed to create this film which was to express the sexual relationships of Romanian were kind of complicate.

On my point of view sexual life is always complicated in everywhere, I don't feel any particular impression and effect from the movie. The love proceeding of Alex and Kiki, and Kiki and her brother Sandu were kind of next door neighborhood story.

The two main reasons I don't like this movie are, firstly, the film didn't told us how they started to fall in love? Sounds like after Alex moved into the building which Kiki was living, then two girls are fall in love. It doesn't make sense at all. How a girl would fall in love with another girl instead of a man. Too much fragments, you need to image and connect those stories by your mind. Secondly, The whole film didn't have a scene of Alex and Kik's sexual intercourse, that 's what I was waiting for. However, it still had some parts were deserved to recommend. The "ear piercing " part was kind of interesting. Alex was willing to suffer the pain of ear piercing to appreciate kik's love. That was a touching scene which gave you a little idea of their love. Also, the scene of they were lying in the soccer field, the conversation express their loves were truthful and passionate.
rewritten_review:
I am not as fond of Love Sick as I imagined. The film explores the intense, frustrating, and jealous sexual relationship between Alex, Kiki, and Sandu. Eventually, Alex realizes their relationship has no future, ending on a sad note. Director Tudor Giurgiu was at the AMC theatre on 08/10/06, sharing that the film aimed to portray the complexity of Romanian sexual relationships. I find sexual life universally complicated, and the film did not leave a strong impression on me. The love story between Alex and Kiki, and Kiki and her brother Sandu felt like a neighborhood tale. 

My main issues with the film are: firstly, it doesn't explain how Alex and Kiki fell in love—it seems sudden and unrealistic. Secondly, the film lacks a scene showing Alex and Kiki's sexual intimacy, which I anticipated. However, some parts are noteworthy, like the "ear piercing" scene, where Alex endures pain to show her love for Kiki, and the heartfelt conversation on the soccer field.

text:
I imagine Victorian literature slowly sinking into the mire of the increasingly distant past, pulled down by the weight of its under-skirts. Along comes television: at its best, it has a redemptive power, and with dramatisations like those the BBC produce so finely, Victorian literature gets a new stab at life. The religious themes, the moral overtones, may be increasingly ill at ease in a world no longer easily shocked, and acquainted with cohabitation, affairs and domestic violence. But those old, well-told stories have enduring power, and this is one's a hidden gem.

It's hard to gauge today just how forceful, feminist and extraordinary Ann Bronte's masterpiece, "The Tenant of Wildfell Hall", actually was. Emerging from the primeval slime of restrictive corsets  bodily, mental, societal  her heroine, Helen Huntingdon, escapes a miserable marriage, flees brutality and alcoholism, braves not only her abusive husband's fury, but society's pinched intolerance and malicious gossip, to wreak change in her life. She pays a price; but retains her self-respect; she falls in love along the way; she emerges battered but victorious, and strong. I just love watching women like these on screen.

The actors are superb  the best Brits have to offer. The love story is beautifully handled, with real passion and feeling by well-matched actors. Tara Fitzgerald inhabits every aspect of the complicated heroine, and as has been said here by other reviewers, no less sharply defined and beautiful a face could survive that petrifying hairstyle. Toby Stephens, striking sparks off her, contributes just the right combination of headstrong, handsome youth and passionate, yearning vulnerability. Rupert Graves (one of my favourite British actors ever) enjoys himself as the charismatic villain (so much so that you're almost with him at the end. No one's perfect). The supporting cast ably create a world into which you sink without feeling that coarse compromises have been made to modern tastes, and without having felt preached to. Another BBC classic, highly recommended: this is how romantic literature should be dramatised.
rewritten_review:
Victorian literature may seem distant, weighed down by its past, but television, especially BBC adaptations, breathes new life into it. Despite modern discomfort with religious themes and moral overtones, stories like Ann Brontë's "The Tenant of Wildfell Hall" endure. Brontë's forceful, feminist masterpiece portrays Helen Huntingdon escaping a brutal marriage, defying societal norms, and emerging strong. Watching such women on screen is a delight.

The cast is superb, showcasing the best of British talent. Tara Fitzgerald captures the complexity of Helen, while Toby Stephens brings a compelling mix of youth and vulnerability. Rupert Graves shines as the charismatic villain, and the supporting cast creates an immersive world without pandering to modern tastes. This BBC classic is a masterclass in romantic literature adaptation, and it's highly recommended.

text:
The Other Boleyn Girl - not to be confused with the book it claims to be based upon. This movie is not even close to a faithful adaptation. I could understand them changing or elaborating on a few things. The book is not perfection, but it was well-written and became very popular. I could understand if the BBC wanted to make this a little more faithful to what actually happened, who Anne Boleyn really was - but it's not even close to being historically accurate either. It's just fluff. Mindless, made-up fluff. A real shame.

To begin with, the writer and director seemed to think it was a good idea to setup the story like it was a reality TV show. Seriously. They have the Boleyns sitting in front of the camera, confessing how they REALLY feel about what's happening in their lives. Anne Boleyn sits in a confessional (not the church kind, the Real World kind) and chooses what she wants to tell and what she wants to just sit and smile about. She looks stupid having to use such a modern cinematic device in a film set in the 1500s. It's "The Real World: Tudor England!"

Jodhi May is a very good actress and after 'The Aristocrats' and 'A Turn of the Screw' I was becoming a real fan of hers. But she should never have been cast as Anne. Actually I think she would have been a better Mary. Natascha McElhone was a poor choice. She's a good actress, sure, but she has very modern features and does not appear convincing in period costume. (Honestly, I spent the first half of the film trying to figure out if she was "that girl" from 'The Truman Show.' She was.) She's also too old to play the teen-aged Mary so for some unknown reason they made Mary the oldest of the sisters. It makes no sense, I know. It's like the BBC seemed to forget that these people actually lived. They're twisting the story around and making things up left and right. I feel ridiculous having to correct the BBC on historical inaccuracies, but REALLY!

Apart from the two sisters the rest of the cast was actually very well chosen. Steven Mackintosh struck me as a brilliant choice for George, and his casting was the real reason I decided to seek out this movie. Big mistake. He does a great job, sure, but he's hardly in this. How can anyone pretend they're adapting The Other Boleyn Girl and hardly mention George Boleyn? That's just absurd. Philip Glenister was another very good casting decision, but yet again, was hardly in the finished product.

The real problem with this is the script. There's just no getting around that. It's bad. It's really, really bad. It's too melodramatic and not engaging. Anne is portrayed as an air-head, Mary as the ringleader, and George as the follower. Mary's first husband is hardly mentioned, her relationship with the king is never explained - they simply do not tell the story Phillippa Gregory wrote. The whole thing comes across as a great big waste. I have no desire to see this thing a second time. I guess I'll just have to read the book again and hope that the Natalie Portman version due out next year will be much better.

*Note: As of this writing, the only way of obtaining this miniseries in the USA is on the last disc of the miniseries 'The Six Wives of Henry VIII.' That's a great miniseries but can cost $50 to $60 and that's way to much to spend if you're just looking for this piece of garbage.

text: So when Bob and Marion Boxletter see a guy at a hotel, Marion believes it is her long lost brother Brian, but when she approaches him he appears to be someone else just with the exact same face. Marion manages to get his fingerprints and takes it to the police and when the identity is confirmed that it was in fact her brother Brian she and Bob leave for New York after tracing his whereabouts. They get a hold of Brian, but still he doesn't know what they are talking about, but all the couple really want to know is where Brian has their 8 maybe 9 year old son Joey... and even when they see Joey he doesn't know them either. The plot thickens and they find themselves one day thinking that they are someone else as well. Experiments made out on people only to make the perfect assassins yet the question of why they would bother putting Bob and Marion in the same building as each other is beyond me. Personally Gregory Harrison played his 2 parts great, but I have no clue what was wrong with the other actors, they seemed bored and lost. 3 out of 10, a little suspense yes but that's it.
rewritten_review: Marion Boxletter believes she spots her long-lost brother Brian at a hotel, but he denies knowing her. She gets his fingerprints, and the police confirm it's Brian. She and Bob head to New York to find him, hoping to locate their missing son Joey, who also doesn't recognize them. The plot thickens as they start questioning their own identities, revealing experiments to create perfect assassins. The reason for placing Bob and Marion together remains unclear. Gregory Harrison shines in his dual role, but the other actors seem bored and lost. A little suspense, but overall, just 3 out of 10.

text:
OLIVER TWIST was to have controversy as well as success following it after Dickens published it in 1837. His picture of life in the urban ghettos was something shocking and new, and his making the central figures of the novel include criminals was another innovation.

One day he was walking in London and passed a young woman he had been friendly with. He said hello, but she was rather stiff with him. He could not understand this. A few days later they met again, and he asked what he had done to upset her. "Well, if you must know, I did not like your last novel.", she said. "Really, everyone else thinks highly of it." He was puzzled: "What's wrong with it?" "Oh, Charles," she said, "I'm Jewish. How could you make up such a character like Fagin?!" He had not expected this: "Well...you know that trial last year of Ikey Solomon, the thief trainer. He's a model for Fagin and he was Jewish."

Dickens found that did not settle things. "Yes," she replied, "He got what he deserved. But Charles, they did not call him "Solomon the Jew" like you call Fagin "the Jew"! Moreover, Solomon did not plan a murder. Fagin does." Dickens had to admit that he might have gotten carried away. He left thinking about what she said.

Oliver Twist was published in several editions. Dickens tried to improve on Fagin a bit. Then he got an idea. He reworked the chapter called "Fagin's Last Night Alive", showing the fears in the man as he faced hanging. He also added some additional details.

He let his female friend know about his resolve to change Fagin. A day or so later he met her at a friend's house. She looked at him as though he was crazy. "Didn't you like the changes?", he asked. "Charles, what changes - he's still a vile villain called "the Jew"!", she replied. "Yes, I did keep those in, but didn't you see how frightened he was in the death cell in prison." The young woman had noticed this, but felt that he was so vile he deserved to be suffering such fears. "Ah...then I was right about that...and did you see the little details I added?", he asked. "What details?", she replied. "When you first see Fagin now he is cooking himself dinner...you read that?", Dickens looked at her expecting a sign of recognition. Instead the lady looked confused. "I read he was at the fireplace, but I must have skimmed the passage." Dickens smiled as though he was brilliant, "He is cooking a pork sausage for his dinner." "A what!"she exclaimed. "He's eating pork, my dear...see - he's not a good Jew!" His friend looked at him, shook her head, and to his dismay left their friend's house. She didn't speak to him for years.

Dickens never totally shook off his own bigotries, but the situation did lead to a partial attempt at amends in his last completed novel. In OUR MUTUAL FRIEND (1865) he has a minor character, Mr. Riah, who is used by an unscrupulous landlord to collect high rents from poor tenants. The landlord figures that Mr. Riah will be blamed because he is Jewish.

But Mr. Riah is a good man. He is a very good man. He is a very, very, very, very good man - so good as to be unbelievable. If Fagin saw Mr. Riah in action he'd probably chase him away with a stick.

The anti-Semitic image of Fagin lingers to this day. It is a measure of Dickens' genius as a writer that the novel overcomes it. However, in presenting the story on film it still causes problems for screenplay writers and directors: how, after the Holocaust, can one do a film treatment of a worthy novel without inflaming bigotry? David Lean showed how by having Alec Guiness appear in one or two scenes showing a human side and in confronting a mob at the end with true dignity. Sir Carol Reed, in his musical version of the novel did it better yet, due to a rewrite in the original musical's script.

OLIVER had been made into a West End musical hit in the middle 1960s, and then taken to Broadway where it was again a hit. With a wonderful score by Lionel Bart, including "Food Glorious Food", "I Am Reviewing the Situation", "Consider Yourself", "Boy For Sale", "Who Will Buy", "As Long As He Needs Me", it deserved it's success. Reed did well in his casting the roles, including his nephew Oliver Reed as Sykes, Ron Moody as Fagin, Mark Lester as Oliver, Jack Wild as the Dodger, Shani Wallis as Nancy, and Harry Secombe as Mr. Bumble. There had been no big musical successes in Hollywood for a decade - the last musical to win the Best Picture Oscar had been GIGI in 1958. OLIVER won it in 1968.

And Fagin - how to handle the eternal problem of the caricature? Well in the musical Fagin is not captured, tried and executed for the murder that is committed. After all, even Lean showed Fagin tried to control his confederate in his actions. But here Fagin realizes that he is getting too old to depend on this kind of chancy life. Although he loses his treasures (those stolen items he kept because he knew their value, and admired their beauty), he decides he can reform. He is allowed to do so, accompanied by his faithful acolyte, the Artful Dodger. I don't think Dickens would have appreciated the change (his female friend might have), but a modern audience certainly accepts it as fitting.
rewritten_review:
OLIVER TWIST sparked controversy and success after its 1837 publication. Dickens' depiction of urban ghettos and criminals was groundbreaking. One day, he encountered a Jewish female friend who criticized his portrayal of Fagin. Dickens explained Fagin was inspired by Ikey Solomon, a Jewish thief. She countered that Solomon wasn't labeled "the Jew," nor did he plan murder. Dickens reconsidered and revised the "Fagin's Last Night Alive" chapter to humanize him. He added a detail of Fagin cooking pork, implying he wasn't a good Jew. His friend was unimpressed, and they parted ways for years.

Dickens' biases lingered, but he partially redeemed himself with Mr. Riah in OUR MUTUAL FRIEND (1865), a good Jewish character. Nonetheless, Fagin's anti-Semitic image persists. Dickens' genius helps the novel endure, but film adaptations face challenges post-Holocaust. David Lean and Sir Carol Reed addressed this in their adaptations. Reed's 1968 musical OLIVER, based on a successful West End show, won the Best Picture Oscar. It featured a stellar cast and altered Fagin's fate, allowing him to reform. While Dickens might not approve, modern audiences find it fitting.

text: I didn't understand what that line meant... I do now. I didn't really want to see Dirty Dancing either. I'd rented it out but never watched it - and today I did. And I thought it was a really fun, great movie that makes you want to get up and dance. Alright, it was cheesy at times... but it's still a great movie. I can't believe Jennifer Grey was 27 in this movie - my friend and I thought she looked about 18 or 19 - 20 at the most. I guess this is attributed to her acting talent. And she did really look awkward at times. Patrick Swayze is also very good, but you can tell he is in his thirties and seems a bit old. Nevertheless, still very good. I love 80s songs so it really struck a chord with me, and the love story (yes, I'm a romantic) was so wonderfully done. I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. Exceeded my expectations!
rewritten_review: I didn't understand what that line meant when I first heard it, but I do now. I didn't really want to see Dirty Dancing either. I'd rented it out but never watched it until today— and today I did. And I'm so glad I finally did because it turned out to be a really fun, great movie that makes you want to get up and dance. Alright, it was cheesy at times, but it's still a great movie overall. I can't believe Jennifer Grey was 27 in this movie—my friend and I thought she looked about 18 or 19, maybe 20 at the most. I guess this youthful appearance is attributed to her acting talent and the way she carried herself throughout the film. She really did look awkward at times, which added authenticity to her character. Patrick Swayze is also very good in his role, but you can tell he is in his thirties and seems a bit old for the part. Nevertheless, he was still very good and brought a lot to the film. I love 80s songs, so it really struck a chord with me, and the love story (yes, I'm a romantic) was so wonderfully done. The romance was touching and beautifully portrayed, making it easy to get emotionally invested in the characters' journey. I thoroughly enjoyed this movie from start to finish and found it exceeded my expectations by far!

text: A bus drops off a nameless man outside a run-down Standard Oil gas station in the middle of nowhere. We never learn where the bus came from, or why he is on it, or who he even is. Why is he the only passenger? Is he a prisoner? Is he the "bothersome man" referred to in the title of the movie? Has he died and gone to heaven, or hell? Like our man, we don't get a chance to stop and wonder. He is met by a gatekeeper of sorts and shuttled off to a nondescript city. From day one, all the choices are made for him. An apartment has been rented, a job has been found, an office assigned. In fact, his life is not entirely unlike life in the virtual reality of corporate cubicles and suburban condos. Women are heartless, dinner parties are a drag, office jobs suck. But some pieces don't fit the puzzle. Silently efficient, gray-clad goons roam the streets. Are they some sort of paramedics, or the secret police? And why are there no children? Is the story even set in the real world? Whenever we think we might be getting some answers, new mysteries unfold. "The Bothersome Man" leaves you half relieved that it's over, half wanting more. I hope they make it into a computer game soon.
rewritten_review: A nameless man is dropped off by a bus at a run-down Standard Oil gas station in the middle of nowhere. We never know where the bus came from, why he's on it, or who he is. Why is he the only passenger? Is he a prisoner? Is he the "bothersome man" from the movie title? Has he died and gone to heaven or hell? Like him, we don't get a chance to ponder. He's met by a gatekeeper and taken to a nondescript city. From day one, all choices are made for him: an apartment rented, a job found, an office assigned. His life resembles the virtual reality of corporate cubicles and suburban condos. Women are heartless, dinner parties a drag, office jobs suck. Some pieces don't fit. Silent, gray-clad goons roam the streets. Are they paramedics or secret police? Why are there no children? Is this even the real world? As answers seem close, new mysteries arise. "The Bothersome Man" leaves you half relieved it's over, half wanting more. I hope they make it into a computer game soon.

text:
Truly awful. Obviously an attempt to cash in on the Star Wars craze, but there's no excuse for this insipid piece of garbage. The storyline gets lost before the middle, the characters are forgettable and the kid is such a non-talent that all he does is pose for the camera. An alien planet they land on is actually the Naval stockyards in Long Beach, California.

This movie actually made me physically ill watching it.

Roger Corman has made some good, some bad movies in his career, but there's no excuse for this one.

0/10 - IMDb won't let you score a zero.
rewritten_review:
Truly awful. Obviously an attempt to cash in on the Star Wars craze, but there's no excuse for this insipid piece of garbage. The storyline gets lost before the middle, the characters are forgettable and the kid is such a non-talent that all he does is pose for the camera. An alien planet they land on is actually the Naval stockyards in Long Beach, California. 

The plot, if you can even call it that, meanders aimlessly, leaving viewers confused and disinterested. Any attempt at character development is completely absent, making it impossible to care about what happens to them. The kid, who seems to be the central figure in this mess, lacks any charisma or acting ability, reducing his performance to little more than posing awkwardly in front of the camera. It's painfully obvious that he's out of his depth, and it's baffling that he was cast in the first place.

Adding to the disappointment is the setting of the alien planet, which is laughably depicted as the Naval stockyards in Long Beach, California. The lack of creativity and effort in creating a believable alien world is staggering. It's as if the filmmakers didn't even bother to try, assuming the audience wouldn't notice or care. This lack of attention to detail further illustrates the laziness that permeates the entire production.

Watching this movie actually made me physically ill. The combination of poor storytelling, forgettable characters, and lackluster settings created an experience that was truly unpleasant. It's hard to imagine how anyone involved thought this was a worthwhile project. 

Roger Corman has made some good, some bad movies in his career, but there's no excuse for this one. His involvement in this travesty is disappointing, especially considering his reputation for producing entertaining low-budget films. This particular effort falls far short of even the lowest expectations.

0/10 - IMDb won't let you score a zero.

text:
After viewing the film, I was truly shocked to see such a high rating on IMDb.

'The Fantastic Mr. Fox' is an adaption of a beloved children's classic, portraying the story of the smooth, slick protagonist Mr. Fox (or 'Foxy') as he attempts one 'last' heist to steal from the dreaded Boggins, Bunce and Bean. That's right, one short, one fat, one lean, or however it goes.

I don't quite know where to start with my criticism.

Well, I'm in my late teens and was never a fan of Roald Dahl, but I like his material well enough, having read a few of his books as a child and seen Matilda and Charlie and the Chocolate Factory over and over again. This film, however, struggles for an audience. Is it aimed at children? Adults? I'm still unsure! Many of the 'jokes' would bore a child, especially as Mr. Fox visits a lawyer for example, or complains about being poor. Also, an audience of (I'm assuming) children is expected to sympathise with a character who steals and kills chickens. I'm all for the food chain, but you practically see Mr. Fox biting down on their necks! Surely that's a bit much? And also, the plot... well, it's kind of boring. I stayed only with the hope of it getting better, but instead I just got more and more annoyed at Mr Fox and his son Ash for making stupid decisions.

The humour, meanwhile, falls flat. I laughed only once or twice, even though I specifically recognised attempts at jokes. I think part of it is that the voice acting is so incredibly flat and monotoned. The voice actors have no sense of comic timing, instead aiming for the subtlety of humour that only works with certain mediums. George Clooney aims to portray Mr. Fox as charming and sleek, but his voice has no character. Meryl Streep shows no emotion, I didn't even realise Bill Murray had a role until the end credits, and Ash, twelve-years old in fox-years, sounds like he's about 30.

I love animation, particularly stop motion, but the visual style actually creeped me out a little bit. Characters are tall, spindly and lacking any warmth of design. They move with very little fluidity and often the animation is jerky and strange. There is also a distinctive 'mixed medium' feel, as 2D components are added in sporadically and unsuccessfully. Characters look straight at the camera and talked; it was very awkward. There was one or two moments when Kylie looked straight at the camera, didn't move and had swirls on his eyeballs. It actually freaked me out.

Fantastic Mr. Fox had so much potential. Lots of people still seem to like it - look at the reviews. Maybe it just wasn't for me.

text:
*SPOILERS AHEAD*

Great WrestleManias were still a few years away. But this one was certainly good, with lots of good matches, and one great match.

Demolition was always at their best at WrestleMania. I'm glad their last WM hoorah (I refuse to include the other version) was a win over the Colossal Connection. I liked the gag of Andre never tagging in.

Few fans know that this was the first time anyone ever beat Mr. Perfect. For some reason, Brutus Beefcake's feat was never recognized. Or the fact that he did it pretty easily.

The Hart Foundation's win over the Bolsheviks was the shortest in WM history, including the 24/9 second match between King Kong Bundy and S.D. Jones.

I'm glad Jake and DiBiase got to fight at WrestleMania. This made up for the fact that the feud had to be put on hold for so long.

I expected the Big Bossman-Akeem feud to heat up, but the Bossman just clobbered him. As good as Bossman was as a heel, he was just great as a face. He was always intense and obviously loved his job.

If the Warrior just had a better work ethic and maybe tried to learn to wrestle, he would have been a great WWF champion.

Worth a watch, especially since the boring matches are too short to complain about. And the tag team matches are all very exciting.
rewritten_review: Great WrestleManias were still a few years away, but this one was good with lots of good matches and one great match. Demolition was at their best at WrestleMania, and their last WM hoorah was a win over the Colossal Connection. I liked the gag of Andre never tagging in. Few fans know this was the first time anyone ever beat Mr. Perfect, but Brutus Beefcake's feat was never recognized, even though he did it easily. The Hart Foundation's win over the Bolsheviks was the shortest in WM history, even shorter than the King Kong Bundy and S.D. Jones match. I'm glad Jake and DiBiase got to fight at WrestleMania, making up for their feud being put on hold. I expected the Big Bossman-Akeem feud to heat up, but Bossman clobbered him. Bossman was great as a face, always intense and loving his job. If the Warrior had a better work ethic and learned to wrestle, he would have been a great WWF champion. Worth a watch, especially since the boring matches are too short to complain about, and the tag team matches are exciting.

text: You get an hour and a half of braindead i have to save the world action all the way, one liners and a woman somewhere in the equation. This time he plays a guy who help people in the witness protection program. to quote the cover of the movie. He erases their past to save their future. Woppi, this have to be cool :) I bet younger people will like it though but it is a little over the top for my taste. And the one liners are really something else, and i don't mean that in a good way. After killing a crocodile he manage to say. "you're luggage" If you are in the right mood you may enjoy the movie. And as far as braindead action go, this is not very bad. But almost before the movie starts you know exactly what is going to happen. But if you like these kind of movies, you will probably enjoy this one. I rate this movie 4
rewritten_review:
You get an hour and a half of braindead, high-octane, save-the-world action all the way through, complete with punchy one-liners and, of course, a woman somewhere in the equation. This time, the lead plays a character who helps people in the witness protection program. To quote the cover of the movie, "He erases their past to save their future." Woppi, this has to be cool, right? I bet younger audiences will enjoy it, though it is a little over the top for my taste. The one-liners are really something else, and I don't mean that in a good way. After he kills a crocodile, he somehow manages to say, "You're luggage." If you're in the right mood, you might enjoy the movie. As far as braindead action flicks go, this one is not very bad. However, almost before the movie even starts, you know exactly what is going to happen. But if you’re a fan of these kinds of movies, you will probably enjoy this one. I rate this movie a 4. 

The film provides a relentless ride through a series of explosive set pieces and adrenaline-pumping scenes, where logic takes a backseat to spectacle. The formulaic plot is something you can see coming from a mile away, with its predictable twists and turns that have been done countless times before. Yet, there's an undeniable charm in its simplicity and dedication to delivering non-stop action. The protagonist is larger than life, embodying the classic hero archetype with unwavering determination and a knack for survival against all odds. His journey is peppered with moments that are both absurd and entertaining, pushing the boundaries of believability while keeping viewers engaged. The supporting characters, including the obligatory female presence, add layers to the narrative, though their roles often fall into familiar tropes. Despite its shortcomings, the movie's commitment to its genre is commendable, offering a straightforward, no-nonsense approach to storytelling that appeals to fans of action-packed cinema. The film doesn’t pretend to be anything other than what it is—a thrill ride designed to entertain with its over-the-top scenarios and gravity-defying stunts.

text:
This is an extremely dense, somber, and complicated film that unravels quite slowly, revealing excruciating detail, like the attention paid in a novel, and watching this film "IS" like watching a novel unfold. While I didn't care for the narrator, as I felt he was out of balance with the rest of the performances, this film features some of the best ensemble acting I have ever seen, and the lead, Summer Phoenix, is fabulous. Her innocence and naivete some might find implausible, sort of a cross between Cinderella and Alice in Wonderland. I can buy that critique, but she's still fabulous, partially because she's unlike anything I've ever seen before.

This film is unbelievably beautiful, filmed by Eric Gautier, and part of what is so unique about this film is how it doesn't ever show what you'd expect. It's always surprising, and despite it's length, the film never reveals more than it needs to. At 163 minutes, it's extremely concise, to a fault, I'd say, which is one of the wonders of this film. It's filled with brief moments which are simply stunning, some of the best you're likely to see all year, and all these moments add up in the end to an extraordinary film experience. The family moments are unique, Ian Holm is brilliant, and what this film has to say about the theater hasn't been seen in films since Cassavetes' "Opening Night," or perhaps Chaplin's "Limelight." But, believe it or not, this film is much "less" conventional. I never knew where this film was going, and now, having seen it, it still has multiple possibilities. This is a powerful, incredibly provocative film.
rewritten_review: This dense, somber, and complicated film unravels slowly, like a novel. While I didn't care for the narrator, feeling he was out of balance with the rest of the performances, the ensemble acting is some of the best I've seen. Summer Phoenix, the lead, is fabulous, embodying an innocence some might find implausible—a cross between Cinderella and Alice in Wonderland. Despite critiques, she's unlike anything I've seen before. The film, beautifully shot by Eric Gautier, is always surprising and never reveals more than necessary. At 163 minutes, it's concise to a fault, filled with stunning brief moments that add up to an extraordinary experience. Ian Holm is brilliant, and its commentary on theater hasn't been seen since Cassavetes' "Opening Night" or Chaplin's "Limelight," yet it's much less conventional. I never knew where it was going, and even now, it holds multiple possibilities. This is a powerful, incredibly provocative film.

text:
I still can't believe how bad this movie was. If I wasn't a massochist I don't know if I would have survived the viewing. It looks like it cost about $1000 to make, but it wasn't the money that brought them down. The acting was horrid - not just bad, 3rd graders could have read the lines better. Second, the only other reason to watch this kind of movie is the skin, and that is sorely lacking in this flick. We don't even get to see the more attractive chicas in the buff.

Ahh well, better luck next time eh?
rewritten_review:
I still can't believe how bad this movie was. If I wasn't a masochist, I don't know if I would have survived the viewing. It looks like it cost about $1000 to make, but it wasn't the money that brought them down. The acting was horrid - not just bad, 3rd graders could have read the lines better. It's astonishing how a film can fail so spectacularly in this department. The actors seemed completely disconnected from the material, as if they were reading the script for the first time during filming. Their lack of chemistry and conviction was almost impressive in its own right, creating an atmosphere that was awkward and uncomfortable to watch. Each line delivery was worse than the last, as if the cast was in a competition to see who could be the least convincing.

Second, the only other reason to watch this kind of movie is the skin, and that is sorely lacking in this flick. We don't even get to see the more attractive chicas in the buff. This was a surprising oversight, considering the genre often relies on such elements to maintain viewer interest. The film teased and hinted at what could have been, but ultimately failed to deliver, leaving viewers feeling unsatisfied and cheated. The lack of any real visual appeal or daring scenes added to the frustration, making the entire experience feel like a waste of time and potential. 

Ahh well, better luck next time, eh? It's always a gamble with these types of films, but the hope is that future endeavors in this genre will learn from the mistakes of this particular disaster. With so many areas needing improvement, there's certainly a lot of room for growth. Hopefully, others will take note and strive to create something that respects the audience's time and expectations.

text: This movie is rich with action and gore. The story line is strong enough to support the action sequences. The English version needs a tad bit of help in the dubbing department but it was still enjoyable. This movie ranks among my personal favorites next to "Hard Boiled" ...
rewritten_review: This movie is incredibly rich with action and gore, providing viewers with an adrenaline-fueled experience from start to finish. The storyline is strong enough to support the intense and thrilling action sequences, ensuring that the film is not just a mindless action flick but one with depth and substance. The English version, however, does need a tad bit of help in the dubbing department. At times, the dubbing could be improved to enhance the overall viewing experience, but despite this minor drawback, it was still incredibly enjoyable to watch. The film captivates with its fast-paced scenes and gripping narrative, making it a standout in its genre. This movie ranks among my personal favorites, sitting proudly next to the classic "Hard Boiled," which is known for its exceptional action and compelling story. The combination of strong storytelling and thrilling action makes it a must-watch for fans of the genre. Overall, while the dubbing in the English version could use some improvement, the film’s engaging plot and exhilarating action sequences firmly cement its place as a personal favorite alongside "Hard Boiled."

text:
Despite an overall pleasing plot and expensive production one wonders how a director can make so many clumsy cultural mistakes. Where were the Japanese wardrobe and cultural consultants? Not on the payroll apparently.

A Japanese friend of mine actually laughed out loud at some of the cultural absurdities she watched unfold before her eyes. In a later conversation she said, "Imagine a Finnish director making a movie in Fnnish about the American Civil War using blond Swedish actors as union Army and Frenchmen as the Confederates. Worse imagine dressing the Scarlet O'Hara female lead in a period hoop skirt missing the hoop and sporting a 1950's hairdo. Maybe some people in Finland might not realize that the hoop skirt was "missing the hoop" or recognize the bizarre Jane Mansfield hair, but in Atlanta they would not believe their eyes or ears....and be laughing in the aisles...excellent story and photography be damned.

So...watching Memoirs of a Geisha was painful for anyone familiar with Japanese cultural nuances, actual geisha or Japanese dress, and that was the topic of the movie! Hollywood is amazing in its myopic view of film making. They frequently get the big money things right while letting the details that really polish a films refinement embarrassingly wrong. I thought "The Last Samurai" was the crowning achievement of how bad an otherwise good film on Japan could be. Memoirs of a Geisha is embarrassingly better and worse at the same time.
rewritten_review: Despite an overall pleasing plot and expensive production, one wonders how a director can make so many clumsy cultural mistakes. Where were the Japanese wardrobe and cultural consultants? Apparently not on the payroll. A Japanese friend of mine actually laughed out loud at some of the cultural absurdities she watched unfold. She later said, "Imagine a Finnish director making a movie in Finnish about the American Civil War using blond Swedish actors as Union Army and Frenchmen as Confederates. Worse, imagine dressing the Scarlett O'Hara female lead in a period hoop skirt missing the hoop and sporting a 1950's hairdo. Maybe some people in Finland might not realize that the hoop skirt was 'missing the hoop' or recognize the bizarre Jane Mansfield hair, but in Atlanta they would not believe their eyes or ears and be laughing in the aisles, excellent story and photography be damned." Watching Memoirs of a Geisha was painful for anyone familiar with Japanese cultural nuances, actual geisha or Japanese dress, and that was the topic of the movie! Hollywood is amazing in its myopic view of filmmaking, getting the big money things right while letting the details that really polish a film's refinement embarrassingly wrong. I thought "The Last Samurai" was the crowning achievement of how bad an otherwise good film on Japan could be. Memoirs of a Geisha is embarrassingly better and worse at the same time.

text:
Having had a great grandfather be captured and sent to Changi during World War two I was hesitant to watch this when it was first screened on TV. My great grandfather kept a diary whilst he was in captivity and when he died over there his mates bought it back and I have been lucky enough to read it and feel I have at least some idea of what Changi was really like, first hand.

This is a fantastic recount of what happened to those poor blokes who were sent to Changi Prison and shows what hardship and cruelty they witnessed in order to protect their country. It is a terrific story of mateship, commitment and Aussie Spirit, that never going to give up attitude. It is worth watching if you like Australian History or anything to do with World War Two.

I enjoyed this mini very much and give it 10 out of 10.
rewritten_review:
Having had a great grandfather be captured and sent to Changi during World War Two, I was hesitant to watch this when it was first screened on TV. My great grandfather kept a diary whilst he was in captivity, and when he died over there, his mates bought it back. I have been lucky enough to read it and feel I have at least some idea of what Changi was really like, first hand. This diary offers a unique and personal glimpse into the past, allowing me to connect with the experiences and emotions that my great grandfather and his fellow soldiers endured during such a challenging time.

This is a fantastic recount of what happened to those poor blokes who were sent to Changi Prison and shows what hardship and cruelty they witnessed in order to protect their country. The portrayal of their struggle and endurance is both moving and enlightening. It is a terrific story of mateship, commitment, and Aussie Spirit, that "never going to give up" attitude. The series does an incredible job of capturing the essence of what it means to stand by your mates even in the direst of situations.

It is worth watching if you like Australian History or anything to do with World War Two. The historical accuracy and depth of storytelling provide viewers with a rich and immersive experience. It serves as a powerful reminder of the sacrifices made by those who came before us, as well as the resilience and strength of the human spirit in the face of adversity. I enjoyed this mini very much and give it 10 out of 10. The impact it left on me is profound, and I highly recommend it to anyone interested in learning more about this significant period in history.

text:
Sometimes, when seeking a movie nothing will do except a good thriller. Dead Line certainly fits the bill.

A little warning however: if you are going to watch this film you are better off not knowing too much specifics about the plot.

The plot thickens as the film goes by. A really remarkably well built tension mounts.

It is deep and horrifying. It goes all the way to the darkest places in human mind.

The plot also has some very surprising shifts.

Just wait till nightfall, turn off the light and watch this film.
rewritten_review:
Sometimes, when seeking a movie, nothing will do except a good thriller. Dead Line certainly fits the bill, offering an experience that is both captivating and chilling. From the moment the film begins, it grips you with its intensity, drawing you into a world of suspense and intrigue. 

A little warning, however: if you are going to watch this film, you are better off not knowing too many specifics about the plot. The filmmakers have crafted a story that thrives on mystery and unexpected turns, and going in with little knowledge enhances the overall experience. The less you know, the more you'll find yourself at the edge of your seat, eagerly anticipating each twist and turn.

As the movie progresses, the plot thickens and draws you deeper into its web. It is a really remarkably well-built tension that mounts scene by scene, leaving you both captivated and anxious about what will happen next. The filmmakers have masterfully woven together a narrative that keeps you guessing, and it's this unpredictability that makes the film so compelling.

It is deep and horrifying, exploring themes that are not only thrilling but also psychologically profound. The film goes all the way to the darkest places in the human mind, challenging viewers to confront fears and emotions that are often left untouched. It's a chilling exploration of the depths of human nature, and it leaves a lasting impression long after the credits roll.

The plot also has some very surprising shifts that catch you off guard and keep you engaged. Just when you think you have it all figured out, the story takes a new direction, keeping you on your toes and invested in the outcome. These shifts are not only surprising but also cleverly executed, adding layers of complexity to the narrative.

For the best experience, just wait till nightfall, turn off the light, and watch this film. The darkness of your surroundings will amplify the suspense, and the film's eerie atmosphere will envelop you completely. It's a movie that demands your full attention and rewards you with a thrilling, unforgettable journey into the unknown.

text: Silverlake Life, The view from here, is an absolutely stunning movie about AIDS as well as about a gay love relationship. Some images are indeed really hard to take, especially when one is gay or fears about AIDS, and probably for any sensitive person watching it. It's not easy to make a movie about such a terrible illness and its consequences about not only one, but two people's lives. This movie teaches how to care for each other in such hard times, but it never gets too morbid, it still shows life at any time, reminding you that outside of the theater or of your room, life goes on, whatever the destiny of some people may be. The characters are incredibly endearing, while we watch their intimacy in shots that never go beyond a very strict limit, never unveiling anything too private or offensive. Children should certainly not watch this movie, but grown-ups whether they have to deal with such situations or not, should do it, and will not regret the tears they shed.
rewritten_review: Silverlake Life, The View from Here, is an absolutely stunning film about AIDS and a gay love relationship. Some images are really hard to take, especially for those who are gay or fear AIDS, and probably for any sensitive viewer. It's not easy to depict such a terrible illness and its impact on two people's lives. This movie teaches how to care for each other in hard times, but it never becomes too morbid. It shows life at any time, reminding you that outside the theater or your room, life goes on, whatever some people's destinies may be. The characters are incredibly endearing, as we watch their intimacy in shots that never go beyond a strict limit, never unveiling anything too private or offensive. Children should not watch this movie, but grown-ups, whether they deal with such situations or not, should see it and will not regret the tears they shed.

text:
I hardly know where to begin.

Huge continuity issues, bad acting, etc. For example, Sam is supposed to be far from any people yet you can see the ski slopes cut into the mountain next to his head.

But the most fundamental problem is that the essence of the book, Sam's adventurousness paving the way to improve the lot of his entire family, is not even touched upon. Instead, in the movie, he gets ticked off at his family and leaves his wealthy parents to be by himself and, when he gets tired of it, he goes home. Where is his development? Where is the arc?

If you have never read the book and can get through the hokey 60isms (double/triple/quadruple visions of the falcon) and terrible production quality (crackling, ahem, fire, winter winds stopping their howling for the dialog and then restarting, etc.) I guess it *might* be OK for an 8 year old.

But compared to the sophistication of the book it is a terrible disappointment.

Read the book instead.
rewritten_review: I hardly know where to begin. Huge continuity issues, bad acting, etc. For example, Sam is supposed to be far from people yet you can see ski slopes cut into the mountain next to his head. The most fundamental problem is that the essence of the book, Sam's adventurousness improving his family's lot, is not even touched upon. Instead, in the movie, he leaves his wealthy parents to be by himself and, when he gets tired of it, he goes home. Where is his development? Where is the arc? If you have never read the book and can get through the hokey 60isms (double/triple/quadruple visions of the falcon) and terrible production quality (crackling fire, winter winds stopping for dialog then restarting, etc.) I guess it *might* be OK for an 8 year old. But compared to the sophistication of the book, it is a terrible disappointment. Read the book instead.

text:
This documentary begins with an interesting premise -- it makes an intriguing and convincing argument that the history of Jesus as is commonly believed is probably a myth. Sadly, though, after priming us with this, the movie completely shifts gears and becomes little more than a non-stop attack on Christianity, and pretty much focusing on the easy targets.

The writer/director clearly has some issues with the Church (he is a former evangelical Christian and has some legit anger) and this film seems to be his form of release. It'd be interesting to see the first 20 minutes expanded, but as a whole, the movie is disappointing.
rewritten_review:
This documentary begins with an interesting premise -- it makes an intriguing and convincing argument that the history of Jesus as is commonly believed is probably a myth. The introduction sets the stage with fascinating theories and evidence that challenge the traditional narratives surrounding Jesus. Sadly, though, after priming us with this, the movie completely shifts gears and becomes little more than a non-stop attack on Christianity, and pretty much focusing on the easy targets. The transition feels abrupt, leaving the viewer longing for more exploration of the initial premise rather than a barrage of criticism aimed at religious institutions.

The writer/director clearly has some issues with the Church (he is a former evangelical Christian and has some legit anger) and this film seems to be his form of release. His personal experiences and frustrations with the Church are palpable, and they permeate much of the documentary's content. However, this shift in focus from the intriguing exploration of historical myths to a critique of Christianity's flaws significantly detracts from the film's potential impact. It'd be interesting to see the first 20 minutes expanded, delving deeper into the historical evidence and scholarly debates surrounding the existence of Jesus. Such an expansion could provide a more balanced and informative perspective. But as a whole, the movie is disappointing. The initial promise of an insightful exploration into the mythologizing of Jesus is overshadowed by the director's personal grievances, leaving viewers feeling as though they have only scratched the surface of a much larger and more complex conversation.

text:
Honestly, I don't really understand why there has been so much controversy about this show. It embraces the elements of the original, while expanding on them. The storytelling has been updated and, while some of the episodes seem to be a bit "Fast", that is a good thing.

Christopher Eccleston is perfect in the role. Easily as good as Tom Baker.

Rose is one of the best companions, on par with Sarah Jane Smith or Leela.

I like the concept that the timelords have been destroyed - No more politicking with the Doctor acting as president emeritus. And it adds something to the character to be the only one left.

The SFX are outstanding - especially in comparison to the original.

Take it from me (And I was a huge Dr Who geek - I actually took notes while watching the show all the way from Dr Number 1 to Dr Number 8. I tossed the horrible movie out of cannon, personally) this is the best sci fi show on TV right now, possibly ever. Watch it and buy the DVD.
rewritten_review: I don't get the controversy about this show. It embraces the original elements while expanding on them. The storytelling is updated, and a few "fast" episodes are a good thing. Christopher Eccleston is perfect in the role, easily as good as Tom Baker. Rose ranks as one of the best companions, on par with Sarah Jane Smith or Leela. The concept of the Timelords being destroyed is intriguing—no more politicking and it adds depth with the Doctor as the last one. The SFX are outstanding, especially compared to the original. As a huge Dr Who geek (I took notes from Dr Number 1 to Dr Number 8 and tossed the horrible movie out of canon), this is the best sci-fi show on TV right now, possibly ever. Watch it and buy the DVD.

text:
The wonderful "Z" Channel in Los Angeles showed this Pia Zadora film about six months or so after "Butterfly". I had such high hopes for the actress, and then she goes from bad to obviously WORSE in this film.

Again, it was the 80's and I gotta tell you Harold Robbin's work had been eclipsed by smarter writers. Jacqueline Susann ripped into him (she hated his way of writing women), Irwin Shaw's work caught on with many women, and of course Sidney Sheldon had his kingdom in the late 70's early 80's and then came Jackie Collins who made women stronger and as equal to men in every way in her books, even more so. Which is why this work smelt. Harold Robbin's work in the 80's just didn't catch on with audiences. Pia Zadora acting in one of Robbin's work was like throwing kerosine on a fire. The supporting cast was not a help either.

Oooooh... this was awful to look at then and even 20 more years later, it looks even worse. I had a hope for Pia as an actress and it all got shot to heck when this was done. It would be tough for Pia to redeem herself as an actress (although John Waters casting her in "Hairspray" was a spark) although she has a nice singing voice.

Hey, Pia, wherever you are...Hairspray may go on tour! Join the show. You may be the biggest comeback story yet.

I just hope they burn this film for ya if you do.
rewritten_review:
The "Z" Channel in Los Angeles aired this Pia Zadora film about six months after "Butterfly". I had high hopes for her, but she went from bad to worse in this film. It was the 80's, and Harold Robbins' work had been eclipsed by smarter writers. Jacqueline Susann criticized his portrayal of women, Irwin Shaw gained popularity, Sidney Sheldon reigned in the late 70's and early 80's, and Jackie Collins empowered women in her books. Robbins' work didn't resonate with 80's audiences, and Pia Zadora in his film was like adding fuel to the fire. The supporting cast didn't help either.

This film was awful then and looks even worse 20 years later. I hoped for Pia as an actress, but this film ruined it. Though John Waters' casting her in "Hairspray" was promising, and she has a nice singing voice.

Hey, Pia, wherever you are...Hairspray might go on tour! Join the show. You could be the biggest comeback story yet. I just hope they burn this film for you if you do.

text: If the redundancy of getting off the boat, on the boat, off the bus, on the bus.. is a way to waste time then you should go back to the Hollywood films that wrap this part up in one montage in order to get to the money shots. and in doing so leave you unconnected and in the cinematic limbo that results from not really showing the realities of life. The long drawn out travel sequences actually allow the viewer the same frustration and 'wait- in-line' feeling the characters must endure. Frustrating? yes. Vital? Indeed. the limbo of that travel is the key to the 'rootlessness' of this Turkish family. Beautiful film with great acting. Sad, but worth it.
rewritten_review: If the redundancy of getting off the boat, on the boat, off the bus, on the bus, and so on, is a way to waste time, then you should go back to the Hollywood films that wrap this part up in one convenient montage in order to get to the money shots. This approach can often leave you feeling unconnected and in the cinematic limbo that results from not really showing the realities of life. The long, drawn-out travel sequences actually allow the viewer to experience the same frustration and 'wait-in-line' feeling that the characters must endure. Is it frustrating? Yes. Is it vital? Indeed. The limbo of that travel is absolutely the key to understanding the 'rootlessness' of this Turkish family. This is a beautiful film with great acting. It's sad, but it's worth it. The way the film captures the essence of these moments, the in-between spaces, is essential to the storytelling. It immerses the audience in the characters' journey, making you feel every tedious step, every moment of uncertainty. This sense of limbo is not just a narrative choice but a thematic one, reflecting the underlying feeling of displacement and uncertainty experienced by the family. The film's ability to evoke such emotions through these sequences is a testament to its craftsmanship. While it may test your patience, it ultimately enriches your understanding of the characters' experiences. The beauty of this film lies not just in its visual or dramatic moments but in its commitment to portraying the unvarnished truth of its characters' lives. It is a poignant reminder that sometimes the journey itself, with all its frustrations and delays, is as significant as the destination.

text:
My interpretation is that the term 'distant' is used in the sense of the opposite of 'warm'; people who are not warm toward others. The film reminds me of the teachings of the Dalai Lama in 'The Art of Happiness' where his main point is that the key to happiness is connecting with others. Not only are the characters in the film insular, but they are also humorless, charmless, shy, quiet and unfriendly. These characteristics appear to prevent them, amongst other things, from forming and enjoying relationships and being able to talk about and deal with their problems. And as a result they are terribly unhappy. I see it as a strong vindication of the Dalai Lama's teaching (I'm not a Buddist by the way). If you are one of the people who thinks that their behavior is a natural response to living in a large city then I think you may be right but I recommend the Dalai Lama's book. City life need not be like this.

I can see why some people found it boring - it does drag a bit in places and the characters are not particularly likable. And it does contrast to Lost In Translation where the insular characters are much more likable and do connect with one another even though they don't connect with people generally.
rewritten_review:
The term 'distant' in the film refers to people who are not warm toward others. This reminds me of the Dalai Lama's teachings in 'The Art of Happiness,' where he emphasizes that connecting with others is key to happiness. The characters in the film are insular, humorless, charmless, shy, quiet, and unfriendly, preventing them from forming relationships and dealing with their problems, leading to unhappiness. This supports the Dalai Lama's teachings (I'm not a Buddhist). If you think their behavior is a response to city life, you might be right, but I recommend the Dalai Lama's book. City life need not be like this.

I understand why some find it boring—it drags in places, and the characters aren't likable. It contrasts with 'Lost In Translation,' where insular characters are more likable and connect with each other, even if not generally.

text: This show is so full of action, and everything needed to make an awsome show.. but best of all... it actually has a plot (unlike some of those new reality shows...). It is about a transgenic girl who escapes from her military holding base.. I totally suggest bying the DVDs, i've already preordered them... i suggest you do to...
rewritten_review: This show is absolutely packed with action, and it has everything needed to create an awesome viewing experience. The best part of all is that it actually has a compelling plot, unlike some of those new reality shows that seem to lack any real substance. The story revolves around a transgenic girl who manages to escape from her military holding base, setting the stage for an intriguing and thrilling narrative. I totally suggest buying the DVDs, as they promise to deliver an exceptional viewing experience. I've already preordered them myself, and I highly recommend you do the same. Trust me, this show is worth every moment and every penny. It's a must-have for anyone who appreciates a well-crafted story with plenty of action and excitement.

text:
Disney, the film name that once stood for all things innocent and suitable for all ages, has finally started to realise that to survive it needs to become more diverse. Such diversity has been very apparent in the last couple of years. Films like "Tarzan" and "The Emperor's New Groove" have made an attempt to move away from the traditional song-driven routine of Disney's past and into new, uncharted territory. "Atlantis" is the boldest step yet, but we have to remember: This is STILL Disney. The first ever serious film to come out of Disney's animation studio is a major achievement for them - in fact it's so serious it makes it into PG territory. Perhaps why a lot of families were scared off from seeing it this past summer.

But despite the more mature subject matter, this is still a film that Disney wanted to draw in the families with, not just mature audiences, so the plot had to be kept simple enough for children to understand, but interesting enough to take it away from the realms of "The Little Mermaid" et al.

So what we get is actually a potentially detailed plot, unfortunately suffering the blow of being condensed into a 96-minute movie. Ultimately, this is an action film about Atlantis, not about the exposition preceding it, so we are whisked through the first half hour with as many sequences bombarding the screen as is possible without losing coherency. Suspend your disbelief of how the characters get from point A to point B so quickly, you're unlikely to find an animated film that detailed coming out of Hollywood! If you want epic levels of detail in the plot, turn to James Cameron's "Titanic". Both films feature a boat in some manner.

And let's talk about love, shall we? Yes, as with a lot of films, the lead male (one Milo Thatch, a bumbling archaeologist) and lead female (Kida, the clichéd Atlantian princess) are set to fall in love with each other. But what I found was not as clichéd as I was expecting. By film's end, for once, the characters touching/feeling/kissing sequence was far more subdued. There's various points in the film where the attraction grows, but it's just not in the ballpark of, say, "The Little Mermaid" (A good thing).

You may have grasped that this is a rather clichéd film. Correct. You have your leading hero and heroine, backed up by more than half a dozen crew members who go on the expedition, all being given their moments during the film. Numerous other characters appear, take up the few minutes of screentime, then disappear. It doesn't take a genius to do the maths  a 96-minute film with a focus on action and visuals, and with a considerable cast, has very little time to expand the characters to any major extent. So what does it rely on? Clichés, and lots of them. Every character emulates something that has been done a thousand times before. You have the bumbling scientist, the attractive princess, the square-jawed colonel, the rich eccentric, the maniacal sleazebag, the Russian femme fatale  need I go on?

I don't know why this got to anyone  I found the tongue-in-cheek nature of this film quite amusing. Alright, this is meant to be a serious flick, but do you really expect Disney to give up every single trait of their history? At least the writers have tried to come up with consistently witty dialogue, and sometimes it even is a little inspired.

But in the end it's those big stunning visuals that put the icing on this cake. The CGI animation is truly amazing in places, and doesn't dwarf the characters, which was a flaw that let the recent "Titan A.E." down. Speaking of characters, Disney hired an outside comics industry artist to create the designs, bringing an anime style to the film. Infact the visual presentation of the film as a whole owes a lot to anime, much more so than any previous Disney outing. This resulted in a conflict with fans of the Japanese anime, "Nadia", for the film's overall similarities with said cartoon series. Having not seen this anime, I can't comment.

With picture, there is sound. Gary Rydstrom heads up the sound team, and what a soundtrack! From the opening shot the sound stage is alive and is a treat. James Newton Howard treats us to a dynamic musical score, which compliments the film in every way, never sounding out of place and always helping to build the tension or subdue it.

Perhaps I missed the point of what the creators intended. To me, the film conveys that it's an adventure thrill ride, albeit with a more serious tone than any Disney film before it. If you don't like the clichéd tongue-in-cheek attitude, then perhaps the effort that has been poured into the visuals will delight. Heck, at least the mythology is far more correct than can be said about other Disney efforts (*cough*Hercules*cough*).

This is a positive, 10 out of 10 review, from someone who was blown away by this film. I always suspend my disbelief with any animated film  after all, the laws of the real world are more than frequently broken in the cartoon medium. So sit back, enjoy the ride, and perhaps everyone can find something to enjoy about this film.
rewritten_review:
Disney, once synonymous with innocence and all-ages content, is evolving to embrace diversity. Recent films like "Tarzan" and "The Emperor's New Groove" have shifted away from Disney's traditional song-driven formula. "Atlantis" marks their boldest step yet, venturing into PG territory with more mature themes, which may have deterred some families this past summer.

Despite its mature content, "Atlantis" still aims to attract families. The plot is kept simple enough for children yet engaging for older audiences, compressed into a 96-minute action film. It's less about exposition and more about the adventure, reminiscent of James Cameron's "Titanic" in its ambition, though both feature a boat.

The film includes a romance between Milo Thatch, a bumbling archaeologist, and Kida, the Atlantian princess, but it's more subdued than expected, unlike "The Little Mermaid." The film is clichéd, with archetypal characters like the bumbling scientist and the attractive princess, but it's amusingly tongue-in-cheek. Disney hasn't abandoned its history entirely, and the witty dialogue occasionally shines.

The visuals are the film's standout feature, with impressive CGI animation and character designs by an outside comic artist, lending an anime style. This sparked conflict with fans of the anime "Nadia" due to similarities. The sound, led by Gary Rydstrom, is exceptional, and James Newton Howard's score enhances the film's tension and mood.

"Atlantis" is an adventure thrill ride with a serious tone, unlike any previous Disney film. If clichés don't appeal to you, the visuals might. The mythology is more accurate than in other Disney films (*cough*Hercules*cough*). This review is a positive 10 out of 10 from someone captivated by the film. Animated films often defy real-world laws, so sit back, enjoy, and find something to appreciate in "Atlantis."

text: One of the funniest films I ever saw in the theater back in the early '70s, and sadly, it's only been on TV a few times since. This movie should be released on video. It's Sellers at his sleaziest, slimiest best as a crooked hospital administrator. Great cast, great movie. If anyone has a good VHS copy, I'd love to buy it.
rewritten_review: One of the funniest films I ever saw in the theater back in the early '70s was an absolute gem, and sadly, it's only been on TV a few times since. This movie should undoubtedly be released on video for everyone to enjoy. It's Sellers at his sleaziest, slimiest best as a crooked hospital administrator, and his performance is truly unforgettable. The way he brings the character to life is both hilarious and captivating. The film boasts a great cast that complements Sellers perfectly, adding layers of humor and intrigue to the story. The dynamic between the characters is something that makes the movie even more enjoyable and memorable. The entire production is just a great movie that deserves more recognition and accessibility for audiences today. If anyone happens to have a good VHS copy, I'd love to buy it and relive those hilarious moments. This film is a classic that should not be forgotten, and more people should have the chance to experience its comedic brilliance.

text: I remember seeing this movie a long time ago, back then even though it didn't have any special effects, the acting was really good. And it still has the same message for today, even though the technology has changed, maybe they should make a remake of this movie, it would be interesting to see a remake. I also enjoyed the music from the movie as well, Larry Norman was a really good songwriter during that time period, although now most Christian music is now worship and praise music. I was always curious to know what ever happened to Patty after the series ended? Did she go on to make more movies, did she get eventually get married and raise a family? I would like to have an update.
rewritten_review: I remember seeing this movie a long time ago, back then even though it didn't have any special effects, the acting was really good. The performances of the actors truly stood out and brought the story to life in a way that was both compelling and memorable. It still has the same message for today, even though the technology has changed, and I think it resonates just as strongly with audiences now as it did back then. The themes and messages conveyed in the film are timeless and continue to be relevant in today's world. Maybe they should make a remake of this movie, as it would be interesting to see a remake with modern technology and special effects. A fresh take on the story might introduce it to a new generation of viewers who could appreciate its core message. I also enjoyed the music from the movie as well, which added a significant layer of emotion and depth to the film. Larry Norman was a really good songwriter during that time period, and his music contributed greatly to the overall atmosphere and impact of the movie. Although now most Christian music is now worship and praise music, back then, his work stood out as innovative and inspiring. I was always curious to know what ever happened to Patty after the series ended. Her character was so intriguing and relatable, and I often wondered if she went on to make more movies or if she eventually got married and raised a family. It would be fascinating to have an update on her life and career, as she left a lasting impression on viewers.

text:
I saw this movie with a friend who ran a marathon with me, and we both had the same feeling about it: it wasn't terribly motivating, and didn't even broach the idea of what a training schedule would look like, so that non-marathoners could have an idea of what it would take for them to train and run one. In fact there was almost zero technical information at all. I didn't expect this to be a tech-heavy instructional video, but when that info was near zero then the film just wasn't balanced, and wasn't particularly useful to non-marathoners contemplating their first run.

There were other problems. Some of the very first images were people collapsing near death while trying to run a race. Yeah, real inspiring. The timing was also hard to follow, because it was semi chronological, but the filmmakers rarely gave you any good clues as to what point in time you were looking at. And they withheld information. You see that Kantor has an injury, and you just assume it's from all her training, but then several scenes later they finally clue you in that it's because she tripped over a pine cone in her yard.

Some parts were very good, though, like the bit about a woman defying race officials who wanted the run to be men-only, and the coverage of a Chicago race where two of the runners portrayed earlier were vying for first place.

Off the top of my head, I'm thinking of other chronological documentaries, like Supersize Me, and Grass, where you always know where you are, and you feel like they told you everything you wanted to know.

In short, it wouldn't have been hard to make a better marathon film, and as it stands I can't recommend this to non-marathoners to educate and motivate them to try one, because I don't think it will have that effect.
